taxonomicNotes: Puffers of the genus Lagocephalus are globally distributed in warm shallow waters, however classification at the species level in Lagocephalus has not yet been studied in depth, causing confusion in the status of several species including L. cheesemanii, L. gloveri, L. spadiceus, and L. wheeleri (Matsuura et al. 2011).

Seven subspecies are generally accepted (TTWG 2017):

Malaclemys terrapin terrapin (Schoepff, 1793) - Northern Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin centrata (Latreille in Sonnini and Latreille, 1801) - Carolina Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin littoralis Hay, 1905 - Texas Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin macrospilota Hay, 1905 - Ornate Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin pileata (Wied, 1865) - Mississippi Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin rhizophorarum Fowler, 1906 - Mangrove Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin tequesta Schwartz, 1955 - Eastern Florida Diamondback Terrapin

These subspecific designations of terrapins were based on morphological characteristics (Carr 1952). However, molecular studies indicate that the morphological subspecific designations do not match well with the range-wide genetic differentiation, suggesting fewer independent lineages. Lamb and Avise (1992) first suggested two subpopulations that diverged near Jacksonville, Florida. More recent work using microsatellites suggested that five genetically distinct terrapin management units exist throughout the range (Hart et al. 2014). One unfortunate consequence of the previous heavy trade and farming of terrapins was the transport of individuals among populations, and the genetic signature of those translocations can still be detected today (Hauswaldt and Glen 2005; Converse et al. 2017; Converse and Kuchta 2018). A more thorough range-wide molecular study using more populations and loci is sorely needed to resolve the phylogenetic relationships and update the taxonomy of Malaclemys.
There is currently a publication in review on the species delineation of Menidia conchorum and Menidia peninsulae (S. O'Leary pers. comm. 2013).

It is unclear whether this species should in fact be placed in the Microdesmidae as subfamily Ptereleotrinae (W. Eschmeyer pers. comm. 2009).

This species may be Parioglossus marginalis (D. Hoese pers.comm. 2011).

Diplodus cervinus was previously recognized as comprising three subspecies: Diplodus cervinus cervinus (NE Atlantic and Mediterranean), D. c. hottentotus (SE Atlantic: Angola, South Africa), and D. c. omanensis (Indian Ocean: Oman). Currently, three species are recognized: D. cervinus, D. hottentotus (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004) and D. omanensis (Bauchot and Bianchi 1984, Amir et al. 2013). However, the Diplodus cervinus complex is in need of taxonomic review (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2014).
In Australia, this species is easily confused with Drombus triangularis, with which it is sympatric across the north. The species may also be a synonym of Drombus palackyi described from Samoa.

Marceniuk (2005) placed this species in Aspistor, but it is now generally agreed that the appropriate name is Sciades parkeri. A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Published data: This species has two subspecies:  Hyporhamphus roberti hildebrandi and Hyporhamphus roberti roberti.
Jamaica Caribbean Workshop:Early records of Hyporhamphus roberti from continental United States refer to either H. meeki or H. unifasciatus.

Two other common and very similar species of western Atlantic Strongylura occur alongside Strongylura marina in the Western Central Atlantic: Strongylura notata and Strongylura timucu. Until the late 1960s, S. timucu was largely considered to be synonymous with S. marina (Berry and Rivas 1962). Collette (1968) notes that S. notata differs from S. marina and S. timucu in having fewer anal rays and fewer predorsal scales, and internal examination also reveals fewer vertebrae and other distinguishing skeletal features. Internal examination also reveals that both gonads are developed in S. tumucu while only the right gonad is developed in S. marina. Typically, S. timucu is also somewhat darker in coloration than S. marina (Hoese and Moore 1977). Strongylura notata differs externally from S. marina, possessing 13-15 dorsal rays and 13-16 anal rays (Hoese and Moore 1977).

This species has recently been placed in the genus Ostorhinchus by Randall (2005) based on L.M.R. Bergman's unpublished PhD thesis (in which Ostorhinchus was shown to be polyphyletic). The generic placement of this species may change.

Genetic studies of Pagrus pagrus have shown Western Atlantic samples to be more closely related to each other than to samples from the Eastern North Atlantic. Within the Western North Atlantic, no significant population differentiation was observed, and within the eastern North Atlantic, only the Azores sample showed detectable differences from those from Crete and Madeira. These data indicate general homogeneity within large areas, and deep divisions between these areas (Ball et al. 2007).
This species appeared in the IUCN Red List prior to 2008 under the generic name Papillogobius.
Has previously been confused with Leucoraja garmani (McEachran and Carvalho 2002).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

Interspecific hybridization of the Pacific Sleeper Shark (S. pacificus) with the Greenland Shark (S. microcephalus) has likely been ongoing at the edges of their distributions since initial divergence (Walter et al. 2017).

Records of eastern Atlantic Myliobatis aquila from southern Brazil probably refer to this species, if both species are indeed distinct (if not, the name M. aquila has priority). There are two sister species in the southern part of its range under the present name M. goodei, with a description of the second species pending (Ruocco et al. 2012).
The similar, but larger, Etmopterus bigelowi was previously confused with this species until described as a distinct species by Shirai and Tachikawa (1993).

Taxonomy remains unresolved for this species, with nominal records from various locations likely to represent other species (Ebert et al. 2013). This species is frequently misidentified with other regional etmopterids, e.g., Etmopterus burgessi (Schaaf-DaSilva and Ebert 2006). Therefore, care should be taken when identifying similar looking lucifer-group lanternsharks.

This species can be visually distinguished from two morphologically similar regional congeners, the Dusky Smoothhound (Mustelus canis) and the Gulf of Mexico Smoothhound (M. sinusmexicanus) by several characters including fin shape and ampullary pore patterns (Giresi et al. 2013).
The Bignose Shark is morphologically distinct but genetically similar to the Sandbar Shark (Carcharhinus plumbeus) (Naylor et al. 2012, Duffy and Struthers 2017).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
Morphological and allozyme analysis have shown that Sepia hierredda is a separate species to Sepia officinalis (Reid et al. 2005).
Sepiella inermis may consist of a species complex (Reid et al. 2005).
Given its wide geographic distribution, this species may represent a species complex   (Reid and Jereb 2005).

This species may consist of a species complex (e.g. the hectocotylus differs in male specimens collected from Australia and Japan) (Reid et al. 2005). Norman (2003) identifies three pharaonis species: Sepia pharaonis I, in the western  Indian Ocean (Red Sea and Arabian Gulf); S. pharaonis II, Japan to the Gulf of Thailand and and northern Australia; and S. pharaonis III, in the Indian Ocean to Andaman Sea.
Sepia latimanus is likely to consist of a species complex (Reid et al. 2005).
For rationale of synonymy see Allcock et al. (2003). Megaleledone setebos is a monotypic genus.

This species is insufficiently described (Khromov et al. 1998). It is one of five species in the Hemisepius species complex, the others being S. dubia, S. pulchra, S. faurei and S. typica. All five species are small (about 2 cm mantle length) and are found off South Africa.
Misidentifications with Sepia acuminata Smith, 1916 and Sepia hedleyi Berry, 1918 (Reid et al. 2005).
This species is known only from the type cuttlebone (Reid et al. 2005).   It is a possible junior synonym of Sepia bandensis Adam, 1939.
The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved   (Reid and Jereb 2005).
This species has a disjunct population distribution and may consist of more than one species   (Reid and Jereb 2005).
This species was originally described from the cuttlebone but was subsequently redescribed from the whole animal (Adam 1955, Adam & Rees 1966).

Nabhitabhata and Suwanamala (2008) doubted the validity of Idiosepius thailandicus because of its ability to cross-breed with I. biserialis from Thailand.  However, Reid (2005) previously disputed that I. biserialis from Thailand actually referred to this species, suggesting that these specimens actually refer to I. thailandicus. Therefore we treat specimens from the IndoWest Pacific region with two rows of suckers on the tentacular clubs as I. thailandicus and treat this as a valid distinct species from I. minimus which we believe to be the senior synonym of I. biserialis and which we believe is restricted in its distribution to the east coast of Africa.

This species is insufficiently described (Khromov et al. 1998).  It is one of five species in the Hemisepius species complex, the others being S. robsoni, S. pulchra, S. faurei and S. typica.    All five species are small (about 2 cm mantle length) and are found off South Africa.
Misidentifications with Sepia vossi Khromov, 1996 (Reid et al. 2005).
There are considerable taxonomic problems within the Heteroteuthinae. Vecchione et al. (2007) treat H. serventyi as a junior synonym of this species. We follow this herein.
The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved   (Reid and Jereb 2005).

This species is only known from the cuttlebones of seven specimens including the type (Reid et al. 2005). Its taxonomic status is uncertain.  It is a possible junior synonym of Sepia bandensis Adam, 1939.
This species was only known from sepions until a full description was provided by Reid (1998).

Records of this species from Viet Nam are likely to be misidentified specimens of Sepiella inermis (Reid et al. 2005). In China this species is treated under the name Sepiella maindroni. Sepiella maindroni Rochebrune 1884 was described from Pondicherry, India (a region that encompasses coasts on both the Arabian Sea and the Bay of Bengal) and has previously been treated as a junior synonym of Sepiella inermis (Van Hasselt, 1835 in Férussac and D'Orbigny, 1834-1848), the type locality of which is also Pondicherry. The latin name Sepiella maindroni Rochebrune 1884 is used in China, and Sepiella japonica is considered its synonym (Dong, 1988). Sasaki (1929) when establishing Sepiella japonica clearly separated it from Sepiella maindroni Rochebrune, 1884. Adam and Rees (1962)  pointed out the problem of using Sepiella maindroni for specimens from Japan and East China Sea and placed S. maindroni Rochebrune, 1884 as a junior synonym of Sepiella inermis, and put Sepiella maindroni of Hoyle (1886) in the synonymy of S. japonica. The correctness of this is reaffirmed by Lu et al. (2011).

This species is insufficiently described (Khromov et al. 1998). It is one of five species in the Hemisepius species complex, the others being S. robsoni, S. pulchra, S. dubia and S. typica. All five species are small (about 2 cm mantle length) and are found off South Africa. Sepia faurei is known from only five specimens.

This species is insufficiently described (Khromov et al. 1998). It is one of five species in the Hemisepius species complex, the others being S. robsoni, S. pulchra, S. faurei and S. typica. All five species are small (about 2 cm mantle length) and are found off South Africa.
The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved   (Reid and Jereb 2005).
Vecchione and Young (2007) believe this species may be synonymous with H. dispar.
This species has been shown to be genetically distinct to both Sepia officinalis and Sepia heirredda.
Often mis-spelled as forbesi. The type locality is in the Atlantic Ocean (Sweeney 2012).
The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved   (Reid and Jereb 2005).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.

The taxonomic status of this species is not clear. Roper and Sweeney (1998) do not include it in their list of valid species, yet it is included in the Integrated Taxonomic Information System (www.itis.gov). Nesis (1987) implies that this species may be a junior synonym of Sepia kobiensis Hoyle, 1885.
Known only from cuttle bones until the redescription by Reid (2000).
Misidentifications with Sepia bertheloti d'Orbigny, 1835 (Reid et al. 2005).

This is given by Reid, Jereb and Roper (2005) as Sepia pardex Sasaki, 1913. Sasaki first described this species as S. pardex in Japanese in an obscure publication (published in 1913), and republished it a year later in English with a slightly different name (as S. pardalis). The Japanese manuscript was discovered a few years ago hence the species epithet pardalis was changed back to the original pardex. They are the same entity, with the same type specimen.
Misidentifications with Sepia brevimana Steenstrup, 1875 (Reid et al. 2005).

The type specimen is lost from the MNHN and type locality is given as 'coast of Africa' (Reid 2005). D'Orbigny described this as "Bras tentaculaires long, cylindriques, sans elargissement a leur extremite; cette partie pourvue de deux rangees de petites cupules alternes pedonculees" which translates approximately to 'tentacular arms long, cylindrical without enlargement at their end; this part with two rows of alternative stalked cups' - in other words, the exact features of Idiosepius biserialis. Given that the holotype (which is no longer extant) of I. minimus was collected from "les cotes d'Afrique" and I. biserialis was described from Mozambique, it is highly likely that I. minimus is the senior synonym. Also, von Byern and Klepal (2010) report on further collecting in this area yielding only a single species. We also treat I. macrocheir Voss, 1962, the holotype of which was also collected in Morrumbene, Mozambique, as a junior synonym. Von Byern and Klepal (2010) suggested that I. macrocheir is in fact synonymous with I. biserialis differing only through preservation distortion.
We follow Nesis (1987) in treating this species as a senior synonym of Sepietta obscura Naef, 1916.

Spirula's discontinuous distribution in the northern and southern hemisphere has led to suggestions that more than one species exists (e.g., Warnke 2007). Currently, this is the only species in the family Spirulidae.
Misidentifications with Sepia esculenta Hoyle, 1885 and Sepia stellifera Homenko and Khromov, 1984 (Reid et al. 2005).
The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved   (Reid and Jereb 2005).
This species is very similar to Euprymna morsei (Reid and Jereb 2005). The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved (Reid and Jereb 2005).
This species is probably a species complex (Reid et al. 2005).
The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved   (Reid and Jereb 2005).
Following Nesis (1987) we treat Idiosepius pygmaeus herbereri as a synonym of I. pygmaeus.
Voss (1962) suggests that this might be synonymous with Austrorossia mastigophora.
Only known from the type locality (Reid et al. 2005).

This species was known until recently from the single type cuttlebone (45 mm long). Recently A. Reid found a complete immature female specimen among the Western Australian Museum collections, confirming its status as valid (A. Reid pers. comm. 2010).

Regional differences between male colour patterns suggest there may be distinct populations or subspecies (Norman 2003). Individuals from the east and southern coast show both genetic and morphological differences that suggest previous isolation and subsequent secondary contact to form a continuous distribution (Reid et al. 2005).  It has been suggested that the Spencer Gulf population may represent a separate species (Bronwyn Gillanders pers. comm. 2010).
Misidentifications include: Sepia bidhaia Reid, 2000; Sepia cottoni Adam, 1979; Sepia limata (Iredale, 1926); Sepia rhoda (Iredale, 1954); and Sepia vercoi Adam, 1979 (Reid et al. 2005).
This species is very similar to Euprymna berryi (Reid and Jereb 2005). The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved (Reid and Jereb 2005).
Pareledone charcoti is the type of the genus Pareledone.
Misidentifications with Sepia vossi Khromov, 1996 (as Sepia rex) (Reid et al. 2005).
Misidentifications include: Sepia esculenta Hoyle, 1885; Sepia madokai Adam, 1939a; Sepia stellifera Homenko and Khromov, 1984.

Reid and Jereb (2005) believe that subpopulations in the eastern and western Atlantic are probably isolated. In contrast, Vecchione and Young (2007) believe that this species may be synonymous with Heteroteuthis hawaiiensis (treated separately herein). Genetic data are required to solve these taxonomic issues.
Is often misidentified with Sepia plathyconchalis Filippova & Khromov, 1991 (Reid et al. 2005).
The validity of this species has been questioned.

This species is insufficiently described (Khromov et al. 1998). It is one of five species in the Hemisepius species complex, the others being S. robsoni, S. pulchra, S. faurei and S. dubia. All five species are small (about 2cm mantle length) and are found off South Africa.
Misidentifications with Sepia kobiensis Hoyle, 1885. Sepia andreana was misidentified possibly as S. kobiensis in Voss (1963) and the 1984 FAO cephalopod guide by Roper et al. (1984).
This species may consist of two subspecies Neorossia caroli jeannae (southwest Atlantic) and Neorossia caroli caroli (northeast, east and southeast Atlantic) (Reid and Jereb 2005).
Misidentifications with Sepia elliptica Hoyle, 1885 and Sepia hoylei Ortmann, 1888 (Reid et al. 2005).
The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved   (Reid and Jereb 2005).
The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved   (Reid and Jereb 2005).
Misidentifications with Sepia smithi Hoyle, 1885 (Reid et al. 2005).
This species is known only from cuttlebones (Reid et al. 2005).
The taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain (Reid et al. 2005). Further collections are required from the type locality.
The type locality is Ambon, Molucca Islands, Indonesia.

Lu and Stranks (1994) synonymised P. aurorae with P. charcoti but given the apparent limited range of P. charcoti it is likely that the species redescribed by Lu and Stranks (1994) as P. charcoti corresponds to P. aurorae.
This species is the type of Bentheledone.
Single deep water species. The relationship between this genus and the poorly diagnosed genus Bentheledone requires revision.
Tetracheledone spinicirrus is the type species of the genus Tetracheledone by monotypy.
This species is the type species of the genus Thaumeledone, original designation by Robson (1930).
Known only from the type specimen, Bathypurpurata profunda is the type of this monotypic genus.
Velodona togata is the type species of the genus Velodona by monotypy.
Vosseledone charrua is the type species of the genus Vosseledone by monotypy.

There are distinct morphological and genetic differences between the smooth-skinned Pareledone and the papillated (sensu Allcock 2005) Pareledone (Allcock, Strugnell and Johnson 2008). However, there is solid molecular evidence that the genus is monophyletic (Strugnell et al. 2008). P. turqueti and P. harrissoni (Berry 1917) and Moschites antarcticus (Thiele 1920) are the only described smooth-skinned species of Pareledone. We treat P. turqueti as the senior synonym of the other named smooth-skinned species.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

Idioctopus gracilipes Taki, 1962 is likely a junior synonym of Amphitretus pelagicus. Hochberg et al. (1992) suggest this on the basis of hectocotylised arm morphology. Voight (1997) places Idioctopodidae in synonymy of Amphitretidae based on additional characters. Until recently, A. thielei Robson, 1930 was considered to be a junior synonym of A. pelagicus, however O'Shea 1999 considers it to be a valid species.

There is some confusion in the literature because until recently Russian researchers considered both T. angolensis and T. filippovae in the southern hemisphere to be the same species and did not discrimate between the two; they are now considered to be separate species (Dunning and Wormuth 1998).
The type locality is Port Langca, Dumaran Island, Philippine Islands (Sweeney 2012).
This is one of the most taxonomically confused families of squid.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This species closely resembles the sympatric Enoploteuthis jonesi in appearance (Tsuchiya and Young 2009).

The type locality is off Ireland (51°54'N, 11°57'W) in the northeast Atlantic. Because there are so many undescribed species in this genus, the distribution of Helicocranchia pfefferi outside the northeast Atlantic is very uncertain. It is likely that the species referred to around Hawaii as H. pfefferi is in fact a different (and probably undescribed) species (Young and Mangold 2014).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
Egea inermis is the only recognized species in the genus. However, Voss et al. (1992) believe this nominal species might actually comprise two species.

This is the type species of the genus. The type locality is off Messina, Italy. The identity of C. sicula remains uncertain as two similar species appear to be present in the Mediterranean Sea and it is not clear to which the original description pertains (Young and Vecchione 2006).  Hence, it is not possible to determine the true distribution of C. sicula and further taxonomic work is urgently required.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This is the only species in the monotypic genus Ameloctopus.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognized as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Gleadall et al. 2010 described a subspecies from around the Falkland Islands.  Holotype BMNH20090272, collected coastal waters off Argentina, Bahia San Julian, 49°22’S 66°7’W in 258m water depth.
The type locality of this species i in the eastern North Atlantic at 36°, 10°W (Young and Mangold 2007)

O'Shea (1999) created the genus Enigmatiteuthis for this species. Collins (2003), in his review of North Atlantic species of Grimpoteuthis, placed Enigmatiteuthis as a junior synonym of Grimpoteuthis. Grimpoteuthis innominata is known from only two specimens, both from the type locality: 42° 36.79'S, 176° 09.81'W, 2,000 m depth.
The species of this genus are poorly defined.
The type locality is Luderitz Bay, southwestern Africa, South Atlantic Ocean (Sweeney 2012).
The relationship of this species with Abralia multihamata is still undetermined (Tsuchiya 2009).
The type locality is the Bay of Kagoshima, Kii, Japan (Sweeney 2012). This species may be a junior synonym of Loliolus sumatrensis. This requires further research.
The species of this genus are poorly defined.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle, 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).
This moderate sized species of squid appears to consist of large, slender and small body types (Kubodera 2006). The taxonomic status of these morphs have not been assessed (Kubodera 2006).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The type locality is the Old Rhodes Key, Florida, Gulf of Mexico (Sweeney 2012).

This species is only known from four specimens. Hoyle (1885) described it on the basis of two specimens: one from off Valpariso (Chile) and the other from off the Crozet Islands. Robson (1932) considered the Crozet specimen to be a different species for which he erected Cirroteuthis hoylei, now considered nomen dubium. Further taxonomic work is required on this species before its true distribution can be elucidated. See also Guerra et al. (1998) and Collins et al. (2001).
The type locality is off Madras, Bay of Bengal, India (Sweeney 2012).
This is the only species in the genus Cranchia.
This genus contains at least three species (Taonius borealis, Taonius pavo and Taonius belone) (Young and Mangold 2009), although Voss and co-workers (1992) suggest as many as five species may occur.
This is one of the most taxonomically confused families of squid.
The validity of this species has been questioned (Nesis 1987, Roper and Jereb 2010).

This species was described from two poorly preserved individuals. A redescription is needed to resolve taxonomic issues (Young and Vecchione 2003). The type locality is 6°39.1'S, 39°30.8'E, 400 m, near Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, western Indian Ocean, off east African coast (400 m).

This is currently the only species in the genus, however, Voss et al. (1992) suggest that it may consist of two or more species and that this currently recognized cosmopolitan species may in fact be a species complex.

According to Tsuchiya (2009) "Abraliopsis chuni is based on the illustration of the enoploteuthid squid from the Indian North Equatorial Current in Chun (1910). Details of morphology and distribution are still unertain. Chun (1910) redescribed Abraliopsis morisii (Vérany, 1839) from Atlantic and Indian Ocean specimens. The illustrations accompanying the text clearly show that more than one species was included in the description. Subsequently, Nesis (1982) named, on the basis of these illustrations, two new species of Abraliopsis (i.e., A. atlantica and A. chuni)."
This is the only member of the genus Grimalditeuthis.
This species was redescribed by Muus (2002)

D. gigas is a well defined species that cannot be confused with any other squid. Within its geographic range, however, there is great variation in the size and age at maturity and size frequency distribution. But there is no evidence at present (2009) that any subpopulations are genetically distinct although Nigmatullin et al. (2001) suggest that they may be separate stocks.
This is the only species in the family Joubiniteuthidae (Young 2008).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus. We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

There are taxonomic issues surrounding this species. Only the holotype can be confirmed as this species. It is possibly a junior synonym of Muusoctopus normani (Massy 1907) but there is considerable distance between the known distributions (separated by deep water). Furthermore, although it shares the small suckers and VV funnel organ, its gill lamellae counts are marginally outside those of M. normani.  It is likely a valid but poorly known species.

This species is similar in appearance and photophore arrangement to Enoploteuthis chuni and Enoploteuthis galaxias which also occur in the Pacific (Tsuchiya 2000). Its taxonomic status in regard to E. galaxias is uncertain (Tsuchiya 2000).
This species is known from four male specimens only (O'Shea et al. 2003). In general morphology it is similar to O. chathamensis and O. mero, but differs notably from them in anatomy (O'Shea 1998)
The syntypes that are not extant were from India, Sumatra (Sweeney 2012) and possibly other places. This species may be a species complex (Jereb et al. 2010).
Currently three nominal taxa are recognised in the genus (Megalocranchia fisheri, M. maxima, M. oceanica), although Voss et al. (1992) suggest that six species may occur.
The type locality is Bahia Magdelena, Mexico at 24.6<sup>o </sup>N, 112.1<sup>o </sup>W (Sweeney 2012).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

This species was originally described as Cirroteuthis glacialis Robson, 1930 from the Schollaert Channel, Palmer Archipelago; 64°21'S, 62°58'W. O'Shea (1999) raises the possibility that Cirroctopus antarctica (Kubodera and Okutani, 1986), from 62° 59'S, 62° 09'W, 804 m depth, may be a junior synonym of Cirroctopus glacialis. Collins and Villanueva (2006), however, point out that the description of the beaks given by Vecchione et al. (1998) for C. glacialis suggests that these species may be distinct. We retain them as separate species for now. It is possible that all Antarctic Cirroctopus specimens pertain to a single species. In this case, C. mawsoni would have precedence over and be the senior synonym of C. antarctica and C. glacialis.

This species forms part of the Mastigoteuthis agassizii species group that is based on morphological similarities (Vecchione et al. 2007). It is currently composed of three species: Mastigoteuthis agassizii, from tropical to temperate regions of the Atlantic, M. dentata, from tropical to temperate regions of the Indo-Pacific, and M. psychrophila from Southern Ocean (Young and Vecchione 2007). This species is similar in appearance to both M. agassizii and M. dentata (Young and Vecchione 2007).

The holotype was purchased in the market at Yokohama, Japan (Sweeney 2012).  Marked polymorphism has been noted in this species and it is possible that it comprises a suite of cryptic species (Chotiyaputta et al. 1992; Jereb et al. 2010).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.
This species is very similar in appearance to Abralia siedleckyi and may be its junior synonym (Tsuchiya and Young 2009).
The type locality is the Caribbean Sea, Western Atlantic Ocean 22° 59' N, 78° 43' W (Sweeney 2012).

Following Young (2008), we herein treat Dorsopsis taningi Thore, 1949 and Eledonella heathi Berry, 1911 as junior synonyms of Japatella diaphana. The type locality of D. taningi is 13o31' N 18o03'W (off The Gambia), that of E. heathi is Albatross Station 4393 near San Diego, California, whilst that of the J. diaphana is north of Papua New Guinea (0o42'S 147oE). Molecular work may eventually show that Japatella comprises more than one species, but there is insufficient evidence currently to support this.

Thore (1949) moved to place V. alberti Joubin, 1924, V. ingeborgae Joubin, 1929 and V. translucida Robson, 1930 into the synonymy of V. richardi after examination of these and 113 specimens of various sizes caught during the Dana expeditions.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This species is the only representative of this monospecific taxon.

This species is known only from small juveniles which makes it difficult to distinguish from other Onykia species (Vecchione et al. 2003). Subadult Onykia robsoni taken in the Gulf of Mexico are likely to synonymous with O. carriboea (Vecchione et al. 2003).
The type locality is in Puget Sound in the eastern North Pacific (Sweeney 2012).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

Collins and Villanueva (2006) suggest that the status of this species is unclear and that an updated classification of the Opisthoteuthis in the North Pacific is needed.  The species is similar to O. albatrossi (Collins and Villanueva 2006).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.

Females of this species are identical to female Lycoteuthis springeri (Vecchione and Young 1999). Based on geographic distribution and morphological similarity, it is currently considered that Lycoteuthis diadema is synonmous with L. lorigera (Vecchione and Young 2008).
This species is only known from planktonic larvae which means its taxonomic status is not fully resolved.
Cirrothauma murrayi Chun, 1911 is the type species of the genus Cirrothauma.

This species was described as Grimpoteuthis tuftsi Voss and Pearcy 1990. It is known only from the type series of seven specimens all collected on the Tufts Abyssal Plain off Oregon, USA. The type locality is at 45°05.2'N, 134°43.4'W. O’Shea (1999) and O’Shea and Lu (2002) suggested that G. tuftsi should be included in Luteuthis, but we follow Collins and Villanueva (2006) and consider it a species of Grimpoteuthis. The Atlantic abyssal species G. challengeri Collins, 2003 is very similar. Both species possess a radula (Collins and Villanueva 2006), a feature that is generally absent in grimpoteuthid species, and may be closely related.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

However, this species has enlarged suckers, and, as such, is probably not a member of Muusoctopus.  Gleadall (pers. comm.) was proposing erecting a neotype to stabilize the taxonomy due to the excessively poor condition of the holotype.  We retain this species in Muusoctopus pending this action.
Microeledone mangoldi is only known from the type specimen (Norman et al. 2004). It is the type species of the genus Microeledone by monotypy.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The type locality is given simply as "Japan" (Sweeney 2012).
The taxonomic relationship of this species to A. semilineata is not clear.  They may be synonymous.
The type locality is Martinique, West Indies, western North Atlantic Ocean (Sweeney 2012).

Grimpoteuthis meangensis Hoyle 1985 was originally described from a single, damaged animal of unknown sex from 4°33'N, 127°06'E in the Philippines. Subsequently Hoyle (1886) illustrated a small octopod from the South Pacific (over 2,000 km south of the type locality) which he assumed to be the same species. Young and Vecchione (2003) believe that this specimen from 915 m depth off the Kermadec Islands (Collins and Villanueva 2006) does not pertain to G. meangensis  and we therefore assume that G. meangensis is known only from the type locality. Young and Vecchione (2003) emphasise that new material is required to provide an adequate redescription.
This species may be synonymous with Abralia andamanica (Young et al. 1998).
A second similar and undescribed species also occurs in the Southern Ocean (Roper and Sweeney 1992).

This species, described by Linnaeus, simply has 'pelago' as its type locality. This is problematic because molecular work has shown that features traditionally used to separate this species from A. subulata are not useful. Hence the delineation of these two species is currently very problematic. Nonetheless, molecular work has confirmed that two species do indeed exist (Anderson et al. 2008).
It is similar in appearance to the Pacific Ocean species, Abralia similis (Tsuchiya and Young 2009).

Earlier workers attribute the name to Solander. This attribution relates to an unpublished manuscript (which fails to meet Art. 8 and hence does not constitute a nomenclatural act) referred to in Lightfoot's (1786) sale catalogue. There is no description in the sale catalogue but this also refers to Rumphius (1705). Although the latter predates the starting point for zoological nomenclature (Art. 3) the information therein may be referred to. Hence A. nodosa Lightfoot, 1876 is a valid name.
This species is similar in appearance to Abralia redfieldi, Abralia similis and Abralia omiae but is recognisable by the extra photophores on the eye (Tsuchiya 2009).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The status of Graneledone sp. A (Kubodera and Okutani 1994) is not clear, but it may pertain to G. gonzalezi, extending the known range of G. gonzalezi.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The type locality is Kojima Bay, Japan (Sweeney 2012).

Originally described as Cirroteuthis muelleri Eschricht, 1836, this species is considered to be the only valid species in this genus since C. hoylei Robson, 1932 is considered nomen dubium (Collins and Villanueva 2006).
The syntypes were obtained from the Canton market, China (Sweeney 2012).  This species may be a species complex (Chotiyaputta et al. 1992; Jereb et al. 2010).
The genus Eledone contains six species and is in need of revision.
Known only from a single type specimen. Type locality: Antarctica, off Wilkes Land
The type locality is given as the coast, south of Flores [Cote Sud de Flores], in island in the Lesser Sunda Islands, which extend east from Java, Indonesia at 122o 39' E (Sweeney 2012).

Differences in morphology between paralarvae in the Atlantic and Pacific suggest more than one species exists (Young et al. 1992), however, currently not enough specimens from different regions are available for proper species-level comparisons (Vecchione and Young 2008). Thelidioteuthis alessandrini is the misidentified juvenile form of this species (Bello 1992).
This species is only known from two male specimens.
This species now has precedence over Abraliopsis pfefferi which is now considered to be the junior synonym (Tsuchiya 2009).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle, 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus. We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

The type locality of this species is southwest of Cape Town in 2,194 m water depth.  The holotype is BMNH 1924.9.9.23.  We know of no records apart from the original description.
Collins and Villanueva (2006) suggest that the status of this species is unclear and that an updated classification of the Opisthoteuthis in the North Pacific is needed.

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.
The type locality is La Plata Island, Ecuador (Sweeney 2012).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

The validity of this species is in doubt since the type specimen is damaged and the type locality is uncertain (Tsuchiya 2009). Furthermore, records from the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans are likely to be misidentifications (Tsuchiya 2009).

The sucker pattern of males is very similar to that of O. californiana and the two species could be synonymous, suggesting that an updated classification of Opisthoteuthis in the North Pacific is needed (Young and Vecchione 2003, Collins and Villanueva 2006).

The systematics of Tremoctopodidae was reviewed by Thomas (1977). He concluded that two species existed, T. violaceus, comprising the subspecie T. v. violaceus in the Atlantic Ocean and T. v. gracilis in the Pacific Ocean, and a new deep-water species T. gelatus Thomas, 1977.  O'Shea (1999) resurrected the New Zealand species, T. robsoni. Given that T. v. violaceus was no more different from T. robsoni than it was from T. v. gracilis, Mangold et al. (2008) elevated the two subspecies of T. violaceus to specific level.
This is currently the only species in the genus, however, Voss and co-workers (1992) suggest that it may in fact consist of 3-4 closely related species.

This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

Type locality: Gulf of Mexico, United States, Florida, off Dry Tortugas and Tampa (Jereb et al. 2014).
It is currently considered that specimens identified as Lycoteuthis diadema in the North Atlantic are synonmous with L. springeri (Vecchione and Young 2008).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

The disjunct distribution and variable morphology of H. bonnellii specimens suggest several distinct populations occur. For example, based on spermatophore morphology three separate populations may occur in the Atlantic (i.e. Southwest Atlantic, Eastern Tropical Atlantic and Northwest Atlantic) (Young and Vecchione 2009).

Collins (2003) stated that Grimpoteuthis bruuni should be placed in the genus Opisthoteuthis as it possesses three bundles in the optic nerve complex, lateral wings of the shell that taper to fine points and two fields of enlarged suckers in the males. Collins and Villanueva (2006) also placed this species in the genus Opisthoteuthis. The specific name has often been misspelt, but bruuni is the original spelling (Voss 1982). The type locality is 23°41'S, 70°34'W.

Treated as a subspecies (A. pelagicus thielei Robson, 1930) by Nesis (1987) and as a synonym of A. pelagicus by many authors, O'Shea (1999) recognised A. thielei to merit specific status based primarily on differences in number of gill lamellae and suckers on the hectocotylized arm, and its association with different water masses.

This species forms part of the Mastigoteuthis glaukopsis species group. It is currently composed of three species: Mastigoteuthis atlantica, in the Atlantic Ocean; M. famelica, in the Pacific Ocean; and M. glaukopis in the Indian Ocean. There is little difference in the morphology of M. glaukopis and M. atlantica and the two species may be synonymous (Vecchione and Young 2007).

Numerous species of Argonauta have been described. A full list is given by Mangold, Vecchione and Young (2008). Taxonomic work on this genus is required, but A. argo is undoubtedly a good species and is the type species of the genus. We treat A. pacifica (type locality California) as a junior synonym of A. argo (type locality Mediterranean Sea).
The type locality is given as "Brazil and Carolina strands" (Sweeney 2012).

The systematics of Tremoctopodidae was reviewed by Thomas (1977). He concluded that two species existed, T. violaceus, comprising the subspecies T. v. violaceus in the Atlantic Ocean and T. v. gracilis in the Pacific Ocean, and a new deep-water species T. gelatus Thomas, 1977.  O'Shea (1999) resurrected the New Zealand species, T. robsoni. Given that T. v. violaceus was no more different from T. robsoni than it was from T. v. gracilis, Mangold et al. (2008) elevated the two subspecies of T. violaceus to specific level.
The species of this genus are poorly defined.
This is a possible species complex (Voss et al. 1992).

Collins and Villanueva (2006) note that Grimpoteuthis plena is known only from a single, small and damaged specimen. The type locality is in the northwest Atlantic, 37°35'N, 71°18.8'W, 1,963 m depth. Grimpoteuthis umbellata may be the senior synonym of both G. plena and G. wuelkeri, but until further specimens are available from various type localities, the taxonomic issues cannot be resolved.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
It has been suggested that Abraliopsis felis is sufficiently different to be placed in its own subgenus, Boreabraliopsis (Young and Tsuchiya 2009).
This species may actually represent a species complex (Roper and Jereb 2010).
This species closely resembles the sympatric Enoploteuthis higginsi in appearance (Tsuchiya and Young 2009).
The type locality is 'India' (Sweeney, 2012).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

Although Ancistroteuthis is monotypic four geographic morphotypes have been described, however further specimens are required in order to investigate their taxonomic significance (Kubodera et al. 1998).

Grimpoteuthis megaptera (Verrill, 1885) was described from five specimens from the northwest Atlantic. Collins (2003) and Villanueva and Collins (2006) searched for these specimens. They were unable to locate four, which are now presumed lost. They identified the fifth specimen, which was small and damaged, as Cirrothauma murrayi Chun, 1911. They believe the larger specimen taken from abyssal depths (4,708 m), which was illustrated by Verrill (1885; Plate XLIII), is a Grimpoteuthis, but believe new material is required from the type locality to redescribe G. megaptera.
Collins et al. (2001) note that there are some differences between Atlantic and Mediterranean specimens of this species.
This is the only species in the family Batoteuthidae.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This species is only known from the type material.  Males are not known.
There is little information on the genus Teretoctopus. The only information is based on two species from deep waters off India.

Members of Asperoteuthis can easily be misidentified as Grimalditeuthis if they have lost their tentacles (Young and Roper 2008).  Asperoteuthis acanthoderma, A. mangoldae, A. sp. B and A. lui and A. nesisi belong to the genus Asperoteuthis (Young and Roper 2008) but A. sp. B is probably a junior synonym of A. nesisi (Arkhipkin and Laptikhovsky 2008).

This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

Type locality: Banda Sea, off Kai Islands (Jereb et al. 2014).
The type locality is Jolo Harbor, Jolo Island, Philippine Islands (Sweeney 2012).

O'Shea (1999) raises the possibility that this may be a junior synonym of Cirroctopus glacialis. Collins and Villanueva (2006), however, point out that the description of the beaks given by Vecchione et al. (1998) for C. glacialis suggests that these species may be distinct. It is possible that all Antarctic Cirroctopus specimens pertain to a single species. In this case, C. mawsoni would have precedence over and be the senior synonym of C. antarctica and C. glacialis.
Jereb et al. (2014) deal with this species under 'Octopus' californicus.  No indication is given as to why it has been removed from Enteroctopus.

This species was originally described as Cirroteuthis pacifica Hoyle, 1885 from a single damaged specimen. O'Shea (1999) suggested that this species might better belong in his new genus Enigmatiteuthis, but we follow Collins (2003) and Collins and Villanueva (2006) in which Enigmatiteuthis is a junior synonym of Grimpoteuthis. Due to the poor condition of the type, and the fact that no new specimens have been captured from the type locality, the description is poor and this species cannot be clearly separated from several others (Young and Vecchione, 2003). The type locality is Papua New Guinea in the South Pacific at 13°50'S, 151°49'E.
The type locality is Abulat Island, off Saudi Arabia in the Red Sea (Sweeney 2012).

The validity of this species has been questioned (Nesis 1987). Robson (1932) considered both this species and A. boettgeri potentially to be variants of A. hians. Molecular work is probably required to clarify validity.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

authority: Gonzalez & Guerra in Gonzalez, Guerra, Pascual & Briand, 1998

taxonomicNotes: This is one of the most taxonomically confused families of squid.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This species may be a subspecies of Abralia steindachneri (Young et al. 1998).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus. We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Following Strugnell et al. (2009), we consider Benthoctopus macrophallus Voss and Pearcy 1990 (holotype USNM 730713 from 44º58'N 126º32'W) to be a junior synonym of this species.
The type locality is Valparaiso, Chile in the eastern South Pacific Ocean (Sweeney 2012).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognized as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

This species was redescribed by Toll (1981) who did not examine the lectotype.  Gleadall et al. (2004) examined the lectotype and Toll's specimens and concluded they were conspecific despite the considerable distance between their capture locations.

The holotype of this species was originally identified as Cirroteuthis umbellata. Grimpe recognised it as a new species and erected Cirroteuthopsis massyae to accommodate it. Villanueva et al. (2002) placed it in Opisthoteuthis.
Its taxonomic relationship with Abralia spaercki is uncertain (Tsuchiya 2009).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.
The type locality is North Port Phillip Bay, Australia (Sweeney 2012).
Muus (2002) proposed this as a new species, but also suggested that it might be a hybrid of B. arcticus and B. bairdii or might be a stunted form of B. bairdii.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus. We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Nesis (1993) has described a complex population structure for S. oualaniensis that incorporates three major and possibly two minor forms:
1. A giant form that occurs only in the northern Indian Ocean in the region of the Red Sea, Gulf of Aden and Arabian Sea (modal  sizes of 400-500 mm ML in the Arabian Sea, maximum size of 650 mm ML). It has the same type of gladius as no. 3 below.
2. A medium form (modal sizes of 120-150 mm for mature males and 190-250 mm for mature females) that occurs throughout most of the range of the species and has a gladius double lateral axes (stiffened ribs) of the rhachis.
3. A medium form but with a gladius having single lateral axes of  the rhachis. It occurs only in the Red Sea, the Gulf of Aden and the Arabian Sea north of 15°-17°N.
4. A dwarf form (modal size of 90-100 mm ML for mature males and 90-120 mm ML for mature females, 140-150 mm ML maximum) that occurs in equatorial waters (roughly within 10°-20° latitude of the equator) of the Pacific and Indian Oceans and lacks the dorsal mantle photophore patch characteristic of the species.         
5.  A small form, similar to the medium form but maturing at a smaller size (mode for females is 120-140 mm with a range of 90-160 mm ML) that is nearly the same size as the dwarf form and is known from the Western Indian Ocean and the eastern tropical Pacific.

The genetic status of the different forms is unknown. The dwarf form is often thought to be a separate species but it has not been given a separate name and its separate specific status has not been proven.
This species closely resembles Abralia heminuchalis and they may be synonymous (Tsuchiya and Young 2009).
Graneledone verrucosa is the type species of the genus Graneledone.

This species forms part of the Mastigoteuthis agassizii species group that is based on morphological similarities (Vecchione et al. 2007). It is currently composed of three species: Mastigoteuthis agassizii, from tropical to temperate regions of the Atlantic; M. dentata, from tropical to temperate regions of the Indo-Pacific; and M. psychrophila from Southern Ocean (Young and Vecchione 2007). There are currently no reliable morphological differences to separate M. dentata from M. agassizii.

There is some confusion in the literature because until recently Russian researchers considered both T. angolensis and T. filippovae in the southern hemisphere to be the same species and did not discrimate between the two; they are now considered to be separate species (Dunning and Wormuth 1998).

Until recently, Eogonatus tinro was only known from juvenile specimens, although it had been suggested that Gonatopsis okutanii might represent the adult form of this species.  Spent females of Gonatopsis okutanii were found to have possessed tentacles just prior to attaining maturity and spawning, which suggested it didn't belong to the genus Gonatopsis (Hochberg 2006), but might in fact represent adult Eogonatus tinro which has a similar distribution range.  This has been confirmed by Katugin et al. (2011) and we treat Gonatopsis okutanii as a junior synonym of Eogonatus tinro.

Ommastrephes bartramii has a cosmopolitan distribution in temperate to subtropical waters. However, genetic tests of populations in different oceans, to determine if gene flow occurs, have not been made.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).
The type locality is South Carolina, western North Atlantic Ocean (Sweeney 2012).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This is the only species of the genus.
The type locality is off the coast of Surinam, 30 miles north east of the Lightship Suriname River, (Sweeney 2012).
This species was recently redescribed by Collins and Henriques (2000).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

Many undescribed members of this genus are incorrectly identified and treated under the name “Octopus macropus group”.  Type locality: South-eastern Pacific Ocean, Easter Island, Hanga Piko (Jereb et al. 2014).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The type locality is 129°28'E, along the Great Australian Bight.
According to Young (1999), this genus may consist of four species (Discoteuthis discus, Discoteuthis laciniosa, Discoteuthis sp. A and Discoteuthis sp. B).
The species of this genus are poorly defined.
The type locality of this species is 32<sup>o</sup>05'N, 64<sup>o</sup>38'W, in the Sargasso Sea, off Bermuda (Sweeney 2012).
The type locality is in the Pacific Ocean, off Panama (Sweeney 2012). Lolliguncula tydeus Brakoniecki, 1980 is a junior synonym (Vecchione 1996, see Nomenclature).
Abralia andamanica robsoni Grimp, 1931 is considered to be the junior synonym of Abralia andamanica (Tsuchiya 2009).
Jereb et al. (2014) deal with this species under 'Octopus' bunurong.  No indication is given as to why it has been removed from Callistoctopus.

Differences in morphology-ecological traits in the northwest African population compared to those present in the North Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea suggest this population may represent a separate sub-species or species (Nigmatullin et al. 2002).

This species is easily identified by its distinctive photophore arrangement on its tentacles (Young and Mangold 1996). Despite both occurring in the South Pacific, its range does not overlap with P. margaritifera (Young and Mangold 1996).
The broad distribution of this species suggests it is probably a species complex.
The type locality is given as Red Sea (Sweeney 2012).
Muus (2002) removed this species from the genus Bathypolypus and placed it in the genus Benthoctopus. Jorgensen (2009) then renamed it under its own genus.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The type locality is in the western South Atlantic Ocean at 41° 47'S, 63° 35'W (Sweeney 2012).

Numerous synonyms have been proposed including Alloposus mollis Verrill, 1880, Octopus alberti Joubin, 1895, Alloposus pacificus Ijima & Ikeda, 1902, Heptapus danai Joubin, 1929, Alloposus hardyi Robson, 1930 and Alloposina albatrossi Robson, 1931. Although the genus name is recognized as Haliphron, the correct family name is Alloposidae.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
Often confused with other ocellate species, such as A. siamensis, A. rex, A. membranaceus and A. neglectus.

Earlier workers attribute the name to Solander. This attribution relates to an unpublished manuscript (which fails to meet Art. 8 and hence does not constitute a nomenclatural act) referred to in Lightfoot's (1786) sale catalogue. There is no description in the sale catalogue, but this also refers to Rumphius (1705). Although the latter predates the starting point for zoological nomenclature (Art. 3) the information therein may be referred to. Hence A. hians Lightfoot 1876 is a valid name. However, A. hians appears to be very variable in form and taxonomic work is required to delineate the species limits.  According to Jereb et al. (2014), Moolenbeek (2008) designated a neotype with type locality Ambon Indonesia.
The type locality is given as "Purchased at market, Yokohama, Japan" (Sweeney 2012).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus. We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

The holotype is USNM 332981.  It was originally reported from four specimens. Benthoctopus violescens Taki has been placed in synonymy of this species (see Voss and Pearcy 1990).  B. violescens was described from off Kashima-nada, Honshu, Japan (exact capture location and depth unknown).
This species may actually be a species complex (Voss et al. 1992).

The type locality is the Mediterranean.  The type specimen of this species, described by Lamarck, is no longer extant.  This is problematic because molecular work has shown that features traditionally used to separate this species from A. media are not useful.  Hence the delineation of these two species is currently very problematic.  Nonetheless, molecular work has confirmed that two species do indeed exist (see Anderson et al. 2008).

This species was described from three octopods taken at depths of 275-365 m. It appears to be separable from other species by its distinctive beak (Young and Vecchione 2003). Note that the original spelling used by Oommen (1976) is 'philipii' although this has subsequently been misspelt in a variety of ways (see for example O'Shea 1999 and Collins and Villaneuva 2006). The type locality is 09°32'N, 75°45'E Arabian Sea, Indian Ocean off southwest India, 275 m depth (Young and Vecchione 2003).
Two species have been described in this genus, however, Cycloteuthis akimushkini is likely to be the junior synonym of Cycloteuthis serventi (Young 2009).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.

This species, originally described as Cirroteuthis umbellata Fischer, 1883, is the type species for Grimpoteuthis. It is known only from the type specimen, which is in extremely poor condition (Collins 2003, Collins and Villanueva 2006). Because G. umbellata remains poorly described, the ‘true’ form of Grimpoteuthis remains unknown. New collections from the type locality (between Fayal and San Miguel in the Azores at 37°55'N, 20°22'W and in 2,235 m of water) are required to solve the taxonomic issues. This species may be the senior synonym of G. discoveryi or G. wuelkeri (Collins 2003).
The type locality is Sri Lanka [Ceylon] (Sweeney 2012).
O. antillarum can be distinguished from its IndoPacific counterpart, O. volitalis only by the detailed structure of the male hectocotylus.
The type locality is off Mozambique, 19o 45' S, 36o 22' E (Sweeney 2012).
This species was redescribed by Muus (2002).

This species was described from a series of small squid (maximum size was 1.9 cm mantle length) obtained from the stomach of the lancetfish Alepisaurus ferox. In spite of its small size, the species was recognized as being distinct by the presence of a relatively broad mantle and a small visceral photophore (Young and Vecchione 2001).

This species was described as Stauroteuthis mawsoni Berry, 1911 and placed in Cirroctopus by Naef (1923). Robson (1932) moved it to Grimpoteuthis, but it was placed back in Cirroctopus by O'Shea (1999). It was described from a single specimen, type locality off Adelie Land, Antarctic waters at 66°55'S, 145°21'E, 530-550 m. It is possible that all Antarctic Cirroctopus specimens pertain to a single species. In this case, C. mawsoni would have precedence over and be the senior synonym of C. antarctica and C. glacialis. It is the type species of Cirroctopus.
Although controversy exists over the validity of this species, recent genetic evidence suggests it is distinct and therefore a valid species (Mart ínez et al. 2005).
The type locality is off Port Maricaban, southern Luzon, Philippine Islands (Sweeney 2012).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognized as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The taxonomic validity of this species is still in question, large individuals closely resemble Gonatus madokai and G. japonicus may represent the immature form of this species (Kubodera 2006).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

According to Young (1999), this genus may consist of four species (Discoteuthis discus, Discoteuthis laciniosa, Discoteuthis sp. A and Discoteuthis sp. B), however, Discoteuthis sp. A may be the mature male of Discoteuthis discus.
Specimens from the North Atlantic may be misidentifications of Planctoteuthis lippula (Young and Roper 2008).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
This species is similar to Abralia andamanica in appearance (Tsuchiya and Young 2009).
Currently three nominal taxa are recognised in the genus (Megalocranchia fisheri, M. maxima, M. oceanica), although Voss et al. (1992) suggest that six species may occur.

The systematics of the Architeuthis group is not well understood since many species have been described from single and often incomplete specimens (Roper 1998). Some authors believe three distinct species may exist based on differences in their geographic distribution: Architeuthis dux in the North Atlantic, A. martensi in the North Pacific and A. sanctipauli in the Southern Ocean (Roper 1998; Norman 2003).  However, we treat Architeuthis as comprising a single global species.
We consider Taningia persica, which is known only from the paralarval type material, to be a junior synonym of T. danae.
This species is known from only five specimens

Four very similar species of Mastigoteuthis (M. agassizii, M. grimaldi, M. schmidti and M. flammea) have been described from the North Atlantic. These were recently synonomized, based partly on the MAR-ECO material, under M. agassizii (Young and Vecchione 2007).  Mastigoteuthis agassizii may itself consist of a temperate/boreal and a tropical form in the Atlantic, in which case M. flammea is the correct name for the tropical form (see Vecchione and Young 2007).  This species forms part of the Mastigoteuthis agassizii species group that is based on morphological similarities (Vecchione et al. 2007). It is currently composed of three species: Mastigoteuthis agassizii, from tropical to temperate regions of the Atlantic; M. dentata, from tropical to temperate regions of the Indo-Pacific; and M. psychrophila from Southern Ocean (Young and Vecchione 2007).

Callistoctopus kermadecensis (Berry 1914) is listed by Norman and Hochberg (2005) under Callistoctopus but treated as 'Octopus' kermadecensis in Jereb et al. (2014). No reason is given by Jereb et al. (2014) for the removal of this species from Callistoctopus.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The type locality is Sumatra, Indonesia (Sweeney 2012).
This species is similar in appearance to Abralia redfieldi.

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.
Two subspecies have been described: G. taniwha taniwha (O'Shea 1999) and G. taniwha kubodera (O'Shea 1999).

Opisthoteuthis persephone, Berry 1918 was described from eight specimens taken off Western Australia. This species needs to be redescribed from new material from the type locality (Young and Vecchione 2003). It differs from the New Zealand species O. mero in the number of primary gill lamellae (almost always 6 vs almost always 7) (O'Shea 1999). It differs from the sympatric O. pluto in its pigmentation (Berry 1918) and fewer gill lamellae (usually 6 vs 8) (Young and Vecchione 2003).  The type locality is 42 miles south and east of Genoa Peak, Victoria, in the great Australian bight, at 480 m depth.

This species was described as Stauroteuthis wuelkeri Grimpe 1920. O'Shea (1999) suggested it be placed in  Enigmatiteuthis, but we follow Collins (2003) and Collins and Villanueva (2006) and place it in Grimpoteuthis. Collins (2003) notes that G. wuelkeri (type locality 35°46'N, 08°16'W, 2,055 m depth) may be a junior synonym of either G. umbellata or G. plena (despite differences in the sucker counts between the type of G. plena and G. wuelkeri). New material from the type localities for G. umbellata and G. plena are required to resolve these taxonomic issues. Piatkowski and Dieckmann (2005) reported a specimen of G. wuelkeri from 5,430 m in the Angola Basin, but Collins and Villanueva (2006) note that this is considerably deeper than other records of this species and may be attributable to one of the deeper Grimpoteuthis species. This record has therefore not been included in the distribution and occurrence records here.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

There are considerable taxonomic difficulties in the genus Amphioctopus which need resolving, although the genus itself is clearly defined. Although some species have been redescribed, there is considerable taxonomic confusion and apparent misuse of names in various regions. For example, no agreement exists as to the name of the species that occurs in the Mediterranean Sea. For this reason, the geographic range of species given herein should be treated with caution, as these ranges may change as taxonomic revisions are undertaken.
The type specimen of Amphioctopus aegina is in the British Museum (BMNH 1928.2.14.1). The original description of A. aegina is brief and does not provide a type locality (Norman et al. 2014).  Norman et al. (2014) note that Amphioctopus kagoshimensis is often incorrectly treated as A. aegina. These authors consider A. hardwickei and A. dollfusi to be junior synonyms of A. aegina.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

Norman and Hochberg (2005) place Octopus harmandi (Rochebrune 1882) in synonymy of this species. Octopus guangdongensis (Dong 1976) may also be a synonym although its current status is unresolved (Norman and Hochberg 2005).
Hochberg (1998) synonymised Graneledone pacifica with G. boreopacifica but it is likely that both species are valid with G. boreopacifica having a shallower distribution.
Only three species included in this genus have been described to date, but there are at least ten species which are distributed throughout the Indo-west Pacific (Jereb et al. 2014).
The genus Eledone contains six species and is in need of revision.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

O’Shea (1999) included Grimpoteuthis bathynectes Voss and Pearcy 1990 in his new genus, Enigmatiteuthis.  Enigmatiteuthis mainly differs from Grimpoteuthis in the form of the shell; however, following examination of specimens of G. bathynectes, Collins (2003) suggested it remain in Grimpoteuthis (Collins and Villanueva 2006).  Only one other species of Grimpoteuthis, G. hippocrepium (Hoyle, 1904) is known from the North Pacific Ocean.

This is an easily recognized species but it is a mesopelagic boundary species and therefore found in close association with land masses. As a result, the numerous "subpopulations" may have some genetic separation. DNA sequencing, however, has not been carried out.
Jereb et al. (2014) deal with this species under 'Octopus' maorum. No indication is given as to why it has been removed from Macroctopus.
This species is similar to Opisthoteuthis borealis, but the digestive gland is not entire in O. grimaldii (Collins and Villanueva 2006).
Despite some confusion over the validity of this species due to its similarity to G. makko, it now appears that it is a valid species that matures at a small body size (Kubodera 2006).

This species forms part of the Mastigoteuthis magna species group (Vecchione et al. 2007). It is currently composed of three species: Mastigoteuthis magna, in the Atlantic Ocean; M. microlucens, in the tropical Pacific Ocean; and an undescribed species from the subantarctic Pacific Ocean (Vecchione et al. 2007). Members of this group are distinctive and easily identified from other Mastigoteuthis species (Young and Vecchione 2007).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus. We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).
Following Young (2008), we treat Bolitaena microtyla Steenstrup in Hoyle, 1886 as a junior synonym of Bolitaena pygmaea.

For taxonomic studies of E. megalocyathus refer to Ré (1980) and Ré (1998a)

Actually, there are not taxonomic revisions.
The morphology of this species is not clear, therefore all records should be treated with caution at this stage.
Abdopus undulatus Huffard 2007, also described from Tongatapu, may be a junior synonym of this species.
The type locality is Martinique (Sweeney 2012).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).
This species may be a synonym of Abralia dubia (Tsuchiya 2009).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

This species was originally described as Cirrhoteuthis [sic] gilchristi Robson, 1924. Robson subsequently amended the spelling and moved the species to Chunioteuthis. The species was redescribed and placed in Stauroteuthis by Collins and Henriques (2000).
Robson (1929) and Norman and Finn (2001) consider Octopus fimbriatus Rüppell in d'Orbigny, 1841 to be a junior synonym of this species.
This species is known from a single female specimen (O'Shea 1999).
Jereb et al. (2014) place this species in Eledone but do not state their reasons for doing so.
The species of this genus are poorly defined.
This species was placed in Bathypolypus by Muus (2002).

This species was described as Cirroctopus hochbergi O'Shea 1999 from off New Zealand (Type locality 39 58.9'S, 178 14.27'E, 800-1070 m). It is most similar to Cirroctopus mawsoni, but a few characters separate it and it is 'strongly allopatric' (O'Shea 1999).
This is the only species in the genus Bathothauma.
