The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed. Type locality: Coast of Patagonia, bay of San Blas (Jereb et al. 2014).

This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

Type locality: New Zealand, North Island (Jereb et al. 2014).

Grimpoteuthis hippocrepium Hoyle 1904 was described from a single, small individual which was damaged by the time it was described. However, the color drawings were made on the freshly captured animal. Nevertheless, many features of this species are unknown and a redescription based on new material is badly needed (Young and Vecchione 2003).
This is one of the most taxonomically confused families of squid.

This species was removed from the genus Octopus by Norman and Hochberg (2005) and placed in the genus Abdopus by Norman et al. (2014). Reasons for these taxonomic decisions are not provided in either publication.
The species of this genus are poorly defined.

Molecular and morphological studies suggest that Onychoteuthis compacta and two other closely related species (O. prolatus and O. aequimanus) inhabit Hawaiian waters (Bonnaud et al. 1998; Kubodera et al. 1998).
Type locality: Western Mediterranean Sea, Italy

Specimens from different regions of the Pacific show variation in the number and size arrangement of their tentacle-photophores compared to individuals from the Atlantic, therefore the taxonomic status of P. margaritifera is unresolved (Young and Mangold 1996).

The type locality is given as New Holland (Australia), and is probably Port Western (Sweeney 2012).

Three genetic types recognized based on allozyme electrophoresis: "peripherial", "hybrid" types found mostly around offshore islands and "central" type found along the mainland of Australia. The latter type is the primary fishery target (Steer et al. 2007).
The North Pacific subpopulation exhibits some different morphological features from its Atlantic counterpart and may prove to be genetically distinct (Young 1972).

This species was described as Luteuthis dentatus O'Shea 1999 from a single specimen. The type locality is 40° 01.3’S, 167° 49.9’E, 991 m. A second specimen was reported but not described from 37° 14.2’S, 167° 22.4’E, 1,050 m (O'Shea and Lu 2002). This species is the type of the genus Luteuthis.
This species is considered to be closely related to other North Atlantic Gonatus species (Kubodera 2006).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus. We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

It is possible that this family may consist of as many as five species (Magnapinna atlantica, North Atlantic; Magnapinna sp. B, North Atlantic; Magnapinna sp. C, South Atlantic; Magnapinna pacifica, North Pacific and North Atlantic; and Magnapinna talismani, North Atlantic) but requires further research and specimens (Vecchione and Young 2008).
The species of this genus are poorly defined. This species is only known from the type material which comprises paralarvae.
The type locality is in the Pacific Ocean at 16<sup>o </sup>47' 30" N, 99<sup>o </sup>59' 30" W (Sweeney 2012).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.
Kubodera et al. (1998) state that Onykia indica Okutani, 1981 is probably the young form of some known species of Onykia, however Bolstad (2010) believes it is a valid species.
Originally this species was believed to have a circumglobal distribution but (Vecchione et al. 2007) considered that these distribution records comprised more than one species.

No type locality was designated for this species and the type specimen is not extant (Sweeney 2012). A neotype is required as part of a major taxonomic revision of this nominal taxon. Australian S. lessoniana can be separated on morphometrics and spermatophore structure from Indonesian and Philippine S. lessoniana (Lu and Tait 1983). In northern Australia, S. lessoniana is thought to consist of two cryptic species based on allozyme electrophoresis (Triantafillos and Adams 2005). Izuka et al. (1994, 1996) found evidence for three species of "S. lessoniana" in Okinawa based on isozyme and chromatophore analyses. These studies suggest that over its broad habitat which includes numerous islands that "S. lessoniana" may consist of many cryptic species.

Originally described from a single specimen as Opisthoteuthis agassizii Verrill 1883, this is the type species of the genus Opisthoteuthis. The type locality is off Grenada, Lesser Antilles, tropical Western North Atlantic, 535 m depth.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The type locality is between Cape Town and Tranquebar in the Indian Ocean (Sweeney 2012).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The type locality is the coast, SE of Sumba [Cote SE de Soemba (Sweeney 2012)], an island east of Java, Indonesia.
The type locality is the Caribbean Sea, western North Atlantic Ocean at 25° 42' 30" N, 79° 20' W (Sweeney 2012).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Hochberg designated a neotype for this species (CASIZ 031369), redescribed the species based on material from Alaska to California and transferred it to Benthoctopus.  However, he did not examine the neotype he designated.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
No morphological differences were observed in specimens taken from the Atlantic with those from the North Pacific (Vecchione and Young 2003).

Numerous species of Argonauta have been described. A full list is given by Mangold, Vecchione and Young (2008). No type material has been located for A. boettgeri and the type locality was unknown ("Patria ignota") at the time of the description, however, the original description contained a clear illustration of the shell. Designation of a neotype might help stabilize nomenclature. The species is often seen spelt A. bottgeri, however the correct transliteration of the name Argonauta Böttgeri given in the original description is Argonauta boettgeri according to Article 32.5.2.1 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The type locality is in the Eastern South Atlantic at 0° 03' S, 9° 07 'E (Sweeney 2012).
This is one of the most taxonomically confused families of squid.  This particular species is known from juveniles only.
Only three species included in this genus have been described to date, but there are at least ten species distributed throughout the Indo-west Pacific (Jereb et al. 2014).

This species has a complicated history entwined with that of Gonatus middendorffi. The latter was erected by Kubodera and Okutani (1981) who had declared Gonatus kamtschaticus nomen dubium on account of the poor description, lack of type material and limited use of its name.  However, Nesis considered G. middendorffi to be a junior synonym of G. kamtschaticus and re-elevated G. kamtschaticus to senior synonym.  We treat Gonatus middendorffi as junior synonym of G. kamtschaticus.
Jereb et al. (2014) deal with this species under 'Octopus' conispadiceus.  No indication is given as to why it has been removed from Enteroctopus.
This species is known only from a single individual, apparently a female, from the type locality (0°57.5'S, 99°51.1'E) in the Indian Ocean (Young and Vecchione 2003).

This species forms part of the Mastigoteuthis glaukopsis species group. It is currently composed of three species: Mastigoteuthis atlantica, in the Atlantic Ocean; M. famelica, in the Pacific Ocean; and M. glaukopis in the Indian Ocean. This species is probably synonymous with both M. atlantica and M. famelica (Young and Vecchione 2007).

This species was originally described from four specimens (from south of the Aleutian Islands) as Stauroteuthis (Sasaki 1920), and was considered a Grimpoteuthis by Voss (1988). Collins (2003) suggested that it be included in the genus Opisthoteuthis. This classification is supported by the holotype (male). Although this is in poor condition, it is clear from the original illustration that the body shape and pattern of greatly enlarged suckers at the web margin are characteristic of Opisthoteuthis. The sucker pattern of males is very similar to that of O. californiana and the two species could be synonymous, suggesting that an updated classification of Opisthoteuthis in the North Pacific is needed (Young and Vecchione 2003, Collins and Villanueva 2006).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Following Voss and Pearcy (1990) we believe that, of purported specimens, only the holotype can be assigned to this species with confidence.  The type locality is off Yokohama, south of Honshu, Japan.  Strugnell et al. (2009) report a specimen with similar characteristics from the East Pacific Rise, but hesitated to refer it to M. profundorum because of the very great distance between the two capture localities.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
Until recently, other taxa were included within the concept of B. maritimus; this obscures the limits of its distribution and may obscure population trends.
The conservation assessment of this taxon is complicated by the conviction that the current taxonomic designation hides a complex of several different species.

Pelochelys bibroni was redescribed and separated from Pelochelys cantorii and restricted to the southern lowlands of New Guinea by Webb (1995), based partly on Rhodin et al. (1993). The genetic divergence of P. bibroni from Asian P. cantorii was confirmed by Engstrom et al. (2004), but it has yet to be compared genetically with P. signifera (Webb 2003), a morphologically distinct species from northern New Guinea. No geographic variation has been reported within the species' range and no subspecies have been named.
There are no taxonomic issues regarding this species.
Listed as Pama pama in Talwar and Jhingran (1991).

All these groups have been synonomised under this one name, M. acculeatus. By designating a neo type for this species (from Java), the type locality has been restricted (Kottelat and Widjanarti 2005).

Hamilton (1822) described this nominal species in his treatment of the fishes of the Ganges River basin and its tributaries. No types are known. This species has since been reported from elsewhere in the Northern Indian Ocean, and if the synonymy listed by Kottelat (2013) is correct, the species would be more widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific. However, data are extremely limited and taxonomic confusion abounds. Major external and internal differences have been reported between immature specimens, mature males, and mature females, such that the different life stages and sexes have been placed in separate genera and even families (Smith 2019). At this time, the number of valid species in the genus Moringua is uncertain. A single species is known from the western Atlantic (M. edwardsi), but the number of species and the correct names for specimens reported from the Indo-Pacific are poorly known. A revision of the family Moringuidae, and especially the genus Moringua, is needed to clarify this situation (Smith 2019).
Toxotes chatareus probably comprises a large species complex; Australian species almost certainly represent a separate species (Heok Hee Ng, pers. comm.). The species is in need of taxonomic review.

Odonteleotris macrodon may consist of two or more species, and further research is required (D. Hoese in litt.). This species was described from West Bengal, India and so if this species is split into more than one species then the name will be associated with the species in India.
Contemporary studies indicate that Tephrinectes is not a member of the family Paralichthyidae (Hensley and Ahlstrom 1984, Hoshino and Amaoka 1998).

The species was reviewed by Allen and Burgess (1990), who noted that the species has often been misidentified and erroneously synonymized with several others (e.g. Ambassis commersoni, A. dussumieri, A. gymnocephalus).
Specimens collected at Can Tho and Vinh Long provinces, Viet Nam, described by Mai (1992), may also be this species
This species has been referred to as Lutjanus malabaricus or Lutjanus altifrontalis by many recent authors.
There are several nominal species referred to with the name Cynoglossus puncticeps. The taxonomic status of these nominal species needs to be determined (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2014).

Species formerly known under the genus Poecilophis are synonyms of the genus Echidna. Poecilophis tritor and Poecilophis pikei are synonyms of Echidna polyzona. In addition, Echidna leihala, Echidna obscura, Echidna psalion, Echidna sauvagel, Echidna vincta, Echidna zonata, and Echidna zonophaea are all considered synonyms of Echidna polyzona. Other synonyms also included under Echidna polyzona are Muraena dizona and Muraena fascigula.

Cynoglossus trigrammus is considered a junior synonym of C. abbreviatus by some; however, both are treated as valid species by other workers (e.g., Li and Wang 1995). According to Kottelat (2001), the status of these nominal species needs clarification.
This species may be part of a complex of similar species (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
Some authors have placed this species in the genus Pleuranacanthus (Su and Li 2002).
This species belong to order Beloniformes, family Adrianichthyidae
This species was described from Java, Indonesia.
This species was previously considered a junior synonym of D. tumifrons (D. hypselsomus) but is considered as valid by Iwatsuki et al. (2007).
This species was recently assigned in the genus Sparidentex (Kume and Yoshino 2008, Iwatsuki and Carpenter 2006). There is a need for genus review (Y. Iwatsuki pers comm. 2009).

This species was previously confused with Rhabdosargus sarba. Rhabdosargus thorpei was described as a separate species by Margaret Smith in 1979 after being recognized by Mr. Anthony Thorpe. The name R. auriventris has also previously been applied to this fish (van der Elst 1988).

The type locality of this species is in the Red Sea. The Red Sea specimen is significantly genetically different from the Arabian Gulf specimens. Further study is needed to clarify the taxonomic status of this species (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2013).

Both the specific and generic status of this species is under review and likely to change (K. Carpenter pers. comm. 2009).


The phylogeny of sparids, and the taxonomy of snapper in particular, has attracted considerable attention. In Australasia, snapper had previously been assigned to the genus Chrysophrys, formerly as Chrysophrys unicolor and more latterly as C. auratus (Paulin 1990). Paulin (1990) determined Pagrus to be the senior synonym of Chrysophrys, and re-described C. auratus as Pagrus auratus. In addition, he concluded that the species known as red sea bream in Japan, i.e. Pagrus major, was a conspecific and should also be re-described as P. auratus. Researchers in Japan, however, have not adopted this taxonomy (Jackson 2007).

Acanthopagrus vagus was previously confused with A. berda (Forsskål 1775) in South Africa (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). This species was recently separated as a separate species from A. berda (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2010).

The taxonomic name was changed to Diplodus capensis from Diplodus sargus capensis in 2004 (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). Two disjunct populations exist, one along the eastern seaboard of South Africa from Cape Point to southern Mozambique (Smith and Heemstra 1991, Mann 1992) and another from Namibia to southern Angola (Richardson 2010). These two populations may represent two separate species (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004, Richardson 2010). This evaluation dealt with D. capensis sensu strictu (distributed from False Bay to southern Mozambique).

This species was described on the basis of specimens collected from Nakagusuku Bay and Haneji Inlet, Okinawa Island, Ryukyu Islands, Japan. Although the present new species has been often misidentified as Acanthopagrus australis (Günther), morphological and genetic evidence showed that it is clearly different from the latter species (Kume and Yoshino 2008, Hsu 2011).
This species has been misidentified as Acanthopagrus latus (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2009).

The south east and south west Australian populations of this species may represent separate species, or subspecies, and there is a need for genetic studies (Y. Iwatsuki pers comm. 2009). It is known to hybridise with A. australis in southern New South Wales (Rowland 1984).

A number of synonyms have been previously used for Rhabdosargus sarba, including Sparus sarba, Austrosparus sarba, Chrysophrys sarba, etc. (Smith and Smith 1986). In Australia, Whitley (1931) described Roughleyia (=Rhabdosargus) tarwhine to distinguish the eastern Australian species from the east African species. Then Munro (1949) reviewed the genus in Australia and confirmed the name Rhabdosargus sarba for the west and east Indian, and west Pacific Ocean populations. Whitley (1964) persisted with the subspecies status as Rhabdosargus sarba tarwhine for the Australian population, but this was not followed by others. The taxonomy of the Rhabdosargus sarba complex is currently under review by Yukio Iwatsuki, (Miyazaki University, Japan). 

Rhabdosargus sarba might be confused with R. haffara. Taxonomic review is urgently needed (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2013).

This may be a subpopulation of Acanthopagrus schlegelli (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2009). Mitochondrial DNA analyses based on cytochrome b gene sequences did not distinguish individuals of A. schlegelii and A. sivicolus, reflecting either historical introgression or recent speciation and incomplete sorting of their mitochondrial lineages (Hsu et al. 2011). Pending further taxonomic work, A. sivicolus is here regarded as a distinct species.

Iwatsuki et al. 2007 examined the lectotype of Chrysophrys tumifrons, concluding that the specimen was actually the species recognized as Evynnis japonica (Tanaka 1931), and therefore a senior synonym of that species. Evynnis tumifrons (Temminck and Schlegel 1843) has not been recorded from Australia. Dentex spariformis Ogilby, 1910 (described from Moreton Island) and previously considered a synonym of Dentex tumifrons, was therefore resurrected. All Australian records of Dentex tumifrons most probably refer to Dentex spariformis.

According to Iwatsuki and Maclaine (2013), Crenidens crenidens and C. indicus are two distinct species. Crenidens crenidens occurs from the Red Sea, East Africa along the east coast of Africa to Aliwal Shoal in South Africa. Juvenile C. crenidens have been found in Algoa Bay, South Africa (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). Crenidens indicus occurs from the southern Arabian Peninsula (occasionally in the Red Sea) to the coasts of Iran and Pakistan, including the Gulf. Bauchot and Smith (1984) reported C. indicus from India; however, C. indicus either doesn't occur around India or it is extremely rare in the area (Iwatsuki and Maclaine 2013). 

Previously, two different sub-species were recognized. Crenidens crenidens indicus from the coasts of India and the Arabian Sea and C. crenidens crenidens along the east coast of Africa. In the Red Sea the two subspecies were found to coexist, with a predominance of C. crenidens crenidens (Fischer and Bianchi 1984).

There are numerous taxonomic studies that have been conducted for Acanthopagrus, with several species complexes identified, including, Black Seabream forms I-II and Yellowfin Seabream forms I-II (Iwatsuki 2013). 

Acanthopagrus longispinnis was previously recognized as a synonym of A. berda. It is currently valid as A. longispinnis (Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes 1830) (Kume and Yoshino 2008). This species was split from A. latus, which is now recognised as five cryptic species. The five species can be distinguished from one another by the counts of dorsal-fin rays, pore lateral-line scales, scale rows between the fifth dorsal-fin spine base and lateral line, and other distinguishing morphological characteristics and body and fin coloration (Iwatsuki 2013).

Archosargus probatocephalus is subdivided into three subspecies by some authors: A. probatocephalus probatocephalus for the northern form from Nova Scotia to Cedar Key on the west coast of Florida; A. probatocephalus oviceps Ginsburg (which is associated with muddy bottoms) in the Gulf of Mexico from St. Harks, Florida to the Campeche Bank; and A. probatocephalus aries from Belize to Bahia de Sepetiba, Brazil (Carpenter 2002).

The Chesapeake Bay Sheepshead population is suggested to constitute a separate population, as large differences in vital rates are often indicative of this. The differences observed in growth could arise due to a variety of factors, including differences in mortality rates, environmental conditions, food sources, or genetic variation (Ballenger et al. 2007).

Frequency distributions of each of five meristic counts are significantly different between the subspecies found in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico: A. probatocephalus probatocephalus and A. probatocephalus oviceps (P < 0.05). However, Bayesian structure analysis of microsatellite genotypes indicated that all Gulf of Mexico Sheepshead populations constitute a single stock.Variance partitioning of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) haplotypes suggests significant but limited divergence between subspecies (genetic differentiation index FST = 0.036, P < 0.005). Molecular data from North American subspecies of  Sheepshead indicate very limited genetic subdivision between the subspecies despite considerable divergence of morphological characters. Genetic structure is defined primarily by the geographic distance between sampling locales from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic. Overall, Sheepshead molecular genetic data indicate very limited genetic subdivision between the subspecies despite considerable divergence of morphological characters (Anderson et al. 2008).
Acanthopagrus omanensis is a new species illustrated and described from two specimens (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2010).
Acanthopagrus taiwanensis is recently described on the basis of six specimens that were previously misidentified as A. berda (Forsskål 1775) (Iwatsuki and Carpenter 2006).

This species was recently assigned in the genus Sparidentex (Kume and Yoshino 2008, Iwatsuki and Carpenter 2006), but the genus Sparidentex from the Indo-West Pacific requires further review (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2010).

Argyrops spinifer may represent three unique species in the Arabian Gulf (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2013). Iwatsuki and Heemstra (2018) recently described A. flavops from Mutrah, Oman and Karachi, Pakistan and A. caeruleops from the Gulf of Oman, southern Oman, Socotra and Pakistan. Further study of additional specimens is required to determine the extent of their distributions in the western Indian Ocean/Arabian Seas region.

Two colour morphs of this species have been observed, and further taxonomic study is needed (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2009). A northern and southern population were originally both described as Acanthopagrus bifasciatus in the Indian Ocean. Iwatsuki and Heemstra (2011) determined that both populations were two valid species, the northern population (Red Sea to the Arabian Gulf) is described as A. bifasciatus, while the southern population (southern Oman to South Africa) is described as A. catenula (Lacepède 1801).

This species was previously misidentified as Dentex tumifrons. However, tumifrons is a senior synonym of Evynnis japonica, and the next available name for this species is hypselosomus (Iwatsuki et al. 2007).
This species was previously recognized as a subspecies of Pagellus bellottii. It is currently valid as Pagellus natalensis (Eschmeyer and Fricke 2009).

Genetic analysis of the geographical partitioning revealed that this species showed an Atlantic-Mediterranean partitioning (Patarnello et al. 2007) indicating that exchanges between subpopulations are reduced and may limit rescue effects from migration and dispersal from other subpopulations to compensate for impacts of direct exploitation.
This species is nested within Dentex in genetic studies (K. Carpenter pers. comm. 2011).
This species is frequently confused with Pachymetopon grande (Smith and Heemstra 1986).

There are numerous taxonomic studies that have been conducted for Acanthopagrus, with several species complexes identified, including, Black Seabream forms I-II and Yellowfin Seabream forms I-II (Iwatsuki 2013). 

The Acanthopagrus latus complex has recently been split to include five cryptic species: A. latus (distributed in east Asia), Acanthopagrus longispinnis (Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes 1830) (northern Gulf of Bengal Bay), and three new species, Acanthopagrus morrisoni, Acanthopagrus arabicus, and Acanthopagrus sheim. The five species can be distinguished from one another by the counts of dorsal-fin rays, pore lateral-line scales, scale rows between the fifth dorsal-fin spine base and lateral line, and other distinguishing morphological characteristics and body and fin coloration (Iwatsuki 2013).
The taxonomy of sea lions in New Zealand (Phocarctos) and Australia (Neophoca) was confused until it was resolved in a paper by King (1960).

Diplodus cervinus was previously recognized as comprising three subspecies: Diplodus cervinus cervinus (NE Atlantic and Mediterranean), D. c. hottentotus (SE Atlantic: Angola, South Africa), and D. c. omanensis (Indian Ocean: Oman). Currently, three species are recognized: D. cervinus, D. hottentotus (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004) and D. omanensis (Bauchot and Bianchi 1984, Amir et al. 2013). Diplodus hottentotus is now believed to be an endemic species occurring from Cape Point to Kosi Bay in South Africa (Smith and Heemstra 1986, Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). Diplodus hottentotus sensu strictu. However, the Diplodus cervinus complex is in need of taxonomic review (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2014).

The species D. hottentotus is the same species in southern Angola as it is along the eastern seaboard of southern Africa. However, as with D. capensis, these populations have been separated for ~ two million years by the Benguela Current so can be treated as separate populations for management purposes (Bauchot and Bianchi 1984, Winkler 2013).

Diplodus cervinus was previously recognized as comprising three subspecies: Diplodus cervinus cervinus (NE Atlantic and Mediterranean), D. c. hottentotus (SE Atlantic: Angola, South Africa), and D. c. omanensis (Indian Ocean: Oman). Currently, three species are recognized: D. cervinus, D. hottentotus (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004) and D. omanensis (Bauchot and Bianchi 1984, Amir et al. 2013). However, the Diplodus cervinus complex is in need of taxonomic review (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2014).

The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

Most often, Spicara flexuosa has been confused with S. maena in identifications, and they are typically lumped in fisheries statistics and in markets. Spicara flexuosa is currently considered a synonym of S. maena (Pollard and Pichot 1972, Heemstra 1990, Bilecenoglu et al. 2002, Minos et al. 2012), although genetic studies using the mtDNA 16S rRNA gene are inconclusive. Recent genetic work by Imsiridou et al. (2011) indicates that there is a clear discrimination between the two species, and Minos et al. (2012) distinguished the two based on morphological differences.

However, Turan (2011) found genetic divergence to be only 0.005 and previous work by Arculeo et al. (1996) using protein electrophoresis found no discriminating genetic markers. Pending further taxonomic studies, we here continue to regard S. flexuosa as a synonym of S. maena (Pichot and Pollard 1970, Pollard and Pichot 1971, Pollard and Pichot 1972).

The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

In the past, specimens of softshell turtles collected from New Guinea were all originally assigned to what was considered to be a widespread Australasian species, Pelochelys bibroni (Owen 1853), until Rhodin et al. (1993) and Webb (1995) defined P. bibroni as being restricted to southern New Guinea, and separate from the previously described P. cantorii (Gray 1864) in the rest of Asia and northern New Guinea. Subsequently, Webb (2003) described the northern New Guinea softshell as the new species Pelochelys signifera. This taxonomy has been accepted since then (TTWG 2017). Pelochelys signifera was described largely based on characteristics of a juvenile specimen and coloration and texturing of the carapace to distinguish it from P. cantorii. No geographic variation has been reported within the species' range and no subspecies have been named. Phylogenetic relationships with P. cantorii and P. bibroni warrant further investigation.
WoRMS (2011) considers the species to be a synonym of Solen delesserti Sowerby, 1874.

Ambassis gymnocephalus was described as Lutjanus gymnocephalus by Lacepède (1802) from Indo-Pacific region. Although the species has been considered as valid by Day (1875), Talwar and Jhingran (1991) and Jayaram (1999), it is considered as 'nomen dubium' by Anderson and Heemstra (2003) because of the considerable taxonomic confusion and on the basis of the lack of diagnostic features. Further taxonomic studies, preferably involving molecular techniques, are essential.
Pomadasys argenteus was originally described as Sciaena argentea by Forsskål (1775) from Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, Red Sea.
The other names are as follows:  Melania riqueti, Thiara riqueti, Melanoider (Sermyla) riqueti.

The systematics of Tremoctopodidae was reviewed by Thomas (1977). He concluded that two species existed, T. violaceus, comprising the subspecies T. v. violaceus in the Atlantic Ocean and T. v. gracilis in the Pacific Ocean, and a new deep-water species T. gelatus Thomas, 1977.  O'Shea (1999) resurrected the New Zealand species, T. robsoni. Given that T. v. violaceus was no more different from T. robsoni than it was from T. v. gracilis, Mangold et al. (2008) elevated the two subspecies of T. violaceus to specific level.

The systematics of Tremoctopodidae was reviewed by Thomas (1977). He concluded that two species existed, T. violaceus, comprising the subspecies T. v. violaceus in the Atlantic Ocean and T. v. gracilis in the Pacific Ocean, and a new deep-water species T. gelatus Thomas, 1977.  O'Shea (1999) resurrected the New Zealand species, T. robsoni. Given that T. v. violaceus was no more different from T. robsoni than it was from T. v. gracilis, Mangold et al. (2008) elevated the two subspecies of T. violaceus to specific level.
The type locality is the Joseph Bonaparte Gulf, Western Australia at 14° 07.30' S, 28° 02.00' E (Sweeney 2012).

Collins (2005) notes that Opisthoteuthis borealis  females are rather difficult to distinguish. Most of the key characters are found on mature males and females could be confused with O. massyae females as both species possess a bilobed digestive gland. The arm sucker count is generally greater in O. massyae. The type locality of O. borealis is 63°10’N 54°14’W.
This species was described in 2002 by Villanueva, Collins, Sanchez and Voss.  Many specimens from the Eastern Atlantic were previously attributed to Opisthoteuthis agassizii.
Until recently, this species was only known from the holotype. The type locality is at 53°18'S, 42°12'W (off South Georgia).

This species was described as Grimpoteuthis challengeri Collins, 2003 from a series of specimens taken from hauls on the Porcupine Abyssal Plain in the Northeast Atlantic. The type locality is 48°56'N, 15°45'W at depths of 4,828–4,838 m. A further specimen is known from the northwest Atlantic although precise co-ordinates are not available.

This species was described as Grimpoteuthis discoveryi Collins 2003 from a series of specimens captured in the North East Atlantic. The type locality is in the Porcupine Seabight, 49°35'N, 14°01'W, 4,190–4,255 m.

This species is known from a single, well-preserved specimen taken from a trawl in the Eastern North Atlantic, Porcupine Seabight, 49°54 N, 12°21 W at 2,274-2,300 m water depth. This species is the type of the genus Cryptoteuthis by monotypy.
Originally described as Luteuthis shuishi O'Shea and Lu, 2002, this species is known only from a single specimen. The type locality is 19° 30.1’N, 114° 09.8’E at water depths of 754-767 m.

Members of Asperoteuthis can easily be misidentified as Grimalditeuthis if they have lost their tentacles (Young and Roper 2008).  Asperoteuthis acanthoderma, A. mangoldae, A. sp. B and A. lui and A. nesisi belong to the genus Asperoteuthis (Young and Roper 2008) but A. sp. B is probably a junior synonym of A. nesisi (Arkhipkin and Laptikhovsky 2008).  Asperoteuthis lui is known from a single damaged specimen.

Members of Asperoteuthis can easily be misidentified as Grimalditeuthis if they have lost their tentacles (Young and Roper 2008). Asperoteuthis acanthoderma, A. mangoldae, A. sp. B and A. lui and A. nesisi belong to the genus Asperoteuthis (Young and Roper 2008) but A. sp. B is probably a junior synonym of A. nesisi (Arkhipkin and Laptikhovsky 2008).
Its wide geographic distribution and morphological variation between individuals collected from different regions both suggest more than one species is present (Roper and Young 2009).
Given its wide geographic distribution and morphological variation between regions it is likely that more than one species is present (Roper and Young 1999).
This species has never been fully described. A redescription is essential.

Recently two subspecies have been described. Berryteuthis magister nipponensis occurs in the waters around northern Japan, and B. magister shevtsovi occurs in the Sea of Japan between 200 and 600m in depth (Kubodera 2006a; Kubodera 2006b).
This species is only known from a small number of specimens and mature animals have never been captured.
Only 25 specimens are known from this poorly understood species.
Unfortunately, identification problems with this species mean that it is not clear which records are valid.
This species is known only from four immature specimens.
This is one of the most taxonomically confused families of squid.
This is one of the most taxonomically confused families of squid.  M. tyroi is only known from paralarvae.  They probably represent the juvenile form of another known species of Mastigoteuthis.

Independent molecular markers suggest A. javanicus includes two species: the first occurring in Thailand, West and East Malayia, North Sumatra and Riau, the second in Jambi and South Sumatra, Java and Kalimanatan (Sanders et al. in review).
Naso lituratus was observed to be actively hybriding with N. elegans at Cocos-Keeling (J.H. Choat pers. comm. 2010, Klanten 2003).
There was a significant level of genetic structure observed between North and South Atlantic populations, suggesting limited dispersal across the Amazon barrier (Rocha et al. 2002).

This species is a member of the Acanthurus achilles species complex known for their propensity to hybridize (Randall and Frische 2000). The four species in this complex (A. achilles Shaw, A. japonicus Schmidt, A. leucosternon Bennett, and A. nigricans Linnaeus) are thought to hybridize when their distributional ranges overlap (Craig 2008).
There is strong geographical pattern in the genetic structure of Acanthurus triostegus throughout the tropical Pacific but this does not warrant species recognition (Planes and Fauvelot 2002).

Acanthurus chronixis is a close relative of Acanthurus pyroferus, sharing the count of VIII dorsal spines and the same morphology, in particular the protruding snout (Randall 2001a).  Its taxonomic status is uncertain due to limited number of specimens. There is taxonomic work underway to determine the status of this species. We accept current taxonomy that this species is valid (Eschmeyer 2011, J.E. Randall pers comm. 2011).

Acanthurus nigricans is a member of the A. achilles species complex known for their propensity to hybridize (Randall and Frische 2000). The four species in this complex (A. achilles Shaw, A. japonicus Schmidt, A. leucosternon Bennett, and A. nigricans) are thought to hybridize when their distributional ranges overlap (Craig 2008). Hybrids have been recorded from the Hawaiian Islands (Acanthurus achilles x nigricans), Taiwan (Acanthurus japonicus x nigricans), Indonesia, Christmas and Cocos Island (Acanthurus leucosternon x nigricans) (Randall 2001a, Marie et al. 2007).

Naso unicornis is widespread throughout the Indo-Pacific region, genetic studies conducted by Horne et al. (2008) did not find any evidence of geographic population structure even at the largest spatial scales.

This species is a member of the Acanthurus achilles species complex known for their propensity to hybridize (Randall and Frische 2000). The four species in this complex (A. achilles Shaw, A.japonicus Schmidt, A.leucosternon Bennett, and A.nigricans) are thought to hybridize when their distributional ranges overlap (Craig 2008).

Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) survey reveal strong separation between the Brazilian and Carribean provinces, and no significant population structure across the oceanic gap separating Brazil and the mid-Atlantic ridge. The genetic differences between the Brazilian and Carribean populations is matched by colour differences: in the North Atlantic, individuals show a distinguishing arrow, bluish posterior margin on the caudal and dorsal fins, whereas in the South Atlantic, individuals have a bright yellow margin (Rocha et al. 2002). Morphological and genetic data indicate that Acanthurus bahianus is now split into two species: Acanthurus tractus, which is distributed in the northwestern Atlantic and  A. bahianus distributed from eastern Brazil to Ascension and St. Helena Islands (Bernal and Rocha 2011).
Acanthurus sohal is closely related to the Indo-Pacific species Acanthurus lineatus (Alwany et al. 2005).

Naso brevirostris is widespread throughout the Indo-Pacific region, genetic studies conducted by Horne et al. (2008) did not find any evidence of geographic population structure even at the largest spatial scales.
This species hybridizes with Acanthurus nigricauda in the Marshall Is. and A. tennentii in Bali (Randall 2001a).
[ probably represents 2 different species (K.E. Carpenter pers. comm. 2012) [ check back on the paper with published taxonomic revision]
Acanthurus tennentii hybridizes with A. olivaceus in Bali, Indonesia (Randall 2001a).
Hybrids of Acanthurus trisis with A. pyroferus were observed in Bali, Indonesia (Randall 2001a).

Acanthurus nigroris is an endemic species in the Hawaiian Islands and Johnston Atoll,  Acanthurus nigros is valid for the species elsewhere in Oceania and the Great Barrier Reef. The genetic analyses, based on mtDNA cytochrome b sequences from a total of 544 Acanthurus nigroris samples, revealed a clear separation (d = 0.041) between individuals from the Hawaiian Archipelago and the rest of the Pacific indicating a cryptic species pair (Randall et al. submitted manuscript, DiBattista et al. 2011).

This species is a member of the Acanthurus achilles species complex known for their propensity to hybridize (Randall and Frische 2000). The four species in this complex (A. achilles Shaw, A.japonicus Schmidt, A.leucosternon Bennett, and A.nigricans) are thought to hybridize when their distributional ranges overlap (Craig 2008).

Acanthurus cf. leucosternon, a hybrid between A. leucosternon and A. nigricans has been recognized from the Cocos Keeling and Christmas Islands (Marie et al. 2007).
Zebrasoma rostratum hybridizes with Z. scopas. Taxonomic status is unkown (L. Rocha pers comm. 2010).
Zebrasoma scopas hybridizes with Z. flavescens and Z. rostratum (Randall 2001a).
A. nigricauda x olivaceous hybrids have been observed in the Marshall Islands (Randall 2001a).
Ctenochaetus flavicauda is closely related to C. cyanocheilus (K.D. Clements pers. comm. 2010).
Hybrids of this species and A. tristis have been observed in Bali, Indonesia (Randall 2001a).

Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). There are four valid species present in the Gulf of Mexico as of January 2014: E. altivelis, E. boehlkei, E. jordani, and E. pectoralis, and these have been assessed as currently valid.

Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). There are four valid species present in the Gulf of Mexico as of January 2014: E. altivelis, E. boehlkei, E. jordani, and E. pectoralis, and these have been assessed as currently valid. Victor (2013) provides a taxonomic revision of this species.

Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). There are four valid species present in the Gulf of Mexico as of January 2014: E. altivelis, E. boehlkei, E. jordani, and E. pectoralis, and these have been assessed as currently valid.

Ophiclinops pardalis appears to be the sister species of O. hutchinsi, with which it shares generally high counts for meristic characters, a large maximum size, and similarity of colour pattern. Ophiclinops hutchinsi is known only from Western Australia while O. pardalis is known only from eastern Australia. These two species should be synonymized when specimens at localities between the two areas of known distribution are examined and if the populations have intermediate fin-ray and vertebral counts between O. hutchinsi and O. pardalis. (George and Springer 1980, Gomon et al. 1994).
This species is described in the genus Pavoclinus, however it should probably be placed in a new genus (W. Holleman pers. comm. 2010).

Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). There are four valid species present in the Gulf of Mexico as of January 2014: E. altivelis, E. boehlkei, E. jordani, and E. pectoralis, and these have been assessed as currently valid.
A sibling species is known from Langebaan, but has yet to be named and published (W. Holleman pers. comm. 2010).

Ophiclinops hutchinsi appears to be the sister species of O. pardalis, with which it shares generally high counts for meristic characters, a large maximum size, and similarity of colour pattern. Ophiclinops hutchinsi is known only from Western Australia while O. pardalis is known only from eastern Australia. These two species should be synonymized when specimens at localities between the two areas of known distribution are examined and if the populations have intermediate fin-ray and vertebral counts between O. hutchinsi and O. pardalis. (George and Springer 1980, Gomon et al. 1994).
Tripterygion tripteronotum was split into two distinct species, T. tripteronotum and T. tartessicum, based on genetic and morphological characteristics (Carreras-Carbonell et al. 2007).
Molecular work indicates that there is no separation between the Australian species from the New Zealand species, and both are regarded as the same (Hoese, D.F. in prep.).
There are two undescribed sibling species, one from False Bay and the second from just east of False Bay (W. Holleman pers.comm. 2010).

Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). There are four valid species present in the Gulf of Mexico as of January 2014: E. altivelis, E. boehlkei, E. jordani, and E. pectoralis, and these have been assessed as currently valid.
This species is possibly a synonym of Holothuria parvula. Rowe (1969) places this species in synonymy with H. difficilis.
This species may be a hybrid between B. argus and B. marmorata (Kim et al. 2009).
A synonym for this species is Platyperona rowei.
This species can hybridize with Holothuria mexicana. The hybrids are viable and difficult to differentiate.
The type-taxon for this species is Roweothuria (WoRMS 2010).
This species may also be known as Holothuria ludwigi.
This species was known as Stichopus variegatus (Rasolofonirina pers comm. 2010), which is now synonomized under S. horrens.
This species has several synonyms: Stichopus kefersteini, Holothuria inornata, Ludwigothuria kefersteini, Holothuria (Halodeima) kefersteini, Holothuria (Paraholothuria) riojai.
Previously known as Bohadschia graeffei (Conand 2008).
Holothuria scabra and H. scabra var. versicolor (now H. lessoni) have recently been properly identified as distinctive species (Uthicke et al. 2005).
Halodeima surinamensis and Semperothuria surinamensis may be other names for this species.
This species is also known as Molpadiodemas involutus.
This species is also known as Pseudostichopus atlanticus in the literature (Hansson 2001, Briggs 1985).
This species has a subgenus, Platyperona.
The taxonomy of this species is not certain over much of its supposed range.
Previously known as Holothuria scabra var. versicolor.
This species may be confused with Labidodemas semperianum.
This species may also be known as Holothuria mollis and Stichopus simulans.
This species is often mistaken for Holothuria arenicola.
This species is sometimes mistaken for L. semperianum (Samyn et al. 2005).
This species is in possible synonymia with Holothuria tubulosa (Borrero-Perez et al. 2009). Gustato and Villari 1979 established there are two species clearly identified in Naples.
Also known as Pseudostichopus villosus (Théel, 1886) (O'Lough and Ahearn 2005).
In many reports this species is spelled as Holothuria polii. A synonym is Muelleria parvula.
This species used to be identified as Panningothuria forskali. Other possible synonyms are H. catanensis, H. nigra, and Stichopus selenkae.

Clark, H.L. (1922) erected the genus Parastichopus with as main characteristic the presence of Thelenota-like dichotomous branching rods. This is a characteristic of the species regalis and tremulus. According to this fact, Rowe (unpublished data) put regalis and tremulus in the genus Parastichopus, in contrast to Cutress & Miller (1982), who included regalis in the genus Eostichopus.

Holothuria murrayi, Mesothuria murrayi are synonyms for this species (Solis-Marin 2003).
This species is better known as Capheira sulcatus (Sluiter, 1901).
This species is also known as Sticopus macroparentheses.
A taxonomic revision of this species is recommended, because it was collected only once in the 19th century (Alvarado pers. comm. 2010).
Uthicke et al. (2004) by genetic analysis differentiated H. whitmaei, H. fuscogilva and H. nobilis, which were previously confused.
This species was known as Platyperona sanctori (WoRMS). Other synonyms include H. farcimen.
The taxonomy for this species is debated between the Atlantic and Pacific distributions (Hansen, 1956).
Australostichopus mollis was previously known as S. mollis.
There is one synonym for this species, B. rubipunctatus (Gutt 1991).
There are a few different morphs in the Africa and Indian Ocean region (Conand 2008) which may make correct identification of the species difficult.
There are two subspecies of Actinopyga obesa, entitled A. obesa obesa and A. obesa palauensi.
There is only one synonym known for this species, B. fuscivinculum (O'Loughlin 2002).

A critical review is needed, as there is some confusion with B. marmorata and B. tenuissima (Rasolofonirina pers. comm. 2010).

This species may be confused with B. subrubra (Conand 2008). Samyn et al. (2006) consider B. similis and B. vitiensis as synonyms of B. marmorata. Conand (2008) recommends the taxonomic revision of the whole genus Bohadschia.
This species has been recently described. It may be mistaken with Bohadschia argus (Samyn et al. 2006) and B. subrubra (Conand 2008).
This species may also be known as Mertensiothuria platei (Deichman 1958). There have been no specimens collected after 1958. This species is in need of a taxonomic review.
This species has three subspecies which are: A. serratidens agassizii, A. serratidens serratidens, and A. serratidens bannwarthi (Samyn et al. 2006).
The taxonomy of this species is not-well established.

A taxonomic review is in progress (Uthicke et al. 2010, and Byrne et al. 2010).

Conand (2008) suggests a taxonomic revision of S. monotuberculatus. In Réunion it was formerly known as S. horrens.
This species is recognized as Parastichopus parvimensis or Apostichopus parvimensis.
This species is a synonym of Vaneyothuria zacae (Diechmann 1958).
This species has a subgenus, Mertensiothuria.
This species may warrant a taxonomic revision (Alvarado pers. comm. 2010).
This species may be the same as Stichopus fuscus. This species was confused with I. badionotus.
Synonyms for this species are Holothuria marenzelleri var. theeli and Selenkothuria portovallartensis.
Bathyplotes bipartitus, Stichopus pourtalessi are synonyms of this species (WORMS database).
This species is also known as Australostichopus mollis.
This species is sometimes confused with Holothuria cubana (Deichmann 1930).
Conand (2008) recommends the taxonomic revision of the whole genus Bohadschia. Samyn et al. (2006) consider B. similis a synonym of B. marmorata.
This species is sometimes confused with Holothruia flavomaculata.
This species may also be known as Holothuria triremis.
Needs taxonomic revisióin based in Appeltans 2002.

Conand (2008) recommends the taxonomic revision of the whole genus Bohadschia. This species may be mistaken with B. subrubra and B. vitiensis (Conand 2008).

Samyn et al. (2006) consider B. similis and B. vitiensis as synonyms of B. marmorata.  Uthicke et al. (2010) states that B. vitiensis is not a synomym of B. marmorata. Clouse et al. (2005) redescribed this species from Micronesia, but its ecological traits are discongruent with the ecological traits of similar looking specimens from the South Pacific.
This species used to be called Holothuria axiloga.

There are two morphs (one is smaller by the coast that asexually reproduces, and another which is larger in outer reefs with no asexual reproduction) that were found to be genetically identical (Uthicke et al. 2010).
Apostichopus japonicus was formerly known as Stichopus japonicus.
This species was thought to be a synonym of H. difficilis (Rowe 1969) but Cherbonnier did not agree (1988).
Holothuria californica, Stichopus californicus, and Stichopus johnsonni may be synonyms for this species. Was previously confused with S. fuscus.
The Holothuria arenicola reported for the Caribbean may be a different species (Samyn et al. 2006). Current status of this species is likely to be a complex and taxonomic revision is needed.
Uthicke et al. (2004), by genetic analysis, differentiated H. whitmaei, H. fuscogilva and H. nobilis, which were previously confused.
This species is also known as Molpadiodemas villosus.
Fossothuria rigida may be another name for this species.
Halodeima stocki may be another name for this species.

Bathyplotes assimilis, Bathyplotes heterotilydes, Bathyplotes moseleyi, Bathyplotes ostergreni, Bathyplotes papillosus, Bathyplotes patagiatus, Holothuria natans, and Stichopus moseleyi are synonyms for this species (WORMs database). It can be confused with Bathyplotes fallax and with Bathyplotes pouratalesii. A taxonomic revision of this species is recommended (Borrero-Perez et al. 2003).
The species was confused with Meseres propiquus (Fisher)
One junior synonym Pseudostichopus (O'Loughlin and Ahearn 2005)
Synonyms for this species are Zygothuria lactea, Holothuria lactea, and H. aspera.
This species is easily confused with Holothuria surinamensis.

Stichopus levis, Stichopus oshimae and Stichopus herrmanni may be synonyms for this species.

Conand (2008) suggests a taxonomic revision of S. naso.
This species is also known as Stichopus cylindricus and Stichopus hirotai .
There is a taxonomic review in process (Uthicke et al. 2010, Byrne et al. 2010).
This species is possibly nomen dubium.
This species is morphologically similar to H. imitans, but the ossicle tables posses a higher number of spines on the border of the disk (Solis et al. 2009).
A synonym for this species is H. affinis.
Fossothuria cubana is a synonym of this species (Quinones 1981).
This species is formerly known as B. argus (see redescription in Massin et al. (1999)).
This species is part of a complex, and the taxonomy needs to be revised.
This species may also be known as Holothuria grammata and Stichopus grammatus.
This species may also be known by Holothuria curiosa pervicax, Holothuria depressa, Holothuria fuscocinerea pervicax, Holothuria mammiculata and Mertensiothuria pervicax .
A possible synonym for this species is Benthothuria valdiviae (Massin, from WoRMS).
In the Philippines this species may previously have been recorded as Actinopyga crassa or Actinopyga bannwarti (Samyn et al. 2006)
Synonyms for this species include Holothuria stellati dakarensis (Pawson et al. 2010).
Synonyms for this species are Fistularia mollis, Holothuria intestinalis, and Thyonidium scabrum.
Conand (2008) recommends the taxonomic revision of the whole genus Bohadschia. This species may be confused with B. atra.

Massin et al. (2009) distinguished this species from H. scabra and H. lessoni, but its identity as a separate species is known only from one specimen in Philippines.  H. lessoni is sometimes misidentified as H. aculeata.
This species may also be known as Theelothuria princeps. The synonym with H. imperator needs to be reviewed to see if they are different species.

Pellegrin and Chevey (1940) described a species of eye-less sole, Typhlachirus elongatus, based on two specimens collected from estuarine waters of the Mekong River. Subsequently, this species was reassigned to the genus Brachirus (Munroe 2000, Kottelat 2013). However, in a recent revision of the genus Typhlachirus, Evseenko and Bolshakov (2018) provided evidence that this species belongs in Typhlachirus. This taxonomic arrangement is followed herein.
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. It is a species complex consisting of at least three species.

Whitehead and Rodriguez (1998) consider the population of the Pacific coast of Baja California to be a different species, Anchovia magdalenae; however, this species is currently considered to be a synonym of A. macrolepidota in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2019). Therefore, for the purposes of this Red List assessment, all records of A. magdalenae will be considered to be A. macrolepidota.

This species has previously been identified as Gerres simillimus, however, G. simillimus occurs in the eastern Pacific (Robertson 2006) and Gerres cinereus in the western Atlantic is considered a distinct species.
The species limits are poorly defined with respect to other described taxa in this family, and they are in need of revision.
According to Ponder (1984) Iravadia reticulata is a synonym of Iravadia ornata Blanford, 1867, while Brandt (1974) treated both taxa as distinct species.

Brandt (1974) placed Rehderiella in the subfamily Rehderiellinae Brandt, 1974, however Davis (1979) noted it should belong in Pomatiopsidae but Bouchet and Rocroi (2005) could not allocate it to any of the current subfamilies
Brandt (1974) refers to the species as Fairbankia cochinchinensis.
Western Atlantic subpopulations are now recognized as a separate species (Ophioblennius macclurei).
The western Atlantic subpopulation was described as H. pseudoaequipinnis (Bath 1994).

Acanthemblemaria macrospilus, which formerly included A. hastingsi, was first described as a subspecies of A. hancocki by Brock (1940). Stephens (1963) elevated it to species and reported that its range included the Gulf of California, the coast of southwestern Mexico, Isla del Coco, and Islas Revillagigedo (Lin and Galland 2010). The Isla del Coco population was later described as A. atrata, and the Islas Revillagigedo population was described as A. mangognatha (Hastings and Robertson 1999).
Further taxonomic study is required to determine the status of the eastern Atlantic populations (J.T. Williams pers. comm. 2014).
Phylogenetic analysis has placed this species within the genus Eucinostomus (Chen et al. 2007).
This species was recently re-described following a split to Acyrtus lanthanum (Conway et al. 2014).
This may be a species complex of several species.
Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera, Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus zebrellus.
Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera: Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus dilepis.
Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera, Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus gemmatus.

Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera: Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus redimiculus (Taylor and Akins 2007).
Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera, Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus pallens.
Evermannichthys spongicola (Radcliffe, 1917) is a valid species that is present in the Western Central Atlantic (previously known as Garmannia spongicola).
This is likely a species complex (Bohlke and Robins 1969).
This species is very visually similar to G. brasilliensis, and they are often confused.

A revision of the Acyrtops genus is currently under way. Due to questions surrounding the validity of Acyrtops amplicirrus (a very similar species), the distribution of A. beryllinus is not clearly understood at this time (K. Conway pers. comm. 2015).
There are known taxonomic issues with this species; more than one undescribed species may be masquerading as A. quadrisquamatus.

There is some confusion surrounding the validity of this name, some workers consider Arcos nudus to be correct (replacing A. macrophthalmus), while Gobiesox cephalus should be applied to the western central Atlantic freshwater clingfish currently known as Gobiesox nudus (R. Robertson and K. Conway pers. comm. 2014).
Records outside of Brazil for A. tajasica may refer A. banana.

This species was originally described as Varicus imswe. There is still some confusion over the taxonomic limits of Chriolepis and Varicus in the western Atlantic. For this assessment we follow Smith et al. 2003.
This species is easily confused with Coryphopterus glaucofraenum and C. venezuelae.

This species is often confused with C. glaucofraenum and C. tortugae. Although genetically distinct, C. glaucofraenum and C. venezuelae are extremely similar (Baldwin et al. 2009). There are some unresolved taxonomic issues surrounding the synonimization of Coryphopterus bol (described from Puerto Rico in 2008) under C. venezuelae (Collette and Smith-Vaniz 2013).

This species is sometimes misidentified as Coryphopterus tortugae or C. venezuelae. Furthermore, although genetically distinct, C. glaucofraenum and C. venezuelae are extremely similar (Baldwin et al. 2009).
This species is easily confused with Coryphopterus hyalinus. Coryphopterus hyalinus and C. personatus are genetically distinct (Baldwin et al. 2009).
Older records of Coryphopterus in the western Atlantic may need to be verified as the genus has recently been revised (Baldwin et al. 2009).
Older records of Coryphopterus in the western Atlantic may need to be verified as the genus has recently been revised (Baldwin et al. 2009).
This species has been confused with C. fasciatus (Gilbert and Randall in Gilbert and Kelso 1971).
This species has been confused with Ctenogobius pseudofasciatus in the past (Gilbert and Randall 1979).
Colin (2010) recognized that this may be a species complex of three to five species. Victor (2014) described the Cayman form as E. cayman.

This species is positively known from Bahamas. The different colour morph in the Cayman Islands, believed to be an undescribed species (Colin 2010), is E. cayman (Victor 2014). For this assessment, we consider only the Bahamas distribution for this species.

Records of this species from Panama refer to Tigrigobius panamensis (Victor 2010). Records from Utila island (Honduras) refer to Tigrigobius rubrigenis (Victor 2010). Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera, Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species may be referred to in the literature as Elacatinus multifasciatus.
Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera, Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus macrodon.
Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera: Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus saucrus.
This is thought to be a species complex with two distinct colour morphs (Colin 2010).
This species is likely comprised of a complex of two (Colin 2010).
Elacatinus lobeli was previously misidentified as E. oceanops (Randall and Colin 2009).

Subpopulations from Trindade Island and Fernando de Noronha Archipelago, Brazil have been designated two new species, Elacatinus phthirophagus (Sazima, Carvalho-Filho & Sazima 2008) and Elacatinus pridisi (Guimarães, Gasparini & Rocha 2004).

This species is found in three colour morphs, a yellow-blue, a yellow and a white form which may represent three separate species (Colin 2010). The very similar cryptic species E. cayman has been confused with this species (Victor 2014).
Eleotris perniger has generally been reported as E. pisonis, but the latter is a continental South American species ranging only from southern Brazil to eastern Venezuela (Pezold and Cage 2002).

Unfortunately, members of the Eucinostomus genus are continually being misidentified. This species was once thought to occur in the eastern Pacific Ocean, but these specimens are now treated as E. dowii (Page et al. 2013). It may be conspecific with E. jonesi (Lee et al. 1980).
The name Eugerres awlae, which was once a synonym of E. plumieri, may be a different species. However, there is still some confusion on the validity and range of E. awlae.
The Atlantic and Pacific subpopulations are probably different species (M. Craig pers. comm. 2011).
This species is easily misidentified as Gobiosoma bosc.

This was formerly regarded as a species of Gobionellus. It is now know as the only species of Oxyurichthys in the Atlantic Ocean (Pezold and Larson 2015).
The species is valid. One of the paratypes (the cleared and stained one) may be a different species (J. Van Tassell pers. comm. 2011).
This species is valid, however, the genus may not be monophyletic.

Taxonomic relations between P. helenae and P. randalli need further clarification with sampling and barcoding of specimens from a range of sites in the Greater Caribbean (R. Robertson and B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015).
Western Atlantic species of this genus are in need of revision (E. Murdy pers. comm. 2009, F. Pezold pers. comm. 2010).
This species was once considered widespread. A recent review split this species into multiple species (Willliams and Tyler 2003).

The taxonomy of species in the Mugilidae family is complex, and under revision (Durand and Borsa 2015). This species is commonly referred to as Valamugil seheli in the literature. According to Eschmeyer's Catalog of Fishes, it is now valid as Crenimugil seheli.
This species better and correctly known as Yongeichthys nebulosus (H.K. Larson pers. comm. 2013).

This species was described as a species of Akysis in the A. pseudobagarius group from the Mekong delta in southern Viet Nam (Ng and Kottelat 1998). Ferraris (2007) subsequently assigned this species and all other members of the A. pseudobagarius group to the genus Pseudobagarius.
The Brazilian population is genetically distinct and is being described as a different species by a Brazilian group (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2010).

This species is restricted to the Coral Sea. Reports of this species from elsewhere (e.g. Fiji and Tonga) are now recognized as separate species belonging to the Pomacentrus philippinus complex (Allen et al. 2017).
Tang et al. (2021) assigned Stegastes aureus (Fowler 1927) to the genus Plectroglyphidodon based on extensive genetic analysis.

As currently understood, Dascyllus trimaculatus is considered to be widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific, with other members of the D. trimaculatus complex of species restricted in distribution: D. albisella, known only from the Hawaiian Islands; D. auripinnis, occuring in the Central Pacific at the Line, Phoenix, and Cook Islands; and D. strasburgi, known only from the Marquesas Islands, French Polynesia (Randall and Randall 2001, Bernardi et al. 2002, McCafferty et al. 2002). However, given the molecular evidence suggesting cryptic diversity among specimens identified as D. trimaculatus (e.g., Bernardi et al. 2001, 2002, 2003; Leray et al. 2010; Hubert et al. 2012, 2017) and the lack of clear genetic differentiation between specimens of D. albisella and D. trimaculatus (McCafferty et al. 2002), further work is needed to clarify the species limits and nomenclature within the genus Dascyllus (Tang et al. 2021).

Dascyllus albisella is a sister species to Dascyllus trimaculatus (Mundy 2005). According to McCafferty et al. (2002), no genetic difference was found between these two species. However, no taxonomic recommendation was made, so the taxonomic question remains unresolved (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2002).

There are colour differences between specimens collected from the Indian Ocean and those collected in the Pacific Ocean (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2010). Further studies are required to determine if the specimens collected from these two regions represent distinct species.

This species as previously recognized (Allen 1991, Allen and Erdmann 2012), represents a complex of closely related species that were recently described as valid taxa (Allen et al. 2015; 2017; 2018), including Chrysiptera burtjonesi (Solomon Islands), C. ellenae (Raja Ampat Islands, West Papua, Indonesia), C. maurineae (Cenderawasih Bay, West Papua, Indonesia), C. papuensis (Papua New Guinea), and C. uswanasi (Fakfak Peninsula, West Papua, Indonesia). The true C. oxycephala (sensu Allen et al. 2018) is known only from central Indonesia, the Philippines, and Palau.

Neopomacentrus xanthurus Allen and Randall 1981 is a secondary junior synonym of Dascyllus xanthurus Bleeker 1853 and is therefore invalid when both species are classified in Neopomacentrus. Thus, Fricke and Allen (2021) proposed Neopomacentrus flavicauda as the replacement name for Neopomacentrus xanthurus Allen and Randall 1981 when both taxa are classified in genus Neopomacentrus.
Tang et al. (2021), based on molecular data, assigned Chromis bami Randall & McCosker 1992 to the genus Pycnochromis, but this change has not yet been accepted by Fricke et al. (2021).
This species was assessed formerly under the name Pomacentrus trichourus. However, this name was not universally used, and it has been changed here to P. trichrourus.

This species is one of the four species in the Dascyllus trimaculatus complex (Randall and Randall 2001). The separation of D. auripinnis and D. trimaculatus was clarified via nuclear and mitochondrial DNA analyses, but these species may hybridize where they occur sympatrically in the northern Cook Islands (Leray et al. 2010).

Randall et al. (1981) considered Chromis miyakeensis, described from the Izu Islands, Japan, to be a subspecies of C. notata. Other authors (e.g., Allen 1991) consider C. miyakeensis to be a junior synonym of C. notata.

As currently understood, Dascyllus reticulatus is considered to be widely distributed in the eastern Indian Ocean and western Pacific Ocean, with other members of the D. reticulatus complex of species more restricted in distribution: D. marginatus, known only from the Red Sea; D. carneus, occurring in the Indian Ocean; and D. flavicaudus, known only from French Polynesia (Randall and Allen 1977, McCafferty et al. 2002). However, given the molecular evidence suggesting specimens identified as D. reticulatus fall into two separate clades (McCafferty et al. 2002), further work is needed to clarify the species limits and nomenclature within the genus Dascyllus (Tang et al. 2021). 

Along the Great Barrier Reef, Australia, a hybrid between D. reticlatus and D. aruanus has been reported and confirmed (He et al. 2019).

This species was previously considered as widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific; however, Allen and Erdmann (2020) recognized Pycnochromis pacifica as a valid species in the Pacific Ocean and P. agilis is now restricted to the western Indian Ocean.
Pycnochromis vanderbilti Fowler 1941 was later assigned to the genus Chromis, but Tang et al. (2021), based on molecular data, reassigned this species to the genus Pycnochromis.
Tang et al. (2021), based on molecular data, assigned Chromis lineata Fowler and Bean 1928 to the genus Pycnochromis.
Ongoing genetic studies indicate that this species belongs to another genus, as of yet undetermined (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2010).
This species as currently defined most likely represents two species: an Indian Ocean form and a west Pacific form (Allen pers. comm. 2010).
Tang et al. (2021), based on molecular data, assigned Chromis retrofasciata Weber 1913 to the genus Pycnochromis.

Allen and Erdmann (2012) determined that specimens previously identified as Neoglyphidodon thoracotaeniatus from Palau, Papua New Guinea, and the Solomon Islands belong to a separate species, which they named N. mitratus.

Borsa et al. (2014) resurrected the name Dascyllus abudafur (Fabricius 1775) for the Indian Ocean population of this species based on very slight differences in the cyt-b gene. However, there is overwhelming evidence based on analysis of the CO1 gene from numerous localities  across the Indo-Pacific that this population is homogenous, and consequently, we recognize a single species (G. Allen pers. comm. 2021).

Along the Great Barrier Reef, Australia, a hybrid has been reported and confirmed between D. aruanus and D. reticlatus (He et al. 2019).
This species was formerly classified in the genus Chrysiptera, but a detailed genetic analysis of the Pomacentridae (Tang et al. 2021) revealed that it belongs to Amblypomacentrus.

Genetic studies are being undertaken to determine whether specimens from the Philippines, which have a colour pattern distinct from specimens collected elsewhere in the Coral Triangle, represent a distinct species (Allen and Erdmann 2012, G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2021).

Unlike nearly all other members of the family, this species has non-pelagic larvae.  Therefore, many isolated geographic populations exist.  Genetic data indicates a complexity of populations and subpopulations.  Populations separated by as little as 30 km may have drastically different color patterns.  Currently, only a single species is recognized but future genetic/morphological data may result in several valid species.
This species has been sometimes confused with Amphiprion latifasciatus (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2010).

Rivas (1960) considered Stegastes otophorus (Poey 1860) a junior synonym of S. leucostictus (Müller & Troschel 1848), but Topp (1970) redescribed S. otophorus as a valid species (Garrido and Varela 2011) and both species are considered valid in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer 2015).

The Pomacentrus amboinensis complex currently comprises four species: P. amboinensis Bleeker 1868, widely distributed in the eastern Indian Ocean and western Pacific Ocean; P. andamanensis Allen, Erdmann and Ningsih 2020, known only from the Andaman Sea; P. bipunctatus Allen and Randall 2004, from Micronesia; and another putative member of the complex, P. spilotoceps Randall 2002, from Fiji and Tonga (Allen et al. 2020).

Tang et al. (2021), based on molecular data, assigned Premnas biaculeatus (Bloch 1790) to the genus Amphiprion. In addition, specimens from the Andaman Sea have distinct pale yellow bars. Thongtam na Ayudhaya et al. (2017) suggested that the different color patterns (yellow vs. white stripes) may represent two different species based on molecular analysis of specimens from both coasts of Thailand; however, more data are needed to verify the presence of two cryptic species.

This species was previously confused with Chrysiptera caesifrons Allen, Erdmann and Kurniashih 2015 from the southwestern Pacific and C. chrysocephala Manica, Pilcher and Oakley 2002 from the Philippines and South China Sea.
The Azores Chromis (Chromis limbata) was long considered the same species as the Mediterranean Damselfish (Chromis chromis) (Wirtz 1994).

Pomacentrus philippinus had previously been considered to be widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific (Allen and Erdmann 2012). However, specimens with distinct color patterns, corresponding to several divergent mtDNA lineages, have been identified as belonging to distinct species (Allen et al. 2017). Four new species have been described: Pomacentrus albiaxillaris, known only from Palau; P. flavoaxillaris, occurring in the Federated States of Micronesia; P. magniseptus, from Queensland, Australia; and P. nigriradiatus, from New Caledonia to Samoa (Allen et al. 2017).
Genetic studies are required to determine the status of the three geographic subpopulations of this species.
Tang et al. (2021), based on molecular data, assigned Chromis lepidolepis Bleeker 1877 to the genus Azurina.
Stegastes lividus is a Marquesan endemic and the species formerly referred to as S. lividus from the Indian Ocean to the central Pacific is now recognized as S. punctatus (Randall 2004, 2005).

This appears to be a hybrid "species" between Amphiprion chrysopterus and A. sandaracinos, but eggs are fertile, and it breeds with other hybrids as well as with back-crossing with parent species (Allen and Erdmann 2012, Gainsford et al. 2020).
Several colour morphs have been identified throughout its range, however, confirmation of specific status is awaiting genetic analysis (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2010).
Tang et al. (2021), based on molecular data, assigned Chromis ovatiformis Fowler 1946 to the genus Pycnochromis.
Although this species is usually listed as authored by Cuvier (in Cuvier & Valenciennes, 1830), the description of Glyphisodon melas is authored by Valenciennes (Kottelat 2013).
Along the Socotra Archipelago, Yemen, a possible hybrid has been reported between Dascyllus carneus and D. marginatus (DiBattista et al. 2015, He et al. 2019).

This species is genetically identical to Stegastes lubbocki and Stegastes sanctahelenae, however, there are consistent colour differences between those species and they will probably retain species recognition (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2010).

Based on genetic analyses, specimens previously identified as Stegastes variabilis collected from Brazil and the Caribbean represent two different species. Stegastes variabilis has been restricted to Brazil, and the widespread species that occurs elsewhere in the western Atlantic is now recognized as S. xanthurus originally described by Poey (1860) (Robertson and Van Tassell 2012, Smith-Vaniz and Jelks 2014, Souza et al. 2016).
Stegastes partitus shows weak genetic differentiation across the entire Caribbean basin (Hogan et al. 2012).
Genetic comparisons are required for the eastern and western subpopulations, which exhibit significant colour differences.
This species is sometimes confused with A. chrysopterus.
