Discernable genetic differentiation was documented between specimens collected in the Indian Ocean and those collected in the Pacific Ocean (Hubert et al. 2012, 2017; Tang et al. 2021). If this differentiation warrants recognition of two species, the Indian Ocean specimens may be referable to Plectroglyphidodon nitidus (Tang et al. 2021). Furthermore, specimens collected from the Hawaiian population have a very distinct colour pattern (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2010). More research is needed to determine the number and limits of species among the specimens currently identified as P. johnstonianus.

Based on a taxonomic review of the Chromis xanthura species group (Motomura et al. 2017), three species are recognized: Chromis xanthura (Bleeker 1854), from the eastern Indian and western and central Pacific Ocean; C. opercularis (Günther 1867), from the Indian Ocean; and C. anadema Motomura, Nishiyama & Chiba 2017, from the oceanic islands of the Pacific Ocean.
Chrysiptera parasema is a name that has been used for a complex of closely related species, including C. arnazae, C. giti, and C. hemicyanea, resulting in frequent mis-identifications.
Tang et al. (2021), based on molecular data, assigned Chromis margaritifer Fowler 1946 to the genus Pycnochromis.

Tang et al. (2021), based on molecular data, assigned Plectroglyphidodon lacrymatus (Quoy and Gaimard 1825) to the genus Stegastes, but this reassignment has not yet been accepted by Fricke et al. (2021). In addition, Hubert et al. (2012; 2017) documented genetic differences between specimens identified as P. lacrymatus collected in the Indian Ocean and those collected in the Pacific Ocean. However, more work is needed to determine whether these differences warrant the recognition of more than one species (see Tang et al. 2021). The genetic evidence presented in Tang et al. (2021) is sufficient to support the reassignment of this species to the genus Stegastes (G. Allen pers. comm. 2021).
Along the Socotra Archipelago, Yemen, a possible hybrid has been reported between Dascyllus carneus and D. marginatus (DiBattista et al. 2015, He et al. 2019).

Rivas (1960) considered Stegastes otophorus (Poey 1860) a junior synonym of S. leucostictus (Müller & Troschel 1848), but Topp (1970) redescribed S. otophorus as a valid species (Garrido and Varela 2011) and both species are considered valid in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer 2015).

This species is genetically identical to Stegastes sanctahelenae and Stegastes pictus, however, there are consistent colour differences between those species and they will probably retain species recognition (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2010).
The population from Cenderawasih Bay, West Papua (Indonesia), may be a separate species on the basis of genetic evidence.
Chromis viridis is easily confused with Chromis atripectoralis.

Stegastes uenfi was described from the coast of southeastern Brazil, but its diagnostic characters are within the range of Stegastes fuscus. Moreover, genetic studies indicate no difference between these two species. Rocha et al. (in prep.) suggest that S. uenfi is a junior synonym of S. fuscus, but it is currently considered a valid species (Fricke et al. 2021).

Hubert et al. (2012, 2017) documented genetic differences between specimens identified as Plectroglyphidodon phoenixensis collected in the Indian Ocean and those collected in the Pacific Ocean. However, more work is needed to determine whether these differences warrant the recognition of more than one species (see Tang et al. 2021).

This species was previously referred to as Paraglyphidodon behnii by Allen (1975). There are two forms: the long-tailed form that is black as adults occurs in the Andaman Sea, east to western Bali, and north to Japan. The second form, possibly valid as N. xanthurus, occurs in the rest of the West Pacific; the two forms overlap in range on Bali's north coast (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). However, further work is needed to determine whether the two forms are sufficiently distinct to be recognized as separate species.
This species has been confused with Amphiprion allardi (e.g., Fautin and Allen 1992).
The eastern Atlantic population is genetically distinct from that in the western Atlantic, but the distinction is below the species level (Rocha et al. 2008).
Specimens from Fiji and Tonga were determined to be genetically distinct from specimens of Pomacentrus moluccensis (Drew and Barber 2009) and were described by Allen and Drew (2012) as P. maafu.
Preliminary genetic studies indicate that this species exhibits several distinct subpopulations and will likely be split in the near future (G. Allen pers. comm. 2021).
Tang et al. (2021), based on molecular data, assigned Chromis acares Randall and Swerdloff 1973 to the genus Pycnochromis.

Allen and Emery (1985) recognized three distinct subpopulations within the nominal Stegastes fasciolatus (Ogilby 1889). Randall (2005, 2007) indicated that each of these subpopulations should be recognized as a distinct species, with S. fasciolatus senso stricto restricted to the eastern Indian Ocean and western central Pacific Ocean (excluding Hawaii). Randall (2007) resurrected Stegastes marginatus, known only from the Hawaiian Islands and Fricke et al. (2009) resurrected S. luteobrunneus, occurring in the Indian Ocean (including the Cocos-Keeling Islands). The status of the three species was further validated by the genetic analysis of Tang et al. (2021), who also demonstrated they should be included in the genus Plectroglyphidodon.
This species is commonly confused with Sepia mestus Gray, 1849 and Sepia rozella (Iredale, 1926).
This species appears to be part of the Sepia pharaonis species complex (Anderson et al. 2011).
This species is only known from two specimens.

This species is known from three  specimens, the largest of which is 33.8 mm ML (holotype). The  holotype is a female missing tentacles as is the second paratype. The  first paratype is a male known from only the head and brachial crown (Lu and Young 2007).
Clinus arborescens was formerly a variety of Clinus supercilious (Holleman 2012, Patzner et al. 2009).
Fricke (1997, 2005) placed E. pallidus into synonym with E. pusillus, but this synonymy is invalid (Holleman 2005).

Previously, this species has been treated as a synonym of Ruanoho decemdigitatus. However, molecular work (e.g. Hickey and Clements 2005, Feary et al. 2009) and ecological studies (Wellenreuther et al. 2008) prove that it is a valid species.
Clinus ornatus was formerly a variety of Clinus supercilious. It has recently been elevated to species (Holleman 2012).

Two subspecies are recognized: Strongylura notata notata (Poey, 1860) from Cuba, Jamaica, Mexico, Belize, and Honduras and Strongylura notata forsythia Breder, 1932 from the Bahamas, Florida Keys, and southern Florida (Collette 2002).
The species was listed in the genus Notarius by Betancur-R. et al. (2007). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Three distinct lineages of this species have been identified through mitochondrial DNA analysis: 1) a northern type found from the Carolinas south to the Florida Keys, and off Panama City, Florida; 2) a southern form found in the Florida Keys, Yucatan, Belize and Puerto Rico; and 3) a third found exclusively in Trinidad (Chapman et al. 1999).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Genetic analysis revealed no difference between three similar Atlantic species, C. rostrata (Bloch), C. figueiredoi Moura & Castro, and C. supramacula Moura & Castro (L.A. Rocha, unpublished data).

In a study focusing on Colomesus pufferfishes, Amaral et al. (2013) produced evidence suggesting that Sphoeroides pachygaster be excluded from Sphoeroides based on the few species of that genus that this study sampled; further comparative investigations on the molecular and morphological features of all Sphoeroides spp. is highly desirable.
The status of this species is not certain as it is known from three specimens collected in poor condition, and may be synonymous with the more widespread species, C. guineensis (McCosker 1998).
This species may be confused with Sciades couma, although it is much more frequent than S. couma.
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).
Based on various rationale, the proper name is Genyatremus cavifrons, not G. luteus (Tavera et al. 2011).
The taxonomy of H. bonariense requires review.
The possibility that a subspecies exists is likely as the population in the Gulf of Mexico has significantly fewer vertebrae than those in the Caribbean (D. Smith pers. comm. 2015).

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001).

Albula nemoptera may eventually be split into Atlantic and Pacific species, pending the outcome of ongoing investigations (Bowen et al. 2008).
Further study is needed to clarify the differences between this species and U. lepturus (Richardson) from the Indo-West Pacific.
Polydactylus oligodon is difficult to distinguish from P. virginicus (Feltes 2002, B. Smith-Vaniz and R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).
This species presents a superficial ressemblance to Facciolella oxyrhyncha.

This species is recorded here as Ariopsis felis (following Betancur et al. 2007, and Page et al. 2013). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).
This species is only known from the holotype.

Holotype Natural History Museum, London, BMNH 20070615. Maturing female, 363 mm ML, with short stumps of both tentacles; 53°44'S 58°46'W, collected by Falkland Islands R/V Dorada pelagic trawl fishing near-bottom, 913 m depth off northern part of Burdwood Bank, Southwest Atlantic, 20 July 2005.  Members of Asperoteuthis can easily be misidentified as Grimalditeuthis if they have lost their tentacles (Young and Roper 2008).  Asperoteuthis acanthoderma, A. mangoldae, A.sp. B and A. lui and A. nesisi belong to the genus Asperoteuthis (Young and Roper 2008) but A. sp. B is probably a junior synonym of A. nesisi (Arkhipkin and Laptikhovsky 2008).
This species may be a junior synonym of P. levimana.

The paralarvae of the genus have a very distinctive appearance. The  paralarva has a very long, slender brachial pillar and a pointed tip to the gladius. Paralarvae of Leachia were originally placed in the genus Pyrgopsis and are now often referred to as pyrgopsis paralarvae (Young and Mangold 2007).  This species may be a species complex according to Voss et al. (1992).

This species was considered a junior synonym of Megalocranchia abyssicola, but given the considerable distance between the type localities (M. abyssicola from the Maldives, M. fisheri from Hawaii) they are unlikely to be synonymous.

Pholidoteuthis boschmai is the junior synonym of P. massyae (Vecchione and Young 2007). This species currently has a worldwide distribution, however, specimens from different oceans have not been closely compared so more than one species may exist (Vecchione and Young 2007).
ZMB Holotype Moll.-111000, female, ML 380 mm, 16<sup>o</sup>N, 18<sup>o</sup>07'W.
This species is known from only two specimens.  The holotype is BMNH 20080519.  The type locality is 45<sup>o</sup>43.2'S 59<sup>o</sup>56.6'W at a depth of 733 to 784m.
The type locality is 26°20'N, 19°21'W, Eastern Atlantic just south of the Canary Islands.  The taxonomic status of this species, which is only known from four specimens, is not clear.
The type locality is off the Cape of Good Hope, Atlantic Ocean (Sweeney 2012).
No type locality was designated for this species (Sweeney 2012).
The type locality is off the Bahamas. The holotype is in the Smithsonian USNM817134.
The type locality is in the Mozambique Channel, at 19<sup>o </sup>49.0’ S, 36<sup>o </sup>5.0’ E (Sweeney 2012).
The holotype is housed in the National Museum of Natural Science, Taichung, Taiwan (NMNS 511-001).
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate and R. p. diegensis Berry, 1912.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle, 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle, 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle, 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested). Gleadall et al. (2010) place Benthoctopus magellanicus Robson 1930 in synonymy with this species.

This species can be distinguished from Lophogobius cristulatus by the lateralis (sensory pore) system (Bouchereau and Gros 2010). Lophogobius androsensis, currently considered a synonym of L. cyprinoides, should be further examined using the lateralis system and 18S RNA sequence (Bouchereau et al. 2010).
This genus is currently being studied using molecular techniques and many additional species are likely to be described and valid species may be redefined.
This species is sometimes confused with other goby species (Mendes et al. 2018).
There are two subspecies recognized: A. l. lyolepis from Bermuda, the Antilles and Brazilian islands, and  A. l. continentalis from the continental shore (Robertson and Van Tassell 2015).
This species was recently split into two with Floridichthys polyommus Hubbs 1936 retained along the Yucatan and F. carpio restricted to Florida (Page et al. 2013).
This species is in need of thorough revision and sometimes appears as 'Octopus' hongkongensis.

Elops saurus was recently split into two largely allopatric species, E. saurus and E. smithi (McBride et al. 2010). In Florida waters, E. saurus and E. smithi may occur sympatrically at early life stages, though this does not appear to persist into the adult stage (McBride and Horodysky 2004). Elops saurus and E. smithi can be differentiated by myomere or vertebral counts; the more northern E. saurus is characterized by a higher count while the more southern E. smithi exhibits a lower count (Smith 1989, McBride and Horodysky 2004, McBride et al. 2010). These phenotypic differences are corroborated by genetic data (McBride et al. 2010).

This species is believed by some to be an albinistic specimen of Conus textile Linnaeus, 1758 (www.schnr-specimen-shells.com). However, the species is known from a single beached specimen and is therefore likely not to be a valid species (G. Raybaudi and S. Veldsman pers. comm. October 2011).

There are three known subspecies for this species, C. suturatus suturatus, C. suturatus kashiwajimensis and C. suturatus sandwichensis (Röckel et al 1995).

C. suturatus kashiwajimensis has been accepted as a synonym of Conus magus but may still be found in the literature under C. kashiwajimensis (marinespecies.org).

C. suturatus sandwichensis is endemic to the Sandwich Islands in Hawaii. It has a less solid shell with a narrower final whorl, and the dorsum of its foot is white with brown specks (Röckel et al 1995).
First described as C. hayesi, but this name was preoccupied by a fossil cone, so the species was named C. brianhayesi.
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain.
Previously considered as a form of C. cancellatus (Kaicher, no date).
Subspecies: C. l. tropicensis. There is also a geographic subspecies in Gulf of Aden: C. subroseus.
C. blainvillei can be considered a more northern population of this species (Eritrea), and can be consistently differentiated (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).

authority: A. Adams in H & A Adams, 1854
taxonomicNotes:
Forms: C. p. sowerbii and C. p. bicolor.

Recently recognised as a distinct species from C. andremenezi (Biggs et al 2010).
Subspecies: C. r. simanoki
Forms: C. nahoniaraensis (da Motta 1986).
All Angolan endemics are placed under subgenus Varioconus.

Some populations along the eastern shores of S Vicente and along the south-western coast of the nearby island of Santa Luzia that were originally considered as C. murichae Röckel, Rolán & Monteiro, 1980, may need to be re-classified as C. lugubris (Monteiro et al 2004). However, this has not been confirmed and is not reflected in this assessment.

Two populations are known, one from Mauritius, the other from Réunion. The form from Réunion may be a separate species (E. Monnier pers. comm. October 2011), but has not yet been described formally. For the purpose of this assessment, both populations have been considered.
There are two subspecies: C. a. australis and C. a. gabryae Massilia, 1989. (Röckel et al. 1995)

Filmer classifies this species as valid, although makes a note that it may be a synonym of Conus milneedwardsi Jousseaume, 1894 (Filmer 2001).  This is confirmed by the World Register of Marine Species where it is accepted as such a synonym (Appeltans et al. 2011) from the WoRMS database. Further information about the protoconch is needed to establish its taxonomic status.
<span id="aphia_ct_source_151837">
There are two subspecies of this species; C. bullatus bullatus, and C. bullatus pongo (in Western Indian Ocean).
There is a possibility of hybridization between C. betulinus and C. figulinus (Röckel et al. 1995).
C. adonis has been suggested as a synonym of this species but it is also considered to represent a valid species (Higo et al. 2001).
Conus krabiensis is usually considered a synonym or form of Conus generalis, but may be a valid distinct species or a local race/form of C. maldivus.

There are two subspecies of this species based on differences in geographical location and shell morphology. Conus gradatulus gradatulus occurs from Cape Agulhas to Cape Recife in South Africa. Conus gradatulus patens occurs in deep water from Cape Agulhas west towards Namibia (Tenorio and Monteiro 2008). There is potentially a third subspecies, C. g. altispiratus (S. Veldsman pers. comm. October 2011).

There is still some debate over the validity of the Conus gradatulus subspecies as some taxonomists believe that the subspecies cannot be reliably separated based on its geographical and morphological characteristics (Tucker 2009).

For the purpose of this assessment, we adhere to Tenorio and Monteiro 2008. Any taxonomic changes, based on the ongoing taxonomic debate, are not going to affect the conservation status of this species or to the outcomes of any species divisions.

This species has two subspecies:
C. anemone anemone Lamarck, 1810
C. anemone novaehollandiae A. Adams, 1855  (Appeltans et al. 2011)

C. anenome probably represents a species complex which is reflected in the large number of synonyms which have been applied to this taxon.  Certainly further taxonomic resolution and research required on this complex and variable species.

C. novaehollandiae has been considered a synonym or subspecies of this species, however, its morphological distinct geographical range may mean a species differentiation, and for conservation purposes should be considered separate species.
It may represent a sub-adult stage of the species group represented by Conus smirna.
This is a recently described species but previously placed under C. praecellens (Adams 1854).

There are eight described subspecies of Conus textile: C. t. concatenatus Kiener, 1845; C. t.  dilectus Gould, 1850; C. t.  gloriamaris Perry, 1810; C. t.  panniculus Lamarck, 1810; C. t.  reteaureum Perry, 1811; C. t.  scriptus G. B. Sowerby II, 1858; C. t. tigrinus G. B. Sowerby II, 1858 and C. t. verriculum Reeve, 1843 (Appeltans et al 2011) from the WoRMS database.
Determined by Filmer to be a valid species (Filmer 2001), but disputed by Tucker who considers this species to be a synonym of Conus hyaena Hwass in Bruguière, 1792 (Appeltans et al. 2011).

There are three described subspecies of Conus striatus: C. s. chusaki da Motta, 1978, C. s. floridus G. B. Sowerby II, 1858, and C. s. subfloridus da Motta, 1985 as described in the WoRMS database (Appeltans et al. 2011).

Recently described subspecies: C. s. oahuensis (Tucker et al. 2011).

There are four known subspecies of this species; C. m. milneedwardsi , C. m. clytospira, C. m. lemuriensis, and  C. m. kawamurai (Rockel et al. 1995). However, C. m. kawamurai is now considered a valid species, C. kawamurai, and has not been considered as part of this assessment (G. Raybaudi and S. Veldsman pers. comm. October 2011).
Suggested synonym of Conus richardbinghami Petuch, 1993
This species is part of the C. colmani species complex and is in need of more taxonomic distinction.
The described subspecies are Conus muriculatus muriculatus, Conus muriculatus laevigata, Sowerby ii 1833 (Röckel et al. 1995).
There is one described subspecies of Conus coelinae (Crosse, 1858): Conus coelinae spiceri (Bartsch and Rehder, 1943) (Appeltans et al 2011) from the WoRMS database.

Determined by Filmer to be a valid species (Filmer 2001), but disputed by Tucker who considers this species to be a synonym of Conus insculptus, Kiener 1845 (Appeltans et al. 2011). Filmer also reports that Conus hypochlorus is a replacement name for Conus croceus Smith, A. E., 1861 (Filmer 2001).
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain and it may be a form of Conus sertacinctus Röckel 1986, but is recognized by Filmer as a valid species (Filmer 2007).
C. brettinghami and C.philippinensis are considered as subspecies or possibly synonyms.

authority: da Motta & Röckel in da Motta, 1982

taxonomicNotes: There are two subspecies, C.a. simplex and C.a. algoensis. There are two clinal variations of subspecies C. a. algoensis: C. a. form scitulus, C. a. form agulhasi.
Conus flamingo is listed as a synonym of this species, however current research shows that it is a separate species restriced to Florida (Petuch and Sargent 2011).

This species is considered a synonym of Conus inscriptus Reeve, 1845 (Appeltans 2011) from the WoRMS database. Here we consider it tentatively as a valid species, because it is known only from five specimens and is almost certainly a fully mature specimen and not a juvenile of Conus inscriptus (as in WoRMS).

The larva shell information is compatible with Conus janus from Madagascar (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).
Synonyms: C. edwardi, C. lapideus, and C. turritus.
Conus alainallaryi, listed as a synonym, is now considered to be a valid species restricted to the northern coast of Colombia (Coltro and Petuch pers. comm. 2011).

Conus moluccensis Kuster, 1838 has been divided into the subspecies C. m. moluccensis, C. m. marielae Rehder and Wilson, 1975 and C. m. vappereaui Monteiro, 2009 (Monteiro 2009, 2010; Rockel et al. 1995).

C. m. marielae Wilson, 1975 is a rare subspecies which has been collected in Polynesia and the Marquesas Islands (Monteiro 2010). C. m. vappereaui Monteiro, 2009 is known from Polynesia (Monteiro 2009).
As well as a typical form there are two other forms of this species: Form C. c. nigropunctatus and form C. c. morrisoni (Röckel et al. 1995) .
This species is related to the group Fumiconus, together with closest relative species C. lizarum, C. traversianus, and C. guidopoppei (Röckel et al. 1995).
C. daucus is included in a complex of species along with C. goajra, C. norai and C. vikingorum.
The holotype of this species is a juvenile.  It has been suggested that this species is a synonym of Conus sulcatus.
Described by Lan in 2002, but is considered possibly a juvenile of C. samiae.
Synonym Conus seychellensis may be a sub-species or local form (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).
There are two variants of this species: C. a. ammiralis and C. a. pseudocedonulli, Blainville 1818 (Appeltans et al. 2011).
There are two recognised forms, aurora and caffra.
C. millepunctatus is considered to be a form by some experts.
This species is related to the group Fumiconus, together with closest relative species C. lizarum, C. stocki, and C. guidopoppei. See RKK 95

Tucker considers this species a synonym of Conus mediterraneus Hwass in Bruguière, 1792, (Appeltans et al 2011) from the WoRMS database.  Filmer considers it a valid species (Filmer 2001).  This species has an exceptional number of synonyms and there may be more than one species within the complex.
Conus petricosus may be considered a synonym.
There are subspecies described: Conus mucronatus mucronatus and Conus mucronatus sibogae, Schepman, 1913 (Röckel et al. 1995).
Taxonomic issues may arise from the distinct supopulations of this species.
This species is closely related to C. brianhayesi (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. 2011).
Sometimes confused with C. broderipii.

Determined by Filmer to be a valid species (Filmer 2001), but disputed by Tucker who considers this species to be a synonym of Conus achatinus (Appeltans et al. 2011) from the WoRMS database.

This species is sometimes confused with C. decurtatus and C. striolatus.
This species is part of the C. colmani species complex and is in need of more taxonomic distinction.
There are two known subspecies for this species; C. aureus aureus and C. aureus paulucciae ( Röckel et al. 1995). For other authors C. paulucciae is considered a distinct species.
This species can be confused with C. flavidus due to its similar colouration and morphology.
This species has three subspecies: Conus biliosus biliosus Röding, 1798; Conus biliosus meyeri Walls, 1979 and Conus biliosus parvulus Link, 1807 (Appeltans et al. 2011)

There are three described subspecies:

Conus biraghii biraghii G Raybaudi, 1992.
Conus biraghii congruens Korn & Raybaudi Massilia, 1993
Conus biraghii omanensis Moolenbeek & Coomans, 1993.

This is the type species for genus Lilliconus.
Subspecies: C. r. tahitiensis

Conus nielsenae typhon Kilburn, 1965,  is considered to be a subspecies by Röckel et al. (1995). However, Filmer and Tücker consider it as a valid species (Filmer 2001; Appeltans et al. 2011). It may have another subspecies as determined by Tucker, Conus nielsenae reductaspiralis Walls, 1979, (Appeltans et al. 2011). However, Filmer and Singleton consider C. n. reductaspiralis as a valid species: Conus reductaspiralis (Filmer 2001, Singleton, 2009).

This species is part of a species complex including Conus reductaspiralis and C. thevenardensis.  It appears that this species is the eastern Australian member of the complex while the other two species are western Australian species.
This species is often been assigned to a variety of names under Conus nigropunctatus, C. achatinus, C. ranunculus, C. vinctus, and C. decurtatus.
This species should not be confused with Conus virgatus cumingii Reeve 1849, which is a Panamic Pacific species.

Determined by Filmer to be a valid species (Filmer 2001), but disputed by Tucker who considers this species to be a synonym of Conus anemone Lamarck, 1810 (Appeltans et al. 2011), also disputed by Morrison and Singleton who consider it as probably the northern form of C. anenome (H. Morrison pers comm 2011).
There are two subspecies of this species; C. circumactus circumactus and C. circumactus hammatus (Poppe and Poppe 2011).
One subspecies: C. excelsus nakayasui.
Subspecies: C. s. vicdani (Lan 1980).
The species can be confused with Conus cakobaui due to its similar colouration (Moolenbeek et al. 2008).
C. fasciatus for which the new name given by Tomlin was anadema, is considered a valid sub-species from Somalia, Socotra and Horn of Africa (see Raybaudi & Rolan 1994 - check).

This species has five subspecies:
Conus generalis generalis Linnaeus, 1767
Conus generalis monteiroi Linnaeus, 1767
Conus generalis pallida Linnaeus, 1767
Conus generalis regenfussi Linnaeus, 1767
Conus generalis subunicolor Linnaeus, 1767
(Appeltans et al. 2011)
Determined by Filmer to be a valid species (Filmer 2001), but disputed by Tucker who considers this species to be a synonym of Conus stramineus stigmaticus A. Adams, 1855 (Appeltans et al. 2011).
This species resembles C. jickelii from Djibouti (see RKK 95; G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).

The taxonomic status of this species is still uncertain, because of a lack of live-collected specimens (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011). Although a lot of material exists, all of these were dead collected. Some taxonomists believe that this species may be a subspecies of Conus infrenatus, Reeve 1848, or possibly Conus timorensis, Hwass 1792 (www.schnr-specimen-shells.com).
This species may be confused with C. spectrum, C. petergabrieli, and C. dolium.
This species is classified in the genus Lilliconus.
Unaccepted by the World Register of Marine Species, instead it is proposed the name Pseudoconorbis coromandelicus Smith E. A., 1894 should be adopted (Appeltans et al 2011) from the WoRMS database.
C. mayaguensis and C. "juliae" from Puerto Rico are synonyms of C inconstans (Petuch pers. comm 2011). [add to synonym list]

Originally two subspecies were recognised, C navarroi navarroi and C navarroi calhetae, however these two are separated on different islands and are now known to be distinct taxa (M. J. Tenorio pers. comm. 2011).
This species was originally described from a single locality, but since then multiple locations have been showing this species (M. Tenorio pers. comm. October 2011).
This species was confused with Conus orbignyi until 2008 (G. T. Poppe pers. comm. 2011).
Conus dealbatus was listed as a synonym of this species in error; this has been removed from the synonym on this record (M. J. Tenorio pers. comm. 2011).
This species has been associated with C. raoulensis, however, they are considered two separate species with very distinct morphological features.

The southern population found in the Namib Province may be a different species so it has not been included in this assessment; however, if validated, this would extend the range of this species presented in this assessment (M. J. Tenorio pers. comm. 2011); see original description in Rolán & Röckel 2000.

This species is part of a species complex including C. reductaspiralis and C. nielsenae.  It appears that this species is the eastern Australian member of the complex while the two species above are western Australian species.

Determined by Filmer and Singleton to be a valid species (Filmer 2001, Singleton 2009), but disputed by Tucker who considers this species to be a synonym of Conus nielsenae reductaspiralis Walls, 1979 (Appeltans et al. 2011).

Despite being in dispute this species is assessed as a valid species in terms of conservation.
There are two recognized subspecies of this species Conus pulicarius pulicarius and Conus pulicarius vautieri (Röckel et al. 1995).
Subspecies: C. p. cebuensis (Rockal et al 1995).
This species is often confused with C. insculptus.

Röckel et al. (1995) and Tucker consider this species as a subspecies of C. nielsenae Marsh, 1962 (Appeltans et al. 2011) whereas for Filmer (2001) and Singleton (2009) it is a valid species. Tucker also considers that C. thevenardensis da Motta, 1987, is a form of C. nielsenae reductaspiralis (Appeltans et al. 2011) but Filmer (2001) considers it as a different and valid species.

This species is part of a species complex including Conus nielsenae  and C. thevenardensis.  It appears that this species is the eastern Australian member of the complex while the other two species are Western Australian species.
This species has two known subspecies C. m. mozambicus and C. m. lautus (Appeltans et al. 2011) from the WoRMS Database.
There is a form considered from East China Sea - Conus dusaveli benten (Shikama 1977).
This species is considered by J.K.Tucker to be a synonym of Conus luteus Sowerby 1833 (Appeltans 2011). However, R. M. Filmer classified it as a valid species in 2009 (Filmer 2001, amended in 2009).
There is uncertainty with the taxonomic name of this species.  Tucker considers its true name to be Conus bruguieri Kiener, 1848 (Appeltans et al 2011) from the WoRMS database.
This species is sometimes referred to as Conus pretiosus in the literature (Filmer 2001, Poppe pers. comm. 2011).
Sub species - C. spurius atlanticus Clench, 1942.

There are two subspecies of this species; C. inscriptus inscriptus, and C. inscriptus adenensis. There is some taxonomic uncertainty about whether C. i. adenensis is a valid subspecies and is generally considered to be a valid species (Smith). For the purpose of this assessment, we follow this view and consider C. adenensis to be separate from C. inscriptus.

Conus nodulosus has been synonymized with C. victoriae or at best considered a subspecies (Wilson 1994).  However, C. nodulosus is a geographically isolated species with very consistent morphological feature and a differing habitat preference.  Furthermore, because of the restricted habitat of C. nodulosus this may present considerable conservation concerns.

This species may be in the same group as C. hamamotoi from Japan, and appears to be not related to any other species of cone snail in the Indian Ocean. It appears to be an old species with an relictual range (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).

This species consists of two subspecies: Conus gubernator gubernator and Conus gubernator leehmani (Rockel et al. 1995). However, C. g. leehmani is considered a valid species (C. leehmani), occurring in the Maldives, Reunion, and Laccadives archipelago (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011). Therefore, for the purpose of this assessment, we have ignored C. g. leehmani and only considered Conus gubernator gubernator.

Conus veillardi - shown as a synonym - may be considered a valid subspecies restricted to Glorioses Archipelago (NW of Madagascar) (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).

This species is comprised of three subspecies:

Conus pulcher pulcher Lightfoot, 1786
Conus pulcher byssinus Röding, 1798
Conus pulcher siamensis Hwass, 1792

The validity of these sub-species is still being researched.
This species is often confused with C. tamikoae. Forms: C. kinoshitai calliginosus.
Form: C. o. rogmartini, granulate form of this species.
This valid species is a close relative to C. angioiorum (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).
There are 2 subspecies: C. asiaticus asiaticus and C. asiaticus lovellreevei

The taxonomy of this species is uncertain. Tucker considers it a synonym of Conus litteratus Linnaeus, 1758 (Appeltans et al. 2011) from the WoRMS database; whereas Filmer considers it a valid species (Filmer 2001, amended 2009).
It has been suggested that this species may be a synonym of Conus imperialis (Filmer 2001, amended 2009)

In 1997, within the original description article of Conus salzmanni, all the taxonomy of this group of species was reviewed, concluding that Conus grangeri is the first available name for this species, found in Sri Lanka. Conus batheon is a deeper water form of the same species and therefore a synonym found in the Red Sea (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).
Conus lucasi (Bozzetti, 2010) is a synonym of Conus chiapponorum.
Subspecies: C. m. macilentus.

The validity of this species needs to be assessed as it may be a local variation of namocanus form badius (G. Raybaudi and S. Veldsman pers. comm. October 2011). It is considered a valid species by Filmer. The small number of specimens available for study does not allow validation of its taxonomic status.
Conus amadis castaneofasciata Dautzenberg, 1937 is a subspecies (Filmer 2001).

There are two described subspecies of Conus terebra:

Conus terebra terebra Born, 1778

Conus  terebra thomasi

There are two subspecies:
Conus araneosus araneosus
Conus araneosus nicobaricus
Form: C. s. kurzi
There is a subspecies Conus miliaris pascuensis as described by Rehder, 1980 (Appeltans et al 2011).
[Conus carcellesi, Conus clenchi and Conus tostesi are valid species and need their own Red List assessment - Jose Coltro]
Rockel et al. (1995) considers this as a synonym of another species C. recluzianus. Majority accept this as a valid species.

There are two subspecies:

Conus hyaena hyaena Hwass in Bruguière, 1792
Conus hyaena concolor Sowerby ii, 1841
The taxonomy of this species is disputed. Tucker considers it a subspecies of C. buxeus (Appeltans et al 2011) whereas Filmer considers it a valid species (Filmer 2001).
The species is considered to be in the subgenus Genuanoconus, a monotypic genus.
Conus pseudoaustini and Conus tristensis once considered as synonyms are valid species (Petuch and Sargent 2011).

There is a separate population on the Gorée Island at the southern tip of the Dakar peninsular, that is currently under review, as it may be a distinct form, and results of the molecular analysis may assist to determine the status of these populations (E. Monnier pers. comm, 2011).

Before 1992, this species was identified as the 'banded form' or the 'dark coloured specimen' of Conus viola Cernohorsky, 1977 (Röckel et al 1995).

The taxonomic status of this species is still uncertain and may be classified as a subspecies (H. Morrison pers. comm. 2011).
Sometimes confused with C. sabulatus and C. blanfordianus (Filmer in press).

This species is endemic to the Cape Verde Islands . There are currently  two subspecies, one found on Boavista and the other on Maio Island.  The  two subspecies are considered separately, pending further information on  their taxonomic status.
This species is classified in Lilliconus.

C. jaspideus is a highly variable species that has led some taxonomists to separate it into several sub-species (Tucker 2010).

[Conus verrucosus, Conus pealii, and Conus nodiferus are good species and need their own Red List assessment - Ed Petuch]

Three subspecies with distinct geographic distribution: C. o. coriolisi, C. o elokismenos, C. o. timorensis. However, C. o. coriolisi (Puillandre et al. 2011) and C. o. timorensis (Tucker 2009) should be considered as a separate species.

This species has two subspecies (Röckel et al 1995): C. tribblei tribblei and C. tribblei queenslandis

C. queenslandis is considered to be a valid species (Wilson 1994).

There are four described subspecies of Conus spectrum: C. s. conspersus Reeve, 1844, C. s. felinus Link, 1807, C. s. stillatus Reeve, 1849 and C. s. verreauxii Kiener, 1845 as described in the WoRMS database (Appeltans et al. 2011).

C. spectrum complex is retained in C. straminaeus complex group, sometimes linked with C. zebra and also confused with C. blanfordianus (Filmer in press).
Synonym: C. tendineus var granulosus (Rockel et al. 1995).
There are 2 subspecies described: Conus luteus luteus: Conus luteus richardsae, Röckel & Korn, 1992 (Röckel et al. 1995).

This species is considered by Tucker to be a synonym of Conus stramineus Lamarck, 1810 (Appeltans et al. 2011) from the WoRMs database. However, Filmer considers this to be a valid species (Filmer 2001).
This is a cryptic species of Conus ebraeus Linnaeus, 1758 (Duda et al. 2009).
This species has been linked with C. howelli, but is considered a distinct species by most authorities (Marshall 1981).

The taxonomy of this species is in dispute. Filmer considers it a valid species (Filmer 2001), whereas Tucker in the World Register of Marine Species consider it to be a synonym of Conus catus Hwass in Bruguière, 1792 (Appeltans et al. 2011) from the WoRMS database. For the purpose of this assessment, we treat it as a valid species as suggested by Tucker.
This species has been confused for other species in the literature (G. T. Poppe pers. comm. 2011).
There are 2 sub-species: C. s. sponsalis and C. s. nanus (Duda et al 2008).
Synonyms: C. kongaensis (da Motta 1984)
Form: C. neotorquatus (Robin 2008).
<span id="aphia_ct_tu_429313">

Two subspecies are recognised: C. anabathrum anabathrum Crosse, 1865 and C. anabathrum burryae Clench, 1942 (Tucker, 2010).

Petuch and Sargent (2011) consider C. burryae to be a separate full species. Conus anabathrum tranthami, previously considered a synonym, has also now been shown to be a valid sub-species from the coral reefs of the Florida Keys.

Note: This species has been assessed as C. anabathrum without the range of C. burryae which will have a separate later assessment as a valid species.
This species is more commonly known as Conus acuminatus Hwass. Conus locumtenens, an oblitum name, was revived by RKK in 95.
Forms: C. v. blatteus (Rockel et al 1995), but this is considered a valid species in some literature.
Forms: C. s. sophiae, granulate form of C. striatellus.
There is a subspecies described of Conus marmoreus marmoreus: Conus marmoreus granulatus, Sowerby ii, 1839 (Röckel et al. 1995).
Conus cedonulli Linneaus, 1767 consists of three subspecies: Conus cedonulli cedonulli Linneaus, 1767, Conus cedonulli insularis Gmelin 1791 and Conus cedonulli dominicanus Hwass in Bruguière, 1792.
This species may be a synonym of C. nobilus (G. T. Poppe and A. J. Kohn pers. comm. 2011).

There are many subspecies of this species including; C. p. behlokensis, C. p. echo, C. p. bazarutensis, C. p. corbieri, C. p ganensis, C. p tsara, and C. p vezoi (Appeltans 2011) from the WoRMS database, and C.p. praelatus (S. Veldsman pers. comm. October 2011). Some specialists have sugested that there may be other currently unidentified subspecies (Rockel et al. 1995).

Although there are some taxonomic issues regarding this species, for the purpose of this assessment, detailed taxonomic discussion for this species has been omitted, as it has no bearing on the resulting conservation assessment.
There are two subspecies of this species; C. barthelemyi barthelemyi and C. barthelemyi jeanduvali from Maldives; (Poppe, G. T. and Poppe, P 2011).

This species has been recently classified into the subgenus Quasiconus (Tucker and Tenorio 2009), together with the closely related species Conus tuticorinensis which is found in Southern India, which suggests this may be a relictual species (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).
Form: C. l. grueneri (Reeve 1843) but some experts put this as a subspecies.

This species has two subspecies:
Conus glans glans Hwass in Bruguière, 1792
Conus glans granulata Dautzenberg, 1937
(Appeltans et al. 2011)

Conus verdensis was originally considered to have two subspecies: Conus verdensis verdensis Trovão, 1979 and Conus verdensis furnae Rolán, 1990; however C. f. furnae is now considered a different species.
Some references in the literature may refer to C. monachus.

This species has at least three subspecies:
Conus crocatus crocatus  Lamarck, 1810
Conus crocatus magister Doiteau, 1981
Conus crocatus thailandis da Motta, 1978
(Röckel et al. 1995, Filmer 2001, Appeltans et al. 2011)

The taxonomy of this species is uncertain.  Filmer considered it a possible subspecies of Conus australis Holton, 1802, but later revised his opinion and classified it as a valid species (Filmer 2001, amended 2009).  Tucker considers it a synonym of Conus australis gracilis G. B. Sowerby I, 1823 (Appeltans et al 2011) from the WoRMS database.

There is one described subspecies of Conus tessulatus: C. t. edaphus Dall, 1910 (Appeltans et al. 2011) from the WoRMS database.

Synonym: C. pavimentum (Rockal et al. 2011).

There is a population on another island (Maio) that is currently known as C. ateralbus, however, at present this has been discounted from the conservation assessment until better data is available on the status of the population (Manuel J Tenorio, pers. comm. 2011).
.
This species is known only from the holotype and a few specimens washed up in the 1970s, and is considered to be a valid species (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).
There is some uncertainty with the taxonomy of this species however, Filmer considers it a true species (Filmer 2001).  Because of conservation consideration it is here considered a true species.
<span id="aphia_ct_tu_429217">
Subspecies: C. p. fletcheri.
Synonyms: C. soyomaruae

This species is considered to be a valid species by Filmer (Filmer 2001), but it is recorded by Tucker, J.K. in World Register of Marine Species as a synonym of Conus inscriptus Reeve, 1845 (Appeltans et al. 2011) from the WoRMS database. It may also be juvenile of C. grangeri batheon (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011). Taxonomic validation is needed.

There are five described subspecies of Conus stramineus: C. s. mulderi Fulton, 1801, C. s. nisus Kiener, 1845, C. s. amplus Röckel & Korn, 1992, C. s. straturantus G. B. Sowerby II, 1865 and C. s. subulatus Kiener, 1845  as described in the WoRMS database (Appeltans et al 2011).
Forms: C. t. rugosus.
Some taxonomists believe this species to be within the genus Asprella and not within the Conus genus (Monteiro 2011).
This species is considered a synonym of C. monilifer (Tenorio et al 2012).

This species is part of a complex of Conus species that is currently under debate in need of further investigation concerning taxonomic status. The group includes C. albellus, C. limpusi, and C. lizadensis.

There are 2 subspecies:

C. v. vexillum Gmelin, 1791
C. v. sumatrensis

Forms: C. v. sulphuratus (a juvenile vexillum)
There is one described subspecies of Conus ochroleucus: Conus ochroleucus tmetus Tomlin, 1937 (Röckel et al. 1995).
This species is considered by Tucker to be a synonym of Conus spurius Gmelin, 1971 (Appeltans et al. 2011) from the WoRMS database, although Filmer considers it a valid species (Filmer 2001).
A formerly considered synonym C. adami is actually a distinct species from C. trigonus with a separate distribution and habitat.
Some taxonomists consider this a subspeces of C. nielsenae (G. Raybaudi and S. Veldsman pers. comm. October 2011).
The subspecies described are Conus musicus musicus and Conus musicus parvatus Walls, 1979 (Röckel et al. 1995).
This species has a multiple forms (Rockel et al. 1995, Poppe pers. comm. 2011).
C. badus is a local form from the Red Sea, which might be a subspecies (G. Raybaudi pers comm. October 2011).
There are some taxonomic confusion between this species and C. advertex  Garrard 1961, and is accepted by Morrison and Singleton and Wilson 1994.

This is considered a valid species by Filmer (2001) but was recently considered by Tucker (2010) to be a synonym of the wider-ranging Conus jaspideus Gmelin, 1791 which is a polytypic species consisting of three subspecies. Until further evidence is provided, this species is considered valid.
C archetypus is now known to be part of a large species complex found from the lesser Antillies to central Brasil, comprising at least eight species.
This species is related to Conus proximus.

Conus grahami has two subspecies:

C. grahami grahami Röckel, von Cosel & Burnay, 1980
C. grahami luziensis Röckel, Rolán & Monteiro, 1983.

A third species has sometimes to been considered as a subspecies of this species, but has recently been considered to be separate:

C. grahami longilineus Röckel, Rolán & Monteiro, 1980

The two subspecies C. grahami and C. luziensis are thought to be conspecific by Tenorio (M. J. Tenorio pers. comm. 2011).
Forms: C. p. chenui and C. p. vitulinus
This species has one known rare subspecies, Conus floccatus magdalenae, which has a different colouration to the normal shells of the species (Poppe, G. T. and Poppe, P.)
Subspecies: C. o. magoides, C. o . marmoricolor
This species is related to the group Fumiconus, together with closest relative species C. traversianus, C. stocki, and C. guidopoppei.
Subspecies: C. n. futunaensis.
This species is often confused with C. mucronatus.
Subspecies: C. f. leobottoni (Philippines) and C. f. kirai (Japan).
The once previously believed synonym to this species, C. roosevelti, has been raised to a distinct species.
Subspecies: C. l. detritus (Menke 1830).

There is uncertainty with the taxonomy of this species.  Filmer considers it a true species (Filmer 2001), whereas Tucker in the World Register of Marine Species considers it to be a synonym of Conus australis gracilis, G.B. Sowerby I, 1823 (Appeltans et al. 2011 from the WoRMS database).

Furthermore, Kohn provisionally recognizes C. a. gabryae as a subspecies of Conus australis, as it is restricted to the Solomon Is. and has different colourations and more ventricose to ovate last whorl than C. a. australis (Röckel et al. 1995).

This species currently has two subspecies C. balteatus balteatus, and C. balteatus pigmentatus ( Appeltans et al 2011 WoRMS database) . There may be other variations of the species but these are not yet identified.

authority: da Motta & Ninomiya in da Motta, 1982

taxonomicNotes: The closest relative of this species occurs in southeastern Australian waters (C. papiliferus), which suggests that this may be a relictual species (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).
Subspecies: C. v. alba and C. v. fasciata (Rockel et al 1995).
C. wakayamensis may be a synonym.
There are two subspecies of this species C. elegans elegans and C. elegans ramalhoi (Appeltans et al. 2011 WoRMS database).
This species is classified in the genus Lilliconus.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. Moolenbeek and Coomans (1987) propose that Conus alconnelli is a synonym of Conus martensi. Tenorio et al. (2008) conclude that differences in colour and shape justify Conus alconnelli as a separate species.

The Conus cardinalis complex refers to a range of shells that vary in colour and shape and this has led to a plethora of synonyms. The complex contains the species C. abbotti, C. caysalensis, C. cidaris, C. dianthus, C. donnae, C. harasewychi, C. lucaya, C. ortneri, C. stanfieldi and C. theodorei.
This species has two recognized subspecies C. p. pictus and C. p. transkeiensis (Appeltans et al 2011) from the WoRMS database.
Rockel et al. (1995) synonymize this with C. macarae but this is recognized as form.
Form nereis often referred to as C. nereis (Röckel et al 1995).
This species is easily confused with Diapterus auratus.

The most recent revision of this species (Watson 1996) considers the species to occur on both sides of Central America, however, there is disagreement. For this assessment we consider only the Western Atlantic species to be Awaous banana. There has not been a genetic analysis that supports the synonomy of A. transandianus (Pacific) and A. banana (Atlantic). It should be noted that the common trend in gobioid fauna is that morphologically similar species that occur on opposite sides of the istmus of Panama have been recognized as distinct species based upon combined morphological and molecular analysis.

This species is regularly confused with other species. Its synonym, Awaous stamineus, is probably another species, endemic to Hawaii and distinct from Awaous guamensis (P. Keith pers. comm. 2011, Lindstrom et al. 2012). Further taxonomic work is needed to clarify this species.
Fin coloration is highly variable between individuals indicating that there are possibly more than one species represented by the population (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
The distribution of T. okinawae possibly represents a complex of several species (Winterbottom pers. comm. in Allen and Erdmann 2012, Winterbottom and Hoese 2015).

Underwater photographs of individuals with similar white eye markings are known from Australia, the Philippines, Palau and the Yaeyama Islands in Japan, but genetic testing is required to verify if these individuals are E. nigriventris (Greenfield and Tornabene 2014)
The population on the eastern coast of Australia may be a different species, more taxonomic research is needed.
Byraninops annella Suzuki and Randall 2014 may be the same as this species.

This species was described from Samoa (Jordan and Seale 1906). Other records throughout the Indo-Pacific may be part of a species complex, found throughout the West Pacific, from Indonesia, north to Japan (Ryukyu Islands), east to French Polynesia (Rapa) and south to Australia (Great Barrier Reef).

The precise identity of this species has not been fully determined. It appears that the species, as recognized is a complex of related species, with some having been previously described. Many published images do not match type specimen. Records of this species have been confused with that of Cryptocentrus multicinctus Allen & Randall, 2011 and probably also with Cryptocentrus leonis (Smith, 1931).
This species has been confused with Gobiodon rivulatus, and there are two color forms of Gobiodon quinquestrigatus, which may indicate a cryptic species (Larson in press).

This is a senior synonym of Palutrus reticularis (Smith 1959), P. meteori (Klausewitz and Zander 1967) and possibly P. pusillus (Tortonese 1976) (H. Larson pers. comm. 2015). The entire genus is in need of revision.

The species has been confused with other species and some records are probably based on other species. Some species treated as junior synonyms are probably distinct species (Delventhal and Mooi 2013). Further studies are needed to fully document its identity and distribution.

Colour photographs from Bogorodsky et al (2010) show individuals from the Red Sea that have different colour patterns than those shown in Allen and Erdmann (2012) and Kuiter and Tonozuka (2011). Additionally, specimens from the Red Sea occupy a different micro-habitat (hard corals) to those individuals from Pacific localities, which are found on sponges. Further research is necessary to determine the taxonomic status of the Red Sea population.
The species as recognized is probably a composite of two or more species and is often misidentified as Istigobius nigroocellatus.

The species is often confused with Istigobius spence, which occur in the same habitat and some records are probably based on misidentifications of I. spence. Istigobius spence is more common on coastal reefs, while I. nigroocellatus more common on near shore reefs.
Further research is needed to determine if Ctenogobiops mitodes is different from this species.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius.
The taxonomy for this species needs to be revised, as it likely represents a complex (Shibukawa pers. comm. 2011, H. Larson pers. comm. 2022).

More research is needed on this species’ taxonomy and distribution, to distinguish it from Cryptocentrus albidorsus. Juveniles are often misidentified as C. albidorsus and it is likely that the two species are largely allopatric.
Amblygobius esakiae is likely closely related to A. nocturnus (Allen and Erdmann 2016).
Has been confused with Amblyeleotris wheeleri Polunin and Lubbock, 1977

This species is very closely related to Gobiodon ceramensis (Duchene et al. 2013). It is often misidentified and may be confused with Gobiodon albofasciatus and Gobiodon heterospilus (Shibukawa et al. 2013, Allen and Erdmann 2012, Hing et al. 2019, Duchene et al. 2013). It may be a synonym of G. ceramensis. The complex is in need of revision.
There is a probable new species included within this species distribution that is under revision by Naomi Delventhal (Larson pers. comm. 2018).
Oxyurichthys guibei and O. visayanus have recently been synonymized with O. lonchotus (Pezold and Larson 2015).
This species may have an older name, and because it is black there have probably been many misidentifications. As a result, it may be more widely distributed.

This species is often confused with Cryptocentrus melanopus. Further work is needed to determine the distinctiveness of the two species. Also, preserved specimens of this species can easily confused with C. altipinna (Hoese 2019).
This species' taxonomy needs additional research, as there have been a number of misidentifications and this species may be a synonym of Cryptocentrus leucostictus.
This species is sometimes confused with Gobiodon quinquestrigatus (H. Larson in press).
This species has been misidentified as Bathygobius fuscus in Hawaii (Randall et al. 1993).
This species belongs to a complex that needs further taxonomic research.
This species may be synonymous with Eviota susanae (Randall 2005); however as these two species have very different morphology and depth ranges, more research is needed to confirm this.

Shibukawa et al. (2012) reviewed the genus Lotilia and determined that the true L. graciliosa is restricted to the Red Sea. The species widely distributed in the western Pacific was described as a new species, L. klausewitzi.

An in depth analysis of the various populations of this species has not been undertaken, and it remains possible or even probable that more than one species are masquerading under this name (Winterbottom and Hoese 2015).
This is considered to be a junior synonym of Palutrus scapulopunctatus (H. Larson pers. comm. 2015). The entire genus is in great need of revision.
The taxonomy within this genus is in need of revision.
There is potential confusion with Kelloggella oligolepis (H. Larson pers. comm. 2015).
This species is replaced by Eviota guttata in the Indian and west Pacific and as far east as Fiji (Greenfield and Randall 2010).
This species may still be referred to as Apogon leptacantha or Apogon leptacanthus, though these names are no longer valid.
This species can be misidentified in the literature prior to 1983 (O. Gon pers. comm. 2011).

This species may represent a species complex. Kuiter and Kozawa (2019) consider populations west of the Andaman Sea to represent one or more different species based on insufficiently researched features seen in in situ photographs, but Gon and Allen (2012) found no morphological differences and make no mention of this, and list the following species as synonyms: S. cupea, S. ovalis, S. permutata, and S. versicolor. Allen and Erdmann (2012) also exclude points west of the Andaman Sea from the distribution.
The name of this species was changed from Apogon hartzfeldii to Ostorhinchus hartzfeldii according to Mabuchi et al. (2014).

This species has been confused with Ostorhinchus angustatus in the literature. It might represent a complex of at least three species (Kuiter and Kozawa 2019).

The name of this species was changed from Apogon nigrofasciatus to Ostorhinchus nigrofasciatus according to Mabuchi et al. (2014).
Records of this species from the Red Sea and the western Indian Ocean are now considered to represent Apogon erythrosoma (Gon and Randall 2003).
This species has been confused in the past with other Nectamia species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2011).
This species was assigned to the genus Verulux based on its lineage being distinct from Rhabdamia (Mabuchi et al. 2015, Yoshida and Motomura 2016).
This species has been confused with young Cheilodipterus macrodon and C. intermedius in the literature prior to 1993 (O. Gon pers. comm. 2011).
This species has been misidentified from many locations by virtually all ichthyological reports except for a few of the most recent publications (Fraser 2008).
Apogonichthyoides opercularis is part of the A. timorensis species complex (Fraser and Allen 2010).

Pacific populations of Zoramia fragilis were reclassified as a separate, distinct species, Zoramia viridiventer. Zoramia fragilis, was previously thought to range from the Indian Ocean into the Pacific, but is now considered restricted to Mozambique, Madagascar, the Seychelles, and the Maldives (Greenfield et al. 2005, Kuiter and Kozawa 2019).
This species has likely been misidentified as Cheilodipterus zonatus in the literature (O. Gon pers. comm. 2011).
Prior to 1990, records of this species were sometimes misidentified as Ostorhinchus fleurieu (O. Gon pers. comm. 2011).
This species has been frequently confused with Ostorhinchus cookii and O. taeniophorus.
This species was placed in the genus Apogon previous to the subdivision of the genera and elevation of the subgenus Apogonichthyoides (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
The name of this species was changed from Apogon melanoproctus to Ostorhinchus melanoproctus according to Mabuchi et al. (2014).
There are misidentifications in the  literature for this species complex as a whole (O. Gon pers. comm. 2011).

Kuiter and Kozawa (2019) apply the name Pristiapogon urostigma to this species based on an illustration in Bleeker’s Atlas (v. VII) and consider P. kallopterus to be a senior synonym of P. exostigma based on another illustration in that same work. We interpret the latter illustration to be more representative of this species and follow Fraser and Lachner (1985). 

Kuiter and Kozawa (2019) mention the application of P. kallopterus for larger and deeper-bodied species that was previously called P. urostigma, following a genus revision by Fraser and Lachner (1985).

The taxonomy of the genus is not clear and requires revision (O. Gon pers. comm. 2011). There are recent reports that this species may be synonymous with Gymnapogon vanderbilti or is restricted to the Marshall Islands in the Pacific (Kuiter and Kozawa 2019).
The name of this species was changed from Apogon novemfasciatus to Ostorhinchus novemfasciatus according to Mabuchi et al. (2014).

Future comprehensive molecular and taxonomic work may reveal that records west of the Andaman Islands represent other similar species (Kuiter and Kozawa 2019). Many contemporary workers continue to recognize the five potential allopatric species noted by Kuiter and Kozawa (species 5 through 9) as Ostorhinchus cyanosoma. The status of a sixth broadly sympatric species (Ostorhinchus sp. 4 of Kuiter and Kozawa 2019) also needs to be determined. Until these presumptive species are formally defined and described, the distribution of O. cyanosoma as currently recognized includes the Red Sea around the Arabian Peninsula to the Arabian Gulf, south to Mozambique (ca. 15°S), most western Indian Ocean islands and the Maldives as well as southern Japan and the Izu Islands (R. Myers. pers. comm. 2021).
Following Fraser's (2013) revision of the genus, Archamia, this species is now recognized as Taeniamia fucata.
This species was previously placed in the genus Apogon, but is now placed in Zoramia (Greenfield et al. 2005, Mabuchi et al. 2014).
There has been confusion between the species of Fowleria in the literature (O. Gon pers. comm. 2011).
The name of this species was changed from Apogon doederleini to Ostorhinchus doederleini according to Mabuchi et al. (2014).
Apogonichthys zuluensis is considered a junior synonym of Foa fo (Fraser 2020). Records of Foa brachygramma in the Red Sea should represent Foa fo (Fraser and Randall 2011).

This species has been confused with Apogon coccineus in the literature. It may comprise a species-complex closely related to Apogon coccineus in the Red Sea and western Indian Ocean (Allen and Erdmann 2012, Kuiter and Kozawa 2019).
The name of this species was changed from Apogon dispar to Ostorhinchus dispar according to Mabuchi et al. (2014).
The name of this species was changed from Apogon selas to Ostorhinchus selas according to Mabuchi et al. (2014).
This species has been misidentified in the literature as Apogon cookii and Apogon taeniophorus.
Pacific populations of Zoramia fragilis are now attributed to a separate species, Z. viridiventer (Greenfield et al. 2005).

Kuiter and Kozawa (2019) apply the name Pristiapogon kallopterus to this species based on an illustration in Bleeker’s Atlas (v. VII) and consider P. exostigma to be a junior synonym. They apply the name Pristiapogon urostigma Bleeker 1874 to the species Fraser and Lachner (1985) and most other contemporary authors consider to be the true P. kallopterus. We interpret the Bleeker’s Atlas illustration to be more representative of the species as interpreted by Fraser and Lachner (R. Myers pers. comm. 2021).
This species can be confused with Cheilodipterus parazonatus.
This species has been frequently confused with Cheilodipterus quinquelineatus due to its identical colour pattern (G. Allen and O. Gon pers. comm. 2011).
Fowleria punctulata is a synonym of F. variegata (Gon and Randall 2003, Gon and Bogorodsky 2010). It may be part of a species complex (O. Gon pers. comm. 2011).
The name of this species was changed from Apogon chrysotaenia to Ostorhinchus chrysotaenia according to Mabuchi et al. (2014).
There are misidentifications in the literature for this species complex as a whole (O. Gon pers. comm. 2011).
This species is often confused with Asterropteryx spinosa.

This species name has been questioned as two similar specific epithets, stellaris and stellatus, have been used by many authors since its description. The currently accepted name is Abalistes stellatus (Matsuura and Yoshino 2004, Matsuura 2015).
This species is sometimes referred to as Takifugu vermicularis radiatus  in the literature.

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986). Arothron caeruleopunctatus was described on the basis of four specimens in 1994 (Matsuura 1994).
The taxonomy of this species should be revised (G. Hardy pers comm. 2011).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008)

Several genetic experiments have suggested that Takifugu chinensis and T. rubripes are very closely related and can possibly be regarded as the same species (Reza et al. 2011). In China, T. chinensis is considered to be a junior synonym of Takifugu pseudommus. However, differences in the anal fin color of these two species makes it unlikely that they are the same species (Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). Skull structure of the two species is identical, however, and therefore further taxonomic studies are required. The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). We accept the taxonomic validity of T. chinensis.

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986).

Arothron immaculatus and A. manilensis are similar species which overlap in their geographic distributions (Randall 1985).
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Although this species is validated in the Catalog of Fishes, molecular data gathered from analysis of mitochondria and nuclear DNA strongly indicated that T. rubripes and T. pseudommus should be regarded as the same species (Song et al. 2001).

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive color patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986).

Sphoeroides andersonianus was originally described in 1957 after an examination of several small specimens. After a re-examination of the S. andersonianus type material and a comparison with S. sechurae specimens, Walker Jr. and Bussing considered S. andersonianus to be a synonym of S. sechurae (Walker Jr. and Bussing 1996). The genus Sphoeroides was found to be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013)

Puffers of the genus Lagocephalus are globally distributed in warm shallow waters. However classification at the species level in Lagocephalus has not yet been studied in depth, causing confusion in the status of several species including L. cheesemanii, L. gloveri, L. spadiceus, and L. wheeleri (Matsuura et al. 2011).

Lagocephalus wheeleri is considered a junior synonym of L. spadiceus (Matsuura pers. comm. 2014).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Canthigaster papua was previously classified as a color morph of C. solandri (Allen and Randall 1977).

Some authors have placed this species in the genus Pleuranacanthus (Su and Li 2002). Puffers of the genus Lagocephalus are globally distributed in warm shallow marine waters, however classification at the species level in Lagocephalus has not yet been studied in depth and there is confusion in the status of several species including L. cheesemanii, L. gloveri, L. spadiceus, and L. wheeleri (Matsuura et al. 2011).
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Canthigaster axiologus was formally described in 2008 (Randall et al. 2008).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain (Matsunuma et al. 2020, K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2022). The genus Canthidermis is in need of a global taxonomic review (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2022).
This species was described in 2002, and little information exists about it.
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Using a number of nuclear and mitochondrial markers, Alfaro et al. (2007) detected almost no difference between the Hawaiian C. jactator and the Indo-Pacific C. janthinoptera.
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

This species has been occasionally misidentified as Arothron reticularis (Randall, in litt.). This species is known on the basis of two syntypes dredged at 100 meters off the Andaman Islands, in the Indian Ocean.

Arothron reticularis has been occasionally misidentified as Arothron hispidus (Randall, in litt.).

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986).

The genus Lagocephalus is undergoing ongoing taxonomic work (K. Matsuura pers. comm 2014). Some authors have suggested that this species be placed in the new genus Laeviphysus Li on the basis of unique morphological features which separate it from its congeners in the genera Gastrophusus, Lagocephalus, Stenocephalus and Pleuranacanthus (Su and Li 2002).
This species has been confused with Lagocephalus spadiceus and Lagocephalus gloveri by previous authors. Ongoing taxonomic work indicate that this is a valid species (Matsuura et al. 2011).

This species is known only in type specimens from Cocos (Keeling), collected in the 1830s. Taxonomic status of this species is uncertain but it is very unlikely to belong in the genus Tetraodon, the species of which are normally found in fresh and brackish water habitats which are lacking in Cocos (Keeling).

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

This species is valid as Canthigaster ocellicincta (Catalog of Fishes), however, C. ocellicinctus and C. ocellatus are used in the literature and in museum collections to refer to this species.
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).
There are two colour morphs of this species: one in the Indian Ocean and the other in the western Pacific.
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).
This species may be a synonym of Lagocephalus lagocephalus (Mastuura pers. comm. 2011) but this requires confirmation.

The origin of the name Arothron leopardus is unclear; it appears to be based on a specimen collected from Madras, India, by Francis Day in the late 1878. This specimen is currently housed as Tetrodon leopardus in the Australian Museum. It is likely a synonym of A. stellatus (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014).

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive color patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Canthigaster coronata, formally ranging from Hawaii and Tonga to the east coast of Africa and the Red Sea, was recently split into three species (Randall et al. 2008). C. coronata is endemic to Hawaii.
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Genetic analysis revealed no difference between three similar Atlantic species, C. rostrata, C. figueiredoi, and C. supramacula (L.A. Rocha, unpublished data).
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Due to morphological variation in colouration and prickles throughout its range, S. nephelus has been frequently misidentified (Shipp and Yerger 1969). The taxonomic status of populations from northern South America to Brazil remain uncertain. The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Alfaro et al. (2007) detected almost no difference between the Hawaiian C. jactator (Jenkins) and the Indo-Pacific C. janthinoptera (Bleeker).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008)
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

The taxonomic status of this species is doubtful (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). Molecular analyses of the whole mitochondrial genome of the genus Takifugu revealed that the genetic differences between T. basilevskiannus, T. pseudommus, T. chinensis, and T. rubripes are not significantly different from the genetic differences between individuals within the species T. basilevskiannus, reinforcing the need for further taxonomic studies of the genus using molecular and morphological techniques (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986).
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008), and we support this recommendation.
This species is referred to as Uranostoma richei in some of the literature used to construct this assessment. Please see Hardy 1981 for description of Contusus richei.
