Canthigaster cyanospilota was recently split from C. coronata and occupies a range from the Indian Ocean and Red Sea (type locality, Gulf of Aqaba) (Randall et al. 2008).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008)

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colourpatterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986). Arothron nigropunctatus colour morphs are similar to those of A. meleagris (Su and Tyler 1986).

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986). Arothron immaculatus and A. manilensis are morphologically similar species which share a large portion of their geographic range (Randall 1985).
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Molecular analysis conducted by Santini et al. (2013) suggest Xenobalistes is a junior synonym of Xanthichthys. More analyses are necessary to clarify the relationship between the genera (Matsuura 2015).

Some Brazilian specimens of Chilomycterus antillarum are intermediate in colour between the crisp, dark hexagonal pattern typical of the species and the dark background with vague lighter spots typical of C. spinosus spinosus. The significance of this is unknown, and further investigation is required (Leis 2006).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

The scientific name Arothron hispidus has been mistakenly used to refer to this species in some literature (Williams et al. 2004).

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colourpatterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986).
Emblemariopsis arawak was recently described as a distinct species from Emblemariopsis signifer (Victor 2010).

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species. Randall and Bauchot (1999) make a compelling argument that A. neoguinaica is a junior synonym of A. forsteri. Colborn et al. (2001) do not list A. forsteri;  this species is referred to as A. neoguinaica. Eschmeyer currently lists A. forsteri and A. neoguinaica as synonyms of Albula argentea (Forster 1801).

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species. The few treatments of fisheries in this region are assumed to be A. glossodonta. Albula glossodonta has been found to be the sister species of A. vulpes (Bowen et al. 2008).  Pacific and Indian Ocean populations are distinct (Colborn et al. 2001). Friedlander et al. (2008) found genetic differences between populations in the Line Islands and Hawaii.

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species.

This newly-described species is part of an Indo-Pacific species complex comprised of two additional species, Albula argentea and Albula virgata (Hidaka et al. 2008). Albula oligolepis is almost certainly the undescribed Albula sp. D in Colborn et al. (2001). There is strong population structure across its range (Colborn et al. 2001).

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species.

This species is part of the Indo-Pacific species complex, comprised of two additional species, Albula argentea and Albula oligolepis (Hidaka et al. 2008).

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species.

Elops saurus was recently split into two largely allopatric species, E. saurus and E. smithi (McBride et al. 2010). In Florida waters, E. saurus and E. smithi may occur sympatrically at early life stages, though this does not appear to persist into the adult stage (McBride and Horodysky 2004).  E. saurus and E. smithi can be differentiated by myomere or vertebral counts;  the more northern E. saurus is characterized by a higher count while the more southern E. smithi exhibits a lower count (Smith 1989, McBride and Horodysky 2004, McBride et al. 2010). These phenotypic differences are corroborated by genetic data (McBride et al. 2010). The sequence divergence in mtDNA cytochrome b (d = 0.023-0.029) between E. smithi and E. saurus is similar to or greater than that measured between recognized species of Elops in different ocean basins (McBride et al. 2010). We recommend the vernacular name Malacho, which is already used for Elops in several countries bordering the Caribbean basin." (McBride et al. 2010; see 'etymology').
Records of Lutjanus russelli from the Indian Ocean are now identifiable as L. indicus, a recently described species (Allen et al. 2013).
Lutjanus lutjanus has been previously reported as L. lineolatus (Randall 2005).

This species closely resembles the congener Lutjanus bengalensis, and can be easily confused (Iwatsuki et al. 1999, Barman et al. 2014, Iwatsuki et al. 2016). Lutjanus octolineatus has been misreported as this species (Iwatsuki et al. 2016).
Some authors suggest this species should be classified in the genus Lutjanus.
This species has been confused with Lutjanus rufolineatus (Randall 2005).
Some reports of this species may have been based on misidentifications of Lutjanus timoriensis.
This species is sometimes confused with Symphorichthys spilurus (citation send to Gina via Barry).
This species may be more widespread than is currently described, as it is sometimes confused in the literature with Macolor niger (Anderson and Allen 2001).

Paracaesio xanthura, a complex of variable populations, may compose a single or two (or more) species (Allen and Anderson 2001). 

[[[from White and Last 2012: Although P. pedleyi McCulloch & Waite, 1916 is currently considered a junior synonym of P. xanthura, Anderson et al. (1992) stated that they were uncertain of its status and further investigation is required to assess its validity.]]]]Rework this later.
This species has been referred to as Lutjanus janthinuropterus and Lutjanus rangus (a junior synonym of Lutjanus bohar) by previous authors.
This species has been referred to as Lutjanus aya by previous authors, but Rivas (1966) concluded that Bodianus aya is not a lutjanid, but probably a sciaenid.
Records of this species from southern Japan and Hong Kong may have been confused with Lutjanus stellatus (Akazaki 1983).
This species is closely related to Lutjanus lemniscatus (Iwatsuki et al. 2015).

This species closely resembles the congener Lutjanus kasmira, and can be easily confused (Iwatsuki et al. 1999, Barman et al. 2014, Iwatsuki et al. 2016). It has also been confused with L. octolineatus (Iwatsuki et al. 2016).
The recently described L. xanthopinnis has been separated from L. madras (Iwaktsuki et al. 2015).

This species has been confused in the east Asian region with Lutjanus ophuysenii. Lutjanus vitta is widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific, except for the eastern Asian shelf. It is sympatric with L. ophuysenii in southwestern Taiwan and Hong Kong (Iwatsuki et al. 1993 - from Barry).
The population of this species in the Marquesas Islands shows significant genetic difference from elsewhere in the Indo-West Pacific (Gaither et al. 2010).
Some uncertainty has surrounded the taxonomic identity of this species (Allen and Talbot 1985) and small fish may be confused with juveniles of other species of Lutjanus.
The name Etelis carbunculus has been wrongly applied to this species by some previous authors, including Fischer and Bianchi (1989).
This species has been referred to as Lutjanus chrysotaenia previously.
It may be a synonym of Lutjanus dentatus.
This species can be commonly confused with Lutjanus malabaricus.

Mesoprion retrospinis Valenciennes, 1830 may be the oldest name for this species as the original description agrees closely to that given by Delais, 1952. There are some taxonomic problems with the correct name for this species.
This species has been referred to as Lutjanus amabilis by previous authors.
This species is sometimes confused with Symphorus nematophorus (citation send to Gina via Barry).
The taxonomy of this species and its relationships are poorly-known (Lindeman and Rocha pers. comm. 2011).
The taxonomy of this species and its relationships are poorly-known (Lindeman and Rocha pers. comm. 2011).
Two species, Plectorhinchus caeruleonothus and P. unicolor, have long been confused with P. schotaf (Johnson and Wilmer 2015).
Pomadasys kaakan may be confused with P. argenteus in the literature.
Synonym: Pomadasys olivaceum

Starksia atlantica has recently been shown to be a species complex. The original species has been divided into Starksia atlantica (known from Bahamas and Turks and Caicos), Starksia sangreyae (Belize) and Starksia springeri (Curacao) (Baldwin et al. 2011).

Starksia sangreyae has been recently described. It was originally known as S. atlantica, now shown to be a species complex comprised of S. atlantica, (known from Bahamas and Turks and Caicos), S. sangreyae (Belize) and S. springeri (Curacao) (Baldwin et al. 2011).

Starksia lepicoelia has recently been shown to be a species complex. The original species has been divided into S. lepicoelia (known from Bahamas and Turks and Caicos), S. weigti (Belize), S. williamsi (Saba Bank, Netherland Antilles) and S. robertsoni (Panama) (Baldwin et al. 2011). However, Baldwin et al. (2011) did not sample populations in the Gulf of Mexico. The taxonomic status of the this population needs to be confirmed with DNA barcode data (R. Robertson and B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015).

Starksia weigti has been only recently described. It was previously known as S. lepicoelia, which is now known to be a species complex comprised of: S. lepicoelia (known from Bahamas and Turks and Caicos), S. weigti (Belize), S. williamsi (Saba Bank, Netherland Antilles), and S.robertsoni (Panama) (Baldwin et al. 2011). The taxonomic status of the Campeche Bank (Gulf of Mexico) population needs to be confirmed with DNA barcode data (R. Robertson and B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015).

Starksia robertsoni has been only recently described. It was previously known as S. lepicoelia, now known to be a species complex comprised of: S. lepicoelia (known from Bahamas and Turks and Caicos), S. weigti (Belize) and S. williamsi (Saba Bank, Netherland Antilles) and S. robertsoni (Panama) (Baldwin et al. 2011).

Starksia sluiteri has recently been shown to be a species complex. The original species has been divided into S. sluiterei (known from Curacao), S. greenfieldi (Tobago, Trinidad and Tobago) and S. langi (Belize) (Baldwin et al. 2011).

Starksia greenfieldi has been recently described. It was previously known as Starksia sluiteri, now shown to be a species complex. The original species has been divided into Starksia sluiterei (known from Curacao), Starksia greenfieldi (Tobago, Trinidad and Tobago) and Starksia langi (Belize) (Baldwin et al. 2011).

Previously Starksia langi was known as Starksia sluiteri, which is now shown to be a species complex. The original species has been divided into S. sluiterei (known from Curacao), S. greenfieldi (Tobago, Trinidad and Tobago) and S. langi (Belize) (Baldwin et al. 2011).

The taxonomic status of this species is not fully understood. It has been treated as a senior synonym of Chlopsis fierasfer Jordan & Snyder, 1901 and Nettastoma elongatum Kotthaus, 1968, but Eschmeyer Catalog of Fishes presently recognizes C. fierasfer and N. elongatum as distinct, valid species, both within the genus Saurenchelys (Klausewitz and Zajonz 2000, Eschmeyer Catalog of Fishes database 7 September 2022).
In Taiwan, some specimens of this species were previously misidentified as Myrophis microchir, which indicates the similarity between these two groups (Ho et al. 2015).

It was previously though that his taxon was likely to include two separate species with widely disjunct distributions - one in the Atlantic/Mediterranean Sea and the other in the west Pacific. However, it is now clear that this species is only present in the Eastern Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea (R. Bañón pers. comm. 2014).
This taxon has a curious, disjunct global distribution, recorded from the Mediterranean Sea, Florida and Hawaii. Taxonomic research is needed.
Cottoperca gobio is almost certainly a synonym of C. trigloides (J.M. Díaz de Astarloa pers. comm. 2019).

Rhynchobatus palpebratus is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.

North Pacific Spiny Dogfish Squalus suckleyi (Girard, 1854) has a rather long and convoluted taxonomic history. It was first described in 1854 as a separate species from the well-known Spiny Dogfish (Squalus acanthias) but was subsequently synonymyzed as the same species even though its life history parameters, meristics, morphometrics, and molecular data suggested otherwise. A comparative study of its morphometrics and meristics, as well as a molecular study on this species complex have revealed it to be distinctive from the North Atlantic and other S. acanthias forms elsewhere (Ebert et al. 2010).
This is a recently described species.
Research indicates that subpopulations from the Atlantic and Indian Oceans are cryptic species (K. Tighe pers. comm. 2011).

Chlopsis longidens is known only from the holotype (a leptocephalus), collected at 0o 36' N, 82o 46' W. It may be the larva of another species, possibly Chlopsis bicollaris, which is known from the Galapagos (Lavenberg 1988, Tighe and McCosker 2003). More work is needed to determine the taxonomic status of this nominal species.

There has been recent changes to the organization of this family, and there has been a taxonomic split of a once thought to be circumtropical species Kaupichthys hyoproroides into two species; K. hyoproroides in the Atlantic and K. diodontus in the Indo-Pacific (Randall and van Egmond 1994). However, ranges have not been fully agreed upon. The taxonomy and distributions of species of Kaupichthys is not fully resolved.

Kaupichthys hyoproroides was previously known as a highly variable, circumglobal species. Recent studies show that the western Pacific distribution is K. japonicus and K. diodontus is known from islands of the central Pacific. The western Atlantic and western Indian Ocean distributions are currently in place for K. hyoproroides, however, these distributions may represent a cryptic species pair. Studies are underway to resolve this taxonomic issue. Until this is published, we accept current taxonomy of this species (K. Tighe pers comm. 2011).
The taxonomy and distributions of species of Kaupichthys is not fully resolved.

Castle (1965) described Leptocephalus tuberculatus based on two larval specimens collected off Manly Beach, Sydney, Australia. Several later authors placed this species in the genus Neoconger (e.g. Paxton et al. 1989; Smith 1989, 1999, 2019, Hoese et al. 2006) and this is the arrangement followed by Fricke et al. (2022); however, further research is warranted to confirm this generic placement.
This species is part of a complex found in the Indo-West Pacific.
Anarchias euryurus is a synonym of Anarchias longicauda.
This species may be part of a species complex with A. leucurus (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
This species may be a junior synonym of Channomuraena bauchotae (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011); further research is needed.
Gymnothorax dorsalis was assigned to the genus Strophidon on the basis of molecular analysis and morphological characteristics (Loh et al. 2015).
Gymnothorax enigmaticus has been confused with G. patelli in the literature (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
More than one species may be passing under the name Gymnothorax eurostus; further research is needed (Smith 2012).
Enchelycore tamarae is now considered a junior synonym of Gymnothorax fimbriatus (Smith 2012).
This species is very similar to G. albimarginatus (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
This species has been confused with G. monochrous in the literature (D. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
This species has been confused with G. pseudoherrei in the literature.
Gymnothorax pescadoris and Muraena melanospilos are considered synonyms of Gymnothorax isingteena (Smith 2012).
Gymnothorax mindonoensis is valid as a synonym of Gymnothorax javanicus.
This species is sometimes confused with a number of white-spotted morays which require further study (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
Muraena similis and Gymnothorax mucifer are valid synonyms of Gymnothorax kidako.
Gymnothorax talofa is a valid synonym of Gymnothorax margaritophorus.
This species is very similar to G. fuscomaculatus, although G. marshallensis is not as widely distributed (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
Gymnothorax leucostictus is a valid synonym of Gymnothorax meleagris.
This species has been confused with G. reticularis (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011). The current anti-tropical distribution may be indicative of two distinct species. Further study is necessary.
This species is often confused with G. hepaticus (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011). Historical records may be questionable. Further study is needed to confirm the status of this species.
Rabula davisi is a valid synonym of Gymnothorax mordax.
Muraena euptera is a valid synonym of Gymnothorax nubilus.
Muraena tuhua is a valid synonym of Gymnothorax obesus.

The validity of this species has been questioned. For example, Nakabo (2002) suggests that it is a junior synonym of G. pseudothyrsoideus. However, it is treated as valid in Böhlke and Smith (2002) and Smith (2012), and thus is included as valid here.

Muraena atomaria, Muraena elegantissima, Muraena erythroptera, Gymnothorax hilonis, Gymnothorax pictus kowanensis, Muraena lita, Muraenophis pantherina, Muraena pfeifferi, Muraena polyophthalmus, Muraena siderea, Gymnothorax thomsoni, and Muraena variegata are valid synonyms of Gymnothorax pictus
This species is similar to G. burndti and G. ypsilon.

This species may be confused with other white-spotted eels. Gymnothorax leucostigma, Gymnothorax nirosus, Muraena shirleyi, Muraena mieroszewskii, and Lycodontis wooliensis are valid as synonyms of Gymnothorax prionodon.
There is an unusually large variation of vertebral counts that needs further investigation (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
This species has been confused with G. herrei in the literature (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
Gymnothorax makassariensis is a valid synonym of Gymnothorax pseudothyrsoideus.
This species may be confused with other white spotted eel species.
This species is characterized by obscure dark spots; this may be unreliable in accurately identifying this species.. More research on taxonomy is warranted (D. G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
This species is easily confused with other Gymnothorax spp., particularly G. minor (Li et al. 2018).

Muraena troschelii, Muraena scoliodon, Muraena venosa, Muraena vermicularis, Muraena diplodon, Muraena chrysops, Muraena florisiana, Muraena modesta, Muraena ceramensis, and Thyrsoidea multifasciata are synonyms of Gymnothorax richardsonii.
Nakabo (2002) claimed Gymnorthorax sagmacephalus represents the juvenile stage of G. albimarginatus (Nakabo 2002), but it is considered valid by Smith (2012).
Muraena thyrsoides, Muraena prosopeion, Echidna kishinouyei, and Thyrsoidea arenata are valid as Gymnothorax thyrsoideus.
Muraena vermiculata, Gymnothorax borneensis, Muraena gracilis, Lycodontis literata, Strophidon maculata, Thyrsoidea microdon, and Strophidon punctacta are valid as Gymnothorax tile.
Muraena acutirostris, Muraena agassizi, Muraena blochii, Muraena cancellata, Thyrsoidea kaupii, and Muraena valenciennii are valid as Gymnothorax undulatus.
Gymnothorax indong is a synonym of Gymnothorax zonipectis.
This species is based on an incomplete description of an unfinished drawing which has been lost (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
The species was considered a synonym of M. helena (Wirtz et al. 2008), but Jiménez et al. (2007) have confirmed the specific identity of M. augusti using morphological and genetic methods.
Gymnothorax megapterus, Strophidon polyodon, and Muraena taenioides are considered synonyms of Pseudechidna brummeri.
Gymnomuraena brevicauda, Uropterygius sealei, and Scuticaria unicolor are considered synonyms of Scuticaria okinawae.
In the literature, this species is still known by its former names: Thyrsoidea macrura and Evenchelys macrurus (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).

Gymnomuraena fascia, Anarchias insuetus, and Anarchias vermiformis are considered synonyms of Uropterygius concolor. This species apparently occurs from the Red Sea and East Africa to Polynesia. However, this range may represent a species complex (Smith pers. comm. 2011).
Uropterygius goslinei is considered a synonym of Uropterygius fasciolatus.
Anarchias knighti, Uropterygius makatei, Gymnomuraena nectura, and Uropterygius reidi are synonyms of Uropterygius macrocephalus.
Anarchias reticulatus and Uropterygius tinkhami are synonyms of Uropterygius micropterus.

The Hawaiian population, described as Uropterygius dentatus (Schultz 1953), is morphologically distinct from U. supraforatus (Smith 2012). Although U. dentatus is currently treated as a junior synonym of U. supraforatus, following Bölke and Randall (2000), further taxonomic work may recognize it as a valid species in the future (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011, Smith 2012).
This species has been confused with U. alboguttatus in the literature.
The subpopulations in the Atlantic and Pacific may represent two different species. More research is needed concerning their taxonomy.

Spelling of Gymnothorax rueppellii has been changed to Gymnothorax rueppelliae. Muraena interrupta, Gymnothorax leucacme, Muraena petelli, Gymnothorax signifer, and Gymnothorax waialuae are synonyms of Gymnothorax rueppelliae.
This species is commonly reported in collections as Bathygobius soporator.
This species has been recently resurrected. It was previously considered a synonym of Bathygobius soporator and may still be confused with this species in collections.
This species has been recently described (Randall and Lobel 2009).
This species has been recently described. It was previously considered to be a color morph of Elacatinus xanthiprora.
This is a sympatric sibling species to Gramma loreto (Victor and Randall 2010).
The whereabouts of the holotype is unknown.
Locality records for this species have been confused with those for Thryssa enchrasichoides and the two species can occur together (Wongratana et al. 1999).

There is a taxonomic problem with this species' name. The holotype of Waitea stomias, Smith 1941, was used for the description of genus Waitea by Jordan and Seale 1906, but was misidentified (as Gobius mystacinus Valenciennes, which is Mahidolia mystacina).

Additionally, the species is regularly confused with Oligolepis acutipennis.

This species was originally described from a small area in southeastern Australia. However, it is thought that Parioglossus neoclaedonicus Dingerkus and Seret, 1992 from New Caledonia may be a synonym. It is also possible that Parioglossus verticalis Rennis and Hoese, 1985 from the Caroline Islands (known only form a single specimen from Pohnpei) may also be a synonym. Genetic studies are required to fully resolve these taxonomic uncertainties (Hoese pers. comm. 2014).
<span id="docs-internal-guid-fefc345a-a89c-783a-6304-5ce48b374b10">This species may represent a species complex (H. Larson pers. comm. 2017).
This species has been confused with P. argentilineatus (Larson pers. comm. 2017).
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius.

There are many misidentifications of this species. This species was separated in 1991 - previously the name was applied to many Stenogobius species. Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius.
In the original description, the species is called Stiphodon hydoreibatus - Watson (1999) misspelled the name throughout the publication.
This genus is presently under review and there are 5-6 names that may apply to various populations of this species. All information is thus tentative.

This species was previously regarded as a junior synonym of Kuhlia marginata and only recognized as distinct in 2001. The work has been based on limited material and further genetic work is needed. The full geographical distribution and literature information on the species are not well known.
This species is often misidentified in older literature as Kuhlia taeniura
Synonyms of this species include: Dules humilis, 1884 (Queensland); Kuhlia proxima Kendall & Goldsborough, 1911 (Fiji); Kuhlia bilunulata Herre, 1935 (Fiji); Kuhlia boninensis (Fowler, 1907).
This species is currently under revision. Clarification of its taxonomy is required.
There has been some confusion with other species in the past (Woodland 1990).

Dawson (1984) and most later authors consider Coelonotus to be a subgenus of Microphis based on morphology and meristics. Kottelat (2013) and Delrieu-Trottin et al. (2015) resurrect Coelonotus with no annotation or justification.
Dawson (1984) and most later authors consider Oostethus to be a subgenus of Microphis based on morphology and meristics. Kottelat (2013) resurrected Oostethus with no annotation or justification.
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).

According to the results of a morphological study by Wiley (1986), the sister group of Fundulus plus Lucania is a group composed of the genera Adinia and Leptolucania. The genus Adinia was synonomized with Fundulus by Ghedotti and Davis (2013).

Bagre marinus is a species complex that includes two species, Bagre marinus sensu strictu and Bagre bahiensis (Betancur and Marceniuk pers. comm. 2011). This assessment refers to Bagre marinus sensu strictu. A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).
This species was formerly placed in the genus Arius. The genus Carlarius was recently described (Marceniuk and Menezes 2007).

Cathorops spixii is often treated as the only coastal marine species in the genus from the western Atlantic. There are at least eight species widely cited in the literature as C. spixii. The taxonomic revisions follow Betancur and Acero (2005), Marceniuk and Betancur (2008), Marceniuk (2007) and Marceniuk et al. (in press). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).
Among the Cathorops species in the Atlantic, Cathorops arenatus is the most similar, and frequently confused with Cathorops spixii.
This is a relatively newly described species (Marceniuk and Betancur 2008). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).
This is a newly described species (Marceniuk and Betancur 2008). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Chelon bispinosus and Chelon labrosus may be conspecific, but further review of the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean populations should be completed before declaring synonymisation (Harrison in press). Heemstra and Heemstra (2004) describes the taxonomy of the Mugilidae family as confused and the genera as obscurely defined.
Heemstra and Heemstra (2004) describes the taxonomy of the Mugilidae family as confused and the genera as obscurely defined.

The taxonomy of species in the Mugilidae family is complex and under revision (Durand and Borsa 2015). The family comprises of seven lineages which radiated early on, and many of its genera are paraphyletic or polyphyletic (Durand et al. 2012).

This species has many synonyms, with over 280 specific names having been assigned to mullets of the Mugilidae family (Thomson 1997). There is a long history of confusion between the populations assigned these names (Ogilby 1908), and many of these have now been recognised as synonyms in the past 120 years (Thomson 1997).

The taxonomy of species in the Mugilidae family is complex and under revision (Durand and Borsa 2015). This species has previously been considered a synonym of Liza tade (e.g.,Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Thomson 1997, Kottelat 2013). The relationship between these two nominal species requires further investigation, as does the potential for cryptic species within the genus Planiliza. At present, it is considered a valid species (Fricke et al. 2020), and based on the most recent molecular work, it belongs in the genus Planiliza. However, some authors continue to place this species in the genus Chelon (e.g., Suresh et al. 2018, Psomadakis et al. 2020).
Heemstra and Heemstra (2004) describes the taxonomy of the Mugilidae family as confused and the genera as obscurely defined.
Heemstra and Heemstra (2004) describes the taxonomy of the Mugilidae family as confused and the genera as obscurely defined.

The species Mugil gaimardianus was supressed. Many specimens misidentified as M. gaimardianus are actually M. rubrioculus (Harrison et al. 2007).

Mugil rubrioculus can easily be confused with Mugil curema. They are very similar morphologically, but separation is easier in fresh specimens due to coloration differences.  They are however clearly separated genetically both by karyotype and molecular analysis (Nirchio et al. 2005, Fraga et al. 2007, Gonzalez-Castro et al. 2009).
The taxonomy of species in the Mugilidae family is complex, and under revision (Durand and Borsa 2015).

This species is listed in the genus Notarius by Betancur et al. (2007), but was reverted back to Amphiarius by Marceniuk (2012). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).
This species is listed in the genus Notarius by Betancur et al. (2007). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).
This is the only species in the family Cheimarrichthyidae worldwide (McDowall 2000).
This species could easily be confused with P. antipodarum without dissection.
Literature references of this species are probably confused with A. meeki or A. anagoides. A. anago may be part of a species complex. More research is need to determine its status.
This species has not been well studied since its description in 1929. Its taxonomic validity may be uncertain, however this has not been investigated to date (J. McCosker pers. comm. 2013).
The taxonomic status of this species is unknown, as the type specimens are small and damaged and the species has not been collected since its original description (J. McCosker pers. comm. 2011).
The identity of this species is uncertain (McCosker pers comm. 2011).
There may be two species that fall under this name, based on vertebral count, size, and depth distribution (Smith pers. comm. 2012).
This species is only known from leptocephali.
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain, as it is known only from the damaged holotype (J. McCosker pers. comm. 2011).

This species faces taxonomic uncertainty. The name is based on a leptocephalus, the holotype of which is in poor condition and the myomere count (species indicator) is unknown. There are several Gnathophis species in the area, and it is impossible to know which adult matches the holotype due to the poor condition of the type specimen (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2012).

The synonym Leptocephalus proboscideus is based on an original description of a larva collected from the north Atlantic Ocean (34°59'N, 33°01'W); however, the genus Leptocephalus has often been used to refer to larval eels, and its validity is uncertain. It represents either a highly variable species or a complex of several closely related species. The Ilyophinae is not well known, and the variety of leptocephali of the L. proboscideus type is greater than had been suspected. Leptocephalus proboscideus may be the leptocephalus of Dysommina or something similar to Dysommina (Smith 1989). We follow the former assumption here.

This species has been referred to the genus Ophichthus, from Pisodonophis (McCosker et al. 2020). It is a possible junior synonym of Pisodonophis boro (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, McCosker et al. 2020).

This species may be erroneously identified as a member of the genus Hoplunnis but may possibly be a leptocephalus of the genus Saurenchelys. (K. Tighe pers comm. 2011). Additionally, this species is possibly a senior synonym of Hoplunnis pacifica Lane & Stewart 1968 (MCZ type catalog, fide D. G. Smith).
The eastern and western Atlantic subpopulations may represent two separate species (D. Smith pers. comm. 2012).
Literature references of this species are probably confused with A. meeki or A. anago. A. anagoides may be part of a species complex. More research is needed to determine its status.
The taxonomy of this species and the related O. erabo is unresolved, and these species are very similar (McCosker pers. comm. 2013).
This species has been previously referred to as Myrophis cheni but is currently valid as Neenchelys cheni (Hibino et al. 2012).
This species was formerly referred to as Callechelys perryae.
This species will be referred to a new unique genus (McCosker in press).
The current taxonomic nomenclature of this species is uncertain and it may need to be moved to a new genus (Smith pers. comm. 2012).
This species is often referred to as Scolecenchelys nicholsae, but as it was named for Mrs. T. Nichols and her daughters, the specific epithet must be nicholsarum (Fricke et al. 2021).
The genus Scolecenchelys requires taxonomic revision (J. McCosker pers. comm. 2013).
The holotype of this species has been lost, and its original description is not sufficient; therefore its taxonomic status should be reviewed (Hibino and Kimura 2015).

This species is most similar to A. flavicaudus and may be conspecific, but current information is insufficient to make a determination at this time (McCosker and Hibino 2015). Therefore, both species are recognized as valid until new information is available.
This species is possibly a junior synonym of H. sicarius (Garman 1889) - (MCZ type catalog, fide D. G. Smith).
This genus is in need of taxonomic revision (McCosker 2013 pers. comm.)
This species has been previously referred to as Apterichtus keramanus but is currently valid as Ichthyapus keramanus (McCosker and Hibino 2015).
This may be a junior synonym of Conger macrocephalus, based on juveniles (D.G. Smith pers comm 2012).

The genus Scolecenchelys has been considered to be a subgenus of Muraenichthys for a long time. Castle and McCosker (1999) elevated Scolecenchelys to the generic level that included this species. However, Hibino and Kimura (2015) proposed Scolecenchelys acutirostris should belong to Muraenichthys and its generic status should be reevaluated.
This species has been previously referred to as Muraenichthys macrostomus but is currently valid as Skythrenchelys macrostomus (Hibino et al. 2013).
Genetic work shows that there may be more than one species involved in this case (Smith pers. comm. 2012).
Several authors have considered this species to be a junior synonym of Ophichthus urolophus (Ho et al. 2015, Hibino et al. 2019, Vo et al. 2019).
The relationship of the Hawaiian Ichthyapus vulturis to those across the Indo-Pacific requires further analysis (McCosker 2004).
Some regional population distinctions are evident, warranting further study.
This species was recently assigned to the genus Ariosoma having previously been in Poeciloconger (Smith et al. 2018).

There is confusion with the taxonomy of this species. Kanazawa (1958) recognized this species as distinct, while Asano (1962) considered this species as a synonym of Conger japonicus (Smith pers. comm. 2012).
The type specimens have presumably been destroyed, and this species is questionable (McCosker 2014).

Apterichtus australis is most similar to A. flavicaudus and may be conspecific, but current information is insufficient to make a determination at this time (McCosker and Hibino 2015). Therefore, both are recognized as valid until new information is available.
This species may be part of a species complex. More research is needed to determine its status.
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain, as it is known only from the damaged holotype (J. McCosker pers. comm. 2011).

This species is known only from larval specimens collected in the Red Sea in 1923 (D'Ancona 1928). The myomere count is suggestive of Gorgasia preclara (Castle and Randall 1999), but there are insufficient specimens to allow for a detailed comparison (Castle 1997).
This species may be more appropriately placed in the genus Heteroconger (Castle 1997).
Until 2008, this species was known as Leiognathus splendens.

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species. This species is newly described, based on five specimens collected from Korea and Taiwan. Its new scientific name, Albula koreana, is derived from its type locality, Korea (Kwun and Kim 2011).
Deichmann (1958) notes that Holothuria inornata was a synonym of Holothuria keferstenii, but there is no current review on the status of this species. A review is likely necessary.
Uthicke et al. (2004) by genetic analysis differentiated Holothuria whitmaei, H. fuscogilva and H. nobilis that were previously confused.

There is significant taxonomic uncertainty surrounding this species (Huber and Schniebs 2009). It may be conspecific with O. libella (Huber 2010, 2015), but both are treated here as valid species until further taxonomic work is completed.
This species may be synonymous with Ostrea denticulata (Born 1778).

This species has been previously placed in several different genera, including Dendostrea, Ostrea, Saccostrea, Saxostrea (e.g., Torigoe 1981, Harry 1985).  Crassostrea plicatula (Gmelin, 1791) is a junior synonym of Alectryonella plicatula.  Historical records in the literature of C. plicatula often refer to A. plicatula.

This species is often referred to as Saccostrea cucullata in China, and is confused with C. gigas.

Though it is genetically similar to Saccostrea cucullata (Lam and Morton 2006), S. kegaki is currently accepted as a valid species. The taxonomy of species in the Saccostrea genus remains unclear due to their highly variable shell forms, and more DNA-based research is needed to resolve confusion (Sekino and Yamashita 2016).

This species has also been referred to as Saccostrea futamiensis (e.g., biodiversity database of India). It is easily confused with other small Ostrea species, and some workers consider it to be a junior synonym of O. denselamellosa, but DNA barcoding research confirms its validity as O. futamiensis (Hamaguchi et al. 2017).
This species is possibly conspecific with Ostrea imputata (Huber 2010, 2015), but it treated as a separate, valid species until additional taxonomic work has been completed.

Ostrea lurida (the Olympia Oyster) was previously synonymized under O. conchaphila; however, they are both now considered to be separate species with O. lurida in the northern portion and O. conchaphila from Mexico southward (Polson et al. 2009). It is still confused with O. lurida in the literature despite this taxonomic resolution.

This species is valid according to Huber (2010, 2015). The taxonomy of species in the Saccostrea genus remains unclear due to their highly variable shell forms, and more DNA-based research is needed to resolve confusion (Sekino and Yamashita 2016).

MolluscaBase (2019) has officially recognised Crassostrea tulipa to be the correct name of the West African Crassostrea populations, described as G. gasar. But molecular studies recently revealed that some tropical West Atlantic oyster populations were identical to this species, which hence occurred on both sides of the Atlantic. Consequently, the name gasar for the East Atlantic populations was replaced by the older name of Lamarck, used for West Atlantic populations, namely tulipa. The taxonomic change is very recent, e.g., Poutiers (2016)  still uses G. gasar as the valid name.

This species is easily confused with other Saccostrea species that overlap its range (M. Bishop, M. Luckenbach, R. Brumbaugh and J. Ruesink pers. comm. 2011). The taxonomy of species in the Saccostrea genus remains unclear due to their highly variable shell forms, and more DNA-based research is needed to resolve confusion (Sekino and Yamashita 2016).

This species has also been referred to as Saccostrea mordax in the literature. The taxonomy of species in the Saccostrea genus remains unclear due to their highly variable shell forms, and more DNA-based research is needed to resolve confusion (Sekino and Yamashita 2016).
This species is the senior synonym of Lopha tridacnaeformis or Ostrea tridacnaeformis (Huber 2010, 2015).
The taxonomy of species in the Saccostrea genus remains unclear due to their highly variable shell forms, and more DNA-based research is needed to resolve confusion (Sekino and Yamashita 2016).
This species was formerly known as Ostrea pestigris. According to Lam and Morton (2009), this species is a synonym of O. palmipes.
Formerly placed in genus Pomolobus (Lee et al. 1980).
Alosa mediocris was formerly placed in the genus Pomolobus. This species forms a geographically separated species pair with A. chrysochloris (Lee et al. 1980).
This species is known from two specimens but its high gillraker count and very short swimbladder tubes make it very distinct among other species of Ilisha (Whitehead 1985).
Parascolopsis baranesi may be conspecific with P. boesemani (B. Russell pers. comm. 2018); however, until more taxonomic research is completed, both species are treated as valid.
This species is easily confused with Upeneus supravittatus, but it is confirmed to be morphologically different. Additional specimens are needed for further study (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species is likely a synonym of Yongeichthys viganensis (Z. Jaffar unpublished PhD Thesis, 2008), however, this is not yet formally recognised.
The placement of this species in the genus Acentrogobius requires confirmation (H.K. Larson pers. comm. 2019).
It is not clear if this is a valid species (H. Larson pers. comm. 2018).
The genus Oligolepis is under revision. This species is likely to belong to the genus Amoya (Pezold and Larson 2015).
This species has been rename Pseudogobius minima (Larson and Hammer in prep).
The name Cynoglossus semifasciatus has been wrongly applied to the commercial species on the Malabar coast, namely, C. macrostomus (Menon 1971, 1977).

There has been some taxonomic confusion between this species and Zebrias cochinensis. These taxonomic issues have not been fully resolved. At present, both nominal species are considered valid (Fricke et al. 2019).

Atlantic Surgeon, Acipenser oxyrinchus, is broadly thought to be closely related to, if not synonymous with, the European Sea Sturgeon, A. sturio (Artyukihn and Vescei 1999). This is due to the substantial morphological similarity of the two species (Vladykov and Greeley, 1963; Vasil’eva, 2010: fig. 3.2; but see Desse-Berset (2011a) for morphological characters separating the two species, and Panagiotopoulou et al. (2014) for methods of genetic discrimination). These species share similar karyotypes and cytogenetic features (Fontana et al. 2008) and in all cladistic-based analyses of sturgeon relationships using both morphological and molecular data, the two are recovered as sister-taxa. Vladykov (1955) distinguished the East Coast and Gulf of Mexico populations (separated by peninsular Florida) of A. oxyrinchus separate subspecies (East Coast populations designated the Atlantic Sturgeon, A. o. oxyrinchus, and the Gulf of Mexico populations designated the Gulf Sturgeon, A. o. desotoi) based on the length of the head, pectoral fins, and spleen and the development and shape of the scutes, a difference in number of gill rakers on the first arch, and a larger pyloric cecum.

Praschag et al. (2007, 2008) demonstrated that the widespread species Batagur baska comprised at least two genetically distinct species, and separated out B. affinis for the southern species occupying southern Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, and Sumatra in Indonesia, retaining the name B. baska for the more northern species from India, Bangladesh, and Myanmar.
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

The Dusky Shark is extremely similar genetically and morphologically to the Galapagos Shark (Carcharhinus galapagensis). These species share mitochondrial DNA haplotypes but are distinguishable based on single nuclear polymorphisms (SNPs) (Corrigan et al. 2017) and also occupy different habitats (insular vs. continental).

Carettochelys insculpta is the only surviving extant member of the genus Carettochelys and the family Carettochelyidae, a formerly widespread turtle family dating back to the Eocene and previously occurring across Asia and much of the rest of the globe. As such, it is considered a deep phylogenetic lineage with high-priority conservation needs, a so-called EDGE species (Evolutionarily Distinct, Globally Endangered). The common name in Indonesian Papua is Kura-kura Moncong Babi and the common name in Papua New Guinea is Piku.
This is the revised taxonomic concept of Centrophorus grandulosus, which includes C. lusitanucs as a junior synonym; C. lesliei and C. longipinnis are also now split out as newly recognised species.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).

Some confusion exists regarding the publication date of the description of S. occulta (Faria et al. 2014). Some taxonomic literature sources list 1991 as the publication date while others list 1992. This confusion is probably due to the distribution of pre-prints of the article in 1991 before the full issue of the journal was printed in 1992. According to The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, the publication date of the S. occulta description is 1991. There has also been discrepancy in referencing the species authority for S. occulta, particularly the name of the second author (Faria et al. 2014); K.G. da Silva’s surname has been spelled ‘da Silva’, ‘Da Silva’, and ‘Silva’. Faria et al. (2014) suggested using the one in the revisions by Vaz and Carvalho (2013) and in online taxonomic databases. Thus, the recommended citation is S. occulta Vooren & da Silva, 1991.

This species is comprised of two valid subspecies: Mustelus canis canis occurs on the continental shelf, whereas M. c. insularis occurs on insular shelves in the Caribbean (Heemstra 1997, Ebert et al. 2013).
The specific name for this taxon is sometimes also spelt as santipaulae, santipaule and santipauli.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

The Galapagos Shark is extremely similar genetically and morphologically to the Dusky Shark (Carcharhinus obscurus). These species share mitochondrial DNA haplotypes but are distinguishable based on single nuclear polymorphisms (SNPs) (Corrigan et al. 2017) and also occupy different habitats (insular vs. continental).
Genetics studies have led some researchers to suspect that there may be an undescribed species of Echinorhinus off Oman and elsewhere in the Arabian Sea region (Henderson et al. 2016).

Squalus mitsukurii was once considered a globally distributed species, but recent morphological and genetic work suggests the species is restricted to temperate waters of Japan and Korea, and is possibly endemic to the Northwest Pacific (Pfleger et al. 2018, Ziadi-Künzli et al. 2020). The resolution of the species-complex is ongoing with further species likely being described in the future.
There is a single extant species in the family Mitsukurinidae.

Yano and Musick (1992) showed that morphometric characters used to separate Pacific Pseudotriakis acrales Jordan & Snyder, 1904 from Atlantic P. microdon de Brito Capello, 1868 did not differ significantly, and these authors confirmed P. acrales as a junior synonym of P. microdon. Pseudotriakis is thus a mono-specific genus.

Soares et al. (2016) redescribed Scyliorhinus haekelii, placing S. besnardi Springer & Sadowsky, 1970 as a synonym. Species of Scyliorhinus were further reviewed and redescribed by Soares and De Carvalho (2019), who recognised 16 valid species. Soares and De Carvalho (2019) also revised the geographic distribution of S. haeckelii, restricting its range to the southwestern Atlantic from southern Bahia, Brazil, to northern Argentina.

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera bonasus, which can only be distinguished by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).
There are a number of errors in the original description (Hulley and Penrith 1966) which led Stehmann and Krefft (1988) to provide a detailed and accurate redescription.
The specific name has been misspelled and consistently used in the literature as Rhizoprionodon lalandei, but the original spelling R. lalandii should be retained.
This species is frequently mis-identified as Epinephelus malabaricus or E. tauvina in aquaculture and fisheries literature (Heemstra and Randall 1993).

The African Nile Crocodile is now recognized as two distinct species: one occupying eastern Africa, the Nile valley and southern Africa and retaining the name Crocodylus niloticus Laurenti, 1768; and the other occupying west and central Africa, including the Congo, Niger and Ogoue drainages and assigned to the existing name Crocodylus suchus Geoffroy, 1807 (Schmitz et al. 2003, Hekkala et al. 2011).  Red List assessments now treat these two taxa independently.
Gymnura micrura has been redescribed with G. lessae and G. sereti split out from G. micrura as separate species (Yokota and Carvalho 2017).

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera brasiliensis, which can only be distinguished from R. bonasus by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).

This species has been mistaken mainly for Dasyatis (=Hypanus) say but also for Dasyatis pastinaca in the past. The specific name has been misspelled as hipostigma, including in the original description.

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Until recently, the species name usually was spelled as sayi rather than say. This is not a synonymy, simply a change to conform to original spelling.

This Gulf of Mexico endemic species has sometimes been mistaken for the sympatric Dusky Smoothound (Mustelus canis) and Narrowfin Smoothhound (M. norrisi) in its limited offshore range (Heemstra 1997).
The western Atlantic and Pacific Ocean forms are thought to be different species (Ebert et al. 2013)
This species might be confused with the congener Cookiecutter Shark (Isistius brasiliensis).

Seigel et al. (1977) considered Squaliolus sarmenti and S. aliae as synonyms of S. laticaudus. Sasaki and Uyeno (1987) subsequently removed S. aliae from the synonymy as distinct and the genus now contains these two widely recognised species. Squaliolus laticaudus is sympatric with S. aliae in some regions.
The scientific name for this species is often misspelled as Carcharhinus perezii. Carcharhinus springeri Sadowsky & Amorim 1977 is considered a synonym (Soto 2001).
Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from C. porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.

Nurse sharks occurring in the eastern Pacific were formerly considered part of this species concept, however the Pacific Nurse Shark (Ginglymostoma unami) has now been formally described as a separate species (Del Moral-Flores et al. 2015).
Previously confused with the similar but smaller Etmopterus pusillus until described as a distinct species by Shirai and Tachikawa (1993).
This species is sometimes confused with Squalus clarkae and may be confused with recently described or undescribed species in the South Atlantic (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020).

Two subspecies are recognised and are considered junior synonyms: Plecoglossus altivelis chinensis Wu & Shan, 2005 (Shandong Province, China) and Plecoglossus altivelis ryukyuensis Nishida, 1988 (Ryukyu Islands, Japan).
Molecular studies are required to determine the level of genetic distinctness between the species in the Southwest Atlantic and the Southeast Pacific.

The spellings Dipturus trachyderma and Dipturus trachydermus have been used for this species. The basionym is Raja trachyderma and the valid name is Dipturus trachydermus following grammatical rules. While Fricke et al. (2019) use Dipturus trachyderma, we follow Last et al. (2016) which correctly uses Dipturus trachydermus.

Etmopterus baxteri Garrick, 1957 is a junior synonym of E. granulosus (Straube et al. 2015). Etmopterus tasmaniensis Myagkov & Pavlov, 1986 is a probable junior synonym of E. granulosus (Weigmann 2016).

Dipturus diehli Soto & Mincarone, 2001, as known only from the holotype taken off Santa Catarina, Brazil (29°39´S, 47°50´W) at a depth of 480 m, is likely a synonym of D. mennii and is treated here as such.

Based on geographical separation and differences in tooth row counts and coloration, Carvalho (1999) considered Narcine bancroftii and N. brasiliensis to be distinct species. However, intraspecific differences in tooth row counts among individuals of varying sizes were observed. Genetic analyses of Narcine specimens from throughout their range in the Western Atlantic Ocean are needed to confirm the presence of two species. Narcine bancrofti is a frequent misspelling of the species name.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted.

Bathytoshia formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis, which is now recognised as a valid species (Last et al. 2016); hence Dasyatis (Bathytoshia) centroura is now Bathytoshia centroura. This western Atlantic species is not conspecific with Bathytoshia of the eastern Atlantic (Last et al. 2016); the eastern Atlantic population that was formerly included within Dasyatis centroura is now included within B. lata (Last et al. 2016). The status of the single record from India is unknown.

Recent revisions have subdivided the previously wide-ranging Narcine brasiliensis into Narcine bancroftii (Griffith, 1834) which is widely distributed from North Carolina, USA, through parts of the Gulf of Mexico, the Caribbean Sea, the Greater Antilles, the Lesser Antilles and the northern coast of South America and Narcine brasiliensis (Olfers, 1831) which is endemic to the Southwest Atlantic in Brazil, Uruguay, and Argentina (Carvalho 1999, Last et al. 2016).
Treated by some authors under the genus Allepithema.
Treated by some authors under the genus Allepithema.
Treated by some authors under the genus Allepithema.
Treated by some authors under the genus Allepithema.
Treated by some authors under the genus Allepithema.
Treated by some authors under the genus Allepithema.

Hippopus hippopus has several common names, such as the horse’s hoof clam and strawberry clam. Unlike the Tridacna species, the Hippopus species lack hyaline organs (small pinhole eyes) in their mantles, which also do not extend over their shell margins, and they have a narrow byssal orifice with tight-fitting teeth. The thick shells of H. hippopus have strong radial ribbing and display reddish blotches in irregular bands. Their mantles usually exhibit green, yellow-brown or grey mottled patterns, and their incurrent siphon bears no guard tentacles.

Hippopus porcellanus was species described from the Sulu Archipelago, Philippines in 1982 (Rosewater 1982). Unlike the elaborate shells of H. hippopus, H. porcellanus has a smoother and thinner shell. This species may be easily mistaken for Tridacna derasa due to its similar shell shape and texture, but the mantles of H. porcellanus are generally grey or brown, lack hyaline organs, and the incurrent siphon has prominent guard tentacles. As with H. hippopus, the mantle does not extend beyond the shell margins, and there is a narrow byssal orifice.
The variability (morphological and ecological) reported for K. caucasica suggests that this is a complex of several species.

There has been much disagreement concerning the relationships of the one family placed in order Mugiliformes (Nelson 2006). Although reasons exist for regarding mugilids as perciform, rather than being related to the Atherinomorpha, there seems to be insufficient reason to change the classification from that given in Nelson (1994), based on Stiassny (1993) and Johnson and Patterson (1993) (Nelson 2006).

This species is treated by some authors as being a synonym of the more widespread Liza melinoptera (Valenciennes, 1836).
M. nonultimus (nape scaled) from Caspian basin, usually listed as a subspecies of M. batrachocephalus, is a distinct species. It does not enter freshwaters.

There are problems with the Order name and the correct placement of the family. The placement in the Order: Nerillida follows the 'Updated Pettibone' which is modified and adapted from J.A. Blake (1994): 50 [Taxonomic Atlas of the Benthic ... Santa Barbara Channel vol.4]. See:  http://biodiversity.uno.edu/~worms/pc-order.html.
Attention RLU: This species is now considered a synonym of Acropora millepora. For reference please see WoRMS: http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=207084. C. Linardich 4Jan2022
The complete mitogenome of this species is 17,886 bp with 13 protein-coding, two rRNA, and two tRNA genes, and this supports the transfer of this species to the family Acroporidae (Cho et al. 2018).
This species was placed in synonymy with Acropora acuminata by Wallace et al. (2012). However, these species are readily separable in the field and in museum collections (Veron et al. 2016).
{Attention RLU: Please change the family from Faviidae to Lobophylliidae. Reference is WoRMS. - C. Linardich 17Jan2022}

There is some taxonomic uncertainty associated with this species. Wallace (1999) considered this species as unresolved and it was not included in the revision of Acropora by Wallace et al. (2012). It is considered a valid species by Veron (2000), Veron et al. (2016) and the WoRMS online database (accessed June 2022).
Attention RLU: Please change the family from Euphyllidae to Merulinidae according to the WoRMS online database. - C. Linardich 12Jan2022

This species is possibly a synonym of Fungia fungites (B. Hoeksema pers. comm. 2008). Lyndon DeVantier considers Fungia puishani a valid species based on specimens observed and the specimen collected by him. According to the WoRMS online database (accessed January 2022), this species is valid.
This species is part of a species complex.
This species was previously unresolved, but is now considered a valid species (Ditlev 2003, N. Santodomingo pers comm. 2022).

This species, resembling Acropora gemmifera, was described in 2006. As Claereboudt (2006) did not designate a holotype, it is considered a nomen nudum (Veron et al. 2016, Hoeksema and Cairns 2019, WoRMS database accessed 5 January 2022). Nomen nudum means that the proposed taxonomic name is invalid because the group designated is not described or illustrated sufficiently for recognition, has no nomenclatural status, and consequently can be used as though never previously proposed.

The complete mitochondrial genome of this species has been sequenced (Terranao et al. 2018). Genome length consisted of 18,630 bp, with a base composition of 25.92% A, 13.28% T, 23.06% G, and 37.73% C. Consistent with other hard corals, this species' mitogenome was arranged in 13 protein-coding genes, 2 rRNA, and 2 tRNA genes. nad5 and cox1 contained embedded Group I Introns of 11,133 bp and 965 bp, respectively.

In the 2008 Red List assessment, a total of 75 extant and five extinct 'subpopulations' were identified across the natural range of O. nerka. In the 2011 Red List assessment, several of these subpopulations were further subdivided based on additional input from salmon specialists (Pacific Salmon Commission, PSC, and Fisheries and Oceans Canada, DFO), resulting in a total of 98 subpopulations, of which 93 are extant. The subpopulations in this assessment are considered independent and reproductively isolated from each other.

The assessors used a combination of ecoregional (i.e., marine and freshwater habitat-based) classification and the degree of genetic divergence between known spawning 'locations', using an FST value of 0.04, representing a threshold level of gene flow between putative 'subpopulations' of less than or equal to one effective migrant per year. The five extinct subpopulations were based on Gustafson et al. 2007. While the assessors acknowledge that it is not straightforward to ascribe demographic or geographic distinctness to a subpopulation based on observed genetic distances, they feel it is the most appropriate methodology given the scale of the assessment and the paucity of observations of stray rates among the spawning locations considered in this assessment.

authority: Pouyaud, Wirjoatmodjo, Rachmatika, Tjakrawidjaja, Hadiaty & Hadie, 1999
taxonomicNotes: This species is nearly identical in appearance to Latimeria chalumnae from the western Indian Ocean.
Previously recognized as Pleuronectes glacialis (Kells et al. 2016).

Molecular studies have revealed the existence of distinct northeast Atlantic and Mediterranean evolutionary lineages, which probably originated through allopatric isolation during the Pleistocene.

Some studies have suggested that these represent semi‐isolated species (i.e., independent lineages in which speciation remains incomplete) rather than differentiated populations of the same taxon. The two lineages hybridise throughout a post-glacial secondary contact zone located in the Alboran Sea, with a sharp divide at the Almeria-Oran Front (AOF). The AOF serves as a barrier by separating colder, less-saline Atlantic waters from the denser Mediterranean.

This phenomenon has generated a supplementary layer of genetic subdivision between Sea Bass inhabiting the eastern and western Mediterranean. Additional genetic diversity has been detected within individual Mediterranean basins, e.g., the Adriatic and Levantine seas, and is potentially present in the Black Sea.

Diagnosis based on Ladoga population (true C. widegreni). Baltic, Swedish (C. polonica) populations referred to this species are probably misidentified as they are shallow water, small-sized species (up to about 200 mm SL), while the true C. widegreni is a deep-water, large size species. Coregonus polonica might be a valid species but more research is needed.
In need of critical taxonomic revision; several species seem to be confused under the name P. flesus.
Was initially described as a subspecies of M. rutila.

There has been much disagreement concerning the relationships of the one family placed in order Mugiliformes (Nelson 2006). Although reasons exist for regarding mugilids as perciform, rather than being related to the Atherinomorpha, there seems to be insufficient reason to change the classification from that given in Nelson (1994), based on Stiassny (1993) and Johnson and Patterson (1993) (Nelson 2006). A recent molecular phylogeny of grey mullets by Durand & Borsa (2015) has erected the genus Myxus to Pseudomyxus.

Sub species:
leniusculus (Signal crayfish): Astacus leniusculus was placed on the Official List of Specific Names in Zoology, name number 2244, in Opinion 855 of the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature. (See Melville, 1968: 84).
klamathensis (Klamath Signal Crayfish)
trowbridgii: (Columbia River Signal Crayfish)

Recent genetic studies (Crandall lab) suggest that these different subspecies are in fact distinct.  Thus the P. klamathensis and P. trowbridgii might themselves be endangered whereas the P. leniusculus is more broad spread and indeed an invasive.

Both Smith (1961) and Gon and Randall (2003) doubt the validity of Foa madagascariensis because of inconsistencies in Petit’s description. The two syntypes used by Petit to describe the species, have apparently been lost (Bauchot and Desoutter 1986).

Chelinus trilobatus is a misspelling of the species name that should not be used (FishBase 2008).

Cheilinus trilobatus has similar colouration to C. chlorourus and been misidentified as C. chlorourus (Myers 1991; Carpenter and Niem 2001).
The family placement of this species is uncertain (W. Eschmeyer pers. comm. 2009).
Synonymous with Coelorinchus labiatus, however C. occa may be the separate species found in the western Atlantic (Marshall 1973)
A taxonomic revision of the Bathygobius genus is needed.
Miller and Stefanni (2001) recognized a different subspecies at each of its three known localities: Bathygobius lineatus arundelii, B. l. lineatus and B. l. lupinus, respectively.
This species may be a synonym of Thamnaconus multilineatus (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2009).

The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

This species is part of a complex of similar species. Apogon semilineatus appears to be restricted to the northwest Pacific from Hong Kong to southern Japan in the Ogasawara Islands. Records from other localities are probably misidentifications, but further study is required (G.R. Allen and O. Gon. pers. comm. 2009).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).
Gon (1990) states that Bathydraco joannae and Bathydraco antarcticus may infact be synonymous and there is little evidence to separate them.

It is likely that this species represents a species complex with one or more distinct species in the Caribbean region.  The nominal species occurs in southeastern Brazil (J. Williams pers. comm. 2009).

Fernholm and Hubbs (1981) discussed and presented a photograph of a specimen (USNM 218400) named "Eptatretus sp. C" off the north coast of Haiti, which they were hesitant to describe as new until more material become available. Hensley (1985) re-examined this specimen and concluded that, in spite of some meristic variations, it could be identified as E. mendozai.
Thalassobathia pelagica was moved from family Bythitidae to the family Ophiidae by Nielsen et al. (2010).
In the tropical Eastern Pacific, Caranx crysos is replaced by Caranx caballus (Günther 1869)
The taxonomy of this genus is under revision.
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).
There may be genetic differences between the three fragmented populations of this species (R. Fricke pers. comm. 2008).

This name used to be applied to a species widely distributed in the central-west Pacific. Recently, genetic evidence indicates that this name should only be used for the Hawaiian Islands population, with the remaining populations now considered part of H. claudia (Randall & Rocha, 2009).
The taxonomy and key characteristics of Brama spp. are in need of review (FAO ECA guide in prep RL Haedrich).

This species is often confused with Ostorhinchus aureus (R. Fricke pers. comm. 2008).

According to Allen and Erdmann (2013), this species is valid as Ostorhinchus fleurieu.
Heteroclinus fasciatus is a synonym of Heteroclinus whiteleggii (Ogilby 1894).
Early records (before  Munro 1943) were recorded under Scomberomorus guttatus.

What is currently known as Acyrtops amplicirrus may be two distinct species; one from the western Caribbean and one from Florida. The differences between the two sub-populations are slight, and may be due to environmental factors; a synoptic study is needed to clarify the taxonomy of this (these) species (Johnson and Greenfield 1983). A revision of the Acyrtops genus is currently underway; some workers question the validity of A. amplicirrus and its distribution is not clearly understood as a result (K. Conway pers. comm. 2015).
This nominal species may be a junior synonym of A. tomentosus (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2009).
There are multiple undescribed species in this group which may have been confused with this species (Moore, Polanco, Russell, McEachran pers. comm. 2013).

Formerly believed to have a widespread Western Pacific distribution but apparently restricted to southern Japan (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2009). Populations from other areas are currently assignable to A. jenkinsi (Everman and Seale 1907).
Creediidae tauensis may be conspecific with Chalixodytes chameleontoculis of the western Indian Ocean (J. Nelson pers. comm. 2009). There is doubt as to whether this is in fact a valid species.
There is doubt on the conspecificity of the second specimen of this species (Stein 2006).
Potential taxonomic problem: Amphichthys hildebrandi (Breder 1925) may be a valid species, although Collette (2003) considered it as a junior synonym of A. cryptocentrus.
There is some genetic differentiation between samples from the Atlantic and those from the Mediterranean, but not at the species level (Vinas et al. 2010).

The synonymy of Chromis bermudae under C. flavicauda was recently revisited by Smith-Vaniz and Collette (2013). They concluded that C. bermudae is a valid species, therefore, C. flavicauda is now known only from Brazil.

This species also seems to be sympatric with Macroramphosus gracilis around the world (Dyer and Westneat 2010). However, there is still some debate about the taxonomic separation of the two species (Granadeiro and Silva 2000). The latest research suggests that M. gracilis represents a different ontological stage of M. scolopax rather than a separate species (Robalo et al. 2009, Noguchi et al. 2015), and this approach is followed here.

However, Noguchi et al. (2016) have foreshadowed that it is likely two different species in the Atlantic and Pacific. Noting that M. scolopax was described from the Mediterranean and that M. gracilis was described from Madeira in the eastern Atlantic, there is probably an undescribed species from the Pacific. The description of this Pacific species of Macroramphosus may be forthcoming from Noguchi et al., but this needs to be confirmed with those authors.
This species was given the alternative classification Bathycallionymus whiteheadi by Nakabo (1982).

This species has been divided into several subspecies (Shakhovskoy 2007): Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus pinnatibarbus (Bennett 1831), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus altipennis (Valenciennes 1847), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus californicus (Cooper 1863), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus japonicus (Franz 1910), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus melanocercus (Ogilby 1885).

The temporal and spatial genetic structure of this species, or species complex, is still under debate, and presents challenges for fisheries management. Clupea harengus stocks have traditionally been delineated on the basis of differences in spawning behavior and meristic or morphological characters. However, there is little concordance between these characters and genetic differentiation (André et al. 2011, Ruzzante et al. 2006, Ryman et al. 1984, Clausen et al. 2007). Morphological differences may be expressions of phenotypic plasticity resulting from early ontogentic exposure to differing environmental regimes (Anokina 1971, Aneer 1985, Rajasilta 1992). The extent to which there is genetic differentiation between NW and NE Atlantic is unresolved. 

In the NE Atlantic, there is some structuring between the population in the English Channel and that found in the remainder of the North Sea (Mariani et al. 2005). Concordant structuring has been found between the North Sea and Baltic spawning populations, and it is hypothesized that the relatively low salinity in the Baltic Sea is driving this divergence (Ruzzante et al. 2006; Bekkevold et al. 2005; Mariani et al. 2005; Larsson et al. 2007, 2010). Spring-spawning populations and autumn spawning populations within the Baltic Sea appear to differ from each other morphologically (Heincke 1898) and genetically (Jøgensen et al. 2005); however, genetic variation within the Baltic Sea is generally low (Johannesson and André 2006). Additionally, there is structuring between the northern and southern populations within the largest, most commercially important stock, the Norwegian Spring spawning stock, which is found in the Barents and Norwegian Sea (Shaw et al. 1999, Reiss et al. 2009). 

The Baltic herring Clupea harengus membras is widely regarded as subspecies of the Atlantic herring Clupea harengus. Baltic herring as a subspecies includes populations of autumn-spawning herrings mainly in the western and southern Baltic Sea and spring-spawning herring mainly in the eastern and northern parts of the sea basin. There is wide overlap in the distribution of the different forms (HELCOM Red List Project). Differences between the two forms (spatial distribution, meristic and morphometric, temporal spawning) are not supported by genetic differentiation when using either allozyme or microsatellite markers. However, some studies employing high-throughput sequencing revealed high levels of genetic differentiation at loci which may under selection, which may suggest the existence of locally adapted populations within the Baltic Sea which are connected by some gene flow (Corander et al. 2013).
This species may be a junior synonym of Amblyeleotris delicatulus (Smith, 1958); However, Smith’s type specimen is not in good condition so this cannot yet be verified (H.K. Larson pers. comm. 2015).
Previously in Remorina, but is currently placed in Remora (Gray et al. 2009).
Closely related to Anampses lineatus from the Indian Ocean (Kuiter 2002).
Closely related to Apogon cyanosoma (Bleeker 1853). DNA studies are required to verify the validity of this species (G.R. Allen and O. Gon pers. comm. 2009).
Atherion elymus is comprised of three subspecies; Atherion elymus aphrozoicus, Atherion elymus freyi, and Atherion elymus asper.
Western Atlantic species of this genus are in need of revision (E. Murdy pers. comm. 2009 and F. Pezold pers. comm. 2011).
Although in appearance this species resembles the juvenile Cirripectes polyzona, it is most closely related to Cirripectes filamentosus.

The Hawaiian population is likely a distinct species (Randall and Rocha 2008 submitted). Kuiter 2002 describes the Indian Ocean subpopulation as H. schwartzii (Bleeker 1847), but there is no formal authority for this.
This species has been described as belonging to a species complex. Other members of this species complex include Starksia ocellata, S. culebrae, S. brasiliensis, S. variabilis, and S. occidentalis.
