Entomacrodus stellifer used to be considered to have two sub-species; Entomacrodus stellifer stellifer and Entomacrodus stellifer lighti, but Entomacrodus stellifer lighti is now considered to be a separate species.
Specimens from the Marquesas Island lack the vertical black bars (Pyle 2001).

This species was described from the middle and southern Caspian Sea; but no syntypes were found for review by Logvinenko and Starobogatov (1968) (Kantor et al. 2009). The species is in need of taxonomic review as few of these species have had their generic status established by data other than conchological data.
The status of this species is uncertain, and it may be conspecific with a more widespread European species.

This species requires a taxonomic review. It maybe conspecific with Mercuria bayonensis, as there is no anatomical information given in Falker et al. (2002); the main differentiation is shell size and the two species have ranges that lie adjacent to each other. It is assessed here as it is considered as a good species by Falkner et al. (2002), who synonymises Amnicola lanceolata Paladilhe 1869 described from St-Jean de Luz (Pyrénées-Atlantiques).
Also known as Ecrobia vitrea (Risso, 1826), which is considered a subgenus by some authors and a genus by others.

There is some doubt as to the validity of this species. Pavon and Bertrand (2009) placed it in synonym with H. stagnorum, another widespread species in the Mediterranean, although it is currently accepted as a valid species by MolluscaBase (2020).

The officially accepted name for this species is Ecrobia ventrosa (Montagu, 1803). A close relationship between North American and European taxa of the H. ventrosa clade has been suggested by Wilke et al. (2000) although this relationship has not been tested at a molecular level. Some have considered that this group merits generic standing as ventrosa, however the use of a separate genus to distinguish this species is contentious and Haase (1993) considered this to be unjustified on genetic distance criteria.

Two subspecies are recognised;

Hydrobia acuta ssp. acuta (Draparnaud 1805), and
Hydrobia acuta ssp. neglecta Muus, 1963.
The species has been listed as a synonym of Heleobia stagnorum (Gofas et al. 2001). MolluscaBase (2022) maintains it as a distinct species.

This species has been placed into various genera (including Hybrobia and Semisalsa) and although it currently resides in Heleobia, further work - probably on a molecular level - is needed to resolve taxonomic uncertainties. Bank (2004) includes this species in the subgenus Semisalsa Radoman, 1974. There is further confusion as to the distribution of this species due to confusion with Hydrobia ventrosa; as Barnes (1994) points out "virtually all continental records of [this species]" refer to H. ventrosa.
This is listed as a valid species by MolluscaBase (2022) and as a synonym of Heleobia stagnorum in Gofas et al. (2001).

There is disagreement over the nomenclature of this species.  Marceniuk and Menezes (2007) regard the species as Cochlefelis insidiator (Kailola, 2000), whereas both Kailola (2004) and Hoese and Gates (2006) place this species in Hemiarius.
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists before 2008 under the generic name Papillogobius.
This species has been confused with Raja montagui and Raja polystigma in the Mediterranean Sea (Bertozzi et al. 2003).

The taxonomy of Ruppia is not completely clear and there are some anomalous populations (e.g. in western Ireland) which do not conform well to described taxa.

Ruppia drepanensis Tineo has been assessed separately; it is considered a Mediterranean species from temporary brackish pools and wetlands. It has been confused with R. cirrhosa (Petagna) Grande, but is maintained as a valid species following Talavera and Garcia-Murillo (2010).
The taxonomy of Ruppia is not completely clear and there are some anomalous populations (e.g. in western Ireland) which do not conform well to described taxa.
This species has formerly been included within Chaetodon modestus (now Roa modestus).
This species is a synonym with Hemitaurichthy multispinus. Hemitaurichthy multispinosus was named in 1975, H. multispinus was named in 1978. Hemitaurichthy multispinosus is the valid species name.

The taxonomic status of populations recorded from areas in the eastern parts of the range (e.g.the Marshall Islands) needs further research to better understand the presence of this species in these areas.
This species is easily confused with Heniochus diphreutes.
Closely related to Chaetodon decussatus and pictus (latter formerly regarded as a synonym).

The Red Sea population generally lacks the dark spot on the soft dorsal fin. This population has been described as the sub-species C. auriga setifer Ahl 1923. However most recent authors regard it a conspecific with C. auriga.
This species has formerly been included within Chaetodon modestus (now Roa modestus).
Was previously treated as a synonym of Chaetodon vagabundus Linnaeus, 1758.

Very similar to Prognathus falcifer, which is found in the northern part of the eastern tropical Pacific region. Genetic and morphological studies are needed to confirm whether specifically distinct from P. falcifer.
Records in the Indian Ocean west of Cocos Keeling are based on its sister species Chaetodon falcula.
Pacific populations formerly referred to as Chaetodon trifasciatus are now considered to be distinct as Chaetodon lunulatus.

Chaetodon modestus is the oldest available name for this species. Sometimes it is broken up into three separate species, C. modestus has a broad Pacific Ocean distribution, C. jayakari is found in the Indian Ocean and the Red Sea and C. excelsa is found in Hawaii and Marianas Islands. Currently, all three species are placed under the genus Roa.
This species is frequently confused with Heniochus acuminatus.
This species has formerly been considered to be a subspecies of Chaetodon unimaculatus.

Chaetodon tinkeri is here defined as comprising the Hawaiian, Johnston Atoll and Raratonga populations. The taxonomic status of populations recorded from areas in the western parts of the range needs further taxonomic research.

Very similar to Prognathus carlhubbsi, which is found in the southern part of the eastern tropical Pacific region. Genetic and morphological studies are needed to confirm whether specifically distinct from P. carlhubbsi.
Widely cited in the literature as Chaetodon trifasciatus, a species now regarded as being restricted to the Indian Ocean and Coral Triangle.
Previously lumped with C. plebeius.
Indian Ocean records west of Coco-Keeling, Christmas Island and Java are based on the sister species Chaetodon interruptus.
This species is often included within the genus Paracentropyge (R. Pyle pers. comm. 2009).
Specimens of this species may be the adult male form of Chaetodontoplus septentrionalis, or might possibly represent hybrids (Carpenter and Niem 1999).

The entire population in Bermuda, Florida Keys, and the east coast of Florida may consist of hybrids between this species and Holacanthus ciliaris (L. Rocha pers. comm. 2009).

H. bermudensis and H. passer may, in fact, be sister species (thus potentially breaking up the subgenera Plitops and Angelichthys) (Alva-Campbell et al. 2010)
Apolemichthys armitagei Smith, 1955, is a hybrid between A. trimaculatus and A. xanthurus (Pyle and Randall 1994).
Apolemichthys armitagei Smith, 1955, is a hybrid between A. trimaculatus and A. xanthurus (Pyle and Randall 1994).

Some populations (e.g. Fiji and Coral Sea) have a black marking on the soft dorsal fin and are sometimes referred to as a different species Centropyge woodheadi, however most taxonomists do no consider these populations to be a distinct (L. Rocha and R. Pyle pers. comm. 2009).
An unusually coloured population of what appears to be this species occurs at Rowley Shoals off Western Australia and may represent a distinct species (Debelius et al. 2003).
Indian Ocean and Pacific Ocean populations may represent separate species.
This species has previously been considered to be a colour form of Chaetodontoplus melanosoma (Steene 1978).
Populations from the Indian Ocean have slight colour differences and are possibly a distinct species (L. Rocha pers. comm. 2009).
Holacanthus ciliaris are closely related to blue angelfish Holacanthus bermudensis Goode, and colouration is the only reliable character to separate these species (Feeley et al. 2009).
The species Chaetodontoplus poliourus was recently separated from C. mesoleucus (Randall and Rocha 2009).

The Pacific and Indian Ocean population of this species may eventually be regarded as distinct species based on differences in colour patterns and potential genetic differences (R. Pyle pers. comm. 2009).
This species is often included within the genus Paracentropyge.

The year of publication of this species is frequently given as 1838, and the species was first assessed with that year of publication. The publication year has been revised to 1836 following MolluscaBase (2021).
The mis-applied name Hyporhampus gaimardi has frequently been used for this species in the Persian Gulf and adjacent waters (B. Collette pers. comm. 2013).
Ayarnangra estuarius was described from the Irrawaddy delta (Roberts 2001).

There is considerable confusion surrounding the identity of Gobiopterus chuno and a taxonomic revision of the genus is badly needed. At the present moment, this appears to be a catch-all taxon for which populations from throughout south and southeast Asia have been lumped. It is likely that a close study would reveal the presence of more than a single species lumped under this taxon.

Three species of Acanthus were recorded in the mangroves of South China, including Acanthus ebracteatus Vahl, Acanthus ebracteatus var. xiamenensis (R.T.Zhang) C.Y.Wu & C.C.Hu (Deng et al. 2006.) and Acanthus ilicifolius L. However, Acanthus ebracteatus var. xiamenensis has been combined with Acanthus ilicifolius in 2008 (Hou and Lu 2008). Only Acanthus ilicifolius is recorded in the Pearl River Region.
This a member of the Halophila ovalis complex, which is under taxonomic review. Historically, other species currently considered to be in this complex may have been labelled as H. ovalis.
The placement of this species within the genus Centropyge is uncertain (R. Pyle pers. comm. 2009).
This species was known as M. andamanicus prior to 1990.
This species has been confused with P. guttatus (Vianna 1986).
This species continues to be confused with S. brasiliensis (Rathbun 1906), due to their similar colour patterns and locally sympatric distributions (Tavares et al. 2009).

There are two recognized subspecies for the species. Panulirus argus argus is found north of the equator and Panulirus argus westonii is found south of the equator in Brazil, however this is an invalid name (Sarver, Silberman and Walsh, 1998).
Fischer and Bianchi (1984) mention that this species may possibly be synonymous with N. stewarti, however no other authors have confirmed this.
This species was previously known as one species (Thenus orientalis), but now has been split into five separate species (Burton and Davie 2007).
Homarus capensis as described by Herbst (1792) has been changed to Homarinus capensis (Kornfield et al. 1995).
FAO states that this species was not formally distinguished from P. antarcticus (Holthuis 1991).

In Hawaii this species has many common names including: Royal Slipper Lobster, King's Hawaiian Lobster, Shovel-nosed Lobster, Spanish Lobster and Ula-papapa (Holthuis 1991).

This species very closely resembles A. guineensis, and at one time they were believed to be conspecific (Holthuis 2006).

There are three sub-species: P. homarus homarus found throughout the range; P. homarus megasculpta is known only from the northern Arabian Sea; and P. homarus rubellus is found southern East Africa, from Mozambique to Natal and southeast Madagascar (Holthuis 1991).
Before 1991, specimens of this species were considered to belong to M. japonicus (Holthuis 1991).
Justitia japonica is now known as Nupalirus japonicus (Chan 2010).
This species was once synonymized by Holthuis (1966) with Puerulus angulatus but this was shown to be incorrect by Berry (1969) (Holthuis 1991).

Chan et al. (2009) recently showed that the banded and non-banded forms of Metanephrops thomsoni were widely, genetically divergent. The banded (widespread) form is now treated as a distinct species and named after a recent fossil, Wongastacia taiwanica Hu, 1983, while the non-banded (Philippines) form remains M. thomsoni (see also Tshudy et al. 2007).
This species was split into two species. Past records referring to I. ciliatus south of the Philippines are now I. pubescens, although both species occur in the Philippines (Chan, 1997).
Holthuis (1991) states that this species has previously been confused with P. antarcticus.
This species is also known as the slipper lobster (Boyko 2003).
The species has often been confused with N. atlantica and most, if not all, records of N. atlantica from the Indo-West Pacific region refer to the present species (Holthuis 1991).
The Australian stock was previously known as Jasus novaehollandiae.
Justitia mauritiana is now a synonym of this species.

Although originally classified as Panulirus femoristriga (von Martens, 1872), this species was later included within P. longipes (Milne-Edwards, 1868) as a subspecies, P. l. femoristriga. Recent morphological and allozyme analysis showed that in fact there were two cryptic forms of P. l. femoristriga, and assigned a new species P. albiflagellum Chan & Chu, 1996 to one of them. Later work (Chan and Ng 2001) revealed that P. albiflagellum is conspecific with the holotype of P. femoristriga, and P. l. femoristriga was synonymized with P. longipes bispinosus Borradaile, 1899. Further molecular work supports this distinction based on nucleotide sequence divergence (Ravago and Juinio-Meñez 2002, Chow et al. 2006a).

In Australia this species is known by many local names including: Red Flapjack, Squat Crayfish, Southern Shovel-nosed Cray, South-eastern Shovel-nosed Crayfish and South-eastern Squat Crayfish.

In New Zealand this species is known locally as the Spanish Lobster (Holthuis 1991).
This species is comprised of two subspecies: Palinurus longipes longipes and Palinurus longipes bispinosus (Chan and Ng 2001).
This species is regarded as a living fossil, with very similar fossils dating from the Jurassic period. There is a debate on whether it is part of the coral lobsters or the spiny lobsters.

The Pacific Chub Mackerel (Scomber japonicus) has a Pacific distribution and is replaced in the Atlantic by Scomber colias (Scoles et al. 1998, Collette 1999, Catanese et al. 2010). Microsatellite and mitochondrial cyt b confirm that Scomber australasicus and S. japonicus are also separate species (Tzeng et al. 2009). Scomber japonicus is apparently absent from Indonesia and Australia, where it is replaced by Scomber australasicus (Collette 2001). The population from the Red Sea and northern Indian Ocean (the Gulf of Aden and Oman) is Scomber australasicus (Baker and Collette 1998). Morphological and genetic data distinguish the Atlantic Chub Mackerel from the Pacific Chub Mackerel (Infante et al. 2007).
Confused with the eastern Atlantic T. belone until described as a distinct species by Robins and de Sylva (1963).
Before 1983, this species was sometimes confused with Grammatorcynus bilineatus (Collette and Nauen 1983).

The Indo-Pacific King Mackerel was mis-identified as Korean Seerfish in India until the Indian ichthyologist Muthiah Devaraj (1976) recognized the distinctness of the two species (Collette and Graves 2019).
A revision of Scomberomorus was conducted by Collette and Russo (1985).

The Plain Bonito has been placed in seven different genera - Scomber, Cybium, Pelamys, Orcynopsis, Thynnus, Pelamichthys, and Gymnosarda - over its more than 250-year history but is morphologically distinct enough to have its own monotypic genus, Orcynopsis (Postel 1950, Collette and Chao 1975).

Three species have often been confused with S. maculatus, namely: Scomberomorus tritor in the eastern Atlantic; S. sierra in the eastern Pacific; and S. brasiliensis in the Caribbean and along the Atlantic coast of Central and South America (Banford et al. 1999).

The first good study of the Island Mackerel was as the mis-identified Pneumatophorus australasicus from the Philippines (Manacop 1958). Three out of four molecular studies (Jamaluddin et al. 2010, Basheer et al. 2015, Muto et al. 2016) indicate that the Island Mackerel is the basal species of the three species of Rastrelliger.

Sometimes, erroneously, this species has been considered a synonym of the western Atlantic Scomberomorus maculatus but  it is a valid species closely related to that species, and to the other Gulf Spanish mackerel, S. concolor, (Collette and Russo 1985, Banford et al. 1999, Bayona-Vásquez et al. 2015).
This species has been erroneously considered as a synonym of Scomberomorus maculatus by many authors (Collette and Russo 1985).

Although once considered a subspecies of the Pacific Chub Mackerel, several morphological and molecular studies have confirmed that the Blue Mackerel is a distinct species, generally separated from the Pacific Chub Mackerel (Scoles et al. 1998, Infante et al. 2007, Catanese et al. 2010). The population in the Red Sea and the Arabian Sea formerly considered to be Scomber japonicus were re-identified as Scomber australasicus (Baker and Collette 1998). This population was described as a separate species, Scomber indicus by Abdussamad et al. 2016 is considered as a subspecies here.
This species was confused with S. niphonius from Munro (1943) until it was described by Collette and Russo (1980).
Recent genetic information suggests that this species is one highly connected population worldwide (Garber et al. 2005, Theisen et al. 2008).
Although the most distinct genetically of the four species of spearfishes (Collette et al. 2006, Hanner et al. 2011), this species was only recently confirmed as a valid species (Shivji et al. 2006).

Literature records before1978 for Scomberomorus maculatus from the Caribbean and the Atlantic coasts of Central and South America apply to Scomberomorus brasiliensis, which were previously indentified as Scomberomorus maculatus by many authors (Collette and Russo 1985, Banford et al. 1999).
This species was redescribed three times in the same publication by Cuvier (1831).
This species has been described four times in three different monotypic genera.
In India this species was confused with Scomberomorus lineolatus until 1976 (Devaraj 1976).

Prior to 1960, many authors have used the name Auxis thazard as including Auxis rochei in the belief that there was only a single worldwide species of Auxis. This species contains two subspecies: the widespread Auxis rochei rochei and the Eastern Pacific Auxis thazard brachydorax (Collette and Aadland 1996).
This species may be misidentified as Scomberomorus niphonius in southern China.
The Papuan Seerfish is the smallest and least known of all the Spanish mackerels and has very few references since its original description (Collette and Graves 2019).

This species has been confused with Scomberomorus lineolatus and with Scomberomorus guttatus (and one of its junior synonyms Scomberomorus leopardus). The primary source of published biological information is based on observations in Zanzibar as S. lineolatus (Williams 1960).

This species is frequently misidentified as juvenile or female of Coryphaena hippurus.

The specific name is sometimes misspelled as equisetis instead of equiselis (Gibbs and Collette 1959).

Two subspecies are recognized: Sarda chiliensis lineolata occurs from Alaska to the tip of Baja California and the southwest Gulf of California, and the Revillagigedo Islands. Sarda chiliensis chiliensis occurs from Ecuador to Chile (Collette and Chao 1975).

In Madagascar and east Africa, this species name has been used for the Queen Mackerel, Scomberomorus plurilineatus. Scomberomorus lineolatus was considered a hybrid between S. commerson and S. guttatus by Srinivasa Rao and Lakshmi (1993, 1996) but Collette (1994) refuted this.

Some authors have placed the other three species of the genus Scomber in a separate genus, Pneumatophorus, based on their possession of a swim bladder that is absent in the Atlantic Mackerel, but all four species are currently included in Scomber.

Before 1960, many researchers thought that there was only one world-wide species in the genus Auxis, which was recorded as Auxis thazard (Collette and Aaland, 1996).

The species contains two subspecies;  A. rochei rochei (Risso, 1810) worldwide except for the eastern tropical Pacific where it is replaced by A. r. eudorax Collette and Aadland, 1996.
Early records of this species from Australia refer to Scomberomorus munroi (Collette and Russo 1985).
This species is now recognized as distinct from the Indo-Pacific Scomber japonicus (Collette 1999, Infante et al. 2007, Catanese et al. 2010, Cheng et al. 2011).
Before 1983, often confused in the literature with Grammatorcynus bicarinatus (Collette and Nauen 1983).
Aplocheilus blockii was described by Arnold (1911) from Sri Lanka.

Ambassis dussumieri Cuvier was described from Malabar, India (Cuvier and Valenciennes 1828). Although two species, A. bleekeri (from Indonessia) and A. denticulata (from Egypt) are placed under the synonymy of A. dussumieri, it is highly unlikely that these are conspecific. Further taxonomic studies, preferably involving molecular techniques, are essential.
Parambassis thomassi was originally described as Ambassis thomassi by Day (1870) from Calicut and Mangalore, India.
Parambassis dayi was originally described as Ambassis dayi by Bleeker (1874) from Cochin (Kochi), Kerala, India.
Stenothyra monilifera was described as Nematura monilifera.
This species is part of the P. ostenfeldii complex and is therefore treated as a separate species (Kuo and Cambridge 1984). This species is currently undergoing taxonomic review.

This species has recently been split from Zostera tasmanica (Kuo 2005). Previous records will be listed under this species. The genus for this species is currently published as Zostera (Les et al. 2002) although it is often still referred to as Heterozostera and Nanozostera.

The taxonomy of the Ruppia genus is uncertain due to difficulties of identification. The taxonomy of the Ruppia genus is confused. These species can be extremely morphologically variable and respond differently to differing environmental conditions. Therefore, species identifications often link to differences in environmental conditions.

This species was first observed in the1950s by Phillips (1960) when he misidentified this species as H. baillonis. It was then collected in 1980 and described as a new species (Eiseman and McMillan 1980). There is some controversy with this species in that genetic analysis showed that H. johnsonii is genetically very similar to H. ovalis, which is an Indo-Pacific species (Waycott et al. 2006, Short et al. 2010), suggesting that H. johnsonii may be an introduced representative of H. ovalis, a concept strengthened by the fact that only female plants have been found.

Halophila euphlebia has recently been recognized as distinct by Uchimura et al. (2006, 2008); however, previous evidence suggested that it is possibly a synonym of H. ovalis (McMahon 2005) or H. major (Kua et al. 2006).
Halophila sulawesii is a very newly described species (Kuo 2007), with no genetic information.
Halodule pinifolia is sometimes confused with Halodule uninervis.
Halodule pinifolia is sometimes confused with this species.

The taxonomy of this species is questionable and it is listed as a synonym of H. wrightii (Hammel et al. 2003). Its taxonomic status is based on leaf-tip morphology which is highly variable (Larkum et al. 2006).
This species is a member of the P. australis complex (P. australis Hook.f., P. sinuosa Cambridge & J.Kuo, P. angustifolia Cambridge & J.Kuo) (Campey et al. 2000).

Halodule ciliata was originally described as Diplanthera ciliata. Current taxonomic status is unclear, as for most other Halodule species, until studies which combine examination of type material, descriptions of leaf tip morphology and genetic analyses are carried out.  Analysis of the type specimen at the US Natural History Herbarium shows a distinctly different leaf and leaf tip morphology compared to any of the other Halodule species (den Hartog 1970, F. Short per.obs.). However Woodson et al (1975) elected to include Halodule ciliata under Halodule wrightii in their Flora of Panama.
This species is a member of the P. australis complex (P. australis Hook.f., P. sinuosa Cambridge & J.Kuo, P. angustifolia Cambridge & J.Kuo) (Campey et al. 2000).

(Creed and Samper-Villarreal, 2019). However, there is no taxonomic uncertainty regarding the identity of either one of these species (Kuo, 2020). Both species have erect shoots with two scales at the base and two more approximately halfway the stem, with two (H. baillonii) or 3-4 (H. engelmannii) pairs of leaves in a pseudo-whorl at the top. Leaf size and morphology differ perceptibly between the species (Den Hartog, 1970).
Halophila hawaiiana is a member of the Halophila ovalis complex, and is under taxonomic review.
Cymodocea angustata may be included within Cymodocea rotundata.
Zostera geojeensis may be conspecific with Zostera caespitosa.

The taxonomy of this species is questionable and it may eventually be found as conspecific with Halodule wrightii. Its taxonomic status is based on leaf-tip morphology which is highly variable (Larkum et al. 2006).
This species has been reclassified as Nanozostera (Tomlinson and Posluzny 2001), although here it is retained in the genus Zostera.
This species is a member of the P. australis complex (P. australis Hook.f., P. sinuosa Cambridge & J.Kuo, P. angustifolia Cambridge & J.Kuo) (Campey et al. 2000).
This species is part of the P. ostenfeldii complex and is therefore treated as a separate species (Kuo and Cambridge 1984). This species is currently undergoing taxonomic review.

The taxonomy of the Ruppia genus is confused. These species can be extremely morphologically variable and respond differently to differing environmental conditions. Therefore, species identifications often link to differences in environmental conditions. This species is potentially a synonym of Ruppia maritima. Flower morphology and genetic studies are needed to evaluate the distribution limits of this species (Larkum et al. 2006).
This species has often been confused with Halophila ovalis. Halophila decipiens is monoecious, has serrate leaf tips and hairs on both sides of its leaves.

The genus for this species is currently published as Zostera (Les et al. 2002) although it is often still referred to as Heterozostera which is a synonym.

Genetic data and analysis is needed.

This species has recently been split from Zostera tasmanica (Kuo 2005). Previous records will be listed under Zostera tasmanica and Heterozostera tasmanica. The genus for this species is currently published as Zostera (Les et al. 2002) although it is often still referred to as Heterozostera.  It has also been formerly been listed as a synonym of Z. marina (Jacobs and Les 2009). No genetic data is available as of yet.

This species was moved to Nanozostera by Tomlinson and Posluzny (2001), although here it is retained in the genus Zostera following Uotila (2009) and The Plant List (2015). Genetic information is needed.

The taxonomy of the Ruppia genus is uncertain due to difficulties of identification. Species can be extremely morphologically variable and respond to differing environmental conditions. Problems in species identification are linked to differences in environmental conditions.
Cymodocea rotundata may include the species Cymodocea angustata
Halophila capricorni may be a variant of H. decipiens; taxonomic clarification is required.

This species is a member of the Halophila ovalis complex.  It is listed as a synonym of H. gaudichadii and some consider H. minor as a synonym of H. ovata. Here it is retained as species until the taxonomy is clarified.

This species is part of the P. ostenfeldii complex and is therefore treated as a separate species (Kuo and Cambridge 1984). This species is currently undergoing taxonomic review.

Campey et al. (2000) suggested that P. robertsoniae is synonymous with P. coriacea and P. coriacea has priority as a species name. Based on their study there is no justification for supporting P. coriacea and P. robertsoniae as separate species.
Zostera capensis has been reclassified as Nanozostera (Tomlinson and Posluzny 2001), although here it is retained in the genus Zostera until genetic information is obtained.
This species is often difficult to distinguish from H. ovalis.

Halodule wrightii is a well established species. However, the taxonomy of the other species of Halodule in the Atlantic is less certain (Larkum et al. 2006) and there are questions about its taxonomy in the Indo-Pacific as well (Green and Short 2003).
Zostera pacifica is a newly resurrected species based on genetic studies in the Channel Is., California, USA.

Originally named Halodule wrightii, Halodule bermudensis was described by den Hartog in 1964 from material collected in 1913 and 1922 in Bermuda and it has not been reported elsewhere since. The current taxonomic status of this species is unclear, as can be said for most other Halodule species, until studies which combine examination of type material, descriptions of leaf tip morphology and genetic analyses are carried out. Extensive searches have been carried out in Bermuda for H. bermudensis over the last 16 years but it had not been found as of 2020 (K. Coates pers. obs.). Therefore, unless genetic analysis of type material is possible, the taxonomic status of Halodule bermudensis is valid based on morphological characteristics. Halodule specimens from Bermuda collected since 2012 revealed specimens of Halodule sp. that were morphologically more similar to H. beaudettei (K.A. Coates, pers. obs.), but forming a genotype that is distinct from Halodule wrightii from the Gulf of Mexico (Larkin et al. 2017).
Halophila minor is considered by some as a synonym of Halophila ovata. This species is a member of the Halophila ovalis complex, and is under taxonomic review.

The taxonomy of the Ruppia genus is confused. These species can be extremely morphologically variable and respond differently to differing environmental conditions. Therefore, species identifications often link to differences in environmental conditions. This species is potentially a synonym of Ruppia maritima. Flower morphology and genetic studies are needed to evaluate the distribution limits of this species (Larkum et al. 2006).
This species is part of the P. ostenfeldii complex (Kuo and Cambridge 1984). This species is currently undergoing taxonomic review.

This species has recently been split from Zostera tasmanica (Kuo 2005). Previous records will be listed under Zostera tasmanica and Heterozostera tasmanica. The genus for this species is currently published as Zostera (Les et al. 2002) although it is often still referred to as Heterozostera (Jacobs and Les 2009). No genetic data is available as of yet.
Halophila nipponica is a member of the Halophila ovalis complex.

The nomenclature for this species has been recently clarified and the clover grass should be referred to exclusively as Halophila baillonii (Creed and Samper-Villarreal, 2019). Halophila baillonis is no longer considered a synonym for H. baillonii (Creed and Samper-Villarreal, 2019). There is no taxonomic uncertainty regarding the identity of this species.  Halophila baillonii has and continues to be often misidentified as Halophila decipiens, Halophila johnsonii, or Halophila engelmannii (Short et al., 2006; Short et al., 2010; Samper-Villarreal et al., 2018b; Creed and Samper-Villarreal, 2019). Both H. decipiens and H. johnsonii can be distinguished from H. baillonii as they only have two leaves per foliar shoot. While H. engelmannii is similar to H. baillonii in also having a cluster of leaf pairs at the top of an erect shoot, H. engelmannii can be identified as it has three to four pairs of leaves which are subsessile or very shortly petioled compared to two pairs of distinctly petioled leaves for H. baillonii, and that the leaves of H. engelmannii are more elongated and firmer than those of H. baillonii (den Hartog 1959; Eisman, 1980; van Tussenbroek et al., 2010).

Zostera muelleri is considered conspecific with Z. capricorni, Z. mucronata and Z. novazelandica. This species has been reclassified as Nanozostera (Tomlinson and Posluzny 2001), although here it is retained in the genus Zostera.

Phylogenetic analysis of morphological characters and DNA sequences of samples from a limited number of locations in New Zealand have identified a lack of molecular divergence among Australian and New Zealand Zostera, which were formerly segregated as four distinct species (Z. capricorni, Z. muelleri, Z. mucronata and Z. novazelandica), as well as a lack of reliable morphological characters to separate these four species (Les et al. 2002). Consequently, Les et al. (2002) recommended the taxonomic merger of Australian/ New Zealand Zostera into a single species, Z. capricorni.

Recent molecular genetic and morphological analysis has indicated that Z. capricorni and Z. muelleri should be considered synonymous (Waycott et al. 2004).  Jacobs et al. (2006) then suggested the retention of the name Z. muelleri as the original and final species name rather than Z. capricorni.

More comprehensive surveys and phylogenetic analyses maybe required to definitively confirm the existence of a single species for these four species (Turner and Swartz 2006).

Although Sri Lankan and Southeast Asian populations of this species exhibit little variation, mitochondrial data suggest divergence of approximately 3% between sequences from Sri Lanka and Singapore (Ukuwela et al. 2017).
This species is the sole member of its genus.

This taxon is probably a species complex of three distinct species with morphological evidence indicating that one specimen from the Aru Islands is distinct from the typical M. richardsonii; and likewise another two specimens (one from Broome) are also distinct from the typical M. richardsonii and the one from Aru (Murphy in prep.).

Based on morphology and DNA evidence, there are possible grounds for dividing this species into three: a South Asian species extending from India to Phuket, a Southeast Asian species from Phuket to Philippines and Indonesia, and a Palau species occurring in Palau exclusively.
There is a manuscript in preparation that suggests that this species should not be in the genus Cantoria (J. Murphy in prep.).
The neotype for this species was described in 2007, and was accompanied by several paratypes (Rasmussen et al. 2007).

Molecular and morphological evidence suggests that this species might be a synonym of the very widespread Asian species Hydrophis cyanocinctus (Sanders et al. 2013), and this issue should be a priority for future taxonomic studies. However, because some morphological data indicate that we have more than one species involved in the Australian complex (Mirtschin et al. 2017),  we suggest following Cogger (1975) and using the name H. pacificus until this complex has been investigated more thoroughly.This species-complex has also been treated under the genus Leioselasma (Kharin 2005), however, based on molecular data is the species included in the genus Hydrophis (Sanders et al. 2013).
This species is sometimes treated under the genus Microcephalophis.

The genus Polyodontognathus has been described for this species (Kharin 2004). Kharin (2004) also suggests there may be two subspecies: H. c .caerulescens in the west (India, Sri Lanka, Burma, Malacca Straits) and H. c. hybridus (Sclegel 1844) in the east (Thailand, Indonesia, Australia). Data from Sanders et al. (2013) confirmed that the taxon belongs to Hydrophis.
This species has also been treated under the genus Leioselasma but is maintained in Hydrophis by Uetz et al. (2018).

The taxonomic status of species in the genus Emydocephalus is uncertain. It has been suggested that populations of E. annulatus in the Philippines are a distinct species (Alcala et al. 2000). Systematic studies are needed to determine the taxonomic status and geographic distributions of species in the genus Emydocephalus (Rasmussen and Ineich 2010). A new species is descripted from Vietnam (Dotsenko 2011), excluding E. annulatus from that area. However, the new species is only based on one specimen giving some doubt of its validity.
This species has also been treated under the genus Pseudolaticauda (the subgeneric name).
This species has also been treated under the genus Disteira.

This is a species complex (A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2009). Three subspecies have been described.

Has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
This species has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
Previously subsumed under the specific name L. colubrina (Cogger and Heatwole 2006).
In the Australian region, most people call this species H. pacificus and they may be the same species (A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2008). Sometimes treated under the genus Leioselasma.

Smith (1926) regarded H. ocellatus to be a subspecies of H. ornatus and referred Australian specimens previously included in H. ornatus to it. Later, H. o. ocellatus was raised to species level because of its distinctive DNA, colour pattern and a higher number of midbody scale rows compared with H. o. ornatus in Asia (Rasmussen et al. 2011, Rasmussen et al. 2014, K. L. Sanders et al. 2013, Smith 1974). This species has by some authors been treated as a subspecies under Chitulia ornata (Kharin 2005) but molecular studies in 2013 included it in the genus Hydrophis (Sanders et al. 2013).
This species was known only from the holotype until 1987 (Rasmussen 1992).  Has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
This species has also been treated under the genus Disteira (Kharin and Czeblukov 2009) but molecular studies have included it in the genus Hydrophis (Sander et al. 2013).

H. geometricus Smith, 1986, is a synonym for this species (Rasmussen and Smith 1997). It has also been treated under the genus Leioselasma by Kharin (2005b). However, molecular data indicate it belongs to the genus Hydrophis (Sanders et al. 2013).
This species has been described as synonymous with, or a subspecies of H. ornatus. Has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
This species has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.

This species has a highly variable colour pattern throughout its range and, as currently recognized, may comprise a complex of two or more species (Cogger 1975, A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2009). The taxon is sometimes treated under the genus Leioselasma, however, molecular analyses place it in Hydrophis (Sanders et al. 2013). A molecular study of 39 Sea Snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera. Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognising a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013).

The identification and distribution of Hydrophis atriceps and H. fasciatus are based on Smith´s monograph (1926), where he separated them at a subspecies level and mentioned the typical form (Hydrophis fasciatus) occurs to west of the Malay Peninsula and the other form (Hydrophis atriceps) is found east of the Malay Peninsula throughout the Malay Archipelago and south to Australia. Smith mentioned the dividing line to be in the region of Singapore, despite including a specimen from China in the western subspecies and two specimens from India and Rangoon in the eastern form. The specimen from China, included by Smith in the western form (H. f. fasciatus), is the type of Hydrophis lindsayi (Gray 1831) which antedates the name H. f. atriceps by 22 years. This indicates that if the taxa are separated into two geographically distinct forms, and this specimen was incorrectly assigned by Smith (1926) to H. f. fasciatus, the right name for the eastern population would be H. fasciatus lindsayi and not H. fasciatus atriceps. Later, Cogger et al. (1983) raised the two taxa to species level, referring the Australian specimens to H. atriceps. Ward (1996) assigned five specimens to H. atriceps from the northern Australian continental shelf. All the specimens were collected by prawn trawlers (Ward 1996).Whether the name for an Australian population of the H. fasciatus complex proves to be atriceps, fasciatus or lindsayi, we regard the species to be in Australian waters based on at least one specimen from the region of Darwin (AMR14022) and the specimens mentioned by Ward (1996). We suggest using the name H. atriceps for the Australian population of this species until further taxonomic clarification (Rasmussen et al. 2014).
Previously subsumed under the specific name L. colubrina, but it has been shown that these are sibling species which are reproductively isolated from each other (Shine et al. 2002).

This species has three subspecies: Hydrophis ornatus ornatus (Gray, 1942), Hydrophis ornatus godeffroyi Peters, 1873, and Hydrophis ornatus ocellatus Gray, 1849. The status of these subspecies is very uncertain, and the subspecies ocellatus is treated in this assessment as a separate distinct species (H. Cogger pers. comm. 2009).

H. lamberti has been incorrectly considered a synonym of H. ornatus (Smith 1926). This species has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.

There is some debate as to whether L. schistorynchus is a separate species, or a subspecies of L. semifasciata, due to similarities in venom chemistry (Guinea et al. 1983, Tamiya et al. 1983) and morphology (McCarthy 1986). This is disputed by Cogger and Heatwole (2005).

The Reptile Database treats this species under the genus Pseudolaticauda.

Some of Smith’s (1926) Hydrophis belcheri specimens have since been re-assigned to H. coggeri and all specimens called H. melanocephalus in Australian waters are regarded as H. coggeri (Rasmussen et al. 2014). Data from Sanders et al. (2013) confirmed that the taxon belongs to Hydrophis.
After the separation of H. fasciatus and H. atriceps (Cogger et al. 1983), H. atriceps is only found east of Singapore and H. fasciatus west of Singapore (A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2008).
Molecular phylogenies place Hydrophis macdowelli within Hydrophis as sister species to H. czeblukovi (Sanders et al. 2013).

Aipysurus dubuisii has ventral scales each with a shallow posterior notch and weak median keel, and body scales smooth. In addition, all its head shields are fragmented except for rostral and nasal scales. This Sea Snake's colour is variable, typically purplish-brown with pale edges to scales forming reticulum, and often with cream bands tending to form triangular lateral blotches (Wilson and Swan 2013).

Before 2006, L. saintigironsi (endemic to New Caledonia), L. guineai (endemic to southern Papua New Guinea), and L. frontalis (a dwarf species endemic to Vanuatu) were considered to be the same species as L. colubrina (Heatwole et al. 2005, Cogger and Heatwole 2006).

Many earlier references to this species, including most records from Australian waters, are based on the misidentification of a species previously known as H. melanocephalus. It has also been treated under the genus Chitulia (Kharin 2005a). Hydrophis belcheri was described by Gray (1849) who gave the type locality “New Guinea” with no further information. Smith (1926) re-described H. belcheri based on 21 specimens mainly from the Philippines, New Guinea and Fiji Islands. Most of Smith’s H. belcheri specimens have since been re-assigned to the following taxa: Hydrophis coggeri, H. czeblukovi, H. pachycercos and H. pacificus (Cogger 1975; Kharin 1983, 1984; Rasmussen et al.2007; Rasmussen et al. 2014; Rasmussen and Smith 1997).
This species has been (incorrectly) described as a synonym of H. ornatus (Rasmussen 1989).  It has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
Shea (1996) notes that the name of this species should be spelled greyae, not greyi, because it was named in honour of a Mrs. Beatrice Grey and hence should bear the feminine ending.

A recent phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognising a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and is followed by most authors (D'Anastasi et al. 2016, Leviton et al. 2014, Lillywhite et al. 2014, Mirtschin et al. 2017, Rasmussen et al. 2014, Rezaie-Atagholipour et al. 2016, Udyawer et al. 2015, Ukuwela et al. 2014).
This species is sometimes treated under the genus Chitulia.

Aipysurus tenuis is a relatively slender snake that can be distinguished from closely-related A. laevis by the number of ventral scales (at least 180) and scale rows at mid-body (19) (Rasmussen et al. 2014). A. tenuis can reach a total length of 1.05 m with tail up to 14 cm. The head is brown and darker in colour than the rest of the body. Dorsally, most scales have a light brown edge in the middle and rear of the scale, and dark brown in the middle and the tip of the scale, forming longitudinal lines along the medial line and more or less distinct cross-bands on the sides(Cogger 2014, Mirtschin et al. 2017) . The body scales are smooth and imbricate (overlapping), and males may have small tubercles along hind edge of the scale. The anal scales are divided and overlapping. Subcaudals 33-36 and single. The head shields are enlarged, symmetrical and occasionally fragmented.
This species has also been treated under the genus Disteira (Kharin and Czeblukov 2009) but was included in the genus Hydrophis in 2013 (Sanders et al. 2013).
This species has been treated under the genus Leioselasma.

Aipysurus fuscus is a small to moderately sized venomous snake, typically reaching a length of 60 cm and maximum total length of 98 cm (Cogger 2014, Francis 2006, Mirtschin et al. 2017, Storr et al. 2002). Adults are brown, blackish-brown or purplish-brown, but often have obscure, paler cross bands on the lower flanks. Sometimes the lateral scales will have a darker patch at the centre, resulting in faint, longitudinal striations; younger snakes are typically lighter and dark banded.

Aipysurus fuscus can be differentiated from closely related A. laevis by its smaller size, darker colouration and by the number of scales on belly and mid-body (155 – 172 ventral scales and less than 21 scale rows around the midbody). Other scale features used in taxonomy of A. fuscus include: head shields are regular with some fragmentation of scales occasionally (prefrontals, frontal and supraoculars) especially the parietals; upper labials six to nine, with the first three or four sometimes divided horizontally; anal scales are divided, while ventral scales are broad with a medium keel and no posterior notch. Body scales are smooth with some lowest rows weakly keeled in males. Body scales are imbricate (overlapping) and there are typically 19 scale rows around the neck and 19 around the mid-body. Females have between 24 to 33 subcaudal scales, while males have 30 to 37 subcaudal scales (Francis 2006, Rasmussen et al. 2014).

Microsatellite markers for A. fuscus and A. laevis sampled across four Timor Sea reefs were analysed to assess evidence for recent inter-specific gene flow and historical introgression (Sanders et al. 2014). The data fit an Isolation–Migration model, which showed significant and asymmetrical levels of gene flow following species divergence, and highest rates of introgression from the large A. laevis population into the much smaller A. fuscus population(Sanders et al. 2014). Population assignment analyses recovered two ancestral clusters that broadly corresponded to morphological species designations, but revealed high frequencies of hybrids on all four reefs and individuals of pure A. fuscus ancestry only at Scott and (historically) Ashmore. Most unexpectedly, 95% of snakes sampled at Hibernia were hybrids that resembled A. laevis in phenotype, revealing a collapse of reproductive barriers (‘reverse speciation’) at this reef. These results have dire implications for the conservation status of A. fuscus, and highlight the fragility of reproductive barriers in a recent marine radiation (Sanders et al. 2014).

This species has also been treated under the genus Microcephalophis, however, a recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors.
Smith (1926) described two subspecies: K. jerdoni jerdoni and K. jerdoni siamensis. Further studies are needed to finalize the validity of the two subspecies (Rasmussen and Anderson 1990).

There has been some discussion regarding two possible subspecies L. l. laticaudata (see Rasmussen 1989) and L. l. affinus (Anderson, 1871) (see Heatwole et al. 2005) though most authorities treat L. laticaudata as a single lineage. The Reptile Database lists a third subspecies L. l. wolfii Volsoe, 1956.
The taxonomy of this species is currently under review. The Reptile Database treats this species under the genus Disteira.
Aponogeton appendiculatus is identified based on terminal plumule, germinating embryo warty, and crowned with a whorl of bent linear or conical about 1 cm long appendages.

Robertson and Allen (2006) treat the Eastern Pacific population as a separate species. However, the taxonomy of this group is in need of revision and the Eastern Pacific population may in fact belong to the circumglobal species Lobotes surinamensis.

Frequently misidentified as Albula vulpes, an Atlantic species. It has also been previously identified as A. neoguinaica (a synonym of the Indo-central Pacific species A. forsteri). However, genetic data indicate the eastern Pacific form is a separate species (Colborn et al. 2001), for which A. esuncula is the oldest name. There is recent genetic evidence that this species may in fact represent two species: Albula esuncula from south of Mazatlan, Mexico, and a yet to be named Albula species from Southern California to Mazatlan (Pfeiler et al. 2008).
This species may have some taxonomic confusion with Centropomus armatus.
Generic name was entered incorrectly in 1996 as Antriscopia.
This species name has three different spellings (N. Duke pers. comm.).
This species used to be considered a variety of A. marina.
This species is commonly confused with Acrostichum aureum. These species are often lumped together making it difficult to know the limits of the distribution.

This species was formerly recognized as C. decandra in the majority of its range. C. decandra is now restricted to the eastern coast of India, Bangladesh, Myanmar, southwest Thailand and the western Malay peninsula (Sheue et al. 2009).
This species is differentiated from A. germinans by cuticular waxes and AFLPs (see Dodd and Rafii 2002). It is a sister to A. bicolor (a Central American Pacific coast endemic).

This species is known from both the Eastern Tropical Pacific (western coast of the Americas) and the southwest Pacific. The population in the Eastern Tropical Pacific was formerly known as R. mangle (Ellison 1991, Duke 2006).
It is possible that Linneaus first described this species.
This species is morphologically similar to B. exaristata.
Shirakiopsis indica is a synonym of this species.
This species is genetically and morphologically similar to R. mucronata (Duke et al. 2002).
This species is now considered to be C. zippeliana in the majority of its range (Sheue et al. 2009).
This species was formally considered part of K. candel but is now considered a distinct species (Sheue et al. 2003).
This species original range has been divided in K. candel and K. obovata (Sheue et al. 2003).
This species was previously considered as Eucinostomus argenteus.
This species has a disjunct distribution that may involve two species, one distributed in the Gulf of California and the other in southern Mexico.

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families. Their study recognized 11 species in Kyphosidae, as well as one Neoscorpis, which is considered a distinct genus within Kyphosidae. Thus, there are 12 species total in the family Kyphosidae. 

Kyphosus lutescens and K. pacificus are now treated as synonyms of K. sectatrix. Both K. incisor and K. analogus are now considered synonyms of K. vaigiensis. K. pacificus/sandwicensis is a synonym of K. elegans. Before Knudsen and Clements (2013) it was thought that only two Kyphosids occurred in the Atlantic, but there are in fact four species, K. sectatrix, K. vaigiensis/incisor, K. bigibbus, and K. cinerascens.

The juvenile of Opistognathus punctatus was described as O. mexicanus by Allen and Robertson (1991). Opistognathus mexicanus is considered the junior synonym of O. punctatus (Bussing and Lavenberg 2003).
This species is sometimes mispelled as Stathmonotus culebrae, but the original orthography is with an '-ai' ending.
Also known as Japanoconger proriger (Robertson and Allen 2006). Ophisoma prorigerum is an objective synonym of Ariosoma prorigerum, and is listed as valid but the genus uncertain.
Possibly a junior synonym of Heteroconger digueti.
Newly discovered species in 2005.
A recent study showed significant genetic structure within the species (Riginos and Nachman 2001).
Newly discovered species in 2005.
The Gruchy (1970) record of Prionotus loxias from the Galapagos is a misidentification of this species.
This species is very similar to Tigrigobius digueti (Taylor and Hellberg 2005, Quimbayo et al. 2018).

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families. Their study recognized 11 species in Kyphosidae, as well as one Neoscorpis, which is considered a distinct genus within Kyphosidae. Thus, there are 12 species total in the family Kyphosidae. 

Kyphosus lutescens and K. pacificus are now treated as synonyms of K. sectatrix. Both K. incisor and K. analogus are now considered synonyms of K. vaigiensis. K. pacificus/sandwicensis is a synonym of K. elegans. Before Knudsen and Clements (2013) it was thought that only two Kyphosids occurred in the Atlantic, but there are in fact four species, K. sectatrix, K. vaigiensis/incisor, K. bigibbus, and K. cinerascens.
Previously this species has sometimes been referred to as Caranx hippos.
This species is also spelled as Chriolepis lepidotus.

This species may represent two species given that no records known between them. Proposed names are Xenistius californiensis from southern California to the Gulf of California, and Xenistius peruanus from Lobos Islands Peru to central Peru (Roberston pers. comm.).

Lythrypnus pulchellus was separated from L. rhizophora based on island vs. coastal distribution by Bussing (1990). However unpublished current molecular data indicates that they may be the same species.
This nomenclature may represent a species complex including available names such as Cathorops liropus.
Springer (1958) recognized two subspecies: Malacoctenus zonifer zonifer from Mexico, and M. zonifer sudensis from Nicaragua to Ecuador.
This genus is in need of revision. This species is likely a synonym of Bollmannia ocellata (Bedenbaugh 1988).
Most recently, Sciades has been used as the genus for this species (Marceniuk and Menezes 2007).
This species was previously in the genus Xenocys, but is now placed in Brachygenys according to work by Tavera et al. (2018).
This species has been incorrectly reported as far north as Mexico (e.g. Nelson et al. 2004, ASIH fish names).

Lythrypnus pulchellus was separated from L. rhizophora based on island vs coastal distribution by Bussing (1990). However unpublished current molecular data indicates that they may be the same species.
This species is possibly conspecific with Halichoeres malpelo from Malpelo Island. Genetic studies should be undertaken.
Aboma is the more commonly recognized genus.
Collection and examination of additional specimens is needed to determine the taxonomic standing of this species (Tornabene et al. 2016).
This genus is in need of revision.

This species has been considered a synonym of Abudefduf concolor, but a recent molecular study by Lessios et al. (1995) confirmed that it is a separate species. It is closely related to A. concolor and is easily confused in the field during visual surveys. The distributions of the two species overlap between El Salvador and Costa Rica, and a combination of morphological and genetic comparisons throughout the ranges of both species are needed to establish the full range of each.
According to genetic analyses, this species is separate from Stegastes leucorus (Bernardi et al. 2014).
This genus is in need of revision. This species is likely a synonym of Bollmannia ocellata (Bedenbaugh 1988).
This species is closely related to ,i>Thalassoma purpureum in the Indo-Pacific region (Bernardi et al. 2004).
Sometimes incorrectly amended as Protemblemaria bicirris.

This species has been considered a synonym of Abudefduf declivifrons, but a recent molecular study by Lessios et al. (1995) confirmed that it is a separate species. It is closely related to A. declivifrons and is easily confused in the field during visual surveys. The distributions of the two species overlap between El Salvador and Costa Rica, and a combination of morphological and genetic comparisons throughout the ranges of both species are needed to establish the full range of each.
This species has been previously considered as a synonym of Cathorops taylori, but is now recognized as a distinct species (Betancur et al. 2007).
Springer (1958) recognized two subspecies: Malacoctenus margaritae mexicanus from the Gulf of California, and M. margaritae margaritae from the remainder of its range.
Original orthography is scudderii.

Genetic analyses of this species by Acevedo-Álvarez et al. (2021) resulted in the description of two new species previously identified as Anisotremus interruptus. Anisotremus interruptus co-occurs with A. espinozai in the Galapagos and Cocos and with A. perezponcedeleoni in the Revillagigedo Archipelago (O. Dominguez pers. comm. 2022).
Separate species for Scorpaena mystes and S. plumieri is more commonly accepted.
This species is also known as Notarius osculus by some authors, but Arius osculus is the nomen dubium (Betancur and Acero 2004). Other generic names used for this species are Ariopsis and Aspistor.
Sciades has also been used recently as the genus for this species.
The form in the extreme southern tip of Baja is genetically distinct from the remainder of the forms within its range (Lin et al. 2009).
Possibly conspecific with Halichoeres salmofasciatus from Cocos Island. Genetic studies are needed.

Dawson (1975) recognized three subspecies: Dactyloscopus pectoralis pectoralis from the Gulf of California and outer coast of Baja California; D. pectoralis fallax from Sinaloa, Mexico to Ecuador, including Isla del Coco; and D. pectoralis insulatus from Islas Revillagigedos.

Two subspecies are recognized. The Peruvian population (Merluccius gayi peruanus) is distributed off the coast of Peru from Paita (5°S) southward to Huarmey (around 14°), while the Chilean subspecies (M. gayi gayi) occurs off the coast of Chile from Arica (19°S) to the Chiloe Island (around 44°S) (FAO-FIGIS 2001).
This species is valid and a Galapagos endemic (Tavera et al. 2018).
This species is also known as Eucinostomus californiensis, but E. gracilis is apparently the senior synonym.
This genus has undergone recent taxonomic revision in the Eastern Tropical Pacific (Miller and Stefanni 2001).
May include Heteroconger canabus in its synonomy.

Springer (1959) recognized the populations from Baja California / the Gulf and the remainder of the range as a separate subspecies, Malacoctenus tetranemus multipunctatus and M. tetranemus tetranemus respectively.
This species is known  only from the type material (Ginsgurg 1935).
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus striatus to the genus Brockius.
This species is also more commonly known as Caranx caballus. This species is probably a junior synonym of Caranx crysos.
Gymnothorax equatorialis is similar, but has three pores below the eye, a narrower tail, and the spots at the rear of the tail are elongate and much larger than the eye.
This species has been redescribed by Betancur and Acero (2004).
Specimens from central Mexico have been assigned to this species, but require confirmation and are not included here.
Newly discovered species in 2005.

There are two described subspecies: Myxodagnus opercularis walkeri from the Tres Marias Islands and Costa Rica; and M. opercularis opercularis form from the Gulf of California and Islas Revillagigedos (Dawson 1976).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

According to Miller and Steffani (2001) there are two subspecies - Bathygobius r. longipinnis from the Revillagigedos and Tres Marias Islands, and Bathygobius r. ramosus from the remainder of the range.
There are two described subspecies: Malacoctenus hubbsi hubbsi occurs in the Gulf, and M. h. polysporosus occurs in central and southern Mexico.
Taxonomic studies are needed to confirm this as a single species.
Gymneleotris is feminine and should be 'a', not 'us' ending.
This genus is in need of revision.
This species was synonomised with Elacatinus digueti by Hoese and Reade. According to Van Tassell (pers. comm.) this was in error and both are valid species.
Closely related to Rypticus saponaceus (Bloch and Schneider) from the western Atlantic.

Some authors (Hensley 1995, Evseenko 1999, Robertson et al. 2017) consider this species to be a possible senior subjective synonym of M. asaedae. Other authors consider M. asaedae to be valid (Castro-Aguirre et al. 1992, Bussing and López 1994, De La Cruz Agüero et al. 1997, Evseenko 1998, Amaoka and Imamura 2000, Nelson et al. 2004, Page et al. 2013). The most recent evidence (Robertson et al. 2017), based on both morphology and molecular evidence, indicate that M. asaedae is a junior synonym of M. dubiosa. {Ask RLU to merge M. asaedae into this account}
This species was previously in the genus Orthopristis, but is now placed in Microlepidotus according to work by Tavera et al. (2018).
Letharcus opercularis and Letharcus pacificus constitute the new genus Paraletharcus (McCosker 1974).
Trachurus murphyi which occurs in the southern part of this region is the sister species of T. symmetricus.
More information should be obtained from Pietch and Grobecker (1987).
This species is also known as Mnierpes macrocephalus.

Attention RLU: Please change the family from Bythitidae to Dinematichthyidae. Reference is Catalog of Fishes. - C. Linardich 31May2022 

This species is closely related to Ogilbia galapagoensis and further taxonomic work is needed to clarify the differences. It also resembles O. cocoensis from Isla del Coco (Møller et al. 2005).

This species is at the single location where it is known. It is intermediate in character between two abundant species (Myripristis benrndti and M. clarionensis) at the same location, therefore it may possibly be a hybrid.
This species was previously considered to be a subspecies of the Atlantic species Fodiator acutus (Parin and Belyanina 2002).
Xyrichtys perlas is a synonym of this species.
This genus is in need of revision. This species is likely a synonym of Bollmannia ocellata (Bedenbaugh 1988).
Newly discovered species in 2005.

The H. rondeletii superspecies complex of the subgenus Danichthys is now recognized as containing four allopatric species: H. volador (western Atlantic), H. rondeletii (Mediterranean), H. gilberti (northern Pacific), and H. rufipinnis (Southern Hemisphere). The other two species, Hirundichthys marginatus (eastern tropical Pacific) and H. albimaculatus(west & central Pacific) are both distinct species in the subgenus, but are not part of the rondeletii superspecies complex (Parin and Belyanina 2002, B. Collette pers. comm. 2014).
This species is also known as Chriolepis walkerii (Findley 1983).
A review of the genus is given in Van Tassell and Baldwin (2004).

Merluccius hernandezi can be a distinct species from ,i>M. angustimanus (Nelson et al. 2004) However, Lloris D., J. Matallanas and P. Oliver (2003) consider both species as the same. Further taxonomic research is needed.
This species can be confused with an undescribed congener known from Baja California, Costa Rica and Panama.
Also listed as Caranx otrynter.

This species is commonly misidentified as Anchoa panamensis (which occurs only in Panama Bay); thus most records of Anchoa panamensis north of Panama Bay refer to Anchoa mundeola (Palacios and Phillips 1984).
Species described in 2005.
This genus is in need of revision.
Most recently, Sciades has been used as the genus for this species (Marceniuk and Menezes 2007). Further research is needed to confirm that this represents a single species.
Although Kailola (2004) treat this species as a synonym of Sciades hymenorrhinos, it is accepted here as Sciades dowii following Betancur-R. et al. (2007).

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families. Their study recognized 11 species in Kyphosidae, as well as one Neoscorpis, which is considered a distinct genus within Kyphosidae. Thus, there are 12 species total in the family Kyphosidae. 

Kyphosus lutescens and K. pacificus are now treated as synonyms of K. sectatrix. Both K. incisor and K. analogus are now considered synonyms of K. vaigiensis. K. pacificus/sandwicensis is a synonym of K. elegans. Before Knudsen and Clements (2013) it was thought that only two Kyphosids occurred in the Atlantic, but there are in fact four species, K. sectatrix, K. vaigiensis/incisor, K. bigibbus, and K. cinerascens.
There are two recognized subspecies: Dactyloscopus byersi heraldi, from Baja California; and D. byersi byersi from the remainder of the range.
It is possible that the southern range of this species may represent a separate, undescribed species.

This species is divided into three geographically isolated subspecies on the basis of morphological differences: one from central west Baja California and the Gulf of California (Lepophidium microlepis microlepis); one from northern Costa Rica to central Colombia (L. m. hubbsi); and one from southern Ecuador and northern Peru (L. m. inca) (Robins and Lea 1978). There is continued debate as to whether these subspecies should be recognized at the specific level.
This genus is in need of revision.
This species is considered to be ver similar to Pomadasys macracanthus.
This species seems to have two forms or subspecies: Harengula thrissina thrissina from the Gulf of California to Panama and Harengula thrissina peruana from Panama to Peru (Watson and Sandknop 1996).
Newly discovered species in 2005.
This species is valid and a Galapagos endemic (Tavera et al. 2018).
One form from California has been recognized as a distinct subspecies (Bohlke 1952).
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus dendriticus to the genus Gobioclinus.
This genus is in need of revision.
References to this species prior to 2001 are to Hyporhamphus unifasciatus which is a western Atlantic species (Banford and Collette 2001).

Some authors (Hensley 1995, Evseenko 1999) consider this species to be a possible junior subjective synonym of M. dubiosa; other authors consider this species to be valid using a variety of spellings for the specific epithet (Castro-Aguirre et al. 1992, Bussing and López 1994, De La Cruz Agüero et al. 1997, Evseenko 1998, Amaoka and Imamura 2000, Nelson et al. 2004, Page et al. 2013). Most recently, Robertson et al. (2017), based on both morphology and molecular evidence, also consider this nominal species to be a synonym of M. dubiosa.

This species, which occurs from California to the Gulf of California, is the sister species of Trachurus symmetricus. This species has smaller scutes (height = 25-44% of eye diameter) on the curved part of the lateral line than T. murphyi. A recent study by Stepien and Rosenblatt (1996) indicates that there is an ongoing genetic connections between these two populations.
A poorly known species whose taxonomy deserves attention.

This species is only known from the type locality which is strongly suspect due to the lack of habitat favoured by all the rest of it congeners. The type specimen, if still existing, needs to be checked (Museum of Vienna, Austria). The species may be valid but the locality might be wrong.
This species was previously confused with Exocoetus obtusirostris.
A possible morphotype variant that is much larger size occurs at the northern end of Isla Angel de la Guarda.
Genetic studies indicate difference between Gulf of California and coastal Californian populations.
Also known as Encheliophis dubius.
The generic status is uncertain according to Dekker and Orlin (2000).
Placed erroneously in the genus Auriculastra by Pilsbry and Bequaert (1927) and Bacci (1951) according to Brown (1994)
Placed erroneously in the genus Auriculastra by Pilsbry and Bequaert (1927) and Bacci (1951) according to Brown (1994).

Molecular evidence has demonstrated that the traditional concept of this species comprises five distinct geographical lineages, one of which has been described as Aphanius almiriensis Kottelat, Barbieri and Stoumboudi 2007.

This species is extremely similar to N. rosea, with the relative position of the gastric tubercle on the carapace being the only difference to separate them (Chan 1997).

Watabe and Iizuka (1999) state that more specimens need to be examined to determine if this is a valid species or not.

Some specimens of this species were incorrectly labelled as Scyllarus martensii (Holthuis 2002).

This species is referred to as Scyllarus modestus in Holthuis (1991).
This species had been assigned as Scyllarus paradoxus (Miers, 1881). More recently, Forest (1963) showed it to be a new species (Holthuis 2002).
This species is named Justita chani by Poupin 1994, but is now accepted as Nupalirus chani (Chan 2010).

This species has previously been confused with T. orientalis, which is now regarded as not occurring in Australia. The species are very difficult to separate using morphological characters (Burton and Davie 2007).

From morphological analyses the two subspecies, Chelarctus cultrifer cultrifer and C. cultrifer meridionalis (Holthuis, 1960) have been abandoned in favour of a single species (Chan 1997, Holthuis 2002).
Synonyms: Arctus depressus (S.I. Smith, 1881); S. nearctus (Holthuis, 1960).
Synonyms: Arctus americanus (S.I. Smith, 1869), Scyllarus gundlachi (Von Martens, 1872).
This species is named Justita vericeli by Poupin (1994), but is now accepted as Nupalirus vericeli (Chan 2010).
This species includes Scyllarides tumidus of Colin & Arneson (1995).
Synonyms: Scyllarus (Arctus) arctus paradoxus (Miers, 1881).
This species was split by Holthuis 1960 into S. chacei and S. americanus, as previous specimens have had some confusion between these two species.

Chan et al. (2009) recently showed that the banded and non-banded forms of Metanephrops thomsoni were widely genetically divergent. The banded (widespread) form is now treated as a distinct species and named after a recent fossil, Wongastacia taiwanica Hu, 1983 (see also Tshudy et al. 2007).
This species is very similar to N. stewarti and they often occur together (Chan 1997).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Bodianus dictynna was long thought to be conspecific with B. diana but the two are separable on colour pattern (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).

Hemigymnus sexfasciatus is almost certainly a valid Red Sea endemic and sister species of H. fasciatus (Kuiter 2002). Color differences are significant and consistent and Kuiter's color photos make a convincing argument. H. sexfaciatus is not recognized by Parenti and Randall (2000) (J.H. Choat pers. comm.. 2008). A detailed comparison of specimens and genetic material is needed (R. Myers pers. comm.. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon and Madden (1981) and Gomon (2006).

Xyrichtys rajapolani and Xyrichtys javanicus probably belong in the genus Iniistius based on Randall narrowly defining the Indo-Pacific Xyrichtys to a few species allied to X. woodi (R. Myers pers. comm.. 2008).

Thalassoma sanctahelenae and T. ascensionis have previously been regarded by some authors as being synonymous (Gomon and Forsyth 1990), but they are in fact good species, as confirmed by the genetic studies of Bernardi et al. (2004) and Castagliola et al. (2004).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
This name has been wrongly used in the past for the Indo-West Pacific species C. batuensis (D. Pollard pers. comm.. 2008).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

According to Parenti and Randall (2000), Julis ventralis (De Vis 1885), was determined by Paolo Parenti and Jeff Johnson of the Queensland Museum, and Thalassoma cupido bipunctatum (Vasiliu 1931) is a sub-adult of Thalassoma lunare.

This widespread species may consist of Indian and Pacific Ocean sister species. Although Parenti and Randall (2000) list this as a single species extending from the Red Sea to the central Pacific, Kuiter (2002) reserves the name marginatus for the Red Sea population of this species and identified the Indian and Pacific Ocean populations as Halichoeres lamarii and further suggests that the Pacific Ocean populations are Halichoeres annularis. Barber and Bellwood (2005) use molecular evidence to show that there are two clades in this species, Indian and Pacific Ocean, but did not discuss the Red Sea populations. No formal taxonomic resolution has been published.

For taxonomic treatment see Mabuchi and Nakabo (1997). This species has in part previously been identified as Pseudolabrus japonicus, a species now regarded as a nomen dubium by Mabuchi and Nakabo (1997). It is closely related and confused with P. eoethinus (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).

Halichoeres poecilopterus has often been used in literature in Japan, such as Kinoshita (1936), Okada (1962), Fukui et al. (1991), Kimura and Kiriyama (1992), Kobayashi and Suzuki (1994) and Miyake et al. (2008).

Parenti and Randall (2000) stated that Parajulis is a distinct genus from Halichoeres, although this has not been always followed by other authors.
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1985).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

This species has in the past been commonly confused with and previously referred to as C. aygula in Australian waters (Randall and Kuiter 1982). It was also referred to as C. cyaena by Whitley (1937) and others.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
This species was previously known as Labrus bimaculatus, e.g. in Golani et al. 2006 (D. Pollard pers. comm. 2008).
Some records of this species from the Mediterranean Sea may have been misidentifications of Labrus viridis (D. Pollard pers. comm. 2008).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
This species was previously identified as H. cyanocephalus, but recent genetic research revealed that Brazilian populations belong to a valid species now recognized as H. dimidiatus (Rocha 2004).
This species was previously regarded as a synonym of Iniistius baldwini, but is now regarded as a separate species by (Randall and Jonsson 2008).
Hybrids with congeners are common for this species (Kuiter 2002).

For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Gomon and Randall (1978) recognized B. albotaeniatus as a subspecies of B. bilunulatus but Gomon (2006) regarded it as a separate species (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002).
