Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
The subspecies Macropharyngodon bipartatus marisrubri Randall (1978) known in the Gulf of Aqaba (western Indian Ocean) has been synonymized with M. bipartatus (Parenti and Randall 2000).
This species was formerly regarded as Coris variegata (Ruppel) prior to the 1990’s. C. variegata is now considered endemic to the Red Sea.
From Senegal southwards along the west African coast, this species is probably replaced by a separate species, Thalassoma newtoni.

This species is possibly misidentified as the male of Choerodon robustus (Lieske and Myers 1994). However, this seems unlikely as C. robustus has a mostly east African distribution, although it is also thought to be present in Japan and Indonesia (see C. robustus Red List assessment) (Parenti and Randall 2000).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
This species belongs in a sub-clade together with Thalossoma cupido and T. trilobatum in the Indo-Pacific region (Bernardi et al. 2004).
This species may be a senior synonym of Oxycheilinus rhodochrous (Randall and Khalaf 2003).
For taxonomic treatment see Allen (1983).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).
Cirrhilabrus bruguieri (Randall, 2004) does not appear to have been published in the literature. It is possibly the same species as C. bathyphilus (R. Myers, pers. comm.. 2008)".
There is a very similar undescribed species in the Central Pacific (J.H.Choat pers. comm. 2009)
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
Halichoeres tenuispinis is misapplied.
This species is replaced by Coris cuvieri in most parts of the Indian Ocean (D. Pollard pers. comm.. 2009).

For taxonomic treatment see Mabuchi and Nakabo (1997). This species has in part been previously identified as Pseudolabrus japonicus, regarded as a nomen dubium by Mabuchi and Nakabo (1997). It is closely related and confused with P. sieboldi (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). This species was previously misidentified as B. opercularis (Myers 1999) (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).
Tautogolabrus brandaonis is a synonym of T. adspersus. The record from Brazil is erroneous (P. Parenti pers. Comm. In Eschmeyer 2007, R. Moura pers. comm. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).

This species was formerly lumped with Cheilinus fasciatus. The true fasciatus does not occur in the North Red Sea. Populations of C. fasciatus recorded from the Gulf of Aden, Socotra and NE Somalia are probably C. quinquecinctus, but this needs to be researched.
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1985). Records of Suezichthys notatus from NW Australia probably are of this species (Kuiter 2002).
This species is closely related to C. lunatus and females look almost identical.
This species lilkely represents a complex of undescribed species (Kuiter 2002).

This species has in the past been confused with Thalassoma pavo, which occurs off the West African coast to the north of the Gulf of Guinea and in the Mediterranean Sea, and to which it is closely related (Bernardi et al. 2004, Costagliola et al. 2004). It has also been confused with the even more closely related insular species T. ascensionis as it was identified as such around Sao Tome Principe by Afonso et al. (1999).
This species is also known as Oxycheilnus digrammus (Eschmeyer and Fricke 2009).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
According to Randall (1999), Halochoeres bleekeri and H. tenuispinis are separate species. However, it is difficult to interpret survey data on this species previous to this change.

Halochoeres chrysotaenia is considered to be the senior synonym of H. vrolikii (Kuiter 2002). Based on type locality (Java) and photographs taken there (R. Myers pers. comm.. 2008). This needs to be checked for its relationship with H. richmondi and H. melanurus.

Although Halichoeres purpurescens has often been recognized as valid, we follow de Beaufort (1940) in regarding it as a synonym of H. leucurus. Labrus leucurus and Anampses moniliger are based on the figure and description of Seba (1761: 95 pl. 31) (Parenti and Randall 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Ayling and Russell (1977) and Randall and Randall (1981).  Kuiter (2002) suggests Japanese specimens may be distinct (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1985). Record of this species from NW Australia may be Suezichthys cyanolaemus (Kuiter 2002).
This species is closely related to Thalassoma bailleui (Bernardi et al. 2004).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

This species was formerly valid as Xyrichtys javanicus, its current status is Iniistius javanicus (Bleeker 1862) (Allen and Adrim 2003).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988)
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
For taxonomic treatment see Randall and Randall (1981).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). There is confusion with B. vulpinus in New Zealand and probably New South Wales in eastern Austailia.
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Bodianus solatus has been confused with B. perditio in the literature (B. Russell pers. comm.).

For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1983). Kuiter (2002) has assigned this species to the genus Suezichthys. Pending further revision, it is retained here in the genus Nelabrichthys (B.Russell, pers. Comm. 2008).
C. balarensis has been synonymized with this species (Parenti and Randall 2000).
This species was thought to occur South to Brazil, but genetic research revealed that Brazilian populations belong to a different species (Rocha 2004).
Records from Indonesia may represent a hybrid of this species (Kuiter 2002).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). This species is one of the most widely ranging species in the genus.
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).

There have been problems arising from earlier records of distribution and management of this species in southern Australia due to confusion with A. viridis up until 30 years ago. Earlier records of large size of A. viridis in South Australia (Scott et al. 1974) refer to A. gouldii as does management aspects of Achoerodus in the Spencer Gulf (J.H. Choat pers. comm.. 2008).

This species appears to hybridise with Thalassoma lunare (Randall and Miroz 2001). Thalassoma rueppelli is closely related to T. duperreyi, T. genivittatum, and T. lutescens in the Indo-Pacific region (Bernardi et al. 2004).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
This species has in the past been confused with the more northerly species Coris julis (D. Pollard pers. comm.. 2008).
This species is closley related to Halochoeres hartzfeldi. Records of H. zeylonicus in the Pacific probably refer to H. hartzfeldi.
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).
A hybrid between Gomphosus varius x T. Lunare was found in Solomon Islands (Allen 2006).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988)
Male Halichoeres nebulosus and Halichoeres margaritaceus have often been misidentified as Halichoeres kawarin, which may be responsible for attributing a greater range to this species.
Population in the Maldives may represent a distinct species (Kuiter 2002).
This species is similar to Halichoeres margaritaceus.

This species was thought to occur along the Brazilian coast, but recent genetic research revealed that coastal Brazilian populations belong to a different species (Rocha 2004).

Several endemic species of the Brazilian province have been taxonomically revised and are now validated as Halichoeres penrosei (previously recorded as H. maculipinna) (Pinherio et al. 2009).

H. maculipinna  is closer to Thalassoma than to any other Halichoeres (Rocha et al. 2010)

Although this species was described in 1835 it was not recognised as a separate species from Halochoeres fasciatus until recently (Kuiter 2002). This species is not recognised by Parenti and Randall (2000).

It was formerly lumped with H. fasciatus, which does not seem to occur in the Red Sea (Kuiter 2002). The true H. fasciatus occurs from Oman and East Africa to the Pitcairn Group of Polynesia. Populations from the Gulf of Aden and Socotra need to be investigated. Halochoeres sexfasciatus differs from H. fasciatus in color pattern, but differences in morphology and genetics have not been investigated.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). This species was previously confused with Bodianus frenchii and B. unimaculatus (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).

For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Bodianus bilunulatus has long been confused with three other closely related species with which it is broadly sympatric: B. loxozonus, B. macrourus and B. perditio (Gomon 2006).
Similarities with juveniles of other of members of the genus may have masked the true distribution of this species (Hutchins and Morrison 1996).

For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1985). Following Kuiter (2002) Suezichthys devisi, previously included as a synonym of S. gracilis, is here provisionally recognised as distinct (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).

For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1985). Following Kuiter (2002) Suezichthys devisi from eastern Australia, previously included as a synonym of S. gracilis, is here provisionally recognised as distinct (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Bodianus prognathus may represent a relatively recent divergence resulting from the isolation of a small population of the ancestral form common to B. dictynna (Gomon 2006).

Identified first as Heterochoerops viridis (Steindachner 1866). A. viridis is considered to be a sibling species of A. gouldii and the two have been generally grouped together as A. gouldii in most of the literature until only fairly recently, i.e ~35 years or so ago (D. Pollard pers. comm. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1985). Kuiter (2002) regards Japanese specimens of Suezichthys soelae as a possible new species (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
This species was recently described in Heiser et al. (2000).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
This species may consitute two species - the one in the northern hemisphere is yet to be described, and the one in the south will retain the name P. atavai (R. Myers pers. Comm. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Bodianus diana closely resembles B. dictynna and B. prognathus, having long been considered to be conspecific with the former (Gomon 2006).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
Females are nearly identical to C. luteovittatus.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

Halochoeres kneri, H. exornatus, H. dussumieri, and H. javanicus are all synonyms of H. nigrescens. However, there are one or two new species that have been misidentified as H. exornatus (Allen in progress) and H. javanicus (R. Myers pers. comm.. 2008).
This species was observed at both St. Helena and Ascension Islands. It is unclear if the Ascension Island species is a conspecific. Molecular data are required (J.H. Choat pers. comm.. 2008).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
This species is very similar in appearance to T. hebraicum.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Previously identified as Verreo oxycephalus (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).
This is a new species of Epibulus similar to the more common and wide ranging E. insidiator, with which it has been previously confused (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

For taxonomic treatment see Ayling and Russell (1977) and Randall and Randall (1981). Kuiter (2002) suggests W. Indian Ocean specimens may be distinct (B. Russell pers. comm. 2008). This species previously appeared on the Red List under the mis-spelling Pseudojuloides ceracinus.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

Labrus albovittatus (Bonnaterre 1788) is the original combination of genus and species name (Froese and Pauly 2009, Catalogue of Life 2009)
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).
This species lilkely represents a complex of undescribed species (Kuiter 2002).
For taxonomic treatment see Allen (1973) and Gomon (2006).

A. lineatus was recognised in 1972 by Randall. Prior to this, was identified as A. melanurus and earlier records probably confuse these two taxa. This has affected the distribution records especially in the eastern Indian Ocean.
C. cuvier is often listed as C. africana.

This species was previously recognised as Pseudolabrus psittaculus (Richardson) by Russell (1988), but Parenti and Randall (2000) pointed out that the name Labrus psittacula (Richardson 1830) is preoccupied by Labrus psittaculus Lacepede 1801 [= Halichoeres bivittaus (Bloch)] and referred Richardson’s species to the synonomy of Pseudolabrus rubicundus (Macleay 1881) which they regarded as the next available name. Allen et al (200X), however, in the most recent Catalogue of Australian Fishes placed Labrichthys rubicundus as incertae cedis, stating “ this name is at best a nomen dubium, as the species does not occur in Western Australia, and the description is not consistent with this south-eastern Australian species.” The next available name is Labrichthys mortonii Johnston (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Records outside the distribution area indicated on the map appear to be based on specimens of B. bilunulatus, B. loxozonus or B. perditio (Gomon 2006).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). This species has been confused with Bodianus axillaris and evidently replaces this species in India and Sri Lanka (Gomon 2006).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).

This species has been confused with the south-western Pacific species Coris picta, which occurs in south-eastern Australia, northern New Zealand and New Caledonia. These two species are probably separate and valid sibling species (Kuiter 2002), even though C. musume had been synonymised with C. picta by Randall and Araga in 1978 (D. Pollard pers. comm.. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).

The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
There is some discussion in the literature as to whether the Indian Ocean form should be considered as a different species (L. Rocha pers. comm.. 2008).

There is taxonomic confusion between H. chrysotaenia in the Pacific and H. vrolikii in the Indian Ocean.

H. chrysotaenia is considered to be a synonym of H. melanurus, a W. Pacific species (J. Randall pers. Comm. 2008). This relationship was based on an initial phase specimen of H. chrysotaenia collected in Java near Jakarta. The initial phases of H. vrolikii and H. melanurus, both W. Pacific species, are nearly indistinguishable. H. melanurus is a Pacific species based on the terminal phase and H. vrolikii is the terminal phase of its East Indian Ocean sister species. Since H. melanurus is considered a Pacific species based on the terminal phase, it is unlikely that H. chrysotaenia is the initial phase of H. melanurus. This species requires genetic research to positively link the type material of H. chrysotaenia to either H. melanurus or H. vrolikii (R. Myers pers. Comm. 2009).

This species has been confused with the north-western Pacific species Coris musume, which occurrs in southern Japan, Taiwan and the Philippines. This latter northern hemisphere species is now regarded as a separate and valid sibling species (Kuiter 2002), even though it was synonymised with C. picta by Randall and Araga (1978).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
This species is replaced by Thalassoma grammaticum in the tropical Eastern Pacific.
This species was previously considered a junior synonym of X. woodi.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

This species has only relatively been newly described (Randall 2003), and is closely related to Thalassoma jansenii (Bernardi et al. 2004). These two species may be confused. The molecular sequences of 16S rRNA in the two species are the same, though they differ in one nucleotide of the cytochrome b sequence (Bernardi et al. 2004). Although there are no significant colour differences between these two species, and they have overlapping scale counts, the former is most probably a separate and valid species (J. Randall pers. comm.. 2009). Therefore, there may be confusion over the identity of this species in previous distribution records.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002).

Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus and I. verrens.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
This species used to be treated as Halichoeres ornatissimus, but the latter is now restricted to Hawaii (Randall and Rocha 2009).

Halichoeres sazimai, n. sp. is described from the Western South Atlantic. During many years it was misidentified as H. bathyphilus from the Northwestern Atlantic, but it can be distinguished from the latter by striking color differences between the two species, with H. sazimai being characterized by a white body with a midline, zigzag patterned stripe on body, black and brownish in terminal males and yellow or golden in females and juveniles (Luiz et al. 2009).

This species was recently described in Heiser et al. (2000).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

The latent slingjaw wrasse, Epibulus brevis, was recently described from Palau, Philippines, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia (Carlson et al. 2008). E. brevis is extremely similar to E. insidiator and any past record and data of E. insidiator likely includes the former species.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species of the genera Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius including I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

This species was previously identified as H. radiatus, but recent genetic research revealed that Brazilian populations belong to a valid species now recognized as H. brasiliensis (Rocha 2004).
This species was thought to occur along the Brazilian coast, but genetic research revealed that coastal Brazilian populations belong to a different species (Rocha 2004).
The Red Sea population is a distinct C. quinquecinctus (Kuiter 2002).
This species is very similar to the closely related C. punctatus from Fiji, Tonga, New Caledonia, eastern Australia and southern Papua New Guinea.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). This species has been previously confused with B. macrourus (Russell, B. pers. comm.).

This species has in the past been misidentified as Symphodus tinca and Symphodus roissali (D. Pollard pers. comm. 2008).
Coris julis has sometimes been confused with C. atlantica, which occurs further south along the West African coastline (D. Pollard pers. comm. 2009).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
This species has only recently been described in 2008 (Allen and Erdmann 2008).
Novaculichthys macrolepidotus has been assigned to the genus Novaculoides by Randall and Earle (2004) (R. Myers pers. comm. 2008).
This species was previously identified as H. maculipinna, but recent genetic research revealed that Brazilian populations belong to a valid species now recognized as H. penrosei (Rocha 2004).

There has been some confusion with the naming of this species. Hector in 1884 named this species as Cymolutes sandeyeri after the collector F.S. Sandeyer, however, this was a misspelling of the collector's real name, Sandager. Since then, both the names sandeyeri and sandageri have been used by various authors, although Mr. Sandager in a paper in 1888 on fishes of Mokohinau Islands listed this species as Cymolutes sandageri. Randall (1999), noted that although the name sandeyeri is inappropriate, the rules of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature indicate that this name correct. See also Parenti and Randall (2000). From Eschmeyer's Catalogue of Fishes, the current status is: Coris sandeyeri (Hector 1884). Sandageri should therefore not be used (K. Carpenter pers. comm.. 2009).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1985).  This species is known only from initial phase individuals, taxonomic status uncertain.
This species is considered to be the ancestral species of Thalassoma rueppelli, T. grammaticum, T. lutescens, T. genivittatum, and T. duperreyi in the Indo-Pacific region (Bernardi et al. 2004).
This species has possibly been confused with B. solatus in western Australia (Abrolhos Islands) (Gomon 2006).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
The status of Julis girardi (Bleeker 1859), has been clarified by Randall (1978). This species is the initial phase of either H. hartzfeldii or H. zeylonicus (Parenti and Randall 2000).
This species was previously recorded as Julis noronhana (Boulenger 1890).
Specimens from the aquarium trade in Sri Lanka and south of Sumatra that have been identified as this species may be a different species.

Julis (Halichoeres) cyanopleura Bleeker 1853 and Julis (Halichoeres) pyrrhogrammatoides Bleeker 1853 were described in the same work, and Randall & Ferraris (1981) serve as first revisers selecting cyanopleura over pyrrhogrammatoides.
This species is closely related to C. flavidorsalis and females look almost identical.
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1988).

For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Gomon and Randall (1978), mistakenly synonymized Bodianus oxycephalus with Bodianus vulpinus, a name that previously had been applied to the species now recognized as Bodianus frenchii (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). This species was previously confused with Bodianus vulpinus and B. oxycephalus (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
Described by Cuvier in Cuvier and Valenciennes (1829). Genus reviewed by Vari (1978).
Recently transferred from Neogobius to Ponticola.
This species is referred to as Melampus sincaporensis in Japanese literature, but M. singaporensis in Indian and Indonesian literature. This species is M. sincaporensis as confirmed by Pfeiffer 1855.

The common south-eastern Australian estuarine ellobiid snails belonging to Ophicardelus have been considered to be one variable taxon by some authors, and three largely sympatric species by others. In 2004, Hyman et al. (2004) clarified that Ophicardelus ornatus, O. quoyi and O. sulcatus should be regarded as valid species.
Golding et al. (2007) established this species as a synonym of Phallomedusa solida (Martens, 1878).

The common south-eastern Australian estuarine ellobiid snails belonging to Ophicardelus have been considered to be one variable taxon by some authors, and three largely sympatric species by others. In 2004, Hyman et al. (2004) clarified that Ophicardelus ornatus, O. quoyi and O. sulcatus should be regarded as valid species, and in 2005 the genus for O. quoyi was changed from Ophicardelus to Pleuroloba by Hyman et al. (2005).
May occasionally be confused with Bathypterois dubius.

According to Miller (1986) and Kovačić (2004) Gobius strictus Fage, 1907 is a junior synonym of Gobius cruentatus Gmelin, 1789. The status of three small syntopic gobiid species (Gobius assoi, Gobius strictus, and Cabotichthys schmidti) was clarified by Miller (1967, 1973). Miller (1967) concluded that Gobius assoi De Buen, 1936 is a junior synonym of Cabotichthys schmidti (De Buen, 1930), and that this species should be assigned to genus Gobius. Miller (1973) later considered Gobius schmidti (De Buen, 1930) a junior synonym of Gobius strictus Fage, 1907, and not a valid species. Finally, Miller (1986) further developed his opinion and suspected that Gobius strictus Fage, 1907 not to be a valid species, but misidentified juveniles of another, larger Gobius, Gobius cruentatus Gmelin, 1789.

Studies of the morphology of juveniles and early juveniles of G. cruentatus confirmed that there was almost no differences between juveniles of G. cruentatus and the morphology given in the description of G. strictus. Without further evidence to justify the validity of G. strictus it should be considered a junior synonym of G. cruentatus (Kovačić 2004, M. Kovačić pers. comm. 2014).
This species was previously misidentified as Galearctus kitanoviriosus (T-.Y. Chan pers. comm. 2011).

According to Fernholm and Wheeler (1983), four specimens in the Naturhistoriska Riksmuseet (Swedish Museum of Natural History) are probably the original material examined by Linnaeus (1758) to describe the species and they should be accorded type status.

The western North Atlantic population was at one time assigned to a separate species, Myxine limosa Girard (1859), and Wisner and McMillan (1995) suggested a return to this practice based on differences in size at maturity (eastern North Atlantic are smaller) and colour differences in preserved specimens. In the absence of other supporting morphological data, these features seem insufficient to justify dividing the eastern and western Atlantic populations into separate species (Martini et al. 1998, Martini and Flescher 2002). More conclusive studies involving morphological and molecular data are necessary to resolve this taxonomic question.

Myxine ios is known from two populations as defined by Fernholm (1981). The Irish population is mainly known from Porcupine Seabight, southwestern Ireland (Fernholm 1981, Merrett et al. 1991, Priede et al. 1994). The West African population is known off Western Sahara, from Cap Boujdour to Cap Blanc (Fernholm 1981). Two specimens were recently trawled off Angolan waters and they present very similar characters to those of the Western Sahara population (Tweddle and Anderson 2008). The populations differ slightly in coloration (Fernholm 1981), and it is unknown if they may represent separate species.
According to Møller et al. (2005), some records of M. ios from the Denmark Strait (Fernholm and Vladykov 1984) and West Greenland (collected by Jørgensen in 2003) might belong to M. jespersenae.

The specimen FMNH 61897 was erroneously listed as a paratype by Ibarra and Stewart (1987). The species was originally described by Richardson and Jowett (1951) as Myxine biniplicata based on a 315 mm dissected female and a second small and damaged specimen measuring approximately 163 mm total length (TL).

The three foremost teeth confluent at the base is given by Günther (1870) as a character of M. australis (but occurs in only one 490 mm specimen from Sandy Point, which was selected by Regan (1913) as the lectotype of M. tridentiger. Based on the recent examination of all type series, the paralectotypes BMNH 1868.6.15.5-6 from Sandy Point (Punta Arenas) were re-identified as Myxine affinis, and paralectotypes BMNH 1868.9.16.12-13 from Tyssen Islands as Myxine knappi (Mincarone unpublished data).
This species is identified by Robertson and Allen (2006) as Gerres simillimus, which considers the Atlantic and Pacific species to be separate. However, it is also known as Gerres peruvianus.

Eptatretus burgeri was briefly described by Girard (1855) based on an illustration of a single specimen from Simabara Bay, which was previously misidentified as Heptatrema cirrhatum by Temminck and Schlegel (1850: 310, pl. 143).

authority: Fernholm, Norén, Kullander, Quattrini, Zintzen, Roberts, Mok & Kuo, 2013
taxonomicNotes:
This species was previously named Eptatretus fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and was renamed as E. luzonicus by Fernholm et al. (2013) to clarify nomenclatural conflict with Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994 (now Eptatretus fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994)).

The species was described based on unpublished notes of Bo Fernholm, taken from a single damaged specimen about 35 years ago. The holotype was possibly lost (McMillan and Wisner 2004).

Bdellostoma-hexatrema was briefly described by Müller (1836) as having six gill apertures on both left and right sides. Based on this character, he also described Bdellostoma heterotrema, which had seven and six gill apertures on the left and right sides, respectively. However, in some specimens of hexatrema, the last branchial duct is not confluent with the pharyngocutaneous duct on the left side. This is the case of the type of Bdellostoma heterotrema, which has six gill apertures plus the pharyngocutaneous opening on the left side.

In the second part of his work, Müller (1838) believed that all the species described by him in 1836, including Bdellostoma heptatrema from southern seas, were just simple varieties of Bdellostoma forsteri (Müller, 1836) (junior synonym of Eptatretus cirrhatus). Recently, the combinations Bdellostoma forsteri var. heterotrema and Bdellostoma forsteri var. hexatrema were treated incorrectly as original descriptions in Müller (1838) by Paepke and Schmidt (1988).

The species name was misspelled once by Wongratana (1983) as E. indambaryai in the species heading and indrambaryi in Table 1. This species is named after Mr. Boon Indrambarya, therefore E. indrambaryai is the correct spelling.
This species was originally placed in the genus Eptatretus but is now placed in Rubicundus according to work by Fernholm et al. (2013).

The name was corrected to Eptatretus laurahubbsae by Wisner and McMillan (1988). Morphological evidence suggests that specimens of E. laurahubbsae could be juveniles of E. carlhubbsi. Further analyses are necessary to confirm this suspicion.
The 338 mm female USNM 161513 (paratype of Paramyxine springeri) is in fact an E. minor, as previously reported by Fernholm and Hubbs (1981) and confirmed by recent examination.

According to Fernholm (1986, 1998), E. octatrema was only known from the 300 mm holotype. In the original description, Barnard (1923) apparently described only one specimen, but he stated “…ventral fin ending only a short distance (8-10 mm) behind last gill-opening”. The range “8-10 mm” could be evidence that there were at least two specimens used for the description. In addition, the only other known specimen BMNH 1927.12.6.1 (formerly SAM 13031) is listed as "co-type" in the original register. According to the SAM database (M. Bougaardt pers. comm.), the station data for these specimens are: SAM 13030, Cape Saint Blaize, North 1/4 North, 6.5 miles, 36 fm (66 m), 28 June 1899, shrimp trawl, RV Pieter Faure; and BMNH 1927.12.6.1 [ex SAM 13031], Cape Saint Blaize, West 3/4 North, 4 miles, 27 fm (49 m), 25 January 1900, trawl, RV Pieter Faure. Based on this evidence, both specimens are considered here as syntypes of E. octatrema. Also, the type locality provided in Barnard’s (1923) original description (“Agulhas Bank, 25-40 fm”) is an assumed approximation.

Many authors reported the occurrence of polibranchiated hagfishes in Chilean waters under the species name polytrema. However, these citations pertain to unrecognizable species in that neither count had useful proportions or color notes provided. A complete list of names and references of these unassignable records was provided by Wisner and McMillan (1988), which also contains citations under the species name dombey (Gastrobranche dombey La Cepède, 1798) or dombeyi (Gastrobranchus dombeyi Shaw, 1804), an unrecognizable myxinid from Chile.

authority: Fernholm, Norén, Kullander, Quattrini, Zintzen, Roberts, Mok & Kuo, 2013
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously named Eptatretus wisneri McMillan, 1999 and was renamed as E. bobwisneri by Fernholm et al. (2013) to clarify nomenclatural conflict with Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994 (now Eptatretus wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994)).

The holotype of Myxine affinis (BMNH 1951.10.4.3) was examined, but it was not possible to take any measurement or count (except teeth), as the specimen was totally dried. Three paralectotypes of Myxine tridentiger Garman, 1899 (BMNH 1868.6.15.5-6) were recently examined and re-identified as Myxine affinis. They were formerly misidentified as Myxine australis by Günther (1870).

Muraenoblenna olivacea La Cepède (1803) from Strait of Magellan was placed in the synonymy of the younger Myxine affinis as nomen dubium by Wisner and McMillan (1995). It is an undoubted Myxine, but can’t be referred with certainty to any species due to the fact that La Cepède’s description was very short and no type material is available for examination.

Shimizu (1983) reported three specimens of an undescribed Myxine off Suriname at 310 m depth. According to Wisner and McMillan (1995), the short description given by Shimizu (1983) is very similar to that of M. mccoskeri, except by the color pattern. However, the colour described by Shimizu was based on fresh specimens, and therefore, is different from those preserved specimens described by Wisner and McMillan (1995).
The species name robinsi was corrected to robinsorum by Fernholm (1998).

European and North American Atlantic Salmon have long been considered as a single species but they are distinguished by chromosome numbers and genetic characteristics (e.g. Lubieniecki et al. 2010). Their taxonomic status should be re-evaluated.
Scaevatula amancioi, Rolán and Fernandes, 1993 on WoRMS and WMSDB. Slight misspelling on SIS?

Lepadogaster lepadogaster was separated in two subspecies (Brigg 1986): L. l. lepadogaster in the Mediterranean region only, and L. l. purpurea in the western Mediterranean and eastern Atlantic.

In 2002, Henriques et al. investigated the relationships between L. l. lepadogaster, L. l. purpurea and L. zebrina. They noted significant differences in microhabitat preferences and their breeding seasons between the two subspecies. They concluded that L. l. purpurea is a valid species, L. purpurea (Bonnaterre, 1788), different from L. l. lepadogaster, which is now designated L. lepadogaster (Bonnaterre, 1788). Lepadogaster zebrina was found to be a synonym of L. lepadogaster.
Giant sea bass was originally assigned to the grouper family, Serranidae, but was later placed in a new family called the Percichthyidae (Domeier 2001).
Note correction to spelling of the generic name from Teinsotoma to Teinostoma.
Note correction to spelling of the generic name from Teinsotoma to Teinostoma.

The very similar and closely related (sister) species occurring around Saint Helena Island is Thaloassoma sanctaehelenae. Thalassoma ascensionis has also been recorded as occurring around Sao Tome Island in the Gulf of Guinea (Afonso et al. 1999), though the species in this latter area is almost certainly T. newtoni. Occurrences listed from Ghana and Congo probably also refer to the latter species, and those from Senegal to T. pavo, which also occurs in the Cape Verde Islands and northwards to the Azores, including in the Mediterranean sea (Bernardi et al. 2004, Castagliola et al. 2004).

The West Indian manatee (Trichechus manatus) is currently divided into two subspecies: the Florida (T. m. latirostris) and Antillean (T. m. manatus) manatees (Hatt 1934, Domning and Hayek 1986). The mtDNA data (García-Rodríguez et al. 1998) and molecular data (Vianna et al. 2006) revealed a population structure with three distinctive lineages corresponding geographically with: (1) Florida, Mexico, the Greater Antilles, Central America, and the Caribbean coast of South America; (2) Mexico, Central America, and the Caribbean coast of South America; and (3) NE South America from Guyana to Brazil. Evidence exists for viable hybridization with T. inunguis near the mouth of the Amazon River, Guyana, French Guiana, and possibly Suriname (Lima et al. 2019).

Recent cranial and chromosomal geographic variation data from Antillean manatees in Brazil show morphological discontinuity and chromosomal divergence within T. m. manatus and the Brazilian population south of the Amazon. These data suggest that the current taxonomy of T. manatus needs to be revised (Barros et al. 2016).

Of all the giant clam species, Tridacna crocea is the smallest with a maximum size of ~15 cm (Rosewater, 1965). Commonly known as the 'burrowing' or 'boring' giant clam, T. crocea is a rock borer that embeds its entire body into the substratum, leaving only the colourful outer mantle exposed (Yonge, 1936). This species is byssally attached to its bored concavity. Tridacna crocea is typically identified by its boring habit, but it also develops well-spaced scutes that become eroded over time within the borehole.

The second largest species, Tridacna derasa, grows up to 60 cm in shell length. It is known as the smooth giant clam because its valves have almost no ribbing (Rosewater 1965). Tridacna derasa has brilliant mantle colours, displaying shades of blue and green with striped patterns. Its incurrent siphon bears relatively inconspicuous guard tentacles (Lucas et al. 1991).

Tridacna gigas is the only truly gigantic giant clam species: the largest individual reported was 137 cm long (Rosewater 1965), while the heaviest known specimen (106 cm shell length) weighed approximately 500 kg (Lucas 1994). The species is easily identified by its size and distinctive elongate and triangular projections on the upper shell margins. Mantle colours are mostly dull brown and olive green, and the mantle edge bears numerous iridescent blue-green circles. Unlike the other Tridacna species, the incurrent siphon of T. gigas bears no tentacles.

The shell morphology of T. rosewateri shares features with both T. maxima (i.e. large byssal orifice) and T. squamosa (i.e. large scutes), but differs from those species in having thinner shell walls, deep triangular valve margin folds, and larger dense scutes on primary radial folds (Sirenko & Scarlato 1991, Monsecour 2016).

There is some potential for confusion with regards the common names of this species. In some areas, Smalleyed Ray may be called Painted Ray or Sandy Ray, though these common names are also used for undulate ray Raja undulata and Leucoraja circularis respectively.

The genus Vanvoorstia contains three species. Vanvoorstia spectabilis and V. coccinea are common tropical (Indo-Pacific, including GBR) species, with the former also recorded from Lord Howe Island. While some confusion exists as to the exact differences between these two species (Price and Scott 1992), both are easily distinguished and considered very different from V. bennettiana, a very much smaller- and finer-meshed species in which the tetrasporangial stichidia are also easily defined.

There are now four species. Eric Coppejans (pers. comm.) indicates that there is a new species he described from East Africa which is probably Critically Endangered: Vanvoorstia incipiens De Clerck, Wynne & Coppejans (Phycologia 38 (1999): 394-400). This newly described species occurs massively in a single (rather small) bay along the east coast of Zanzibar, at about low tide level (large amounts drifting or entangled to other seaweeds in intertidal pools). Coppejans carried out over 200 collecting excursions along the Kenyan, Tanzanian (incl. Zanzibar) coast and NEVER found a single specimen anywhere else than the type locality, where we find it again year after year. It doesn't occur in the neighbouring bays, which look "identical" to this one! If that bay would be disturbed (harbour, oil pollution, etc.) the only known (type) locality would disappear and we would have a similar story there within the same genus!! Apparently some representatives do not succeed in colonizing larger areas!

The degree of genetic separation between Polyprion americanus populations in the Atlantic, and those occurring in the southern Pacific (Australia and New Zealand) is similar to the degree of separation seen between P. americanus and congener P. oxygenios. Given ongoing developments in genetic sequencing, further examination may re-define Polyprion systematics.
Considered as a possible subspecies of C. xanthicus Dall, 1910.
This species is said to be conspecific with Coregonus autumnalis, but is treated separately here. It appeared on the Red List from 1996 to 2006 incorrectly spelt as Coregonus artedii.

Ris (1919) described Orthetrum poecilops poecilops from Guangdong. The subspecies Orthetrum poecilops miyajimaense Yuki & Doi, 1938 was described, originally as separate species, from Miyajima, a small island near Hiroshima, southern Honshu, Japan. Asahina and Sawano (1957) synonymised the two taxa but later Asahina (1970) reinstated miyajimaense at subspecies level, based principally on its smaller size. Wilson (2001) considers the two taxa are probably synonyms. Nevertheless the Japanese population represents a distinct and isolated (fragmented) population.
Accepted name is Plesiocystiscus gutta (Gofas and Fernandes, 1988), with Cystiscus gutta now unaccepted (According to WoRMS).
Accepted name is Plesiocystiscus josephinae (Fernandes and Rolán, 1992). Cystiscus josephinae is unaccepted (According to WoRMS).

There are no recent synonyms. In terms of identification, juvenile spotted rays can be confused with the morphologically similar blonde ray (Raja brachyura) and thornback ray (Raja clavata). Some spotted rays have fewer spots that are concentrated in the centres of the wings and can be misidentified as cuckoo rays (Leucoraja naevus).
Attention RLU: Please change the taxonomic authority from (Durham & Barnard, 1952) to Durham & Barnard, 1952. Reference is WoRMS. - C. Linardich 13Jan2022

This alga has not been taxonomically evaluated since its initial description. The name of this taxon is illegitimate according to AlgaeBase (http://www.algaebase.org; checked 11 July 2007). This taxon may be synonymous with another taxon.

Rhizoclonium is a notoriously difficult genus. Additionally, this species was described from insufficient material (K.A. Miller pers. comm.). This taxon was not included in AlgaeBase (http://www.algaebase.org; checked 11 July 2007).
This species needs to be critically compared with D. cokeri (Howe) Taylor.

Farghaly (1980) reported Dictyota major from the Indian Ocean (Madagascar); however, according to De Clerck (2003), Dictyota major remains a poorly known species, rarely reported outside its type locality (Post Office Bay, Floreana, Galápagos) and its presence in the tropical Indian Ocean would be highly unusual. Moreover, De Clerck (2003) did not find D. major in the course of his study of the genus Dictyota in the Indian Ocean (K.A. Miller pers. comm.). Two other publications report D. major outside the Galápagos; Silva et al. (1987) reported this species from Southwest Asia, and Silva et al. (1996) reported D. major from Madagascar (Africa). Nevertheless, according to K.A. Miller (pers. comm.), Silva references are compendiums of published reports and nomenclatural notes, not critical assessments of species. Thus, all confirmed references to Dictyota major are from Galápagos.
There is taxonomic uncertainty in this genus.
Taylor (1945) doubted the validity of this species because it is difficult to distinguish from S. galapagense. He favored varietal status – Sargassum galapagense var. setifolia).

The Banggai Cardinalfish has eight dorsal spines, 14 dorsal soft rays, two anal spines, and 13 anal soft rays (Koumans 1933). This species is distinguished further by having a tasseled first dorsal fin and a deeply forked caudal fin. Both the second dorsal fin rays and anal fin rays are elongate. The colour pattern is quite distinctive with three black bars across the head and body, black edges along the anterior margins of the second dorsal and anal fins, black edges along the upper and lower margins of the caudal fin, and black pelvic fins marked with white spots. A series of similar white spots run along the edges of the second dorsal, anal and caudal fins (Allen and Steene 1995, Allen 2000). The body is silvery and contains about 20 brilliant whitish dots between the second and third black bars. Dots of each individual have a unique disposition that can be used for specimen identification (Vagelli 2002). Body size of adults reaches 80 mm total length and 55 mm standard length (SL) (Allen 2000). Secondary sexual dimorphism has not been demonstrated for this species (Vagelli and Volpedo 2004).

The genus Pterapogon contains only one other species, P. mirifica from northwestern Australia. However, ongoing studies on the reproductive biology, behaviour, anatomy and preliminary data on molecular studies on P. mirifica (A. Vagelli, pers. comm. on 27th Feb 2007) indicate that it is distantly related to the Banggai Cardinalfish and may in fact merit separate generic status. Therefore the Banggai Cardinalfish may be unique at the generic level.
A. svedelii may be synononymous with A. taxiformis, a widespread species (K.A. Miller pers. comm.).
A. papenfussii needs further taxonomic study.
Difficult to distinguish from the closely related Austrofolium howellii (Taylor) M.J.Wynne.
Difficult to distinguish from the closely related Austrofolium equatorianum (Dawson) M.J.Wynne.
Uncertain taxonomic status (K.A. Miller pers. comm.).
Laurencia is difficult to identify at the species level. There is considerable confusion between species in this genus and further taxonomic work is essential (K.A. Miller pers. comm.).
Laurencia is difficult to identify at the species level. There is considerable confusion between species in this genus and further taxonomic work is essential (K.A. Miller pers. comm.).

Laurencia is difficult to identify at the species level. There is considerable confusion between species in this genus and further taxonomic work is essential (K.A. Miller pers. comm.).
This taxon is not included in AlgaeBase (http://www.algaebase.org; checked on 11 July 2007).

Foliose red algae are notoriously difficult to identify; without fertile material, even experts cannot make firm determinations. This species is likely to be misidentified and all records need confirmation (K.A. Miller pers. comm.)

Foliose red algae are notoriously difficult to identify; without fertile material, even experts cannot make firm determinations. This species is likely to be misidentified and all records need confirmation.

Foliose red algae are notoriously difficult to identify; without fertile material, even experts cannot make firm determinations. This species is likely to be misidentified and all records need confirmation. This species has a distinctive internal anatomy and can often be identified by examining cross-sections microscopically.
Foliose red algae are notoriously difficult to identify; without fertile material, even experts cannot make firm determinations. This species is likely to be overlooked or be misidentified.
