Some specimens of this species approach P. cuticulosa Howe (Howe 1914) from Peru. Critical study is warranted.
Foliose red algae are notoriously difficult to identify; without fertile material, even experts cannot make firm determinations. This species is likely to be overlooked or be misidentified.
Taxonomic work is needed. The type specimen in UC is annotated as "not Sebdenia" (K.A. Miller pers. comm.).

Nerodia clarkii formerly was included in N. fasciata. Allozyme data support separation of clarkii and fasciata as distinct species (Lawson et al. 1991). Nerodia clarkii may interbreed with N. fasciata in areas of distributional overlap; this may be related to habitat disturbance caused by humans or hurricanes (Lawson et al. 1991).

Three subspecies have been recognized (clarkii, compressicauda, and taeniata). Dunson (1979) lumped taeniata with compressicauda. Based on allozyme data, Lawson et al. (1991) resurrected taeniata as a valid subspecies, but the genetic distances used to support this action were quite small.

This species formerly was included in the genus Natrix.

Genetic analyses in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific indicate that nesting populations comprise separate and identifiable stocks that should be treated as separate management units (Bass et al. 1996, Bowen et al. 1996, Bowen and Karl 2007). Hawksbill aggregations on foraging grounds comprise animals from multiple nesting populations and often include animals from distant rookeries (Broderick et al. 1994, Bowen et al. 2007).

Treated by some authors under the genus Palola. May even be a junior synonym of Palola siciliensis (Grube, 1840), in which case it may have a much wider distribution and could probably be listed as Least Concern. See: Fauchald, K. 1992. Review of the types of Palola (Eunicidae: Polychaeta) Journal of Natural History 26: 1177-1225.

The taxonomy of anadromous Ponto-Caspian shads remains in question, with molecular studies revealing low genetic divergence between species inhabiting the Black, Caspian and Aegean sea basins.

Given that a conclusive taxonomic revision has not yet emerged, the approach applied in the majority of recent literature is maintained for the purposes of this assessment. The Pontic shad is therefore considered to be allospecific with the Azov shad (Alosa maeotica) and Black Sea shad (A. tanaica).
Species of the Acropomatidae family are ill-defined (FAO ECA guide in prep PC Heemstra).
Species of the Acropomatidae family are ill-defined (Heemstra in press).

Phipps (1774) first described the Polar Bear as a distinct species and named it Ursus maritimus. Other names were suggested including Thalassarctos, Thalarctos, and Thalatarctos. Erdbrink (1953) and Thenius (1953) ultimately settled on Ursus (Thalarctos) maritimus because of interbreeding between Brown Bears (Ursus arctos) and Polar Bears in zoos. Based on the fossil record, Kurtén (1964) recommended the Phipps (1774) name Ursus maritimus, which was promoted by Harington (1966), Manning (1971) and Wilson (1976) and is used today (see DeMaster and Stirling 1981, Amstrup 2003, Wilson and Reeder 2005).
This species is also reported as Gobius (Awaous) aeneofuscus (antiquated name).
Species-level identification of Arnoglossus is problematic and the taxonomy of this genus requires further clarification.

There are issues of taxonomic quality within the family Ammodytidae. Gymnammodytes capensis and G. cicerelus do not significantly differ morphologically and therefore, their status is uncertain. They were described as separate species due to differences in geographic distribution of regional populations, however a systematic revision is needed (Nizinski in press).

A second morphotype found in the Gulf of Guinea, with larger eyes and a narrower interorbital width, is currently considered, with some question, as part of this species but may represent another valid species, Halobatrachus conspicillum (Cuvier, 1829) according to Collette et al. (2006).

Three subspecies are recognized (Collette and Parin 1970, Collette 2003): Belone belone belone (Linnaeus, 1761) from northeastern Atlantic Ocean, Belone belone euxini Günther, 1866 from the Black Sea and the Sea of Azov, and Belone belone acus Risso, 1826 from the Mediterranean Sea and adjacent parts of the Atlantic, Madeira, Canary Islands, Azores, and south to the Cape Verde Islands.

Four subspecies are recognised:
  • T. a. acus (Lacepède, 1803) in the western Atlantic (Massachusetts, USA to Brazil) and east Atlantic (off Morocco and the western Mediterranean Sea);
  • T. a. imperialis (Rafinesque, 1810) in the Mediterranean Sea and Cape Verde Islands);
  • T. a. rafale Collette and Parin 1970 from the Gulf of Guinea; and
  • T. a melanotus (Bleeker, 1850) in the the Indo-West Pacific and oceanic islands in the eastern tropical Pacific (Revillagigedos, Clipperton, and Cocos).
There are three subspecies B. p. podas, B. p. maderensis, and B. p. africanus, and there some questions regarding the taxonomic status of these subspecies.
There is confusion as to whether C. rubescens is the true valid species name.

Morphological studies based on gill raker counts and head length supported the designation of two sub-species within Sardina pilchardus: S.p. pilchardus (Eastern Atlantic from the North Sea to southern Portugal) and S. p. sardina (Mediterranean Sea and Northwest African coast)(Parrish et al. 1989). Genetic analysis using nuclear micro satellites supports S. pilchardus as a single evolutionary unit with present day gene flow among subpopulations, with some weak but significant structuring best explained by an isolation-by-distance model (Gonzalez and Zardoya 2007). Sardina pilchardus is treated as a single evolutionary unit by fisheries managers, and the various stocks have been designated arbitrarily as magnitude of exchange between areas continues to be uncovered. This species does not appear to be as commercially important in the southeastern Mediterranean. Long-term changes in the environment are related to productivity of S. pilchardus and other sardine and anchovy species in the Mediterranean (ICES 2010).

Exocoetus obtusirostris is endemic to the Atlantic Ocean and showed no significant differences from different parts of this ocean. It was thought to occur circumglobally before it was split into three other closely related species (Parin and Shakhovskoy 2000).

This may represent a species complex (Tomio pers. comm. 2012).
Coelorinchus caelorhincus was formerly considered as having a number of subspecies, but those are here recognized as full species. Eschmeyer and Bailey in Eschmeyer (1990:70) changed the spelling of the name from Coelorinchus coelorhincus (or Coelorhynchus coelorhynchus) to Caelorinchus caelorhincus, based on their interpretation. Iwamoto (2008: xi) agreed with the “ae” spelling of the species name (i.e., caelorhincus) but disagreed with the use of that dipthong in the generic name. He considered “Coelorinchus” to be the correct spelling, but accepted that there is room for doubt and agreed that the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature should be petitioned to fix the spellings of the generic and specific names (Iwamoto 2016).
Subpopulations south of Mauritania may represent another species; further taxonomic research is warranted (T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2012).
This species is often confused with Nezumia aequlis.
Gadella maraldi is quite often misidentified as G. imberbis in tropical waters where G. maraldi probably does not occur (Iwamoto in press).
The subpopulation in the Gulf of Guinea may prove to be a distinct species Perisedion macronema (Cadenat, 1951).

Two subspecies are recognized, Scomberesox saurus saurus (Walbaum, 1792) from the Northern Hemisphere and S. saurus scombroides (Richardson, 1843) from the Southern Hemisphere (Hubbs and Wisner 1980, Collette 2004).
This species is often confused with P. impar.

Some authors (Ben-Tuvia 1990, Tinti and Piccinetti 2000) consider that S. aegyptica is a synonym of S. solea. Other authors consider S. aegyptica a valid species (Desoutter 1997, Borsa and Quignard 2001).

After several years of confusion and mistake, the underwater identification of S. viridensis is now correct. Consequently, Dufour et al. (2007) gives accurate repartition of S. sphyraena and S. viridensis (P. Francour pers. comm. 2007).

Two subspecies are recognized by Collette (2003), T. crocodilus crocodilus (Peron and Lesueur 1821) from the Atlantic and Indo-West Pacific and T. crocodilus fodiator (Jordan and Gilbert 1882) in the eastern tropical Pacific.

This species has two subspecies, T. cristulata cristulata in the Western Atlantic, and T. cristulata echinata in the Eastern Atlantic. Specimens from Peru and Australia/New Zealand likely represent a different, distinct species or subspecies of a different species (Poss in press).
Subpopulations of this species should be further investigated as they may represent separate species (Tomio pers. comm. 2012).

Cheilopogon melanurus has been reported from the eastern Atlantic, from Senegal to Angola (Parin 1999). The eastern tropical Atlantic population was studied earlier by Gibbs and Staiger (1970). They discovered significant differences in pectoral-fin pigmentation and barbel structure between juvenile specimens of this population and similar-sized western Atlantic specimens and suspected, even not finding any distinctions between adults of both populations, the presence of yet undescribed species near the shores of West Africa. Parin and Belyanina (2000) reexamined three of these smaller eastern Atlantic specimens (USNM 203903, 203905 and 218912) and re-identified them as C. milleri (Gibbs and Staiger 1970). However, the western and eastern populations are so different in predorsal-scale number (25-33, mean 28.4, by 8 specimens, vs. 31-36, mean 33.7) that recognition of another species is highly probable (Parin in prep).

Parin and Belyanina (1998) separated the subspecies Cheilopogon furcatus furcatus from two new subspecies in the Indian and Pacific oceans. Another subspecies, C. furcatus neimani Parin & Belyanina occurs in the Indian Ocean and the third subspecies C. furcatus fisunovi Parin & Belyanina is widely distributed in the Pacific Ocean from western to eastern Pacific.
This species has been sometimes been recorded as E. indica, but all records of this species from the Atlantic are now known to be E. melanoderma (Swinney 1994).
This species has been previously recorded as Gigantura vorax but this is now regarded as a synonym of G. chuni.
Within the Mediterranean, this species has also been reported as Bathypterois mediterraneus, a junior synonym of B. dubius (Quéro and Ribes 1999).
The correct spelling for this species is Omosudis lowii (Günther, 1887), though other spellings are in use (Eschmeyer 2014). This species is also referred to as Omosudis loweii by FAO.

The name S. brasiliensis (type locality: Cape Frio, Brazil) has been generally used for this species.  However, genetic evidence indicates approximately 5-6% divergence in CO1 between eastern and western Atlantic populations, which suggests the populations on either side of the Atlantic are distinct species [Baldwin et al. in press]. Thus, the name S. parri Norman 1935 (type locality: Angola) should be applied to this species.

Gymnammodytes capensis and Gymnammodytes cicerelus do not significantly differ morphologically and therefore, their status is uncertain. They were described as separate species due to differences in geographic distribution of regional populations. A systematic revision is needed. (Nizinski in press).
Hemiramphus balao is frequently misidentified as Hemiramphus brasiliensis.

Oxyporhamphus micropterus similis is replaced in the Indo-Pacific by the nominal species Oxyporhamphus micropterus micropterus.  It is considered to be Exocoetidae by some authors (Collette 2002). The recent acceptance of Oxyporhamphus similis as a species by Eschmeyer should be reviewed (B. Collette pers. comm. 2012).
This species is sometimes placed in its own genus, Nanichthys (Collette 2004). It is also often confused as the juvenile form of Scomberesox saurus scombroides (Bianchi et al. 1999).

This nominal species, Etrumeus teres (DeKay 1842), was described based on specimens collected off New York. Whitehead (1985) included all populations of round herrings that were identified as this species in a single species, which was thought to be  globally distributed. However, in a recent taxonomic revision (Randall and DiBattista 2012), this nominal species, Etrumeus teres (sensu Whitehead 1985) was split into four distinct species: E. makiawa Randall and DiBattista 2012, restricted to the Hawaiian Islands; E. micropus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846), from Japan, and perhaps south to Indonesia; E. acuminatus Gilbert 1890 from the eastern tropical Pacific; and E. sadina (Mitchill 1814) from the northwestern Atlantic (with Etrumeus teres (DeKay 1842) as a junior synonym).

The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be one to two hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014). Further, the importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through checklists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).

The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be one to two hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014). Further, the importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through checklists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).
The Caristiidae family is in need of a thorough revision (Moore et al. 2003, Stevenson et al. 2016).
This species is possibly a junior synonym of Cepola macrophthalma (Smith-Vaniz in press).

There has been confusion regarding the validity of Cynoglossus microphthalmus and this nominal species. Menon (1977) considered C. microphthalmus to be a junior subjective synonym of Cynoglossus capensis, though he noted several characters to distinguish these nominal species. Barnard (1925) also noted differences between characters of specimens that he identified as Trulla microphthalmus compared to those of C. capensis, however, he did not consider these differences to be significant enough to recognize two species. Further study based on additional material is needed to resolve this taxonomic question (T. Munroe unpublished data). Munroe (unpublished data) considers the morphological differences sufficient to recognize both as valid species.

There are three co-occurring species of the genus Syacium in the western Atlantic. Identification of specimens to species is difficult because the species are morphologically similar and there is a significant amount of sexual dimorphism. Often times, these fishes are not identified to the species level and it is likely that in some studies catches consist of more than one species (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).

It is difficult to identify this species with certainty (Desoutter et al. 2001). Torchio (1973) recorded the species as questionably a synonym of Microchirus azevia (de Brito Capello, 1867), but Desoutter (1990) accepts Microchirus theophila (Risso 1810) as a valid species.

Vachon et al. (2008) state that Synaptura has never been a valid genus name, and re-assigned all Synaptura spp. to Dagetichthys.

Synaptura cadenati is a junior synonym of Dagetichthys lusitanica (Desoutter et al. 2001). However, in the Eastern Central Atlantic, many studies and many scientists still consider two nominal species to occur. More detailed information is available under S. cadenati than D. lusitanica.
Ophidion josephi is a senior synonym of O. welshi. The O. marginatum/josephi complex is in need of review (Lea and Robins 2003).
The genus of this species was recently changed from Carangoides to Caranx (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2012, Page et al. 2012).
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
Synodus bondi was recently resurrected from synonymy under S. foetens and both were redescribed by Frable et al. (2013).
Dornburg et al. (2012) proposed changing the genus of this species to Flammeo, however, this has not yet been generally accepted.
The genus of this species was previously Hypoatherina, but is now Atherina.
This species can be commonly misidentified as B. maculiferus (Weigt et al. 2012).

Many specimens historically identified as A. maculatus that have been found off the coast of Brazil around St. Paul's Rocks may have been misidentifications of A. strigosus, which has been recorded there based on molecular evidence (Bowen et al. 2001).
Dornburg et al. (2012) proposed changing the genus of this species to Neoniphon, however, this has not yet been generally accepted.

This species was described based on a single specimen collected off Haiti (Jordan in Jordan and Goss 1889). Other studies dealing with the taxonomy of Atlantic species of Citharichthys (Jordan and Goss 1889, Jordan and Evermann 1900, Norman 1934, Gutherz 1967) did not report any additional specimens. It has since been reported in several books and checklists from Central America (e.g. Castro-Aguirre et al. 1999, Munroe 2003, Angulo et al. 2013), but the basis of these records and the number of additional specimens is uncertain. The taxonomic status of this nominal species requires further investigation (Munroe 2003); for example, Robertson and Van Tassell (2019) suggested that this nominal species may be conspecific with Citharichthys arenaceus.
Dornburg et al. (2012) proposed changing the genus of this species to Neoniphon, however, this has not yet been generally accepted.
Lepophidium profundorum reported from the Southern Caribbean are referable to as L. cultratum (R. Robins pers. comm. 2013).
There are multiple undescribed species in this group which may have been confused with this species.
Page et al. (in press) accept the present taxonomic standing of Foetorepus agassizii.
In Brazilian waters, this species has been previously misidentified as Saurida suspicio (Carvalho-Filho et al. 2010).
There are multiple undescribed species in this group which may have been confused with this species.
Foetorepus agassizii and F. dagmarae were previously recognized as subspecies but have relatively recently been determined to be full species (Nakabo and Hartel 1999).
In the Gulf of Mexico, this species is known as the subspecies C. striata melana. In the Atlantic, it is known as C. striata striata (Roy et al. 2012).
The West Pacific population may represent another species.
Brotula barbata may be a species complex (Nielsen et al. 1999, de Paiva et al. 2010, R. Robins pers. comm. 2013).
This species may represent a complex of more than one species and further work is required to resolve it taxonomic status of S. suspicio and its distribution in the region (A. Polanco 2006).
Specimens of Opsanus dichrostomus may easily be misidentified as O. phobetron.

Species of the Ogilbichthys genus are easily confused with A. minyomma due to very similar morphologies and sympatric occurrences, therefore, extra care should be taken to determine an accurate identification (Moller et al. 2004).
The O. marginatum/josephi complex is in need of review (Lea and Robins 2003).

Böhlke and Thomas (1961) discussed geographic variation in Opistognathus aurifrons, especially with regard to color pattern. Although they noted that specimens from the Bahamas and Florida can be consistently distinguished from each other by the presence or absence of black markings on the head, their observation that these markings are inconsistent in Virgin Island specimens led them to synonymize Gnathypops bermudezi. Subsequently, Ho et al. (2012) examined population genetics and color pattern of four Caribbean populations of O. aurifrons; although each population exhibited high levels of genetic differentiation, phenotype variation and genetics were not congruent.

Specimens from Brazil, including Trinidade Island and Fernando de Noronha, possibly represent a geminate species of O. aurifrons. They cannot be distinguished genetically and have virtually identical color patterns, but differ in vertebral counts. The taxonomic status of the Brazilian population is presently unresolved.

There is some uncertainty surrounding the taxonomic status of this species. There are two recognized species: Bathyanthias mexicanus and B. cubensis. A third, not yet described species occurs in the southern part of the Caribbean, and it is unknown if this confuses the distribution of B. cubensis. However, specimens examined from Colombia by A. Polanco pers. comm. (2018) are recognized as B. cubensis. The genus Bathyanthias requires further taxonomic study and it is not known how the ranges of B. mexicanus and B. cubensis overlap in the Gulf of Mexico (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2018).
Some workers consider the genus of this species to be valid as Serranus, not Centropristis.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.
This species should be regarded as valid as Ancyclopsetta quadrocellata, not as A. ommata (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).

There are three co-occurring species of the genus Syacium in the western Atlantic. Identification of specimens to species is difficult because the species are morphologically similar and there is a significant amount of sexual dimorphism. Often times, these fishes are not identified to the species level and it is likely that in some studies catches consist of more than one species (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).
Lonchopisthus meadi (Menezes and Figueiredo 1971) is a junior synonym of L. lemur (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2012).
Lonchopisthus linderi Ginsburg, 1942 is a junior synonym of L. micrognathus.
Common names and scientific names for non-Atlantic and non-South African localities are probably missapplied (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2013).

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families. Their study recognized 11 species of Kyphosus in Kyphosidae, and the monotypic Neoscorpis. Thus, there are 12 species total in the family Kyphosidae. 

Kyphosus lutescens and K. pacificus are now treated as synonyms of K. sectatrix (Knudsen and Clements 2013). Both K. incisor and K. analogus are now considered synonyms of K. vaigiensis (Knudsen and Clements 2013). Kyphosus sandwicensis is a junior synonym of K. elegans (Knudsen and Clements 2013). 

Before Knudsen and Clements (2013) it was thought that only two Kyphosids occurred in the Atlantic, but there may in fact be four species, K. sectatrix, K. vaigiensis, K. bigibbus, and K. cinerascens. However, Sakai and Nakbo (2014) have presented an alternative view on the kyphosids occurring in the Atlantic.

The 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists included Hippocampus horai, H. novaehebudorum, H. raji, and H. taeniops. These are now all considered to be synonyms of H. kuda. According to Vincent (1996) and Lourie et al. (1999), there may be as many as ten distinct species that are included under the name Hippocampus kuda. Further research into the literature on this species is needed to determine whether H. kuda is the correct name for populations occurring within the Persian Gulf (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2014).

Individuals from the western Indian Ocean appear to be genetically distinct from individuals from the rest of its distribution (BOLD; Ratnasingham and Hebert 2007); additional material is needed to determine whether these specimens represent two geographically isolated populations and to determine the limits of their respective distributions.

Lethrinus nebulosus may represent a complex of species, and further taxonomic work is required (K. Carpenter pers. comm. 2015). A cryptic species under L. nebulosus was detected in a study off southeastern Africa, but further study is required to resolve the taxonomy and distribution (Healey et al. 2018).
This name was frequently applied to what is now recognized as Lethrinus rubrioperculatus and its use prior to 1989 is probably not reliable (K. Carpenter pers. comm. 2015).

Morphological and genetic variability of the nominal species Lethrinus olivaceus support the presence of two distinct species (Lethrinus sp. A in the Indian Ocean and Lethrinus sp. B in the western Pacific Ocean) whose distribution ranges meet or overlap in the Coral Triangle (Borsa et al. 2013). This species complex will be treated as one species until further taxonomic revision has been completed.

The validity of the sub-species is questionable (Munroe 2002). "Etropus delsmani" is a valid species according to Eschmeyer 2012, and this account is in reference to E. delsmani; Etropus delsmani spp. pacificus is considered a synonym of Etropus delsmani.
The genus of this species was recently changed from Hemanthias to Baldwinella (Anderson and Heemstra 2012)

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in colour patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them. This species also shows the greatest amount of variation of the hamlets (Thresher 1978).

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.
The eastern Atlantic and Brazilian subpopulations may represent variations of R. subbifrenatus or an undescribed species (Baldwin and Weigt 2012).
There are likely two well-defined sub-species that differ in coloration and meristics: a northern one and a southern one (Bullock and Smith 1991).
There is ongoing debate as to the taxonomic status of M. antillarum; Munroe (2002) considered it a junior synonym of M. sessilicauda.
Currently, this species is valid as S. civitatum, based on "of the states" rather than "of the citizenry" (see Munroe 1991 and etyfish to flesh this out).

Etropus crossotus was originally described from specimens collected in the eastern Pacific Ocean. Populations identified as this species from the western Atlantic, though morphologically similiar, have not been examined from a genetic perspective to determine if they are conspecific with the eastern Pacific populations (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015). For now, we continue to use E. crossotus for Atlantic populations.

The generic assignment of Pleuronectes oblongus Mitchill 1815 has been questioned. Some authors consider the appropriate placement to be in the genus Hippoglossina, while others consider this species to be a member of the genus Paralichthys. A comprehensive revision of these genera is necessary to resolve this conundrum.

There are three co-occurring species of the genus Syacium in the western Atlantic. Identification of specimens to species is difficult because the species are morphologically similar and there is a significant amount of sexual dimorphism. Often times, these fishes are not identified to the species level and it is likely that in some studies catches consist of more than one species (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).
Polydactylus oligodon is difficult to distinguish from P. virginicus (Feltes 2002, B. Smith-Vaniz and R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).
There should be some investigation into the taxonomic standing of this species (i.e., whether it it belongs in the Syngnathiformes or Gasterosteiformes).
In the field, this species is difficult to distinguish from Stephanolepis hispidus (R. Robertson and J. Tyler pers. comm. 2015).
This species can be confused with its congener, R. subbifrenatus (Smith-Vaniz and Collette 2013).

Specimens from NE Australia are morphologically similar to those from the rest of the Indo-West Pacific (Sara Lourie, unpublished data). Kuiter (2001) however classifies them as H. dahli. Genetic data on BOLD suggest that specimens of putative H. dahli are >5% different from H. trimaculatus and may reflect cryptic speciation. This requires further investigation.

Kuiter (2001) also resurrected H. kampylotrachelos based on a single specimen which, upon examination by SL, was found to be in poor condition, although it did have low fin ray counts for H. trimaculatus.

Eschmeyer (2014) considers H. manadensis to be valid, and H. mannulus to be a synonym of H. comes, however the type descriptions and type specimen (of H. manadensis) clearly ally them with H. trimaculatus . There is a deep genetic division (approx. 2.9% K2P distance) between specimens east and west of Wallace’s line based on 696bp of cyt b mtDNA (Lourie and Vincent, 2004).
This species is closely related to Prionurus punctatus, and genetic and morphological studies are required to confirm the taxonomic status of these two species.
This species is closely related to Prionurus laticlavious, and genetic and morphological studies are required to confirm the taxonomic status of these two species.
Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).

Clements et al. (2004) recognize the Odacini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

This species was previously referred to the genus Odax by Gomon and Paxton (1985), but recent phylogenetic analysis (Clements et al. 2004) indicates Odax is polyphyletic and that acroptilus should be separated in its own genus, Heteroscarus. It is treated as H. acroptilus by Gomon et al. (2008).
Clements et al. (2004) recognize the Odacini as a tribe within the family Labridae.
Clements et al. (2004) recognize the Odacini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

Clements et al. (2004) recognize the Odacini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

This species was previously referred to the genus Odax by Gomon and Paxton (1985), but recent phylogenetic analysis (Clements et al. 2004) indicates Odax is polyphyletic and that cyanomelas should revert to its own genus, Olisthops. It is treated as Olisthops cyanomelas by Gomon et al. (2008).

Clements et al. (2004) recognize the Odacini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

There has been a suggested taxonomic rearrangement of Siphonognathus to split the genus into two genera (Sheardichthys and Parodax) on the basis of (a) the type species S. argyrophanes only should retain the genus Siphonoganthus as it is morphologically distinct from the other five species of Siphonoganthus, which should be placed in Sheardichthys, and (b) Siphonognathus caninis is sufficiently distinct from the remaining four species (i.e. Siphongnathus attenuatus, S. beddomei, S. radiatus and S. tanyourus) to warrant placement in a separate genus, Paradax (R. Kuiter pers comm. 2010).
Clements et al. (2004) recognize the Odacini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

Clements et al. (2004) recognize the Odacini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

The east and west Atlantic populations of N. usta were designated as separate subspecies by Schultz (1968) on the basis of minor morphometric divergences in preserved fishes (Nicholsina usta usta and Nicholsina usta collettei ).

Recent data show that these two forms are highly divergent genetically, more so than many of the Sparisoma species are from each other (Robertson et al. 2006). Hence, the east and west Atlantic forms represent a sister pair of species, N. collettei and N. usta, respectively (Parenti and Randall unpublished).

There has been a suggested taxonomic rearrangement of Siphonognathus to split the genus into two genera (Sheardichthys and Parodax) on the basis of the type species S. argyrophanes only should retain the genus Siphonoganthus as it is morphologically distinct from the other five species of Siphonoganthus, which should be placed in Sheardichthys (Kuiter pers comm. 2010).

Grubb (1993) lists five subspecies: H. a. amphibius from eastern Gambia to Sudan, Ethiopia, the northern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Tanzania and Mozambique, H. a. tschadensis from Nigeria and Chad, H. a. kiboko from Somalia and Kenya, H. a. constrictus from Angola, the southern DRC and Namibia, and finally, H. a. capensis from Zambia southwards to South Africa. It is important to note, however, that this classification has not been widely accepted (Eltringham 1999; Beckwitt et al. 2016), and recent taxonomic research of this species is lacking. Furthermore, these five subspecies are visually indistinguishable in the wild, and the geographic extent of each range remains vague (Eltringham 1993).
Fennane and Ibn Tattou (1998) do not refer to the taxa Puccinellia distans subsp. fontquerii Maire and Puccinellia distans subsp. embergeri (H. Lindb.) Maire & Weiller as synonyms.
This species was originally described as Triathalassothia gloverensis, but was later moved into the genus Vladichthys (Greenfield et al. 2008).

This species' taxonomy remains partially unresolved, with molecular studies demonstrating the current concept to comprise at least three potentially distinct taxa in the western Mediterranean alone. Some authors refer to the subpopulation inhabiting the Azov and Black Sea basins, including their affluent rivers, as S. nigrolineatus (Eichwald 1831), but this view had not gained wide acceptance at time of writing. The former subpopulation from the Caspian Sea basin is currently valid as S. caspius (Eichwald 1831).

It is important to note that there is some taxonomic uncertainty associated with Salmo taxa. Collectively, all nine proposed taxa identified by the IUCN SSC Salmon Specialist Group (SSG) as uncertain—Salmo tigridis, S. platycephalus, S. ischchan, S. abanticus, S. labecula, S. chilo, S. opimus, S. rizeensis, and S. coruhensis—could be considered to fall within what some authors have referred to as the Salmo trutta species complex. This statement means nothing more than the fact that the mtDNA of these taxa would fall within the multiple clades of what sometimes has been simply referred to as Salmo trutta, comprising five or six major mtDNA lineages.  The only Salmo taxa outside of this group of clades (genetically speaking) would be Atlantic Salmon (S. salar), S. belvitca, S. ohridanus and Soft-mouthed Trout (S. obtusirostris). Whereas future higher resolution genetic data (i.e. genomic) will undoubtedly shed more light on the pairwise divergence and  phylogenetic position of these taxa, the SSG sees no evidence, nor has any expectation, that genomic level data will place any of these taxa outside of these major mtDNA lineages.
The taxonomy and key characteristics of Brama species are in need of review (Haedrich in press).

The western Pacific/Indo-Pacific populations of this species were previously considered a subspecies Lagocephalus lagocephalus oceanicus, while those in the Atlantic were previously considered the subspecies Lagocephalus lagocephalus lagocephalus.

The Lucifuga genus is known as one of the most diverse stygiobiotic fishes to have been described. The taxonomy of Lucifuga species may still be incomplete due to relatively common discoveries of new species. Garcia-Machado et al. (2011) concluded that Lucifuga spp. are genetically divergent, but morphologically indistinguishable and recommends revisiting the taxonomy of the genus. Since the distribution of certain morphological characters among these species are disjointed, they possibly may not be used for classification in the future. A revision of the Lucifuga spp. of Cuba with the description of a new species is currently in preparation by Hernández et al. (Hernández, D., Casane, D., García, A., Chevalier-Monteagudo, P., Møller, P. R. and García-Machado, E.)
Ariomma melanum and Ariomma bondi were historically considered the same species.

Acanthopagrus schlegelii was divided into two subspecies: A. schlegelii czerskii and A. schlegelii schlegelii. However, these subspecies have overlapping distributions (Akazaki 1962, Lindberg and Krasyukova 1969) which contradicts the criterion of a subspecies and suggests that these taxa belong to a single species (Mayr 1971, Dolganov et al. 2008). Further taxonomic work needs to be conducted for the A. schlegelii complex. This species is currently recognized as Acanthopagrus schlegelii.

This species is in need of taxonomic review for the whole East Asian Shelf (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2014).
This may be a subspecies of Anchoviella perfasciata (Whitehead et al. 1988).
There has been some uncertainty surrounding the family and genus placement of this species (Prokofiev 2007).
Benthodesmus tenuis may represent a group of closely related species (Parin and Nakamura 2002).
The taxonomy of this species needs review.
This species almost certainly belongs to Haemulidae (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2010 in Catalog of Fishes).
This species was redescribed by Ho et al. (2017).

Fundulus majalis is in the subgenus Fontinus (E.O. Wiley 1986). The Gulf of Mexico population of this form has often been referred to a separate species, F. similis. Ross (2001) and Relyea (1983) consider the Atlantic and Gulf populations to be conspecific. According to McEachran and Fechhelm (1998), there is an allopatric population of F. majalis in the Florida Keys and Florida Bay which may represent a distinct species. If F. similis is valid, then all Gulf of Mexico F. majalis should be considered F. similis (Duggins et al. 1995).
A recent taxonomic revision of this genus was conducted by Ho et al. (2010).
A subspecies, Hoplostethus mediterraneus trunovi, has been reported off of Namibia (Moore in press).
Howella atlantica is considered by some a subspecies of Howella brodiei Ogilby, 1899, although accepted by Eschmeyer (2015).
Previous to the description of Lepophidium cultratum many workers applied the name Lepophidium profundorum to the undescribed species (Rob Robins pers comm 2013).

Lepophidium entomelan and L. zophochir are similar, disjunctly distributed species. Further sampling in the Southern Caribbean may reveal an adjacency or overlap in distribution that will clarify relationships between the species (R. Robins pers. comm. 2012).

L. zophochir and L. entomelan are similar, disjunctly distributed species. Further sampling in the Southern Caribbean may reveal an adjacency or overlap in distribution that will clarify relationships between the species (Rob Robins pers comm 2013).
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.

Neobythites ocellatus was split into two species based on differences in color patterns, which resulted in the naming of a new species (Neobythites multiocellatus) and restricted the distribution of N. ocellatus to Brazil between 233-641 m depth (Nielsen et al. 2009).
Records in the northwestern Gulf of Mexico are suspected to be O. pantostictus due to taxonomic issues within the genus (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).
Populations of this species in the Western Atlantic versus the Pacific may represent two separate species (Kotlyar 2001).
This species was previously known as Parexocoetus brachypterus or Parexocoetus brachypterus hillianus, but the Atlantic population was raised to species level by Parin (2003).
Before its description by Parin in 1999, it was usually misidentified as Prognichthys gibbifrons (Valenciennes 1846).

Previously known as Prognichthys gibbifrons throughout the Atlantic, but Parin (1999) described P. occidentalis for the western Atlantic population and P. glaphyrae for open waters of the tropical Atlantic, leaving the eastern Atlantic population to retain the name of Prognichthys gibbifrons.
This species had a genus change in 2016 according to Poulsen et al., and should now be considered as Monacoa grimaldii. need to request change in SIS

Lepadogaster lepadogaster was separated in two subspecies (Brigg 1986): L. l. lepadogaster in the Mediterranean region only, and L. l. purpurea in the western Mediterranean and eastern Atlantic.

In 2002, Henriques et al. investigated the relationships between L. l. lepadogaster, L. l. purpurea and L. zebrina. They noted significant differences in microhabitat preferences and their breeding seasons between the two subspecies. They concluded that L. l. purpurea is a valid species, L. purpurea (Bonnaterre, 1788), different from L. l. lepadogaster, which is now designated L. lepadogaster (Bonnaterre, 1788). Lepadogaster zebrina was found to be a synonym of L. lepadogaster.
This species was originally described as Dactylostomias ater.

Leptostomias gracilis, Leptostomias macropogon,Leptostomias longibarba, Leptostomias bermudensis, Leptostomias analis and Leptostomias leptobolus are probably synonyms of a single species. The entire complex needs a thorough study (Gibbs and Barnett 1990).
This species was first described as Echiostoma micripnus.
The Trachipteridae family needs revision (Olney in press).
The Trachipteridae family needs revision (Olney in press).
This species may be a misidentification of C. suttkus.
Heemstra and Heemstra (2004) describes the taxonomy of Callionymidae as unsettled and the genera as poorly defined.
Heemstra and Heemstra (2004) describes the taxonomy of Callionymidae as unsettled and the genera as poorly defined.
The Trachipteridae family needs revision (Olney in press).
The Trachipteridae family needs revision (Olney in press).

About eleven species are recognized in Watson (1992) included Chonophorus and Euctenogobius as subgenera of Awaous. Watson (1996) recognizes one species, A. (Chonophorus) lateristriga from West Africa.
According to Maugé (1986), reports of the Western Atlantic species Guavina guavina from Senegal are probably based on misidentifications of Bostrychus africanus
E. cyanescens, previously considered a synonym of E. nitidus, has recently been recognized as a valid species (Fricke et al. 2014 description of marisrubri).

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families.

Girella stuebeli was originally described by Troschel (1866) as a different species from Girella zonata, however, the ontogenetic or intraspecific variations are also shown in several species of Girella. Also, there are no substantial morphological character differences recognized. Thus, Girella stuebeli is regarded as a junior synonym of Girella zonata.
Gobius strictus Fage, 1907 is considered a synonym of C. cruentatus according to Miller (1986) and Kovačić (2004).
Gobius pappenheimi is a questionable synonym of Porogobius schlegelii (Eschmeyer 2013).
This species is sometimes referred to as Argyropelecus olfersi.
Maurolicus muelleri is recognized here in the restricted sense based on the most recent review of the genus by Parin and Kobyliansky (1993).

Marceniuk and Menezes (2007) reviewed the phylogeny of the Ariidae and applied the genus Carlarius to this species. Historically, misidentifications of species in the genus Arius were common: for example, Golani and Sonin (1996) reidentified a specimen reportedly of A. thalassinus as A. parkii. Further, many records of this species have been reported as Arius heudelotii (Taylor 1990).
Preliminary molecular studies suggest that the genus Schedophilus is not monophyletic (Milana et al. 2011)

The family Cheilodactylidae has long been the subject of taxonomic debate along with its type species, Cheilodactylus fasciatus. Recently, Ludt and colleagues (2019) performed extensive taxonomic sampling analyzing morphological characters and molecular data and determined C. fasciatus is a valid species.

The taxonomy of C. niger does not appear to be resolved; while Melo (2009) recognizes seven species in the genus, Prokofiev and Kukuev (2009) placed many of these species in synonymy with C. niger, only recognizing two species in genus.
Barcode of Life Database (BOLD) lists Schedophilus labrinthicus a distinct species. Eschmeyer lists Schedophilus labrinthicus as a synonym (Milana et al. 2011).
The Trachipteridae family needs revision (Olney and Hartel 2016).
Breviraja marklei McEachran & Miyake, 1987 is now recognised as a synonym of Rajella fyllae (Dyldin 2015, Weigmann 2016, Last 2016).
The species that has previously been referred to as Squatina dumeril in the southern Caribbean has recently been described as Squatina david by Acero et al. (2016).
Sometimes known as Cephaloscyllium sarawakense (Fricke et al. 2020).

The characters thought to differentiate Zenion longipinnis from Z. hololepis are erroneous. The course of the lateral line is the same for both species. The isthmus of Z. hololepis is completely scaly, but scales were missing on the holotype from abrasion in the trawl. The membrane joining the pelvic-fin spine to the rays is fragile and easily torn in trawl-caught specimens (Heemstra in press).

Aetobatus ocellatus (Kuhl, 1823) was previously considered to be an Indo-West and Central Pacific form of the wider ranging Aetobatus narinari (Euphrasen, 1790). Comparative analysis of the morphology, molecular and parasite diversity has resulted in the redescription of A. ocellatus from tropical and warm-temperate waters of the Indian Ocean and West-Central Pacific Ocean with A. narinari being restricted to the Atlantic Ocean (Richards et al. 2009, White et al. 2010). Molecular analyses suggest greater levels of speciation within the Aetobatus genus, with distinguishable groups in the Western Indian Ocean and Northwest Pacific (Schluessel et al. 2010, White et al. 2010). Samples from Qatar cluster separately -- designated as A. cf. ocellatus 2 (D. Ebert pers. comm. 2017). This requires further examination to delineate species boundaries.

Smith (1964) redescribed Cruriraja parcomaculata from the Eastern Cape of South Africa, assuming that the Cruriraja present in the Western and Eastern Cape was the same as von Bonde and Swart's R. parcomaculata from KwaZulu-Natal (Compagno and Ebert 2007). Smith also described C. triangularis from two specimens off Durban, as distinct from C. parcomaculata Smith, 1964. Re-examination of the type material by Compagno and Ebert (2007) and Aschliman et al. (2010) found that C. triangularis Smith, 1964 is in fact a junior synonym of C. parcomaculata (von Bonde and Swart, 1923), and concluded that the Cruriraja species common along the south and west coasts referred to as C. parcomaculata was an undescribed species. Aschliman et al. (2010) after a reviewing these species described a new species C. hulleyi while synonymizing C. triangularis as a junior synonym of C. parcomaculata. Therefore, information on the life history and distribution of C. triangularis prior to 2010 should now be referred to as C. parcomaculata, and life history and distribution information previously referred to for west coast C. parcomaculata is referable to as C. hulleyi. See Aschliman et al. (2010) for further explanation of this issue.

Aphanopus intermedius is easily confused with A. carbo the areas where both species occur, because there are no conspicuous external characteristics that differentiate the two species (Nakamura and Parin 1993, Parin 1995). Biscoito et al. (2011), analysed both species in terms of genetic and morphological features and stated that they could not be correctly identified in a classical taxonomic way and a full separation of the two species could only be achieved through the use of a combination of morphometric and meristic characters in a numerical taxonomic approach.

Sequences of two markers (control region and cytochrome b) of A. intermedius from Angola were extremely similar to the A. carbo phylogroup corresponding with the southern coast of Pico Island, Azores, suggesting that the two species may exist in sympatry in the Azores (Stefanni and Knutsen 2007). Aphanopus carbo and A. intermedius differ by geographic distribution, maximum adult size and vertebral count; and external distinguishing characters are absent (Parin 1983, Stefanni and Knutsen 2007). A PCR-based method for the rapid identification of A. intermedius and A. carbo has recently been developed (Stefanni et al. 2009).

This species may comprise at least two separate species (Ward et al. 2008), therefore taxonomic research is needed.

Cryptic species
Lepidopus caudatus shows very high levels of intra-specific divergence (2.75% using the CO1 barcode region) between northern (Atlantic and Mediterranean) and southern (Australasian) clades (Ward et al. 2008). Additionally, there are differences in pigmentation and meristic characters between these main population centers which require further study (FAO 2014).
The narrow distribution of this species is uncommon for this family (Iwamoto pers. comm. 2013).
This assessment includes M. b. barbatus and M. b. ponticus.
This species was originally named Serranus fuscus by Lowe (1836), and was previously confused with Mycteroperca rubra, which occurs only along mainland West Africa and the Mediterranean Sea.
The subpopulation in the Gulf of Guinea may prove to be a distinct species Perisedion macronema (Iwamoto pers. comm. 2013).

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

Hybrid specimens of Cephalopholis fulva and C. furcifer have been observed in the Brazilian oceanic islands of Trindade (Pinheiro et al. 2009), Atol das Rocas (Batista et al. 2012) and Fernando de Noronha (B. P. Ferreira and A.A. Bertoncini pers. comm. 2016) and in the North Atlantic from Cuba and Bermuda (Smith 1966, Bostrom et al. 2002). These were initially described by Poey in 1860 and 1875 as Menephorus dubius and M. punctiferus (Smith 1966, Bostrom et al. 2002).
This species is also known as Chelidoperca africana (Heemstra and Anderson in press, Iwamoto pers. comm. 2013).

Diplodus sargus as presently recognized is an assemblage of genetically closely related species whose current taxonomic assignments of species and subspecies are somewhat inconsistent and require further work (Summerer et al. 2001, Domingues et al. 2007). Pending more detailed population genetic work, the six subspecies of D. sargus, are retained in individual species accounts but are not separated in the parents species account.  

Two geographic subspecies of Diplodus sargus have been recognised in the European region: Diplodus sargus subspecies sargus in the Mediterranean; and Diplodus sargus subspecies cadeneti in the northeastern Atlantic - from the Bay of Biscay to Senegal, including the Azores, Madeira and the Canary Islands (Summerer et al. 2001). Only weak genetic differentiation is found for the European subspecies of D. sargus (Bargelloni et al. 2005) that is not associated with the transition between the Atlantic and the Mediterranean, contradicting the separation into distinct sub-species of the Mediterranean and Atlantic D. sargus populations, classified as D. s. sargus and D. s. cadenati, respectively (De la Paz et al. 1973, Bauchot and Hureau 1986).

Diplodus sargus requires taxonomic revisions and there may also be two forms in the Persian Gulf (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2013).

This species is considered by some to be a synonym of Conus ventricosus, but it is listed on the World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS), and considered by Monteiro et al (2004) as a valid species. The populations around Malta and Lampedusa are not considered to be certain they are this species (Monteiro et al 2004).
This species is endemic to the Cape Verde Islands where it was originally considered to be a subspecies of C. verdensis.  It is now considered a distinct species.

Originally two subspecies were recognised, C navarroi navarroi and C navarroi calhetae, however these two are separated on different islands and are now known to be distinct taxa C. navarroi and  C. calhetae (M. J. Tenorio pers. comm. 2011).

The Caristiidae family is in urgent need of revision due to confusion of the number of genera, species and distributions (Britz in press). This issue has recently been remedied by Stevenson and Kenaley (2011) and Kukuev et al. (2012).

This circumglobal species is restricted to subtropical waters, and consisting of a series of disjunct subpopulations, many of which until recently were considered to represent distinct species. Until recently, most of the literature in the eastern Pacific referred to this species are Seriola dorsalis.

Some workers consider Trachurus capensis to be a subspecies under Trachurus trachurus (Smith-Vaniz 2016). Bianchi et al. (1993) notes 'W. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. (1992) does not believe that Trachurus capensis is a valid species, but admits that an adequate series of this species along the coast of Africa is not available'. For the purposes of this assessment, it is considered a valid species.
Some authors recognize a second species in the southern portion of the range, T. capensis (Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2014).

Caranx hippos from the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean was recently split into two species. A new species, C. fischeri, was recently described by Smith-Vaniz and Carpenter (2007). Caranx hippos and C. fischeri are largely sympatric, however it is C. fischeri which is found in the Mediterranean. There have been no confirmed records of C. hippos in the Mediterranean.
This species is likely to belong to a monotypic genus (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2014).

The taxonomy of Trygonorrhina spp. was previously confused because of problems with type information (Last and Stevens 2009, White and Last 2012). Two similarly patterned species were considered allopatric off southern Australia, i.e. the Southern Fiddler Ray (Trygonorrhina fasciata) off southern and southwestern Australia and the Eastern Fiddler Ray (T. sp. A) (Last and Stevens 1994) off eastern Australia. Based on the locality and the illustration of the T. fasciata type specimen, it was identified as the Eastern Fiddler Ray, thus replacing T. sp. A as the name for the eastern species. The Southern Fiddler Ray, previously called T. fasciata, was renamed as T. dumerilii Castelnau, 1873 based on the oldest available name which could be accurately attributed to the southern species (White and Last 2012). 

The Magpie Fiddler Ray (T. melaleuca) is now considered to be a colour variant of T. dumerilii (Donnellan et al. 2015).

Trygonorrhina fasciata differs from T. dumerilii by having a diamond-shaped marking behind the eyes, which are parallel in T. dumerilii.

The taxonomy of Trygonorrhina spp. was previously confused because of problems with type information (Last and Stevens 2009, White and Last 2012). Two similarly patterned species were considered allopatric off southern Australia, i.e. the Southern Fiddler Ray (Trygonorrhina fasciata) off southern and southwestern Australia and the Eastern Fiddler Ray (T. sp. A) (Last and Stevens 1994) off eastern Australia. Based on the locality and the illustration of the T. fasciata type specimen, it was identified as the Eastern Fiddler Ray, thus replacing T. sp. A as the name for the eastern species. The Southern Fiddler Ray, previously called T. fasciata, was renamed as T. dumerilii Castelnau, 1873 based on the oldest available name which could be accurately attributed to the southern species (White and Last 2012). 

Trygonorrhina fasciata differs from T. dumerilii by having a diamond-shaped marking behind the eyes, which are parallel in T. dumerilii.
Records of this species from the Cook Islands and Society Islands (French Polynesia) may refer to an undescribed species (Woodland et al. 2001). Further taxonomic research is required.
A taxonomic review of this group is required to properly identify the species of this genus.

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. chabaudi), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

The North Island subpopulation of Hector’s Dolphin is recognized as a subspecies, Cephalorhynchus hectori maui (Baker et al. 2002), with the common name Māui Dolphin, and has been assessed separately.  The common name Hector’s Dolphin refers either to the whole species, or to the nominate subspecies, C. h. hectori, depending on context.
There are issues of taxonomic quality within the family Ammodytidae (Nizinski in press).

There are issues of taxonomic quality within the family Ammodytidae (Nizinski in press). Prior to the revision by Sabatés et al. (1990), the accepted description of G. cicerelus included two species: G. cicerelus and G. semisquamatus.
There are issues of taxonomic quality within the family Ammodytidae (Nizinski in press).

Based on molecular data, Parablennius ruber is a sister species of Parablennius gattorugine, with which it forms a very differentiated clade within the genus Parablennius (Almada et al. 2005). Its validity as a separate species has been confirmed by Almeida (1982) and Bath (1982).
There has been considerable historical confusion regarding the taxonomic validity of this species. It has often been considered a synonym of Arnoglossus kessleri.
The subpopulations in French Mediterranean coastal lagoons may comprise a separate subspecies (J.P. Quignard pers. comm. 2008).
Syngnathus temminckii is a valid species, and the southern African portion of the previously assessed S. acus is in fact under that name (Mwale et al. 2013).
In Georgia and Romania (Black Sea), the subspecies M. m. euxinus (Nordmann, 1840) is recorded.
Herler et al. (2005) clarified the status of G. fallax Sarato (1889).
This species was previously (prior to 1992) identified as Gobius auratus (Risso 1810). This species is easily misidentified, especially with the yellow morph of G. auratus.
This species has been confused with Lebetus guilleti, Le Danois, 1913 (Herler and Kovacic 2002).
Pomatoschistus norvegicus was previously considered a subspecies of P. minutus (P. minutus norvegicus) but has since been elevated to a valid species (Webb and Miller 1975).

Vanneaugobius dollfusi Brownell, 1878 was considered a synonym of Vanneaugobius pruvoti, however Pallaoro and Kovačić (2000) collected additional specimens that are thought to belong to the valid species V. dollfusi.
This species was classified as a subspecies (Molva dypterygia macrophthalma) but is now recognized as a species (Cohen 1990).

Sea Mink has been regarded as a subspecies of the American Mink Neovison vison, but Mead et al. (2000) and Wozencraft (2005) recognized it as a distinct species. Both are commonly included in Mustela, but were separated into Neovison according to Abramov (2000). Cytogenetic and biochemical data support their placement in the genus Neovison (Wozencraft 2005).

In 2011 the genus of all Fur Seals other than Arctocephalus pusillus was changed from Arctocephalus to Arctophoca (Committee on Taxonomy 2011) based on evidence presented in Berta and Churchill (2012). However, in 2013, based on genetic evidence presented in Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds (2012), this change was considered to be premature and these species were returned to the genus Arctocephalus pending further research (Committee on Taxonomy 2014).

In the past, two subspecies were recognized: Arctocephalus australis australis (Zimmerman, 1783) for the Falkland subpopulation and A. a. gracilis (Nehring, 1887) for the mainland subpopulation. Animals from the Falklands have been reported to be larger than animals from coastal South America (Rice 1998). However, the validity of these subspecies was disputed (Reijnders et al. 1993). In their review of pinniped taxonomy, Berta and Churchill (2012) concluded that the Fur Seals in Peru and northern Chile probably represent an unnamed subspecies. After examining all the morphological, genetic and distributional evidence, Oliveira and Brownell (2014) concluded that A. a. gracilis should be treated as a junior synonym of A. a. australis, and they supported the recognition of a Peru/northern Chile subspecies. This assessment combines the IUCN Red List assessments for the South American and Peruvian Fur Seal subspecies to assess the status of the South American Fur Seal as a species.

In 2011 the genus of all Fur Seals other than Arctocephalus pusillus was changed from Arctocephalus to Arctophoca, Peters 1866 (Committee on Taxonomy 2011) based on evidence presented in Berta and Churchill (2012). However, in 2013, based on genetic evidence presented in Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds (2012), this change was considered to be premature and these species were returned to the genus Arctocephalus pending further research (Committee on Taxonomy 2013).

This species was formerly referred to Arctocephalus australis galapagoensis (Repenning et al. 1971). New genetic information suggests that it is indeed very close to A. australis and may also be categorized as A. australis galapagoensis (Wolf et al. 2007). The population shows strong matrilineal structure where geographically close colonies display separate mitochondrial haplotypes, but it is well connected and mixed through gene flow presumably caused by male dispersal (Lopes et al. 2015).

Two subspecies are recognised: Arctocephalus pusillus pusillus (Cape Fur Seal) and Arctocephalus pusillus doriferus (Australian Fur Seal). The two recognised subspecies of Arctocephalus pusillus are almost identical in both anatomy and behaviour (Warneke & Shaughnessy 1985). Repenning et al. (1971) accorded them subspecific status based on one cranial character and separate geographic ranges. Very low genetic divergence indicates that they split relatively recently, with the Australian subspecies being the more recently established (Lento et al. 1997; Wynen et al. 2001).

In 2011 the genus of all Fur Seals other than Arctocephalus pusillus was changed from Arctocephalus to Arctophoca, Peters 1866 (Committee on Taxonomy 2011) based on evidence presented in Berta and Churchill (2012). However, in 2013, based on genetic evidence presented in Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds (2012), this change was considered to be premature and these species were returned to the genus Arctocephalus pending further research (Committee on Taxonomy 2013).

The species was originally named Arctocephalus townsendi (Merriam 1897) after a specimen collected on the beach on the west side of the type locality ‘‘Guadalupe Island, Baja California, México”. This species is also referred to as Arctophoca townsendi (Sivertsen 1954), Arctocephalus philippii (King 1954) and Arctocephalus philippii townsendi (Brunner 2004). Skull morphology and genetics suggest that the closest relative of A. townsendi is A philippii, which explains why the Guadalupe Fur Seal has been considered a subspecies of the latter. However, using criteria of skull morphology, Repenning et al. (1971) retained them as separate species, but their conclusion was based on a small sample size. Wynen et al. (2001) in a comparative study of two regions of the mitochondrial genome of the family Otariidae also separated these two taxa as species. A recent genetic study by Higdon et al. (2007) suggests that Arctocephalus townsendi and A. philippii are valid separate species with an estimated time of separation of about 0.3 mya.

This species was referred to formerly as Arctocephalus elegans, A. gazella and A. tropicalis tropicalis. It is now named as A. tropicalis (Repenning et al. 1971; Rice 1998). In 2011 the Taxonomy Committee of the Society for Marine Mammalogy revised the genus of this, and many other species of fur seals to Arctophoca based on evidence presented in Berta and Churchill (2012). However, in 2013, and based on genetic evidence presented in Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds (2012), this change was considered to be premature and these species were returned to the genus Arctocephalus pending further research (Committee on Taxonomy 2013).

The Northern Fur Seal, Callorhinus ursinus, (Linneaeus, 1758) is in the family Otariidae and  is the only extant species within the genus Callorhinus. Although earlier work had suggested that more than a single species or subspecies might exist, the current belief is that there is only the one species (Rice 1998) and genetic studies suggest that they are panmictic (Dickerson et al. 2010). Despite the genetic history that indicates mixing, there are currently two recognized stocks of Northern Fur Seals in North America. The Eastern Pacific stock includes those Fur Seals breeding on the three primary rookeries in Alaska, the Pribilof Islands and Bogoslof Island in the Aleutian chain. The San Miguel stock includes those seals breeding on the Channel Islands and the Farallon Islands of California.

Morphometric and allozyme analyses, as well as molecular genetics analyses, suggest that Hooded Seals are a single panmictic population (Wiig and Lie 1984, Sundt et al. 1994, Coltman et al. 2007). Three breeding stocks are commonly recognized: Gulf of Saint Lawrence and the Front (east coast of Canada); Davis Strait; and the West Ice (north of the island of Jan Mayen) (Sergeant 1974, Lavigne and Kovacs 1988).

Rice (1998) lists two intergrading subspecies of Bearded Seals, Erignathus barbatus nauticus in the Pacific Ocean and peripheral seas and E. b. barbatus in the Atlantic Ocean and peripheral seas. The ranges of the two putative subspecies are thought to be divided near the central Canadian Arctic in the west and the Laptev Sea in the east, with the Atlantic subspecies occurring from the central Canadian Arctic east to the central Eurasian Arctic and the Pacific subspecies occurring from the Laptev Sea east to the central Canadian Arctic, including animals in the Sea of Okhotsk (Rice 1998). However, Burns (1981) noted that the boundaries between the subspecies have never been firmly established and he considered subspecific distinction to be an open question. Geographical variation does exist in the calls of Bearded Seals across their range, suggesting some population substructure (Risch et al. 2007), and recent genetics studies support the recognition of two subspecies (Davis et al. 2008).

In previous IUCN evaluations, Steller Sea Lions have been treated as a single species. The species was listed as two separate stocks (officially called “distinct population segments”) under the US Endangered Species Act (ESA) in 1997 based on the phylogeographic method (Loughlin 1997). Although the strongest evidence for stock separation at the time was the distribution of mtDNA haplotypes across the range, a divergence in population trend was also apparent. Phillips et al. (2009) published a manuscript that argued for subspecies designation for the two stocks based on morphological and genetic studies. The Society for Marine Mammalogy Committee on Taxonomy subsequently recognized two subspecies of Eumetopias jubatus; E. j. jubatus commonly known as the Western Steller Sea Lion, and E. j. monteriensis, commonly known as Loughlin’s Steller Sea Lion (Committee on Taxonomy 2014). The Pinniped Specialists Group has assessed the two subspecies independently. This assessment combines the assessments for the subspecies and reports the status of the entire species.

The taxonomy of the Grey Seal, Halichoerus grypus, has been confusing. Bonner (1981) concluded that there are three populations isolated both geographically and by timing of reproduction. Chapskii (1975) recognized the three populations as separate subspecies, H. g. grypus in the western North Atlantic, H. g. atlantica in the eastern North Atlantic, and H. g. baltica in the Baltic Sea.

Rice (1998) recognized two subspecies, H. g. grypus in the western and eastern North Atlantic and H. g. macrorynchus in the Baltic Sea. However, Boskovic et al. (1996) found large differences in mtDNA between the three breeding areas, with the Baltic and east Atlantic populations much closer to one another than they were to the west Atlantic population. The Society for Marine Mammalogy recognizes two subspecies, the Western Atlantic Grey Seal (H. g. grypus) and the Eastern Atlantic Grey Seal (H. g. macrorynchus) (Committee on Taxonomy 2014). The IUCN Pinniped Specialist Group prefers the common names Northwest Atlantic Grey Seal and Northeast Atlantic Grey Seal, and has assessed those subspecies separately. This assessment combines the subspecies assessments to evaluate the Red List status for H. grypus as a species.
Rice (1998) notes that the specific name was frequently misspelled (weddelli) prior to Bonner (1988).
Rice (1998) states that the correct spelling of the specific name is carcinophaga, not the previously more widely used carcinophagus.
None

The genus Monachus previously included three geographically widely separated species: the Mediterranean Monk Seal, Monachus monachus; the Caribbean Monk Seal, M. tropicalis; and the Hawaiian Monk Seal, M. schauinslandi (Rice 1998). Recent studies (Scheel et al. 2014) have shown that molecular, morphological, and temporal divergence between the Mediterranean and New World Monk Seals (Hawaiian and Caribbean) is equivalent to or greater than between sister genera of other phocids. As a result, Caribbean and Hawaiian Monk Seals have been reclassified together in a newly erected genus, Neomonachus. Considered the most primitive of all living phocid species, Monk Seals have anatomical features that resemble those of seal fossils from 14-16 million years ago (Barnes et al. 1985). Studies of N. schauinslandi DNA microsatellites revealed unprecedented low levels of diversity and heterozygosity. Evidence indicates low genetic diversity prior to recorded human influence, little contemporary inbreeding, and no significant population structure (Schultz et al. 2009, 2010).

The genus Monachus previously included three geographically widely separated species: the Mediterranean Monk Seal, Monachus monachus; the Caribbean Monk Seal, Monachus tropicalis; and the Hawaiian Monk Seal, Monachus schauinslandi (Rice 1998).  Recent studies  (Scheel et al. 2014) have shown that molecular, morphological, and temporal divergence between the Mediterranean and New World Monk Seals (Hawaiian and Caribbean) is equivalent to or greater than between sister genera of other phocids. As a result, Caribbean and Hawaiian Monk Seals have been reclassified together in a newly erected genus, Neomonachus. Considered the most primitive of all living phocid species, monk seals have anatomical features that resemble those of seal fossils from 14-16 million years ago (Barnes et al. 1985).
According to Rice (1998) the taxonomy of Phocarctos of New Zealand and Neophoca of Australia was confused until clarified by King (1960).

The Walrus, Odobenus rosmarus, was in the past divided into three subspecies: the Atlantic Walrus (O. r. rosmarus), the Pacific Walrus (O. r. divergens), and the Laptev Walrus (O. r. laptevi) (Rice 1998). However, the status of the Laptev Walrus has always been somewhat uncertain, animals from that region are described as being intermediate in size between the Pacific and Atlantic forms, with skull morphology most similar to the Pacific subspecies (Fay 1982). Recent analyses of mitochondrial DNA and morphometric data suggest that the taxon O. r. laptevi should be abandoned (Lindqvist et al. 2009). The walruses found in the Laptev Sea are in all probability the westernmost part of the Pacific Walrus population.

The IUCN Pinniped Specialist Group has assessed the status of the Atlantic and Pacific Walrus subspecies separately. This assessment combines those two analyses to assess the global status of the Walrus as a species.

There are five commonly recognized subspecies of Harbor Seals: Phoca vitulina richardii, the Eastern Pacific Harbor Seal; P. v. stejnegeri, the Kuril Seal or Western Pacific Harbor Seal; P. v. vitulina, the Eastern Atlantic Harbor Seal; P. v. concolor the Western Atlantic Harbor Seal; and P. v. mellonae, the Ungava Seal or Seal Lake Seal (Rice 1998). Berta and Churchill (2011) recognized only one subspecies in the North Pacific (P. v. richardii) and one in the North Atlantic (P. v. vitulina). The IUCN Pinniped Specialist Group believes that pending additional genetics studies, conservation and management of these taxa are best served by following Rice (1998) and maintaining the five subspecies.

Morphological, reproductive and behavioural differences separate Spotted Seals from their close relatives, the North Pacific Harbour Seals (Phoca vitulina richardii and P. v. stejnegeri) both of whose ranges overlap with the Spotted Seal (Rice 1998). Recent studies of mtDNA confirmed the distinctiveness of the Harbour and Spotted Seals at the species level. The two species have hybridized in captivity, although information on hybrids occurring in the wild is limited to one possible case (O’Corry-Crowe and Westlake 1997). While Shaughnessy and Fay (1977) identified several separate breeding concentrations, the initial, small, genetic samples did not show geographic substructure within the species (O’Corry-Crowe and Westlake 1997). More recent analyses of larger samples indicate possible population structure between the Yellow Sea, the Sea of Okhotsk, and the Bering Sea (Li et al. 2010, O’Corry-Crowe and Bonin 2009, Boveng et al. 2009).

In 2011 the genus of all Fur Seals other than Arctocephalus pusillus was changed from Arctocephalus to Arctophoca, Peters 1866 (Committee on Taxonomy 2011) based on evidence presented in Berta and Churchill (2012). However, in 2013, based on genetic evidence presented in Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds (2012), this change was considered to be premature and these species were returned to the genus Arctocephalus pending further research (Committee on Taxonomy 2013).

This species was formerly referred to Arctocephalus doriferus in Australia (King 1969). Small genetic differences, but no morphological differences, between the Australian and New Zealand populations have been reported (Lento et al. 1994, Rice 1998).

The traditional common name for this species, New Zealand Fur Seal, is problematic because most of the current population lives in Australia, not New Zealand. A new, more appropriately descriptive common name, Long-nosed Fur Seal, has been proposed for the Australian population (Shaughnessy and Goldsworthy 2014).

California Sea Lions were once considered a subspecies of Zalophus californianus (Z. c. californianus) by many authors, but Rice (1998) argued that Z. californianus, Z. japonicus, and Z. wollebaeki are distinct species. Other studies have confirmed the separate species status of Z. japonicus and Z. californianus (Brunner 2004, Sakahira and Niimi 2007) and the separation of Z. californianus and Z. wollebaeki (Wolf et al. 2007).

The species has been considered a subspecies of Z. californianus (Z. c. wollebaeki) by many authors. Rice (1998) argued for the retention of Z. californianus, Z. japonicus, and Z. wollebaeki as distinct species. Recent genetic data support the classification as a separate species that separated from the California Sea Lion (Zalophus californianus) about 2.3 ± 0.5 million years ago (Wolf et al. 2007).

The Ribbon Seal was originally placed in the genus Phoca by Zimmerman (1783), but later it was listed as Histriophoca by Gill (1873) and Scheffer (1958). The taxonomy of northern phocids was reviewed by Burns and Fay (1970) and they returned Ribbon Seals to Phoca based on cranial morphology. More recently, molecular genetics studies (Árnason et al. 1995, Higdon et al. 2007) have shown that Ribbon Seals belong in the separate genus, Histriophoca, and thus Histriophoca fasciata is the currently accepted scientific name (Rice 1998, Committee on Taxonomy 2014).

The scientific name for the Harp Seal has shifted frequently in the past with generic names of Pagophoca, Pagophilis and Phoca, and specific names of groenlandicus and groenlandica. Berta and Churchill (2011) used the name Pagophilis groenlandicus and that is the name recognized by the Society of Marine Mammalogy (Committee on Taxonomy; SMM 2021).
