Rice (1998) recognized two subspecies, P. g. groenlandicus and P. g. oceanicus, the former breeding in the western North Atlantic off North America and also around Jan Mayen in the Greenland Sea, and the latter breeding in the White Sea. There certainly are three distinct subpopulations (Lavigne 2002) centred on the breeding localities, with some associated morphological, genetic and behavioural differences. Heptner et al. (1996) provided evidence for two distinct groups, but included the Jan Mayen breeding group with the White Sea group. Analysis of DNA sequence variation, and also comparisons of fingerprint band-sharing coefficients, revealed that the breeding groups in the Northwest Atlantic (Gulf of St. Lawrence and the Front off Labrador and Newfoundland) were one group and that the animals that breed in the White Sea and those in the Greenland Sea (north of Jan Mayen) were another group (Meisfjord and Sundt 1996, Perry et al. 2000).

Given the uncertainties in the level of genetic differentiation between the breeding populations (i.e., whether subspecies should be recognized) and their actual affinities, they will not be differentiated in this assessment.

The Ringed Seal has been moved back and forth between the genus name Pusa and Phoca in recent decades, largely a result of difficulty in reconciling the molecular and morphological relationships of the Grey Seal, Halichoerus grypus, to those two genera (Rice 1998). The very limited genetic differences between these taxa (Fulton and Strobeck 2010) argue for inclusion of all of them in a single genus, Phoca, (Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds 2012) but widespread reluctance to rename the Grey Seal has led to common, though not universal, use of Pusa as a full genus despite the typical placement of Halichoerus in its midst on recent molecular phylogenetic trees (e.g., Committee on Taxonomy 2014). In contrast to the nomenclature for the genus, use of the species name hispida for the Ringed Seals inhabiting the Arctic Ocean and adjoining seas has been broadly accepted (Rice 1998).

There are currently five recognized subspecies of Ringed Seal (Rice 1998, Committee on Taxonomy 2014), the Arctic Ringed Seal (P. h. hispida), the Okhotsk Ringed Seal (P. h. ochotensis), the Baltic Ringed Seal (P. h. botnica), the Ladoga Seal (P. h. ladogensis), and the Saimaa Seal (P. h. saimensis). Each of the subspecies has been individually assessed by the IUCN Pinniped Specialist Group. This assessments combines those results to determine the status of Ringed Seals at the species level.
Cottunculus konstantinovi is not clearly distinguished from C. microps (Parin et al. 2002).

Previously two subspecies were recognised; Monochirus hispidus with a distribution in the Mediterranean and M. atlanticus with a distribution from Portugal to the Gulf of Guinea. Hoenywell et al. (in review) elevated a subspecies to species status. They considered M. hispidus to be a Mediterranean endemic and M. atlanticus to have a distribution from Portugal to Guinea not including the Mediterranean (Hoenywell et al. in review).
Sphyraena intermedia was only recently described on the basis of 19 specimens collected from the Mediterranean Sea (Pastore 2009).
Ophioblennius steindachneri clippertonensis from Clipperton is now recognised as a distinct species (Hastings and Springer 2009).
Cirripectes heemstraorum is closely related to C. auritus, an Indo-Pacific species ranging from Kenya to South Africa to the Philippines and Line Islands (Williams 2010).
Although several geographic populations have been named as species, morphological and genetic data show there is one world-wide panmictic species (Gibbs and Collette 1967, Scoles and Graves 1993).

Mitochondrial DNA restriction analysis reveals that genetic differentiation occurs between populations inhabiting the Mediterranean Sea and the tropical Atlantic Ocean, indicating that little genetic exchange occurs between the two (Kotoulas et al. 1995).

Recent study of mitochondrial DNA by Viñas et al. (2010) found further differentiation between populations in the eastern and western Mediterranean Sea.

There has been taxonomic confusion and misidentifications between Epinephelus coioides, E. tauvina and E. malabaricus (Heemstra and Randall 1993). Therefore, historical data for E. malabaricus can be uncertain.
Prior to this species' formal description in 1991, it was identified as Epinephelus chlorostigma, particularly in India.

Recent genetic and demographic evidence suggests that the population of Cephalopholis hemistiktos in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden may be a distinct species from the population in the Arabian Gulf and Gulf of Oman (Priest et al. 2016).
The generic name of this species was changed to Hyporthodus by Craig and Hastings (2007), and the family name to Epinephelidae by Smith and Craig (2007).
This species has been confused with Epinephelus stictus in the western Pacific and with E. rivulatus in South Africa (Heemstra and Randall 1993).

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.
This species can be confused with Epinephelus rivulatus, which is superficially similar.

Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Craig and Hastings (2007) included the species Aetheloperca rogaa within the genus Cephalopholis. Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. episticus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

This species is sometimes misidentified as Epinephelus magniscuttis or Mycteroperca heniochus.

Terapon jarbua was originally described as Scieana jarbua by Forsskål (1775) from Djedda, Red Sea. Golani and Appelbaum-Golani (2010) have suggested that the specimens from Red Sea and Mediterranean Sea differ slightly from the specimens collected from far east (Hong Kong and Japan) indicating that further molecular taxonomy research is necessary to clarify the identity of this taxon.

Gerres filamentosus forms part of a species complex and new species have been described (Iwatsuki et al. 2002), and some records of this species may be confused with these (Gerres infasciatus, G. macracanthus and G. microphthalmus).
Some authors have included Skipjack Tuna in the genus Euthynnus, but recent authors agree with its placement in the monotypic genus Katsuwonus (Collette and Graves 2019).
This species previously was included in the genus Makaira (Collette et al. 2006).

There is no genetic evidence in the mtDNA control region to indicate that the Atlantic (Istiophorus albicans) and Indo-Pacific (Istiophorus platypterus) Sailfishes are separate species (Collette et al. 2006). However, there are two distinct mtDNA clades, both evident in the Atlantic while only one is found in the Indo-Pacific (McDowell 2002). There is also no difference in pectoral fin length or in any other morphometric or meristic characters between the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific populations of sailfish (Morrow and Harbo 1969, McDowell 2002).
Hippichthys penicillus was originally described as Syngnathus penicillus by Cantor (1849) from Sea of Pinang (Penang), Malaysia.
There is a disagreement with the generic placement of this species. The species has also been confused with Liza macrolepis and some records may be misidentifcations.

This species, originally described as Atherinomorus lacunosa (Forster in Bloch and Schneider 1801) is often confused or incorrectly synonymized with Atherinomorus forskalii (Rüppell 1838), which is known from the Red Sea and eastern Mediterranean, and Atherinomorus pinguis (Lacepède 1803), which, similarly to A. lacunosus, is widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific, from East Africa to northern Australia and north to southern Japan (Kimura et al. 2007). Atherinomorus lacunosus differs from A. forskalii in lacking conspicuous, large endopterygoid teeth which form noticeable tooth ridges, and from A. pinguis in having a wider midlateral band and more numerous midlateral scales (Kimura et al. 2007).

In the past, there has been confusion from the use of the names D. acuta and D. elopsoides. Records of D. acuta in the eastern Mediterranean may refer instead to D. elopsoides (Whitehead 1985). However, this confusion has since been resolved (H. Hata pers. comm. 2017).
The record for Siganus spinus in Woodland (1984) is a misidentification of S. luridus (Randall 1995).
Caesio varilineata has previously been identified and recorded as Caesio caerulaurea (Carpenter 1988).
This species has been previously referred to in the literature as Formio niger.

Saurida tumbil has been widely misidentified in the literature, and has been misapplied to other species of Saurida. The true Saurida tumbil is probably restricted in range to India, the Arabian Sea, the Persian/Arabian Gulf and the Red Sea (B. Russell pers. comm. 2015).
This species is often misidentified as Herklotsichthys quadrimaculatus in the Arabian Gulf.

Based on Nelson and McCarthy (1995), Carpenter et al. (1997) suggested this species might be a junior synonym of Nematalosa nasus. However, that interpretation may be incorrect considering that Nelson and McCarthy (1995: 382) stated that “N. resticularia seems to be a well marked species, differing from N. persara and N. nasus in meristic characters and in the larger and fewer intestinal diverticula.”
It is difficult to distinguish this species from Nematalosa nasus (Nelson and McCarthy 1995).

Based on a recent taxonomic study of the Antennariidae (Arnold and Pietsch 2012), both Antennarius and Antennatus are valid genera, but Antennarius nummifer is now valid as Antennatus nummifer. Specifically, it is stated that: "Antennatus was recovered nested within the Antennarius nummifer group, requiring reallocation of all members of the later, resulting in a much expanded Antennatus."
There may be several species within this complex (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species was placed in the genus Apogon previous to the subdivision of the genera and elevation of the subgenus Apogonichthyoides (Mabuchi et al. 2014).

Additional DNA studies are needed. Some unpublished molecular studies have reportedly revealed four potential 'fasciatus' species in the seas off China (Kuiter and Kozawa 2019). Subtle colour variation as well as maximum size within and among geographic regions differ from the eastern Australian population, which is the type locality (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
The generic placement of this species is under revision (H.K. Larson pers. comm. 2017).

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families. Their study recognized 11 species of Kyphosus in Kyphosidae, and the monotypic Neoscorpis. Thus, there are 12 species total in the family Kyphosidae. 

Kyphosus lutescens and K. pacificus are now treated as synonyms of K. sectatrix (Knudsen and Clements 2013). Both K. incisor and K. analogus are now considered synonyms of K. vaigiensis (Knudsen and Clements 2013). Kyphosus sandwicensis is a junior synonym of K. elegans (Knudsen and Clements 2013). 

Before Knudsen and Clements (2013) it was thought that only two Kyphosids occurred in the Atlantic, but there may in fact be four species, K. sectatrix, K. vaigiensis, K. bigibbus, and K. cinerascens. However, Sakai and Nakbo (2014) have presented an alternative view on the kyphosids occurring in the Atlantic.
More taxonomic research is needed to clarify the status of the paratype specimen from off Madras, India (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species is easily confused, and very similar to Parupeneus heptacanthus, and has been synonymised in the past. Taxonomic work is needed (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).

This species was previously misidentified as Upeneus sulphureus in the Arabian/Persian Gulf (Carpenter et al. 1997b, Ali et al. 2018). These two species have overlapping distributions, but rarely co-occur (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
Nemipterus bipunctatus has been previously recorded as N. bleekeri, a junior synonym, in some reports from the Persian Gulf (B. Russell pers. comm. 2013)

There may be nomenclature implications for the Indian Ocean population of Nemipterus japonicus due to a 2.7% genetic difference between the western Pacific and Indian Ocean populations, but further investigation is needed (Ping et al. 2015). According to Hung et al. (2017), Nemipterus japonicus contains two distinct cryptic species, and further taxonomic work is needed.

Nemipterus randalli was not described until 1986 and it may previously have been confused with N. japonicus (B. Russell pers. comm. 2013). This species was identified as N. mesoprion in India prior to its description, but it continues to be misidentified as N. mesoprion by some workers to the present (B. Russell pers. comm. 2018).
Kuronuma and Abe (1986) mistakenly recorded Scolopsis bimaculata as S. phaeops [=S. frenata].
Scolopsis vosmeri is a complex of two or three species (two forms of S. vosmeri and S. torquata), and the taxonomic status of this complex requires further study (B. Russell pers. comm. 2018).
This species has been confused with Pseudochromis dutoiti in east Africa, and it is possible that it constitutes two species given future taxonomic work (Gill 2003).
Pseudochromis caudalis forms a species-complex (Gill and Zajonz 2011).
Arnoglossus tapeinosoma is easily misidentified and there is much taxonomic uncertainty surrounding the genus (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2014).
There is much taxonomic uncertainty surrounding this species (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2014).

The taxonomic status of the nominal species Cynoglossus arel and C. macrolepidotus remains uncertain. Menon (1977) and Munroe (2001) consider C. macrolepidotus to be a junior synonym of C. arel; however, other authors (e.g., Li and Wang 1996, Mishra et al. 1999) consider both to be valid species. Cynoglossus macrolepidotus was recently included in the comparative material for the description of C. crepida (Fricke et al. 2017) and it is currently listed as valid in Eschmeyer's Catalog of Fishes (Fricke et al. 2020). Research is needed to clarify the taxonomic status of these two nominal species.
The taxonomic status of Cynoglossus kopsii requires further study as there are several nominal species currently referred to under the name Cynoglossus kopsii (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2019).

Cantor (1849) considered Brachirus Swainson 1839 to be preoccupied by Brachyrus Swainson 1838 and proposed the replacement name Synaptura. Subsequently, Brachirus Swainson was determined to be a valid genus name (Jordan 1923). Bleeker (1875) distinguished Brachirus Swainson from Synaptura, but did not designate a type species. Later, Chabanaud (1928) restricted the name Synaptura to accommodate four nominal species of elongate soles, Synaptura albomaculata Kaup 1858, Pleuronectes commersonnii Lacepede 1802, S. lusitanica Brito Capello 1868, and S. marginata Boulenger 1900. 


Desoutter et al. (2001) commented that Synaptura sensu Chabanaud was not a valid genus name. In a revision of members of the genus Synaptura sensu Chabanaud, Vachon et al. (2007) also stated that Synaptura sensu Chabanaud was not valid. Based on the results of their study, the five nominal species (including Synaptura cadenati Chabanaud 1948) formally placed in Synaptura sensu Chabanaud were found to be closely related to Dagetichthys lakdoensis Stauch and Blanc 1964 and they transferred these species to Dagetichthys. This generic assignment is recognized herein.
Historically synonymised with M. longimanus, however clearly defined as two distinct species in the 1980s (Amaoka and Kanayama 1981).

Acentronura tentaculata subsumes A. breviperula. Dawson (1985) examined the specimens and concluded that there were no substantial differences, and thus synonymized the two under A. tentaculata. Western Pacific specimens were originally attributed to A. breviperula. Subsequent authors (e.g., Fricke 2004; Kuiter 2009; Fricke et al. 2011, 2014; Allen and Erdmann 2012) have all resurrected Acentronura breviperula in species checklists or picture guides with no justification.
There has been some confusion surrounding the correct name for this species. It is now placed as Paramonacanthus oblongus, separate from P. japonicus, by Gill and Hutchins (2002).
Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name of this species from Epinephelus to Hyporthodus. The family name was changed to Epinephelidae by Smith and Craig (2007).
Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name from Epinephelus to Hyporthodus and Smith and Craig (2007) changed the family name to Epinephelidae.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.
This species is often confused with juvenile Thunnus obesus, which also has very long pectorals, but with rounded tips.
The genus Thunnus is divisible into two subgenera, Thunnus and Neothunnus, but the Bigeye Tuna does not neatly fit in either subgenus (Collette and Graves 2019).
This is now considered to be a separate species from the Pacific bluefin, Thunnus orientalis (Collette 1999).
Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus, and Smith and Craig (2007) changed the family name to Epinephelidae.

The Eastern Pacific population may be a distinct species, and further future taxonomic work is planned (M. Craig pers. comm. 2018). Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus and Smith and Craig (2007) changed the family name to Epinephelidae.
This species can be misidentified in Brazil as Mycteroperca rubra.
This species is frequently confused with Coryphopterus personatus; C. hyalinus and C. personatus are genetically distinct (Baldwin et al. 2009).

Blue Marlin (Makaira nigricans) of the Indo-Pacific and the Atlantic are conspecific (Buonaccorsi et al. 1999, 2001; Collette et al. 2006). The Indo-Pacific Blue Marlin previously was known as Makaira mazara (Jordan & Snyder, 1901).

Previously, this species was known as Tetrapturus albidus (Collette et al. 2006). There is a question as to whether this species is distinct from the Pacific Striped Marlin, Kajikia audax (Graves 1998, Collette et al. 2006, Hanner et al. 2011).
This species was recently described and all evidence indicates that it is endemic to the Pelican Keys in Belize (Randall and Lobel 2003).

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

This species was originally described as Syngnathus dendriticum by Thomas Barbour in 1905. The genus Amphelikturus was subsequently described by Parr (1930), with this species subsumed within it. Dawson (1984) later subsumed Amphelikturus and Idiotropiscis as subgenera of Acentronura based on morphology.
This species should not to be confused with Briggs’ Crested Pipefish (Histiogamphelus briggsii), which is found in southern Australia.
This species was recently resurrected from synonymy under S. foetens (Frable et al. 2013).

This species was previously considered a synonym of E. plumieri by Deckert (1973), Deckert and Geenfield (1987), and González-Acosta (2005), because the original description was based on juveniles of this species.  Eugerres awlae has been re-described and considered a valid gerreid species from the western Atlantic by González-Acosta et al. (2007). It was recently reviewed in 2014 with conclusion that this species is valid (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).

Both the specific and generic status of this species is under review and likely to change (K. Carpenter pers. comm. 2009).

The phylogeny of sparids, and the taxonomy of snapper in particular, has attracted considerable attention. In Australasia, snapper had previously been assigned to the genus Chrysophrys, formerly as Chrysophrys unicolor and more latterly as C. auratus (Paulin 1990). Paulin (1990) determined Pagrus to be the senior synonym of Chrysophrys, and re-described C. auratus as Pagrus auratus. In addition, he concluded that the species known as red sea bream in Japan, i.e. Pagrus major, was a conspecific and should also be re-described as P. auratus. Researchers in Japan, however, have not adopted this taxonomy (Jackson 2007).

Tweddle and Willoughby (1982) synonymised the Lake Malawi species M. nyasensis (Worthington, 1933) with M. livingstonii from the Rovuma River. This was based on the overlap of key characters, with the two key character differences used by Worthington (1933) shown to be invalid.Two specimens were collected by Tweddle and Willoughby (1982) from Lake Chilwa streams, i.e. the headwaters of the Rovuma River. These authors did, however, caution that only the small holotype of M. livingstonii was available from the type locality for examination and that "Further collecting from the Ruvuma system is needed for confirmation". The synonomy of the Malawi and Rovuma species therefore needs to be verified using modern methods of electrical organ discharge and genetics.
This species is also reported as Lophotus lacepedei (Quignard and Tomasini 2000).

This species is commonly confused with Laemonema barbatulum, particularly when small. This introduces uncertainty in assessing the distribution and habitat utilization of L. goodebeanorum (S. Ross pers. comm. 2018).
This species is of hybrid origin (Echelle and Mosier 1982, McEachran and Fechhelm 1998).

Some workers consider the correct genus of this species to be Tigrigobius. The genus Tigrigobius is currently defined as not monophyletic and will at some point be divided into two or more genera (J. Van Tassell pers. comm. 2015).

Elacatinus panamensis is distinguished by marginal meristic counts that are very similar to E. rubrigenis and E. multifasciatus (Victor 2010). Some workers consider the correct genus of this species to be Tigrigobius. The genus Tigrigobius is currently defined as not monophyletic and will at some point be divided into two or more genera (J. Van Tassell pers. comm. 2015).
Previously considered conspecific with Hyporhamphus unifasciatus.
Further taxonomic work is needed on western Atlantic members of this family.

Neobythites ocellatus was recently split into two species based on differences in color patterns, which resulted in the naming of a new species (Neobythites multiocellatus) and restricted the distribution of N. ocellatus to Brazil between 233-641m depth (Nielsen et al. 2009).

Species in the genus Urophycis are difficult to identify, and therefore, determining the limits of individual species' distributions can be problematic. For example, Lemes et al. (2016) questions the presence of this species in the South Atlantic (Brazil, Uruguay and Argentina).

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

This species is possibly a synonym of Hypoplectrus aberrans (Heemstra et al. 2002). There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them. Due to its rarity, and the similarity of its color pattern to that of the common species H. aberrans (the only difference is that H. aberrans lacks a strong tail-base blotch), H. maculiferus may be a color variant of the latter (Robertson and Van Tassell 2015).

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

A recent taxonomic revision of Hippocmpus suggests that H. planifrons Peters 1877 and H. biocellatus refer to the same species. H. planifrons takes precedence, subsuming H. biocellatus as a junior synonym (Lourie et al. 2016)

Some confusion exists around the taxonomic status of this species and that of Hippocampus pontohi. For the purposes of this assessment Hippocampus pontohi is currently recognized as being endemic to Lord Howe Island.

Hippocampus pontohi was described from and originally thought to be restricted to Central Indonesia and West Papua. There are now records of the species from more widespread locations, including the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, and Fiji. At times there have been specimens from PNG identified as H. colemani. Given the morphological overlap between specimens of the two, further morphological and molecular work needs to be done to ensure that these are in fact distinct species. Hippocampus colemani would take precedent if the two were deemed the same, as it was described earlier.
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus kalisherae to the genus Gobioclinus.
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus filamentosus to the genus Gobioclinus.
Formerly this species was considered a subspecies of Malacoctenus hubbsi (Hastings and Springer 2009).
The three species Andamia heteroptera, A. reyi and A. tetradactylus are currently confused taxonomically (J. Williams pers comm).
Previously this species was recognized as a subspecies of Omobranchus rotundiceps.
This species has three colour forms: frontalis and albicaudatus forms, occur throughout the species' range, but nigrovittatus form is unknown from the Red Sea and Gulf of Aqaba.

Until recently this species included Aspidontus tractus. The validity of A. tractus is questioned by Smith-Vaniz (1976) based on the fact that it is a mimic of Labriodes dimidiatus (Smith-Vaniz pers comm. 2009).
Parablennius tasmanianus postoculomaculatus was recently been elevated to a full species (Bath 2008).
Previously this species was considered a subspecies of Dactyloscopus byersi (Hastings and Springer 2009).
This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Malacoctenus margaritae (Hastings and Springer 2009).
Until recently, this species was recognized only as an allopatric subspecies of Plagiotremus laudandus (Hastings and Springer 2009).
This species was previously considered a subspecies of Stathmonotus stahli (Hastings and Springer 2009).

Medusablennius chani was first described in 1966 by V.G. Springer. This species has been assigned to the family Blenniidae but further research is needed to resolve the variability within the blennioid families.
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus bucciferus to the genus Gobioclinus.
This species is considered valid (Patzner et al. 2009). Previously it was considered a synonym of Antennablennius bifilum (Springer and Spreitzer 1978).
Parablennius tasmanianus caledoniensis is a junior synonym of P. intermedius (Bath 2008).

Scartella cristata is generally recognized to be a species complex. Currently it is under taxonomic review. The eastern Atlantic and Brazillian populations may represent separate species (Williams pers. comm. 2009).
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus gobio to the genus Gobioclinus.
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus guppyi to the genus Gobioclinus.
There are only two species in the genus Omox but they are easily distinguished (Springer 1981).
Formerly this species was considered a subspecies of Dactyloscopus pectoralis (Hastings and Springer 2009).
Previously, this species was considered a subspecies of Entomacrodus thalassinus, but is now recognized as a valid species (Hastings and Springer 2009).
Specimens recorded from Oman were tentatively identified and there is a possibility these could represent a different species.
Previously, this species was considered a subspecies of Entomacrodus stellifer, but is now recognized as a valid species (Hastings and Springer 2009).
A report of Meiacanthus lineatus from Sulu Archipelago (Smith-Vaniz 1976) was subsequently shown to be based on a misidentification of M. abditus (Smith-Vaniz 1987).
This species used to be considered as a subspecies of Alticus kirkii; it is now known as a distinct species (J.T. Williams pers comm. 2009).
This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Dactyloscopus pectoralis (Hastings and Springer 2009).
This species was previously considered a synonym of Antennablennius variopunctatus.

Baldwin et al. 2011 revealed that most broadly distributed species of Starksia are comprised of a complex of species with discrete distributions. Assignment to a specific species requires barcode data for specimens outside the type locality. Since no barcode data are available for the Gulf of Mexico, all that can be concluded is that the population is a member of the S. nanodes species complex (B. Smith-Vaniz and R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).
Lupinoblennius dispar has recently been recognised as a junior synonym of L. vinctus (Bath 1996).
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus albigenys to the genus Brockius.

Labrisomus nuchipinnis is likely a species complex and there is only one species in the Gulf of Mexico (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). The holotype of L. nuchipinnis is from Brazil, so the name will change.
Blennius maoricus is now a junior synonym of Parablennius tasmanianus (Bath 2008).
Previously this species was recognized as a subspecies of Meiacanthus atrodorsalis (Smith-Vaniz 1976); it is now recognized as a separate species (Smith-Vaniz 1987).

Malacoctenus triangulatus is a species complex. There is at least one species in the Gulf. Further work is needed to determine how many species and where they are found, however, we assessed M. triangulatus as one species that is endemic to the Western Central Atlantic.

Acanthemblemaria spinosa is commonly misidentified as A. maria in photo guides (Humann and DeLoach 2002, Wilk 2003), and on the internet. The "Punk Blenny" (Wilk 2003) is actually A. maria. (R. Eytan pers. comm). This may also be a species complex.

Until recently this species included Aspidontus tractus. The validity of A. tractus is questioned by Smith-Vaniz (1976) based on the fact that it is a mimic of Labriodes dimidiatus (Smith-Vaniz pers comm. 2009).
The three species Andamia heteroptera, A. reyi and A. tetradactylus are currently confused taxonomically (J. Williams pers comm).
The three species Andamia heteroptera, A. reyi and A. tetradactylus are currently confused taxonomically (J. Williams pers comm).
Previously this species was considered a subspecies of Atrosalarias fuscus (Hastings and Springer 2009).
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus nigricinctus to the genus Brockius.
This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Malacoctenus zonifer (Hastings and Springer 2009).
Many pictures identified as Acanthemblemaria maria in guidebooks and on the internet are actually A. spinosa (R. Eytan pers. comm).
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus haitiensis to the genus Gobioclinus.

Western Atlantic records of Tetrapturus belone through the early 1960s are of T. pfluegeri (Robins and de Sylva 1963). Tetrapturus belone is very close to T. pfluegeri (Collette et al. 2006, Hanner et al. 2011).

Previously thought to be endemic to the Mediterranean Sea, an International Game Fish Association record from Madeira (June 1980), outside the Mediterranean has been identified, based on a photograph, Tetrapturus belone; identification is uncertain, however expert opinion (B. Collette, J. Graves, J. Schratwieser pers. comm. 2013) is that the record is likely to refer to Tetrapturus belone.
There is a possibility that this species is a complex, similar to the Dipturus batis-complex (Iglésias et al. 2010), but further taxonomic work is required.
Originally described in the genus Breviraja.

In some areas of the Mediterranean Sea (particularly along the Italian coasts) this species is probably misidentified with Raja montagui. Further investigation is required into this and morphometric and genetic studies are still in progress (Mancusi et al. 2005).
This species is most closely related to Hydrolagus affinis (Moura et al. 2005).

The genus Apristurus contains at least 32 described species and a relatively large number of potentially undescribed ones. Morphological conservatism and, until recently, a lack of objectively defined characters makes this one of the most taxonomically confused shark genera (Compagno 1984, Nakaya and Sato 1999).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species-groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species), and spongiceps-group (10 species). A. aphyodes belongs to the spongiceps-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% total length(TL)); 7 to 12 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows subequal to, or shorter than the lower furrows; a continuous supraorbital sensory canal.

Dipturus nidarosiensis may be a composite species with a small and large morphotype similar to that seen in Dipturus batis-complex (Iglesias et al. 2010) and Dipturus oxyrinchus-complex. Further genetic research is needed before a taxonomic revision is made, but Dipturus nidarosiensis refers to the larger morphotype and for now the smaller morphotype is referred to as Dipturus sp., as described in the Food and Agricultural Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) catalogue by Ebert and Stehmann (2013).
Formerly called Raja circularis. Early papers often confused Leucoraja circularis and Leucoraja naevus.

Raja maderensis, or a very similar species, is found in the Azores. The taxonomy and relationship of skates on these islands should be assessed. This species is now thought to be distinct from similar specimens from the Canary Islands and West Africa (Ebert and Stehmann 2013).

This species may have been confused with one other, and possibly two other species, causing uncertainty in some of the literature. Pristiurus jenseni Saemundsson, 1922, is considered a junior synonym of this species. Recent analyses indicate that life-history data collected from specimens of Galeus murinus are incompatible with Saemundsson’s (1922) description of Pristiurus jenseni and data on Galeus murinus, provided in Magnússon’s (2000) fishery survey. Consequently, two possibilities require investigation: (1) The synonym P. jenseni is a valid species from Iceland, larger than G. murinus, and commonly confused with it and/or (2) G. murinus is in part confused in Magnússon et al. (2000) with a larger species of Apristurus present in Iceland. Molecular phylogenetic analysis of G. murinus was conducted by Iglésias et al. (2005) and Pristiurus jenseni requires critical taxonomic examination.
This species was previously referred to as Raja naevus. Early papers often confused Cuckoo Ray with Sandy Ray (Lecoraja (Raja) circularis).
The subgenus Leucoraja was elevated to genus rank by McEachran and Dunn (1998).

Some authors (Ben-Tuvia 1990, Tinti and Piccinetti 2000) claim that S. aegyptica is a synonym of S. solea. Some other authors consider S. aegyptica a valid species (Desoutter 1997, Borsa and Quignard 2001, Vachon et al. 2008). It is currently accepted as a valid species (Eschmeyer 2014).

It is often confused with the sympatric Solea vulgaris (Quensel, 1806), a junior synonym of Solea solea (Linnaeus, 1758).
Although there have been concerns as to the taxonomic status of Eretmophorus kleinenbergi (Cohen 1986), it is currently considered a valid species (Eschmeyer 2014).

This species appears to have been newly described by Matallanas (1985) based on few specimens, although there are doubts about its validity (C. Papaconstantinou pers. comm. 2007). The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be 1-2 hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014). Further, the importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through checklists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).
Pomatoschistus tortonesei was redescribed and separated from P. bathi (Miller 1982).

Miller (1971) described two subspecies of Chromogobius zebratus, Chromogobius zebratus zebratus (Kolombatović, 1891) and Chromogobius zebratus levanticus Miller, 1971. Ahnelt and Patzner (1996) showed that there is no real morphological differences in supposed subspecies populations of C. zebratus, and that separation into two subspecies is not justified.
The two juvenile specimens that are known for this species in the Mediterranean Sea, off Banyuls, France, may be juveniles of Buenia jeffreysii (Kovacic and La Mesa 2010).
It was inventoried under the name Oligopus ater in Risso (1810), and was recorded in Algeria under the name Grammonus armatus Dodelein (Dieuziede and Roland 1958).
Lipophrys basiliscus (Valenciennes, 1836) is a commonly used synonym in the literature.

All freshwater taxa of Proteorhinus were previously included under the name P. marmoratus, but morphological and molecular data show that the real P. marmorata does not enter pure freshwaters (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007).

As a result, in 2007 the freshwater taxa P. nasalis, P. semilunaris and P. tataricus were split from P. marmoratus and raised to species level. Nielson and Stepien (2009) identified a further freshwater species of the genus, which may be P. semipellucidus,  from the Caspian.Therefore any data on P. marmoratus may include data on these four taxa. Further work is required to clarify the taxonimic status of the Caspian Sea Proterorhinus.
Tripterygion tripteronotum was split into two distinct species, T. tripteronotum and T. tartessicum, based on genetic and morphological characteristics (Carreras-Carbonell et al. 2007).

There is a lot of taxonomic uncertainty for the correct name to be used for this species. There is a type locality but no type specimens which has created confusion in the identification of this species. We follow Eschmeyer's conclusion that N. coibor is a good species and concur that it is a valid name (K. Carpenter and N. L. Chao pers comm 2018).

Atrobucca marleyi was described on the basis of a single specimen collected from South Africa. It has been treated previously as a synonym of A. nibe and as a valid species. More research is needed to verify the validity of this species. See also the Red List assessment of A. nibe for further taxonomic explanation.
Records of this species along the western coast of the Malaysian peninsula refer to Pennahia ovata (Sasaki 1996, 2001).
The validity of the genus Protonibea is uncertain (L. Chao pers. comm. 2019) and therefore the generic-level placement of this species remains in doubt.
<span>
Johnius vogleri (Bleeker 1853) is a junior synonym of  this species.
This species was previously known as Johnius dussumieri in the Western Indian Ocean (Sasaki 1997).
Macrodon atricauda was revalidated by Carvalho-Filho et al. (2010). Macrodon ancylodon (Bloch & Schneider 1801) was used prior to 2010.

Records of this species from western Indian Ocean may represent a new, undescribed species based on genetic (Zemlek et al. 2009) and morphological data (Sasaki 2001). There is evidence of northern and southern subpopulations in the western Indian Ocean (Kiper 2014).

Umbrina canariensis and U. ronchus were once recognised as separate species but taxonomic and genetic work (Hutchings and Griffiths 2005) have shown that these are one species with the correct name being U. robinsoni. The name Umbrina canariensis belongs to a separate, deep-water species.
Identification of species of Nibea is difficult, and records of this species outside of the Fujian Provence need to be verified (K. Sasaki pers. comm. 2016).

The populations of this species in Australia and South Africa may represent two different species (Farmer 2008, Barnes et al. 2015). Argyrosomus amoyensis is most likely a junior synonym of A. japonicus (Taniguchi and Okada 2984, K. Sasaki pers. comm. 2016).

Smith and Heemstra (1986) placed Atrobucca marleyi in the synonymy of A. nibe, but Sasaki and Kailola (1988) regard the former as a separate species. There appear to be two genetic lineages of A. nibe in Taiwan (Lo et al. 2017; Wei-Jen Chen, National Taiwan University, pers. comm.); and South African A. nibe samples group together genetically, but appear to be a separate lineage from the Taiwanese Atrobucca spp (Wei-Jen Chen, National Taiwan University, pers. comm.). Thus either A. nibe represents a species complex and A. nibe in South Africa is a new species, or the South African specimens are another Atrobucca species - probably A. marleyi (Norman, 1922; Wei-Jen Chen, National Taiwan University, pers. comm.) Sasaki and Kailola 1988 were hesitant to designate Indian Bay of Bengal Atrobucca as A. nibe until more material was examined, as there were different gill raker and dorsal ray counts to East China Sea specimens.
In the Western Indian Ocean, previously referred to as Johnius amblycephalus, which only occurs east of Pakistan (Sasaki 1997); see also Lo et al. (2017)
This species may represent a new genus but further examination is needed (Lo et al. 2017).
Lutjanus indicus, previously recorded in the Indian Ocean as L. russellii, has recently been described as a new species (Allen et al. 2013).

Acanthopagrus latus was recently split in to five cryptic species: A. latus (distributed in east Asia), A. longispinnis (Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes 1830) (northern Gulf of Bengal Bay), and three new species, A. morrisoni, A. arabicus, and A. sheim. The five species can be distinguished from one another by the counts of dorsal-fin rays, pore lateral-line scales, scale rows between the fifth dorsal-fin spine base and lateral line, and other distinguishing morphological characteristics and body and fin coloration (Iwatsuki 2013).

Acanthopagrus latus was recently split in to five cryptic species: A. latus (distributed in east Asia), A. longispinnis (Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes 1830) (northern Gulf of Bengal Bay), and three new species, A. morrisoni, A. arabicus, and A. sheim. The five species can be distinguished from one another by the counts of dorsal-fin rays, pore lateral-line scales, scale rows between the fifth dorsal-fin spine base and lateral line, and other distinguishing morphological characteristics and body and fin coloration (Iwatsuki 2013).

Acanthopagrus latus was recently split in to five cryptic species: A. latus (distributed in east Asia), Acanthopagrus longispinnis (Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes 1830) (northern Gulf of Bengal Bay), and three new species, Acanthopagrus morrisoni, Acanthopagrus arabicus, and Acanthopagrus sheim. The five species can be distinguished from one another by the counts of dorsal-fin rays, pore lateral-line scales, scale rows between the fifth dorsal-fin spine base and lateral line, and other distinguishing morphological characteristics and body and fin coloration (Iwatsuki 2013).

According to Iwatsuki and Maclaine (2013) and Bogorodsky et al. (2017), Crenidens crenidens and C. indicus are two distinct species. Crenidens crenidens occurs from the Red Sea, East Africa along the east coast of Africa to Aliwal Shoal in South Africa. Juvenile C. crenidens have been found in Algoa Bay, South Africa (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). Crenidens indicus occurs from the southern Arabian Peninsula (occasionally in the Red Sea) to the coasts of Iran and Pakistan, including the Gulf. Bauchot and Smith (1984) reported C. indicus from India; however, C. indicus either does not occur around India or is extremely rare in the area (Iwatsuki and Maclaine 2013).
Acanthopagrus catenula was previously thought to be a southern population of A. bifasciatus but was recently validated as a separate species (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2011).

Trisopterus capelanus was previously considered the Mediterranean sub-species of T. minutus (T. m. capelanus) and has since been elevated to the status of a fully valid species (Mattiangeli et al. 2000, Delling et al. 2011, Gonzalez et al. 2012).

Despite the occurrence of separate sub-populations of Plaice within the continental shelf populations, no significant differentiation was found using microsatellites (Hoarau et al. 2002, Was et al. 2010, Watts et al. 2010). Only mitochondrial DNA, which has a higher resolution, revealed that the North Sea-Irish Sea samples were weakly distinguishable from Norway, the Baltic and the Bay of Biscay samples (Hoarau et al. 2004). Clear genetic differentiation was found between the populations of Iceland, the Faroes, and the continental shelf of western Europe, that are separated by deep ocean channels (Hoarau et al. 2002, Was et al. 2010).
Acanthopagrus pacificus is recently described and was previously known as and confused with A. berda in the western Pacific (Iwatsuki et al. 2010), including northern Australia.
The taxonomy of the Bowhead Whale is not in doubt. There are four identified subpopulations two of which (Okhotsk Sea and East Greenland-Svalbard-Barents Sea) have separate IUCN Red List assessments.

Until the 1990s, only one species of Minke Whale was recognized, the Antarctic Minke Whale, Balaenoptera bonaerensis, being regarded as conspecific with the Common Minke Whale, B. acutorostrata. Most of the scientific literature prior to the late 1990s uses the name B. acutorostrata for all Minke Whales including Antarctic Minke Whales. Since 2000, the International Whaling Commission (IWC) Scientific Committee has recognized Antarctic Minke Whales as the separate species B. bonaerensis, and provisionally assigns all Northern Hemisphere Minke Whales and all Southern Hemisphere "Dwarf" Minke Whales to B. acutorostrata (IWC 2001). This practice has been followed by management and treaty bodies, such as the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).

The Dwarf Minke Whale is the common name used for B. acutorostrata in the Southern Hemisphere. It was initially described by Best (1985) and Arnold et al. (1987) in terms of its differences from the Antarctic Minke Whale. Subsequent genetic analyses (Wada et al. 1991, Pastene et al. 1994) revealed that the Dwarf Minke Whale is conspecific with the "ordinary" Minke Whale of the Northern Hemisphere, which was given the name Common Minke Whale, while the Antarctic Minke Whale is the separate species B. bonaerensis (see separate Red List assessment).

Following Rice (1998) the Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy provisionally recognizes three subspecies: B. a. acutorostrata (Lacépède, 1804) in the North Atlantic, B. a. scammoni (Deméré, 1986) (= B. a . davidsoni) in the North Pacific, and the Dwarf Minke Whale as an unnamed subspecies in the Southern Hemisphere (Committee on Taxonomy 2017). However, the limited sampling of Dwarf Minke Whales to date does not support the grouping together of all Southern Hemisphere Dwarf Minke Whales. For example, Pastene et al. (2010) found Dwarf Minke Whales from Brazil and Chile to be more closely related to Common Minke Whales in the North Atlantic than to Dwarf Minke Whales in the South Pacific.

Rice’s Whale (Balaenoptera ricei) is a distinct evolutionary lineage closely related to Eden’s Whale (Balaenoptera edeni edeni), Bryde’s Whale (B. e. brydei) and Sei Whale (Balaenoptera borealis) (Rosel et al. 2021). Previously considered an undescribed subspecies of Balaenoptera edeni and referred to as the Gulf of Mexico Whale or the Gulf of Mexico Bryde’s Whale, a recent morphological study of Rice’s Whale has revealed diagnostic differences in the shape and size of bones in the skull in comparison to the two subspecies of B. edeni. This morphological evidence reinforced earlier findings of significant genetic divergence and fixed DNA differences found in several mitochondrial DNA genes; together these data supported the description of the new species B. ricei . With elevation of Rice’s Whale to species status, there is still uncertainty as to whether Eden’s Whale and Bryde’s Whale, each of which is clearly distinct, represent subspecies of B. edeni or full species.

The Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy provisionally recognizes three subspecies: the Northern Fin Whale, Balaenoptera physalus physalus, (Linnaeus, 1758); the Southern Fin Whale, B. p. quoyi (Fischer, 1829), which is larger than B. p. physalus, and the Pygmy Fin Whale, B. p. patachonica (Burmeister, 1865), proposed by Clark (2004), which is smaller than B. p. quoyi and has dark baleen (Committee on Taxonomy 2018). However, Archer et al. (2013) proposed on genetic grounds that Fin Whales in the North Atlantic and North Pacific should be considered separate subspecies. There are few records of B. p. patachonica and the type specimen is currently (May 2018) awaiting genetic analysis. In older accounts, the common name Fin Whale, and its equivalent in other languages, tended to be used for any whales of the genus Balaenoptera.

Until the 1990s, only one species of Minke Whale was recognized, the Antarctic Minke Whale Balaenoptera bonaerensis being regarded as conspecific with the Common Minke Whale (B. acutorostrata). Most of the scientific literature prior to the late 1990s uses the name B. acutorostrata for all Minke Whales including Antarctic Minke Whales. Since 2000, the International Whaling Commission (IWC) Scientific Committee has recognized Antarctic Minke Whales as the separate species B. bonaerensis, while all Northern Hemisphere Minke Whales and all Southern Hemisphere "dwarf" Minke Whales are regarded as B. acutorostrata (IWC 2001). This has been followed by management and treaty bodies, such as Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). This is based on genetic and morphological evidence that the two Minke Whale species, which are partially sympatric in the Southern Hemisphere, are distinct species (Rice 1998, Wada et al. 1991, Pastene et al. 1994, Pastene et al. 2007).

There has been some suggestion that Baird’s and Arnoux’s Beaked Whales are the same species, but analyses of mitochondrial and nuclear intron sequence data revealed multiple fixed genetic differences, confirming that the species are reproductively isolated and valid taxonomic entities (Dalebout 2002).  The recently described Berardius minimus  (Yamada et al. 2019) differs from all of its congeners by having the following unique characters: much smaller body size of physically mature individuals, proportionately shorter beak, and darker body color. Also, within 431 base pairs of the mtDNA control region, B. minimus can be differentiated from B. bairdii and B. arnuxii by 16 and 22 diagnostic sites, respectively. The range of B. minimus lies within the northern part of the distribution of B. bairdii such that earlier assessments would have included both species, especially in northern Hokkaido and the eastern Aleutian Islands (Yamada et al. 2019).

Despite its common name, the Pygmy Right Whale (Caperea marginata) is not closely related to Right Whales (Eubalaena spp.). Currently assigned to its own family, the Neobalaenidae, it may be the last surviving member of the formerly diverse Cetotheriidae (Marx and Fordyce 2016).

No subspecies have been described for Cephalorhynchus heavisidii (Skinner and Chimimba 2005). Recent genetic research using mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) control region and thirteen microsatellite loci to determine population genetic structure and gene flow revealed contrasting patterns of geographical variation among seven sampling sites (N = 395 specimens) across South Africa and Namibia (Gopal 2014). Mitochondrial DNA suggested fine-scale division, with six populations identified, whilst microsatellite markers indicated two widespread populations. These results are in contrast to earlier genetic work that found no evidence of population structure between South Africa and Namibia (van Vuuren et al. 2002), due to poor sampling. Gopal’s (2014) results highlight the importance of evaluating multiple markers to have a comprehensive understanding of population structure in order to implement the correct conservation measures and for continual monitoring to take place to ensure the survivorship of this species.

The Beluga Whale (Delphinapterus leucas) and the Narwhal (Monodon monoceros) are the only two species in the cetacean family Monodontidae (Rice 1998). While these are well defined taxa, Heide-Jørgensen and Reeves (1993) described a skull from West Greenland of what apparently was a Narwhal-Beluga hybrid. Some early Russian researchers split Belugas into three species or subspecies, but that approach was rejected by Kleinenberg et al. (1964) and Rice (1998).

While Belugas occur broadly in Arctic and Subarctic waters, their distribution, movements, and life history characteristics suggest the existence of numerous subpopulations or management stocks using a diverse range of habitats (e.g., Frost and Lowry 1990, Heide-Jørgensen and Wiig 2002). Studies using genetic markers have confirmed the existence of at least 21 subpopulations that are largely demographically isolated (O’Corry-Crowe et al. 1997, 2010, Brown-Gladden et al. 1999, de March et al. 2002, Laidre et al. 2015). The pattern of subpopulation isolation in the Pacific likely results from relatively rapid dispersal into new habitats following recession of the last Pleistocene ice sheets (O’Corry-Crowe et al. 1997). Land masses and heavy sea ice cover limit interchange between subpopulations across the Arctic, as does strong site fidelity, but climate oscillations in the Holocene may have provided relatively recent opportunities for subpopulations to mix (O’Corry-Crowe et al. 2010).

The Southern Right Whale has for some time been widely accepted as a species separate from its Northern Hemisphere relatives, although Rice (1998) regarded the Right Whales in all oceans as a single species and placed them in the genus Balaena along with B. mysticetus, the Bowhead Whale. Genetic analyses support the concept of three separate phylogenetic species of Right Whale, one in the North Atlantic, one in the North Pacific, and one in the Southern Hemisphere (Rosenbaum et al. 2000). The International Whaling Commission (IWC 2004) and the Society for Marine Mammalogy's Taxonomy Committee (Committee on Taxonomy 2017) accept the latter taxonomy. The ranges of the three Right Whale species do not overlap.
Pygmy Killer Whales (Feresa attenuata) are easily confused with Melon-Headed Whales (Peponocephala electra) in the field because of their similar external morphology (Jefferson et al. 2015).

Two forms of Short-finned Pilot Whales (Globicephala macrorhynchus) are found off northern and southern Japan, differing in external and cranial morphology (Kasuya et al. 1988, Van Cise et al. 2016). Although it has been suggested that these might represent two distinct sub-species (Oremus et al. 2009), evidence has not been marshalled to make this distinction official and no subspecies of Short-finned Pilot Whale are currently recognized (Van Cise et al. 2016, Committee on Taxonomy 2017).

Three subspecies of the Long-finned Pilot Whale are currently recognized: Globicephala melas melas in the North Atlantic, G. m. edwardii in the Southern Hemisphere, and an un-named subspecies in Japanese waters (extinct since the 8th-12th century A.D.) (Rice 1998, Oremus et al. 2009, Committee on Taxonomy 2017).

The Northern Bottlenose Whale forms an anti-tropical species pair with the Southern Bottlenose Whale, Hyperoodon planifrons. The variation in mitochondrial control region sequences between the two species of Hyperoodon was 4.12% higher than for all other beaked whale species, and 3.78% higher than between the anti-tropical species pair Berardius bairdii and B. arnuxii  (Dalebout et al. 1998). Also, the skull characters are very distinct between the two species.

The Southern Bottlenose Whale forms an antitropical species pair with the Northern Bottlenose Whale, Hyperoodon ampullatus. Intraspecific variation in mitochondrial control region sequences of two specimens from New Zealand was 4.12% higher than for all other cetacean species, and higher than between the antitropical species pair Berardius bairdii and B. arnuxii (3.78%) (Dalebout et al. 1998). Also, the skull characters are very distinct between the two species.

It was only in 1966 that the two species in the genus Kogia (K. breviceps and K. sima) were recognized as distinct (Handley 1966, Chivers et al. 2005). No subspecies have been described (Committee on Taxonomy 2018). The cryptic behavior and similar external morphology of the two species mean that records are often not displayed at the species level and are instead combined into Kogia spp.

This species was not widely recognized until 1966, therefore, in literature that predates this time it is often not clear which species of Kogia is intended. No subspecies of K. sima are currently recognized. However, based on mitochondrial cytochrome b gene sequencing, it has been suggested that K. sima consists of two species: one in the Atlantic and the other in the Indo-Pacific (Chivers et al. 2005). Further evidence is required before this can be shown definitively (McAlpine 2018).
Fraser’s Dolphin was described in 1956 and the external appearance of this species was not known until 1971 (Perrin et al. 1973).

The Atlantic White-sided Dolphin is currently placed in the multi-species genus Lagenorhynchus (Cipriano 1997). However, molecular analyses have for some time suggested that it is not closely related to any of those other species, (LeDuc et al. 1999, Harlin-Cognato and Honeycutt 2006). A recent study by Vollmer et al. (2018) compiled the findings from studies of morphology, genetics, historical biogeography, and acoustics and suggested an extensive revision of the genus, with the Atlantic White-sided Dolphin proposed as a single species in its own genus: Leucopleurus acutus. It is likely that the scientific name of the species will be change formally in the near future.

Genetic studies conducted in the 1990s suggested that White-beaked Dolphins are not closely related to any of the other dolphins currently assigned to the genus Lagenorhynchus. It was suggested that future work would lead to splitting, with the White-beaked Dolphin as the only member of the Lagenorhynchus clade (LeDuc et al. 1999, Harlin-Cognato and Honeycutt 2006). More recent molecular research (McGowen et al. 2011) supported this and suggested that the White-beaked Dolphin is in a monotypic genus Lagenorhynchus, which together with the Atlantic White-sided Dolphin (Leucopleurus acutus) forms a separate North Atlantic sub-family (Lagenorhynchinae). However, according to the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (2017), Lagenorhynchus is considered a polyphyletic taxon containing morphologically convergent species and there is continuing disagreement about how to sort and assign those species to different genera. Therefore, the Committee recommends retaining the current taxonomy and nomenclature until there is greater clarity. Morphological differences have been found between White-beaked Dolphins from the eastern and western Atlantic (Mikkelsen and Lund 1994).

The genus Lagenorhynchus is likely an artificial genus (LeDuc et al. 1999, Harlin-Cognato and Honeycut 2006). A revision of the taxonomy for this species has been proposed that will see it reassigned to the genus Sagmatias and renamed Sagmatias australis (Vollmer et al. 2018).
The genus Lagenorhynchus is in need of revision (LeDuc et al. 1999) and this species may end up being reassigned to the resurrected genus Sagmatias.

The genus Lagenorhynchus is polyphyletic and likely an artificial genus (LeDuc et al. 1999, Harlin-Cognato 2010), and this species is likely to be included eventually in the genus Sagmatias along with L. obliquidens (Pacific White-sided Dolphin) (Vollmer et al. 2018).

Four subspecies of Dusky Dolphin (Lagenorhynchus obliquidens) are currently recognized by the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (2018): African Dusky Dolphin L. o. obscurus off southern Africa, Fitzroy’s Dolphin L. o. fitzroyi off eastern South America, Peruvian/Chilean Dusky Dolphin L. o. posidonia off western South America, and the New Zealand Dusky Dolphin (un-named) off New Zealand (Perrin 2002). The populations centered in New Zealand, the west coast of South America, and southwestern Africa are genetically and morphologically distinct (Harlin-Cognato et al. 2007, Cassens et al. 2003, Würsig et al. 1997, Van Waerebeek 1993a,b). Dusky Dolphins also occur around some oceanic island groups (e.g., Tristan da Cunha, Prince Edward, Amsterdam, and St. Paul Islands). The subspecies affinities of these groups are uncertain.

The Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy recognizes three subspecies of Humpback Whale: the nominate subspecies M. n. novaeangliae (Borowski, 1781) refers to the North Atlantic Humpback Whale; M. n. australis (Lesson, 1828) is the Southern (Hemisphere) Humpback Whale; and M. n. kuzira (Gray, 1850) is the North Pacific Humpback Whale (Committee on Taxonomy 2017). This is based on the finding that Humpback Whales in the three ocean basins, although not separate clades, appear to be on diverging genetic trajectories (Jackson et al. 2014). The Arabian Sea contains a genetically isolated population of Humpback Whales (Pomilla et al. 2014), which is also assessed on the Red List separately as a subpopulation (Minton et al. 2008).

Some researchers previously suggested that this species and Hubb’s Beaked Whale (Mesoplodon carlhubbsi) may represent subspecies of the same species. However, genetic (Dalebout et al. 1998, 2004a) and morphological studies (Baker 2001) have supported the distinctness of the species.

The type specimen, from California, was originally identified as M. bowdoini (Hubbs 1946), but Moore (1963) subsequently described it as a new species, M. carlhubbsi, based on morphology. Recent genetic studies have agreed with the morphological analysis (Dalebout et al. 1998, 2004).
Blainville’s Beaked Whales (Mesoplodon densirostris) is one of 15 species of Mesoplodon with a worldwide range in tropical and warm-temperate waters. No subspecies are currently recognized.

Mitochondrial DNA evidence revealed that stranded specimens from the eastern North Pacific previously identified as M. hectori were a new species of Mesoplodon subsequently described as M. perrini (Dalebout et al. 2002).

Mesoplodon layardii was described from drawings of a skull made by Roland Trimen at the South African Museum, Cape Town at the request of E. L. Layard, keeper of the museum. Layard submitted the drawings and skull measurements to J. E. Gray at the British Museum of Natural History (Gray 1865). Gray (1874) also described Dolichodon traversii from the Chatham Islands as a new species. However, it was not accepted by other researchers and considered a synonym of M. layardii until Van Helden et al. (2002) showed that it had genetic and morphological differences distinct from M. layardii. The misidentified specimen from the Chatham Islands is now known to be a Spade-toothed Beaked Whale (M. traversii) (Van Helden et al. 2002).

Mesoplodon peruvianus was first described in 1991 (Reyes et al. 1991) based on specimens from Peru. Prior to that, beginning in the late 1970s, there had been numerous sightings of a distinctively patterned, but unidentified, mesoplodont during regular cetacean surveys in the eastern tropical Pacific. These were originally referred to in the survey sighting records and earlier publications as “Mesoplodon sp. A” (Pitman et al. 1987), but after the description of M. peruvianus, it was suggested that M. sp. A was, in fact, M. peruvianus (Pitman and Lynn 2001). This contention was later confirmed by genetic analysis of a fresh-stranded Mesoplodon in western Mexico with the same diagnostic color pattern (Urbán et al. 2013).

The Narwhal (Monodon monoceros) and the Beluga Whale (Delphinapterus leucas) are the only two species in the cetacean family Monodontidae (Rice 1998). While these are well-defined taxa, Heide-Jørgensen and Reeves (1993) described a skull from West Greenland of what apparently was a Narwhal-Beluga hybrid.

While Narwhals occur broadly in Arctic waters, their distribution, movements, and genetic characteristics suggest the existence of about 12 discrete or semi-discrete subpopulations or management stocks (Palsbøll et al. 1997, Richard 2010, NAMMCO in prep).

This taxonomic unit is treated as a single species even though there is extensive and growing evidence that it is, in fact, a complex of multiple forms with morphological, genetic, ecological, and behavioural differences that merit subspecies if not also species designations. At the time of writing (June 2017), the Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy (www.marinemammalscience.org/species-information/list-marine-mammal-species-subspecies), which is generally regarded as the authority for marine mammal taxonomy, recognized a single killer whale species, Orcinus orca (Linnaeus, 1758), and two unnamed subspecies in the eastern North Pacific, the ENP resident killer whale (O. o. un-named subsp.) and the ENP transient killer whale (O. o. un-named subsp.) also known as Bigg’s killer whale. The Committee noted, however, “Other forms of killer whales in the North Pacific, North Atlantic and Antarctic [Southern] Ocean may warrant recognition as separate subspecies or even species, but the taxonomy has not yet been fully clarified or agreed (Morin et al. 2010; Foote et al. 2009, 2013).” One population (a “distinct population segment”) of the ENP resident subspecies (the “southern resident” population) was listed as Endangered under the Canadian Species at Risk Act in 2003 and the U.S. Endangered Species Act in 2005.

No subspecies of the Melon-headed Whale (Peponocephala electra) are currently recognized (Committee on Taxonomy 2018). This species is morphologically similar to the Pygmy Killer Whale and the two species can be easily confused in the field.  Although they sometimes form resident populations around oceanic islands, Melon-headed Whales show low levels of genetic differentiation both within and between ocean basins, suggesting high levels of population connectivity (Martien et al. 2017).

Three subspecies of Harbor Porpoises are currently recognized by the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (2019). The Pacific Harbor Porpoise (Phocoena phocoena vomerina) occurs in the North Pacific, the Atlantic Harbor Porpoise (P. p. phocoena) has a distribution spanning the North Atlantic from North America to Europe and northwestern Africa, and the Black Sea Harbor Porpoise (P. p. relicta) occurs in the Black Sea (Viaud-Martinez et al. 2007).

In the eastern North Pacific hybrids between Harbor Porpoise and Dall’s Porpoise (Phocoenoides dalli) occur fairly often (Willis et al. 2004, Jefferson et al. 2015). Harbor Porpoises around the Iberian peninsula and northwestern Africa are genetically distinct from those in the rest of the European Atlantic (Fontaine et al., 2010) and Fontaine et al. (2014) suggested they were a new subspecies, P. p. meridionalis. A distinct mitochondrial lineage has been found in one porpoise from West Greenland, which raises the possibility that another Atlantic subspecies exists (IMR/NAMMCO 2019). A recent workshop on the status of Harbor Porpoises in the North Atlantic recognised 18 different assessment units there (IMR/NAMMCO 2019).

Rosa et al. (2005) found fixed differences in mtDNA of Burmeister's Porpoises between Peru and strata in Chile and Argentina. Results were consistent with levels of differentiation at a subspecies or greater level (Taylor et al. 2017) but the basis for a change in taxonomy has not been evaluated. The genetic data also supported differences, though of a lesser degree, between Chile and Argentina, which would be consistent with morphological differences between Burmeister’s Porpoises in the two ocean basins reported by Corcuera et al. (1995).

The Dall’s Porpoise (Phocoenoides dalli) includes animals of two main color morphs: dalli-type and truei-type (Escorza Trevino and Dizon 2000), which are currently recognized by the Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy as subspecies: Phocoenoides dalli dalli and P. d. truei (Rice 1998, Jefferson 2018; Committee on Taxonomy 2017).

The genus Stenella is paraphyletic, and it is likely that the Delphininae will be restructured in the coming years (LeDuc et al. 1999, Perrin et al. 2013). Two subspecies are recognized: S. attenuata attenuata in oceanic tropical waters worldwide, and S. a. graffmani in the coastal waters of the eastern tropical Pacific (ETP) (Jefferson et al. 2015, Perrin 2018).

The Clymene Dolphin (Stenella clymene) is likely to have evolved through a case of hybrid speciation, involving widespread hybridization of Spinner (S. longirostris) and Striped (S. coeruleoalba) Dolphins (Amaral et al., 2014). Recent genetic work suggests that the genus Stenella is paraphyletic, and it is likely that taxonomy of the Delphinidae will be restructured in coming years (LeDuc et al. 1999, Perrin et al. 2013). This species might even move to a different genus. Coloration differences between the Clymene Dolphins in the eastern and western Atlantic Ocean suggest possible population structuring, although this remains unconfirmed (Weir et al. 2014).

Recent genetic work suggests that the genus Stenella is paraphyletic, and it is likely that the Delphininae will be restructured in coming years (LeDuc et al. 1999, Perrin et al. 2013). Morphological and genetic studies strongly suggest that the Mediterranean and eastern North Atlantic Striped Dolphin populations are isolated from each other, with little or no gene flow across the Strait of Gibraltar (Calzada and Aguilar 1995, García-Martínez et al. 1995, Archer 1997, Gaspari 2004). No subspecies are recognized.

Recent molecular work suggests that the genus Stenella is paraphyletic, and it is likely that the Delphininae (the subfamily to which the species currently belongs) will be restructured in coming years, at which point this species may be assigned to a different genus (LeDuc et al. 1999, Perrin et al. 2013). Some evidence suggests a close relationship with the Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin (Tursiops aduncus) (Jefferson et al. 2015). There is a large, heavy form of Atlantic Spotted Dolphin found along the coasts on both sides of the Atlantic (formerly called Stenella plagiodon along the U.S. coast), while a smaller form that is lightly spotted or unspotted as an adult occurs in the Gulf Stream and the central North Atlantic (Perrin et al. 1987, Herzing and Perrin 2018, Viallelle 1997).

Cuvier’s Beaked Whale (Ziphius cavirostris) is the only species in the monotypic genus Ziphius (Rice 1998, Dalebout et al. 2005). During the 19th century numerous specimens of Cuvier’s Beaked Whales were described as new species but none of them have been accepted as valid and a single species is recognized to occur throughout its range.

This species was originally included in the genus Mesoplodon (Longman 1926), but based on morphological features, Moore (1968) created the monotypic genus Indopacetus. There has been debate about the validity of this genus (e.g., Mead 1989, Rice 1998), and, although Dalebout et al. (2003) were unable to validate Indopacetus based on available genetic evidence, they recommended retention of the genus based on morphological features. Prior to descriptions of its field characteristics, sightings in tropical waters of what are now known to be this species were sometimes mistakenly attributed to the genus Hyperoodon (Pitman et al. 1999, Dalebout et al. 2003).

The taxonomy follows the view of the International Whaling Commission (IWC) Scientific Committee (IWC 2004) and the Convention on Migratory Species (CMS), which now recognize Right Whales in the North Atlantic, North Pacific, and Southern Hemisphere as three distinct species in the genus Eubalaena, namely E. glacialis (North Atlantic Right Whale), E. japonica (North Pacific Right Whale), and E. australis (Southern Right Whale), based mainly on the mtDNA phylogenetic analyses of Rosenbaum et al. (2000).

In most of the scientific literature prior to 2000, including previous Red Lists (e.g., Baillie and Groombridge 1996), all Northern Hemisphere Right Whales were treated as the single species E. glacialis.

Rice (1998) classified Right Whales in the North Atlantic, North Pacific and Southern Hemisphere as the single species Balaena glacialis, in the genus Balaena along with B. mysticetus, the Bowhead Whale. While not all cetologists accept that the three Right Whale taxa qualify as full biological species, their clear geographical separation ensures that their treatment as separate taxa for conservation purposes is appropriate.

The Indo-Pacific Bottlenose Dolphin (Tursiops aduncus) has been recognized as a different species from the more widely distributed Common Bottlenose Dolphin (Tursiops truncatus) since the late 1990’s (Rice, 1998). Indo-Pacific Bottlenose Dolphins are distinct from Common Bottlenose Dolphins based on concordance among genetic, osteology, coloration and external morphology data (Wang et al. 1999, 2000a,b). No Indo-Pacific Bottlenose Dolphin subspecies are currently recognised by the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (2018). However, a recent re-assessment of Tursiops taxonomy worldwide (IWC 2019) and extensive genetic studies (Moura et al. 2013, Amaral et al. 2016, Gray et al. 2018) identified 4 or 5 different lineages (Africa, Pakistan, Bay of Bengal, China and Australia), including the recently described "T. australis" (Charlton-Robb et al., 2011) that may eventually be recognized as a subspecies. There is considerable population structure throughout the range of the species and multiple studies of morphology (Hale et al., 2000, Kemper 2004, Charlton-Robb et al., 2011) and genetics (Natoli et al. 2004, Särnblad et al. 2011, Charlton-Robb et al. 2011, Amaral et al. 2016) indicate that the taxonomic status for a number of populations in different regions should be re-evaluated.

The Spectacled Porpoise was briefly considered to be in its own genus, Australophocaena, and was listed in the 1996-2002 Red Lists as Australophocaena dioptrica. However, due to more recent genetic and morphometric findings (Rosel et al. 1995, Perrin et al. 2000), it has again been assigned to the genus Phocoena (Committee on Taxonomy 2018).

The recognition of two externally distinct morphological forms of Finless Porpoises as separate biological species (Neophocaena phocaenoides and N. asiaeorientalis) was accepted when it was demonstrated that the two forms are reproductively isolated (and likely have been separated since the last glacial maximum) even though they are sympatric in a fairly large area of East Asia (Wang et al. 2008, Jefferson and Wang 2011). Differences in the external morphology of the dorsal aspect of the two species are distinguishable even amongst free-ranging animals (as opposed to animals in-hand for close inspection) (Wang et al. 2010) and intermediate individuals have never been reported even though several hundred to thousands of carcasses have been examined. The two species also clearly differ in craniometry (Amano et al. 1992, Jefferson 2002). Within the Narrow-ridged species, two subspecies are retained: the Yangtze Finless Porpoise, N. a. asiaeorientalis, and the East Asian Finless Porpoise or Sunameri, N. a. sunameri (Gao 1991, Wang 1992a,b; Gao and Zhou 1995). Where Narrow-ridged Finless Porpoises have been studied fairly well (e.g., Yoshida et al. 1995, 2001; Yoshida 2002, Jefferson 2002, Zheng et al. 2005, Yang et al. 2008, Chen et al. 2010, Xu et al. 2010, Li et al. 2011, Ju et al. 2012, L. Li et al. 2013, S. Li et al. 2013, Chen et al. 2014, Jia et al. 2014, Lin et al. 2014), there is evidence to suggest subpopulation structure.

authority: Dalebout, Mead, Baker, Baker & van Helden, 2002
taxonomicNotes: Mesoplodon perrini was described in 2002, based on five animals that stranded on the coast of southern and central California from 1975 to 1997 (Dalebout et al. 2002, 2004). Four were initially identified as Hector's Beaked Whales (M. hectori), based on cranial and tooth morphology (Mead 1981, Mead and Baker 1987, Mead 1989), and the fifth was initially identified as a newborn Cuvier's Beaked Whale (Ziphius cavirostris), based on external characters. Although externally similar to Hector’s Beaked Whale, the genetic evidence does not support a close evolutionary relationship between the two, but instead suggests that M. perrini has a possible sister-species relationship with the Pygmy Beaked Whale M. peruvianus (Dalebout et al. 2002, Dalebout et al. 2004).

In 1996, a new species of beaked whale was described as Mesoplodon bahamondi (Reyes et al. 1996). However, further study showed that it was the same as a previously-described beaked whale (M. traversii , Gray, 1874) that had long been erroneously considered a junior synonym of the Strap-toothed Beaked Whale (M. layardii). Using morphology and genetics, Van Helden et al. (2002) determined that M. traversii was a valid species and that M. bahamondi was its junior synonym.
