The recognition of two externally distinct morphological forms of Finless Porpoises as separate biological species, the Indo-Pacific Finless Porpoise (Neophocaena phocaenoides) and the Narrow-ridged Finless Porpoise (N. asiaeorientalis), was accepted only recently when it was demonstrated that the two forms are reproductively isolated (and likely have been separated since the last glacial maximum) even though they occur sympatrically in a fairly large area of eastern Asia (Wang et al. 2008, Jefferson and Wang 2011). [Much of the literature published before ca 2010 refers to all Finless Porpoises (both species) as N. phocaenoides.] Differences in the external morphology of the dorsal aspect of the two species are distinguishable even amongst free-ranging animals (as opposed to only specimens in-hand) (Wang et al. 2010). Intermediates between the two main forms have never been reported even though several hundreds to thousands of carcasses have been examined. The two species also clearly differ in craniometry (Amano et al. 1992, Jefferson 2002).

There is evidence to suggest subpopulation structure within Indo-Pacific Finless Porpoises in some areas (Jefferson 2002, Yang et al. 2008, Chen et al. 2010, Xu et al. 2010, Li et al. 2011, Ju et al. 2012, L. Li et al. 2013, S. Li et al. 2013, Jia et al. 2014, Lin et al. 2014) and this may apply throughout much of the species’ distribution.

The species was firstly described as Muricea macrospina (Koch, 1882) and many times considered as a variety of the red gorgonian (Paramuricea clavata) or misidentified as Paramuricea placomus (Pax & Müller, 1962), but finally accepted as a different species (Carpine & Grasshoff, 1975).

Differences between adults of Uraspis helvola and U. secunda are virtually impossible to distinguish. If subsequent studies indicated that these two nominal species are conspecific, the oldest available name is Uraspis helvola (Smith-Vaniz 1984).
Some biologist in the past have seen the species as a variety form of A. equine (Pax, 1907) but today it is seen as a separate species by most workers.
This species could be considered as a species of the Genus Actinia by some authors (Verena Haussermann, 2003).
Previously this species was considered a synonym of Chromis flavicauda (Smith-Vaniz and Collette 2013).
This species can be confused with Pseudochromis aldabraensis (Gill 2003).

Dawson (1985) recognizes three subspecies, Doryrhamphus excisus abbreviatus (from the Red Sea), D. e. excisus (pan-Indo-Pacific), and D. e. paulus (endemic to the Revillagigedo Islands off the west coast of Mexico). In contemporary literature subspecific designations are no longer followed but as Dawson (1985) recommended more research is needed to understand the systematic status of these populations. All are treated here as subspecies of D. excisus.
This species is closely related to Hippocampus histrix (Lourie et al. 2016). Molecular work is needed to confirm that this is in fact a distinct species.
According to the WoRMS database (accessed 5 January 2022), the taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain or disputed by different experts.
For additional taxonomic information, please refer to Gittenberger and Hoeksema (2006).
This species is now in the genus Cycloseris (Hoeksema and Cairns 2019).
{Attention RLU: Please change the family from Pectiniidae to Merulinidae. For reference please see WoRMS. - C. Linardich 18Jan2022}
Attention RLU: This species is now considered a synonym of Acropora speciosa. For reference please see WoRMS: http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=207088. C. Linardich 4Jan2022
Millepora tenella is considered a synonym of this species (Randall and Cheng 1984).
Acropora lianae and Acropora rosaria are now synonyms of this species (WoRMS accessed January 2022).
Attention RLU: Please change the family from Faviidae to Merulinidae. Reference is WoRMS. - C. Linardich 13Jan2022
Attention RLU: Please change the family from Faviidae to Leptastreidae. Reference is WoRMS. - C. Linardich 13Jan2022
Acropora ocellata is now a synonym of this species (WoRMS accessed January 2022).

Acropora torresiana and Acropora wallaceae are now synonyms of this species (Wallace et al. 2012, WoRMS accessed January 2022). This is a well-defined species in the field but not in collections as it has been confused with other species and taxonomic research is needed (Veron et al. 2016).

The status of this nominal species requires further research. It has been considered a synonym of Pocillopora elegans (Reyes-Bonilla 2003) and a valid species (Reyes-Bonilla et al. 2005). The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain since Wallace (1999) considered it unresolved, while Veron (2000) considered it valid. According to the WoRMS online database (accessed June 2022), the taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain or disputed by different experts. Further integrated phylogeographic or population genetic study may reveal this to be a distinct species and further taxonomic research is warranted (Z. Richards pers. comm. 2022).

Taxonomic Note: A species complex which is likely to be divisible into several cryptic species. The species irregularis has been used with three related genera, Porites, Napopora and Synaraea. Porites irregularis Verrill (1864) is not recognisable from the original description. The Porites irregularis of Vaughan (1907), Nemenzo (1955) and Maragos (1977) is this species. Napopora irregularis Quelch (1884) (illustrated by Bosserelle, Berteaux-Lecellier, Chancerelle et al. 2014) is currently under review but is likely to be accepted as a valid species.
This species was synonymized with Psammocora profundacella (Benzoni et al. 2010); however, this synonymy remains uncertain (Veron et al. 2016).

The current morphological identification criteria for Goniopora lobata and G. djiboutiensis do not match the existing genetic boundaries, and thus, the two should be regarded as a species complex (Yasuda et al. 2021). 

The complete mitogenome sequence of Goniopora djiboutiensis is 18,765 bp in length, comprising unique 13 protein-coding genes (PCGs), two ribosomal RNAs, and two transfer RNAs genes of each, showing a typical Scleractinia pattern. New phylogenetic analysis upon complete mitogenomics revealed that G. djiboutiensis is most closely related to G. columna, with high bootstrap values (Tong et al. 2019).

There remains some confusion regarding the valid name of this nominal species. In a review of the staghorn corals, Wallace (1999) considered Acropora formosa to be a junior synonym of A. muricata. Currently, A. formosa is not valid in WoRMS (Hoeksema and Cairns 2019) or Corals of the World (Veron et al. 2016). Acropora copiosa is also considered a junior synonym of A. muricata (Hoeksema and Cairns 2020).
Attention RLU: Please change the family from Faviidae to Merulinidae. For reference please see WoRMS. - C. Linardich 12Jan2022
Acropora irregularis and Acropora tutuilensis are now synonyms of this species (WoRMS accessed January 2022).

Attention RLU: This species is now considered a synonym of Acropora hyacinthus. For reference please see WoRMS: http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=430640. C. Linardich 4Jan2022

This species is a synonym of Acropora hyacinthus (Wallace 1999).
The genus Isopora was previously a subgenus but was elevated (Wallace et al. 2007).
Mkare et al. (2017) found that genetic admixture between estuaries was high, and recommend recognizing the subpopulations from the three estuaries as a single Evolutionarily Significant Unit (ESU).

Hippocampus abdominalis was first described from New Zealand and there is a question as to whether specimens from Australia represent the same species. Studies that have addressed this question do not support the existence of multiple species based on morphological, meristic, and genetic data (357 bp, cyt b) and show more variation within populations than among populations (Armstrong 2001, Lourie et al. 2016). There is some genetic divergence between Australian and New Zealand populations (814bp cytb, 624bp CO1, 404bp CR, plus four microsatellite loci), however, the level of divergence is low (1.4–1.7%, Nickel and Cursons 2012). Divergence within New Zealand is 0.7–2.2% without any clear geographical structure (Nickel 2009; Nickel and Cursons 2012). The name H. abdominalis takes precedence with H. agnesae and H. bleekeri being treated as synonyms. Hippocampus graciliformis is a juvenile specimen of H. abdominalis and therefore is also synonymized.

The name H. coronatus has often been applied to H. sindonis in the past. Morphometric (Lourie et al. 1999) and genetic (Mukai et al. 2000) research suggest that these two are not the same species. Mukai et al.’s (2000) data also suggest that H. coronatus is distinct from H. mohnikei.

The wide geographic range of H. histrix (from east Africa to Japan) warrants further investigation, as Song and Mabuchi (2014) suggest that the genetic distance between Indian and Pacific populations is 6.6–6.7% (CO1) and this is also suggested by BOLD (2016) which indicates a 6.13% distinction between specimens from Mozambique/India versus Vietnam/Japan (648bp CO1). This high degree of divergence indicates the presence of at least one cryptic species across the range. There are no genetic data currently available for H. jayakari, which is morphologically very similar to but replaces H. histrix in the Red Sea and Arabian Gulf (Lourie et al. 2016).
This species has often been misidentified as H. coronatus or H. mohnikei.

The 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists included Hippocampus aimei; this is now considered a synonym of H. barbouri and H. spinosissimus. More recently, Lourie et al. (2016) placed H. alatus (which was listed as Data Deficient in previous versions of the IUCN Red List) into synonymy with H. spinosissimus.

This species is commonly confused with H. histrix.

From Lourie et al. (2016):
The type specimens of H. spinosissimus are surprisingly small, yet they are males with fully developed pouches. They also have clear nose spines, double cheek spines, and all body spines are approximately equally developed. A third specimen labelled as ‘type’ (ZMA 114.473) had single cheek spines. Lourie et al. (1999) used this name to refer to spiny seahorses from across Southeast Asia, even though the latter frequently lacked a nose spine. No genetic data are available from the type specimens. Morphological and genetic data do not support the distinctness of H. queenslandicus nor H. semispinosus from what is understood as H. spinosissimus by Lourie et al.(1999) (Teske et al. 2007; BOLD 2016; see also Zhang et al. 2014). Admittedly there exists variation in spine development and colour pattern among H. spinosissimus specimens and genetic data indicate that haplotype diversity is high, with three major lineages, two of which are broadly sympatric and one that is restricted to the central Philippines (Lourie et al. 2005). However, the genetic divergence among specimens of H. spinosissimus examined from Australia, Malaysia and the Philippines is only 0.82% (648bp, CO1) (BOLD 2016), and the average cytochrome b sequence divergence among 172 specimens from 29 populations is only 1.3% (Lourie et al. 2005). At present we suggest that the variation represents polymorphism within a single species, rather than different species, however further investigation is warranted. Kuiter (2009) and Allen and Erdmann (2012) identify spiny Southeast Asian seahorses variously as H. arnei, H. alatus, H. moluccensis, and H. polytaenia. The illustration of H. polytaenia (Bleeker, 1893) does show markings and moderately developed spines that are reminiscent of H. spinosissimus, however the type specimens conform to H. kuda (SL pers. obs.). Hippocampus alatus is tentatively synonymised here on the basis of morphological similarity, pending further work (especially genetics).

Although the names Hippocampus subelongatus and H. elongatus were first described in the same document, there are apparently no type specimens for H. elongatus, and thus Hippocampus subelongatus is the proper name (Lourie et al. 1999, Eschmeyer et al. 2017).
Lourie et al. (2016) placed H. montebelloensis into synonymy with H. zebra.
Lourie et al. (2016) placed H. grandiceps Kuiter 2001, H. hendriki Kuiter 2001, and H. multispinus Kuiter 2001 into synonymy with H. angustus.

Both Hippocampus mohnikei and H. japonicus were described from Japan and examination of their type specimens shows them to be the same species (Lourie et al. 2016 - Appendix J). Specimens from elsewhere in the Indo-Pacific morphologically conform to H. mohnikei, and differ genetically (e.g. Japanese and Vietnamese specimens differ by an average of 2.25%—648 bp, CO1, BOLD 2016), indicating that there is the possibility of cryptic species within what we know as H. mohnikei.

The type specimen was sent from Algiers, Algeria by Guichenot who reported this species occurred, albeit ‘very rarely’, in Béjaïa (formerly Bougie) (Guichenot 1850). No other specimens have been found from Algeria since this time, and we restrict the current distribution of Hippocampus algiricus to West Africa. H. algiricus is very closely related to the H. kuda-complex (Teske et al. 2005) and is only 1.3% divergent from H. reidi (Silveira et al. 2014; Casey et al. 2004; Teske et al. 2004; BOLD 2016), but is here retained as a valid separate species due to the geographic distance between the West African and Brazilian coasts. Further research is needed to determine the level of connectivity and gene exchange between the two populations.

Specimens from Lord Howe Island, Australia and New Caledonia that were previously tentatively assigned to this species have subsequently been described as Hippocampus jugumus and H. pusillus (Kuiter 2001, Fricke 2004, Lourie et al. 2016).
This species is named in honour of Hence Pontoh, an Indonesian dive guide. Lourie et al. (2016) placed Hippocampus severnsi into synonymy with H. pontohi.

This species is named in honour of Miss Satomi Onishi, the dive guide who collected the type specimens (Lourie and Kuiter 2008). Lourie et al. (2016) placed Hippocampus waleananus into synonymy with H. satomiae.
This species was likely misidentified as Hippocampus erectus prior to its description in 2004.
The name Saurida undosquamis has been widely misapplied in the literature. The true Saurida undosquamis is probably restricted in range to northwestern Australia (B. Russell pers. comm. 2015).

Specimens nominally identified as this species from the Philippines and Indonesia are likely to be incorrect identifications of the similar species Sardinella lemuru (Willette and Santos 2013). 


Recent analysis of micro-satellite markers suggests genetic differentiation of this species between the Gulf of Oman and the coast of India (Sebastian et al. 2017). Subsequent sub-structuring of this species within India revealed genetic differentiation between samples obtained from Mumbai and Mangalore on the western coast of India and the samples obtained from the southwest and eastern coast of India (Calicut, Kollam, Trivandrum, Chennai and Vizag: Sebastian et al. 2017).
Chakrabarty et al. (2009) discuss generic placement of this species.
Along northern and western Australia, Arnoglossus aspilos is often treated as a distinct subspecies: Arnoglossus aspilos praeteritus (Whitley, 1950) (Hensley and Amaoka 2001).

The presence of Ilisha megaloptera in the Persian Gulf is questionable as it may be confused with  I. melastoma and I. compressa. Due to the uncertainty, reports from the Persian Gulf are not considered for the purposes of this assessment.
Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). This species was recently split from E. boehlkei (Victor 2013).

A recent taxonomic revision of the genus Brachypterus (Matsunuma et al. 2013) resulted in three valid species: B. serrulifer Fowler 1936, widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific; B. serrulata (Richardson 1846), restricted to the northwestern Pacific Ocean; and B. curvispina Matsunuma, Sakurai & Motomura 2013, restricted to northeastern Australia.
Some individuals from Taiwan that have been identified as P. eriomma may represent a cryptic species (B. Russell pers. comm. 2018).

Often included in the genus Alopex, current evidence suggests that inclusion in Vulpes (sensu Wozencraft 2005) is warranted as Vulpes is otherwise paraphyletic with respect to Alopex. Nuclear and matrilineal (mitochondrial) DNA unambiguously support the inclusion of Alopex lagopus in Vulpes (Geffen et al. 1992, Lindblad-Toh et al. 2005, Perini et al. 2010).

This genus was reviewed by Larson (2010), and the current limits of the species may comprise several taxa. Genetic and morphological studies covering all habitat types and geographic localities may help to clarify if there are cryptic species within R. bikolanus.
This species was submitted as Chonophorus macrorhynchus and subsequently corrected to Awaous macrorhynchus on recommendation of Paul Loiselle.

The species was reviewed by Allen and Burgess (1990) who noted that this species is frequently misidentified and some distributions may be suspect (e.g. it does not occur in Australia). It is often misidentified as Ambassis commersoni Cuvier, 1828, which is a synonym of Ambassis ambassis Lacepède 1802.

Ambassis ambassis was originally described as Centropomus ambassis by Lacepède (1802) from Réunion, western Mascarenes, southwestern Indian Ocean. Günther (1859), Talwar and Jhingran (1991) and Jayaram (1999) considered Ambassis ambassis as a synonym of Ambassis commersoni, which should be other way round (Anderson and Heemstra 2003). This widespread species is likely to be a complex and further taxonomic studies, preferably involving molecular techniques, are essential.

Dawson (1984, 1985) and most later authors consider Coelonotus to be a subgenus of Microphis based on morphology and meristics. Kottelat (2013) and Delrieu-Trottin et al. (2015) resurrect Coelonotus with no annotation or justification. See Hamilton et al. (2016) for a molecular phylogeny which includes this species.

Kuiter (2009) resurrects Microphis vaillantii Juillerat 1880 with no annotation or justification. That species was synonymized by Dawson (1984, 1985).
Numerous synonyms all outside the southern African region.

Elops machnata and E. hawaiensis occur sympatrically in the Western Pacific and possibly the Hawaiian Islands, so further research appears warranted. In the northern south China Sea, for example, Shao et al. (2008) claim that E. hawaiensis historically reported in the region are misidentifications of E. machnata. Wang et al. (2002) state that genetic data are now available to discriminate between E. machnata and E. hawaiensis.
It is very likely to be a species complex and work is ongoing.
This species consists of three subspecies: Sarotherodon melanotheron melanotheron, Sarotherodon melanotheron leonensis and Sarotherodon melanotheron heudolotii (Paugy et al. 2003).

Subgenus (Chrysichthys): C. auratus exhibits pronounced intraspecific variability, and a clinal series can be demonstrated in the size of the adipose fin and the number of gill rakers (Risch 1986): subpopulations from the Nile, Chad, Senegal and the upper reaches of Niger River, Comoe, Benue and Volta have a lower number of gill rakers and a larger adipose fin than the populations of the coastal areas from Liberia to Cabinda. The subpopulations of the middle and lower reaches of the Niger, the Comoe, the Benue and the Volta are more or less intermediate between the two. Therefore we consider all populations to represent a single, highly variable, species (Geerinckx et al. 2007).

Chrysichthys persimilis and Chrysichthys rueppelli are considered to be males of Chrysichthys auratus (Risch and Vreven 2007).
This species previously appeared in the genus Tilapia but is now considered valid in the genus Pelmatolapia (Eschmeyer et al. 2018).
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Tilapia but is now considered valid in the genus Coptodon (Eschmeyer et al. 2018).

The taxonomy of all Stenogobius species is in flux, with about 30 nominal species (and only a few of these probably valid) and the genus in great need of review. Stenogobius gymnopomus is often misidentified in books and online databases under a variety of names.
The taxonomy of this species has never been reviewed and it may represent more than one species.

There are no issues regarding the validity of the species, but it should be noted that it is often confused with Elops lacerta (Whitehead 1990). Elops senegalensis and E. lacerta occur sympatrically across the entire range of E. senegalensis, so further research appears warranted.

Even though Elops lacerta and Elops senegalensis occur sympatrically across the entire range and appear confusing with each other they can always be distinguished by number of scales on the lateral line; 92-100 for E. senegalensis and 72-83 for E. lacerta (Paugy et al. 2003).
The genus Eleotris is feminine, but Kottelat (1993) accepts acanthopomus as a noun, which does not need to change gender when combined with Eleotris.
The species in the synonymy were listed by Keith et al. (2015).
Pristis pristis was formerly known as P. perotteti in the Atlantic and sometimes in the Eastern Pacific, and P. microdon in the Indo-West Pacific. These are both now synonyms of P. pristis.
This species can be easily confused with Drombus halei which can co-occur (Larson pers comm. 2018).
At times confused with Glossogobius giuris (see Maugé 1986). Two of the syntypes from India are different species (H. Larson in press).
Further work is needed for a taxonomic review of the genus Evynnis (Iwatsuki et al. 2007).

The placement of this species in the Macrouridae is not supported by current morphological and genetic analyses; rather, it belongs in the family Bathygadidae (Howes and Crimmen 1990, Roa-Varón and Ortí 2009, Nelson et al. 2016).
Notopterus notopterus is a very widespread species that most likely represents a species complex.
Dayella malabarica was described by Day (1873) from erstwhile Malabar.

Oryzias dancena was originally described as Cyprnus dancena from Estuary below Calcutta, India by Hamilton (1822). While revising this genus, Parenti (2008) has placed several questionable synonym under this species. Therefore, this widespread species is likely to be a complex and further taxonomic studies, preferably involving molecular techniques, are essential.
Ambassis nalua was originally described as Chanda nalua by Hamilton (1822) from fresh waters of lower Bengal. The species was reviewed by Allen and Burgess (1990).
Ambassis interrupta was reviewed by Allen and Burgess (1990) for the Australia/Pacific and by Anderson and Heemstra (2003) for the western Indian Ocean.

This species was described as Aplocheilus carnaticus Jerdon (1849) from 'river that passes by Waniambaddy [= Vaniyambadi], 'Carnatic', southern India. This widespread species is likely to be a complex and further taxonomic studies, preferably involving molecular techniques, are essential.

A few early references use the name Oxyeleotris gyrinoides. There are several other species names (Bunaka pelewensis and Bunaka pinguis) that may or may not apply to this species. Taxonomic work is required.

One of its common names, Green-backed Guavina, is often misspelled as Gauvina (by later references quoting the original misspelling by Allen (1991)). Guavina is an American term for gudgeon (therefore not very appropriate for a non-American species).
Ichthyocampus carce was described by Hamilton (1822) from the tide way of Ganges River, India.

The genus Horadandia was monotypic until the description of a subspecies, H. atukorali brittani, by Rema Devi & Menon (1992). This subspecies has since been treated uncritically as a synonym of H. atukorali (eg: Rema Devi 1996: 304; Menon 1999: 49). However, Batuwita et al. (2013) distinguished H. atukorali from H. brittani, resulting in two separate species.
The family Bathylaconidae is not monophyletic (Poulsen et al. 2009).
It is in need of a taxonomic revision (Poulsen et al. 2009).
The genus Narcetes, and Rinoctes and Bathytroctes are in need of a taxonomic revision (Poulsen et al. 2009).
The genus Narcetes, and Rinoctes and Bathytroctes are in need of a taxonomic revision (Poulsen et al. 2009).
The genus Narcetes, and Rinoctes and Bathytroctes are in need of a taxonomic revision (Poulsen et al. 2009).

This species' taxonomic status is under review. It is now only known from the holotype, which is in such a poor state that it can no longer be used for comparison to other specimens (J. Nielsen pers. comm. 2014).
Until recently, Melanolagus bericoides was assigned to the genus Bathylagus, and it is often confused with Bathylagus euryops (Møller et al. 2010).

Ongoing taxonomic work is expected to confirm that Mirapinna esau actually represents juvenile specimens of Procetichthys kreffti, and therefore, is its senior synonym (Johnson et al. 2009, Paxton et al. 2016).
May be known by the older name Paruroconger drachi.
The taxonomy of this species is not currently well understood. Hymenocephalus gracilis is a synonym of Hymenogadus gracilis in the Catalog of Fishes.

The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be 1-2 hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species. The importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through check lists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).

The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be one to two hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014). Further, the importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through checklists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).

The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be one to two hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014). Further, the importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through checklists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).

The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be one or two hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014). Further, the importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through checklists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).

Taxonomic revision of the genus Bathyonus is needed in order to verify species distributions (Nielsen et al. 1999). Nielsen et al. (2008) collected an specimen from the Southern Ocean, but did not describe it past the genus level because of unresolved taxonomic issues within the genus.
The genus Dicrolene is in need of taxonomic revision.
Nielsen (2009) revised the genus Luciobrotula, finding three species in the Atlantic Ocean: L. brasiliensis, L. corethromycter, and L. nolfi.
Mentodus perforatus Sazonov and Trunov, 1978 was described as a separate species, distinct from M. rostratus (Quéro et al. 1990).
Mentodus perforatus Sazonov and Trunov, 1978 was described as a separate species, distinct from M. rostratus (Quéro et al. 1990).
Sutton et al. (2013) report that recent molecular analyses suggest this species may be aheteromorphic synonym of Maurolicus muelleri.

The type specimen in British museum could not reliably be identified to the species level as the specimen is in poor condition and is a juvenile (11.4 mm SL). This species is undetermined and is likely a junior synonym.

The South American Sea Lion has been referred to by the scientific names Otaria byronia (following Blainville 1820) and O. flavescens (following Shaw 1800). Rice (1998) concluded that O. flavescens has priority. More recently, Berta and Churchill (2012) noted that the specific name for this taxa is controversial, but concluded that O. byronia is “the earliest available name applicable with certainty.” O. byronia is the name approved by the Society for Marine Mammalogy (Committee on Taxonomy 2014) and will be used in the document. However, O. flavescens is still in use, particularly by South American scientists.

Szapkievich et al. (1999) conducted the first genetic study on the species, analyzing 10 protein loci in 70 South American Sea Lion pups from two rookeries 1,300 km apart (Isla de Lobos, Uruguay and Peninsula Valdés, Argentina). They found only a small genetic distance between the rookeries, suggesting that they belong to the same population in which gene flow is currently occurring. Túnez et al. (2007) studied the population structure of South American Sea Lions by analyzing mtDNA from a few colonies along the Atlantic coast, and comparing their results with five sequences previously published from Peruvian populations (Wynen et al. 2001). They found no haplotypes shared between the Atlantic and Peruvian colonies. The South Atlantic population from Uruguay to southern Patagonia was studied by means of mtDNA (Túnez et al. 2007, 2010; Feijoó et al. 2011) and microsatellites (Feijoó et al. 2011). While mitochondrial markers showed geographically structured sub-populations, the nuclear loci showed a lack of geographical structure. These opposite patterns in genetic structure can be explained by female phylopatry and high male dispersion (Feijoo et al. 2011). On the Chilean coast, Weinberger (2013) using eight microsatellite loci showed the existence of two genetic clusters separated at approximately 41° S, supporting the existence of two sub-populations or management units.

Gehara (2009) and Túnez et al. (2007) concluded there is significant genetic differentiation between South American Sea Lions in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, suggesting complete and prolonged isolation and distinct evolutionarily significant units (ESUs). This was based on 10 microsatellite loci and mtDNA sequences from 4 areas (Uruguay, Argentina, Chile, and Peru). However, the rookeries of southern South America need to be sampled and analyzed in order to establish the limit of gene flow between the two ocean basins (Oliveira pers. comm.).

In 2011 the genus of all Fur Seals other than Arctocephalus pusillus was changed from Arctocephalus to Arctophoca, Peters 1866 (Committee on Taxonomy 2011) based on evidence presented in Berta and Churchill (2012). However, in 2013, based on genetic evidence presented in Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds (2012), this change was considered to be premature and these species were returned to the genus Arctocephalus pending further research (Committee on Taxonomy 2013).

In earlier taxonomic reviews (Repenning et al. 1971) this taxon was referred to as Arctocephalus philippii, subspecies philippii, and was considered conspecific with A. townsendi, which was referred to as A. p. townsendi. Brunner (2003) argued that this species should belong to the genus Arctophoca, and considered philippii and townsendi to be subspecies. However, Higdon et al. (2007) used genetic evidence to argue that these are separate species, regardless of the generic name, as they split about 0.3 mya
The genus Conocara is in need of a taxonomic revision (Poulsen et al. 2009).

There remains some uncertainty as to the taxonomic status of Gnatholepis thompsoni. It has previously been considered a synonym of Gnatholepis cauerensis.

The taxonomic concept of Gnatholepis cauerensis is undergoing revision. Gnatholepis has often been misidentified and confused for many years. Previously, there were four proposed subspecies (G. c. cauerensis, G. c. australis, G. c. hawaiiensis and G. c. pascuensis), and G. thompsoni was considered a synonym (Randall and Greenfield 2001). Thacker (2004) shows G. thompsoni to be a separate species and also concludes that G. cauerensis should be synonymised with G. anjerensis. Variation in mitochondrial DNA suggested that G. thompsoni is a valid species that is widespread in the Atlantic Ocean and separate from G. cauerensis (Rocha et al. 2005). However, Randall and Greenfield (2007) consider G. thompsoni a synonym of G. cauerensis. Randall (2009) elevated three subspecies to the species level (resulting in four species: G. cauerensis, G. australis, G. hawaiiensis and G. pascuensis). During a recent revision of Gnatholepis, the classification presented by Rocha et al. was discussed and validated with meristic and other morphological characters by Larson and Buckle (2012). Larson and Buckle (2012) concluded that G. cauerensis includes subspecies G. c. cauerensis, G. c. australis and G. c. hawaiiensis and G. inconsequens is considered a synonym. They elevated G. thompsoni and G. pascuensis to valid species. Gnatholepis thompsoni, as valid in Larson and Buckle (2012), is restricted to the Atlantic Ocean. Rocha et al. (2005) examined genetic differences between the Atlantic G. thompsoni and the Indo-Pacific G. cauerensis, concluding that G. thompsoni is the result of a relatively recent (~ 145,000 years ago) invasion of the Atlantic by G. cauerensis. However, Smith-Vaniz and Collette (2013) recorded G. cauerensis, not G. thompsoni, in Bermuda, as "the meristic and other morphological characters purported to separate these two 'species' have broadly over-lapping values". Despite the issues with the characters used by Larson and Buckle (2012), G. thompsoni likely forms its own monophyletic group in an isolated ocean basin, and with threats and evolutionary trajectory separate from that of G. cauerensis. Therefore, G. thompsoni is retained as a valid species.
Many Epizoanthus taxa in the Mediterranean are doubtful. Some studies considers that Epizoanthus tergestinus could be a synonym of E. univittatus (Lorenz, 1860).
Epizoanthus species records in the Mediterranean are doubtful and might correspond to Epizoanthus arenaceus.

There is a lack of taxonomic information on the genus Epizoanthus in the Mediterranean and further taxonomy studies are required, and there is no information to distinguish E. univittatus from the more common species E. arenaceus.
There is a lack of taxonomic information on the genus Epizoanthus in the Mediterranean and further taxonomic studies are required.
A. oligopodus could be a complex of species and also can be misidentified with A. maderensis.
Many Epizoanthus taxa in the Mediterranean are doubtful. Some studies considers that Epizoanthus steueri could be a synonym of E. vatovai (Pax and Lochter, 1935).
Some authors (e.g., Akazaki in Masuda et al. 1984, Chen et al. 1997) recognize two species: Caesio cuning and C. erythrogaster; however, this is doubtful (K. Carpenter pers. comm. 2015).
Some Epizoanthus species records from the Mediterranean are doubtful and may correspond to Epizoanthus arenaceus.

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).

Terminal males closely resemble those of S. tricolor, differing primarily by lacking a yellow blotch on the inner pectoral axil (R.F. Myers pers comm. 2009).

Antarctic Fur Seals were formerly considered a subspecies of Arctocephalus tropicalis and were known as A. t. gazella (Repenning et al. 1971). Rice (1998) listed the species as A. gazella.  In 2011 the genus of this, and many other species of Fur Seals was changed to Arctophoca, Peters 1866 (Committee on Taxonomy 2011) based on evidence presented in Berta and Churchill (2012). However, in 2013, based on genetic evidence presented in Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds (2012), this change was considered to be premature and these species were returned to the genus Arctocephalus pending further research (Committee on Taxonomy 2013).

This species has long been synonymized with Hippocampus ramulosus Leach 1814. The most recent and comprehensive taxonomic reviews suggest there are only two European species, H. guttulatus and H. hippocampus, and that each is a single undifferentiated species across its range (Woodall et al. 2018). Riquet and colleagues (2019) evidenced the existence of five clearly distinct genetic lineages of  H. guttulatus: one from North Sea to southwestern France, one around the Iberian Peninsula to the Alboran Sea, one in the Black Sea, one in the Mediterranean Sea, and the last limited to Thau and other Occitania lagoons in southern France. Further research is needed to understand if this has taxonomic incidences and to establish if H. ramulosus is a different species of H. guttulatus or a different morphological type (Woodall et al. 2018).

The most recent and comprehensive taxonomic reviews suggest there are only two European species, Hippocampus guttulatus and Hippocampus hippocampus, and that each is a single undifferentiated species across its range (Woodall et al. 2018). However, three distinct genetic subpopulations of H. hippocampus have been identified: in the English Channel and Bay of Biscay, Europe including the Mediterranean, and West Africa (Woodall et al. 2011).

This assessment was updated to reflect current taxonomic knowledge, namely that populations sometimes referred to as subspecies of C. arctus (C. arctus coccineus and C. arctus heraldi - Dawson 1985) are distinct species (i.e., C. coccineus and C. heraldi) (Fritzsche 1980). Further morphometric and molecular analyses are needed in order to confirm this.
The Order for this Family has changed  from Syngnathiformes to Gasterosteiformes (Nelson 2006).

Syngnathus euchrous is thought to comprise two subspecies: S. euchrous euchrous and S. euchrous ollotropis. The physical difference between the two is in number of dorsal rays, tail rings and rings covering their brood pouch (S. e. euchrous having slightly more rays and rings). In regards to range and habitat, S. e. euchrous is found in the northern part of the species’ range, off rocky shores; while S. e. ollotropis is found in the southern part of the range, in eelgrass beds and drifting algae. The separation point between the two varieties is between Punta Eugenia and Bahia Tortugas, Baja California, Mexico. Syngnathus euchrous is also closely related to S. leptorhynchus (Fritzsche 1980).
The Order for this Family has changed  from Syngnathiformes to Gasterosteiformes (Nelson 2006).

Further DNA data could provide greater detail on whether the southern population is in fact a separate species (in which case the name Syngnathus griseolineatus would be resurrected for that purpose).

Due to the large range of distribution of Syngnathus leptorhynchus, scientists are debating whether there is a single species of Bay Pipefish or several subspecies. Genetic evidence suggests that the southern population has been separated (with a biogeographic boundary near Point Conception, CA) from the northern populations for a significant period of time, although there is not enough evidence to conclude that the southern population is a genetically distinct species from the northern populations (Wilson 2006). The northern population ranges from Alaska to Monterey Bay, California, and the southern population from Morro Bay, CA to its southern extent in Baja California, Mexico (Wilson 2006).
The Order for this Family has changed  from Syngnathiformes to Gasterosteiformes (Nelson 2006)
Synonym = Phycodurus glauerti Whitley, 1939.

Kuiter (2000) regarded the Indonesian and Western Australian forms of S. lettiensis to be separate species. According to his taxonomy, the Indonesian form retains the original name Solegnathus lettiensis Bleeker, 1860 (the type was from Indonesia), and the Western Australian form should be classified as Solegnathus guentheri Duncker, 1915. Pogonoski et al. (2002) treated the two forms as one species, citing that the only difference described by Kuiter (2000) was colour pattern. The two forms are treated here as one species.

Preliminary investigations into the taxonomy of this species suggest that the true Solegnathus hardwickii is restricted to the South China Sea and Japan (the type specimen is from China). It has been suggested that there may be two undescribed species, one distributed on the east coast and the other on the west coast of Australia (Kuiter 2000). Until the taxonomy is resolved, we have treated Solegnathus hardwickii as one species which occurs in all the areas mentioned below.

Various authors ascribe the name Dunckerocampus to either a separate genus (Kuiter 2000, 2009) or as a subgenus of Doryrhamphus (Dawson 1985). Dunckerocampus is treated here as a separate genus.

Dunckerocampus naia is likely a synonym of D. dactyliophorus. The species was described as different based on the colour pattern on the caudal fin, with very little in the way of morphological comparisons between the two (Allen and Kuiter 2004). Further morphological and molecular work are needed in order to clarify the taxonomic status of this species, but until further analyses are undertaken the species is treated as valid.
This species is easily confused with Pseudocaranx georgianus and P. dentex (Smith-Vaniz and Jelks 2006).
The genus of Decapterus koheru is under revision (Smith-Vaniz 2015).
This species can be easily confused with Pseudocaranx georgianus (Smith-Vaniz 2008).
The taxonomy of this species has recently been clarified by (Kimura et al. 2013).
This species has been referred to as Decapterus kurroides in the past (Kimura et al. 2013).
This species has been misidentified as Pseudocaranx dentex in the past (Dyer and Westneat 2010).
Saurida flamma was separated from S. gracilis on the basis of morphological characters (Waples 1981).
This species is often wrongly identified as Saurida gracilis (Russell 1999). Therefore, the exact distribution of this species requires confirmation.

This species has been misidentified by most recent authors as Synodus variegatus (Randall 2005). The type locality of this species is Hawaii, but it has been widely reported throughout the Indo-West Pacific. Therefore, the exact distribution of this species needs to be verified. Synodus amaranthus, described by Waples and Randall (1988), is now considered a junior synonym of S. dermatogenys (Randall 2007).

This species has been widely mis-identified in the literature. Two paratypes of S. doaki taken by trawl off coast of Kenya are missing from the Smithsonian fish collection and presumed lost, but it is likely that these specimens are S. randalli (Randall 2009).The specimen identified as S. doaki from the Red Sea by Baranes and Golani (1993) was re-identified as S. randalli (Randall 2009). The specimens recorded from Easter Island by Randall (2005) were determined to represent a new species, S. isolatus (Randall 2009) and those reported from Hawaii by Waples and Randall (1988), Mundy (2005), and Randall (2007) were determined to represent a new species, S. mundyi (Randall 2009).
Synodus janus, described by Waples and Randall (1988) from a single specimen collected from Hawai'i Island, is likely a synonym of S. falcatus (Randall 2007).
Synodus hoshinonis is part of a species complex, which includes S. tectus, S. similis and S. indicus, and may have been misidentified.
Records of Synodus lobeli from Taiwan and southern Japan were based on another species, S. orientalis (Randall and Pyle 2008).
This species has been previously confused with S. macrops (Cressey 1981). The replacement name S. cresseyi proposed by Prokofiev (2008) for S. macrocephalis is invalid (Ho et al. 2010).
This species was recently separated from Synodus doaki and described as a valid species known only from the Hawaiian Islands (Randall 2009).
This species has previously been confused with Synodus hoshinonis, but was regarded as distinct by Cressey (1981).

The name Synodus variegatus was wrongly used for nearly two centuries by many authors (Randall 2007). This species has been confused with S. dermatogenys and S. ulae (Waples and Randall 1988). Cressey (1981) considered S. dermatogenys to be a synonym of S. variegatus, but Waples and Randall (1988) regarded both of these species as distinct.
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).
Emblemariopsis carib was recently described as a distinct species from Emblemariopsis signifer (Victor 2010).

Starksia springeri has been recently described. It was originally known as S. atlantica, now shown to be a species complex comprised of S. atlantica, (known from Bahamas and Turks and Caicos), S. sangreyae (Belize) and S. springeri (Curacao) (Baldwin et al. 2011).

Starksia williamsi has been only recently described. It was previously known as S. lepicoelia, now known to be a species complex comprised of: S. lepicoelia (known from Bahamas and Turks and Caicos), S. weigti (Belize),  S. williamsi (Saba Bank, Netherland Antilles), and S. robertsoni (Panama) (Baldwin et al. 2011).

Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). This species was recently split from E. boehlkei (Victor 2013). Enneanectes flavus replaces E. matador in Venezuela, Aruba, Bonaire, Curacao, Tobago and up to St. Vincent, and both species occur at St. Vincent (Victor 2019).
Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014).This species was recently split from E. boehlkei (Victor 2013).

This species was previously in the genus Antennarius until Pietsch and Arnold (2020) resurrected the genus Abantennarius. It was considered a junior synonym of Abantennarius coccineus in the past but is now accepted as a separate valid species (Pietsch and Arnold 2020).
This species was previously in the genus Antennarius until Pietsch and Arnold (2020) resurrected the genus Abantennarius.
This species was previously in the genus Antennatus until Pietsch and Arnold (2020) resurrected the genus Abantennarius.
This species was described from the Halieutichthys aculeatus species complex (Ho et al. 2010).

The H. rondeletii superspecies complex of the subgenus Danichthys is now recognized as containing four allopatric species: H. volador (western Atlantic), H. rondeletii (Mediterranean), H. gilberti (northern Pacific), and H. rufipinnis (Southern Hemisphere). The other two species, Hirundichthys marginatus (eastern tropical Pacific) and H. albimaculatus (west & central Pacific) are both distinct species in the subgenus, but are not part of the rondeletii superspecies complex (Parin and Belyanina 2002).

The generic assignment of the new species to Liopropoma is tentative pending the results of an extensive genetic and morphological study of the Serranidae family currently in progress (Baldwin and Johnson 2014).

The generic assignment of the new species to Liopropoma is tentative pending the results of an extensive genetic and morphological study of the Serranidae family currently in progress (Baldwin and Johnson 2014).
Ongoing genetic studies indicate that populations from Brazil and the Caribbean represent two different species (Smith-Vaniz and Jelks 2014, Rocha et al. in prep).
This species was recently described as distinct from the very similar E. evelynae and E. genie based on results from DNA barcoding (Victor 2014).
This species was recently described based on results from DNA barcoding (Victor 2014) and resembles T. multifasciatus.

This species was recently described based on results from DNA barcoding. It had been considered to be conspecific with E. horsti and also closely resembles E. louisae (a sympatric species) in appearance (Victor 2014).
It is unclear if the species belongs to the genus Arenigobius, Amoya or Acentrogobius (H.K. Larson and D.F. Hoese pers. comm. 2015).  It is a good (valid) species.
This species may be a synonym of Gobiodon heterospilos (Shibukawa et al. 2013).
This species may belong in a separate genus, Amblygobius.
This species may belong in the genus Amblygobius (H. Larson pers. comm. 2016).
This species has been confused with Oxyurichthys nuchalis in east Africa.

The single specimen from Shark Bay differs in a some features including color differences noted above and in having cycloid scales on the nape and operculum. Counts agree with other specimens of the species. The specimens may represent a separate species and are not included in the type series (Hoese and Larson 2010).
Aetomylaeus caerulofasciatus has recently been described as distinct from the wider-ranging Indo-West Pacific A. nichofii (White et al. 2015).

This species is poorly represented in collections. The lack of specimens has caused some nomenclatural problems that have not been fully resolved. Older scientific names may apply to earlier growth stages of this species.

This species can be confused with other Amblyraja species with different distributions, such as Amblyraja georgiana (M. Stehmann pers. comm). In the northwest Atlantic, it is easily confused with Jensen' s skate (A. jenseni). Refer to Bigelow and Shroeder (1953), Jensen (1948) and Stehman and Burkel (1984).

Last and Stevens (2009) suggest that there are subtle shape differences between populations in the southwest of Western Australia compared to those in the northwest of Western Australia (the Pilbara region). They also suggest that habitat differences exist, with those in the north being found found well offshore, while those in the south are found near the shore. This warrants further investigation.
Originally placed under genus Halaelurus and subgenus Bythaelurus. Bythaelurus has now been elevated to generic level.

Carcharhinus dussumieri is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).

Carcharhinus sealei is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).

White, Ebert, and Compagno (2008) described the Western Gulper Shark (Centrophorus westraliensis) in 2008, as it previously had been considered to be synonymous with Centrophorous harrissoni McCulloch, 1915.

The Reticulate Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium hiscosellum) was considered by Last and Stevens (1994) to be conspecific with C. fasciatum Chan, 1966. White and Ebert (2008), however, described it as a distinct species, which is endemic to northwestern Australia.

The Flagtail Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium signourum) was described by Last et al. (2008) and was previously referred to in part as Cephaloscyllium sp. E in Last and Stevens (1994). In that volume, this species was thought to also occur off northwestern Australia, but that form has since been described as Cephaloscyllium speccum Last, Séret & White, 2008. As such, C. signourum is restricted to the Western Central Pacific and is known from certainty only off Queensland, Australia. Similar forms from New Caledonia, Vanuatu and Fiji need to be critically compared with the Australian specimens in order to determine their identity (Last et al. 2008).

The two undescribed species referred to in Last and Stevens (1994) as Cephaloscyllium sp. B and Cephaloscyllium sp. C are considered to be the same species by Last and White (2008) and Last and Stevens (2009), and were described as the Saddled Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium variegatum) by Last and White (2008). However, Last and Stevens (2009) note that the lumping of the tropical and temperate forms of the species (Cephaloscyllium sp. B and Cephaloscyllium sp. C, respectively) is provisional. Their relationship still requires some examination.

In the past, the Whitefin Chimaera (Chimaera argiloba) has been confused with the northern Pacific Silver Chimaera (Chimaera phantasma), however the Whitefin Chimaera differs in some morphological traits and lacks the dark stripes that characterise the Silver Chimaera (Last et al. 2008).

Confusion between this species and the Shortspine Chimaera (Chimaera obscura) has existed in the past, however the two species differ in some morphological traits; C. fulva is notably lighter in colour compared to C. obscura, and the two are genetically distinct (Didier et al. 2008).

Although only recently described (in 2002) this species has long been known to occur on deep-water slopes and fishing grounds around New Zealand and Tasmania (Paulin et al. 1989, Hardy 1990, Last and Stevens 1994).
The Southern African Frilled Shark C. africana Ebert & Compagno, 2009 is distinct from C. anguineus.

Previously this taxon was considered to be conspecific with Cirrhigaleus barbifer from the Northwest and Western Central Pacific. Further clarification of the taxonomic relationship between the two species is required.
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
A taxonomic review of this group is required to properly identify the species of this genus.
A taxonomic review of this group is required to properly identify the species of this genus.

The Pygmy Thornback Skate (Dentiraja flindersi) was first identified as Raja sp. M in Last and Stevens (1994) and is one of the smallest hard-nose skates. It appears to have been confused with other skate species and is a small relative of the Thornback Skate (D. lemprieri). The Pygmy Thornback Skate differs from the Thornback Skate by having an extremely broad interorbital space, nuchal thorns widely separated, and plain colour with fine white spots (Last and Stevens 2009). Some confusion remains with specimens collected from the inner continental shelf off Albany (southwestern Australia), which are most likely to be of a different species (Last and Stevens 2009).

Together with the closely related Pygmy Thornback Skate Dentiraja flindersi, D. lemprieri differs from other Australian skates in having a prominent blackish patch on the undersurface of the snout tip.
The Deepwater Skate (Dipturus acrobelus) was previously misidentified as Bight Skate Raja gudgeri (Last et al. 1983).
Last et al. (2016a) reassigned Dipturus australis to the resurrected and elevated genus Dentiraja.
Last et al. (2016a) reassigned Dipturus cerva to the resurrected and elevated genera Dentiraja.
Last et al. (2016a) reassigned Dipturus endeavouri to the resurrected and elevated genera Dentiraja.

The False Argus Skate (Dipturus falloargus) is a short-nosed Dipturus species which differs from the Ocellate Skate (Dipturus oculus) in morphometrics and the lack of a well-developed ocellus on each pectoral fin, and differs from all other Dipturus spp. in body shape and colouration (Last 2008).
This species is often confused with other long-nosed skates.

The Blacktip Skate (Dipturus melanospilus) is a recently described species that is easily confused with other Australian members of the genus Dipturus, including the Pale Tropical Skate (Dipturus apricus) and Queensland Deepwater Skate (Dipturus queenslandicus) (Last and Stevens 2009).

Last (2008) considered the previously wider-ranging Dipturus polyommata (Ogilby, 1910) to consist of two species, the southern form was described as Dipturus endeavouri Last, 2008 and the northern form (that considered here) is the Argus Skate (D. polyommata). Last (2008) outlines in detail the justification for this taxonomic change and explains nomenclature.

Last and Yearsley (2002) discussed the generic placement of Australasian rajin skates. Six long-snout species were considered to conform closely with non-Australian members of the genus Dipturus. This group consists of the Bight Skate (Dipturus gudgeri), Heald's Skate (Dipturus healdi), Graham's Skate (Dipturus grahami), the Blacktip Skate (Dipturus melanospilus), Pale Tropical Skate (Dipturus acrobelus) and the Queensland Deepwater Skate (Dipturus queenslandicus). The Queensland Deepwater Skate is a problematic skate possibly involving two similar species. Unusual among Australian Dipturus skates in having the characteristic nuchal thorn either present or absent (usually present but it is easily removed). Individuals lacking a nuchal thorn can be confused with the Blacktip Skate. More specimens are required (Last and Stevens 2009).

Weng’s Skate (Dipturus wengi) appears to belong to a complex of closely related skate species that differ only slightly in their morphology (Last and Stevens 2009). Records of this species from off Indonesia and the Philippines are likely a different species.

The Sculpted Lanternshark Etmopterus sp. from Namibia and South Africa, has been referred to as E. cf. brachyurus, but is probably not conspecific with true E. brachyurus from the western Pacific (Ebert et al. 2013). This species is often confused with E. molleri and E. lucifer.
A poorly known species which is often misidentified. A similar species reported from the Western Indian Ocean may in fact represent a different species.
The taxonomy of Etmopterus unicolor remains unresolved (see Straube et al. 2011). Records from South Africa refer to E. compagnoi (Ebert et al. 2013).

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).

Glaucostegus microphthalamus is currently considered a synonym of G. typus (W.T. White and D.A. Ebert pers. comm. 2016).
Glyphis garricki is sympatric with G. glyphis in northern Australian and southern New Papua Guinea, but the two are separable externally by colouration (Compagno et al. 2008).
Glyphis glyphis is sympatric with G. garricki in northern Australian and southern New Papua Guinea but the two are separable externally by colouration (Compagno et al. 2008).

The Australian Butterfly Ray has two distinct morphological variants which are principally separated by the presence or absence of a small dorsal fin (Jacobsen and Bennett 2009). Dorsal surface colouration can vary in this species from a uniform light green to a dark olive or grey-green and is highly dependent on the surrounding environment.
Previously this species was considered to be conspecific with H. boesemani but its taxonomy was recently resolved (White et al. 2007).

Hemigaleus australiensis is described as having substantially lower vertebral counts, much higher tooth counts in lower jaw, and a black-tipped second dorsal fin, separating it from Hemigaleus microstoma (White et al. 2005).

The taxonomic concept for Hexanchus nakamurai has been revised and Hexanchus vitulus has now been resurrected to a separate species that occurs in the Western Central Atlantic Ocean (Belize, Gulf of Mexico, and Bahamas) (Daly-Engel et al. 2019).

Several species of sixgill stingrays have been named from the Western Pacific; H. longirostris, H. yangi, H. taiwanensis and H. brievirostra, mainly on snout length and shape. However, these forms may be based on variation with growth and state of preservation. The current opinion of the occurrence of a single species of sixgill stingray, H. bickelli based on morphological comparisons, should be confirmed by genetic analyses.

The Leopard Whipray (Himantura leoparda) is a recently described (2008) species closely related and similar in shape and dorsal disc pattern to the Reticulate Whipray (H. uarnak) and Honeycomb Whipray (H. undulata). These three species are in the ‘uarnak’ species-complex, a subgroup of mainly reticulated, ocellated or spotted whiprays. The Leopard Whipray can be distinguished by its unique arrangement of midscapular denticles and the leopard-like markings on the dorsal surface of adults and large specimens. Juveniles of the three species are born at different sizes and vary slightly in colour patterns and denticle shapes (Manjaji-Matsumoto and Last 2008, Last and Stevens 2009). Taxonomic work is currently ongoing to more clearly define the sister species relationships (P. Last pers. comm. 2010).

Previously, this species has been misidentified as Dasyatis uarnak: Wallace 1967; Himantura fava: Compagno and Roberts 1982; Himantura sp. 1: Gloerfelt-Tarp and Kailola 1984; Himantura uarnak: Compagno 1986, Compagno et al. 1989; and Himantura undulata: Last and Stevens 1994, Last and Compagno 1999, White et al. 2006.

The Black Ghostshark (Hydrolagus homonycteris) is probably closely related to Abyssal Ghostshark (H. trolli), but the two differ in that the Black Ghostshark has a longer dorsal spine, smaller claspers and is darker in colour.

The Marbled Ghostshark differs from other species within the genus Hydrolagus through several morphological characteristics, by being lighter in colour and possessing a distinctive reticulated pattern (Didier 2008). Tissue samples for molecular sequencing have not been obtained to genetically distinguish the Marbled Ghostshark from other species (Didier 2008).
Insentiraja laxipella could be generically distinct. Unique among Australian skates, in lacking dorsal fins.

Shape differences are evident between populations across its range and need further investigation (Last and Compagno 1998). There is a need to ascertain if this species is conspecific with the population in the type locality (i.e., the Philippines).

The Western Spotted Gummy Shark (Mustelus stevensi) was recently described by White and Last (2008). It appeared in Last and Stevens (1994) as the undescribed Mustelus sp. nov. B, which was reported to occur both off western and eastern Australia. However, White and Last (2008) described the western form as M. stevensi, and the eastern form as M. walkeri.

The Eastern Spotted Gummy Shark (Mustelus walkeri) was recently described by White and Last (2008). It appeared in Last and Stevens (1994) as the undescribed Mustelus sp. nov. B, which was reported to occur both off western and eastern Australia. However, White and Last (2008) described the western form as M. stevensi, and the eastern form as M. walkeri.

Previously considered to be restricted to Australia. A recent taxonomic study by White et al. (2015) provided a redescription of the Purple Eagle Ray and the Japanese Eagle Ray (M. tobijei). The results of that study showed that previous records of the Japanese Eagle Ray from Indonesia, the Philippines, Taiwan and Okinawa in Japan actually refer to the Purple Eagle Ray. The Japanese Eagle Ray if confined to the western North Pacific, primarily in Japan. Thus, the Purple Eagle Ray's distribution is now extended from Australia north to Taiwan and southern Japan.

The Ornate Numbfish (Narcine ornata) is a recently described species of numbfish (Carvalho 2008). It has previously been confused with Banded Numbfish (Narcine westraliensis) that is found further south in Western Australia outside the range of this species (Last and Stevens 2009).

The Painted Maskray (Neotrygon leylandi) was formerly Dasyatis leylandi until resurrection of the genus Neotrygon by Last and White (2008). The Painted Maskray was previously considered to be more wide-ranging off northern Australia, before the eastern form was recently (2008) described as a new species, the Speckled Maskray (N. picta).

There is uncertainty about the identification of some specimens referred to as the Ningaloo Maskray (Neotrygon ningalooensis). Those from Shark Bay (Western Australia) and Gove (Northern Territory) need to be further validated as being the same species. There is some evidence that the Shark Bay population could represent an additional species (W.T. White unpubl. data 2010), which may affect the assessment of this species, as the restricted geographic range could become more of an issue with any threats.

The Speckled Maskray (Neotrygon picta) was thought to be a regional colour variant of Neotrygon (formerly Dasyatis) leylandi (Last, 1987) until described as a new species by Last and White (2008). The latter publication also resurrected the genus Neotrygon for the maskray species, Bluespotted Maskray (N. kuhlii), Painted Maskray (N. leylandi), Plain Maskray (N. annotata), Ningaloo Maskray (N. ningalooensis) and the Speckled Maskray.

The Blue Skate (Notoraja azurea) is a recently described species of Notoraja first recognized as distinct by Last and Stevens (1994). There is some regional variation in color pattern and meristics of this species that could result in separate species being described (Last and Stevens 2009).
Closely related to Notoraja subtilispinosa but distinct in many ways.
Four Notoraja species were previously identified by Last and Stevens (1994) but remained undescribed until recently (McEachran and Last 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).

The Arafura Skate (Okamajei arafurensis) is a recently described species (Last and Gledhill 2008), not previously recognised. It is a new skate of the Indo–Pacific genus Okamejei. The species is morphologically similar to theYellow-spotted Skate (O. hollandi) from the western North Pacific and is also superficially similar to some Australian short-snout Dipturus species (Last and Gledhill 2008).

Orectolobus halei was previously synonymized with O. ornatus and was believed to be the adult form of O. ornatus. Taxonomic revision of New South Wales species showed that O. halei differs from O. ornatus in colour pattern (O. halei has black edges around saddles and is less freckled), an adult size larger than 120 cm total length, more dermal lobes at the posterior preorbital group (4–6), precaudal vertebrae count (>106), spiral valve count (>25), and two supraorbital knob. Morphometrically, O. halei has a shorter pelvic fin to anal fin interspace, larger pectoral fins, larger head dimensions, and relatively larger claspers in mature specimens (Huveneers 2006).

Orectolobus halei is also often confused with O. maculatus but differs with less dermal lobes at the posterior preorbital group (4-6) and a distinctive brownish upper body colouration with well-defined, darker brown saddles surrounded by black edges, and containing paler markings that lacks whitish rings and blotches (unlike O. maculatus) (Huveneers 2006).
As Orectolobus sp. nov. A, this was given a DISCARDED flag because is was an undescribed species assessed as LC; therefore it did not appear on the published Red List until 2009.

In New South Wales, O. maculatus is often confused with O. halei, but differs from O. halei by having more (6-10 dermal lobes at the posterior preorbital group) and saddles containing whitish rings and blotches (unlike O. halei).

In Western Australia, O. maculatus was previously synonymised with O. parvimaculatus. Taxonomic revision of Western Australian species showed that O. maculatus differs from O. parvimaculatus by having have relatively smaller and less densely distributed ocelli and dorsal fins lacking dark markings (blackish marginal blotches present in O. parvimaculatus). The dorsal fins of O. maculatus are also smaller and less upright than those of O. parvimaculatus (Last and Chidlow 2008).
Records from Japan and the South China Sea are likely to be mis-identified O. japonicus or another undescribed species.

Orectolobus ornatus was previously synonimised with O. halei and was believed to be the juvenile form of O. halei. Taxonomic revision of New South Wales species showed that O. ornatus differs from O. halei in color pattern (more freckled in O. ornatus), an adult size smaller than 120 cm TL, fewer dermal lobes at the posterior preorbital group (3-4), precaudal vertebrae count (<106), spiral valve count (<25), and the absence of supraorbital knob. Morphometrically, O. ornatus has a longer pelvic fin to anal fin interspace, smaller pectoral fins, smaller head dimensions, and relatively smaller claspers in mature specimens (Huveneers 2006).

Assessment is complicated by taxonomic uncertainties based on the identification of the Papua New Guinea specimen. This species should at present be considered as an Australian endemic (L.J.V. Compagno, pers. comm.).

Orectolobus parvimaculatus has been confused in the literature with the larger O. maculatus (e.g., Compagno 1984, 2001, Last and Stevens 1994, Compagno et al. 2005, Hoese et al. 2006, Last and Chidlow 2008) and was believed to be juvenile O. maculatus. Taxonomic revision of Western Australian species showed that O. parvimaculatus differs from O. maculatus by having have relatively larger and more densely distributed ocelli, and dorsal fins with blackish marginal blotches (absent in O. maculatus). The dorsal fins of O. parvimaculatus are also taller and more upright than those of equivalent size O. maculatus (Last and Chidlow 2008).

The Network Wobbegong (Orectolobus reticulatus) was previously misidentified as the Northern Wobbegong (O. wardi) (Whitley 1939). Both species belong to a subgroup of small, morphologically similar wobbegongs, termed the ‘wardi-complex’. This species-complex contains at least three colour forms. All forms attain less than 100 cm total length and possess simple dermal lobes. Differences in colouration was initially thought to be intraspecific variation, however recent comparison of multiple specimens has shown that the forms differ consistently in colour, pattern and some morphological features. Further taxonomic and genetic research is required to elucidate the true number of species in the ‘wardi-complex’, their distributions and conservation status, but has not yet been possible due to the small number of specimens available for comparison. At this stage, the complex is considered to consist of the Northern Wobbegong, the Network Wobbegong and one (or more) potentially undescribed species (Last et al. 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).

The Northern Wobbegong (Orectolobus wardi) belongs to a subgroup of small, morphologically similar wobbegongs, termed the ‘wardi-complex’. This species complex contains at least three colour forms. All forms attain less than 100 cm total length and possess simple dermal lobes. Differences in colouration was initially thought to be intraspecific variation, however recent comparison of multiple specimens has shown that the forms differ consistently in colour, pattern and some morphological features. Further taxonomic and genetic research is required to elucidate the true number of species in the ‘wardi-complex’, their distributions and conservation status, but has not yet been possible due to the small number of specimens available for comparison. At this stage, the complex is considered to consist of the Northern Wobbegong, the Network Wobbegong (O. reticulatus) and one (or more) potentially undescribed species (Last et al. 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).

The genus Parascyllium was considered to comprise of four valid species. Last and Stevens (2008) described a fifth species – Elongate Carpetshark (Parascyllium elongatum) – characterised by a very short head, no dark collar in gill region and vertical rows of white spots on the body. It was described from a single specimen collected from the stomach of a School Shark (Galeorhinus galeus) in 1990.

This species is distinct in shape from all other stingarees, resulting in its placement in the separate monospecific family, Plesiobatidae. There has never been a comparison of populations of this species, which needs to be undertaken to elucidate whether there is in fact more than one species.

The Dwarf Sawfish (Pristis clavata) is similar to the Smalltooth Sawfish (Pristis pectinata), with which it may have been previously confused, but it has fewer rostral teeth than the Smalltooth Sawfish (Last and Stevens 2009).
Scymnodon plunketi may be a junior synonym of Scymnodon macracanthus (Regan 1906) (White et al. 2015). Taxonomic clarification is required.
There are two sympatric forms of this species which differ in colour pattern; the relationship between these forms requires study (Last and Stevens 2009).

Colour variation has been noted in this species with specimens from the northwest Pacific (Japan) noticeably darker in overall colour than those from the southwest Pacific (New Zealand) (Didier and Nakaya 1999). The distinction between R. atlantica and R. pacifica is problematic and solely based on the number of caudal tubercles, a highly variable and often overlapping characteristic (tends to be greater in R. atlantica). Resolution on the distinction of these two species will require examination of larger series of specimens and potentially molecular data (Compagno et al. 1990).
This ray is considered by some authors to be identical to the wide-ranging Javanese Cownose Ray (Rhinoptera javanica). Further systematic studies are required.
Molecular evidence supports the idea that Rhizoprionodon acutus is a complex of (at least) four species that needs further taxonomic investigation (Naylor et al. 2012).

Rhynchobatus australiae is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.

The Western Legskate (Sinobatis bulbicauda) was recently described by Last and Séret (2008). In the species description Last and Séret (2008) elevated Sinobatis to the rank of genus on the basis of the conservative intragroup clasper morphology of its member species, and its strong differentiation from Hulley’s (1973) other subgenera Anacanthobatis.

The medium-sized Western Legskate has affinities to the slightly smaller species the Borneo Legskate (S. borneensis) (South and East China Seas). Based on its description of the adult male holotype, S. borneensis has a filamentous (vs. bulbous) tail and the snout is relatively longer with preorbital length 6.5 times the interorbital length (vs. 3.9–4.8 in adult males and 3.4–5.7 in all types of S. bulbicauda) (Last and Séret 2008). Additionally, adult males of the two species are not identical in size, S. borneensis, 31.7 cm total length (TL) (vs. 42.9–43.3 cm TL in S. bulbicauda) and also differ in many morphometric characteristics including their relative disc widths, precloacal lengths, preoral lengths, orbit diameters, mouth width, and intergill distances which will aid in differentiating the two species (see Last and Séret 2008 for measurement ranges).

The Blue Legskate (Sinobatis caerulea) was recently described by Last and Séret (2008) from five specimens. Last and Séret (2008) elevated Sinobatis to the rank of genus on the basis of the conservative intragroup clasper morphology of its member species, and its strong differentiation from Hulley’s (1973) other subgenera of Anacanthobatis. This species has been provisionally placed into the genus Sinobatis in the absence of an adult male specimen.  It may have been confused in the past with the smaller Western Legskate (S. bulbicauda).

Revision of Squalus in the Indo-Australasian region resulted in the resurrection of S. montalbani (Philippines, Indonesia, Australia) and S. griffini (New Zealand) and the description of S. chloroculus Last, White & Motomura, 2007. These species were previously considered to be conspecific with S. mitsukurii, which this work has revealed, does not occur in Australasian waters. Continued investigation of Squalus mitsukurii from around the world is resulting in more taxa being recognized.

Previously this species was included in Squalus sp. C. (= S. altipinnis) (Last and Stevens 1994). It was referred to as Squalus sp. C in Compagno et al. (2005) and as Squalus cf. sp. C in White et al. (2006).

The name Squalus megalops has been used widely for what represents a species-complex, with the true S. megalops endemic to Australia. Squalus acutipinnis has recently been resurrected as a distinct species (Viana and Carvalho 2016), and S. mahia and S. margaretsmithae have been described as new species (Viana et al. 2018).

Squalus montalbani was previously considered a likely junior synonym of S. mitsukurii but was resurrected as a valid species by Last et al. (2007). Referred to as Squalus sp. 1 in White et al. (2006a).
Formerly, U. asperrimus was the only species within Urogymmus. Last et al. (2016) added five more species to the genus.

The Banded Stingaree is morphologically similar to the Yellowback Stingaree (Urolophus sufflavus) and genetics are nearly identical; further investigation is required to confirm that these are separate species (Last et al. 2016).
Further investigation is required to confirm the species' Pacific distribution (Last et al. 2016).
Appears to hybridize with the Banded Stingaree (Urolophus cruciatis) at the southern end of its range. Further information is required to assess the validity of this species (Last et al. 2016).

Previously considered to be a junior synonym of the Common Stingray (Dasyatis pastinaca), this species differs in disc shape, shape of the dorsal skin fold, and form and number of oral papillae (Last et al. 2016b).

The Flapper Skate (Dipturus intermedius) and Common Blue Skate (Dipturus batis) were synonymised in a taxonomic revision of European skates (Rajidae) in the 1920s (Clark 1926), before being recognised again as separate species in 2010 (Iglésias et al. 2010). Consequently, information for both species were reported as ‘Dipturus batis’ (the 'common skate complex') for much of the 20th and early 21st centuries.
This and the other two species in the genus Centrolabrus were moved to the genus Symphodus, based on morphological and behavioural evidence (Almada et al. 2002).
This and the other two species in the genus Centrolabrus were moved to the genus Symphodus, based on morphological and behavioural evidence (Almada et al. 2002).
This species' eastern Pacific distribution is now known as R. samoensis.

According to Larson (in press; WIO book), the Indian Ocean species, Gunnellichthys copleyi, may be synonymous with Gunnellichthys pleurotaenia. More research is needed on the taxonomy of this species.

The western Indian Ocean populations of this species have been recently recognized as a distinct species, Nemateleotris exquisita (Randall and Connell 2013). However, the status of this species requires further taxonomic study.
The distribution remains in question until further studies have been completed within the Eviota nigriventris complex.

The Indian Ocean subpopulation was recognized as a subspecies, Ptereleotris grammica melanota (Randall and Lubbock 1982). The taxonomic status of this subpopulation needs further investigation given its disjunct distribution from other populations identified as Ptereleotris grammica grammica.
This species varies in colour with locality and BOLD molecular data suggest that it comprises a species complex (Randall 2008, BOLD online database accessed May 2022).
