Acanthoplesiops indicus, is sister to two allopatric West Pacific species, A. psilogaster to the north (Japan, Taiwan, Batanes) and A. echinatus to the south (southern Philippines and Moluccas) (Mooi and Gill 2004).
Pristigenys refulgens was recently resurrected from synonymy with P. niphonia (Iwatsuki et al. 2012).
C. unicolor may be a synonym of C. longimanus.
The Hawaiian Islands and Johnston Atoll populations are morphologicallydistinct from western Pacific populations (Mundy 2005).
This species is sometimes placed in the monotypic genus Zalanthias (FishBase).
This binomial was recently resurrected from the synonymy of P. squamipinnis and P. fasciatus is a junior synonym of P. gibbosus (Heemstra and Akhilesh 2012)
Records from the Maldives and Mascarene Islands are now recognized as P. unimarginatus.

Randall et al. (2002) restricted the name Pseudogramma australis to the individuals found at Easter Island, and provided a replacement name for the individuals previously identified as P. australis in the western Pacific Ocean (Pseudogramma xantha). Therefore, the specimens reported as P. australis in FishNet2 are regarded as P. xantha (accessed through the FishNet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.net, 14/06/2016).

The Pseudogramma polyacantha species complex was recently split into four valid species: P. polyacantha, occurring from French Polynesia to South Africa; P. brederi from Hawaii to Mauritius; and P. galzini and P. paucilepis, both known only from French Polynesia (Williams and Viviani 2016).

Randall et al. (2002) restricted the name Pseudogramma australis to the individuals found at Easter Island, and provided a replacement name for the individuals previously identified as P. australis in the western Pacific Ocean (Pseudogramma xantha). Therefore, the specimens reported as P. australis in FishNet2 are regarded as P. xantha (accessed through the FishNet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.net, 14/06/2016).
This species may be a synonym of Arnoglossus brunneus (Hensley and Amaoka 2001), but is treated as a valid species until additional evidence is available.
This may be a junior synonym of Bothus leopardinus (Hensley 1995, Grove and Lavenberg 1997); further research is needed to clarify its status.

Most systematists working with flatfishes (Pleuronectiformes) now recognize the Rhombosoleidae as a family (Chapleau and Keast 1988, Chapleau 1993, Guibord 2003, Munroe 2015). 

James (1972) noted significant variation in body proportions for specimens purportedly of Peltorhamphus latus from Blueskin Bay. He considered these differences to represent population variation within the species P. latus. Munroe (2015) examined these and other specimens and found other morphological differences that indicated an undescribed species (Peltorhamphus sp. A) was represented among the specimens from Blueskin Bay. Munroe (2020) provided a formal description of this species, and named it Peltorhamphus kryptostomus.
Most systematists working with flatfishes (Pleuronectiformes) now recognize the Poecilopsettidae as a family (Chapleau and Keast 1988, Chapleau 1993, Guibord 2003, Munroe 2015).

Taxonomic revisions in the genus Aseraggodes have resulted in the assignment of many specimens previously assigned to A. melanostictus to other species. For example, Schultz (1943) recorded  A. melanostictus from the Phoenix Islands, but this has been re-identified as A. whitakeri (Randall and Bartsch 2005); Woods in Schultz et al. (1966) identified a specimen from the Marshall Islands as A. melanostictus, but this has been re-identified as A. heraldi (Randall and Bartsch 2005). Other records of specimens assigned to A. melanostictus are lacking voucher specimens, and thus the correct identifications are unable to be confirmed.

The "true" Cociella crocodila is known only from Japan, China and Taiwan; the records of C. crocodila from the western Indian Ocean should be attributed to C. punctata, C. heemstrai and C. somaliensis (Knapp 1996).
Unpublished data shows that the Indian Ocean and Pacific Ocean populations are genetically distinct (H. Motomura pers. comm. 2015).
There is much taxonomic confusion within the genus Neomerinthe (H. Motomura pers. comm. 2015).
There is much taxonomic confusion within the genus Neomerinthe (H. Motomura pers. comm. 2015).
There is much taxonomic confusion within the genus Neomerinthe (H. Motomura pers. comm. 2015).

Specimens from the western Indian Ocean likely represent true P. mossambica; however, specimens from the central eastern Indian and Pacific Oceans probably apply to P. armata (H. Motomura unpublished data).
This species is often confused with Parascorpaena aurita (Motomura et al. 2009).

Pontinus rhodochrous and Pontinus macrocephalus may represent the same species. Specimens from Japan and Hawaii are referred to as P. macrocephalus, while records from southeast Asia are reported as P. rhodochrous. Further research is needed regarding the validity of these species (H. Motomura pers. comm. 2015). For the purposes of this assessment, and until addition information suggests otherwise, these two species are considered distinct.

Pterois mombasae was recently split into two distinct species: P. mombasae, which occurs exclusively in the Indian Ocean, and P. paucispinula sp. nov., which occurs in the Pacific Ocean (Matsunuma and Motomura 2014).

Scorpaena cardinalis is part of a species complex, including S. jacksoniensis and S. orgila, that was recently redefined (Motomura et al. 2011).  Scorpaena jacksoniensis Steindachner 1866, previously treated as a junior synonym of S. cardinalis Solander and Richardson 1842, is now regarded as valid. Scorpaena cookii Gunther 1874, previously treated as valid, is now regarded as a junior synonyms of S. cardinalis. Australian records of S. cardinalis are S. jacksoniensis. Scorpaena plebeia Solander 1842 is a junior synonym of S. cardinalis. New Zealand records of S. cookii are S. cardinalis (Motomura et al. 2011).

The recent redescription of Scorpaenodes evides (Motomura et al. 2010) recognized at least seven geographic populations, which may represent more than one subspecies. The true S. evides may be restricted to Japan and Taiwan (Motomura et al. 2010).

Sebastes meleagris may be a junior synonym for this species (Poss 1999). Scorpaenodes guamensis and S. scaber have been recorded widely in the Indo-West Pacific. In the literature, grayish individuals living in rocky reefs are identified as S. guamensis, while the reddish individuals living in coral reefs are identified as S. scaber; however, all individuals are the same species, S. guamensis (H. Motomura unpublished data).

Scorpaenodes guamensis and S. scaber have been recorded widely in the Indo-West Pacific. In the literature, greyish individuals living in rocky reefs are identified as S. guamensis, while the reddish individuals living in coral reefs are identified as S. scaber; however, all individuals are the same species, S. guamensis. The true S. scaber is known only from two type specimens, collected off southeastern Australia (H. Motomura unpubl. data).

This species is commonly confused with Scorpaenodes guamensis or Scorpaenodes littoralis (Poss 1999).

Carcharhinus coatesi is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).

Carcharhinus tjutjot is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).

White (2014) confirmed that Myliobatis australis Macleay, 1881 (from southern Australia) is a junior synonym of M. tenuicaudatus Hector, 1877 (which was previously considered to be endemic to New Zealand).

The Australian form of this species is provisionally identified as Apristurus melanoasper, although it is possible that the North Atlantic and southwestern Pacific forms represent distinct species (Last and Stevens 2009).
Forms provisionally assigned to Apristurus sinensis from Australian waters are genetically distinct and may represent separate species (Last and Stevens 2009).

Two very small juveniles were originally described by Bigelow and Schroeder as H. raleighana. However, it was recognised by Karrer in her 1972 description of H. haeckli, and by others, that some references to H. raleighana from the Canary Islands may actually be referred to H. haeckeli.

Nakayama et al. (2020) reviewed the genus Harriotta and merged H. haeckeli Karrer 1972 as a synonym of H. raleighana.

Synonyms = Hydrolagus sp. C Paulin et al., 1989; Hydrolagus sp. cf lemurs Séret in Grandperrin et al., 1997; Hydrolagus sp. Séret in Grandperrin et al., 1999.

A recently described, highly distinctive species, Hydrolagus trolli is often caught with a species of giant black chimaera (cf. Hydrolagus affinis), and the range of these two species may overlap in some areas, but H. trolli is readily separated by its distinctive blue colouration and more acute snout.

Previously two subspecies of Monochirus were recognized. Currently, Monochirus hispidus is considered endemic to the Mediterranean Sea and Monochirus atlanticus occurs from Portugal south to the Gulf of Guinea (Hoenywell et al. in review, Munroe pers comm. 2013).
This species was previously mis-identified as Eviota pellucida.

The genus Saurida is currently under revision by B.C. Russell. This species has been commonly misidentified as Saurida elongata (Temminck and Schlegel 1846) by most authors, but should be referred to as S. eso Jordan and Herre 1907. Saurida microlepis Wu and Wang 1931 is a synonym of S. eso (B.C. Russell pers. comm. 2019). However, this name change is not yet published, so pending publication the name Saurida elongata is used here.
This species has been confused with Saurida longimanus, and published distributional recoords may be unreliable (B.C. Russell pers. comm. 2019).
Amblygaster leiogaster is commonly misidentified as Amblygaster sirm.
Hybridization has occurred between N. come and N. japonica at Okinawa (Imai et al. 2005, Uehara et al. 2011)

The applicable scientific name for the species historically treated as Encrasicholina devisi is E. heteroloba, and E. devisi is a junior synonym of E. heteroloba. The applicable scientific name for the species historically treated as E. heteroloba is E. psuedoheteroloba (Hata and Motomura 2016).
Previous records of Encrasicholina punctifer in the Indian Ocean are now attributable to E. gloria (Red Sea and Persian Gulf) or E. intermedia (East Africa and India: Hata and Motomura 2016).
This species was placed in the genus Apogon previous to the subdivision of the genera and elevation of the subgenus Jaydia (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species was previously placed in the genus Apogon. After the subdivision of the genera and elevation of Ostorhinchus, the species was placed in Ostorhinchus (Mabuchi et al. 2014).

The Catalog of Fishes online database (accessed March 2022) places this species in the genus Callionymus without justification. The genus Repomucenus is retained here based on published work by Nakabo (2002; 2013), Sonoyama et al. (2020) and Kim et al. (2021). 

This species has also been referred to in the literature as Callionymus richardsoni or Repomucenus richardsonii (Motomura et al. 2010).
According to Hung et al. (2017), Nemipterus marginatus contains cryptic species, and further taxonomic work is needed.

This species has been widely confused with Nemipterus randalli, and records of N. mesoprion from the Western Indian Ocean can be referred to N. randalli. It has also been confused with N. marginatus as well as N. celebicus (Russell 1990, 1991, 2001).
This species has genetically distinct clades in the Indian Ocean and the West Pacific Ocean (Hung et al. 2017).

The taxonomic status of the nominal species Cynoglossus arel and C. macrolepidotus remains uncertain. Menon (1977) and Munroe (2001) consider C. macrolepidotus a junior synonym of C. arel; however, other authors consider both to be valid species (e.g., Li and Wang 1995, Mishra et al. 1999). Cynoglossus macrolepidotus was recently included in the comparative material for the description of C. crepida (Fricke et al. 2017) and it is currently listed as valid in Eschmeyer's Catalog of Fishes (Fricke et al. 2020). Research is needed to clarify the taxonomic status of these two nominal species. For the purposes of this assessment, C. macrolepidotus will be considered to be a valid species.
This species can be easily confused with other Paramonacanthus spp. (Hutchins 1997).

Based on the anatomy of the Azorean Ovatella, all records of Ovatella from the Azores are O. vulcani. Hence all former reports of O. aequalis from the Azores must be treated as O. vulcani (A.M. de Frias Martins pers. comm. 2017).

This small to medium-sized species (to 109 mm) has two subspecies: Haliotis diversicolor diversicolor and H. d. squamata (Geiger and Owen 2012). However, Hsu and Gwo (2017), using molecular markers in their genetic analysis, described four forms:
  1. Haliotis diversicolor diversicolor;
  2. Haliotis diversicolor aquatilis (WoRMS considers this as a misapplication and synonym of the European H. tuberculata tuberculata Linnaeus, 1758);
  3. Haliotis diversicolor supertexta (WoRMS recognises this as the species H. supertexta Lischke, 1870); and
  4. Haliotis diversicolor squamata.
Hsu and Gwo (2017) described the first three forms as a single species, but H. d. squamata as a separate species. There was a wide genetic difference between Japanese and Taiwanese stocks, offering the opportunity for hybridisation to strengthen the genetics of species bred in aquaculture, with a warning of the dangers of releasing hybrid stock into the wild. The classification of the H. diversicolor group, which includes H. d. squamata and H. d. supertexta (H. supertexta), has been discussed on the basis of a limited number of localities and samples, which may lead to taxonomic inconsistencies. Further taxonomic studies of this group will be needed in the future, in particular to corroborate or refute whether H. supertexta is a separate valid species.

In the waters around Japan, both Haliotis diversicolor diversicolor and H. d. supertexta (H. supertexta) are found, but the distribution areas of these subspecies overlap, and the boundaries are not clear. Thus, both subspecies (species) are treated as H. diversicolor in this assessment.

Geiger and Owen (2012) observe that owing to long-term consolidation of this species with H. madaka (previously referred to as ‘Giant Abalone’ but since accepted as a separate species), there are no medium to long term unambiguous data on H. gigantea that are known and that "segregation of the data among those two taxa is impossible after the fact". The common-name species of abalone, Megai-awabi, was previously described as H. sieboldii, but Habe (1983) confirmed that the type specimens of H. gigantea should instead be attributed to Megai-awabi and its name changed to H. gigantea, while that of Madaka-awabi changed to H. madaka from H. gigantea. Haliotis gigantea shares a sympatric distribution with two other abalone, H. madaka and H. d. discus. With regard to the relationship of these three species: “population genomic analyses revealed that although the three species are genetically distinct, there is evidence for historical and ongoing gene flow among these species” (Hirase et al. 2021).
This species has two subspecies: Haliotis jacnensis jacnensis Reeve, 1846 and H. j. kershawi Owen, 2012.

Haliotis madaka was, until recently, considered to be a synonym of H. gigantea, and most ecological and biological data of both species are therefore confused, restricting accurate assessment of bathymetry, habitat, diet etc from the literature (Geiger and Owen 2012).

The scientific name for Madaka-awabi was previously H. gigantea, but Habe (1983) confirmed that the type specimens of H. gigantea were Megai-awabi (H. sieboldii at that time). Therefore, the scientific name of Madaka-awabi changed to H. madaka from H. gigantea, and that of Megai-awabi changed to H. gigantea from H. sieboldii (Habe 1983).  H. madaka shares sympatric distribution with two other abalone, H. gigantea and H. d. discus. In terms of the relationship of these three species: “population genomic analyses revealed that although the three species are genetically distinct, there is evidence for historical and ongoing gene flow among these species” (Hirase et al. 2021).
This species of abalone has two subspecies: Halitois rubra rubra Leach, 1814 (commonly known as Blacklip Abalone), and H. r. conicopora Peron, 1816 (commonly known as Brownlip Abalone).
This species of abalone has two subspecies: Halitois scalaris scalaris Leach, 1814 and Haliotis scalaris emmae Reeve, 1846. H. s. emmae has no synonyms recorded.
Morphological and molecular evidence indicate that Bairdiella ronchus represents a species complex (Marceniuk et al. 2019).

This species is sometimes confused with Cynoscion nothus.

Its taxonomic status as a species distinct from Cynoscion regalis has been questioned since it was described by Ginsburg (1930). In Florida, DNA analysis has shown that it can hybridize with C. nebulosus and C. regalis (Nemeth et al. 2006).
Parascorpaena armata (Sauvage, 1873) was recently resurrected from synonymy with P. mossambica (Peters, 1855) (Motomura et al. 2011, H. Motomura unpublished data).
Parascorpaena moultoni has been regarded as a junior synonym of Parascorpaena mcadamsi, but is confirmed as a distinct species (Motomura et al. 2011).

Pterois mombasae was recently split into two distinct species: P. mombasae, which occurs exclusively in the Indian Ocean, and P. paucispinula sp. nov., which occurs in the Pacific (Matsunuma and Motomura 2014).

This species is valid as Scorpaena pascuensis Eschmeyer and Allen, 1971 in Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer 2015), but was placed in the genus Sebastapistes in a taxonomic revision (Motomura 2014, in Japanese).
Several taxonomic problems remain with the Pseudomonacanthus genus (Matsuura 2015).

Clark and Gohar (1953) described the Red Sea population as subspecies Brachaluteres baueri fahaqa and Hutchins and Swainston (1985) elevated it to a specific level, but still with taxonomic uncertainty due to the lack of specimens (Golani and Bogorodsky 2010).
This species has previously been classified as Cantherhines but is now considered to belong in the genus Thamnaconus (Motomura et al. 2017).
This species is also frequently referred to as 'Nelusetta ayraudi' in the literature (Miller and Stewart 2012).
This species is very similar to, and has even been known to hybridize with Paramonacanthus choirocephalus (Hutchins 1997).
This species has previously been referred to as Laputa cingalensis (Hutchins 2001).
Several taxonomic problems remain with the Pseudomonacanthus genus (Matsuura 2015).
Several taxonomic problems remain with the Pseudomonacanthus genus (Matsuura 2015).
Several taxonomic problems remain with the Pseudomonacanthus genus (Matsuura 2015).
This species can be easily confused with Paramonacanthus pusillus (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004).
The European and North African records of this species are now considered to belong to T. gallica (Villar 2017).
The literature suggests that this species may also occur off the coasts of Ecuador and Peru, but these records are unconfirmed and may have been misidentifications of another species.

The genus Apristurus contains at least 32 described species and a relatively large number of potentially undescribed ones. Morphological conservatism and, until recently, a lack of objectively defined characters makes this one of the most taxonomically confused shark genera (Compagno 1984, Nakaya and Sato 1999).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). The brunneus-group is characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length <6% total length (TL), 0.36 to 0.94 times in interorbital); 13 to 22 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows; a discontinuous supraorbital sensory canal.

Compagno (1984) considered it likely that the specimens and records of A. brunneus from the western North Pacific represent an assemblage of two or more brunneus-like species.

The genus Apristurus contains at least 32 described species and a relatively large number of potentially undescribed ones. Morphological conservatism and, until recently, a lack of objectively defined characters makes this one of the most taxonomically confused shark genera (Compagno 1984, Nakaya and Sato 1999).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus kampae belongs to the spongiceps-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length <6% total length (TL)); 7 to 12 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows subequal to, or shorter than the lower furrows; a continuous supraorbital sensory canal.

The genus Apristurus contains at least 32 described species and a relatively large number of potentially undescribed ones. Morphological conservatism and, until recently, a lack of objectively defined characters makes this one of the most taxonomically confused shark genera (Compagno 1984, Nakaya and Sato 1999).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). The spongiceps-group is characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length <6% TL, 0.36 to 0.94 times in interorbital); 7 to 12 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows subequal to, or shorter than the lower furrows; a continuous supraorbital sensory canal (Nakaya and Sato 1999). A. spongiceps is readily distinguished from its congeners by its unique pleated gills (Compagno 1984).

Shark species within the genus Mustelus are very similar in both appearance and size, making proper identifications challenging. Five species of Mustelus are known to frequent the waters surrounding Baja California. One of these five species, M. albipinnis, was only recently described and has likely been misidentified in the past as other Mustelus spp. (Castro-Aguirre et al. 2005, Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005). Mustelus albipinnis is distinguished from M. californicus by white margins present on its fins and a habitat preference for deeper waters (Castro-Aguirre et al. 2005, Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005, Ebert et al. 2013). Another Baja California smooth-hound, M. lunulatus is considered to be the most similar to M. californicus due to similar colour patterns (grey dorsal colouration with a lighter ventral side). Mustelus lunulatus can be distinguished from M. californicus by its wider set eyes, longer snout and shorter upper labial furrows (Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005, Ebert et al. 2013). Both species, however, have well developed lower caudals and molariform teeth (Ebert et al. 2013). Dentition can be used to distinguish M. californicus from both M. dorsalis and M. henlei which both have sharper high-cusped teeth (Starks 1917, Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005, Ebert et al. 2013). Mustelus henlei can also be differentiated by the dorsal fins, which are frayed at the posterior margins and more anteriorly placed along the body than M. californicus (Starks 1917, Ebert 2003, Ebert et al. 2013).

The Brown Smooth-hound was originally described as Rhinotriacis henlei by Gill in 1863. This name was changed to Triakis henlei and then to the currently valid name Mustelus henlei (Gill 1863).

In the past, misidentification has lead to a lack of information about the basic biology of the Mustelus species in the Gulf of California. A recent taxonomic revision of this group in the Northern Gulf of California and off southwest peninsula of Baja California has identified a fourth smooth-hound species (Castro-Aguirre et al. 2005, Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005).

This species may have been misidentified for other Mustelus spp. in the Gulf of California, including M. californicus. Records of this species from South America refer to another undescribed lunulatus-type Mustelus species. This lunulatus-type Mustelus occurs in the Eastern Pacific to Ecuador and the Galapagos Islands and has likely been recorded as M. lunulatus in South America in the past (see Compagno in prep. for discussion).
There are possible taxonomic problems in tropical latitudes (possible confusion with Zapteryx xyster), which may severely limit the functional range of  Z. exasperata (Ebert 2003).

Bathyraja kincaidii is very similiar morphologically to Bathyraja interrupta and these have been considered to be the same species by some authors. However, Knuckey (2017) clarified that these species are distinct.

This species was first described from the Bering Sea (57°47'N, 173°47'W) by Ishiyama and Ishihara (1977). Subsequent Russian authors have considered this species a junior synonym of Bathyraja matsubarai (Sheiko and Fedorov 2000, Dolganov and Tuponogov 1999, Mecklenburg et al. 2002). However, recent Russian literature (e.g. Grigorov and Orlov 2013), and other authors, have considered B. lindbergi to be a valid species (Compagno 1999, Compagno 2005). Information from Alaska appears to pertain only to B. lindbergi. Bathyraja lindbergi and B. matsubarai are very similar and further taxonomic study is required on both species.

This skate been misidentified as the Roughtail Skate, Bathyraja trachura, but B. microtrachys is clearly a distinct species. Although adult males have not been observed for this species, egg cases have been collected and are distinct from those of other eastern North Pacific skates (D.A. Ebert unpubl. data).

In the Northeast Pacific this species has been misidentified on occasion with the starry skate, Raja stellulata, but these skates are distinctive from each other. Bathyraja parmifera is somewhat common in the Gulf of Alaska, but does not appear to occur south of this area, while R. stellulata does not appear to occur as far north as the Gulf of Alaska. B. parmifera and B. smirnovi have also been considered similar (Dolganov and Tuponogov 1999, Parin 2001) though this seems questionable (Sheiko and Fedorov 2000, H. Ishihara pers. obs.).

B. simoterus is a synonym of B. parmifera (H. Ishihara pers. comm. 2007).
Some authors (Dolganov and Tuponogov 1999) suggest B. trachouros and B. violacea may be synonymous.
This skate is often misidentified with other hardnose skates from the northeast and eastern central Pacific.

First described by Jordan and Gilbert (1880). Gilbert (1915) described Raja montereyensis based on an adult male of this species. However, R. montereyensis was later determined to be a junior synonym of R. stellulata.

Urobatis concentricus, U. halleri, and U. maculatus have sometimes been considered colour variants of a single species, but molecular studies have shown that these are distinct species (Last et al. 2016).

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

The nomenclature of this species is often confused, occasionally resulting in the listing of brevis and dipterurus as separate species. Both Jordan and Gilbert and Garman published descriptions of this species in the same year, 1880. However, Jordan and Gilbert published their account of specimens from San Diego in May 1880, while Garman published his description in October of that year. Garman (1913) subsequently overlooked these facts and inappropriately synonymized dipterurus with brevis. However, Jordan and Gilbert's description has precedence.
Myliobatis californica Gill, 1865 was a misspelling of this species.
Fowler (1910) stated that Chimaera neglecta Ogilby, 1888 is probably a synonym of H. colliei, but it is more likely to be a synonym of H. novaezealandiae (Didier and Rosenberger 2002).

Bathyraja interrupta was first described by Gill and Townsend (1897) from a type specimen from the Bering Sea. It was initially placed into the genus Raia, which has undergone several revisions since. Dolganov (1983) and Compagno (1999) reallocated this species to the genus Rhinoraja. Eschmeyer (2016) considers the genus Rhinoraja valid, but lists this species within Bathyraja. Both scientific names are still in use.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted.
Ishihara et al. (2012) established the new genus Beringraja for the two species B. binoculata  (previously Raja binoculata Girard, 1855) and B. pulchra (previously Raja pulchra Liu 1932).
This species is also known as Microchirus hexophthalmus in certain texts.

Sousa plumbea has been recognized as a species since taxonomic revision of the genus Sousa in 2014 (Committee on Taxonomy 2014, Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014). Previously this species was lumped with the Indo-pacific Humpback Dolphin (Sousa chinensis) but animals occurring in the Indian Ocean from South Africa to India are now recognized as taxonomically distinct from those that occur further east, based on genetics, skeletal morphology, external morphology and colour. There is uncertainty about the taxonomic affinities of the Humpback Dolphins that occur in the Bay of Bengal and future studies will confirm whether S. plumbea actually occurs east of the southern tip of India.

Previous formal taxonomy of this genus recognized the existence of only two species: S. teuszii in the Atlantic Ocean and S. chinensis in the Indo-Pacific Oceans (Committee on Taxonomy-Society for Marine Mammalogy 2009). However, recent morphological and molecular studies have shown the genus is composed of four species including: S. teuszii (Atlantic Ocean), S. plumbea (Indian Ocean), S. chinensis (eastern Indian and western Pacific Oceans) and a newly described species S. sahulensis found in the waters of the Sahul Shelf from northern Australia to southern New Guinea (Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014, Mendez et al. 2013).

The Australian Humpback Dolphin can be visually differentiated from the other species of the genus by the following combination of morphological characters: 1) the body is typically more dark grey in colour, 2) a diagonal cape line running from just above the eye and neck down to the urogenital area separates the dark back and lighter belly, 3) dorsal fin is lower in size, triangular in shape, and has a wide base without a visible dorsal hump and 4) white scarring and dark flecking on the head, back, dorsal fin, and tail stock are common in adult animals (Jefferson & Rosenbaum 2014). Seven diagnostic mtDNA characters and a single nuDNA character distinguish Sousa sahulensis from other species in the genus.
Allen et al. (2010) described Chrysiptera arnazae as a new species, previously misidentified as C. parasema.
Pristigenys refulgens was recently resurrected from synonymy with P. niphonia (Iwatsuki et al. 2012).
Photo records in FishBase from the Marshall Islands identified as Rabaulichthys altipinnis are of a new, undescribed species.

Recent genetic analyses suggested that Plectorhinchus orientalis, often treated as a junior synonym of P. vittatus, should be recognized as a valid species (Liang et al. 2016). However, further work is needed to determine the validity of P. orientalis, and, if valid, to determine the geographic distributions of these two nominal species. For the purposes of this assessment, we are treating P. vittatus as including P. orientalis.
This complex has recently been separated into three species: B. lacertus, B. antilliensis, and B. soporator (Tornabene et al. 2010).

Recent genetic evidence suggests three distinct lineages in the eastern Atlantic that may represent distinct species (Galvan-Quesada et al. 2016, Guiamaes-Costa et al. 2017). Recognition of these lineages at the species level would considerably reduce the range extent of this species, and would likely warrant reassessment.
Eleotris perniger has generally been reported as E. pisonis, but the latter is a continental South American species ranging only from southern Brazil to eastern Venezuela (Pezold and Cage 2002).

Recent genetic evidence suggests potential species level cryptic diversity between Gulf of Mexico and Atlantic coast subpopulations (Milá et al. 2017). Formal description of undescribed species would result in a non-genuine change in distribution and warrant reassessment.

Heemstra and Heemstra (2004) describes the taxonomy of the Mugilidae family as confused and the genera as obscurely defined. 

Misidentification with Mugil gaimardianus, now an invalid species, has caused much confusion in the past.  

Currently, the most frequent misidentication is with Mugil rubrioculus (Harrison et al. 2007). Mugil curema and M. rubrioculus are very similar morphologically. They are clearly separated genetically both by karyotype and molecular analysis (Nirchio et al. 2005, Fraga et al. 2007, Gonzalez-Castro et al. 2009). 

Fraga et al. (2007) identified two species occurring along the Brazilian coast, Mugil curema type I (Mugil rubrioculus) and Mugil curema type II and showed that their distribution overlaps in most of their distribution. Therefore, species identification in landings and ecological studies may confuse the two species in Brazil.
This species was previously thought to be confused with C. mexicanus off Sao Paulo State (Brazil), however, it is now known these two species do not co-occur in this area.

Gonzalez Castro et al. (2008) found morphological and genetic differences between Mugil cephalus from the Mediterranean coast and M. liza/M. platanus from the Southwestern Atlantic coast. According to Fraga et al. (2007), M. liza and M. platanus should be treated as a single species or even subpopulations of M. cephalus. Heras et al. (2009) found that M. platanus and M. liza represent a continuum of a single species that is closely related to but distinct from M. cephalus, which itself appears to comprise a grouping of multiple and closely related species.

According to Menezes et al. (2010), only one species of lebranche mullet exists in the Caribbean Sea region and off the Atlantic coast of South America, with Mugil liza as the appropriate name. Considering the above, M. liza and M. platanus are considered the same species and the adopted name is M. liza. Mugil cephalus does not occur in the Southwestern Atlantic (Menezes et al. 2010).

Forms a geographically disjunct species pair with Alosa alabamae. Meristic differences have been found among different spawning populations along the Atlantic coast (see Lee et al. 1980). Nolan et al. (1991) discriminated among Atlantic coast populations using mtDNA.
This species is easily confused with Centropomus parallelus (Orrell FAO report).
Records of this species from Brazil represent an undescribed species.

There is no type specimen for Mugil trichodon Poey 1875. Its description is based on Plate 8. Figure 4-8. from Cuba. Thompson (1997) considered it a "nomen nudum" (an invalid name).

This species is genetically most similar to M. rubrioculus and M. brevirostris, but is considered to be valid (Menezes et al. 2015).

Macrodon ancylodon is genetically distinct from the previously known southwestern population (Santos et al. 2006), which is now distinguished as M. atricauda (Günther, 1880) (Carvalho-Filho et al. 2010).
This species has been confused with Chromis atripectoralis (R. Fricke pers. comm. 2008).

Kuiter (2000) and subsequent authors (Fricke et al. 2009, Kuiter 2009) resurrect the name Choeroichthys valencienni based on these specimens having a longer snout. This is insufficient to warrant the splitting of this species, and C. valencienni is here treated as a junior synonym of C. brachysoma.

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.
Jereb et al. (2014) state that ‘Octopus’ minor is in urgent need of review, given that it is highly likely "that this name is being applied to a suite of related soft-bodied, long-armed species from the cooler waters of Russia and northern Japan to the warmer waters of southern coastal China". As such, taxonomic review is urgently needed to resolve the distribution of this species.
Kharin (1981) recognized two subgenera in the genus Aipysurus: Aipysurus and Smithohydrophis. He included Aipysurus foliosquama in Smithohydrophis (Kharin 1981).

Molecular data indicate strong population subdivision around Australia between the Great Barrier Reef, Gulf of Carpentaria and Timor Sea Reefs (Lukoschek et al. 2007, 2008). In addition, there is a deep genetic divergence along the west Australian coastline between populations that occur in the offshore Timor Sea reefs and coastal populations that occur in Broome (Lukoschek unpublished data) and potentially further south. Some specimens from Western Australia are included in the species Aipysurus pooleorum. However, the taxonomic status between A. pooleorum and A. laevis need to be investigated. Microsatellite markers for A. fuscus and A. laevis sampled across four Timor Sea reefs were analysed to assess evidence for recent inter-specific gene flow and historical introgression (Sanders et al. 2014). The data fit an Isolation–Migration model, which showed significant and asymmetrical levels of gene flow following species divergence, and that the highest rates of introgression from the large A. laevis population into the much smaller A. fuscus population (Sanders et al. 2014). Population assignment analyses recovered two ancestral clusters that broadly corresponded to morphological species designations, but revealed high frequencies of hybrids on all four reefs and individuals of pure A. fuscus ancestry only at Scott and (historically) Ashmore. Most unexpectedly, 95% of snakes sampled at Hibernia were hybrids that resembled A. laevis in phenotype (morphology), revealing a collapse of reproductive barriers (‘reverse speciation’) at this reef. These results have dire implications for the conservation status of A. fuscus, and highlight the fragility of reproductive barriers in a recent marine radiation (Sanders et al. 2014).
Kharin (1981) recognized two subgenera in the genus Aipysurus: Aipysurus and Smithohydrophis. He included A. apraefrontalis in Smithohydrophis (Kharin 1981).
Aetomylaeus caerulofasciatus has recently been described as distinct from the wider-ranging Indo-West Pacific A. nichofii (White et al. 2015).

Myosotella denticulata was previously thought to extend into the Mediterranean basin along the European coast. However, following examination of dissected records, the records from the Mediterranean now refer to another species (A. Frias Martin pers. comm. 2017).

A large number of names have been synonymised with this species. The species within this genus are in need of further taxonomic study. There are at least three species in Europe, with data not available for North Africa:

  • Myosotella myosotis (continental European Mediterranean, from Valência to Dalmatia;
  • Myosotella denticulata (perhaps a species complex; continental European Atlantic from Cádis to England); and
  • Myosotella cf letourneuxi (perhaps a species complex; eastern Mediterranean, islands and Turkey.
Acanthopagrus randalli, a new sparid species, is described on the basis of two specimens, collected from Bahrain and Kuwait in the Arabian Gulf, respectively (Iwatsuki and Carpenter 2009).
Previously this species was considered a synonym of Ophioblennius steindachneri (Hastings and Springer 2009).

This species has not been recorded or studied since its original description, and as it appears in the Marine List of Europe (CLEMAM) and Gofas (2015) it may be a marine species. This taxon was not mentioned in the revision of the genus Assiminea by Aartsen (2008). Beckmann (2007) indicates that it has not found it. Gofas (2015) indicates that it is a dubious species or inquerendum (under enquiry). Given the impossibility of collecting alive specimens a study of the type series of this species is recommended, since it has not been done before, and perhaps it can help solve its taxonomic status.
Spatula querquedula (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.

Hybrids with G. monacha recorded on migration in NE China (Williams et al. 1992). New subspecies archibaldi appears to be distinctive owing to absence of red on hindcrown, but other characters remain to be determined; not yet accepted by some authorities (Dickinson & Remsen 2013). E form lilfordi (Turkey to EC Asia; wintering NE Africa E to S China) sometimes recognized, but here regarded as probably undiagnosable, differences from nominate believed to be based on plumage colour variations due in part to differences in feather-painting behaviour. Two subspecies recognized.

Previously a circumtropical species, Trachinocephalus myops was recently separated into three species: T. myops, restricted to the Atlantic Ocean; T. trachinus, known from throughout the Indo-West Pacific; and T. gauguini restricted to the Marquesas Islands (Polanco et al. 2016). The geographic range of T. myops has therefore been reduced considerably.
This species can be misidentified with Pomadasys corvinaeformis.
This species was split into two by Duggins et al. (1983), with Floridichthys polyommus retained along the Yucatan and F. carpio restricted to Florida.

Relyea (1983) synonymized Fundulus similis of southern Florida with F. majalis because F. similis was based on the Gulf population of F. majalis. The same author earlier had recommended (1967, Doctoral dissertation, Tulane Univ.) that populations from southeastern Florida and the Florida Keys be recognized as an undescribed species. Though recognizing that a new scientific name is needed, the 1991 AFS checklist (Robins et al. 1991) continued to use the name F. similis for the southeastern Florida population. The genus Fundulus was removed from Atheriniformes: Cyprinodontidae and placed in Cyprinodontiformes: Fundulidae by Parenti (1981); pending confirmation based on other character suites, this change was not accepted in the 1991 AFS checklist (Robins et al. 1991). See Wiley (1986) for a study of the evolutionary relationships of Fundulus topminnows based on morphological characters. See Cashner et al. (1992) for an allozyme-based phylogenetic analysis of the genus Fundulus (NatureServe 2013).

Recently, Caranx hippos from the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean was split into two species. A new species, Caranx fischeri, was described by Smith-Vaniz and Carpenter (2007). Caranx hippos and C. fischeri are largely sympatric, however it is C. fischeri which is found in the Mediterranean. There have been no confirmed records of C. hippos in the Mediterranean.

According to Catalog of Fishes and Kong and Valdes (1990), Micropogonias manni, which is known to occur only in Chile, may be a junior synonym of M. furnieri. This is not correct, as M. manni is valid, but with nomen dubium (uncertain name). Micropogonias furnieri does not occur in Chile. Specimens collected from Lago Budi, southern Chile (N.L. Chao, 15 March 2011, deposited at the Museo Nacional de Historia Natural, Santiago, Chile) are distinct from M. manni. Taxonomic work on the East Pacific Micropogonias species is needed (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2020).

The taxonomy of the genus Jenkinsia is in need of review (Whitehead 1985). This species may be a synonym of other species of Jenkinsia in the region, though it is possible that this is a valid species with a wider distribution. For the purposes of this assessment, Jenkinsia parvula is considered valid.

Variations in body depth, eye size, etc., of individuals collected throughout this range suggest that more systematic work is needed on this taxon (Munroe 2002). It may be a synonym of Harengula clupeola (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2012).

Some authors question the validity of this species and its taxonomic status need to be determined when a systematic revision is conducted (Whitehead et al. 1988, Nizinski and Munroe 2002). For the purposes of this assessment, Anchoviella blackburni will be treated as valid.

In a revision of the genus Cyclopsetta, Khidir et al. (2004) noted variation in several characters between specimens of C. fimbriata from the Gulf of Mexico and those from the Caribbean Sea. However, they indicated that more specimens were needed to address the question of whether or not more than one species is represented by these specimens. To date, no further studies have addressed this question and it is the position herein that only one species is represented by all the material examined by Khidir et al. (2004).
This species has been previously confused with Strongylura marina (Collette 1968).
Prior to 1993, this species was commonly identified as Hyporhamphus unifasciatus.

Hamlet species are defined primarily on differences in colour patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them. Prior to its description, it was confused with the phenotypically-similar Hypoplectrus gemma (Domeier 1994). A recent genomic analysis of H. maya confirms it is a distinct evolutionary lineage from other Caribbean hamlet species, including H. nigricans, H. puella, H. unicolor and H. gemma (Moran et al. 2019).
As observed during a re-examination of the type specimens of Ophioscion panamensis, it is suspected that this is a junior synonym of O. punctatissimus (L. Chao pers. comm. 2015).

The genus Lucifuga is one of the most diverse stygiobiotic genera of fishes to have been described. The taxonomy of Lucifuga species may still be incomplete due to relatively common discoveries of new species. García-Machado et al. (2011) concluded that Lucifuga spp. are genetically divergent, but most closely related lineages are morphologically indistinguishable and recommend revisiting the taxonomy of the genus. Since the distribution of certain morphological characters among these species is disjointed, they possibly may not be used for classification in the future. A description of a new species, Lucifuga gibarensis of Cuba, was recently published (Hernández et al. 2020).

The genus Lucifuga is known as one of the most diverse of stygiobiotic fishes. The systematics of Lucifuga may still be incomplete due to the relatively common discoveries of new species. Garcia-Machado et al. (2011) concluded that Lucifuga spp. are genetically divergent, but with some of the species being morphologically indistinguishable and recommends revisiting the taxonomy of the genus. A revision of the Lucifuga spp. of Cuba with the description of a new species is currently in preparation by Hernández et al. (Hernández, D., Casane, D., García, A., Chevalier-Monteagudo, P., Møller, P. R. and García-Machado, E.). Recently a species from eastern Cuba, formerly described as a variety of L. dentata, was described as a new species, L. gibarensis (Hernández et al. 2020). The species appears to be more closely related to Bahamian species, than to the other Cuban species. 

There are no species of Lucifuga spp. on Little Bahama Bank other than L. lucayana and the other Bahamian species L. spelaeotes separated from L. lucayana by the deep waters of the Providence Channels (Møller et al. 2006).
Calidris pugnax (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Philomachus.

Type locality: Northeastern Pacifc Ocean, Hawaiian Islands Archipelago, O’ahu Island, Honolulu, between Black Point and Kahala Mandarin Oriental Hotel, 21º15.49’N, 157º46.34’W (Huffard and Hochberg 2005).

This little-known taxon is the type species for the genus Amphioctopus (Jereb et al. 2014), however it is poorly diagnosed, so that additional material and full description of this taxon are required.

Type locality: New Guinea (= West Papua), Port Dorey.

authority: X.D. Zheng, X.Z. Lin, C.C. Lu & R.J. Ma, 2012
taxonomicNotes:
Type locality: Xiamen, 24º31’N, 118º03’E.

Like Cistopus taiwanicus, this species has been misidentified as Cistopus indicus (Jereb et al. 2014).

Type locality: Taiwan, Miaoli (Liao and Lu 2009).

Like Cistopus chinensis, this species has been misidentified as Cistopus indicus (Jereb et al. 2014).
Type locality: South of New Caledonia, Norfolk Ridge, Sponge Bank (Norman et al. 2009).
Type locality: Australia, Western Australia, North West Shelf, 18° 44’S 117° 00’E (Norman et al. 2009).
Type locality: New Caledonia, lagoon off north tip of island, 19°49’S, 163°48’E (Norman and Hochberg 2005).

Type locality: Indonesia, Bali (Hochberg et al. 2006).

This species is sometimes confused with the mimic octopus Thaumoctopus mimicus which co-occurs in similar habitats.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus. We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Type locality: Northeast Atlantic Ocean, southern boundary of Porcupine Seabight, 49º27’N, 13º21’W (Allcock et al. 2006).

Specimens identified as Benthoctopus piscatorum in Collins et al. (2001) were found by Allcock et al. (2006) to be Benthoctopus johnsoniana.

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Geographical variation at least partly clinal; nominate subspecies grades into turcmenica in N Iran, but evidence for intergradation otherwise scant or not conclusive. Three subspecies recognized.

Elops machnata and E. hawaiensis occur sympatrically in the Western Pacific and possibly the Hawaiian Islands, so further research appears warranted. In Japan, for example, Sato and Yasuda (1980) claim that E. machnata historically reported in the region are misidentifications of E. hawaiensis.
This species has previously been confused with Glossogobius giuris and other species in Papua New Guinea (and elsewhere) (Akihito and Meguro 1975, Hoese and Allen 2009).
This is a poorly defined species taxonomically and likely represents a species complex (Kottelat 2013).

The genus Dermogenys was revised by Meisner (2001). Before this, several species of Dermogenys were placed in synonymy with Dermogenys pusilla, which led to the extensive use of D. pusilla in museum collections and throughout the literature. This species was identified as D. pusilla populations from Binton, Singapore and Johor with Type I form of halfbeak viviparity.
The genus Gobiopterus is currently under revision and many species names are uncertain.
Glossogobius celebius was re-described by Hoese and Allen (2011).
The species was last reviewed by Larson (2001). Current work suggests that this taxon comprises several cryptic species (M. Hammer pers. comm. 2018).
This species was re-described by Watson in 1995.
The taxonomy of all Stenogobius species is in flux, with about 30 nominal species (and only a few of these probably valid) and the genus in great need of review.

This species was re-described by Watson (1996) and again with inclusion of Sumatran specimens by Maeda and Tan (2013). Keith et al. (2015) considers Stiphodon allen Watson, 1996 to be a junior synonym of Stiphodon semoni Weber, 1985 without offering justifications for this decision.

The genus Dermogenys was revised by Meisner (2001). Before this, D. sumatrana and other Dermogenys species were placed in synonymy with Dermogenys pusilla, which led to the extensive use of D. pusilla in museum collections and throughout the literature. Some records before and after this time may therefore require confirmation and D. sumatrana may be referred to as Dermogenys pusillus or D. pusillus borneensis.

Kottelat (2013) pointed out that Euctenogobius striatus (from Madras, India) was a junior homonym of Awaous litturatus. The taxonomy of Awaous remains to be resolved. For the purposes of this assessment, A. litturatus is treated as endemic to the Philippines.It is also the type species of the genus Awaous.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. The holotype (unique) has not been examined since Koumans (1953). It has been listed as a synonym of Awaous melanocephalus (Koumans 1953; Maugé 1986), but Kottelat uses the name Awaous personatus (based on Ron Watson in litt.).
This species may include specimens of Brachygobius sabanus in museum collections.
Glossogobius sandakanensis is considered in this Red List assessment to be a junior synonym of Glossogobius circumspectus (D.F. Hoese in litt.; Akihito and Meguro 1975).
The genus Gobiopterus is currently under revision and many species names are uncertain.

The type specimen of Pseudapocryptes borneensis, collected from Banjarmasin, South Kalimantan, Indonesia, is lost (Murdy 1989). Yet a neotype was not designated because specimens from the type locality were unavailable, and the uncertainty of the identity of this species persisted (Murdy 1989). In a revision of the subfamily Oxudercinae, in which this species was included, Murdy (1989) considered individuals caught in Singapore as conspecifics but no recent records of this species are found in Singapore despite persistent efforts in searching for them (Larson et al. 2016). The most recent report of this species is in the mangrove forest of the Nakhon Si Thamarat province in Southern Thailand (Islam and Ikejima, 2010) but specimens are unavailable for identity confirmation.
This genus was reviewed by Larson (2010).
Maeda et al. (2018) provides a re-description of this species based on type specimens.

Keith et al. (2015) synonymised Sicyopus cebuensis Chen and Shao, 1998 and Sicyopus exallisquamulus Watson & Kottelat 2006 under Sicyopus auxilimentus Watson & Kottelat 1994 without justifications for the decision.
Watson synonymised Sicydium balinense under Sicyopus zosterophorus in 1995, and re-described the species in 1999.
Keith et al. recognised Stiphodon birdsong Watson, 1996 as a junior synonym of Stiphodon surrufus Watson and Kottelat, 1995 based on teeth counts.
Watson and Kottelat (1995) synonymised Microsicydium formosum under Stiphodon atropurpureus and re-described the latter species.
This species may be a junior synonym of  Stiphodon atropurpureus, as recently collected specimens from the type locality of S. carisa could not be distinguished (Keith et al. 2015).
Maeda et al. (2015) synonymised Stiphodon aureorostrum Chen and Tan, 2005 under Stiphodon multisquamus Wu and Ni, 1986.
This species was re-described by Maeda and Tan (2013).
Its generic placement is unresolved (it does not belong in Oxyeleotris). Also it is likely that at least one more species has been confused under this name (Hoese D. pers. comm. 2018).
In mainland south-east Asia Pangasius elongatus is often reported as this species. Pouyaud et al. (2002) revised the species.
It is unclear from the litterature if Laemodonta clausa (Deshayes, 1830) and Laemodonta octanfracta (Jonas, 1848) are distinct species.
This is a recently described species (Perugia 2010).
The form from Réunion is referred by some authors as N. bensoni forma guerini Récluz, 1841.

Neritilia vulgaris Kobe & Kane, 2003 is one of the three species in which the former Neritilia rubida was split by Kobe and Kane (2003). Two of these species, namely N. rubida s.s. and N. vulgaris have a partly overlapping range.
The current understanding of this species appears to be composed of several cryptic taxa, however the taxonomic work has not been undertaken (Z. Jaafar pers. comm. 2019).
A. cygnoid (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as A. cygnoides.
Anser canagicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Chen.
Radjah radjah (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Tadorna.
Mareca falcata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.
Spatula smithii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.
Spatula platalea (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.

Spatula rhynchotis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas. Apparently closest to S. clypeata. New Zealand population often treated as a separate subspecies, variegata, but differences from Australian and Tasmanian birds are trivial. Monotypic.

Sometimes placed in genus Nettion. Usually treated (along with A. albogularis, which see for specific differentiation) as conspecific with A. gibberifrons, but recent trend to accord it species status (Kear 2005) accepted here on basis of its lack of a bulbous forehead (3); slightly darker crown contrasting more with paler face (1); slightly whiter, less marked chin and throat (1); distinct pattern of downy young, with different head pattern and anterior underparts colour (2) (Young and Brayshaw 2004). Extinct taxon †remissa of Rennell I, in S Solomons, appears to be sufficiently different from the nominate to warrant recognition. It is darker, smaller and the white stripe on the underwing coverts is vestigial. Two subspecies recognised.
Monotypic.
Ceyx azureus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Alcedo as A. azurea.
Corythornis vintsioides (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Alcedo following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Corythornis leucogaster (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Alcedo following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Todiramphus saurophagus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as T. saurophaga.
Chalcites basalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Chrysococcyx.

Molecular data indicate that G. nigricollis is this species’ closest living relative (Krajewski & King 1996). Hybrids between this species and G. grus recorded on migration in NE China (Williams et al. 1992). Monotypic.

Hypotaenidia philippensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Gallirallus.

Gallirallus sharpei (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) is now considered a colour morph of Buff-banded Rail H. philippensis based on unpublished genetic work (R. W. R. J. Dekker in litt. 2008).
Zapornia flavirostra (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Amaurornis.

Laterallus spilopterus (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously in the genus Porzana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014). Stervander et al. (2019) found that Inaccessible Rail Atlantisia rogersi, Dot-winged Crake Porzana spiloptera and Yellow-breasted Crake Hapalocrex flaviventer nest within a clade of Laterallus crakes, with the first two grouped closely with Black Rail Laterallus jamaicensis. It thus appears appropriate to move all three species to the genus Laterallus, and this option is adopted by BirdLife.
Zapornia tabuensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Porzana.
Zapornia monasa (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Porzana.
Amaurornis cinerea (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Porzana.
Gallinula angula has been assigned to Paragallinula based on molecular findings (Sangster et al. 2015), which are accepted by the BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group.
Tringa brevipes (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Heteroscelus.
Tringa incana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Heteroscelus as H. incanus.
Tringa semipalmata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Catoptrophorus as C. semipalmatus.
Nycticryphes semicollaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Rostratula.
Thinornis cucullatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as T. rubricollis; the name cucullatus has priority.

Previously placed in family Accipitridae but moved to current family based on the phylogeny of Starikov and Wink (2020). Traditionally thought to form a species-group with E. caeruleus and E. axillaris; all three sometimes considered conspecific, but differ variously in plumage, morphology and behaviour. Two subspecies recognized.
Microcarbo africanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Phalacrocorax.

Provisionally treated within genus Urile based on morphological similarities between this species and the other three species recently assigned therein following Kennedy and Spencer (2014); however this extinct taxon was not included in the molecular sampling.
Threskiornis moluccus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as T. molucca.
Cinclodes antarcticus and C. maculirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. antarcticus following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) andStotz et al. (1996).

Previously listed as Calamanthus pyrrhopygius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that as Hylacola pyrrhopygia. Now moved back to Hylacola following Norman et al. (2018). Three subspecies recognized.
Corvus macrorhynchos and C. levaillantii (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped into C. macrorhynchos following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).
Rhipidura javanica and R. nigritorquis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. javancia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cincloramphus timoriensis and C. macrurus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Megalurus timoriensis following Christidis & Boles (2008); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cinnyris pulchellus and C. melanogastrus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. pulchella following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Eurostopodus mystacalis, E. nigripennis and E. exul (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as E. mystacalis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Halcyon smyrnensis and H. gularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as H. smyrnensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Merops viridis and M. americanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. viridis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Merops viridis and M. americanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. viridis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ciconia episcopus and C. microscelis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. episcopus following  Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Charadrius tricollaris and C. bifrontatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. tricollaris following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Charadrius tricollaris and C. bifrontatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. tricollaris following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ardea intermedia, A. brachyrhyncha and A. plumifera (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Mesophoyx and lumped as M. intermedia following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Padda fuscata (Handbook of the Birds of the World and Birdlife International 2022) was recently listed as Lonchura fuscata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), but the distinctiveness of this and P. oryzivora has been demonstrated genetically (Olsson and Alström 2020) and they are returned to the genus in which they were previously placed following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Esacus magnirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as E. giganteus; the name magnirostris has priority.
Sometimes placed in genus Pseudobulweria. Monotypic.
Monotypic.

Egretta gularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) contains the taxon dimorpha, which was previously included within E. garzetta following Kushlan and Hancock (2005). Prior to that, all three taxa were treated as separate species following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Stelgidopteryx serripennis and S. ridgwayi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. serripennis following AOU (1998 & supplements) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Charadrius alexandrinus, C. dealbatus and C. nivosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. alexandrinus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Momotus momota, M. coeruliceps, M. lessonii, M. subrufescens, M. bahamensis and M. aequatorialis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. momota following SACC (2005). Prior to that, M. aequatorialis had been split following Stotz et al. (1996), and before that all forms were lumped with M. momota following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Corythornis cristatus, C. nais and C. thomensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Alcedo and lumped as A. cristata following Melo and Fuchs (2008). Prior to that, all three taxa had been split as A. cristata, A. thomensis and A. nais following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Circus spilonotus and C. spilothorax (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. spilonotus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Haematopus ater (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as H. ater and H. bachmani following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Gallinula chloropus and G. galeata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. chloropus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Rallus longirostris, R. crepitans and R. obsoletus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. longirostris following AOU (2000). Rallus elegans and R. tenuirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. elegans following AOU (2000). Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) included tenuirostris within R. longirostris.
Fulica americana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as F. americana and F. caribaea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Prosobonia cancellata and P. parvirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. cancellata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Anas platyrhynchos and A. fulvigula (incorporating diazi) (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously treated as A. platyrhynchos (incorporating diazi) and A. fulvigula following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The taxonomy of this species is not fully resolved due to the lack of comprehensive taxonomic studies. It may be a homonym of Neritina fuliginosa (Theobald, 1859) or represent the same species, but since its descripition, this species has been ignored in taxonomic studies. As a result, data on its biology and distribution are scarce or unreliable and further taxonomic research is needed.

Note that there is disagreement on the taxonomy of Atherinomorus and some researchers believe that Atherinomorus lacunosus is the species present in the western Indian Ocean, including East Africa, the Seychelles, to Madagascar and the Mascarenes, whereas A. duodecimalis exhibits a more easterly range, Sri Lanka to East Indies (Eschmeyer et al. 2016).

Lontra provocax had been considered a subspecies of L. canadensis (Davis 1978). It was placed in the genus Lontra by van Zyll de Jong (1987). Koepfli and Wayne (1998) and Bininda-Emonds et al. (1999) supported the separation of New World otters into genus Lontra from Lutra, except Pteronura.
This species was formerly misidentified as Synodus doaki (Randall 2009).
This species will be replaced by an undescribed species in South Africa. This is currently under investigation (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species had previously been synonymised with Trimma stiratus and is now recognised as a separate species (Winterbottom et al. 2014)
This species appeared on the IUCN Red List prior to 2008 as Glossogobius biocellatus.
The taxonomy of species in the Mugilidae family is complex and under revision (Durand and Borsa 2015).
This species was previously confused with Acanthopagrus vagus in South Africa (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004, Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2010).

The older species name Tridacna mbalavuana Ladd, 1934 takes priority over the newer name Tridacna tevoroa Lucas, Ledua & Braley, 1990 (M. Seddon pers. comm. 2016; Newman and Gomez 2000).


Tridacna mbalavuana was first described from fossils on Viti Levu, Fiji (Ladd 1934), and was already commonly known to the locals as ‘tevoro’, the devil clam. After closer examination of their morphological characters the two species are now considered synonymous, with T.  tevoroa the junior synonym of  T. mbalavuana (Newman & Gomez 2000).

There is some evidence that Brevoortia aurea and B. pectinata may be synonyms (Cosseau and Diaz de Astarloa 1993, Garcia et al. 2008). However, for the purposes of this assessment, B. aurea and B. pectinata will be treated as two separate species.

There is record of significant taxonomic confusion between Herklotsichthys punctatus and Herklotsichthys quadrimaculatus. Given the discrepancies, this assessment uses a more conservative distribution estimate and describes this species as being a Red Sea endemic and lessepsian migrant to Mediterranean waters.

Trionyx triunguis has been considered a single widespread, relatively uniform species for decades, with no subspecies or other taxonomic units recognized or proposed in recent years. Phylogeographic studies of regional variation have demonstrated different, partly conflicting results, but were based on generally limited sets of specimens and genetic markers (Gidis et al. 2011; Guclu et al. 2011, 2015; Shanas et al. 2012). However, there is still uncertainty as to whether Mediterranean and African subpopulations may in fact represent genetically definable separate Management Units (O. Türkozan unpubl. data).

There are no recognized Trichechus senegalensis subspecies and limited genetic information indicates high genetic diversity (Vianna et al. 2006, Keith Diagne 2014). Anecdotal assertions of morphological differences between isolated inland populations and coastal populations persist, but there is no genetic or morphological evidence (Domning and Hayek 1986, Vianna et al. 2006, Keith Diagne 2014).

The Green Sturgeon was once considered conspecific with the Sakhalin Sturgeon (Acipenser mikadoi) and the two forms were synonymized (Berg 1948). However, recent molecular data on three mitochondrial genes and morphometric studies show large differences between North American and Asian forms (Birstein and DeSalle 1998, North et al. 2002). Sakhalin Sturgeon is now believed extinct in Japan, Korea and China and the species sustains only a remnant population in Russia's Tumnin River where there is a hatchery (Adams et al. 2002).
Diodon hystrix has a very wide distribution and a genetic analysis is warranted.
Given its extremely wide distribution, genetic studies should be conducted on this species to determine its taxonomic status (Leis, Matsuura and Carpenter pers. comm. 2011).

Mola mola differ slightly genetically and morphologically between the Pacific and Atlantic Ocean basins, but the two clades are currently treated as one species pending further taxonomic research (Yoshita et al. 2009, Nyegaard et al. 2018a, Sawai et al. 2018, 2020, Caldera et al. 2020, Baptista et al. 2021). The taxonomic history of M. mola is extensive and complicated (Nyegaard et al. 2018b; Sawai et al. 2018, 2020; Fricke et al. 2021), and M. mola literature written before the redescription of Mola alexandrini and description of Mola tecta (both in 2017) may have misidentified these two other species as M. mola.

Ranzania laevis has a circumglobal distribution and is currently considered a single cosmopolitan species (Caldera et al. 2020, Sawai et al. 2020, Fricke et al. 2022), although no phylogenetic study across its range has been undertaken. Genetic differences have been documented between specimens collected in the Sargasso Sea and those from Hawai’i (Caldera et al. 2020), and additional research is needed to confirm whether this represents a species complex. Preliminary genetic comparisons show little variation across the mitochondrial locus CO1 (among 12 individuals sampled across a wide range, including North Atlantic, South Africa, and Hawai’i.; Nyegaard et al. 2018), although a 5% sequence divergence (in the mitochondrial D-loop locus) between two specimens has been noted (Yoshita et al. 2009, Yamanoue et al. 2004). Fraser-Brunner (1951) suggested morphological differences in R. laevis between the Atlantic and North Pacific Ocean, with intermediate forms in the Indian Ocean. Research combining morphological and genetic analysis is required to clarify this species' taxonomy.

This species is not listed in the Clupeidae catalouge (Whitehead 1985). Whether or not this is a valid species needs to be researched. It may be a senior synonym of another species of Herklotsichthys.

Shibukawa et al. (2012) reviewed the genus Lotilia and determined that the true L. graciliosa  is restricted to the Red Sea. The species widely distributed in the western Pacific was described as a new species, L. klausewitzi.
This species is sometimes treated under the genus Chitulia.
Known as Alosa brashnikovi in literature.

There is confusion regarding the taxonomic status of this species. This species was once considered a synonym of Alosa brashnikowii (Whitehead 1985) and has been considered a subspecies of A. brashnikowi (see Svetiovidov 1952). However, this species is currently considered to be valid as Alosa curensis (Suvorov 1907: Reshetnikov et al. 1997, Dorofeeva 1998, Esmaeili et al. 2014, Jouladeh-Roudbar et al. 2015) and will be treated as such for the purposes of this assessment.

The validity of this species has been contested by some studies after considering specimens as hybrids between different shad species (Reshetnikov et al. 1997). According to Coad (2017) and Berg (1948,1949), this is not a valid species.
This species closely resembles A. leiogaster, which has more lower gill rakers (Breder and Rosen 1966).

There is some evidence that Brevoortia pectinata and B. aurea may be synonyms (Cosseau and Diaz de Astarloa 1993, Garcia et al. 2008). However, for the purposes of this assessment, B. aurea and B. pectinata will be treated as two separate species.
The validity of this species has been questioned. It is possibly a synonym of Herklotsichthys castelnaui (Whitehead 1985).

In the published literature and online websites, there are discrepancies reported on the distributional range of Herklotsichthys koningsbergeri. Whitehead (1985) reports a more restricted distribution in northern Western Australia, whereas Allen (2002) reports the distribution from Western Australia to the Gulf of Carpentaria and possibly to southern New Guinea. Williams and Cappo (1990) recorded this species around Townsville, northern Queensland. Online databases (e.g., Fishes of Australia and Atlas of Living Australia) agree in distribution they report (from Shark Bay to central New South Wales). At this time, we are unable to determine the reliability of information reported in these various data sources.

Sardinella melanura may represent a species complex that includes 1-2 additional undescribed species (H. Hata pers. comm. 2017). The type locality for the true S. melanura is Santa Cruz Islands. Additional genetic and morphological work is needed to determine the status of these nominal, undescribed species and thus their distribution. However, at this time, all records of S. melanura were considered for the assessment.
Sprattus antipodum is commonly misidentified and grouped with the related S. muelleri; Whitehead (1985) described the species as distinct.
Sprattus muelleri is commonly misidentified and grouped with the related S. antipodum; Whitehead et al. (1985) described the species as distinct.
The taxonomic validity of this species may need to be reviewed.
The type specimens of this species are reportedly lost and the taxonomy is uncertain (Nelson 1983, Whitehead et al. 1988).

Setipinna taty and S. tenuifilis can be easily confused, but the only species of Setipinna that occurs off China is S. tenuifilis (Whitehead et al. 1988, Young et al. 1994). Some authors identify S. taty as occurring in fisheries in the East China and Yellow seas (Sun et al. 2006) and Bohai Sea (Cheng and Zhou 1997, Tang et al.2003, Jin 2004); these records refer to S. tenuifilis (Whitehead et al. 1988, Young et al. 1994, Xu et al. 2014, H. Hata pers. comm. 2017).

Setipinna taty and S. tenuifilis can be easily confused, but the only species of Setipinna that occurs off China is S. tenuifilis (Whitehead et al. 1988, Young et al. 1994). Some authors identify S. taty as occurring in fisheries in the East China and Yellow seas (Sun et al. 2006) and Bohai Sea (Cheng and Zhou 1997, Tang et al.2003, Jin 2004); these records refer to S. tenuifilis (Whitehead et al. 1988, Young et al. 1994, Xu et al. 2014, H. Hata pers. comm. 2017).
This species is frequently confused with S. waitei which makes its complete distribution uncertain (H. Hata pers. comm. 2017).
This species is easily confused with Thryssa hamiltonii.

Ilisha macrogaster is known from only two specimens, and the characters used to separate this species from I. filigera are slight differences in gill raker counts (Whitehead 1985). These two nominal species may be synonymous (Whitehead 1985).

Wongratana (1980) was only able to identify three specimens of this species, however, Whitehead (1985) considered that this species was probably distinct from other species. For the purposes of this assessment, we accept the preliminary conclusion of Whitehead (1985) that this is valid.
Ilisha striatula is caught with I. melastoma in Indian waters and may be subject to some misidentification with this species (Whitehead 1985, Coppola et al. 1994).

In a recent taxonomic revision (Randall and DiBattista 2012), the nominal species Etrumeus teres (sensu Whitehead 1985) was split into four distinct species: E. makiawa Randall and DiBattista 2012, restricted to the Hawaiian Islands; E. micropus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846), from Japan, and perhaps south to Indonesia; E. acuminatus Gilbert 1890 from the eastern tropical Pacific; and E. sadina (Mitchill 1814) from the northwestern Atlantic (with Etrumeus teres (DeKay 1842) as a junior synonym).

In a recent taxonomic revision (Randall and DiBattista 2012), the nominal species, Etrumeus teres (sensu Whitehead 1985) was split into four distinct species: E. makiawa Randall and DiBattista 2012, restricted to the Hawaiian Islands; E. micropus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846), from Japan, and perhaps south to Indonesia; E. acuminatus Gilbert 1890 from the eastern tropical Pacific; and E. sadina (Mitchill 1814) from the northwestern Atlantic (with Etrumeus teres (DeKay 1842) as a junior synonym).
This species can be confused with Cephalopholis miniata and C. argus in the Coral Triangle.
This species is sometimes confused with Cephalopholis boenak.
This species resembles Cephalopholis urodeta, but can be distinguished by the distinctive dark saddle on caudal peduncle (Myers 1999).
This species can be confused with Cephalopholis boenak in Australia (Hoese et al. 2006).
This species was removed from synonymy with Cephalopholis urodeta by Craig and Hastings (2007).
A recent publication suggests changing the family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007).
