Until 1984, this species was incorrectly included in the genus Gracila (Heemstra and Randall 1993).

The taxonomy of this species requires further investigation (M. Craig pers. comm. 2018), especially to discern differences from two very similar congeners, Cephalopholis microprion and C. cyanostigma (Randall and Satapoomin 2000).
This species is often misidentified as Cephalopholis aurantia (or as C. analis, a junior synonym of C. aurantia).

This was previously considered to be a widespread species in the Indian and West Pacific oceans, but the Indian Ocean form has now been shown to be Cephalopholis nigripinnis (Craig and Hastings 2007).

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.
Perca robusta (Couch, 1832) was listed as a synonym of “Epinephelus guaza” (= E. marginatus) by Smith (1971), but Heemstra (1991) considered this latter species a synonym of E. aeneus.

Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Craig and Hastings (2007) consider Epinephelus albomarginatus to be a member of the genus Mycteroperca. Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. albomarginatus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

This species has been much confused with Epinephelus maculatus in the literature, and many museum specimens have been misidentified. It was illustrated in colour as Epinephelus maculatus by Allen (1985) and Sainsbury et al. (1985). Epinephelus merra, E. bilobatus, E. faveatus, E. hexagonatus, E. macrospilos, E. maculatus, E. melanostigma, E. quoyanus and E. spilotoceps comprise the ‘reticulated groupers’, which are shallow coral reef species that can be similar in appearance and are sometimes confused.
Craig and Hastings (2007) consider the species Epinephelus caninus to be a member of the genus Mycteroperca.

Epinephelus chlorostigma is very similar to and easily confused with E. gabriellae and E. polylepis. These two species replace E. chlorostigma in the northwest Indian Ocean, including the Persian Gulf.

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. cifuentesi), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.
This species is very closely related to Epinephelus labriformis and was often reported as E. labriformes or Epinephelus sp. prior to its description in 1999 (Craig et al. 2006).

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. costae), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

The name Epinephelus alexandrinus (Valenciennes 1828) was used for this species from 1895 to 1988, but this name is incorrect, as the holotype of Serranus alexandrinus Valenciennes is a specimen of Epinephelus fasciatus, a known species from the Red Sea and Indo-Pacific area.
This species is replaced by Epinephelus flavocaeruleus in the Indian Ocean (Myers 1989).

This species is often misidentified as Plectropomus maculatus (Heemstra and Randall 1993). In Australia, small adults in blue spot phase can be misidentified as P. leopardus (CRC Reef Information Brochure).

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. marginatus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

Plectropomus pessuliferus is often misidentified as P. maculatus (Heemstra and Randall 1993). Heemstra and Randall (1993) recognized two subspecies: Plectropomus pessuliferus marisrubri in the Red Sea, and P. pessuliferus pessuliferus from the remainder of the Indo-Pacific region. Phylogenetic analyses by Ma et al. (2016) identified P. pessuliferus as a relatively small species with a distribution from the central Indian ocean to the Coral Triangle with a single record from deep water Tonga. It is the sister species of P. leopardus and is not directly related to the Red Sea species previously identified as P. pessuliferus marisrubri.

Heemstra and Randall (1993) indicate that there is considerable intraspecific variation, and suggest that there are six populations based on scale counts and colour differences: Indian Ocean and Red Sea, Western Australia, Western Pacific, Japan, Pacific Plate islands, Marquesas Islands.

This species has been previously mis-identified as Epinephelus malabaricus in Sri Lanka. Epinephelus merra, E. bilobatus, E. faveatus, E. hexagonatus, E. macrospilos, E. maculatus, E. melanostigma, E. quoyanus and E. spilotoceps comprise the ‘reticulated groupers’, which are shallow coral reef species that can be similar in appearance and are sometimes confused.

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. goreensis), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. heniochus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

Epinephelus hexagonatus may be confused with several other small Epinephelinae species, in particular E. merra. Epinephelus merra, E. bilobatus, E. faveatus, E. hexagonatus, E. macrospilos, E. maculatus, E. melanostigma, E. quoyanus and E. spilotoceps comprise the ‘reticulated groupers’, which are shallow coral reef species that can be similar in appearance and are sometimes confused.

Epinephelus howlandi is often confused with closely related species, in particular E. macrospilos and E. corallicola. It is distinguished from E. macrospilos by the presence of a black blotch at the base of the dorsal fin and of a rounder head and from E. corallicola by a higher density of brown spots, a shorter head and a lighter background colour.
Smith and Craig (2007) changed the family name to Epinephelidae; however, some workers retain its classification under Serranidae.

Epinephelus macrospilos may be confused with a number of other Epinephelinae, in particular, E. howlandi, E. corallicola, E. quoyanus or E. faveatus. Epinephelus merra, E. bilobatus, E. faveatus, E. hexagonatus, E. macrospilos, E. maculatus, E. melanostigma, E. quoyanus and E. spilotoceps comprise the ‘reticulated groupers’, which are shallow coral reef species that can be similar in appearance and are sometimes confused.

Epinephelus merra, E. bilobatus, E. faveatus, E. hexagonatus, E. macrospilos, E. maculatus, E. melanostigma, E. quoyanus and E. spilotoceps comprise the ‘reticulated groupers’, which are shallow coral reef species that can be similar in appearance and are sometimes confused.

Adults of this species are sometimes confused with other deep water species including Mycteroperca radiatus, M. poecilinotus and Epinephelus tuamotuensis.
This species is closely related to Epinephelus summana that is known only from the Red Sea.

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. poecilonotus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

This species belongs to the Mycteroperca morrhua species complex, which also includes M. radiatus and E. tuamotuensis and these four species have often been confused (Heemstra and Randall 1993).

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. posteli), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

Epinephelus quinquefasciatus was previously considered E. itajara, but is now considered a separate species, with E. itajara only in the Atlantic and E. qinquefasciatus in the Pacific (Craig et al. 2009).

Epinephelus merra, E. bilobatus, E. faveatus, E. hexagonatus, E. macrospilos, E. maculatus, E. melanostigma, E. quoyanus and E. spilotoceps comprise the ‘reticulated groupers’, which are shallow coral reef species that can be similar in appearance and are sometimes confused.

Ma and Craig (2018) revised the classification of groupers, concluding that there are now nine genera: Alphestes, Cephalopholis (subsuming Aethaloperca, Gracila, and Paranthias), Dermatolepis, Epinephelus (sensu stricto), Gonioplectrus, Hyporthodus (subsuming Triso dermopterus, with the addition of three species previously placed in Epinephelus), Mycteroperca (with the addition of 11 species previously placed in Epinephelus, including E. radiatus), Plectropomus (subsuming Saloptia), and Variola.

This species is regularly confused with Mycteroperca morrhua, which it closely resembles, throughout much of its range. In Japan, the species is referred to as Epinephelus morrhua morrhua (Gloerfelt-Tarp and Kailola 1984). Juveniles of M. radiatus may also be confused with those of E. magniscuttis.

This species is a member of the Epinephelus fasciatus complex, which also contains E. rivulatus and E. irroratus. The differences between these four species are outlined by Heemstra and Randall (1993).

This species is a member of the Epinephelus fasciatus complex that includes E. irroratus and E. retouti, although E. rivulatus is distinguishable by the dark blotch on the pectoral fin (Heemstra and Randall 1993).

Epinephelus sexfasciatus has been previously confused with E. diacanthus, a northern Indian Ocean species, and records of the latter from the Western Pacific are likely of E. sexfasciatus (Randall and Heemstra 1991).

Epinephelus merra, E. bilobatus, E. faveatus, E. hexagonatus, E. macrospilos, E. maculatus, E. melanostigma, E. quoyanus and E. spilotoceps comprise the ‘reticulated groupers’, which are shallow coral reef species that can be similar in appearance and are sometimes confused.
This species was previously misidentified as Epinephelus diacanthus, which is a northern Indian Ocean species (Randall and Heemstra 1991).
This species has been and still is frequently confused with Epinephelus coioides and possibly E. malabaricus as well (M. Craig and Y. Sadovy pers. comm. 2018).
This species is very similar to Epinephelus flavocaeruleus, but differs notably in colour. It may represent a Western Australian subspecies of E. flavocaeruleus (Heemstra and Randall 1993).

A recent publication changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus (Craig and Hastings 2007) and a change of family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007).
A recent publication changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus (Craig and Hastings 2007) and a change of family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007).

Recent publications have changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus (Craig and Hastings 2007), and the family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007). This species is closely related to Hyporthodus septemfasciatus (known only from Japan, Korea and China) and H. octofasciatus (widespread in the Indo-Pacific region, including in eastern and western Australia, New Zealand and South Africa). The differences between these three species are outlined by Heemstra and Randall (1993). More taxonomic work is needed on this group, especially as it has been proposed that individuals of H. ergastularius recorded in fisheries catches off parts of Queensland may be H. octofasciatus (Pogonoski et al. 2002).

This species can be easily confused with Hyporthodus niveatus. Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus and Smith and Craig (2007) changed the family name to Epinephelidae.

This species has likely been occasionally confused with Epinephelus marginatus under the names of E. guaza and E. gigas (Heemstra 1991). The stuffed holotype of Cerna sicana Doderlein 1882 from Sicily may represent an abnormal specimen of H. haifensis (Heemstra 1991). The generic name of this species has been changed relatively recently from Epinephelus to Hyporthodus (Craig and Hastings 2007), and its family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007).

This species has been misidentified as Hyporthodus niveatus by some workers. The generic name was changed from Epinephelus to Hyporthodus by Craig and Hastings (2007), and the family name was changed to Epinephelidae by Smith and Craig (2007).
A recent publication changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus (Craig and Hastings 2007) and the family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007).
This species is easily confused with Hyporthodus octofasciatus, which has likely led to many cases of misidentification (M. Craig pers. comm. 2018).

Heemstra and Randall (1993) described the morphological differences between Mycteroperca prionura, M. jordani and M. xenarcha. Mycteroperca prionura can easily be confused with Epinephelus analogus, which it closely resembles in colour.

This species is frequently confused with Plectropomus leopardus.
This species has been previously confused with Plectropomus maculatus (Quoy and Gaimard), which occurs only in the Western Pacific (Randall and Hoese 1986).

Variola albimarginata is often mis-identified as V. louti.
Epinephelus bruneus was recently split into two species, the other being a former synonym of E. bruneus: E. moara (Liu et al. 2013).

WoRMS (2016) considers Actinia striata Risso, 1826 to be a junior synonym of Paractinia striata (Risso, 1826). However we follow Ocaña et al. (2015) in accepting Actinia striata Risso, 1826 as a valid species.

The species Actinia striata Quoy & Gaimard, 1833 corresponds to a species described from New Zealand (O. Ocaña pers. comm. 2016). However Ottaway (1975) commented that no author subsequent to Quoy & Gaimard has recognised Actinia striata Quoy & Gaimard, 1833, considered it likely that it was probably not an Actinia, and that since Actinia striata Quoy & Gaimard, 1833, is also a junior primary homonym of Actinia striata Risso, 1826, rejected the name and description of Actinia striata Quoy & Gaimard.

References to H. whitei off the east coast of Africa should be H. camelopardalis. Genetic data indicate that this species is distinct from H. whitei in Australia (S. Casey in litt. to Lourie et al. 1999).
Actinopyga agassizi is sometimes incorrectly referred to as Muelleria agassizi.
Astichopus multifidus may also be known as Stichopus multifidus.
This species may warrant a taxonomic revision, as it may be a synonym or previously confused with Astichopus multifidus (Cutress and Miller 1982).
This species can hybridize with H. floridana in the Florida Keys. The hybrids are viable (Engstrom 1980).
This species is a synonym of Holothuria marenzelleri (Deichmann 1958).
Isostichopus macroparentheses, Stichopus badionotus, Stichopus macroparentheses and Stichopus moebii may be synonyms for this species.
This species is a synonym of Irenothuria maccullochi and Holothuria maccullochi.

This species was previously treated as a subspecies or variety of Clupeonella cultriventris (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007). In Iran, individuals of this species are still nominally referred to as C. cultriventris, the subspecies C. cultriventris caspia (F. Kaymaram pers. comm. 2018), or C. caspia (Fazli et al. 2020). For the purposes of this assessment, the taxonomy of species of Clupeonella follows Eschmeyer's Catalog of Fishes (Fricke et al. 2020). Therefore, both C. caspia and C. cultriventris are treated as valid species; C. cultriventris is distributed within the Black Sea and the Sea of Azov, while C. caspia is endemic to the Caspian Sea (Fricke et al. 2020). For this assessment, any reference of C. cultriventris or C. cultriventris caspia in the literature from Iranian waters is considered to be C. caspia.

Two sub-species of Engraulis mordax have been recognized based on small anatomical differences, mainly in body depth, head length number of vertebrae and maximum standard length: Engraulis mordax mordax known from British Columbia to Baja California and E. mordax nanus found in the bays of California (Hubbs 1925, Hildebrand 1943, Whitehead et al. 1988). Three subpopulations are currently recognized (McHugh 1951) based on evidence from morphometric characters (Spratt 1972), protein variation (Vrooman and Palmoa 1975, Vrooman et al. 1981, Diaz-Jaimes et al. 1999) and genetic data (LeComte et al. 2004, Lewis and Lema 2019): the northern subpopulation distributed in waters off British Columbia to northern California; the central subpopulation extending from San Francisco Bay to Central Baja California in the southern California Current Ecosystem (CCE); and the southern subpopulation distributed from central to southern Baja California and into the Gulf of California (Sydeman et al. 2020).
This species is morphologically similar to other closely related species and can be easily confused and misidentified (Wongratana et al. 1999).
Originally spelled as fürthii and subsequently emended to fuerthii (Eschmeyer et al. 2017).

The validity of this species has been questioned in the literature as it is only apparently distinct from the other regional species of Opisthopterus based on subtle morphological differences (e.g., a more anteriorly placed dorsal fin and a slight variation in the number of gill rakers: Whitehead 1985). Whitehead (1985) suggested that more species should be examined; however there has been no recent work on this species in the available literature since the 1980s. Despite the lack of available research on this species, it is currently listed as a valid species in Eschmeyer’s Catalog of Fishes (Fricke et al. 2020). Therefore, for the purposes of this Red List assessment, Opisthopterus macrops will be treated as a valid species distributed in the eastern tropical Pacific. Future taxonomic work on this species is needed.
The assessment has been amended in September 2016 to reflect newly available information which places this species in the genus Raja (formally Malacoraja).

Morphological data for the type specimen of H. dahli have been lost. Specimens from northeast Australia that are classified as H. dahli by Kuiter (2001) are meristically indistinguishable from H. trimaculatus from elsewhere in their range (Appendix D in Lourie et al. 2016), although they apparently lack the three spots characteristic of H. trimaculatus (data for Lourie et al. 1999). Genetic data (648bp, CO1) from a single specimen identified as H. dahli (not publicly available) suggests a 4.86% divergence between this specimen and others from India to Taiwan, Province of China, Indonesia and the Philippines (BOLD 2016).

Further investigation as to the taxonomic status of this species is warranted; however, for this assessment, H. dahli is treated as a valid species restricted to north and northeastern Australia (Lourie et al. 2016).

Encrasicholina pseudoheteroloba (Hardenberg 1933), previously regarded as a junior synonym of E. heteroloba, is in fact a valid species in its own right and is therefore elevated accordingly (Hata and Motomura 2017).

The species was first described by Risso (1810) as Squalus ferox from the type locality at Nice and most early records were from the Mediterranean and eastern North Atlantic. Whitley (1950) described O. herbsti from southeastern Australia, differentiating it from O. ferox mainly on differences in dental formulae, and the absence of pigment spots. Garrick's (1974) account of two specimens from New Zealand cast doubt on any differences in dentition between the species but retained O. herbsti for the plain-coloured Odontaspis.

However, Compagno (1984) reviewed the two species and considered that O. herbsti was a junior synonym of O. ferox, noting (as did Robins et al. 1980) that the presence or absence of spots was highly variable, much as with Carcharias taurus. The existence of spotted specimens outside the Mediterranean Sea, including from California (Seigel and Compagno 1986), is supported by in-situ observations made off Lebanon, New Zealand and Malpelo Island (Columbia), where specimens exhibit considerable variability in the presence, density and size of spots. There may be some regionalised trends controlling the intensity of such pigmentation. In the absence of any further evidence to support the validity of an O. ferox/O. herbsti dichotomy, recognition of the single Odontaspis ferox of Risso, as previously argued by Compagno (1984, 2001), remains valid.
Conger marginatus was removed from synonymy with Conger cinereus by Randall (2005, 2007).

This species has long been known as Conger wilsoni (Bloch and Schneider 1801), applied to specimens from throughout the Indo-Pacific. However, the species as described by Bloch and Schneider is unidentifiable. The oldest available name that unequivocally refers to this species is Leptocephalus monganius Phillipps, 1932 (Smith and Stewart 2015).
This species has been referred to the genus Ophichthus (Hibino et al. 2019).
This species was recently assigned to the genus Bathycongrus (Smith and Ho 2018).
Some authors contend this species is a junior synonym of S. cancrivora Peters, 1864 (Klausewitz and Zajonz 2000).

Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status. The taxonomic validity of this species is in question and requires review. However, until such time as this problem is solved it is treated as a valid species.

Heymer and Zander (1992) concluded that the Yellow Mediterranean Goby, called Gobius luteus by Miller and El-Tawil (1974), is the ‘true’ G. auratus Risso, 1810 and designated a neotype. The species supposed to be G. auratus by Miller and El-Tawil (1974) was designated as an undescribed species and the new name G. xanthocephalus was applied after the investigation of abundant populations of both forms at Banyuls-sur-Mer, France (Heymer and Zander 1992). Herler et al. (2005) redescribed G. auratus Risso, 1810 to extend the morphological characteristics of the species to cover also the northern Adriatic population. Two colour morphs are described: pure yellow colour morph 1 from the Mediterranean and south and central Adriatic and yellow dotted colour morph 2 from the northern Adriatic.
This species might have been misidentified as Lebetus scorpioides (Collett, 1874), Herler and Kovacic (2002).
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

This species was previously confused with other guitarfishes and erroneously considered to be widespread in the Indo-Pacific. Rhinobatos formosensis from Taiwan is now known to be a junior synonym of R. schlegelii (Last et al. 2016a, Last et al. 2016b).
The species is distinguished from its regional congeners, the Bottlennose Guitarfish (Rhinobatos schlegelii) by colour, morphology, and meristic characters (Last et al. 2014).

The taxonomy of the 'whitespotted wedgefish' species-complex (which includes several Indo-West Pacific wedgefishes) is not fully resolved, and the status of the Taiwanese Wedgefish is in need of critical re-evaluation by comparing it to other regional species.
This species was previously considered to be conspecific with Aetobatus flagellum, but the species have since been shown to differ genetically and morphologically (White et al. 2013).

authority: Ruocco, Lucifora, Díaz de Astarloa, Mabragaña & Delpiani, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Bathytoshia was resurrected for a subgroup of Dasyatis and molecular data reveal that B. brevicaudata and Dasyatis matsubarai Miyosi, 1939 are populations of just one species: Bathytoshia brevicaudata (Last et al. 2016).

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).

Séret and McEachran (1986) tentatively synonymised Glaucostegus petiti (reported from the Western Indian Ocean) with G. cemiculus because the morphometrics and the meristics of the holotype and only known specimen of G. petiti fell into the ranges of variation of G. cemiculus. Glaucostegus cemiculus is an Eastern Atlantic species, however, and does not occur in the Western Indian Ocean from which G. petiti is reported (Bernard Séret pers. comm. 2008). It is possible that there was a mistake in the origin of the type specimen, although the collector Georges Petit did explore the Tuléar region of Madagasar. No further specimens of Glaucostegus petiti have been found to date, despite the presence of an active research station in Tuléar for decades, although other guitarfishes (Acroteriobatus annulatus and Rhinobatos holcorhynchus) have been collected from the region (Bernard Séret pers. comm. 2008).

Glaucostegus petiti is considered a synonym of G. cemiculus (William T. White and David A. Ebert pers. comm. 2016).

Bathytoshia formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis, but it is now recognised as a valid genus (Last et al. 2016a); hence Dasyatis (Bathytoshia) lata is now Bathytoshia lata. Molecular data (G. Naylor pers. comm. 1 November 2012) provide evidence that Bathytoshia (as Dasyatis) lata, D. thetidis Ogilby, 1899, D. ushiei (Jordan & Hubbs, 1925), and eastern Atlantic stingrays identified as D. centroura (e.g. McEachran and Capapé 1984), are populations of D. lata (Last et al. 2016a). The species was originally described by Garman (1880) from Hawaii and also confirmed by Fowler (1941). Teng (1962) reported this species from Taiwan (1962) although the record from Taiwan may be a different species.

Last et al. (2016a) revised the family Dasyatidae, erecting the morphologically conservative genus Telatrygon and moving zugei across to this new genus. Telatrygon crozieri (Blyth, 1860) from the northern Indian Ocean is considered distinct from T. zugei (which occurs in the western Pacific).
Last et al. (2016a) resurrected the species Telatrygon crozieri (Blythe, 1886) from its former synonymy with Dasyatis (=Telatrygon) zugei.
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

The Dwarf Black Stingray (Hemitrygon parvonigra) was referred to as Dasyatis sp. A in Last and Stevens (1994) before being described as a new species by Last and White (2008).

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae. Petean et al. (2020) revised Hypanus americanus, separating the newly described species, H. berthalutzae, whose distribution includes the Brazilian coastline from the mouth of the Amazon River to São Paulo State.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

This species was mistakenly named Dasyatis macrophthalma in the title of the original description. A correction note was provided by Rosa et al. (2000).

Last et al. (2016) note that the placement of Megatrygon microps in the family Dasyatidae is provisional; it may be more closely related to the freshwater Neotropical stingrays (Potamotrygonidae) of South America. Further investigations are needed to determine the position of this species in the order Myliobatiformes, but it may belong in its own family (Last et al. 2016).

Previously included within Neotrygon kuhlii, N. australiae was described as a separate species by Last et al. (2016a). The Neotrygon genus has recently been split and currently includes at least 11 species. It is difficult to distinguish some members of the genus based solely on morphology, thus the true distribution and overlap of species is not currently known. More work is required to fully understand where each member of the Neotrygon genus occurs.

Previously included within Neotrygon kuhlii, N. trigonoides was described as a separate species by Last et al. (2016a). The Neotrygon genus has recently been split and currently includes at least 11 species. It is difficult to distinguish some members of the genus based solely on morphology, thus the true distribution and overlap of species is not currently known. More work is required to fully understand where each member of the Neotrygon genus occurs.

Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. The two Western Atlantic species (F. colarensis and F. geijskesi) differ significantly from the other taxa in this genus and may prove to be non-congeneric with the four species from West Africa (Last et al. 2016).

This species is often mistaken with Hypanus guttatus but snout length and pelvic fin shape differ.

Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. The two Western Atlantic species (F. colarensis and F. geijskesi) differ significantly from the other taxa in this genus and may prove to be non-congeneric with the four species from West Africa (Last et al. 2016).

Last et al. (2016a) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. Records of Dasyatis (=Fontitrygon) margarita have included misidentified specimens of the smaller sympatric species, F. margaritella.
Last et al. (2016a) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon.

Himantura heterurus has been placed within the newly described genus Brevitrygon (Last et al. 2016a). Brevitrygon heterura is the correct name of a common western Pacific species, misidentified as Himantura (=Brevitrygon) walga; B. walga is confined to the Indian Ocean (Last et al. 2016a).
Last et al. (2016a) placed Himantura heterurus, H. imbricata, H. javaensis, and H. walga within their newly described genus Brevitrygon.

The genus Himantura has been further revised by Last et al. (2016). Himantura, which was once represented widely in the Indo–West Pacific by ~20 species, is now restricted to a group of four large Indo–Pacific species with strong colour patterns (Last et al. 2016). Himantura astra is now within the newly erected genus Maculabatis, along with eight other medium to large marine whiprays that were previously placed in Himantura (Last et al. 2016).

Himantura (=Maculabatis) astra had previously been confused with Himantura (=Maculabatis) toshi and the two forms had been considered to be a single species, however they are now known to be two morphologically distinct species. Himantura toshi (sensu Last & Stevens, 1994) was renamed H. astra Last, Manjaji-Matsumoto & Pogonoski, 2008 (Last et al. 2008, Last and Stevens 2009) and Himantura sp. A (sensu Last & Stevens, 1994) is considered to be H. toshi Whitley, 1939 (Last et al. 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).
Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, comprised of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including macrura).

The genus Himantura has been further revised by Last et al. (2016). Himantura, which was once represented widely in the Indo–West Pacific by ~20 species, is now restricted to a group of four large Indo–Pacific species with strong colour patterns (Last et al. 2016). Himantura toshi is now within the newly erected genus Maculabatis, along with eight other medium to large marine whiprays that were previously placed in Himantura (Last et al. 2016).

The Brown Whipray (Himantura (=Maculabatis) toshi) had previously been confused with the Blackspotted Whipray (Himantura (=Maculabatis) astra) and the two forms had been considered to be a single species; however they are now known to be two morphologically distinct species. Himantura sp. A (sensu Last & Stevens, 1994) has been named H. toshi (Last and Stevens 2009), and Himantura toshi (sensu Last & Stevens, 1994) was renamed H. astra (Last and Stevens 2009).
Taeniopygia guttata and T. castanotis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. guttata following Christidis & Boles (2008); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including fai).

This species is frequently misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) jenkinsii.

Oenanthe oenanthe and O. seebohmi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. oenanthe following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Formerly monotypic (containing only U. asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) added five more large to very large species to Urogymmus, including dalyensis.

The Freshwater Whipray (Urogymmus dalyensis) is a recently described species which was previously referred to as Himantura chaophraya Monkolprasit & Roberts, 1991 (for example, in Last and Stevens 1994). Himantura chaophraya was considered to occur in Southeast Asia and in northern Australia. However, Last and Manjaji-Matsumoto (2008) consider the Australian form to be distinct from the Southeast Asian form, and they described the former as Himantura (=Urogymmus) dalyensis. They also clarified the correct name for the Southeast Asian species as Himantura (=Urogymmus) polylepis (Bleeker, 1852). Thus, the name H. chaophraya is invalid.
This species requires further taxonomic research and it is possible that populations in the Mekong and other drainage systems may pertain to other species (Vidthayanon et al. 2016).

Cinnyris pulchellus and C. melanogastrus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. pulchella following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
This species was previously confused with Pastinachus sephen with which it co-occurs (Last and Manjaji-Matsumoto 2010).
Rhipidura javanica and R. nigritorquis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. javancia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Historically, the name Haemulon steindachneri included both Pacific and Atlantic populations. Recently, the species was revised; Haemulon steindachneri is now restricted to the Pacific Ocean and H. atlanticus (removed from H. steindachneri) occurs in the Atlantic Ocean (Carvalho et al. 2020).
The taxonomic status and validity of this species is uncertain. The only known specimen (which may be lost) may have actually been an Apristurus species.

A record of an egg capsule from the Indian Ocean identified as Harriotta indica (Balakrishnan 1962), as well as records of H. pinnata in the Arabian Sea and Southwest India (Manilo and Movchan 1989, Silas and Selvaraj 1980) probably refer to this species.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

This species was first described by Gubanov and Schleib (1980) but Dingerkus and DeFino (1983) described it as a separate species, Chiloscyllium confusum, without mention of C. arabicum. Compagno (1984) provisionally recognized C. arabicum but noted it was apparently very close to C. punctatum. Dingerkus and DeFino's account clearly establishes this species as separate from C. punctatum (Compagno 2001).

This species has been widely misreported as C. griseum, at least in the Arabian Gulf, and the distribution of these two similar species requires clarification. There is a high need for taxonomic investigation regarding species in the genus Chiloscyllium in the Arabian Sea region (D. Ebert pers. comm. 2017).

Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

Acroteriobatus variegatus is morphologically very similar to A. zanzibarensis, with only subtle differences in mitochondrial DNA between the two species. Further work is required to clarify their relationship (Last et al. 2016b).

This species was confused with H. buergeri until Springer and D'Aubrey (1972) found it to be a different species (Compagno 1984). Previously considered to occur in the Philippines, Viet Nam and northwestern Australia but two new species recently described from Indonesia/Philippines and northwestern Australia have resulted in a more restricted range for this species (White et al. 2007). The Viet Nam populations need to be examined further as it is unsure which Halaelurus species they are (W. White pers. obs).

Previously Torpedo suessi was considered a junior synonym of T. sinuspersici (Carvalho et al. 2002). Garman (1913) considered T. suessi to be a valid species, but thought that it may be synonymous with T. panthera. However, Carvalho et al. (2002) believe that this is not possible due to the inconceivability that the ornate colour pattern of T. suessi could transform into the typical pattern of small, irregular whitish spots present in T. panthera. Rather than being a synonym of T. sinuspersici, or T. panthera, it is much more likely that T. suessi is a valid species that occurs at least in the southern Red Sea (Carvalho et al. 2002). This species may also be identifiable with the paralectotype of T. fuscomaculata, but there is some uncertainty surrounding this, and T. suessi would still prove to be a valid species even it if it was conspecific with the paralectotype (Carvalho et al. 2002).
Although only recently described (Carvalho et al. 2002), the Bigeye Electric Ray (Narcine oculifera) is distinctive and is not easily confused with any other electric rays.

The female holotype of the Pita Skate was comprehensively examined in a recent taxonomic assessment of Okamajei (Weigmann et al. 2015). This showed unequivocally that the Pita Skate does not belong to the genus Okamejei, but instead to either Leucoraja or Rajella. This is evidenced by its overall appearance, particularly the absence of dark-marked ventral pores (vs. dark marked ventral pores present in Okamejei), a rather short and thick tail (vs. a long and slender tail), a very short interdorsal space (vs. a wide interdorsal space), and a short postdorsal tail section (vs. a long postdorsal tail section). Due to the lack of an adult male specimen and the accordingly unknown clasper characters, the Pita Skate specimen cannot definitely be assigned to a genus and for the time being should be placed as incertae sedis in the general genus Raja Linnaeus. More specimens are urgently needed (Weigmann et al. 2015).

Himantura imbricata has been placed within the newly described genus Brevitrygon (Last et al. 2016a). Brevitrygon imbricata is very similar to B. walga (it is often confused with B. walga), particularly in general disc shape, however their geographical distributions appear limited and almost non-overlapping (P. Last pers. obs). The former is apparently found only in the Indian Ocean, the latter in the South China Sea. Two forms of B. imbricata are recognized, based on the morphology of the tail.
Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis to consist of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including randalli).
Aetomylaeus milvus is considered to be distinct from A. maculatus (Last et al. 2016).

Last et al. (2016a) placed Himantura heterurus, H. imbricata, H. javaensis, and H. walga within the new genus Brevitrygon, previously confused with other dwarf whiprays (Brevitrygon species) (Last et al. 2016b). There remains considerable taxonomic confusion over 'B. walga' with different forms across its range. These may turn out to represent a series of different species.
Ardea intermedia, A. brachyrhyncha and A. plumifera (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Mesophoyx and lumped as M. intermedia following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Mareca penelope (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.

There was some misidentification of this genus in the past by Koch where it was described as Paramuricea placomus. Currently there is some debate about being the same species as the Atlantic one Spinimuricea atlantica.
Eurostopodus mystacalis, E. nigripennis and E. exul (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as E. mystacalis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

This species is likely closely related to Hippocampus kuda and H. mohnikei. Further research is needed to identify the full extent of its range and how it overlaps with those of H. kuda and H. mohnikei (Zhang et al. 2016).
Hirundo tahitica and H. domicola (Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped, and subsequently split into H. tahitica and H. javanica following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).
This species has been relocated from the genus Okamejei to Orbiraja (Last et al. 2016a).

The Japanese Sea Lion has sometimes been considered a subspecies of Zalophus californianus, Z. c. japonicus. Rice (1998) argued for the retention of Z. californianus, Z. japonicus, and Z. wollebaeki as distinct species without providing new evidence. From studies of skull morphology Brunner (2003) argued for species status for these three taxa. In addition, Sakahira and Niimi (2007) and Wolf et al. (2007) provide genetic evidence that Z. japonicus is best considered a separate species.
This species has been referred to as Lutjanus spilurus (Allen 1985).
The family Bathyclupeidae requires revision (Paxton and Carpenter 2002).
The single paratype for this species was described as a new species, Bellottia galatheae (Nielsen and Møller 2008).
The type specimens of this species were destroyed during World War II (Eschmeyer et al. 2017).
This species was re-described by Smith-Vaniz and Johnson (2016). The proper spelling is Owstonia doryptera.
This species was re-described by Smith-Vaniz and Johnson (2016).

DiBattista et al. (2014) presented evidence that there might be two species nested within what is currently recognized as Etrumeus jacksoniensis, with one species restricted to western and south Australia and the other occurring off New South Wales. More research is needed to determine if those two apparently distinct lineages represent two species. For the purposes of this assessment Etrumues jacksoniensis is treated as one species.
Previously, this species was regarded as a junior synonym of S. gracilis. The validity of S. atrofasciatus was confirmed by Ishimori et al. 2015.

The genus Hapalogenys has been traditionally placed in the family Haemulidae (Akazaki 1984, McKay 2001 and Nelson 2006). A new family name, Hapalogeniidae (Springer and Raasch 1995) was established; however, this was not based on strong supporting evidence. Furthermore, Hapalogenys has been reported to be close to the family Dinopercidae and may belong to a group of ‘Lobotes-like’ species. There is a need for further study on the familial position of Hapalogenys (Iwatsuki and Russell 2006).

The validity of this species is questionable as the holotype is a small specimen (~7 cm) that still shows juvenile characteristics, and this species may be conspecific with one of the other species in the area (McGrouther 1999).
The taxonomic validity of this species is questionable. It is not recognized by Paxton and Hulley (1999) and its status has not been evaluated (Eschmeyer et al. 2017).
Satyrichthys kikingeri is considered a junior synonym of Scalicus laticeps (Kawai 2014).

Various authors ascribe the name Dunckerocampus to either a separate genus (Kuiter 2000, 2009) or as a subgenus of Doryrhamphus (Dawson 1985). Dunckerocampus is treated here as a separate genus based on observable morphological differences, including the absence of brood pouch folds on pregnant males.
This species has been reassigned to the genus Oxyurichthys (Pezold and Larson 2015).

Osterhage et al. (2016) have described a new species of seamoth (Pegasus tetrabelos) that is sympatric with P. volitans in the Torres Strait and Great Barrier Reef. They also designated a lectotype for P. volitans.
Dawson (1984) and most later authors consider Idiotropiscis to be a subgenus of Acentronura.
There is continuing debate as to whether Myctophum lychnobium is a valid species (J. Paxton pers. comm. 2008).
There is a possibility that Stegastes fuscus and Stegastes dorsopunicans are the same species, in which case the species would be called S. fuscus (Lavett-Smith 1997).
The subgenus Minysynchiropus is treated by some authors as a genus (see Hoese and Bray 2006, p. 1584 in Hoese et al. 2006), however, we have followed Fricke (2002) in treating it as a subgenus.
Subfamily: Anthiinae

This species was hesitantly suggested to be a synonym of Leptostomias longibarba by Gibbs and Barnett (1990). This species is found in the eastern Atlantic between Ireland and the Azores and from the Canary Islands to South Africa, but it is not recorded from the Gulf of Guinea.
Scorpaenopsis cotticeps, from the Philippines, may be the same species (Eschmeyer and Randall 1975).
This species is placed by some authors as a species under the genus Foetorepus, however, following Fricke (2002) Foetorepus is treated here as a sub-genus.

Seven geographic subspecies were recognized by Collette and Parin (1970):

Platybelone argalus argalus from the western Atlantic;
P. a. lovii from the Cape Verde Islands;
P. a. annobonensis from Annobón and Fernando Po islands in the Gulf of Guinea;
P. a. trachura from Ascension and St. Helena;
P. a. platyura in most of the Indo-West Pacific;
P. a. platura in the Red Sea and Persian Gulf; and
P. a. pterura from the eastern Pacific.
The Azores population is of taxonomic interest (B. Collette pers. comm. 2012).

The taxonomic concept of Gnatholepis cauerensis is undergoing revision. Gnatholepis has often been misidentified and confused for many years. Previously, there were four accepted sub-species (G. c. cauerensis, G. c. australis, G. c. hawaiiensis, and G. c. pascuensis), and G. thompsoni was considered a synonym (Randall and Greenfield 2001). Thacker (2004) shows G. thompsoni to be a separate species and also concludes that G. cauerensis should be synonymised with G. anjerensis. Variation in mitochondrial DNA suggested that G. thompsoni is a valid species that is widespread in the Atlantic Ocean and separate from G. cauerensis (Rocha et al. 2005). However, Randall and Greenfield (2007) consider G. thompsoni a synonym of G. cauerensis. Randall (2009) elevated three sub-species to the species level (resulting in four species: G. cauerensis, G. australis, G. hawaiiensis, and G. pascuensis).


During a recent revision of Gnatholepis, the classification presented by Rocha et al. was discussed and validated with meristic and other morphological characters by Larson and Buckle (2012). Larson and Buckle (2012) concluded that G. cauerensis includes sub-species G. c. cauerensis, G. c. australis, and G. c. hawaiiensis, and G. inconsequens is considered a synonym. They elevated G. thompsoni and G. pascuensis to valid species. Gnatholepis thompsoni, as valid in Larson and Buckle (2012), is restricted to the Atlantic Ocean. Smith-Vaniz and Collette (2013), however, recorded G. cauerensis, not G. thompsoni, in Bermuda, as “the meristic and other morphological characters purported to separate these two ‘species’ have broadly over-lapping values”.
It is currently not clear whether Hephthocara crassiceps and Hephthocara simum are separate species or conspecific.

It is unclear whether this species should in fact be placed in the Microdesmidae as subfamily Ptereleotrinae (W. Eschmeyer pers. comm. 2009).

This species has been misidentified with P. formosus and P. raoi.

This species is now limited to the Philippines and Indonesia (Allen 2004). The eastern population (Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands and Vanuatu) is recognized as a distinct species, P. aurifrons (Allen 2004).
Recently, an older name for the widely used name N.rotunda was synonymized with N. erostris (Motomura et al. 2015).
There are two subspecies: Pseudanthias ventralis ventralis and Pseudanthias ventralis hawaiiensis.
This species has also recently been listed under the genera Sciadeops and Sciades. Original orthography with 'ii' ending.
Lethrinus genivittatus has often been recognised as L. nematacanthus, and the name L. genivittatus is often misassociated with many other species (Froese and Pauly 2006).
A specimen caught off the northwest coast of Africa is thought to be a misidentification of this species (D. Smith pers. comm. 2008).
This species was previously confused with Apogon coccineus and A. erythrinus (Greenfield 2001).
Paraliparis copei consists of three subspecies: Paraliparis copei copei, P. c. wilsoni and P. c. kerguelensis.
Older records of this species from the western Indian Ocean are now thought to be misidentifications of Pelates quadrilineatus.
There remains some taxonomic debate surrounding the species status of Merluccius hernandezi (Lloris et al. 2003).  It was previously classed as belonging to the species M. angustimanus.
Dactylanthias aplodactylus is only known from a single specimen.
Subfamily: Anthiinae

Preliminary molecular studies suggest that the genus Schedophilus is not monophyletic (Milana et al. 2011).

In the Mediterranean, this species is frequently confused with the con-familial Schedophilus ovalis (Stefanescu and Massutí 1992).
The taxonomic status of populations of this species in different oceans needs to be investigated (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).
The genus Saurida is in urgent need of revision and the taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain (B. Russell pers. comm. 2009)
This species may prove to be conspecific with Pterois russellii.
The species status of Eustomias monodactylus has recently been restored and it should no longer be considered a synonym of Eustomias filifer (Sutton and Hartel 2004).
This species is commonly misidentified as Sillago sihama.
Parupeneus crassilabris is one of a complex of 3 species, along with P. insularis from the more eastern islands of Oceania, and P. trifasciatus from the Indian Ocean.
This species is probably a junior synonym of Heteroconger pellegrini.
Due to the small number of specimens and the range overlap with the similar species, Sebastes cortezi, the species status of Sebastes peduncularis is questioned (Love et al. 2002).
The senior synonym has been changed from Arius platystomus (Day, 1877) to Plicofollis platystomus (Day, 1877) (Eschmeyer 2008).
Lycodes paamiuti has been previously treated as L. pallidus, L. frigidus, and L. squamiventer in the literature (Møller 2001).
Mulloidichthys dentatus is closely related to M. martinicus of the western Atlantic and M. vanicolensis, an Indo-Pacific species that also occurs in the region.
The “golden basses” off Curaçao are now comprised of three species: Liopropoma aberrans, L. olneyi, and L. santi (Baldwin and Robertson 2014).
This species is easily confused with Peristedion nierstraszi Weber, 1913 (Ho et al. 2013).
Scorpaena hatizyoensis maybe a junior synonym of Sebastapistes mauritiana (H. Motomura pers. comm. 2008).
Formerly known as Dinematichthys dasyrhynchus.
Apogon guamensis is a synonym. Apogon ocellatus and Apogon spongicolus are juvenile specimens of Apogon guamensis.
This species was formerly known as Pseudanthias sheni.
Genus changed from Apogon to Nectamia (Fraser 2008).

Although considered a worldwide species by previous authors, T. lepturus is now known with certainty only from the western Atlantic and Indo-west Pacific. The eastern Atlantic population reported as this species is probably an undescribed species. There are multiple lines of evidence showing geographically-correlated divergence and supporting the treatment of at least 3 species in the T. lepturus complex (Chakrabarty and Iwatsuki 2006, Hsu et al. 2009). 

Trichiurus japonicus, which was originally described from Japan as Trichiurus lepturus japonicus, was synonymized with Trichiurus lepturus. Another nominal species synonymized with Trichiurus lepturus is Trichiurus nitens from the eastern Pacific Ocean (California to Peru).

Gibbs and Staiger (1970) found some minor difference between the western and eastern Atlantic populations of C. cyanopterus (considered at that time as disjunct) in two meristic characters, visible number of vertebrae and number of predorsal scales. Atlantic and Indo-West Pacific populations of C. cyanopterus have been never compared.This species has been historically known as Cypselurus cyanopterus.
This species was previously placed under the family Inermiidae (Sanciangco et al. 2011).
Taxonomic note: This species is difficult to distinguish from the closely related Echeneis neucratoides which occurs only in the western central Atlantic (O’Toole 2002)

Recent work indicates significant genetic divergence between specimens from deep waters off Central America and in the Gulf of Mexico, indicating the possibility that the name poeyi may represent two species (Baldwin et al. in press).
The northern populations of this species show genetic differences in comparison to the southern populations, and may be different species (L. Rocha pers. comm. 2014)

According to a redescription of this species by Frable et al. (2013), the taxonomic authority was changed from (Spix and Agassiz, 1829) to (Agassiz, 1829). Additionally, S. intermedius was split into a new species named S. macrostigmus.

This species has been confused with Diodon hystrix (Brito et al. 2002). This latter species is littoral, with a generally brown colouration and rounded anal and dorsal fins; D. eydouxii is, in contrast, a pelagic species, with back and sides blue and belly white, and pointed anal and dorsal fins (Leis 1978). Given its extremely wide distribution, genetic studies are warranted.

The taxonomy of the genus Masturus is in need of further study. Earlier authors (e.g., Fraser-Brunner 1951) suggested that Masturus comprises two species: M. lanceolataus and M. oxyuropterus based on the degree of claval extension. Preliminary genetic data suggest M. lanceolatus is a single, global population with no structuring among ocean basins, but no global studies have examined the taxonomy or population structure of M. lanceolatus, and a global genetic analysis is warranted (see Caldera et al. 2020).

Tyler (1980) tentatively recognized four species in this complex that have different distributions, based on his material examined and text: Chilomycterus atringa (western Atlantic); C. reticulatus (eastern Atlantic and Indo-Pacific); C. tigrinus (western Indian Ocean); and C. affinis (Eastern Pacific). However, Tyler (1980) said that C. tigrinus may be the young of C. reticulatus.
This species has a very wide distribution and a genetic analysis is warranted. Leis (1978) noted some differences in spine morphology between Pacific and north Atlantic specimens.

Several papers provide genetic evidence that Lutjanus purpureus, Caribbean Red Snapper, can be considered a synonym of L. campechanus (Gomes et al. 2008, Gomes et al. 2012). All assessors and reviewers agreed that L. campechanus and L. purpureus should be treated according to the many functional differences between the North American and Brazil populations and their massive and distinct biological and management literatures. {need to update this with info from Pedraza-Marron et al 2019 revision of campechanus and purpureus - C. Linardich April 2019}
This species was previously known as Pomadasys corvinaeformis and all Haemulopsis species, like Pomadasys, are associated with softbottom habitats (Tavera et al. 2012).

Earlier records may have been recorded as Lampris guttatus or Lampris regius (Hawn and Collette 2012). Southern Ocean records pertain to a second species L. immaculata (Parin and Kukuyev 1983). The species may consist of multiple cryptic species (Hawn and Collette 2012). The correct spelling for the family Lampridae is Lamprididae (Olney in press). Genetic data suggests that there may be several species of Opah (B. Collette pers. comm. 2015). Further conformation of additional species may be found at (Underkoffler et al. 2018).

Disjunct populations of S. aurita in the western and eastern Atlantic are in need of further study to determine their taxonomic status (Whitehead 1985). Sardinella brasiliensis is a species which has been described from the southeast Brazilian Bight and is a valid species according to Eschmeyer (Figueiredo et al. 2010). There are reports of sympatric occurrence with S. aurita in the Gulf of Mexico; however, these may be based on misidentifications (Kinsey et al. 1994). We accept the conclusions presented in Tringali and Wilson (1993) that S. brasiliensis is a junior subjective synonym of S. aurita.
This species is commonly misidentified as Seriola rivoliana and S. carpenteri, making market data unreliable (W. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2013).

There is ongoing taxonomic uncertainty involving this species. Golani et al. (2011, 2013) suggest that Sillago sihama is restricted to the southern Red Sea. Eschmeyer (2014) currently recognizes a distribution throughout the entire Indo-West Pacific, including the Red Sea.

The name Synodus synodus (Linnaeus 1758) (type locality: "America") has been widely used for this species. Genetic evidence indicates approximately 5-6% divergence in COI between eastern and western Atlantic populations indicating deep population structure or potential cryptic species within its lineage (Frable et al. 2013). This suggests that populations on either side of the Atlantic may represent distinct species. The nominal Synodus atlanticus (Johnson 1863) is currently available for this species.  However, further work is needed to stabilize the nomenclature.

There is molecular and morphological evidence available that Atlantic specimens identified as Antennarius striatus represent a separate species (Antennarius scaber) (Arnold and Pietsch 2012). Work is underway to resurrect the species (R. Arnold pers. comm. 2013).

The higher taxonomy of this species is currently uncertain, though it is currently included in the family Caproidae (Perciformes). However, there is currently no evidence to suggest that the genera Antigonia and Capros belong in the same family (Heemstra in press). Some authors suggest that it should be placed in the Beryciformes due to otolith shape (Zehren 1987).
A geminate species, Chloroscombrus orqueta Jordan and Gilbert, occurs in the eastern Pacific Ocean (Smith-Vaniz FAO ECA Guide in prep).

The validity of this species is in question. Molecular evidence may identify it as Echeneis neucratoides as Echeneis naucrates (Gray et al. 2009). Occasional studies consider Echeneis neucratoides and Echeneis naucrates one species (O'Toole 1999).

Taxonomic study needs to be conducted for this species complex. Adults of Uraspis helvola and U. secunda are virtually impossible to distinguish although juvenile characters involving allometric growth patterns suggest that they may be distinct species. If subsequent studies indicate that these two nominal species are conspecific, the oldest available name is Uraspis helvola. A complete description is given only for U. secunda because that name has been widely used for Atlantic Uraspis (Carpenter in prep.).

This species was previously known as Inermia vittata and formerly in the family Inermiidae. Genetic analyses published in Rocha et al. (2008) place it within the genus Haemulon, within the family Haemulidae. The new combination, Haemulon vittatum, is recognized by Eschmeyer and other recent publications.
This species was previously known as Priacanthus cruentatas and Cookeolus boops.
Fistularia petimba has often wrongly been cited as the more common Fistularia commersonii (Randall et al. 1990).
In the field, this species is difficult to distinguish from Stephanolepis setifer (R. Robertson and J. Tyler pers. comm. 2015).

In Hawaii, this species has been referred to as Carangoides dasson. Easter Island occurrences are likely conspecific with the Hawaiian fish (W. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015). Taxonomic clarification is needed on the disjunct populations reported for this species.
This species is likely often misidentified as Carangoides gymnostethus (W. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015).
This species is likely often misidentified as Carangoides fulvoguttatus (W. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015).
In regions of sympatry, Carangiodes hedlandensis is easily confused with Carngoides armatus.
This species can be easily confused with Carangoides talamparoides (W. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015).
Carangoides talamparoides is easily confused with Carangoides malabaricus (W. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015).
This species has frequently been misidentified in the literature as Decapterus macarellus (W. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015).
In much of the Australia literature, this species has been called Trachinotus velox (W. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015).
Sphyraena picudilla, considered by some authors to be a different species, is here regarded as a junior synonym of S. borealis (for discussion see Smith-Vaniz et al. 1999).
Gerres britannus, G. poieti, and G. acinaces, and four other species, are considered synonyms of G. longirostris (Iwatsuki et al. 2001).

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families. Their study recognized 11 species in Kyphosidae, as well as one Neoscorpis, which is considered a distinct genus within Kyphosidae. Thus, there are 12 species total in the family Kyphosidae. However, Sakai and Nakabo (2014) have a different view on the taxonomy of the Atlantic species of Kyphosus and do not consider K. cinerascens to occur in the Atlantic Ocean.


Kyphosus lutescens and K. pacificus are now treated as synonyms of K. sectatrix. Both K. incisor and K. analogus are now considered synonyms of K. vaigiensis. K. pacificus/sandwicensis is a synonym of K. elegans. Before Knudsen and Clements (2013) it was thought that only two Kyphosids occurred in the Atlantic, but there are in fact four species, K. sectatrix, K. vaigiensis/incisor, K. bigibbus, and K. cinerascens.
This species is sometimes mis-identified as Upeneus sulphureus and Upeneus doriae.
Until recently, records of Upeneus tragula from the Indian Ocean were based on misidentifications of Upeneus heemstrai (Uiblein and Gouws 2014).
There is some uncertainty about the taxonomic validity of Siganus fuscescens versus S. canaliculatus.
This species was recently revalidated based on genetic and morphological data (Bernal and Rocha 2011). Acanthurus bahianus is now considered to be endemic to Brazil.

Due to previous difficulties in the correct identification of the species, the records prior to 2013 are difficult to verify, and therefore the species' distribution in northeastern Atlantic waters is unknown for now. However, Sakai and Nakabo (2014) have a different view on the taxonomy of the Atlantic species of Kyphosus and do not consider K. bigibbus to occur in the Atlantic Ocean.

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families. Their study recognized 11 species in Kyphosidae, as well as one Neoscorpis, which is considered a distinct genus within Kyphosidae. Thus, there are 12 species total in the family Kyphosidae. 

Kyphosus lutescens and K. pacificus are now treated as synonyms of K. sectatrix. Both K. incisor and K. analogus are now considered synonyms of K. vaigiensis. K. pacificus/sandwicensis is a synonym of K. elegans. Before Knudsen and Clements (2013) it was thought that only two Kyphosids occurred in the Atlantic, but there are in fact four species, K. sectatrix, K. vaigiensis/incisor, K. bigibbus, and K. cinerascens.

Sado and Kimura (2005) suggest that S. armatus is a synonym of S. leptosoma (sic - the correct Latin formulation of the name is leptosomus - see Eschmeyer et al. 2016), however they don't provide any rationale for this.

Corythoichthys waitei was considered a synonym of C. intestinalis because of a lack of morphological differences by Dawson (1985). Kuiter (2000, 2009) resurrected the name and considered the species valid based on the fact that it "has a longer snout which is strongly marked with black lines". Further morphological and/or molecular data are needed in order to consider C. waitei a valid species; meanwhile it is here included as a synonym of C. intestinalis.
Various authors ascribe the name Dunckerocampus to either a separate genus (Kuiter 2000, 2009) or as a subgenus of Doryrhamphus (Dawson 1985). Dunckerocampus is treated here as a separate genus.

Various authors ascribe the name Dunckerocampus to either a separate genus (Kuiter 2000, 2009) or as a subgenus of Doryrhamphus (Dawson 1985). Dunckerocampus is treated here as a separate species.

Molecular work is needed to confirm that this species is in fact different from D. dactyliophorus. Most species, including D. boylei, are distinguished solely based on colour patterns and tail markings (Kuiter 1998).

Various authors ascribe the name Dunckerocampus to either a separate genus (Kuiter 2000, 2009) or as a subgenus of Doryrhamphus (Dawson 1985). Dunckerocampus is treated here as a separate species This species was originally described as a subspecies of D. caullleryi, which is a synonym of D. dactyliophorus (Bleeker, 1853). Dawson (1985) deemed it a valid separate species.
Various authors ascribe the name Dunckerocampus to either a separate genus (Kuiter 2000, 2009) or as a subgenus of Doryrhamphus (Dawson 1985). Dunckerocampus is treated here as a separate genus.

Dawson (1985) considered Dunckerocampus to be a subgenus of Doryrhamphus. Kuiter (1998) separates the two as distinct genera, stating that morphological differences between the two are sufficient for this (although he doesn't make these differences explicit). Dunckerocampus is treated here as a separate genus.
Dawson (1984) and most later authors consider Idiotropiscis to be a subgenus of Acentronura.
Dawson (1984) and most later authors consider Idiotropiscis to be a subgenus of Acentronura.

The description of this species (Fricke 2004) failed to compare it to the congenerics Micrognathus brevirostris pygmaeus and M. natans, both of which were noted as being present in New Caledonia by Dawson (1985). Kuiter (2009) suggested that M. brevicorpus may in fact be a synonym of M. pygmaeus, which he considered a full species as opposed to Dawson's (1985) assignment to subspecies status - M. b. pygmaeus. The specimens for all of the aforementioned species show only minor differences in meristic counts (Dawson 1985, Fricke 2004). Further taxonomic research and DNA analyses are needed to understand the diversity of this genus, especially in New Caledonia.

Pseudophallus brasiliensis Dawson 1974 is a junior synonym of P. mindii. Dawson (1974) originally described P. brasiliensis based on low meristic counts in Brazil compared to the previously described P. mindii. Later research revealed similar or lower counts in other parts of the range of P. mindii, indicating that the two are one and the same (Dawson 1982). From Dawson (1982): "Specimens with low counts from the Amazon drainage were described as P. brasiliensis, but samples with similar or lower counts have subsequently been examined from the Orinoco River and Lake Izabal, Guatemala. In the apparent absence of consistent differences in coloration or other morphological features, these specimens are considered to represent local populations of P. mindii wherein low meristic values result from unknown environmental influences."

The highly separated distribution of this species suggests that it is either more widely distributed than current records indicate, or that the Japanese records represent a distinct species (D. Greenfield pers. comm. 2015).

Cirrhitus pinnulatus is separated into two subspecies C. pinnulatus pinnulatus and C. pinnulatus maculosus. It was determined that C. pinnulatus found in the Red Sea was a separate species and was reclassified as C. spilotoceps (Gaither and Randall 2013). This species is known from the Red Sea and Gulf of Oman (Gaither and Randall 2013); records of C. pinnulatus from East Africa south to Port Alfred, South Africa and elsewhere in the Indian Ocean may also pertain to S. spilotoceps.

Species in the family Gerreidae are difficult to identify, even by specialists familiar with the group. Therefore, individual species' population trends are difficult to document, as species are often harvested and grouped as a single species.
Some reports of this species may have been based on misidentifications of Lutjanus malabaricus.
Due to recent taxonomic changes within the genus Parupeneus, the abundance and population status of P. insularis is not fully understood.
Until recently, Upeneus arge was recognized as a valid species.  It is now considered a synonym of Upeneus taeniopterus (Uiblein & Heemstra 2010, Eschmeyer 2015).

This species has several color morphs; in the type locality females are orange and males are usually blue (Smith-Vaniz 2009). There are many variations in meristic values, morphometrics, and color pattern in allopatric populations of O. variabilis (Smith-Vaniz 2009).

This is a relatively widespread species. However, it exhibits pronounced geographic variation in several meristic characters and it is likely that further study will warrant division of the species as currently recognized into two or more species (Gill 2004).

Given the relatively extensive geographic range of this species, as well as the presence of geographic variation in certain meristic characters, it is highly probable that further studies (particularly field- and aquarium-based studies of live coloration) will provide justification for the subdivision of Pseudochromis fuscus as currently conceived into several species.

Given the wide geographic distribution of this species, and the presence of geographic variation in some meristic characters, it is likely that further studies will justify subdivision of the species as currently diagnosed into two or more species (Gill 2004).

Kuiter and Debilius (2001) recognized three species (Siganus corallinus, S. studeri, and S. tetrazonus) based on minor color pattern differences. This is not followed by Allen and Erdmann (2012). Eschmeyer (2014) recognizes S. corallinus and S. studeri but not S. tetrazonus. Without genetic data, we follow Allen and Erdmann (2012) and only recognize S. corallinus.

Kuiter and Debelius (2001) recognized Siganus margaritiferus where S. fuscescens where is widely recognized. This was followed by Allen and Erdmann (2012) but not followed by Kottelat (2013). Eschmeyer (2014) follows Kottelat and considers S. margaritiferus a synonym of S. fuscescens. We concur with Eschmeyer (2014) and do not recognize S. margaritiferus as a distinct species.
Records of this species from the northern Indian Ocean are now considered to be of Siganus insomnis (Woodland and Anderson 2014).
Paramonacanthus curtorhynchus is a junior synonym of Paramonacanthus japonicus (Hutchins 1997); P. japonicus is now a junior synonym of P. oblongus (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2016).
This species is replaced by Pervagor marginalis in the Line and Marquesas Islands (Myers 1999).
This fish is the sole member of its genus (Matsuura 2015).
The taxonomy of species in the Mugilidae family is complex and under revision (Durand and Borsa 2015).

Motomura and Iwatsuki (2001b) noted that Polydactylus persicus, previously identified as P. sextarius (e.g. Kuronuma and Abe 1972, Randall 1995, Carpenter et al. 1997), was recently described as a new species on the basis of 13 specimens.

Some earlier reports (Dames and Moore 1983) likely captured this species but recorded it as Solea elongata. Given the recency of description of S. stanalandi, conceivably other studies published prior to its description also included this species in the accounts of S elongata.

In the Persian Gulf, Upeneus oligospilus was formerly recorded as U. tragula. Uiblein and Heemstra (2011b) suggested that due to the lack of research in the area, U. oligospilus may occur outside of the Persian Gulf.
Ophidion rochei is often confused with Ophidion barbatum.
This species is easily confused with Pseudocaranx dentex (Smith-Vaniz and Jelks 2006).

The Lost Shark is a recently described, distinct, whaler shark of the Carcharhinus porosus subgroup (White et al. 2019a). Originally described as Carcharhinus obsolerus, the correct spelling is actually Carcharhinus obsoletus (Dubois and Seret 2019, White et al. 2019b).

The Java Stingaree is known only from the type specimen and is considered valid with the holotype housed at the Humboldt-Universität, Museum für Naturkunde, Zoologisches Museum, Berlin, Germany. It is a unique species of stingaree and its placement in the genus Urolophus is provisional (Last et al. 2016). It is the only known stingaree (family Urolophidae) from Java; the Kai Stingaree (Urolophus kaianus), the only other stingaree known from Indonesia, doesn't overlap with the historical range of the Java Stingaree (Last et al. 2016).
This species has recently been removed from synonymy with G. scaber (Knapp and Imamura 2014).

A recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors (e.g., Leviton et al. 2014, Lillywhite et al. 2014, Rasmussen et al. 2014, Ukuwela et al. 2014, D'Anastasi et al. 2016, Rezaie-Atagholipour et al. 2016, Udyawer et al. 2015, Mirtschin et al. 2017).

A distinctive new subspecies of sea snake from inner-basin waters of Golfo Dulce, Costa Rica has been described (Bessesen and Galbreath 2017). The Yellow sea snake, Hydrophis platurus ssp. xanthos Bessesen & Galbreath, 2017 is diagnosed by a notably smaller body size and nearly uniform yellow colouration, which contrasts with the black and yellow striae and tail spots or bands typical of the species (Bessesen and Galbreath 2017).
This species has been recognised as a distinct species from Psychrolutes inermis and is considered the more abundant species in South Africa (Nelson et al. 1985).

Sebastes capensis is the only species in this genus to be described around the coasts of South Africa and the Southern Atlantic. All other species are described from Peru and Chile in the southeastern Pacific. Comparisons of colour patterns and morphological characteristics have not revealed features allowing for specific separation. S. capensis is the only species to be identified in the southern hemisphere according to taxonomic revisions, though more research is needed (Rocha-Olivares et al. 1999).
This species was historically synonymised with M. inermis but confirmed a distinct species in 1981 (Amaoka and Kanayama 1981).

The genus Apristurus is one of the most taxonomically confused groups of sharks. Most species are superficially very similar and many have been poorly described. Sexual dimorphism in some species, and changes in body proportions with growth also complicate identification. There are at least seven species of Apristurus in New Zealand, however taxonomy and identification issues remain unresolved (Ford et al. 2015, Roberts et al. 2015).
Last, Burgess and Séret (2002) suggest that Etmopterus caudastigmus, E. splendidus and E. fusus might be placed within a different genus.
