This species has been reported from New Caledonia in an unpublished checklist of fishes. However, the specimens from there represent an undescribed species of Gollum (Gollum sp. B in Ebert et al. 2013).

Viana and de Carvalho (2018) propose S. rancureli as a junior synonym of S. melanurus, however the reported differences in colour pattern, morphology and mersitics indicate that further sampling, and a genetic comparison of the two nominal species is needed to support their synonymy. The distributions of Squalus melanurus and S. rancureli also need to be clarified through examination of collected materials. The correct taxonomic authority for this species requires clarification.
Typhlonarke tarakea Phillipps, 1929 is probably based on a poorly preserved specimen of T. aysoni (Last et al. 2016), and the genus Typhlonarke is here treated as monospecific.

The species was described in 1971 from nine specimens collected from southern New Zealand. However, the collection locality of the holotype and four paratypes was incorrectly reported as 44°32.5' S, 166°41' E which is in depths of several thousand metres; it should be 46°32.5' S, 166°41' E.
he taxonomy for this species was recently resolved and described. Specifically it is distinct from congeners in the Coral Sea.
The Kermadec Spiny Dogfish (Squalus raoulensis) is superficially very similar to the Northern Spiny Dogfish (S. griffini) but is a member of the S. megalops–cubensis species complex.

Somniosus longus from the Pacific Ocean has long been considered a synonym of S. rostratus from the Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean Sea (Compagno 1984, Francis et al. 1988, Compagno 1999). Yano et al. (2004) resurrected S. longus on the basis of several morphological and meristic characters. However their sample sizes of S. longus and S. rostratus were too small to properly define the range of variation in these characters, so their conclusion needs verification using larger sample sizes and preferably DNA analyses. Nevertheless, S. longus has been considered valid by recent authors (Ebert et al. 2013).

Brochiraja aenigma remains poorly defined. A recent trawl survey to the type locality provided no additional specimens. Hence, its generic placement is provisional because features of adult males are unknown, and the only known female lacks a rostral thorn and is in a poor state of preservation. Within the southwest Pacific it is unique in appearance having a rounded disc covered in very fine granular denticles, a very long tail, and high meristic values (Last and McEachran 2006).

authority: Barbosa du Bocage & de Brito Capello, 1864

taxonomicNotes: The Broken Ridge Skate (Notoraja lira) is a recently described species (McEachran and Last 2008).

The Sapphire Skate (Notoraja sapphira) was first documented in 1996, when a single specimen was collected on the Norfolk Ridge, and thought to be a member of the genus Pavoraja (Séret in Grandperrin et al. 1997). In 2006, four more specimens were collected, and it was determined that the specimens were all part of the genus Notoraja (Last and Séret in Anonymous 2006). The Sapphire Skate was described from these five specimens, and comparison with its closest congener, Blue Skate (N. azurea), found the two species to be distinct.

The Northern Spiny Dogfish (Squalus griffini) is a member of the S. mitsukurii species complex (‘mitsukurii-group’).

Garrick (1960) reviewed the Australasian species of Squalus and incorrectly synonymised S. griffini and S. fernandinus Molina, 1782 (sensu Bigelow and Schroeder 1948, 1957) with S. blainvillii (incorrect spelling of S. blainville (Risso, 1827), Eschmeyer 1998). Garrick recognised S. acanthias and S. blainville from New Zealand, and S. acanthias, S. blainville and S. megalops from Australia. Squalus blainville was thought to be widespread in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans (Bigelow and Schroeder 1948, 1957; Garrick 1960). Chen et al. (1979) subsequently defined S. blainville from Japan as a species with high dorsal fins and long dorsal-fin spines. They observed that Squalus, referred to S. fernandinus and S. blainville by Bigelow and Schroeder (1948) and Garrick (1960) had short dorsal-fin spines and were more similar to S. mitsukurii from Japan, and suggested that nominal S. blainville from New Zealand could be identical to S. mitsukurii. Compagno (1984) also noted that dogfishes resembling S. mitsukurii occurred off Australia and New Zealand, and did not recognise S. blainville from the Southern Hemisphere. As a consequence this species was widely synonymised with S. mitsukurii (Paulin et al. 1989, Yano in Amaoka et al. 1990, Roberts 1991, Paul and Heath 1997, Cox and Francis 1997, Anderson et al. 1998, Compagno et al. 2005). Last and Stevens (1994) provisionally mapped New Zealand populations as S. mitsukurii but suggested that regional forms may represent a species complex. This species was formally resurrected and re-described by Duffy and Last (2007).

Genetic evidence indicates that a morphologically inseparable taxon occurring on Gascoyne Seamount, Tasman Seamount Chain, is a distinct species (Ward et al. 2007). Sequencing of the barcode region of mtDNA CO1 by Ward et al. (2007) groups this taxon with Squalus chloroculus but it is morphologically distinct from that species. The only specimen of this taxon is NMNZ P.38327.
Squatina aculeata is difficult to identify to the species level, therefore many of the records from fisher reports are often assigned only to the genus level. Misidentification is common.
Squatina oculata is difficult to identify to the species level, therefore many of the records from fishermen reports are often assigned only to genus level.
Formerly this species was considered a subspecies of Dactyloscopus fimbriatus (Hastings and Springer 2009).

The Chilean Angelshark (Squatina armata), has previously been considered to be conspecific with the Pacific Angelshark (S. californica). Recent molecular evidence places S. armata as the sister taxon to the Neotropical angel sharks, indicating it is a distinct species (Stelbrink et al. 2010). Given its prior taxonomic placement, some literature on the elasmobranch fauna of Peru, Ecuador, and Colombia list S. californica as part of their coastal fauna, while others only mention S. armata. To add to the confusion, some country checklists include both S. armata and S. californica (see Cornejo et al. 2015). These records of S. californica occurring sympatrically with S. armata are likely incorrect, thus for the purpose of this assessment all angel shark records in the Southeast Pacific are considered to be S. armata. Further research is needed to elucidate the distributions of S. armata and S. californica, particularly in the Pacific coast of Central America and the northwest coast of South America.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).
The taxonomy and nomenclature of the Neotrygon kuhlii species-complex has been problematic. It has largely been resolved with the description of several new species (Last et al. 2016).
This species formerly included Teanira lessoni, which is now recognised as a separate species (Last et al. 2016).
Taeniura lessoni Last, White & Naylor, 2016 has recently been described as distinct from the wide-ranging T. lymma (Forsskål, 1775).

This species has strong molecular divergence from the once conspecific Coach Whipray (Himantura uarnak) and from another reticulate whipray, Honeycomb Whipray (Himantura undulata) (Last et al. 2016a). It can be morphologically distinguished from the Coach Whipray by a more pronounced reticulate pattern in adults, with work to elucidate smaller individuals still in progress, and it can be distinguished from the Honeycomb Whipray by smaller reticulations and a lack of suprascapular denticles (Last et al. 2016a).
This species belongs to the small, recently designated Telagtrygon genus that consists of four species in the tropical Indo-Pacific (Last et al. 2016a).
Scymnodon plunketi may be a junior synonym of Centroscymnus macracanthus (White et al. 2015). Taxonomic clarification is required.

Torpedo fairchildi and Torpedo macneilli were recently synonymized with the Great Torpedo Ray (Torpedo nobiliana) and the Western Atlantic Torpedo Ray (Tetronarce occidentalis) is now recognized as a valid species based on molecular data (Carvalho et al. 2016).
Previously included within Tetronarce nobiliana, T. occidentalis is now recognised as a separate species (Carvalho et al. 2016).

Until this species' formal description in 2016 (Acero et al. 2016), angel sharks caught in the southern Caribbean were thought to be Squatina dumeril. Further work is needed to determine whether and where the ranges of these two species overlap.
The genus Icthyophaga (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously spelled Ichthyophaga.
Suttonia lineata is a sister species of S.suttoni (Randall and Baldwin 1997).

Eviota nigripinna resembles E. nebulosa but differs in its pelvic fin ray count, a solid dark first dorsal fin in males, having uniform predorsal bars, trunk coloration uniform brownish, a central peduncle spot, and scale pockets are not outlined (Lachner and Karnella 1980).

Viana and de Carvalho (2018) propose S. rancureli as a junior synonym of S. melanurus, however the reported differences in colour pattern, morphology and mersitics indicate that further sampling, and a genetic comparison of the two nominal species is needed to support their synonymy. The distributions of Squalus melanurus and S. rancureli also need to be clarified through examination of collected materials. The correct taxonomic authority for this species requires clarification.

Angel sharks (Squatina spp.) in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean are difficult to identify to species level, therefore many of the records from fishermen reports in the Mediterranean are often assigned only to genus level. Squatina squatina is the only species to occur in the Northeast Atlantic from Portugal northwards.

The Mediterranean Monk Seal (Monachus monachus) is the sole representative of the genus Monachus (Scheel et al. 2014). Differences in skull morphology between Mediterranean Monk Seals from the Atlantic and the western Mediterranean, including differences in the occurrence of dental aberrations, have been suggested based on a limited sample size (van Bree 1979). Examination of mitochondrial DNA has also indicated genetic differences between Atlantic and eastern Mediterranean Monk Seal populations: only one haplotype was found in Monk Seals in Madeira and Cabo Blanco in the Atlantic in contrast to four different haplotypes found in Monk Seals in the eastern Mediterranean (i.e., Libya, Croatia, and Greece; Karamanlidis et al. 2014a). Furthermore, a comparison of 24 nuclear microsatellite loci in eastern Mediterranean and western Sahara (Atlantic) Monk Seals showed that the first group had 14 unique alleles and the second had 18; highly significant differences in allele frequencies between the two subpopulations were found for 14 out of 17 loci (Pastor et al. 2007). All this suggests substantial (genetic) differentiation between subpopulations, but to date, no separation of this species has been suggested taxonomically.
Oxuderces dentatus has recently been split from Oxuderces nexipinnis, and is now just restricted to China (Jafaar and Parenti 2016).
The generic level placement of this species needs further research; it is probably not a member of the genus Oligolepis (H.K. Larson pers. comm. 2017).
Previously identified as Tomiyamichthys fourmanoiri, but has been found to be a different species more similar to T. smithi (Bogorodsky et al. 2011).
This species was the previous identification of Tomiyamichthys dorsostigma (Bogorodsky et al. 2011). Tomiyamichthys dorsostigma in the Gulf of Aqaba may be this species.
This species has been confused with Trimma macrophthalma in some cases (Winterbottom in prep. 2017)

This species was previously regarded as a synonym of Epinephelus chlorostigma, but was recognized as a valid species by Randall et al. (2013). It replaces E. chlorostigma in the Red Sea, but the two species are sympatric in the western Gulf of Aden. Epinephelus geoffroyi is very similar and likely to be confused with E. gabriellae and E. polylepis (Randall and Heemstra 1991).

Phylogenetic reconstruction has identified the Red Sea taxon Plectropomus pessuliferus marisrubri as a distinct species and sister species to P. laevis with a geographic distribution restricted to the Red Sea.

This species is similar in appearance to, and has been treated as, Epinephelus amblycephalus in the past. The two species are both found in deep waters of the Indo-Pacific and have overlapping ranges in some areas (Tucker et al. 2016).
This species was previously considered a synonym of Epinephelus bruneus (Liu et al. 2013).

Dooley and Iwatsuki (2012) considered this species to be nomen dubium; however, one specimen questionably identified as this species is catalogued as USNM 402156 (accessed via FishNet2 portal, www.fishnet2.net, March 2017).
Dooley and Iwatsuki (2012) considered this species to be nomen dubium.
Alaudala raytal (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Calandrella raytal.

Poodytes gramineus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Megalurus gramineus. 
Plumage pattern and biogeography suggest ancestral link with P. punctatus of New Zealand, and possibly also with Madagascar’s Amphilais (now Bradypterus) seebohmi. Validity of poorly known subspecies papuensis doubted in past, but separating characters have recently been confirmed and the taxon may merit further attention given its isolation (Beehler & Pratt 2016). Subspecies thomasi sometimes included in nominate (Johnstone & Storr 2004). Four subspecies recognised.
Corvus orru and C. insularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. orru following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Poecile palustris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus palustris.
Stelgidopteryx serripennis and S. ridgwayi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. serripennis following AOU (1998 and supplements) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Poodytes punctatus and P. caudatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Bowdleria punctata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Turbott (1990).
Prosobonia cancellata and P. parvirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. cancellata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Halcyon smyrnensis and H. gularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as H. smyrnensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hirundo tahitica and H. domicola (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped, and subsequently split into H. tahitica and H. javanica following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).
Diaphus burtoni is the senior synonym of D. bryani, also known only from the Philippines (Paxton 1979).
This species has previously been considered a junior synonym of O. acutipennis, but is recognized as valid by Pezold and Larson (2015).
The genus Sarcocornia A.J. Scott was merged under Salicornia L. by Piirainen et al. in 2017.

Rhynchobatus djiddensis is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.
Brachionichthys australis and B. hirsutus are similar in appearance, but are confirmed to be separate species (Last et al. 2007).
The genus Gyrinomimus is being revised by John Paxton (Moore et al. 2003).
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.
This species was previously referred to as Lophotus lacepede on the west coast of North America (Craig et al. 2004, Kells et al. 2016).

Historically, it has been proposed that American Eels (Anguilla rostrata) and European Eels (A. anguilla) may be conspecific (vertebral count differences were believed to be entirely ecophenotypic); this has now been shown to be incorrect by several studies. Separate species status has been confirmed by demonstrations that American and European Eels comprise two largely separate gene pools (see Avise et al. 1990, Bastrop et al. 2000, Avise 2003, Bernatchez et al. 2011). Eels in Iceland include, in low frequency, the products of hybridisation between American and European Eels (Avise et al. 1990, Avise 2003, Albert et al. 2006, Pujolar et al. 2014). Phylogenies of the genus Anguilla based on mitochondrial DNA have shown the two species to be distinct, although more closely related than most species of the genus (Aoyama et al. 2001, Minegishi et al. 2005).

Individuals from India and Indonesia appear to be genetically distinct from individuals from South Africa and Madagascar (BOLD www.barcodinglife.org, double check correct citation); additional material is needed to determine whether these specimens represent two distinct species and to determine the limits of their respective distributions.
Halieutaea liogaster was listed as junior synonym of H. fitzsimonsi, but is now recognized as valid in a forthcoming publication (H. Ho pers. comm. 2019)

Due to various issues with the identification of the type species of Paludinella littorina, the next available name is taken: P. globularis. Of course, the type locality changes also, from near Naples to Weymouth.

Kadolsky (2012) has shown that the real Helix littorina Delle Chiaje, 1828, was most probably based on small specimens of Melarhaphe neritoides (Linnaeus, 1758). However, Pfeiffer (1841) based the genus Paludinella on the taxonomic extension given to that name by Philippi (1836), i.e., a misidentified type species. For Paludinella littorina of authors, non Delle Chiaje, Kadolsky restored the name Paludinella globularis and, under Art. 70.3 of the Code, designated the latter as type species of Paludinella.
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).
This species is very similar to Anotopterus pharao and may need further taxonomic investigation (Mundy 2005).
Recent molecular systematics work by Ghedotti et al. (2015) placed this species in the family Paralepididae.

Taxonomic work is needed to resolve the validity of records from further south in the Cocos Islands, the Galapagos and Ecuador that may represent a separate, undescribed species (Robertson and Allen 2015). Thompson (1998) provided a redescription of this species, wherein records from Ecuador and the Galapagos were considered valid as Aulopus bajacali.
Further taxonomic work is needed to determine the differences between this species and Hime formosanus (Prokofiev 2012).
Further taxonomic work is needed to determine the differences between this species and Hime diactithrix (Prokofiev 2012).
Records from Australia, New Caledonia, New Zealand and the Hawaiian Islands are now considered a separate species (Gomon et al. 2013, Gomon and Struthers 2015).
This species is sometimes confused with Chlorophthalmus nigromarginatus (Gomon 2015).
This species has been confused with Chlorophthalmus pectoralis at times (Gomon 2015).

This species is listed as valid by Sato and Nakabo (2002) and Kobyliansky (2013) without explanation. Previously, the species was considered a synonym of Chlorophthalmus agassizi, and further taxonomic work is needed to resolve its validity.
Chlorophthalmus bicornis is now considered a synonym of C. corniger (Bineesh et al. 2014).
This species was previously considered a synonym of Chlorophthalmus agassizi (Sato and Nakabo 2002).
This species was once considered a synonym of Ipnops agassizii (Sulak 1990).
This species can be easily misidentified as Scopelosaurus harryi, and some workers have considered it a synonym of S. harryi previously (Balanov and Savinykh 1999, Milkova et al. 2016).
This species can be easily confused with Scopelosaurus hamiltoni (Stewart 2015).
This species can be easily confused with Scopelosaurus adleri (Milkova et al. 2016).

This species was described on the basis of a single juvenile specimen, which is in very poor condition now. Based on the position of dorsal and pelvic fins and the vertebral counts, it belongs to the Lestidium atlanticum species complex, and if valid, this is comprised of at least four distinct species. Moreover, many publications confuse this species with Lestidiops jayakari, which is also an unresolved complex (H. Ho pers. comm. 2019).
The holotype of this species was originally designated as a paratype of Lestidiops pacificus described by Parr (1931).

Harry (1953) reported that the two known types were not conspecific and recognized the holotype as a valid species and the paratype was described as a new species, Lestidium neles (now Lestidiops neles). Some records from the western Pacific Ocean were confused with Lestidiops jayakari (H. Ho pers. comm. 2019).

This species was originally recognized as Lestidium nudum and described as new by Harry (1953). It represents a species complex that is comprised of more than four morphologically similar species, and this is currently under study (H. Ho pers. comm. 2019).
This species belongs in the genus Lestidiops, and should be considered a valid species (Ho and Golani 2019, H. Ho pers. comm. 2019).
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.
This species may have been previously identified as Notolepis coatsi.
This species may belong in the genus Lestidiops. The taxonomy of Lestidiops is quite confused and a complete revision is needed (H. Ho pers. comm. 2019).
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.
This species was previously in the genus Chlorophthalmus (Sato and Nakabo 2002).
The genus of this species was changed from Benthalbella to Lagiacrusichthys according to Davis (2015).
This species possibly represents another species of Harpadon, pending further taxonomic study we provisionally recognise it as distinct here (B. Russell pers. comm.).

This species is part of a complex of several species of Saurida that have very short pectoral fins. Its taxonomic position is currently subject to ongoing study but the name argentea is one of the oldest available names for the complex and for the present we recognise it as a valid species (B. Russell pers. comm. 2019).
This species has been confused with the closely-related Saurida undosquamis and is currently subject of taxonomic review (B.C. Russell pers. comm. 2019).

This distinctive species has very long pectoral fins and is not easily confused with other species of Saurida. However, individuals from the Red Sea appear to be genetically distinct from individuals from the rest of its distribution (B. Russell unpublished data); additional material is needed to determine whether these specimens represent two distinct species and to determine the limits of their respective distributions.

Russell et al. (2015) regarded S. macrolepis as restricted to the Western Pacific, and described a new species, S. lessepsianus, for the species previously identified in the Western Indian Ocean as S. macrolepis or S. undosquamis. However, the exact distribution of S. macrolepis remains uncertain, and further research is needed.
This species was previously considered a synonym of Saurida brasiliensis, but is now considered valid according to Russell (2016).
This species has been misidentified as Saurida filamentosa by some authors. All records of S. filamentosa from Japan, China and Taiwan should represent S. wanieso (B. Russell pers. comm. 2019).

Synodus houlti was previously synonymised with S. variegatus by Cressey 1981 and others, but was considered as a possibly distinct species by Waples and Randall 1988. It is here regarded as a valid species, but further taxonomic work is needed.
This species was previously identified as Synodus lobeli (Randall and Pyle 2008).
In the Red Sea, Baranes and Golani (1993) mistakenly reported this species as Synodus doaki (Randall 2009).
This species was previously misidentified as Synodus macrocephalus (Ho et al. 2010).

The nearly circumtropical T. myops was recently separated into three valid species: T. myops, restricted to the Atlantic Ocean; T. trachinus, known from throughout the Indo-West Pacific; and T. gauguini restricted to the Marquesas Islands (Polanco et al. 2016).

The nearly circumtropical T. myops was recently separated into three valid species: T. myops, restricted to the Atlantic Ocean; T. trachnius, known from throughout the Indo-West Pacific; and T. gauguini known from the Marquesas Islands (Polanco et al. 2016) and New Ireland, PNG (Wang et al. 2018). However, more recent genetic analyses suggest that this may actually consist of several cryptic species in the Western Indian Ocean (B. Russell unpublished data). More research is needed to resolve this.

According to Moore (2002), this species is only known from juvenile specimens and some specimens identified as Anoplogaster cornuta may be adult forms of A. brachycera. The validity of this species is in question due to recent genetic analyses (J. Moore pers. comm. 2018).
This species is often misidentified as Centroberyx affinis (Roberts and Gomon 2008).
Some workers suspect this species may be a synonym of Centroberyx druzhinini (Randall and Lim 2000).

There is some question as to whether this is a junior synonym of Hoplostethus atlanticus, as the features to distinguish H. fragilis from H. atlanticus are mostly minor differences, but without the specimens to examine, it is difficult to conclusively show this (J. Moore pers. comm. 2019).

Although originally described as in the genus Paratrachichthys, this species has the striated tubular light organs found in Aulotrachichthys. The three Paratrachichthys species all lack these tubular light organs. The genus name here should be changed to Aulotrachichthys (J. Moore pers. comm. 2019).

Since there is no published or in prep. taxonomic publications to support the genus name change, the original name is retained in the IUCN Red List, with Aulotrachichthys sajademalensis included as a synonym. If a taxonomic revision is accepted and published, the IUCN Red List will be updated then.
The genus Gyrinomimus is being revised by John Paxton (Moore et al. 2003).

The taxonomy of Lophotus species remains uncertain due to the lack of type specimens, comparative material and oversight of previous taxonomic treatment. This species was previously considered a synonym of Lophotus lacepedei by Goin and Erdman (1951), but further analyses by Craig et al. (2004) established it as a valid separate species. The examination of additional specimens of this species is needed (Craig et al. 2004, Koeda and Ho 2017).

The taxonomy of Lophotus species remains uncertain due to the lack of type specimens, comparative material and oversight of previous taxonomic treatment (Craig et al. 2004). It has been suggested that Lophotus machadoi may be a synonym of L. lacepede, and its taxonomy requires further investigation (Menezes et al. 2003, Koeda and Ho 2017).
<span id="docs-internal-guid-e6ed6f2f-7fff-9395-dbf2-3c47860e8647">There are very few intact specimens of this species, which has caused some confusion when classifying individuals.
Savinykh and Baitalyuk (2011) suggested Trachipterus altivelis is a junior synonym of T. trachypterus, but this requires further study.

There is taxonomic confusion amongst species in the Trachipteridae family (Scott 1983, Martin 2015). The taxonomic status of Trachipterus arawatae appears uncertain. Scott (1983) recognized T. arawatae as a senior synonym of T. jacksonensis, while Heemstra and Kannemeyer (1984) recognized T. arawatae as a junior synonym of T. trachypterus (Martin 2015, Roberts et al. 2015).
The Trachipterus genus is in need of revision (Savinykh and Baitalyuk 2011). Savinykh and Baitalyuk (2011) and Martin (2015) consider T. ishikawae a junior synonym of T. trachypterus.
This species
<span id="docs-internal-guid-39cb8422-7fff-0882-ba8c-052d6bbd6d58">The family Veliferidae is in need of revision (Olney 1999).
<span id="docs-internal-guid-5f2a9be7-7fff-2c96-12ab-c53c97d0c116">The family Veliferidae is in need of revision (Olney 1999).
Synonyms of this species include Dules maculatus Valenciennes 1831 (Sulawesi) and Dules papuensis Macleay, 1884 (New Guinea).
This species was originally described from the Ganges river system in India. It is likely to be a species-complex, with work presently ongoing (D.F. Hoese pers. comm. 2018).
This species is often referred to in older literature as Ophieleotris aporos. There are at least three species under this name and further research is needed.
The name of this species has been mis-used for a long time.

Using combined genetic analyses, Morgan et al. (2016) confirmed the presence of genetically distinctive western and eastern subpopulations in G. truttaceus, but found no evidence that these subpopulations reflect either different species or subspecies (congruent with morphological data), meeting only part of the genetic criteria for separate evolutionary significant units (ESUs) (McDowall and Frankenberg 1981, Morgan et al. 2016). These authors state that the western populations do merit recognition as discrete ESUs when the definition of an ESU is broadened to include ecological criteria, namely, the unique ecology of western populations as a signal of evolutionary divergence and regional adaptation (see Morgan 2003, Morgan et al. 2016).

This species is similar in appearance and may have been confused in the past with Brachionichthys hirsutus (Last et al. 2007). A molecular study of subpopulations across the range of B. australis may reveal additional species (Last and Gledhill 2009).
The Pezichthys species as a group are relatively newly described, and further taxonomic resolution is needed (Last and Gledhill 2009).
The Pezichthys species as a group are relatively newly described, and further taxonomic resolution is needed (Last and Gledhill 2009).
The Pezichthys species as a group are relatively newly described, and further taxonomic resolution is needed (Last and Gledhill 2009).
The Pezichthys species as a group are relatively newly described, and need further taxonomic resolution (Last and Gledhill 2009).
The Pezichthys species as a group are relatively newly described, and need further taxonomic resolution (Last and Gledhill 2009).
The genus Thymichthys is relatively new, and needs further taxonomic resolution (Last and Gledhill 2009).

A molecular study of subpopulations across the range of Thymichthys verrucosus may reveal additional species (Last and Gledhill 2009). Based on some morphological differences, it is possible that T. verrucosus represents two species: one in the west and one in the east (P. Last pers. comm. 2018).
This species was previously confused with P. variabilis (Jafaar et al. 2009).
This species has possibly been misidentified as D. kurroides or D. tabl in the past (Kimura et al. 2013).

This species was previously considered a synonym of P. dentex (Bloch & Schneider 1801 (Springer and Smith-Vaniz 2008, Eschmeyer et al. 2017). Genetic studies may be needed to resolve the taxonomic confusion (Randall and Cea 2011). However, until more information is available, it is treated here as a valid species.

This species was previously considered a junior synonym of Seriola lalandi, until Martinez-Takeshita et al. (2015) considered it to be distinct based on genetic data. Evidence reported by Purcell et al. (2015) reinforces the distinctiveness of these populations.

This species was previously considered a junior synonym of Seriola lalandi, until Martinez-Takeshita et al. (2015) considered it to be distinct based on genetic data. Evidence reported by Purcell et al. (2015) reinforces the distinctiveness of these populations, but further research is needed to improve the spatial resolution of genetic structure in some regions.

Parin (1991) states that there are some morphological differences between three geographic localities that have been reported as P. rubiginosum, but given the limited material available did not make any formal distinctions. At this time, P. rubiginosum is considered widely distributed in the southern Indo-Pacific, but additional taxonomic work is needed (Trnski 2015).

This species will  be synonomized as Yongeichthys signatus (H. Larson in press) based on Zeehan Jaffar research. Acentrogobius madraspatensis has also been synonymized as Yongeichthys signatus (Z. Jaafar in prep).
The taxonomic status of this nominal species requires clarification (H.K. Larson pers. comm. 2019).
This species may be a synonym of Amblyeleotris triguttata (Randall 1994). However, the type specimen is in poor condition, and it is not possible to confirm if it should be synonomized.
This species was recently assigned to the genus Aulopareia from Parachaeturichthys (Zare et al. 2012).
This species has previously been confused with Gobiodon albolineatus, especially in the Indian Ocean (Winterbottom and Emery 1986).
This species may belong to another genus (Larson pers. comm. 2018). The name has been used to described to many populations, that appear to be disparate.
May be a subspecies of Mesogobius batrachocephalus (Coad 1995).
This species taxonomy is uncertain. The type specimens are in poor condition, which has made identification of this species difficult (Larson pers comm. 2018).

Diagramma labiosum has been treated as a subspecies of D. pictum, but is currently considered valid at the species level (Eschmeyer et al. 2018). Genetic data suggest that this species may be the same as D. pictum and D. melanocrum (K. Carpenter unpublished data). Addition research is needed to resolve these three nominal species.
Hung et al. 2017 suggests three distinct lineages within specimens identified as P. inermis; however, further taxonomic work is required.
This species was redescribed by Mooi (1995).
This species can be easily confused with Priacanthus hamrur if specimens are not freshly caught (Starnes 1988, Motomura et al. 2001).

The Oman subpopulation was previously thought to represent a separate species from that in Kenya (Gill and Mee 1993, Gill 2003), but current knowledge indicates a single widespread population from Oman to Kenya (Gill and Zajonz 2011).
This species closely resembles Pseudochromis kristinae and was previously misidentified as P. natalensis (Gill 2003).
This species closely resembles and has been confused variously with P. kristinae, P. madascarensis and P. taubare (Gill 2004).
This species closely resembles and has previously been confused with P. linda (Gill 2004).
This species closely resembles Pseudochromis natalensis, P. kristinae and P. madagascariensis (Gill 2003).
Bothus swio most closely resembles B. guibei, B. panterinus, and B. tricirrhitus. In addition, it also resembles species within the genus Grammatobothus (Hensley 1997).
Engyprosopon mozambiquensis closely resembles E. natalensis (Hensley 2003).

Laeops natalensis Norman 1931 was described based on two specimens collected off KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. No additional specimens have been reported to date. Voronina et al. (2020), in the most recent revision of the genus Laeops, considered L. sinusarabici from the Red Sea to be the junior subjective synonym of Laeops natalensis Norman 1931. However, several morphological differences (albeit small) were noted between the holotype of L. natalensis from off South Africa and specimens (including types) of L. sinusarabici from the Red Sea. Given the large geographic distance between capture sites of these nominal species, the difference in the depths of capture, and the fact that the Red Sea is a renowned area of endemism for fishes, both nominal species are treated herein as valid and separate conservation assessments are required.

Laeops sinusarabici Chabaunaud 1968 was described based on specimens collected in the Red Sea. This nominal species was synonymized with Grammatobothus krempfi Chabanaud 1929 by Desoutter et al. (2001) without detailed comment regarding this decision. Later authors (e.g., Bogorodsky et al. 2014, Bogorodsky and Randall 2018, Golani and Fricke 2018) considered L. sinusarabici to be a valid species, endemic to the Red Sea.

In the most recent revision of the genus Laeops, Voronina et al. (2020) considered L. sinusarabici to be the junior subjective synonym of Laeops natalensis Norman 1931 from off South Africa. However, several morphological differences (albeit small) were noted between the holotype of L. natalensis from off South Africa and specimens (including types) of L. sinusarabici from the Red Sea. Given the large geographic distance between capture sites of these nominal species, the difference in the depths of capture, and the fact that the Red Sea is a renowned area of endemism for fishes, both nominal species are treated herein as valid and separate conservation assessments are required.
Voronina et al. (2020) considered Laeops cypho Fowler 1934 to be a junior subjective synonym of Neolaeops microphthalmus (von Bonde 1922). This taxonomic decision is followed herein.

According to Hoshino (2001), the citharid genus Paracitharus Regan 1920 is sometimes mistaken as the synonym of Citharoides Hubbs 1915 (e.g. Chapleau 1993). He reports that this idea can be traced back to Norman (1934), who synonymized C. macrolepidotus Hubbs 1915 with Arnoglossus macrolepis Gilchrist 1904, which was later transferred to Paracitharus. Norman (1934) applied the name Citharoides macrolepis (Gilchrist 1904) as the senior synonym. 

Hubbs (1945) recognized both species and genera as valid based on differences in the canal shape on their posterior lateral line scales. Hoshino (2001) confirmed these observations and concluded that it was incorrect to synonymize Paracitharus with Citharoides. However, this systematic decision has not been accepted by all subsequent authors (e.g. Choi et al. 2003, Hoese and Bray 2006, Fricke et al. 2018). Following the morphological data presented in Hubbs (1945) and Hoshino (2001), Paracitharus is herein recognized as a valid genus, distinct from Citharoides, with its type species, P. macrolepis (Gilchrist 1904).

This species is sometimes referred to in the literature as Cynoglossus ecaudatus (e.g., Menon 1977, Yokogawa et al. 2008). Cynoglossus natalensis, described from off Natal, South Africa, is considered a junior subjective synonym of C. acaudatus by Menon (1977). Cynoglossus hunteri, described from Point Vermetha, Mozambique, was also placed in synonymy of C. acaudatus by Menon (1977).
There is some confusion between Cynoglossus semifasciatus and C. macrostomus (R. Nair pers. comm. 2019).
Menon (1980) synonymized several nominal species under the name Paraplagusia bilineata Bloch 1787. The status of these nominal species needs to be re-evaluated (T.A. Munroe pers. comm. 2020).

Symphurus microrhynchus was described based on a single specimen collected in the Java Sea at a depth of 82 m (Weber 1913). A second specimen was taken off Indonesia (Koumans 1953). Munroe and Marsh (1997) redescribed S. microrhynchus based on 11 specimens collected at different localities ranging from Tanzania to French Polynesia, including the holotype of S. holothuriae, which they considered to be a junior subjective synonym of S. microrhynchus. Subsequent study (Lee and Munroe unpublished data) re-examined these specimens and discovered that actually seven different species were represented in the material, including S. microrhynchus, S. holothuriae and five undescribed species. Lee and Munroe (unpublished data) provide a redescription of S. microrhynchus and limited the known material of this species to the holotype and the specimen mentioned in Koumans (1953).
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.
The taxonomy of species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.
This species was previously placed in the genus Solea; Vachon et al. (2008) elevated the genus Barnardichthys to accommodate this species.
Western Indian Ocean reports of Achirus pavoninus are actually records of Pardachirus morrowi (Randall and Johnson 2007).

Cantor (1849) considered Brachirus Swainson 1839 to be preoccupied by Brachyrus Swainson 1838 and proposed the replacement name Synaptura. Subsequently, Brachirus Swainson was determined to be a valid genus name (Jordan 1923). Bleeker (1875) distinguished Brachirus Swainson from Synaptura, but did not designate a type species. Later, Chabanaud (1928) restricted the name Synaptura to accommodate four nominal species of elongate soles, Synaptura albomaculata Kaup 1858, Pleuronectes commersonnii Lacepede 1802, S. lusitanica Brito Capello 1868, and S. marginata Boulenger 1900.


Desoutter et al. (2001) commented that Synaptura sensu Chabanaud was not a valid genus name. In a revision of members of the genus Synaptura sensu Chabanaud, Vachon et al. (2007) also stated that Synaptura sensu Chabanaud was not valid. Based on the results of their study, the five nominal species (including Synaptura cadenati Chabanaud 1948) formally placed in Synaptura sensu Chabanaud were found to be closely related to Dagetichthys lakdoensis Stauch and Blanc 1964 and they transferred these species to Dagetichthys.

Cantor (1849) considered Brachirus Swainson 1839 to be preoccupied by Brachyrus Swainson 1838 and proposed the replacement name Synaptura. Subsequently, Brachirus Swainson was determined to be a valid genus name (Jordan 1923). Bleeker (1875) distinguished Brachirus Swainson from Synaptura, but did not designate a type species. Later, Chabanaud (1928) restricted the name Synaptura to accommodate four nominal species of elongate soles, Synaptura albomaculata Kaup 1858, Pleuronectes commersonnii Lacepede 1802, S. lusitanica Brito Capello 1868, and S. marginata Boulenger 1900. 


Desoutter et al. (2001) commented that Synaptura sensu Chabanaud was not a valid genus name. In a revision of members of the genus Synaptura sensu Chabanaud, Vachon et al. (2007) also stated that Synaptura sensu Chabanaud was not valid. Based on the results of their study, the five nominal species (including Synaptura cadenati Chabanaud 1948) formally placed in Synaptura sensu Chabanaud were found to be closely related to Dagetichthys lakdoensis Stauch and Blanc 1964 and they transferred these species to Dagetichthys. This decision is followed herein.

The taxonomic status of this species and Zebrias annularis needs to be investigated (T. Munroe and R. Nair pers. comm. 2019). At present, both nominal species are considered valid (Fricke et al. 2019).
Dolphins of the genus Orcaella were split into two species by Beasley et al. (2002, 2005), the Irrawaddy Dolphin (Orcaella brevirostris) and the Snubfin Dolphin (O. heinsohni).

This species was listed in the 1996-2002 IUCN Red Lists under the family Platanistidae. It is now most commonly assigned to the family Pontoporiidae, and at least sometimes in the superfamily Inioidea (Muizon et al. 2017).

The Sousa teuszii holotype (a skull) was recovered in the “Bucht des Kameruner Kriegsshiffhafens,” (“Bay of Warships” or ‘Man O’War Bay’), in Cameroon by the German agronomist Eduard Tëusz. The German zoologist Willy Kükenthal examined it at Jena and described it as the new species Sotalia teuszii in honour of its discoverer (Kükenthal 1891, Kükenthal 1892, Van Beneden 1892, Ayissi et al. 2014). The species was originally placed in the genus Sotalia; the genus name Sousa came into general use only in the 1960s (Fraser and Purves 1960, Fraser 1966). Thorough reviews of the species taxonomy are provided by Van Waerebeek et al. (2004) and Jefferson and Rosenbaum (2014). Photographs of the holotype are provided by Kükenthal (Table 21, Kükenthal 1892), Pilleri and Gihr (1972) and Jefferson and Van Waerebeek (2004). Illustrations of the holotype were provided by Van Beneden (1892). The holotype is now held by the British Museum (catalogue number 1893.8.1.1).

The collection details for the holotype are unclear but were of consequence. The dolphin skull and a shark-mauled carcass of a West African manatee were apparently recovered by Tëusz following a heavy rain storm and were subsequently confused (Van Waerebeek et al. 2004). The stomach of the manatee contained vegetable matter, leading Kükenthal to hypothesize that the species was perhaps riparian and vegetarian, an impression reinforced by the dolphin’s rounded (worn) teeth. The Belgian zoologist Pierre Joseph Van Beneden (with whom Kükenthal corresponded) compounded the misunderstanding in a separate publication (Kükenthal 1891, Kükenthal 1892, Van Beneden 1892, Van Waerebeek et al. 2004). Necropsies of fresh animals in the 1950s confirmed that they were piscivorous and marine (Cadenat 1956, Cadenat and Paraiso 1957).

Recent genetic and morphometric work has served to clarify the taxonomy of the genus Sousa (Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014, Jefferson and Van Waerebeek 2004, Mendez et al. 2013). The available data indicate that there is “strong and significant genetic and morphologic differentiation between S. teuszii and all other sampling units…with no evidence of exchange or contact” (Mendez et al. 2013). Principal components analysis demonstrated that S. teuszii have significantly shorter rostra, wider skulls and lower tooth counts (an average of about 30 teeth per row vs. about 33-37 for other species) when compared with Southeast African, Arabian/Persian Gulf and Indian Sousa specimens (Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014, Jefferson and Van Waerebeek 2004). There are no shared mtDNA haplotypes with other species in the genus, but a phylogenetic assessment of combined nuclear and mtDNA datasets indicates that S. teuszii is most closely related to Indian Ocean Humpback Dolphins (Sousa plumbea) from South East Africa (Mendez et al. 2013). The most plausible mechanism for their isolation is the Benguela upwelling system, an area dominated by cold upwelling that is located within the ~2,000 km distribution gap between S. teuszii and S. plumbea (Jefferson and Van Waerebeek 2004, Mendez et al. 2013).

Until 2005, the genus Orcaella was considered monotypic, with the Irrawaddy Dolphin (Orcaella brevirostris) being the only species (Rice 1998). In 2005, a study on the external and skull morphology, colour pattern, and mitochondrial DNA control region using samples from much of the genus’s range, showed that the Orcaella in Australia differ from those elsewhere and they are now regarded as a separate species, the Australian Snubfin Dolphin (Orcaella heinsohni) (Beasley et al. 2005). No subspecies are recognised.

Recent genetic analyses including samples from Papua New Guinea, and new samples from northern Australia (including the type specimen of O. heinsohni), confirmed the occurrence of the Australian Snubfin Dolphin in at least southern Papua New Guinea (Beasley et al. 2017).

Until recently, all Indian and Pacific Ocean humpback dolphins were considered to be part of a single widespread and highly-variable species, S. chinensis, whose range extended throughout the coastal rim of the Indian Ocean to the western Pacific, from South Africa in the west to northern Australia and central China in the east (see for example, Jefferson and Karczmarski 2001). However, there has long been a suspicion that the form with a distinctive dorsal hump and restricted to the Indian Ocean may be a distinct species – S. plumbea (see Jefferson and Van Waerebeek 2004). In the last few years, mitochondrial (mt) DNA analyses also suggested that humpback dolphins from Australia (previously also included in the chinensis species) were highly distinct from other Indo-Pacific populations, possibly at the species level (Frere et al. 2008, 2011).

A global study of variation in the genus Sousa, combining data on skull morphology with both mtDNA and nuclear DNA data obtained throughout its range, confirmed that both S. plumbea and the Australian form were in fact distinct species (Mendez et al. 2013). A follow-up paper by Jefferson and Rosenbaum (2014) reviewed all the available taxonomic evidence and nomenclature, and proposed a formal revision of the genus’ taxonomy. In this scheme, humpback dolphins found in the Indian and Pacific oceans are split into three species: S. plumbea (Indian Ocean Humpback Dolphin), found only in the western Indian Ocean; S. chinensis (Indo-Pacific Humpback Dolphin), found in the eastern Indian Ocean and throughout Southeast Asia; and S. sahulensis (Australian Humpback Dolphin), found off northern Australia and southern New Guinea. The Atlantic Humpback Dolphin, S. teuszii, is the fourth species in the genus, found only off West Africa. This view has been accepted by the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (Society for Marine Mammalogy 2014).

There are still several unresolved issues in humpback dolphin taxonomy. Humpback dolphins off Bangladesh have been assumed to correspond to S. chinensis, based on external appearance (primarily the shape of the dorsal fin, absence of a dorsal hump, and similar spotting patterns – see Smith et al. 2008), but recent mtDNA genetic evidence suggests that they do not group with either S. chinensis or S. plumbea, and may in fact be more closely related phylogenetically to S. sahulensis (Amaral et al. 2015). Further work is needed to clarify their taxonomic status, but for this assessment they are provisionally included, with the caveat that future work may very well show them to be of a species separate from S. chinensis. In fact, the taxonomic affinities of humpback dolphins in the entire Bay of Bengal (i.e., eastern India, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and Myanmar) need to be urgently re-examined. There is also still some uncertainty regarding the exact taxonomic status of populations observed in Mainland Malaysia and Borneo (see Minton et al. 2016).

There is extensive geographic variation below the level of the species in S. chinensis, most of it not yet properly documented, and the validity/limits of most proposed subspecies or geographic forms are not yet well known. However, the taxonomic status of the Eastern Taiwan Strait subpopulation has recently been evaluated, and has been proposed to represent a subspecies, S. chinensis taiwanensis Wang et al. 2015. The nominotypological subspecies, S. chinensis chinensis, would then apply to all other animals in the species (Wang et al. 2015). This taxonomic change has been recognized by the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (Society for Marine Mammalogy 2016).

Glyphis gangeticus was originally described from the Hooghly River, India. Records of G. gangeticus are sparse and there have been previous issues with reporting due to misidentification with other carcharhinds, mainly the Bull Shark (Carcharhinus leucas) and Broadfin sharks (Lamiopsis spp.), resulting in historic ambiguities about the range of G. gangeticus. The taxonomic status of the species was recently resolved with Li et al. (2015) demonstrating that G. siamensis and G. fowlerae are synonyms of G. gangeticus. Based on molecular data, there is an undescribed Glyphis species currently known from Bangladesh and Malaysian Borneo (Li et al. 2015).
Haploblepharus edwardsii is commonly misidentified for other Haploblepharus species.

Mustelus mustelus and M. asterias are morphologically similar and may be misidentified. Many early works may refer to either of the two species (Wheeler 1978). Mustelus asterias is distinguished from M. mustleus by a narrower inter-narial space and the presence of white spots on the dorsal and upper lateral sides of the former.

There is a demonstrated high level of contemporary and historical misidentification of unspotted Mustelus asterias as M. mustelus in the Northeast Atlantic Ocean region (Farrell et al. 2009, Farrell 2010). There are no reliably confirmed records of M. mustelus occurring north of Portuguese waters (Farrell 2010). Quignard and Capapé (1972) described a M. mustelus specimen from Portuguese Atlantic Ocean waters based on dermal denticle morphology and this remains the most northerly reliably identified record of this species. Similarly, some misidentification can occur between M. mustelus and M. punctulatus. This is because the black spots on the body are not unique to M. punctulatus and their absence is not diagnostic for M. mustelus. The distance of the nostrils and the shape of the mouth appear to be more useful features to distinguish the two species during fieldwork (Marino et al. 2018).

Taxonomy of the genus Centrophorus has been much controverted during the last fifty years. Part of the confusion has been focused on two species with sessile dermic denticles (thus different from C. squamosus) whose most conspicuous anatomic differences are maximum size and size at sexual maturity. The species assessed here is to be considered the “smaller” species, and has been recently reported under the name of C. granulosus or C. uyato. In Australia, this species has been referred to as C. zeehaani.

Taxonomic confusion comes from a long history of mistakes in the literature but also from a problem of nomenclature. A recent review by White et al. (2013) included a re-description and the settlement of a neotype of the “larger species” as C. granulosus (Bloch and Schneider 1801). Nomenclature status of this species is pending a paper in preparation that is based on classic taxonomy, review of nomenclature and genetic data, and that will also include a re-description of the species (Guallart et al. 2013, Veríssimo et al. 2014).

At present this assessment is presented under the name C. uyato (Rafinesque 1810) pending this review. It must be noted that this species is assumed not to fit the description made as Squalus uyato by Rafinesque (1810) but its first descriptions of reference are those made as Spinax uyatus by Bonaparte (1834) and Müller and Henle (1839) as C. granulosus.

Rhynchobatus laevis is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Rhynchobatus yentinensis Wang, 1933 (described from China) might be applicable to this species or may be a synonym of R. springeri. Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species), and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus fedorovi belongs to the spongiceps-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% total length) and upper labial furrows subequal to, or shorter than the lower furrows.

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus herklotsi belongs to the longicephalus-group. This group is characterized by a long, narrow snout (prenarial length >6.4% TL).  A. herklotsi is distinguished from A. longicephalus by the position of the first dorsal fin origin (behind pelvic fin insertion c.f. above pelvic fin base), the spiral valve count (8–12 c.f. 13–17), and a short duodenum as in all other Apristurus species except A. longicephalus (Nakaya 1988, Nakaya 1991, Nakaya and Sato 1999).
Apristurus internatus has been considered a possible junior synonym of Apristurus gibbosus (Nakaya et al. 2008) but is considered valid here.

The genus Apristurus contains at least 39 described species and a number of potentially undescribed ones (Weigmann 2017). Morphological conservatism and, until recently, a lack of objectively defined characters makes this one of the most taxonomically confused shark genera (Compagno 1984, Nakaya and Sato 1999).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus investigatoris belongs to the brunneus-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% TL); 13 to 22 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows; a discontinuous supraorbital sensory canal.

Apristurus atlanticus was previously distinguished from A. laurussonii (Nakaya and Sato 1998), however Iglésias and Nakaya (2004) could not find any significant differences between the holotype of A. atlanticus and A. laurussonii, and therefore consider A. atlanticus to be a junior synonym of A. laurussonii.

Research is required to clarify the taxonomic status of nominal records of A. laurussonii from the US east coast, Gulf of Mexico, and Caribbean (Nakaya and Sato 1998, Kiraly et al. 2003). These records are not considered here to represent A. laurussonii, and as such these regions are not included in this assessment.

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus macrorhynchus belongs to the brunneus-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% total length) and upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows. This species is a local synonym of Broadmouth Catshark (Apristurus macrostomus) in Taiwan (Ebert et al. 2013a, Nakaya and Kawauchi 2013).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). A. macrostomus belongs to the brunneus-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% TL); 13 to 22 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows; a discontinuous supraorbital sensory canal.

Apristurus micropterygeus is unique among the species of Apristurus in having a narrow and sharply pointed first dorsal fin. However, Nakaya and Sato (2000) recommended that the status of the species be reviewed once additional specimens are available, citing the possibility that the dorsal fin of the holotype may have been malformed.

Nominal records of this species from the Eastern Atlantic are possibly A. manis or another species of Apristurus (Ebert and Stehmann 2013). This species is potentially confused with A. laurussoni of which there are only two confirmed records west of Iceland — one from “Davis Strait” on the Canadian side and the other in the Denmark Strait between Iceland and Greenland (Møller et al. 2010).
Weigmann et al. (2020) revised the genus Pliotrema, describing two new species as distinct from P. warreni: P. annae and P. kajae.

A second species of pocket shark, Mollisquama mississippiensis Grace, Doosey, Denton, Naylor, Bart & Maisey, 2019, was recently described from the Gulf of Mexico in the Western Central Atlantic (Grace et al. 2015, Grace et al. 2019). Mollisquama parini Dolganov, 1984 remains known from only the holotype (Dolganov 1984).
No taxonomic notes.

Note that the type locality reported in Compagno (1984) (Stanley, Falkland Islands) is in error and is correctly Challenger Station 311 (52°45.5'S, 73°46'W), which is in the northwestern Strait of Magellan in the Southeast Pacific (coordinates reported by L.J.V. Compagno in a draft manuscript (unpublished), calculated from Günther's station list in the Challenger Reports; Günther 1887).

Compagno (2001) notes that N. Chirichigno (1980, pers. comm. to Compagno 1984) suggested that there may be two species under Heterodontus quoyi, with some differences between the true H. quoyi from the Galápagos Islands and the Peruvian form. Taylor (1972) examined material from both localities and concluded them to be one species. Compagno (2001) follows Taylor (1972).

Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

In Chile, a second rhinobatid species is known from just a dried head: Tarsistes philippi Jordan, 1918. The taxonomic situation of this species is not clear.
this species recently moved from Anacanthobatis to Indobatis (Weigmann et al. 2014).

Specimens from off Somalia formerly identified as this species are in fact of the newly described Vivaldi's Catshark (Bythaelurus vivaldii) (Weigmann and Kaschner 2017). A specimen from off northern Tanzania formerly identified as this species is in fact of the newly described Narrowhead Catshark (Bythaelurus tenuicephalus) (Kaschner et al. 2015).
Dipturus campbelli has previously been incorrectly synonymized with D. pullopunctata (Smith, 1964) by Hulley (1988), but this species is distinct (Compagno et al. 1989, Last et al. 2016).
Formerly known as Rajella leopardus but amended to R. leoparda in accordance with the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (Weigmann et al. 2014).

The holotype and only known specimen of Urobatis marmoratus is missing and the species is unrecognizable from the drawing in the original description (which is from 1892). The species was not treated in Last et al. (2016) but is considered valid by Fricke (2020). Additional specimens are required to confirm its validity.

A species of Amblyraja has been taken around South Georgia Island which appears not to be A. georgiana, but may be either A. frerichsi or A. robertsi (Mike Endicott via M. Stehmann pers. comm. 2004). The occurrence of this species in the Falklands Islands (Malvinas) is uncertain. Since the inception of the longline fishery around the islands in 1994, this species has been captured in the Falklands as the primary skate by-catch, and recorded as A. cf. georgiana (J. Pompert unpubl. data 2020).
A careful examination of North Atlantic vs. southern African forms is needed.

When first redescribed, Urolophus armatus was considered to possibly represent a new genus (Séret and Last 2003). A new genus, Spinilophus, has since been erected for this species as it was unique among the Urolophus in having dorsal denticles and thorns with all other Urolophus devoid of squamation (Yearsley and Last 2016).

Genetic differences have been detected between Taiwanese and Japanese specimens of Urolophus aurantiacus but there are no major morphological or meristic differences and further work is needed to determine if this is a consistent difference (Ebert et al. 2013, Last et al. 2016).

Urobatis concentricus, U. halleri, and U. maculatus have sometimes been considered colour variants of a single species, but molecular studies have shown that these are distinct species (Last et al. 2016).

Urobatis concentricus, U. halleri, and U. maculatus have sometimes been considered colour variants of a single species, but molecular studies have shown that these are distinct species (Last et al. 2016).
This species was previously considered to be conspecific with Aetobatus narutobiei, but the species have since been shown to differ genetically and morphologically (White and Moore 2013).
This species is considered distinct from Aetomylaeus milvus (Last et al. 2016).
Myliobatis chilensis is easily differentiated from the sympatric M. peruvianus by colour and rostral fin form.
Myliobatis peruanus was a misspelling of this species. This species is easily differentiated from the sympatric M. chilensis by colour and rostral fin form.
White (2014) placed the genus Pteromylaeus Garman, 1913 into the synonymy of Aetomylaeus Garman, 1908. This species is often confused with Common Eagle Ray (Myliobatus aquila).

This species is often confused with the sympatric Persian Gulf Torpedo (Torpedo sinuspercisi), though it can be distinguished by a less reticulate dorsal pattern (Last et al. 2016). There is some taxonomic uncertainty with both species possibly part of a species complex (Last et al. 2016).

The distinction between R. atlantica and R. pacifica is problematic and based solely on the number of caudal tubercles, a highly variable and often overlapping characteristic (tends to be greater in R. atlantica). Resolution on the distinction of these two species will require examination of a larger series of specimens and potentially molecular data (Compagno et al. 1990).

Last et al. (2016a) revised the family Dasyatidae, erecting the genus Telatrygon. Telatrygon acutirostra resembles other species of Telatrygon in disc shape and was previously confused with T. zugei but is distinguishable by a longer snout and tail, smaller eyes, and less well developed dorsal tail fold (Last et al. 2016a). Phylogenetic and whole genome analyses indicate that T. acutirostra does not cluster with other species of Telatrygon, hence its placement in the group is provisional pending more detailed anatomical studies (Last et al. 2016a).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status. This species is commonly misidentified as A. blochii.
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status. This species is commonly misidentified as A. annulatus.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

Rhynchobatus springeri is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future. 

Rhynchobatus yentinensis Wang, 1933 (described from China) might be applicable to this species or may be a synonym of R. laevis.
Finucci et al. (2018) redescribed Chimaera ogilbyi, merging Hydrolagus lemures as a synonym.

This species is part of a complex of giant black or purple-black species of Hydrolagus, which includes H. affinis and all 'trolli-like' species from Australia and New Zealand, South Africa, the southern Atlantic, and the California coast including the Davidson and San Juan Seamounts in the Eastern Pacific. The giant black Hydrolagus from the Atlantic is likely Hydrolagus affinis; however, the giant black or purple-black species of Hydrolagus from the Pacific may represent at least two separate species, one of which is H. purpurescens (Gilbert, 1905). Hydrolagus eidolon (Jordan & Hubbs, 1925) described from Sagami Bay, Japan, is here considered a synonym of H. purpurescens.

This species belongs to the long-snout group of Centrophorus which includes C. harrissoni, C. isodon, C. seychellorum, and C. westraliensis. The long-snout species group requires further taxonomic attention (White et al. 2017).
Yano et al. (2004) confirm that sleeper sharks found in the South Atlantic Ocean and Southern Ocean are a separate species, Somniosus antarcticus Whitley, 1939.

Dingerkus and DeFino (1983) synonymized Chiloscyllium caerulopunctatum with C. plagiosum, an action tentatively (and reluctantly) followed by Compagno (2001). The species name is not addressed in Ebert et al. (2013), however, C. caerulopunctatum is considered to be distinct from C. plagiosum and thus a valid species (W. White pers. comm. cited in Weigmann 2016).
Holohalaelurus melanostigma was synonymized with H. punctatus and H. regani until a revision of this genus identified this species as valid (Human 2006).
The West African Catshark has been previously confused with the Nursehound (Scyliorhinus stellaris), which has a more northern distribution.
Heterodontus mexicanus co-occurs with H. francisci in the Gulf of California and these species may be confused in the field. It may be confused with H. quoyi in the southern part of its range.
In geographic regions other than North America sharks referred to as this species are Etmopterus baxteri or Etmopterus unicolor (Compagno and Niem 1998).
The paratype of Bathyraja aguja designated by Kendall and Radcliffe (1912) was found to be distinct and was later described as Bathyraja peruana McEachran & Miyake, 1984.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, but Rhinoraja is now accepted as Bathyraja (Last et al. 2016, Ebert 2016).

While there has been some previous discussion over the validity of Hydrolagus pallidus, recent research confirms that H. pallidus is genetically distinct from H. affinis (Violi et al. 2018). Some genetic evidence suggests H. lusitanicus is synonymous with H. pallidus (Violi et al. 2018).
Some similarity in external morphology may occur with congeneric Richardson's ray Bathyraja richardsoni, with which the distribution and bathymetric ranges overlap.
Appearance is very similar to Hydrolagus pallidus; recent research confirms that H. affinis is genetically distinctive from H. pallidus (Violi et al. 2018).

The Oxynotus recorded as O. centrina from Angola, Namibia, and South Africa may not be that species but an undescribed one, differing from O. centrina in having a much shorter interdorsal space. If this is correct, the records of O. centrina from tropical West Africa need to be reexamined, but until the problem is resolved the southern and southwestern African Oxynotus is retained in O. centrina (Bass et al. 1976).

Previously this species was synonymized with Galeus melastomus, but it is now considered a valid species supported by both morphometric external field marks and genetic evidence (Muñoz-Chapuli and Perez-Ortega 1985, Rey et al. 2005, 2006, 2010; Castilho et al. 2007).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
This species is sometimes called the Spotted Electric Ray, which has resulted in confusion between this species and the Blackspotted Torpedo Ray (Torpedo foscomaculata) (Last et al. 2016).
Moved from Zameus Jordan & Fowler 1903 into Scymnodon Barboza du Bocage & de Brito Capello 1864 by White et al. (2015).
The quality of taxonomic identification of some skate species may be an issue particularly with historic data, however, Bathyraja spinicauda is a relatively easy species to identify.

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species), and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus japonicus belongs to the brunneus-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% total length) and upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows.

There are only two possible specimens from Grand Banks, that have been taken to represent the Western Atlantic. These are likely to be confused with Rajella bathyphila in Canada as older specimens captured there tended to be named Rajella lintea (D. Kulka pers. comm. (20/06/2019).
Anacanthobatis donghaiensis and Anacanthobatis nanhaiensis are now considered junior synonyms of Sinobatis borneensis (Last et al. 2016a, Weigmann 2016).
This species is frequently confused with the Bigtail Skate (Dipturus macrocaudus), particularly at the juvenile stage (Ebert et al. 2013).
White (2014) placed the genus Pteromylaeus Garman, 1913 into synonymy with Aetomylaeus Garman, 1908.
This is the revised taxonomic concept for Scyliorhinus canicula, which now excludes Scyliorhinus duhamelii (Soares and de Carvalho 2019).
This species has been confused with the Polkadot Skate (Dipturus chinensis) in recent literature (Last et al. 2016a).
Changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).

Morphologically similar to some members of the ‘megalops-cubensis group’ but distinguished from those species by the presence of a dark caudal bar. Differs from all other Squalus species in having an unusually low number of precaudal vertebrae (White et al. 2007).
Often confused with Breviraja spinosa.
This species has been confused with Breviraja spinosa in the past.

Sympatric to the Winter Skate (Leucoraja ocellata), immature Little Skates are often confused with immature Winter Skates (especially females). However, the probability of misidentification decreases with skate size as they mature. Skates originally identified as little skate in the Gulf of St. Lawrence were later confirmed as winter skate.

The genus has changed from Raja to Leucoraja (McEachran and Dunn 1998). This assessment assumes a single species. However, populations north of Cape Hatteras have been considered as the subspecies L. garmani virginica while those between the Cape and the Dry Tortugas have been considered as L. g. garmani, but they may represent two distinct species (McEachran 1977, McEachran 2002).
A third nominal species of Narcine from the eastern Pacific, N. schmidti Hildebrand, 1948 is thought to be a junior synonym of N. vermiculata (Carvalho 1999).

Bathyraja matsubarai was first described by Ishiyama (1952), but there has been some level of uncertainty around relationships with other described species. Bathyraja caeluronigricans and B. notoroensis are recognized as junior synonyms of B. matsubarai (Ishihara 1990). Last et al. (2016) note that B. notoroensis is most likely a synonym of B. matsubarai, which was confirmed by Hajime Ishihara (pers. comm., 27/08/2019).

Bathyraja lindbergi Ishiyama & Ishihara, 1977 is also considered by some authors (Dolganov and Tuponogov 1999) as a junior synonym of B. matsubarai but that is not followed here and is considered a valid species (Last et al. 2016).
Izu Catshark (Scyliorhinus tokubee) is now a junior synonym of Scyliorhinus torazame (Soares and de Carvalho 2019).

Squalus brevirostris from the northwest Pacific has previously been considered a synonym of S. megalops. A revision of Indo-Pacific Squalus species and molecular data revealed that this species is clearly separable from the true S. megalops from Australia (Last et al. 2007, Weigmann 2016). Misidentifications of the Squalus species in the Northwest Pacific is an issue and may affect the quality of data available for this species.

The description of this species (Dolganov 1983) was based on capture of single specimen caught off Japan. Only several additional specimens have been caught in the Sea of Okhotsk since then (Dudnik and Dolganov 1992) but only few additional taxonomic notes are available (Dolganov and Tuponogov 1999).

authority: Castro-Aguirre, Antuna-Mendiola, González-Acosta & de la Cruz-Agüero, 2005

taxonomicNotes: The abundance and geographic range of this species may have been previously overestimated because of confusion between two species (D. tortonesei and D. pastinaca). It is likely that a distinct Dasyatis species lives in the Mediterranean Sea, but with nomenclature issues that are under investigation (Serena 2005, Last et al. 2016).
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the Western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000).

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the Western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000).
This species is possibly sometimes confused with the smaller Smallspotted Catshark (Scyliorhinus canicula).
The distribution of the two other Mustelus species (M. asterias and M. mustelus) overlap with this species and misidentification is probably common.

A species of Amblyraja, previously identified as A. cf. georgiana, occurs around the Falkland Islands (Malvinas) and appears to be most closely related to A. frerichsi. It does however, differ from A. frerichsi in a number of characteristics and may be identical to an undescribed Amblyraja from South Georgia (as specified in Endicott et al. 2002) (J. Pompert pers. comm. 2019). Amblyraja georgiana from the Ross Sea appears to have low-level genetic differentiation from South Atlantic A. georgiana, and further work is required to determine whether the Ross Sea A. georgiana is distinct (M. Francis pers. comm. 2019). Taxonomic resolution of this issue is ongoing. Endicott et al.
