(2002) found A. georgiana to have a restricted depth range around South Georgia, with an unknown rajid species comprising the rest of the deep water captures. Although A. georgiana is reported to have been regularly caught around Antarctica in deep water, findings by Endicott et al. (2002) suggest that complications and difficulties in identification of Antarctic rajids may lead to misidentification.

In the northwest Atlantic, this species is easily confused with Arctic skate (Amblyraja hyperborea)  (Bigelow and Shroeder 1953). There is clear geographic separation of both species and tooth count distributions are almost completely separated, but all other meristics are not significantly different (D.W. Kulka unpubl. data 2019). Further, Jensen's Skate is genetically indistinguishable from Arctic Skate (Amblyraja hyperborea) using COI barcoding. In-turn the sequence divergence between both these species and Badia’s Skate (A. badia) is minimal (0.2 to 0.3%). This could result from (1) hybridization, (2) they are all the same species, or (3) “recent divergence and insufficient time for reciprocal monophyly to have occurred” and distinguishing among these hypotheses would require evaluation with other molecular markers (Coulson et al. 2011).

This species has been relocated from the genus Okamejei to Orbiraja (Last et al. 2016). The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. Orbiraja philipi has been considered a possible synonym of Orbiraja powelli Alcock 1898 by Séret (1989) and further specimens are needed to determine its validity (Last et al. 2016).

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was recently revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000), which is generally accepted. This species was previously known as Galeus arae antillensis (in part).

This species is morphologically varied and sometimes difficult to distinguish from other members of the G. arae complex. It is however, separated from its congeners by the combination of the presence of a ventral precaudal crest of enlarged denticles, colour pattern and vertebral counts (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998). It occurs sympatrically with G. antillensis.
Poroderma marleyi was previously considered separate from P. pantherinum, however, it has been shown that P. marleyi represents an extreme colour pattern of P. pantherinum (Human 2006).
Gymnura tentaculata identified from Papua New Guinea (Kailola 1987) are a misidentification of G. australis, as G. tentaculata appears to be restricted to the Northern Indian Ocean.
Previously included a junior synonym, the Maculate Panray (Zanobatus maculatus), which is now a separate species (Last et al. 2016).

Last et al. (2016a) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. Records of Dasyatis (=Fontitrygon) margaritella have included misidentified specimens of the larger sympatric species, F. margarita.
A comparison of Southeastern to North Atlantic specimens should be carried out to determine if both populations are the same species.
This species is very similar to Narcine maculata but can be distinguished by dorsal coloration and the nostril and mouth proportions (Last et al. 2016)
Often confused with Breviraja claramaculata.

Holohalaelurus grennian was originally included within H. melanostigma (Norman, 1939), was then synonymized with H. punctatus (Bass et al. 1975), and in recent years was included in the East African Holohalaelurus species-complex (Compagno 1988). However, H. grennian is clearly distinct from all other Holohalaelurus taxa (Human 2006).
Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, comprised of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including pastinacoides).
McEachran and Dunne (1998) moved this species from genus Raja to Amblyraja.

Formerly a monotypic genus (containing only Urogymnus asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) moved five more medium to large species to Urogymmus, including lobistomus. This species is probably misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) uarnacoides and Himantura (=Pateobatis) hortlei (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007).
Last et al. (2016a) assigned this species to the recently described genus Orbiraja.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.
Sympatric with the Chinese Numbfish (Narcine lingula) and distinguished by the oronasal region morphology (Last et al. 2016).

It is unclear whether this, or a similar, species occurs along the east and west African coasts and Mediterranean Sea. A systematic review of this species is needed in these areas. This species is sometimes confused with Duckbill Eagle Ray (Aetomylaeus bovinus).

The taxonomy of Lamiopsis has recently been resolved with White et al. (2010) resurrecting and redescribing Lamiopsis tephrodes from Southeast Asia, and Akhilesh et al. (2016) redescribing Lamiopsis temminckii from the Arabian Sea. This species is potentially endemic to the Arabian Sea, however, further taxonomic work is required in the Bay of Bengal to determine if this species occurs there or if recorded specimens refer to L. tephrodes.

Historically there has been confusion between Holohalaelurus regani and other members of the genus. Holohalaelurus favus was previously considered to be a subspecies of H. regani, however, it is distinct from H. regani (Human 2006).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Iwatsuki et al. (2011) revised the genus Platyrhina, describing two new species as distinct from Platyrhina sinensis.
Last et al. (2016a) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including hortlei).

Raja miraletus was considered wide-ranging in the Eastern Atlantic, but this is a species-complex with R. miraletus occurring in the Northeast Atlantic and the Mediterranean, R. parva occurring off West Africa, and R. ocellifera off South Africa (Last and Séret 2016).
Some published records of this species may be a result of misidentification of the Roughbelly Skate (Dipturus springeri), which is similar in appearance.
No taxonomic notes.
Several published works have suggested that Bathyraja smirnovi may be a synonym of B. parmifera. However, B. smirnovi is widely recognised as a valid species (see Dyldin and Orlov 2018).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

This species is similar to  the Leopard Whipray (H. leoparda) (Last et al. 2016). The Honeycomb Whipray juveniles of 50 cm disc width (DW) have a well-developed main denticle band with inconspicuous primary denticles while the adults have a strong pattern of large ocelli and reticulations.

Sympatric to the Little Skate, immature specimens of the two species are often confused, especially females. However, chance of misidentification decreases as they mature. Disk is rounded, with many small dark spots on upper surface. Usually 1-4 ocelli are found on the upper surface on each side of disk, each with a dark brownish center and pale edge. Young have long middorsal row of large spines on disk and tail. Upper jaw has 72 rows of teeth. Lower surface is usually white but marked with irregular pale brownish blotches (although this colouration is found in several other species within range).

This species has been previously confused with the Marbled Stingray Dasyatis marmorata and the Common Stingray D. pastinaca, neither of which overlap with the range of the Blue Stingray (Last et al. 2016).

Previously considered to be conspecific with the Speckled Catshark (H. boesemani) but taxonomy has been resolved. Confusion with the Blackspotted Catshark (H. buergeri) possible and referred to in White et al. (2006) as the Indonesian Spotted Catshark (H. cf. buergeri).

Okamejei kenojei has various morphotypes, which previously lead to some taxonomic confusion. Ishihara (1987, 1990) synonymised Raja atriventralis, R. fusca, R. japonica, R. katsukii, R. kenojei, R. porosa, and R. tobae with (Ishihara et al. 2002).

Previously this species was referred to as a subpopulation of Holohalaelurus regani (occurring off KwaZulu-Natal and southern Mozambique). A revision of the genus Holohalaelurus has shown that this species is in fact distinct from H. regani (Human 2006). Specimens of H. favus were first referred to and illustrated by Bass et al. (1975).

Previously considered a "Natal" form of Haploblepharus edwardsii (Schinz, 1822) by Bass et al. (1975) and subsequent authors, H. kistnasamyi has a colour pattern that superficially resembles, although is distinct from, that of H. edwardsii, and also differs in morphological features (Human and Compagno 2006). DNA Barcoding confirms that H. kistnasamyi is distinct from H. edwardsii and other Haploblepharus species (K. Geldhill, unpubl. data, 2018).
Ishihara et al. (2012) established the new genus Beringraja for the two species B. binoculata  (previously Raja binoculata Girard, 1855) and B. pulchra (previously Raja pulchra Liu 1932).

Tentatively placed in the genus Sinobatis Hulley 1973 by White and Last (2013). According to White and Last (2013), this species should be considered as questionably valid pending a thorough review of the western North Pacific anacanthobatids.
The revision of the genus Holohalaelurus showed that H. polystigma is a junior synonym of H. punctatus (Human 2006).

This species was previously provisionally considered to occur in Australia but now the Australian and other Indo-Pacific long-tailed torpedo rays are considered to be variants of other species (Last and Stevens 2009, Last et al. 2016). Around Taiwan, this species has been confused with Tetronarce formosa (Ebert et al. 2013).

The Triangular Legskate (Cruriraja parcomaculata) was described by von Bonde and Swart (1923) from off KwaZulu-Natal. Smith (1964) later described a small legskate from off Durban as C. triangularis. However, examination of the type specimens of both C. parcomaculata and C. triangularis confirmed that both species were one in the same. A common legskate from off the south and west coasts of South Africa and Namibia commonly referred to as C. parcomaculata was determined not to be that species, but an undescribed legskate. Aschliman et al. (2010) after a reviewing these species described a new species C. hulleyi while synonymizing C. triangularis as a junior synonym of C. parcomaculata. Therefore, information on the life history and distribution of C. triangularis prior to 2010 should now be referred to as C. parcomaculata, and life history and distribution previously referred to for west coast C. parcomaculata is referable to as C. hulleyi. See Aschliman et al. (2010) for further explanation of this issue.
No taxonomic notes.

Himantura uarnak was recently split from other Himantura species (Last et al. 2016a). The new distribution no longer includes Australia and Papua New Guinea (Last et al. 2016b). There is some continued taxonomic uncertainty with the Himantura genus and this assessment should be updated if the current distribution changes.
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

Dolganov and Tuponogov (1999) suggest that B. trachouros may be synonymous with B. violacea (Ishihara pers. obs.), however, B. trachouros is treated as a valid species here (clasper structure is distinct) and was recognized as valid by Compagno (2005).
Often confused with Breviraja claramaculata.

The specimen from off Tanzania identified as Cruriraja andamanica by McEachran and Fechhelm (1982) was found to be well-separated (i.e. the ordination of principle components with respect to its morphometric vectors fell outside the 90% confidence ellipse area) from the holotype and other specimens (Vinu et al. 2017). These authors conclude that this Tanzanian specimen is questionable and should be thoroughly re-evaluated to determine whether it might represent a separate species that has yet to be described.

Cephaloscyllium umbratile was recognized as a distinct species by Nakaya (1975). Later, Springer (1979) treated C. umbratile as a junior synonym of C. isabellum. However, recent workers such as Compagno et al. (2005) and Schaaf-da Silva & Ebert (2008) treat C. umbratile as a distinct species and Nakaya et al. (2013) also recognized it as a valid species. The sympatric C. formosanum was considered a junior synonym of C. umbratile by Schaaf-da Silva & Ebert (2008) but resurrected as a valid species by Nakaya et al. (2013).
This species has previously been confused with Okamejei kenojei (Ishihara et al. 2009).

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the Western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000). This species was previously known as Galeus arae antillensis (in part) and was noted as the island form of Galeus arae (Springer 1979).
This species may get confused with Atelomycterus marmoratus which is more widespread in the region and co-occurs off the island of Bali (White et al. 2005).
This species is frequently confused with the Giant Skate (Dipturus gigas), particularly at the juvenile stage (Ebert et al. 2013).

Genetic studies show that B. eatonii in the southern Atlantic is distinct from populations in the Ross Sea (Pacific) and Indian Ocean (Smith and McVeagh 2004, M. Francis pers. comm. 2007). Therefore this Red List assessment is restricted to B. eatonii in the Atlantic Ocean, and data from other areas excluded, as these are considered to refer to, as yet, unidentified but similar species. Hulley’s (1988) suggestion that B. eatonii may be synonymous with B. smithii, (found off South Africa) is probably not correct (Stehmann and Bürkel 1990).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Squalus acutipinnis is a recently resurrected member of the megalops-cubensis group of Squalus species (Viana and Carvalho 2016). It was previously referred to locally as Squalus megalops.

Dasyatis marmorata is a species occurring off western Africa. This species has often been confused with Dasyatis chrysonota, which is a South African species. However, molecular data supports the non-conspecificity of these two species (Last et al. 2016a).
Squalus bassi has previously been referred to locally as Squalus mitsukurii (Viana et al. 2017).

Dipturus wuhanlingi was described in 2008 (Jeong and Nakabo 2008). Among the Dipturus species distributed in the western North Pacific (i.e., Dipturus gigas, D. kwangtungensis, D. macrocauda, D. tengu, and D. wuhanlingi) this species has the unique character of a continuous row of mid-dorsal thorns from nape to the tail distinguishing it from other regional Dipturus spp. The validity of this species is not doubtful.
Squalus mahia is a recently described Squalus of the megalops-cubensis group (Viana et al. 2018).
Squalus margaretsmithae is a recently described Squalus of the megalops-cubensis group (Viana et al. 2018).

There has been a great deal of historic uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of Eastern Pacific gymnurids, with some authors considering Gymnura crebripunctata to be a junior synonym of G. marmorata. However, Smith et al. (2009) confirmed the validity of G. crebripunctata as a distinct species using both morphometric and molecular techniques.
 
In previous IUCN Red List publications Gymnura marmorata included G. crebripunctata as a synonym. Therefore assessments of G. marmorata from 2012 onwards are not directly comparable with previous assessments under that name.

There has been a great deal of historic uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of Eastern Pacific gymnurids, with some authors considering Gymnura crebripunctata to be a junior synonym of G. marmorata. However, Smith et al. (2009) confirmed the validity of G. crebripunctata as a distinct species using both morphometric and molecular techniques.

Recently, molecular data confirmed that the single, widespread Indo–Pacific species, Pastinachus sephen consists of two species, the widespread P. ater and a more restricted P. sephen (Last et al. 2016a).

While there are reported subpopulations of Squalus acanthias (Linnaeus, 1758) elsewhere in the world, the North Pacific subpopulation is now considered a separate species, Squalus suckleyi (Girard, 1854) (see Ebert et al. 2010). Further taxonomic studies on this genus are required, including in relation to Mediterranean and Black Sea subpopulations. In Europe, three subpopulations are inferred to occur.

Raja miraletus was considered wide-ranging in the Eastern Atlantic, but is a species-complex with R. miraletus occurring in the Northeast Atlantic and the Mediterranean Sea, R. parva occurring off West Africa, and R. ocellifera off South Africa (Last and Séret 2016).

Dingerkus and DeFino (1983) synonymized Chiloscyllium caerulopunctatum with C. plagiosum, an action tentatively (and reluctantly) followed by Compagno (2001). The species name is not addressed in Ebert et al. (2013), however, C. caerulopunctatum is considered to be distinct from C. plagiosum and thus a valid species (W. White pers. comm. cited in Weigmann 2016).

Gambusia manni was synonymized under G. hubbsi (Fink 1971) to which it is a sister species (Lydeard et al. 1995), and later re-elevated to the specific level, which may confound existing records (Rauchenberger 1989).

Even though some previous studies have treated Limia as one of the multiple subgenera in the genus Poecilia (Rosen and Bailey 1963, Meredith et al. 2010, Meredith et al. 2011), several other works have supported the generic classification for Limia (Rodriguez 1997, Hamilton 2001, Poeser 2003, Palacios et al. 2016, Weaver et al. 2016). Here we endorse the latter assessment that Limia should be considered a valid, separate genus.

The taxonomic role of genera to express relationships among species is clearly justified in the case of Limia from different points of view. From the biogeographic point of view, species of Limia show a discrete distribution since they are only found in the Antilles, specifically on Hispaniola, Cuba, Jamaica and the island of Grand Cayman. However, only three species of Poecilia sensu strictu occur in this region and they are restricted exclusively to Hispaniola. In addition, recent phylogenetic analyses have found Limia to be a monophyletic group probably originated from a South American ancestor with the three Hispaniolan Poecilia species mentioned above representing the closest sister group (Palacios et al. 2016, Weaver et al. 2016). A very detailed analysis is currently in prep, also confirming Limia as monophyletic (Spikes et al. in prep). Moreover, there is enough morphological distinctiveness in characters with adaptive value such is the case of gonopodial traits to separate species of Limia and Poecilia (Rivas 1978). Furthermore, all of the existing ecological and behavioral literature is using Limia, not Poecilia. Not recognizing Limia as a separate genus from Poecilia may obscure their similarities and cause even more confusion in a group that in fact deserves more taxonomic attention.
Charadrius obscurus and C. aquilonius (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. obscurus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

At least some specimens previously identified as M. ginkgodens have been re-identified as the recently resurrected M. hotaula (Dalebout et al. 2014), which has resulted in some confusion about the distribution of both species.

Flathead mullet taxonomy remains unresolved, and there is a wealth of evidence suggesting that it comprises a complex of closely-related species rather than a single cosmopolitan taxon. It is thus likely to be revised in the future.

For example, the subpopulation occurring from Morocco to Angola is genetically different to that in the Mediterranean, and there may even be two distinct subpopulations present in Morocco alone.
Zenarchopterus species are now considered to be in the family Zenarchopteridae (B. Collette pers. comm. 2009).
The genus Monomitopus is in need of revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).

According to the Catalog of Fishes, this species has been synonymized with Brephostoma carpenteri; however, recent genetic studies of both species indicate they are valid as separate (J. Moore pers. comm. 2019).
This species is easily confused with Neoscopelus macrolepidotus (Roberts 2015).
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Chelon but is now considered valid in the genus Planiliza (Eschmeyer et al. 2018).

There is confusion surrounding this genus. Some records may be misidentified, and based on other species. There is also confusion on the correct name for this species. It is sometimes referred to as Liza pleniceps.

This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Liza but is now considered valid in the genus Planiliza (Eschmeyer et al. 2018).

Two subspecies are recognized: C. c. commersonii in southern South America and C. c. kerguelenensis in the Kerguelen Islands (Robineau et al. 2007). The Kerguelen subspecies was apparently founded by a few individuals as recently as 10,000 years ago.

The New Zealand and Australian populations of this species are likely to be split into five separate species in the future, as genetic data indicate significant diversity between them (Waters and Wallis 2001, Raadik 2011). The New Zealand species will remain as G. brevipinnis, as it was originally described from New Zealand. The remaining four species will be in Australia (T. Raadik unpublished data).
This species has appeared in earlier literature as Bostrichthys zonatus; Bostrichthys is an unnecessary replacement name for Bostrychus.
This species is now called Smilosicycopus leprurus (Keith et al. 2011). A revision is in progress as its taxonomy is not clear.

This species was re-described by Suzuki et al. (2010). Keith et al. (2015) synonymised Stiphodon atratus Watson 1996 and Stiphodon weberi Watson, Allen & Kottelat 1998 under Stiphodon pelewensis Herre 1936 without justifications for the decision.

Based on previous genetic work (Jerry et al., 2001) it is clear that this taxon, including its sister taxon Macquaria novemaculeata (Australian Bass), is incorrectly placed in the Percichthyidae and is supported to belong in a separate and new, though yet taxonomically defined, family. Currently no taxonomic work to define the family and revise this species (and M. novemaculeata) is underway, but when it eventuates will revise the generic name for both taxa as Macquaria is nested within Percichthyidae and will be unavailable. The generic name for the two species may then revert to Percalates, as this is the earliest available generic name previously assigned. As no formal taxonomic revision has yet been undertaken Eschmeyer et al. (2018) list the correct generic name for this species as Macquaria, and Percalates as a junior synonym (T. Raadik, pers. comm.).

Micropogonias manni may be a junior synonym of M. furnieri (Kong and Valdés 1990). The latter occurs in the southwest Atlantic from Cuba to northern Argentina. Micropogonias manni is endemic to the Araucanía Region of Chile but the taxonomy of this species requires further study (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2020).

authority: Sanders, Rasmussen, Elmberg, Mumpuni, Guinea, Blias, Lee & Fry, 2012
taxonomicNotes: Aipysurus mosaicus was previously considered to be an allopatric population of A. eydouxii, which occurs throughout the Sunda Shelf and in New Guinea. Molecular analyses reveal these two species to be sister lineages with fixed nucleotide substitutions at three independent mitochondrial and nuclear loci, and a deep phylogenetic divergence exceeding that of all other sampled species pairs in Aipysurus. Aaipysurus mosaicus is also distinguished from A. eydouxii by morphological characters relating to scalation (for example, number of ventral scales), colour pattern (for example, number and shape of transverse body bands), internal soft anatomy (for example, position of heart in relation to ventral scales), and skeletal morphology (for example, shape of nasal and caudal neural spines; Sanders et al. 2012).

This species was first described in 2012 using a combination of molecular (mitochondrial and nuclear) and morphological (scalation, colour pattern and skull osteology) characters (Ukuwela et al. 2012).
Lutjanus octolineatus was previously considered a junior synonym of Lutjanus bengalensis, but is now considered a valid species according to work by Iwatsuki et al. (2016).
Lutjanus sapphirolineatus was formerly misidentified as L. bengalensis (Iwatsuki et al. 2016).
This species was previously placed in the family Mussidae but is now placed under Faviidae (Budd et al. 2012, Budd et al. 2019).
Squalus albicaudus is a member of the Squalus megalops species-complex. The taxonomic description includes specimens that were formerly identified as S. megalops and S. cubensis (Viana et al. 2016).

Squalus bahiensis is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. The taxonomic description includes mostly specimens formerly identified as S. blainvillei and S. mitsukurii, and fewer specimens formerly identified as S. cubensis and S. fernandinus.
Squalus lobularis is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. Its taxonomic description includes specimens formerly identified as S. cubensis and S. mitsukurii (Viana et al. 2016).

Squalus quasimodo is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. Its taxonomic description includes specimens formerly identified as S. blainvillei, S. fernandinus, S. lebruni, and S. mitsukurii (Viana et al. 2016).

authority: Díaz de Astarloa, Mabragaña, Hanner & Figueroa, 2008
taxonomicNotes: Concha et al. (2019) synonymised the genus Zearaja with Dipturus, thereby relegating this species to the genus Dipturus.
There is some taxonomic uncertainty within this species complex that requires further work (Mundy 2005).
The validity of this species has been questioned (Paxton 1979, Becker 1983, Mundy 2005, J. Paxton pers. comm. 2018).
There is possibly confusion between identifications of Diaphus aliciae and D. impostor, and taxonomic work is ongoing (A. Williams and J. Paxton pers. comm. 2018).
Further taxonomic research is needed.
Further taxonomic research is needed.
Gymnoscopelus aphya and G. nicholsi are considered to be the same species, with the valid name being G. nicholsi (J. Paxton pers. comm. 2018).
This species can be easily confused with other Lampanyctus species (A. Williams pers. comm. 2018).
Further taxonomic work is needed to determine the status of this species as it is suspected by some workers to be a junior synonym of Lampanyctus festivus (Paxton 1979, Mundy 2005).
Lampanyctus fernae has been misidentified as L. ritteri in the past (Wisner 1976).
This species has been misidentified as Lampanyctus atrum in the past (Mundy 2005).
This species was previously synonymized with Triphotourus mexicanus (Hulley 1986), but recent work supports T. oculeum as a valid species (Evseenko 2008).
According to Evseenko (2008), Triphoturus mexicanus has two genetically different forms; one in California and one in Peru.
Closely related to Elops saurus of the western Atlantic.
Other workers have questioned the separation of this species from Brotulotaenia crassa in the past, but Nielsen and Møller (2015) consider it a valid species.
Molecular studies suggest that the genus Schedophilus is not monophyletic (Milana et al. 2011).
This species was previously considered a possible synonym of Pseudoscopelus scriptus by Prokofiev and Kukuev (2007), but further investigation by Prokofiev (2011, 2014) concluded it is valid.

Commerson's original specimen from Fort Dauphin, Madagascar and his description of the species were lost (Cuvier and Valenciennes, 1830 - in: Griffiths and Heemstra (1995)). Following examination of Argyrosomus specimens from several countries, including Madagascar, Griffiths and Heemstra (1995) designated a neotype of A. hololepidotus to resolve some of the taxonomic confusion in this genus.

Vaz and Carvalho (2018) carried out morphological analysis of South- and Northwestern Atlantic specimens of Squatina revealing this previously undescribed species of angel shark occurring on the continental slope of Brazil between latitudes 11° and 22°S.
Séret and Naylor (2016) described Rhynchorhina mauritaniensis (and Rhynchorhina as a new genus) from limited specimens collected off Mauritania (Eastern Central Atlantic).

The new taxonomic concept for Squatina guggenheim includes S. punctata as a junior synonym.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).
There is possibly confusion between identifications of Diaphus aliciae and D. impostor (A. Williams pers. comm. 2018).
This species closely resembles Diaphus coeruleus and D. lucidus (Gjøsaeter 1989), and has not been reported since its first description.
Kawaguchi and Shimizu (1978) list Diaphus trachops as the Hawaiian sibling species of D. suborbitalis, and proposed it does not occur in Hawaii (Mundy 2005).
This species is part of the Diaphus fulgens complex in the eastern Pacific (Wisner 1976).

Becker (1964) recognised four valid species of Centrobranchus, and was followed by most authors until the review of Gago and Lavenberg (1992), who recognised only the two species C. andrae and C. nigroocellatus. A number of authors in the last decade have considered Centrobranchus choerocephalus (Fowler, 1904) a valid species without mention of the problems described in Gago and Lavenberg (1992). The record of C. choerocephalus from Lord Howe Island (Allen et al. 1976), inadvertently omitted from the first Zoological Catalogue of Australia, Pisces (Paxton et al. 1989), and subsequent editions, is now considered C. nigroocellatus (J. Paxton pers. comm. 2018).
Records from Australia (OZCAM database accessed June 2018) require study of additional specimens and a comparison with specimens collected off Japan (J. Paxton pers. comm. 2018).
This species is very similar to Protomyctophum crockeri (Shinohara et al. 1994).

This species was originally described as distinct from Tarletonbeania crenularis by Eigenmann and Eigenmann in 1890. Gilbert (1915) reports that original described differences between T. tenua and T. crenularis are due to the poor condition of the original specimens and that T. tenua and T. crenularis are not significantly different. Parr (1929) accepted Gilbert’s opinion on this and also T. tenua as a junior synonym of T. crenularis. Kobayashi (1958) refers to T. tenua as a junior synonym of T. crenularis. In summary, it is doubtful that T. tenua is a valid species.
Some workers consider this species to be a synonym of Scopelgenys tristis (Becker and Shcherbachev 1990, Mundy 2005).
Eurostopodus mystacalis, E. nigripennis and E. exul (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as E. mystacalis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The Sei Whale, Balaenoptera borealis is a recognized species but catch and sightings records of Sei Whales prior to 1972 tended to include Bryde's Whales (B. edeni or B. brydei) in areas where both species occur. The Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (Committee on Taxonomy 2017) recognizes two subspecies, B. b. borealis in the Northern Hemisphere and B. b. schlegelii in the Southern Hemisphere, as proposed by Tomilin (1957). The Sei Whales found in the North Pacific and North Atlantic have not been formally compared and so are still placed in the same nominate subspecies by default, although Huijser et al. (2018) found a high degree of genetic divergence between North Atlantic and North Pacific Sei Whales.
Martin et al. (2018) suggests a possible placement of Myctophum fissunovi in Dasyscopelus.
This species is a synonym of Cynoscion parvipinnis (Chao et al. 1995, Chao 2002).
A possible nomenclature problem with species name needs to be clarified between L. Chao and L. Findley.
This species is easily misidentified as congeneric species.
This species is easily misidentified as congeneric species.
This species is easily misidentified as congeneric species.
The type specimens were probably lost in a Tsunami in Valparaíso in 1962. There is some uncertainty about the taxonomic validity of this species (Kong and Valés 1990).
Original orthography is petersii.
Original orthography is stearnsii.

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. magellanicus, P. bougainvilliorum, P. atriceps, P. verrucosus, P. carunculatus, P. chalconotus, P. onslowi, P. campbelli, P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi moved into Leucocarbo (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). In past, often considered a subspecies of P. carunculatus (which see). Monotypic.
Thalasseus bernsteini (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
This species is often misidentified with cogenerics.
This species is often misidentified with cogenerics.

The morphology of the northwest Indian Ocean subpopulation and the Mediterranean and southeast Atlantic subpopulation is similar, but their ranges of distribution are separated. They probably belong to different taxonomic and conservation units (L. Chao pers. comm. 2013).
This species is often misidentified with cogenerics.
This species is often misidentified with congenerics.

According to Walker and Radford (1992), there have been many instances where Eastern Pacific species have been ascribed to Umbrina (e.g., U. imberbis = Sciaena, probably callaensis). However, current taxonomic authority databases continue to use the name Umbrina imberbis.
This species is often misidentified with cogenerics.

Umbrina robinsoni Gilchrist & Thompson, 1908 was considered a junior synonym of Umbina ronchus (Chao and Trewavas 1990), however the former is a valid species distributed from South Africa to Oman (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). Umbrina ronchus is often reported from the northwest Indian Ocean, but specimens from there are U. robinsoni.
This species is often misidentified with cogenerics.
This species is often misidentified with cogenerics.

Corythornis cristatus, C. nais and C. thomensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Alcedo and lumped as A. cristata following Melo and Fuchs (2008). Prior to that, all three taxa had been split as A. cristata, A. thomensis and A. nais following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Eleotris melanosoma was described from Wahai in the Maluku islands (Bleeker 1852). It is distinguished from congeners in having 46–58 lateral row scales, usually 18–19 pectoral rays, 12–13 gill rakers on the first gill arch and two longitudinal rows of papillae on the opercle meeting posteriorly (Kottelat et al. 1993).

This species has been confused with Eleotris fusca; hence Pusey et al. (2004) combined their natural history account of both. Research on the taxonomy of E. fusca is currently underway (P. Keith pers comm. 2011).

This species name is frequently misused for other species of Eleotris causing Pusey et al. (2004) to combine their summary of the natural history of this species.

There may be several species under this name and further research on this has begun (Mennesson and Keith 2017); with two species being found in the Indian Ocean (E. fusca and E. klunzingeri).

Corythornis cristatus, C. nais and C. thomensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Alcedo and lumped as A. cristata following Melo and Fuchs (2008). Prior to that, all three taxa had been split as A. cristata, A. thomensis and A. nais following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
This species previously synonymized with Poromitra crassiceps.
Hypotaenidia torquata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Gallirallus as G. torquatus.
Grus vipio (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2021) was previously moved to the genus Antigone (del Hoyo & Collar 2014), prior to which it was included in Grus. Monotypic.
Chlidonias albostriatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna as S. albostriata.
Argya squamiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Turdoides squamiceps.

Alauda arvensis (AERC TAC [2003]; AOU [1998 and supplements]; Christidis and Boles [2008]; Cramp et al. [1977-1994]; Dowsett and Forbes-Watson [1993]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]; Turbott [1990]) and A. japonica (Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped into A. arvensis following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).

Oenanthe oenanthe and O. seebohmi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. oenanthe following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 and supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Taeniopygia guttata and T. castanotis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. guttata following Christidis & Boles (2008); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Puffinus bryani (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was first described by Pyle et al. (2011).

The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group is aware that phylogenetic analyses have been published which have proposed generic rearrangements which may affect this species, but prefers to wait until work by other taxonomists reveals how these changes affect the entire groups involved.

Rallus longirostris, R. crepitans and R. obsoletus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. longirostris following AOU (2000). Rallus elegans and R. tenuirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. elegans following AOU (2000). Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) included tenuirostris within R. longirostris.

Puffinus lherminieri (incorporating baroli), P. bannermani, P. persicus, P. subalaris and P. bailloni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. lherminieri and baroli was subsumed under P. assimilis, following Brooke (2004), before which P. bannermani and P. persicus where split following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
This species was previously misidentified as Hime japonica (Gomon and Struthers 2015).

Hydrobates castro (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into H. castro and H. jabejabe (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018). Previously, Oceanodroma castro (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was been split into O. castro and O. monteiroi following Bolton et al. (2008) and all Oceanodroma species were moved to Hydrobates (del Hoyo and Collar 2014).

Hydrobates castro (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into H. castro and H. jabejabe (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018). Wallace et al. (2017) provides molecular support for the acceptance of the population of Band-rumped Storm-petrel Hydrobates castro jabejabe on the Cape Verdes as a full species, as indicated by at least two previous studies (cited in del Hoyo and Collar [2014]: 372). A study by Bolton (2007) revealed that the Cape Verde birds differ rather strongly in voice:

'The hot-season Azores calls generally have a simple one- or two-syllable, rising breath note, stressed on the last syllable, that contrasts markedly with the more protracted, four-syllable (rarely five-syllable) breath note of the sympatric cool-season population, stressed on the penultimate syllable. Cape Verde Burrow Calls are typified by extremely infrequent interruptions of the purr phrase, which on occasion may continue for several minutes without a breath note.'

Examination of the sonagrams in Bolton (2007) strongly suggests that Tobias scores on vocal differences would be very high. This and the very consistent molecular evidence points to the recognition of the Cape Verde population as a full species. Bocage (1875) tentatively described the taxon jabe-jabe from Raso, Cape Verdes, on the basis of a single specimen which he distinguished from H. leucorhous (rather than from H. castro) by its stronger and glossier (vs grey-washed matt sooty) black head and back, lack of brown shafts in the white uppertail-coverts, less forked tail, slightly stronger bill, slightly shorter toes and legs. This is unhelpful in establishing whether there are any characters that distinguish jabejabe from castro, but photographs on the internet suggest it has a marginally wider white rump and more contrasting upperwing-coverts.

Hydrobates leucorhous has been split into H. leucorhous, H. socorroensis and H. cheimomnestes (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018), based on the proposal of Howell (2012).

Hydrobates leucorhous has been split into H. leucorhous, H. socorroensis and H. cheimomnestes (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018). The taxa can be separated only tentatively and on combinations of characters and items of evidence. Using such combinations, Howell (2012) treated both taxa as potentially separate species from Leach’s, using ‘[l.]’ in the scientific name, apparently to indicate the uncertainty involved in that decision. The accounts of the morphological differences between the taxa repeatedly refer to means and inclinations (‘typically’, ‘averages’, ‘generally’, ‘usually’, ‘relatively’, ‘often’, ‘tends to’). Clearly the fact that cheimomnestes breeds at different times of year from socorroensis (and therefore also has a different moult schedule) strongly suggests that two species are involved, but this in itself cannot be the single decisive factor. Moreover, Howell’s (2012) case for the split of socorroensis from leucorhous is hard to discern. In an online post Howell (2015) produced some photographs of cheimomnestes which he used to further his call to split the taxa, which he there described as ‘distinct’. Even so, this new evidence was not different evidence, and nothing was provided which increased the confidence with which the taxa can confidently be discriminated.

            In the case of Monteiro’s Storm-petrel H. monteiroi the evidence for separating it as a species included vocal playback experiments that showed a lack of response to calls of Band-rumped Storm-petrel H. castro (see Checklist 1: 372). This, combined with the difference in breeding schedule, has widely clinched approval for the split. It turns out that Ainley (1980) reported in considerable detail on the vocal differences of the two Guadalupe taxa from leucorhous and from each other, although he did not conduct playback experiments to test for responses and the differences of socorroensis and cheimomnestes are not so remarkable. Nevertheless, the differences he found, repeated in summary form in Howell (2012), represent moderately firm evidence to incline the decision on the taxonomic rank of these taxa in favour of species; and accordingly we accept these splits.

Further evidence is nonetheless highly desirable, and could reverse this conclusion, if a large sample of vocalisations were to demonstrate overlap or if birds in burrows were to react to playback. It is to be noted that the tree in Wallace et al. (2017) shows one specimen of socorroensis grouping with cheimomnestes, ‘possibly as a result of recent ancestry and incomplete lineage sorting’ (and NB: ‘these relationships are being investigated further with larger sample sizes (Taylor et al., unpubl.).’).

            The generic position of the Leach’s Storm-petrel complex varies among lists. Wallace et al. (2017), however, are aligned with the Checklist use of Hydrobates: ‘Our results…  agree with recent taxonomy changes (subsuming Oceanodroma into genus Hydrobates…)’.

Hydrobates leucorhous (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into H. leucorhous, H. socorroensis and H. cheimomnestes (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018), based on the proposal of Howell (2012).

Puffinus newelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into P. newelli and P. myrtae (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018). Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) found that P. (n). myrtae, ‘Rapa Shearwater’, is genetically more distinct from newelli than newelli is from auricularis. On this basis they propose that myrtae be treated as a full species. Such an arrangement is supported by Shirihai et al. (2017), who noted:

'Rapa Shearwater is much smaller (in all biometric characters) than the other two taxa…, and is furthermore highly distinctive in having a unique combination of white undertail-coverts (vs. dark in both newelli and auricularis) and whitish inner webs to the remiges, as well as a white face.'

Following revised scoring of parsed characters for the differentiation of P. auricularis, P. newelli and P. myrtae, the latter emerges as a very strong candidate for species rank, given that the effect size for wing length vs the smaller of the other two taxa (auricularis), based on Table 3 in Shirihai et al. (2017), is –6.56 (score 3); white vs dark undertail-coverts (at least 2); whitish inner webs to the remiges (at least 1); and a ‘white face’ (impossible to interpret, and in fact not apparent in several photographs online).

We will seek to confirm the characters identified as distinctive by Shirihai et al. (2017) but accept the strong likelihood of at least minor vocal differentiation. Allowing 1 for such an eventuality, and having a score of 6 already on morphological grounds, we tentatively accord myrtae species status as Rapa Shearwater.
There are questions on whether Aipysurus pooleorum is a distinct species as many of the morphological characters mentioned are overlapping with A. laevis (Mirtschin et al. 2017).

Catharacta skua (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Stercorarius.

Catharacta skua, C. antarctica and C. maccormicki (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993), cross-regional species, are retained as separate species contra Christidis and Boles (1994) and Turbott (1990) who include lonnbergi and antarctica as subspecies of C. skua and AERC TAC (2003) who include C. maccormicki as a subspecies of C. skua.
Catharacta chilensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Stercorarius.

Catharacta maccormicki (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Stercorarius.

Catharacta skua, C. antarctica and C. maccormicki (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993), cross-regional species, are retained as separate species contra Christidis and Boles (1994) and Turbott (1990) who include lonnbergi and antarctica as subspecies of C. skua and AERC TAC (2003) who include C. maccormicki as a subspecies of C. skua.
Larus scoresbii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Leucophaeus.
Saundersilarus saundersi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Larus.
Hydrocoloeus minutus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Larus.

Thalasseus bengalensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Thalasseus bergii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.

The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group is aware that phylogenetic analyses have been published which have proposed generic rearrangements which may affect this species, but prefers to wait until work by other taxonomists reveals how these changes affect the entire groups involved.
Sternula antillarum (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Sternula nereis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Onychoprion lunatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna as S. lunata.
Microcarbo melanoleucos (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Phalacrocorax.
Sometimes placed in genus Stictocarbo or occasionally in Leucocarbo. In past, often considered a subspecies of P. punctatus. Monotypic.

F. g. audoboni, recognised in del Hoyo and Collar (2014), is here synonymised with F. g. glacialis following the observation that the difference is based upon a cline and that there is no genetic evidence whatsoever to indicate a distinction (Kerr and Dove 2013).
Aphrodroma brevirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Lugensa.
Usually considered part of assemblage referred to as subgenus Cookilaria. Closely related to P. nigripennis. Monotypic.
Ardenna pacifica (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus as P. pacificus.
Ardenna bulleri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.
Ardenna creatopus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.
Ardenna tenuirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.

P. auricularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) is retained as a separate species from P. newelli (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018), following a revision of the scoring of parsed characters for these taxa plus P. myrtae (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018), split from P. newelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2014).

Puffinus lherminieri (incorporating baroli), P. bannermani, P. persicus, P. subalaris and P. bailloni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. lherminieri and baroli was subsumed under P. assimilis, following Brooke (2004), before which P. bannermani and P. persicus where split following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Thalassarche melanophris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as T. melanophrys.
Hydrobates microsoma (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genera Oceanodroma and Halocyptena.

Hydrobates monorhis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma.

Hydrobates matsudairae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma.
Hydrobates homochroa (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma.
Pterodroma feae and P. deserta (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. feae following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Fregetta maoriana endemic to New Zealand (Brooke 2004), was not listed by Turbott (1990) as it was previously believed to be extinct. Fregetta maoriana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanites as O. maorianus (Oliver 1955) and genus Pealeornis as P. maoriana (Mathews 1932) by the New Zealand Checklist (2010).

Calonectris diomedea and C. borealis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. diomedea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993), which was also formerly lumped with C. edwardsii following Hazevoet (1995), contra Brooke (2004).

Calonectris diomedea and C. borealis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. diomedea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993), which was also formerly lumped with C. edwardsii following Hazevoet (1995), contra Brooke (2004).

Oceanodroma castro (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) has been split into O. castro and O. monteiroi following Bolton et al. (2008). All Oceanodroma species have since been moved to Hydrobates (del Hoyo and Collar 2014).

L. michahellis and L. armenicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. michahellis following a review by the BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group. Prior to that, L. armenicus had been split and L. cachinnans (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) had been lumped with L. michahellis as L. cachinnans following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pterodroma feae and P. deserta (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. feae following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sula dactylatra (AOU 1998 + updates) and Sula tasmani (Christidis and Boles 1994) have been lumped as S. dactylatra following Christidis and Boles (2008).
Pterodroma macroptera and P. gouldi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. macroptera following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pterodroma macroptera and P. gouldi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. macroptera following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Calonectris diomedea and C. borealis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. diomedea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993), which was also formerly lumped with C. edwardsii following Hazevoet (1995), contra Brooke (2004).
Oceanites pincoyae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was newly described by Harrison et al. (2013).
Puffinus assimilis (not including baroli) and P. elegans (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. assimilis, under which baroli was also subsumed, following Brooke (2004).

Puffinus lherminieri (incorporating baroli), P. bannermani, P. persicus, P. subalaris and P. bailloni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. lherminieri and baroli was subsumed under P. assimilis, following Brooke (2004), before which P. bannermani and P. persicus where split following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Puffinus assimilis (not including baroli) and P. elegans (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. assimilis, under which baroli was also subsumed, following Brooke (2004).
Larus novaehollandiae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as L. novaehollandiae and L. scopulinus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Gelochelidon nilotica and G. macrotarsa (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Sterna and lumped as S. nilotica following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Synthliboramphus hypoleucus and S. scrippsi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as S. hypoleucus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Catharacta antarctica (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Stercorarius, following Chu et al. (2009), and split as S. antarcticus and S. lonnbergi, following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

This species was formerly known as Lapemis curtus, however, a recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors.

Hydrophis curtus is sometimes regarded as two species, H. curtus occurring in the Indian Ocean and H. hardwickii occurring in southeast Asia and Australasia (Smith 1926, Cogger 2000). This division is not supported by morphological analyses based on large numbers of individuals from populations throughout the species’ geographic range (Gritis and Voris 1990). However, molecular data show a deep divergence between clades of H. curtus in the Indian Ocean versus the West Pacific (Ukuwela et al. 2014). Further work is required to confirm the identity of this species across its range, and at present, a single species, H. curtus, is maintained.
This species was resurrected from synonymy under Spectrunculus grandis by Uiblein et al. (2008).

Cibois et al. (2016) found that Procelsterna sits within Anous, which is accepted and results in P. albivitta changing name to Anous albivattus (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). Procelsterna cerulea and P. albivitta (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. cerulea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cibois et al. (2016) found that Procelsterna sits within Anous, which is accepted and results in P. cerulea changing name to Anous ceruleus (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). Procelsterna cerulea and P. albivitta (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. cerulea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into six genera, with P. penicillatus, P. pelagicus and P. urile moved into Urile (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).
Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. aristotelis moved into Gulosus (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. auritus, P. brasilianus and P. harrisi moved into Nannopterum (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. auritus, P. brasilianus and P. harrisi moved into Nannopterum (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. auritus, P. brasilianus and P. harrisi moved into Nannopterum (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. magellanicus, P. bougainvilliorum, P. atriceps, P. verrucosus, P. carunculatus, P. chalconotus, P. onslowi, P. campbelli, P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi moved into Leucocarbo (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). Phalacrocorax bougainvilliorum (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as P. bougainvillii.

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. magellanicus, P. bougainvilliorum, P. atriceps, P. verrucosus, P. carunculatus, P. chalconotus, P. onslowi, P. campbelli, P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi moved into Leucocarbo (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). Phalacrocorax atriceps and P. verrucosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. atriceps following Turbott (1990).

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. magellanicus, P. bougainvilliorum, P. atriceps, P. verrucosus, P. carunculatus, P. chalconotus, P. onslowi, P. campbelli, P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi moved into Leucocarbo (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). Phalacrocorax atriceps and P. verrucosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. atriceps following Turbott (1990).

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. magellanicus, P. bougainvilliorum, P. atriceps, P. verrucosus, P. carunculatus, P. chalconotus, P. onslowi, P. campbelli, P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi moved into Leucocarbo (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). In past, often considered to include L. chalconotus and L. onslowi; these three were sometimes treated as conspecific with P. campbelli complex (campbelli, ranfurlyi and colensoi). Monotypic.

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. magellanicus, P. bougainvilliorum, P. atriceps, P. verrucosus, P. carunculatus, P. chalconotus, P. onslowi, P. campbelli, P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi moved into Leucocarbo (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). In past, often considered a subspecies of P. carunculatus (which see). Rawlence et al. (2016) argued for the instatement of the name stewarti for southern populations of Stewart Shag P. chalconotus in and around the Foveaux Strait, and its recognition as a species. In one sense their case is strong, inasmuch as the genetic differences between stewarti (“Foveaux Shag”) and ‘nominate’ chalconotus (“Otago Shag”) are greater than those between chalconotus and Chatham Shag P. onslowi, which the Checklist recognises. However, the evidence that Rawlence et al. (2016)  mustered is otherwise weak. They stated “The Chatham Island shag exhibits pied plumage only… with pronounced bright orange caruncles in breeding plumage… Otago shag populations have 20–30% pied morphs… and 50:50% small bright orange caruncles: dark orange scattered papillae in prenuptial breeding plumage… compared with 50–60% pied morph and dark orange scattered papillae in prenuptial breeding plumage in the Foveaux shag.” This information is repeated in their Table 1 which, however, fails to provide any further insight but which contains the paradoxical assertions that onslowi is ‘smaller on average than… L. stewarti’ and that stewarti is ‘similar in size to L. onslowi’. The paper concludes that “Hypothesis 3 (three species) is supported based on combined diagnosable evidence from genetic analysis, plumage characters, and morphometric and behavioural data. Specifically, these data strongly support recognition of L. onslowi, along with separate species status of the Otago and Foveaux lineages of L. chalconotus, under the diagnosable species concept (also known as the phylogenetic species concept…).” The plumage and morphometric characters that discriminate stewarti from chalconotus are, however, averages (i.e. these two taxa cannot be reliably diagnosed on morphology), and the ‘behavioural data’ appear to refer to the breeding season, with the latter breeding, like onslowi, from September whereas the former breeds in May–September, according to a 1983 PhD thesis. Curiously, however, HANZAB 1B (1990): 879 made no reference to this thesis and gives the breeding season as ‘at almost any time throughout the year, varying annually and from colony to colony, depending on weather and availability of food’. Given these weaknesses, the claim that the data assembled by Rawlence et al. (2016) ‘strongly support… separate species status’ for stewarti is insubstantial. We recognise stewarti as a subspecies. Two subspecies recognised.

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. magellanicus, P. bougainvilliorum, P. atriceps, P. verrucosus, P. carunculatus, P. chalconotus, P. onslowi, P. campbelli, P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi moved into Leucocarbo (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). In past, often considered a subspecies of L. campbelli (which see). Monotypic.

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. magellanicus, P. bougainvilliorum, P. atriceps, P. verrucosus, P. carunculatus, P. chalconotus, P. onslowi, P. campbelli, P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi moved into Leucocarbo (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). In past, often considered to include P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi; these three were sometimes treated as conspecific with P. carunculatus complex (carunculatus, chalconotus and onslowi), all then being listed as subspecies of P. carunculatus.
