Monotypic.

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. magellanicus, P. bougainvilliorum, P. atriceps, P. verrucosus, P. carunculatus, P. chalconotus, P. onslowi, P. campbelli, P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi moved into Leucocarbo (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. penicillatus, P. pelagicus and P. urile moved into Urile (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).

This species is often misidentified with the Taiwan Angelshark (Squatina formosa). Diagnostic features for this species include pelvic fin tips which extend to origin of the first dorsal fin and angular pelvic, dorsal, and caudal fins (Walsh et al. 2011).

This species is often misidentified with other regional Squatinids. Diagnostic features for Squatina japonica include pelvic fin tips which do not reach the first dorsal origin and spines along the midback line (Walsh et al. 2011).

McDowell (1972) first mentioned a specimen from Sepik River, East Sepik District, New Guinea (AMNH 104340) that was very similar to the ‘beaked sea snake’, Hydrophis schistosus, but showed some morphological characters which were not in accordance with H. schistosus. Later, Kharin (1985) described a new species, Enhydrina zweifeli, based on McDowell´s (1972) data. The morphological similarity between E. zweifeli and H. schistosus is striking. However, a recently published paper (Ukuwela et al. 2012) presented molecular evidence showing the two species represent distinct lineages and are not each other’s closest relatives, indicating convergent phenotypic evolution probably related to a specialist diet of large, spiny prey (Ukuwela et al. 2012). See also Rasmussen et al. (2014).

A phylogenetic study of 39 Sea Snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognising a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013).

Stolephorus continentalis was recently described based on 36 specimens collected off Hong Kong and northern Vietnam (Hata and Motomura 2018). It is morphologically similar to the congener S. chinensis.

This species was previously described as Stolephorus insularis oceanicus by Hardenburg (1933). Recently, it was tentatively elevated to the species level by Hata and Motomura (2018) as Stolephorus oceanicus. Detailed taxonomic studies are needed and in progress. For the purposes of the assessment, S. oceanicus will be treated as a valid species.

One of the most variable characters of the species is the length of dorsal and caudal fins. Specimens from rivers usually have a longer dorsal fin reaching or exceeding the adipose fin  compared to those from lakes and lagoons (Paugy et al. 2003).

This species is distinguished from all other Tylochromis occurring in West Africa except T. intermedius by presence of three scale rows (against two) between upper lateral line and the anterior part of lower lateral line (Paugy et al. 2003)
According to Paugy et al. (2003) Citharinus eburennsis is closely related to Citharinus citharus but distinct based on a number of meristic features.

Laeviscutella dekimpei is closely related to Sierrathrissa leonensis. However, it is distinguished from that taxon by the presence of non-keeled prepelvic scutes with ascending arms, and keeled postpelvic scutes lacking ascending arms as well as by the dorsal fin insertion at midbody above the pelvic fins. Sierrathrissa leonensis has both pre- and postpelvic scutes without keels or ascending arms, and the dorsal fin is situated clearly behind the pelvic insertion.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Liza but is now considered valid in the genus Neochelon.
The name ‘scheeli’ has frequently, and erroneously, been used for Poropanchax stigmatopygus.
This species was previously misidentified as Melamphaes microps.

There are no issues regarding the validity of the species, but it should be noted that it is often confused with Elops senegalensis (Whitehead 1990). Elops senegalensis and E. lacerta occur sympatrically across the entire range of E. senegalensis, so further research appears warranted.

Even though Elops lacerta and Elops senegalensis occur sympatrically across the entire range and appear confusing with each other they can always be distinguished by number of scales on the lateral line; 92-100 for E. senegalensis and 72-83 for E. lacerta (Paugy et al. 2003).
There are nuclear and mitochondrial genetic markers available for the identification of this species and its hybrids.

Molecular studies strongly suggest that Russian Sturgeon (Acipenser gueldenstaedtii) is very closely related to Persian Sturgeon (Acipenser persicus), and it may be the case that these two taxa are conspecific. However, this is still under discussion, and currently they are treated as two separate species.

Molecular studies strongly suggest that Persian Sturgeon (Acipenser persicus) is very closely related to Russian Sturgeon (Acipenser gueldenstaedtii) and it cannot be excluded that these two taxa are conspecific. However, this is still under discussion, and currently they are treated as two separate species.
The Adriatic population described as a subspecies and may have been a conservation unit, is now extinct.

The placement of this species in the Macrouridae is not supported by current morphological and genetic analyses; instead, it belongs in the family Steindachneriidae (Howes 1993, Roa-Varón and Ortí 2009).
Species in the genus Barathronus were previously classified in the family Aphyonidae before reclassification to Bythitidae by Moller et al. (2016).
Species in the genus Barathronus were previously classified in the family Aphyonidae before reclassification to Bythitidae by Moller et al. (2016).
This species has been considered a synonym of Lophius piscatorius by some workers in the past.
This species is commonly confused with Malacocephalus occidentalis and Ventrifossa mucocephalus (Cohen et al. 1990).
This species is commonly confused with Ventrifossa macropogon.

The systematics of the genus Chiasmodon is still poorly understood and the exact number of species is unknown. There are two main theories: Prokofiev and Kukuev (2009) consider the existence of only two species in the genus (C. niger and C. lavenbergi), while Melo (2009) defends the existence of seven species in the genus (including C. microcephalus). For the purposes of this assessment, we are treating C. microcephalus as a valid species. Further taxonomic research on this genus is needed.

The systematics of the genus Chiasmodon is still poorly understood and the exact number of species is unknown. There are two main theories: Prokofiev and Kukuev (2009) consider the existence of only two species in the genus (C. niger and C. lavenbergi), while Melo (2009) defends the existence of seven species in the genus (including C. pluriradiatus). For the purpose of this assessment, we are treating C. pluriradiatus as a valid species. Further taxonomic research on this genus is needed.

Two species descriptions were occurring simultaneously, Kali caribbaea Prokofiev 2008 and K. colubrina Melo 2008. These descriptions were accepted and published within a very short time, leading to disagreement as to which species name had priority (Melo 2010, Prokofiev 2011). Based on the ICZN rules and interpretations, K. colubrina was given priority (e.g., Melo 2010, Eschmeyer et al. 2018).

There is some disagreement on the validity of this species. Pseudoscopelus australis was described by Prokofiev and Kukuev (2008) on the basis of a single specimen from Antarctica (specific locality information unavailable) but later synonymized with P. australis by Melo (2010). For the purposes of this assessment, it is treated as a valid species; however, further taxonomic research is needed to confirm its status.
Some of the specimens identified as Pseudoscopelus aphos by Melo (2010) may refer to P. parini (Prokofiev 2011).
There is an ongoing discussion on the correct identification of this species - especially whether it is valid in the Atlantic as according to Prokofiev (2009, 2011), or not (Melo 2010).

This species was considered a junior synonym of Bathyanthias cubensis by McEachran and Fechhelm (2005), but the Catalog of Fishes does not reference this. There are specimens of both B. cubensis and B. mexicanus taken off Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico, and they are recognized as distinct (M. Vegas-Cendejas pers. comm. 2018). However, specimens examined from Colombia by A. Polanco pers. comm. (2018) are recognized as B. cubensis. The genus Bathyanthias requires further taxonomic study, and it is not known how the ranges of B. mexicanus and B. cubensis overlap in the Gulf of Mexico (D.R. Robertson pers. comm. 2018).

Poulsen et al. (2018) placed this species under the family Neocyematidae and resolved the hypothesis that identified Leptocephalus holti specimens as Cyematidae larvae (Poulsen 2015, Poulsen et al. 2018).
Specimens of this species may have been previously identified as Melamphaes longivelis.
This species was previously identified as Melamphaes longivelis.
This species may have been previously identified as Melamphaes janae.
This species is part of a complex of various forms of Melamphaes, and some further taxonomic work may be needed (Kotlyar 2011, Stewart and Bray 2015).
This species is part of the ‘Poromitra cristiceps-group’ (Stewart and Bray 2015).
According to Kotlyar (2008), this species is similar to Poromitra unicornis.

This species was recently described from one specimen previously identified as Poromitra crassiceps (Kotlyar 2008). Subsequently, Mincarone et al. (2014) suggested that P. kukuevi and P. indooceanica are synonyms and that further taxonomic work is needed.
This species may have been previously identified as a juvenile of Scopleoberyx robustus.

Taxonomy in the family Gonostomatidae has been continuously discussed. The genera Diplophos and Manducus have been both combined and separated in the past, and consensus about their relatedness remains in flux (Weitzman 1974, Harold 1998).
There is some taxonomic uncertainty associated with this species.
This species was previously referred to as Maurolicus muelleri by Vazzoler (1975), Zavala-Camin (1981), Séret and Andreata (1992) and Haimovici et al. (1994).

Bathophilus longipes has been treated as a junior synonym of B. digitatus by some authors, but is considered a valid species according to the Catalog of Fishes. Given this taxonomic uncertainty, its distribution is not clearly understood (T. Harold pers. comm. 2018).
There is taxonomic uncertainty associated with Chauliodus dentatus; it has been treated at times as a junior synonym of C. sloani (T. Harold pers. comm. 2018).
According to Gomon and Gibbs (1985), the status of this species is “uncertain”, but it is considered valid by Harold (2002).

Gomon and Gibbs (1985) list the status of this species as “uncertain” since the holotype is an incompletely metamorphosed specimen; however, Harold (2002) accepts Eustomias micropterygius as a valid species.
This species was once considered a subspecies of Eustomias bigelowi (Parin and Pokhil’skaya 1974). It is considered a valid species by Clarke (2000, 2001) and Harold (2002).
This species was previously considered a synonym of Melanostomias macrophotus by Gibbs and Barnett (1990) and Mundy (2005).
This species was previously considered a synonym of Photonectes mirablis Parr, 1927 (Gibbs and Barnett 1990, Prokofiev 2014).
This species was once considered a synonym of Stomias boa Risso, 1910, but also a valid subspecies (Paulin et al. 1989).
This species is sometimes referred to as Liza aurata, but a series of studies published since 2010 have demonstrated that Liza is a synonym of Chelon.
This species is sometimes referred to as Liza saliens, but a series of studies published since 2010 have demonstrated that Liza is a synonym of Chelon.

Chelon dumerili is the only species of Liza whose distribution extends from the tropical Atlantic Ocean, around the Cape, to the Indian Ocean coast of Africa. Some authors have suggested that geographically distant populations should be recognised as different subspecies. Delais (1954), studying mullets from Mauritania and Senegal, recognized two subspecies: C. saliens dumerili from the north with 37-42 (mode 40) scales in longitudinal series, and C. saliens hoefleri in the south with 33-42 (mode 36) scales. However, scale counts for specimens from different regions of West Africa might not be as clearly demarked as Delais (1954) suggested and there is insufficient evidence of a subspecific distinction between dumerili and hoefleri. Trewavas and Ingham (1972) recognized two subspecies of Chelon dumerili: C. d. dumerili characterized by 37-41 gill rakers and distributed from Senegal to the Niger river; and C. d. canaliculatus characterized by 45-55 gill rakers and distributed from the Congo river to Mozambique. However, the diagnostic difference in raker numbers is not consistent for all specimens examined from the western and southern ranges. Some variation has been detected in pharyngobranchial organ morphology for C. dumerili, but this variation is not sufficient to define separate species or subspecies. Further analyses are in progress.
Heemstra and Heemstra (2004) describes the taxonomy of the Mugilidae family as confused and the genera as obscurely defined.

This species has been placed in several different genera in the past, however, a recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors.

A recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors.

There are three forms of this species (Smith 1926).
This species is sometimes referred to as Liza ramada, but a series of studies published since 2010 have shown that Liza is a synonym of Chelon.
This species was previously considered a synonym of Lophiodes mutilus (Caruso 1981), but is now accepted as valid according to Ho et al. (2016).
Some variations were observed in the specimens collected from the Indonesian population. Examination of additional specimens may provide better information for the species (Ho et al. 2016).
Preliminary molecular and morphological analysis indicates Sladenia remiger may actually be a junior synonym of S. gardineri (J. Caruso pers. comm. 2019).
Preliminary molecular and morphological analysis indicates Sladenia remiger may actually be a junior synonym of S. gardineri (J. Caruso pers. comm. 2019).
Lophiodes infrabrunneus is a junior synonym of L. triradiatus (Ho et al. 2014).
There is a possibility that the populations from Sundaic southeast Asia are not conspecific with those from mainland southeast Asia.
Mareca americana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.

Archaelogical remains suggest that Acipenser sturio colonised the Baltic Sea about 3,000 years ago from the North Sea, and vanished from the Baltic Sea about 800 years ago. Climatic changes about 100 years ago (Little Ice Age) might have had an impact indirectly in favouring introgression by hybridization with A. oxyrinchus.

Some authors consider this species valid under Hyrcanogobius, who place it in this genus on the basis of slightly different organisation of cephalic sensory pores. Here, we follow Kottelat and Freyhof (2007) and consider it valid in the genus Knipowitschia.

Specimens identified as this species taken in relatively shallow waters are likely to be a separate species from specimens taken in deeper waters. The species Bidenichthys consobrinus is argued to be the more common, shallow-water species, with B. beeblebroxi as a junior synonym. The more rare, deep-water specimens probably represent B. paxtoni (Møller and Nielsen 2015).

This species was previously assigned to the now synonymized genus Fiordichthys (Paulin 1995, Nielsen et al. 2004, Møller and Nielsen 2015). Specimens of Bidenichthys consobrinus or B. beeblebroxi captured at deeper depths possibly represent B. paxtoni, but further work is needed (A. Williams pers. comm. 2019).
Future taxonomic work may reveal separate species within Brosmophyciops pautzkei (Nielsen et al. 1999).

Eurypleuron cinereum (Smith 1955) is currently a junior synonym of Eurypleuron owasianum (Eschmeyer et al. 2018), but Williams and Machida (1992) tentatively consider E. cinereum a valid species. If E. cinereum is in fact a valid species, E. owasianum (type locality: Japan) is found in the western Pacific north of 20°N, and E. cinereum (type locality: Mozambique) to the Indian Ocean and southwestern Pacific south of 20°N. Further taxonomic work is needed on this possible species-complex.

Geographical variation marked, but considerable intergradation of subspecies; phylogenetic analysis reveals considerable genetic variation, with S all-blue and white-spotted forms ancestral to N red-spotted subspecies (Johnsen et al. 2006). The species of Cynoglossus that has been confused with this should be recognized as C. quadrilineatus (Bleeker 1851) according to Kottelat (2013).

The placement of this species in the family Gadidae is not supported according to current morphological and genetic analyses; instead, it belongs in the family Gaidropsaridae (Howes 1993, Roa-Varón and Ortí 2009, Iwamoto 2016, Nelson et al. 2016).

This species is distributed in two disjunct localities: the eastern Pacific (type locality) and eastern Indian Ocean (Caruso 1989). It is possible that specimens from these two localities represent distinct species, but further taxonomic research is needed (Caruso 1989, Lundsten et al. 2012, Ho and McGrouther 2015).
This species belongs to the Chaunax fimbriatus-species group (Ho and Last 2013).

Chaunax stigmaeus is highly suspected to be a synonym of C. pictus, but until gene sequencing research is conducted, C. stigmaeus remains recognized as distinct (J. Caruso and R. Robertson pers. comm. 2018). Chaunax pictus is the older name, therefore, C. stigmaeus would be designated as a synonym of C. pictus.

This species is known from only male specimens, and given the uncertainty associated with this method, especially for members of Gigantactinidae, significant taxonomic uncertainty is associated with this species until a female specimen is verified (Pietsch 2005, Pietsch 2009, Priede 2017).
Pietsch and Kenaley (2011) recently described a new species from the Himantolophus appelii species group based on specimens that had been misidentified as H. appelii.
This species was once considered a synonym of Himantolophus groenlandicus Reinhardt, 1837.

This species was described by Tanaka (1918) and was later brought in to synonymy with Himantolophus groenlandicus Reinhardt, 1837 (Regan 1927, Bertelsen 1951). The genus name Sciaena should be restricted to Sciaena umbra, which is a Mediterranean species. Therefore the original genus name Cheilotrema (Tschudi 1846) should be used (N.L. Chao pers. comm.).
Specimens from various parts of the species' patchy range need to be critically examined to understand if these represent the same species.

This species was described with no type specimen and locality, but it has been presumed to be from the Arabian Gulf (Wallace 1967, Compagno 1986, Carvalho et al. 2002). It is considered to be one of the most widely distributed electric rays of the Western Indian Ocean (Carvalho et al. 2002, Last et al. 2016). However, the status of this species is uncertain as it is possibly a species-complex (Last et al. 2016). It is highly variable and confused with the Panther Torpedo (Torpedo panthera) (Last et al. 2016). The present account is therefore provisional, and in the event that species within the complex are better delineated, reassessment will be required (this may result in the status of electric rays being revised upwards, on the basis of small populations with localized distributions).
This species was originally described as Dolopichthys flagellifer Regan & Trewavas, 1932.

This species was long considered a junior synonym of Malthopsis lutea, but according to Ho and Shao (2010), it is a valid separate species. It belongs to the Malthopsis tiarella species complex.

The taxonomy of the Malthopsis genus has been long debated, and is in need of further revision (Bradbury 2003). Malthopsis mitrigera, M. annulifera, M. tiarella and M. kobayashii have been considered junior synonyms of M. lutea by some authors in the past, but all are currently considered valid species (Ho and Shao 2010). It belongs to the Malthopsis annulifera species complex.

The taxonomy of the Malthopsis genus has been long debated, and is in need of further revision (Bradbury 2003). This species is quite distinct and is unlikely to be confused with other taxa (H. Ho pers. comm. 2019).
This is a recently described species with a clear diagnosis and is not likely to be confused with other species. It belongs to the Malthopsis annulifera species complex (H. Ho pers. comm. 2019).

This species was once part of the wide-ranging Polyipnus spinosus species complex, but it is now considered restricted to the seas off Australia (Borodulina 1979).
This species is under review presently (A. Harold pers. comm. 2019).
This species was previously referred to as Trachinostomias munificus (Prokofiev 2015).

This species is genetically and morphologically similar to Siganus vulpinus, but differs in coloration (Nanami 2015). Species of the family Siganidae are known for their morphological uniformity, therefore, for some authors, the colour has been enough to consider both species valid; while for others, S. unimaculatus is only a color variety of S. vulpinus. Further studies are necessary to understand its taxonomic status (Gawel and Woodland 1974, Kuriiwa et al. 2007). It has also been suggested that two sub-genera exist within Siganus: Siganus and Lo, with this species belonging to the latter. Borsa and colleagues (2007) have suggested that this division does not exist and all species should be considered as Siganus.
<span lang="EN-CA">

This species was previously considered under Didymothallus mizolepis (Schwarzhans and Møller 2007). After further study, it is now understood to be valid as Didymothallus nudigena and distributed in central and northwestern Western Australia. It may overlap geographically with D. mizolepis (Schwarzhans and Møller 2011).
This species was previously considered under Majungaichthys simplex, but was described as a valid species by Schwarzhans and Møller (2011).
This species was previously misidentified as Neobythites steatiticus and N. stefanovi (Uiblein and Nielsen 2018).
This species has been misidentified as Neobythites fasciatus in most previous Japanese fish literature (Nielsen 2002).

This species is possibly a synonym of Ophidion muraenolepis according to Nielsen et al. (1999) and Randall (2007). Further work is needed to compare the materials of these species (H. Ho and F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species is questionably distinct from Ophidion genyopus from southeastern Australia (Nielsen et al. 1990, J. Nielsen and F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
The Porogadus genus requires revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).
The Porogadus genus requires revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).
The Porogadus genus requires revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).
The Porogadus genus requires revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).
The Porogadus genus requires revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).
The Porogadus genus requires revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).
The Porogadus genus requires revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).
There is some taxonomic uncertainty associated with this species (Struhsaker 1973).
This species was transferred from the genus Spottobrotula to Sirembo by Nielsen et al. (2014).

Plectorhinchus griseus was previously treated as a junior synonym of P. schotaf; however, it has been confirmed as a valid species due to the distinguishing characters of body depth and dorsal-fin ray count (Johnson and Wilmer 2015).
Enneanectes flavus replaces E. matador in Venezuela, Aruba, Bonaire, Curacao, Tobago and up to St. Vincent, and both species occur at St. Vincent (Victor 2019).
There is taxonomic uncertainty associated with this recently described species. According to Prokofiev (2010), this species is a junior synonym of Chiasmodon lavenbergi.

The family Cheilodactylidae has long been the subject of taxonomic debate. Cheilodactylus nigripes has been considered part of the subgenus Goniistius, however some authors defend it should be excluded from it (Burridge and White 2000). Recently, Ludt and colleagues (2019) performed extensive taxonomic sampling analyzing morphological characters and molecular data to resolve taxonomic issues with the families Cheilodactylidae and Latridae. It was concluded that this species belongs to the family Latridae and to the new, monotypic genus Pseudogoniistius; therefore, Pseudogoniistius nigripes (Richardson 1850) is a valid species (Ludt et al. 2019).
There is taxonomic uncertainty associated with this species. According to Melo (2009), Chiasmodon lavenbergi Prokofiev 2008, is a synonym of C. pluriradiatus Parr 1933.
This species can be easily misidentified as Pseudoscopelus scutatus (Prokofiev and Kukuev 2007, Melo 2010).

Pseudoscopelus cephalus is included in the P. scriptus species-groups along with P. cordilluminatus, P. obtusifrons, P. pierbartus, P. sagamianus and P. scriptus (Melo 2010). Recent reviews affirmed it is a valid species and have not identified further specimens beyond the holotype.

According to Melo (2010), Pseudoscopelus parini and P. vityazi are the same species that was described twice using the same diagnostic characters. However, Prokofiev (2011) still regards P. vityazi as a valid species. According to Eschmeyer's Catalog of Fishes, P. vityazi is currently considered a synonym of P. parini (Fricke et al. 2019); therefore, for the purposes of this Red List assessment, all records of P. vityazi will be treated as P. parini.
There is taxonomic uncertainty associated with this species. According to Prokofiev (2011), Pseudoscopelus paxtoni is a synonym of P. altipinnis.

This species was recently split from Atractoscion aequidens (Cuvier 1830) (Song et al. 2017). Atractoscion atelodus Song, Kim & Kang 2017 is endemic to the eastern coasts of Australia while Atractoscion aequidens (Cuvier 1830) occurs off South Africa. Therefore, literature referring to A. aequidens (Cuvier 1830) off Australia is actually A. atelodus Song, Kim & Kang 2017.

This species was recently split from Atractoscion aequidens (Cuvier 1830) (Song et al. 2017). Atractoscion microlepis Song, Kim & Kang 2017 is known from Oman while Atractoscion aequidens (Cuvier 1830) occurs off South Africa. Therefore, literature referring to A. aequidens (Cuvier 1830) from the Arabian Sea is likely to be A. microlepis Song, Kim & Kang 2017.

Achirus zebrinus Clark 1936 was described on the basis of a single specimen. It was not until 1977, when Castro-Aguirre et al. listed a second capture for this species. And, in 1999, Castro-Aguirre et al. reported that this species was poorly represented in museum collections. They also commented that the taxonomic status of this nominal species is uncertain. Supporting this hypothesis is the fact that this species was not included in three major works on the fish fauna of the tropical eastern Pacific (Allen and Robertson 1994, Krupp 1995, Robertson and Allen 2015). However, numerous specimens identified as this species are listed in several ecological works on fishes of the Gulf of Tehuantepec (e.g. Tapia-García and Mendoza-Rodríguez 2005, Martinez-Muñoz et al. 2016) and some of these specimens are listed in museum databases (accessed via iDigBio portal, https://www.idigbio.org/, 2021 March). Provided that these ecological works have correctly identified specimens as Achirus zebrinus, then it appears that this species is more abundant than historical literature indicates and possibly that this species has a rather restricted distribution off southern Mexico.

Chabanaud (1928) described this nominal species on the basis of about 11 specimens taken from Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. In an unpublished dissertation, Ramos (1998) indicated that Catathyridium grandirivi is a junior, subjective synonym of C. garmani. This opinion has not been recognized by subsequent authors (e.g. Desoutter et al. 2001, Fricke et al. 2021). For the purposes of this assessment, C. grandirivi is treated as a valid species. Further work is needed to determine the taxonomic status of this nominal species.
This species was previously confused with Anodontostoma chacunda.

Diagnosis:

  • Dorsal with 12-13 banched rays; anal with 37-43 branched rays; pectoral with 12-13 branched rays; pelvic with seven banched rays. 41-44 body along scales.
  • Body is long and very compressed. Short head. Snout is obtuse and short. Mouth extending to head.
  • One average dorsal fin with one small spine in anterior. Anal fin is long. Pectoral is quite large. Pelvic fin is small and short.
  • Scales are round and easy leave. Axillary scale in pectoral and pelvic fins. No lateral line.
  • Belly with 23 to 26 keeled scutes from isthmus to anus. Tip of snout above level of eye center, usually about level of upper rim of eye. Maxilla short or moderate; first supra-maxilla small, oval. A dark blotch behind upper part of gill opening.
Hilsa kelee was originally described as Clupea kelee by Cuvier (1829) from Vishakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh, India.

Sardinops sagax has historically comprised five geographically isolated subpopulations that were given taxonomic names at some time in their history. There has been considerable confusion as to what rank these subpopulations should be recognized. The current version of the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2018) accepts three valid species within this complex: S. sagax (Jenyns 1842), S. melanosticta (Temminck and Schlegel 1846) and S. ocellatus (Pappe 1853). However, the most recent global analyses found no morphological or genetic differentiation between any of the five subpopulations (Parrish et al. 1989, Grant and Leslie 1996). Therefore, for the purposes of this assessment, we are treating S. sagax as a single species with five geographically isolated subpopulations.

Historically, the genetic level placement of this species has been confused in the literature. Currently, it is placed in the genus Anchoa (Miller 1945). However, in more recent taxonomic reviews of engraulids (e.g., Whitehead et al. 1988, Loeb et al. 2018) this species seems to be more appropriately placed within the genus Anchoviella. As this species is currently considered to be valid as Anchoa analis in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2018), for the purposes of this assessment, Anchoa analis will be used as the valid species name.

There is uncertainty about this species' geographical distribution, and taxonomic studies should be undertaken to confirm whether populations from Sundaic southeast Asia are conspecific with those from mainland southeast Asia. Currently, no evidence is available to support this species distribution outside of northwestern Borneo and it is considered that the existing records outside that region are erroneous and likely refer to Tenualosa ilisha or T. macrura (D. Milton pers. com. 2011). Therefore, for the purposes of the assessment, the distribution of Tenualosa toli is restricted to Sarawak, Malaysia.

Several sub-species of Sprattus sprattus have been recognized, which are distinguished by small differences, mainly in numbers of post-pelvic scutes; S. sprattus sprattus; S. sprattus phalericus (Mediterranean, Adriatic, Black Sea); S. sprattus balticus (Baltic Sea). The subspecies S. sprattus balticus ranges from southern Skagerrak, and Mecklenburg and Kiel Bays to Kvarken in the Gulf of Bothnia, and to Kornstadt in the Gulf of Finland (FAO 2017). However, no genetic evidence for a subspecies in the Baltic Sea or the occurrence of one subspecies in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea has been found (Debes et al. 2008). Rather, population analysis using the mT Control Region supported four genetically distinct groups of S. sprattus, which fall under two major phylogroups; Phylogroup 1: Northern group (Baltic Sea, North Sea and Bay of Biscay) and Gulf of Lyon group; and Phylogroup 2: Adriatic Sea group and Black Sea group (Bosporus and Black Sea: Debes et al. 2008). The Strait of Sicily, with water temperatures of 24-25 oC, acts as a dispersal barrier between eastern and Western Mediterranean.

Separation of S. aurita from S. brasiliensis based on gill raker shape is tentative (Whitehead 1985). Sardinella brasiliensis may be a junior synonym of S. aurita (Whitehead 1985).  Purported differences in gill raker morphology between these two nominal species need to be confirmed.  More study is needed to evaluate the morphological and genetic differences between and among these populations in order to determine their taxonomic status (Whitehead 1985, Munroe 2002). Recent studies based on molecular data indicate that S. brasiliensis is a junior synonym of S. aurita (Mabragana et al. 2011, Stern et al. 2017) but this species is still recognized as valid (Eschmeyer et al. 2017). Sardinella janeiro (Eigenmann, 1894) has been erroneously applied for Sardinella brasiliensis in some older publications (Figueiredo et al. 2010). For the purposes of this assessment, Sardinella brasiliensis will be treated as valid.

Sardinella gibbosa is often confused with S. fimbriata in Indian waters (Whitehead 1985). There is at least one cryptic species present in the northern Philippines that has been called S. gibbosa (Thomas et al. 2014).
Hybridization has occurred between N. come and N. japonica at Okinawa (Imai et al. 2009, Uehara et al. 2009).
It is commonly misidentified which may make some of the data unreliable.

Some confusion has existed regarding the geographical distribution of Sardinella jussieu because some authors placed S. dayi, which is known from southern India and Sri Lanka, into the synonymy of this species. Currently, both species are regarded as valid.  
Sardinella dayi was described from Karwar, India, and S. jussieu was described from Mauritius. Wongratana (1980) recognized both as valid species. Subsequently, S. dayi was considered a junior subjective synonym of S. jussieu (Whitehead 1985). More recently, S. dayi has been recognized as a valid species (e.g., Bijukumar and Sushama 2000, Mishra and Krishnan 2003). This hypothesis is also supported by the conclusions of Hata (pers. comm. 2018). Therefore, for purposes of this assessment, specimens collected off southern India and Sri Lanka are considered to be S. dayi. Specimens collected at insular localities in the southwestern Indian Ocean (Reunion, Mauritius, and Madagascar) are considered to be Sardinella jussieu.

This species has been previously misidentified as Sardinella longiceps (Willette and Santos 2013). There may be a second undescribed species in the Philippines similar to S. lemuru (H. Hata unpublished data); however, further research is required for confirmation.
Records of this species from India may refer to the similar Thryssa kammalensoides (Whitehead et al. 1988).

Whitehead et al. (1988) report taxonomic confusion regarding identifications of this species. They note that perhaps all records since description of the species have been either compilations or misidentifications.

Confusion exists regarding the taxonomic status and geographical distribution of Sardinella dayi. Sardinella dayi was described from Karwar, India, and S. jussieu was described from Mauritius. Wongratana (1980) recognized both as valid species. Subsequently, S. dayi was considered a junior subjective synonym of S. jussieu (Whitehead 1985). More recently, S. dayi has been recognized as a valid species (e.g., Bijukumar and Sushama 2000, Mishra and Krishnan 2003). This hypothesis is also supported by the conclusions of Hata (pers. comm. 2018). Therefore, for purposes of this assessment, specimens collected off southern India and Sri Lanka are considered to be S. dayi. Specimens collected at insular localities in the southwestern Indian Ocean (Reunion, Mauritius, and Madagascar) are considered to be Sardinella jussieu.
This species may be misidentified as Spratelloides gracilis and S. delicatus.

The validity of Alosa pontica is questioned in the literature. Some refer to this species as a synonym of A. immaculata (Kottelat 1997, Bogutskaya and Naseka 2004, Parin et al. 2014); others recognize it to be a valid species (Svetovidov 1973, Whitehead et al. 1984, Whitehead 1985, Hoestlandt 1991, Kolarov 1991, Coad 1995, Vasil'eva 1996, Reshetnikov et al. 1997, Dorofeeva 1998, Coad 1998, Bilecenoglu et al. 2002, Vassilev and Pehlivanov 2005, Eschmeyer et al. 2017).  For the purposes of this assessment, Alosa pontica will will be treated as valid.
Coilia mystus is easily confused with the co-occurring C. nasus (Whitehead et al. 1988).

The scientific name of this species has been contested in the past. In China, it has been referred to by Coilia ectenes (Whitehead et al. 1988).

There are taxonomic uncertainties surrounding the species of Coilia present in China, Korea, and Japan. For the purposes of this assessment, we are treating C. nasus as being distributed in China, Korea, and Japan, as treated in Whitehead et al. (1988).
This species can easily be confused with Coilia borneensis (Whitehead et al. 1988).

The most recent global analysis of the world's clupeoid fishes treated Engraulis australis (Shaw 1790) as valid (Whitehead et al. 1988), but noted the similarities between this species and the four other Old World anchovies, E. capensis Gilchrist 1913, E. encrasicolus (Linnaeus 1758), E. eurystole (Swain & Meek 1884) and E. japonicus Temminck & Schlegel 1846; further taxonomic study may conclude that these five similar species which are treated as valid are perhaps one species with five geographically isolated subpopulations (Whitehead et al. 1988). As this species is currently considered valid in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2018), for the purposes of this assessment Engraulis australis is considered a valid species distributed along the southern coast of Australia and off New Zealand.

The validity of this species is uncertain according to the literature (Whitehead, 1985). Engraulis capensis Gilchrist 1913 was originally described from South Africa with no type specimen known. This species has previously been considered a junior synonym of E. japonicas Temminck & Schlegel 1846 by Whitehead and Wongratana (1986) and E. encrasicolus (Linnaeus 1758) by Whitehead (1990). The most recent global analysis of the world's clupeoid fishes treated this species as valid (Whitehead et al. 1988), but noted the similarities between these three species and two other Old World anchovies, E. eurystole (Swain & Meek 1884) and E. australis (Shaw 1790); further taxonomic study may conclude that these five similar species which are treated as valid are perhaps one species with five geographically isolated subpopulations (Whitehead et al. 1988). However, as all five species in the encrasicolus group (E. australis, E. capensis, E. encrasicolus, E. eurystole and E. japonicus) are currently considered valid in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2018), for the purposes of this assessment, Engraulis capensis is considered a valid species distributed along the southern coast of Africa.

The most recent global analysis of the world's clupeoid fishes treated Engraulis japonicus Temminck & Schlegel 1846 as valid (Whitehead et al. 1988), but noted the similarities between this species and the four other Old World anchovies, E. australis (Shaw 1790), E. capensis Gilchrist 1913, E. encrasicolus (Linnaeus 1758) and E. eurystole (Swain & Meek 1884); further taxonomic study may conclude that these five similar species which are treated as valid are perhaps one species with five geographically isolated subpopulations (Whitehead et al. 1988). As this species is currently considered valid in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2018), for the purposes of this assessment Engraulis japonicus is considered a valid species distributed off the coasts of Japan, Korea and Taiwan as well as parts of China and Russia; records of this species in the western Indian Ocean (e.g., Madagascar) are considered to be in reference to E. capensis.

Randall and DiBattista (2012) proposed Etrumeus acuminatus as a valid species. According to the Catalog of Fishes, the name was valid in Eschmeyer and Herald (1983); but not in Whitehead (1985). This species was considered Etrumes teres, but was changed back to the older name Etrumeus sadina. All accounts of either Etrumeus teres or E. sadina in the eastern Pacific are most likely Etrumeus acuminatus (Randall and DiBattista 2012). DiBattista et al. (2014) provided molecular evidence that this species is valid and distinct from other species of Etrumeus from the Pacific Ocean.
This species was recently separated from Etrumeus sadina (Dibattista et al. 2012) which was previously recognized as E. teres by Whitehead (1985).

This species was recently recognized as a species separated from E. sadina and E. whiteheadi off the coast of eastern Africa (DiBattista et al. 2012) which was previously recognized as E. teres by Whitehead (1985). This species is very similar to E. golanii (DiBattista et al. 2012). E. wongratanai can be easily separated from E. sadina based on vertebral counts (52-53 vs. 49, respectively: DiBattista et al. 2012).

This nominal species has previously been considered a junior synonym of Arnoglossus muelleri (Gomon et al. 1994) and its status remains questionable (KA pers. comm. 2019). More research is needed to determine the validity of this species.

The generic placement of this species is uncertain (K. Amaoka pers. comm. 2019). It was originally described in the genus Paralichthys (Steindachner 1898) but was later placed in Arnoglossus (Pequeno and Lamilla 2000).
Arnoglossus kotthausi was designated as a replacement name for Arnoglossus profundus Kotthaus 1977 (Klausewitz and Schneider 1986).
The status of this recently-described species is uncertain (K. Amaoka pers. comm. 2019).

This species is regarded as valid by some authors; however, others consider it to be a synonym of Bothus maculiferus (Poey 1860) (Munroe 2002). Poey (1860) described Bothus ellipticus and Bothus maculiferus in the same publication and identified them as separate species.

The taxonomic status of this nominal species is uncertain. D. Hensley considered Bothus tricirrhitus a synonym of B. pantherinus (in litt., Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003), but no formal taxonomic revision has been published.
The status of this recently-described species, known only from the type series, is uncertain. More research is needed to verify the validity of this nominal species (K. Amaoka pers. comm. 2019).
This species is often referred to as Chascanopsetta prognathus.
This may be the senior synonym of Crossorhombus kanekonis and of Engyrosopon kanekonis (Hensley and Randall 1993, Shao et al. 2008).
Scaeops ui Tanaka 1918, reported as Engyprosopon ui (Tanaka 1918), is a junior synonym of Crossorhombus kobensis (Hensley and Amaoka 2001).

The nominal species Anticitharus annulatus Weber 1913 was historically considered a junior synonym of Asterorhombus intermedius (Bleeker 1866). It was recognized as a valid species in the genus Asterorhombus by Amoaka and Mihara (2001), but during the generic revision of Asterorhombus (Hensley 2005), it was transferred to the genus Engyprosopon. However, its general appearance is different from most species of Engyprosopon and its generic placement remains in question (Hensley 2005).

This species was originally described as Arnoglossus bleekeri Macleay 1881 based on a young specimen (Amaoka and Arai 1998). It was later placed in the genus Asterorhombus (Hensley and Randall 2003), but during the generic revision of Asterorhombus it was transferred to the genus Engyprosopon (Hensley 2005).

This species was originally described as Asterorhombus osculus Amaoka and Arai 1998, and later transferred to Engyprosopon, when the genus Asterorhombus was redefined (Hensley and Randall 2003, Hensley 2005).
This species was originally described as the subspecies Arnoglossus aspilos praeteritus Whitley 1950, and later considered a junior synonym of Arnoglossus aspilos (Amaoka and Last 2014).

The validity of Grammatobothus krempfi Chabanaud 1929 is questionable. This nominal species was described on the basis of a single specimen taken in the South China Sea off Con Son Island, southeastern Viet Nam (Chabanaud 1929). This appears to be the only record for this species for which there is a voucher specimen. Records from Taiwan (Shen 1983, 1993; Li and Wang 1995; Hensley and Amaoka 2001; Shao et al. 2008; Shen and Wu 2012) are questionable, because at least one is based on a misidentification and for the other records, no voucher specimens exist to verify the identifications of these specimens (Amaoka and Ho 2019). Further specimens are needed to validate the taxonomic status of this nominal species.

Uncertainty has surrounded the taxonomic status of Laeops lanceolata Franz 1910. This nominal species was synonymized with Laeops kitaharae by Amaoka (1969). Later authors (e.g., Li and Wang 1995, Voronina 2016) treated L. lanceolata as valid; however, in a personal communication, Amaoka (2019) still maintained that L. lanceolata was not a valid species. In the most recent revision of the genus Laeops by Voronina et al. (2020), Laeops lanceolata is considered to be a valid species. Additionally, L. kitaharae was placed in the synonymy of L. parviceps. These decisions are followed herein.

Ho et al. (2009) determined that the type series of Laeops tungkongensis Chen and Weng 1965 could be identified as L. clarus Fowler 1934 using the taxonomic key of Hensley and Amaoka (2001). However, as Ho et al. (2009) were unable to examine the type series of L. clarus, they made no further comparisons and made the taxonomic decision to regard L. tungkongensis as valid.

Later, Amaoka and Ho (2019) examined types of Laeops tungkongensis Chen and Weng 1965 and Laeops kitaharae Smith and Pope 1906. They determined L. tungkongensis to be a junior subjective synonym of L. kitaharae.

Voronina et al. (2020), in a revision of the genus Laeops, examined types of L. tungkongensis and L. clarus and determined that L. tungkongensis Chen and Weng 1965 is a junior synonym of L. clarus Fowler 1934. They also determined that L. kitaharae Smith and Pope 1906 is a junior synonym of L. parviceps Günther 1880. These conclusions are followed herein.

Laeops parviceps Günther 1880 was described based on three specimens collected during the voyage of the H.M.S. Challenger in 1873-1876. Voronina et al. (2020) determined that two of the three syntypes, collected off Twofold Bay, New South Wales, Australia, were not members of the genus Laeops; thus, Voronina et al. (2020) designated the third syntype (BMNH 1879.5.14.98), collected in the Arafura Sea, as the lectotype of Laeops parviceps.

Species of Lophonectes exhibit ontogentic and sexually dimorphic variation (Munroe 2015). Lophonectes mongonuiensis has been considered a junior synonym of L. gallus, but differs in meristic and morphological characters and is therefore considered a valid species (Munroe 2015).

Species of Lophonectes exhibit ontogentic and sexually dimorphic variation (Munroe 2015). Lophonectes mongonuiensis has been considered a junior synonym of L. gallus, but differs in meristic and morphological characters and is therefore considered a valid species (Munroe 2015).

This nominal species was described from a single specimen collected pelagically in the Gulf of Panama (Bruun 1937). Evseenko (1999) considered it to be a junior subjective synonym of Monolene maculipinna; however, Amaoka and Imamura (2000) consider it a valid species. Further work is needed to clarify the status of this nominal species.

The taxonomic status of this nominal species remains uncertain. Bogorodsky and Randall (2018) considered this species to be a junior synonym of Bothus pantherinus (Rüppell 1830) while Golani and Fricke (2018) and Fricke et al. (2019) consider it a valid species. Further research is needed to determine the status of this species.

There is controversy whether this species is a valid species or an ecomorph of E. encrasicolus (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2013).  Since the species was first described in 2004 based on its genetic and morphological distinctness from sympatric E. encrasicolus, new surveys have confirmed its validity. The new data include a nuclear DNA study by Bouchenak-Khelladi et al. (2008) which revealed a complex of three species in the northeastern Atlantic and Mediterranean region (namely, E. encrasicolus, E. albidus, and a third anchovy species from the Canary islands and Alboran Sea); a nuclear-DNA and morphometric study by Karahan et al. 2014) which reported E. albidus from southern Turkey and distinguished it from the pelagic species occurring there (E. cf encrasicolus).

There are clearly two ecomorphs, but the morphological and habitat differences correspond to clearcut genetic differences at nuclear loci (Borsa 2002; Borsa et al. 2004; Bouchenak-Khelladi et al. 2008; Karahan et al. 2014; Le Moan et al. 2016). However, it is currently considered a valid species in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2018). For the purposes of this assessment, Engraulis albidus is considered a valid species distributed in coastal waters of the northern Mediterranean Sea.

Symphurus trewavasae Chabanaud 1948 was described from specimens collected off Cape Frio, Brazil. In his revision of western Atlantic Symphurus, Ginsburg (1951) suggested that S. trewavasae was possibly not distinct from S. plagiusa (Linnaeus 1776). Subsequent authors (Menezes and Benvengú 1976, Munroe 1998) provided data warranting recognition of these as distinct species.
Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from Carcharhinus porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.

authority: Del Moral-Flores, Ramíz-Antonio, Angulo & Pérez-Ponce de León, 2015
taxonomicNotes: Morales-Flores et al. (2015) described Ginglymostoma unami as distinct from Ginglymostoma cirratum. Ginglymostoma unami is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and G. cirratum to the Atlantic.

The Shorttail Yellownose Skate (Dipturus brevicaudatus) was split out from the former species concept of Zearaja chilensis (Gabbanelli et al. 2018). Concha et al. (2019) re-described Zearaja chilensis as Dipturus chilensis and subsumed the genus Zearaja Whitley 1939 as a junior synonym of Dipturus Rafinesque 1810.

Mystus gulio was described from the higher parts of the Gangetic estuary by Hamilton (1822). Although it is often regarded as a species widely distributed throughout South and Southeast Asia, there is some evidence to indicate that the populations from Southeast Asia constitute one or more species that are distinct from populations in the Indian subcontinent (H.H. Ng pers. comm.). A taxonomic reappraisal of this species based on material from throughout its entire distribution is badly needed.

Two species are recognized in the genus Sotalia: S. guianensis, the Guiana Dolphin, and S. fluviatilis, the Tucuxi. They are very similar in appearance and the genus was long considered monotypic. Two issues concerning the taxonomy of the dolphins in particular parts of the range of the genus deserve mention.

First, there is some uncertainty about the taxonomic status and range of Guiana Dolphins in the Orinoco River. There are frequent records of Sotalia at Ciudad Bolívar, some 300 km upstream from the river mouth. Such records are suspected to correspond to S. guianensis (da Silva and Best 1996, Meade and Koehnken 1991, Flores and da Silva 2009, da Silva et al. 2010). It is generally assumed that Sotalia dolphins cannot traverse the rapids at the Casiquiare Channel, which connects the Orinoco and Amazon basins (da Silva and Best 1996). This barrier has existed since the uplift of the Mérida Cordillera (10 million years ago; Lundberg et al. 1998), which predates the divergence of the two species of Sotalia (Cunha et al. 2005, Caballero et al. 2007, 2008). Thus, Sotalia in the Middle Orinoco are likely to be an isolated population of Guiana Dolphins (da Silva et al. 2010, Cunha et al. 2010). Seven animals from the Orinoco all possessed the same mitochondrial DNA sequences and had an estimated divergence from S. guianensis of 640,000 years ago (Caballero et al. 2017). Caballero et al. (2017) suggested that the Orinoco River animals belong to an independent population unit isolated from other coastal populations and worthy of separate conservation and management efforts.

The second issue relates to the taxonomic status of Sotalia dolphins from the southern freshwater portion of Maracaibo Lake. Those individuals are morphologically different from the marine Sotalia that inhabit the northern portion of the lake, adjacent to the Gulf of Venezuela. Dolphins from southern Maracaibo are smaller than marine Sotalia and about the same size as S. fluviatilis (Casinos et al. 1981, da Silva and Best 1996, León 2005). However, there is no connection between Maracaibo Lake and the known present-day range of riverine Sotalia, and the lake has been isolated from the Amazon basin for the last 8-10 million years (Hoorn et al. 1995, Días de Gamero 1996 cited in Cunha et al. 2010). The morphological distinctiveness of the southern Maracaibo Lake Sotalia population could be a result of phenotypic plasticity, unlike the difference between S. guianensis and S. fluviatilis. However, it may also indicate a lack of gene flow with the marine Sotalia from the mouth of the lake and the Gulf of Venezuela. Indeed, Caballero et al. (2006) observed some exclusive haplotypes in samples from the lake, but they did not consider this to signify a species-level difference. All haplotypes in Maracaibo Lake were S. guianensis (Caballero et al. 2017) with one of those being most closely related to the single haplotype found in the Orinoco River. Both of the populations here—in Maracaibo Lake and the Orinoco River—would meet the IUCN definition of a subpopulation.

Although it was only recently described (Wada et al. 2003), the separate species identity of Omura’s Whale, Balaenoptera omurai, is now well established phylogenetically (Sasaki et al. 2006). It was formerly regarded as a pygmy form of Bryde’s Whale (B. brydei/edeni), but it is not closely related to that group, lying outside the clade formed by the Sei Whale (B. borealis) and two forms of Bryde's Whales). The morphology of Omura’s Whale is quite distinct from those of Bryde’s Whales and other known baleen whales, but its colouration resembles that of the Fin Whale (B. physalus) while lacking lateral rostral ridges (Wada et al. 2003).

To date (December 2017), the only genetically confirmed observations of living Omura’s Whales are of 18 biopsied individuals in an apparently resident population off northwestern Madagascar (Cerchio et al. 2015). Specimens collected in 1976 in the Solomon Sea (Ohsumi 1978) and in 1978 in the eastern Indian Ocean (Ohsumi 1980) were originally taken under a scientific permit for Bryde’s Whales and were subsequently genetically identified as Omura’s Whales (Wada et al. 2003). LeDuc and Dizon (2002) genetically analysed specimens of small “Bryde’s Whales” from the Bohol Sea, Philippines, and found that they segregated phylogenetically outside the Sei/Bryde’s Whale clade and basal to B. edeni/B. borealis. From a comparison of the published phylogenies, Sasaki et al. (2006) concluded that these specimens corresponded to Omura’s Whale. Yamada et al. (2008) identified 24 skulls from a whaling operation in the Philippines as Omura’s Whales.

Based on recent genetics studies, the taxonomic status of this species in the Black and Marmara seas is somewhat uncertain. According to Turan et al. (2019), Scophthalmus rhombus is a distinct species in the region, but Firidin et al. (2020) concluded it is not distinct from S. maximus in the region. For purposes of this assessment, and based on past literature (e.g., Giragosov et al. 2012), S. rhombus, though rare, is considered to represent a distinct species in the Black and Marmara seas.

The taxonomic history of this species is complicated in the Black Sea region (Parin et al. 2014). Scophthalmus maeoticus has been considered a junior synonym of S. maximus with uncertainty by some workers (Chanet 2003, Suzuki et al. 2004, Nielsen et al. 2004, Bailly and Chanet 2010). Scophthalmus maeoticus has also been considered as a subspecies of S. maximus by some (Parin et al. 2014), but both cytogenetic and population genetic data suggest that these two nominal species are part of the same species (Bouza et al. 1995, do Prado et al. 2018). 

Currently, the subpopulation in the Black Sea is very likely isolated from other residual Mediterranean subpopulations due to the high temperature of the Mediterranean waters. A notable genetic differentiation has been reported in the subpopulation inhabiting the Black Sea, but this differentiation is similar to that of other residual subpopulations in the Mediterranean Sea (do Prado et al. 2018). This has prompted some authors (Turan et al. 2019) to claim that S. maeoticus and S. maximus are different species. A study by Firidin et al. (2020) that used mitochondrial DNA concluded that only S. maximus occurs in the Black Sea. Based on evidence provided in Firidin et al. (2020), it is concluded that S. maeoticus is a junior subjective synonym of S. maximus even if sampling conditions differed from those reported in Turan et al. (2019) (B. Chanet and T. Munroe pers. comm. 2020). 

This species is still frequently referred to in the literature as Psetta maxima, but the proper generic placement and nomenclature is Scophthalmus maximus (Bouza et al. 1995, Bailly and Chanet 2010). Different scientific names are used for this species in the coastal countries of the Black Sea. For example, in Russia, the name S. maeoticus is used, while in the Ukraine, both S. maximus and Psetta maeoticus are used. The region-level stock assessment conducted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) primarily refers to this nominal species as S. maximus (V. Shlyakhov pers. comm. 2020).
This species was reviewed by Larson (2001). It was often previously referred to as Mugilogobius fontinalis (Jordan and Seale 1906).
In 2009, Craig et al. confirmed that the Pacific “subpopulations” of Epinephelus itajara as a distinct species: E. quinquefasciatus (Craig et al. 2009).

Menon (1977) considered Cynoglossus semilaevis Günther 1873 as the senior synonym of C. rhomaleus (Jordan and Starks 1906) and C. roulei Wu 1932. Although Li and Wang (1995) considered C. roulei to be a valid species, it is treated here as a junior synonym of C. semilaevis.

authority: C. Chen, Y.-D. Zhou, C.-S. Wang & Copley, 2017
C. Chen, Y.-D. Zhou, C.-S. Wang & Copley, 2017

taxonomicNotes: No subspecies of False Killer Whale (Pseudorca crassidens) are currently recognized. However, there is evidence of geographic variability in skull morphology and life history (Kitchener et al. 1990, Ferreira et al. 2014). Based on genetics there is substantial population structure, both between and within-ocean basins, and even within a single archipelago (Martien et al. 2014). This species has been intensively studied only in Hawaii (Baird 2016) and more recently in New Zealand (Zaeschmar 2014). In Hawaii, three subpopulations have been identified based on a combination of genetic studies (Martien et al. 2014), satellite tagging (Baird et al. 2010, 2012, 2014, Bradford et al. 2014a), and analyses of photo-identification data (Baird et al. 2008, Baird 2016). These include two partially overlapping insular populations, one around the main Hawaiian Islands, and one in the northwestern Hawaiian Islands, as well as a partially overlapping pelagic population that ranges throughout and beyond the U.S. Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) around the Hawaiian Archipelago. In New Zealand, based on high resighting rates of photo-identified individuals and a relatively small number of individuals documented, it is likely that this represents a distinct subpopulation (Zaeschmar 2014). While the number of subpopulations world-wide is unknown, this is due primarily to incomplete sampling in most of the range. Based on the evidence from Hawaii, subpopulation structure likely exists throughout their range.

authority: Johnson, Warén, Tunnicliffe, Van Dover, Wheat, Schultz & Vrijenhoek, 2014
Johnson, Warén, Tunnicliffe, Van Dover, Wheat, Schultz & Vrijenhoek, 2014
Johnson, Warén, Tunnicliffe, Van Dover, Wheat, Schultz & Vrijenhoek, 2014
Johnson, Warén, Tunnicliffe, Van Dover, Wheat, Schultz & Vrijenhoek, 2014

taxonomicNotes: The taxonomic status of the species has only recently been clarified. Previously, it was considered conspecific with North American Green Sturgeon (A. medirostris) (Shmigirilov et al. 2007).

In the past, Citharoides macrolepidotus has been considered by some authors to be a junior synonym of Paracitharus macrolepis (e.g., Norman 1934). 

Hubbs (1915) described Citharoides macrolepidotus. Earlier, Gilchrist (1904) had described a species macrolepis that he placed in the bothid genus Arnoglossus. Regan (1920) determined that A. macrolepis was not a member of this bothid genus, so he described a new genus, Paracitharus, for this species.

Norman (1934) considered Paracitharus as a junior synonym of Citharoides and also synonymized P. macrolepis with C. macrolepidotus. He considered there to be only a single genus and species with the name Citharoides macrolepis (Gilchrist 1904). Hubbs (1945) recognized both species and genera as valid based on differences in the canal shape on their posterior lateral line scales. Hoshino (2001), based on this character and other morphological data, confirmed these observations and agreed that both species and genera were distinct from each other. 

Following the morphological data of Hubbs (1945) and Hoshino (2001), Paracitharus is herein recognized as a valid genus, distinct from Citharoides, and C. macrolepidotus is recognized as a valid species, distinct from P. macrolepis.

This species has long been considered to be a synonym of Cynoglossus kopsii (Bleeker 1851) by some authors (e.g., Norman 1928, Menon 1977, Shen et al. 1993, Shen and Wu 2011). Wang et al. (2016) and Lee (2019) considered Cynoglossus brachycephalus to be a valid species. Currently, it is considered valid in the Catalog of Fishes (Fricke et al. 2020); however, further work is needed to clarify the status of this nominal species.

Menon (1977) considered this species to be a junior synonym of Cynoglossus dollfusi; however, this hypothesis is not supported by the data. Despite the two species being currently considered distinct, more specimens are needed for a better understanding of the taxon (Munroe 2017). Furthermore, Gruvel and Chabanaud (1937) reported C. lingua from the Red Sea based on the specimen that Chabanaud (1949) later designated as the holotype of C. cleopatridis. These two species are currently considered to be valid species (Munroe 2017).

This species was originally described by Chabanaud (1931) as Paraplagusia dollfusi based on a single specimen. Shortly after, Gruvel and Chabanaud (1937) placed P. dollfusi in the genus Cynoglossus as Cynoglossus (Trulla) dollfusi (Munroe and Kong 2016). However, when Gruvel and Chabanaud (1937) transferred this species to Cynoglossus, the designation was not explicit, leading several subsequent authors to believe that Gruvel and Chabanaud (1937) had described a new species (see Munroe and Kong 2016, Munroe 2017 for history). Uncertainty was further aggravated by the apparent loss of the only two known specimens. Extensive analysis of the taxonomic history of this species, as well as the location of the two long lost known specimens, has confirmed that Paraplagusia dollfusi and Cynoglossus (Trulla) dollfusi referred to the same species, now valid as Cynoglossus dollfusi (Munroe 2017). Furthermore, C. dollfusi had been proposed to be a senior synonym of C. cleopatridis (Menon 1977). The two specimens of C. dollfusi were misidentified as C. sealarki by Chabanaud (1947, 1954), and thus C. dollfusi was treated as a junior subjective synonym of C. sealarki. Recently, Munroe (2017) determined that these two misidentified specimens were actually the holotype and the second known specimen of C. dollfusi. Cynoglossus dollfusi is a valid species distinct from C. sealarki and C. cleopatridis (Munroe and Kong 2016, Munroe 2017).

This species was long considered to have two forms, one was characterized by having two lateral lines and the other by having three lateral lines. Yokogawa et al. (2008b) examined isozymes and demonstrated these forms are genetically distinct at the specific level. The species with two lateral lines was identified as Cynoglossus interruptus, while the form with three lateral lines was described as the new species, Cynoglossus ochiaii (Yokogawa et al. 2008b).

Menon (1977) considered Cynoglossus lighti Norman 1925, C. tenuis (Oshima 1927) and C. tshusanensis Chabanaud 1951 as junior subjective synonyms of Cynglossus joyneri. Cynoglossus tenuis is known only from the holotype, collected in Taiwan, and this specimen has subsequently been lost. Cynoglossus tshusanensis was described on the basis of three specimens collected off China. It has been regarded as a junior subjective synonym of C. joyneri by most authors that have dealt with this nominal species. Cynoglossus lighti has been considered a valid species by several authors working with this nominal species, but the prevailing opinion is that this is a junior subjective synonym of C. joyneri (see Fricke et al. 2020 for relevant literature).

There has been confusion regarding the validity of this nominal species. Menon (1977) considered it to be a junior subjective synonym of Cynoglossus capensis, though he noted several characters to distinguish the nominal species. Barnard (1925) also noted differences in characters of specimens that he identified as Trulla microphthalmus compared to those of C. capensis, however, he did not consider these differences to be significant enough to recognize two species. Further study based on additional material is needed to resolve this taxonomic question (T. Munroe unpublished data). Munroe (unpublished data) considers the morphological differences sufficient to recognize both as valid species.

Cynoglossus interruptus was long considered to have two forms, one was characterized by having two lateral lines and the other by having three lateral lines. Recently, isozymic analysis demonstrated these forms are genetically distinct at the specific level. The species with two lateral lines was identified as Cynoglossus interruptus, while the form with three lateral lines was described as the new species, Cynoglossus ochiaii (Yokogawa et al. 2008). Thus, data from prior to the description of C. ochiaii, data for the two species were intermingled.

This nominal species was originally described based on a single specimen (36.5 cm total length) as Plagusia oligolepis Bleeker 1855 from Java, Indonesia. Norman (1928) considered Cynoglossus oligolepis as a junior synonym of C. macrolepidotus (Bleeker). Menon (1977) considered both C. macrolepidotus and C. oligolepis as junior synonyms of C. arel. Li and Wang (1995) considered both C. oligolepis and C. arel as valid species, and it was included in the comparative material for the description of C. crepida (Fricke et al. 2017). 

Given the confusion, the taxonomic status of this nominal species remains uncertain. More work is needed to establish the validity of this nominal species. Erring on the side that this species is valid, we provide an assessment using information only on this species and not that of proposed senior synonyms.

This nominal species was described on the basis of two specimens, which are apparently lost. Features overlap those of two other species of Cynoglossus from the Red Sea, so the taxonomic status of C. pottii is uncertain (Bogorodsky and Randall 2019, T. Munroe pers. comm. 2019).
This species was previously considered a junior synonym of Cynoglossus brachycephalus (Norman 1928) and C. kopsii (Menon 1977) but was recently treated as valid (Wang et al. 2016).

Regan (1905) described Cynoglossus purpureomaculatus on the basis of a single specimen from the Inland Sea of Japan. Matsubara (1955) and Ochiai (1963) consider C. purpureomaculatus Regan a junior synonym of C. trigrammus. Menon (1977) considered both C. purpureomaculatus and C. trigrammus as junior synonyms of C. abbreviatus. Lindberg and Fedorov (1993) also consider C. purpureomaculatus a junior synonym of C. abbreviatus. 

However, later authors, e.g., Li and Wang (1995) and Kottelat (2001, 2013), consider C. purpureomaculatus to be a valid species. These authors (Li and Wang 1995; Kottelat 2001, 2013) also placed Cynoglossus pellegrini Wu 1932 in the synonymy of C. purpureomaculatus. Chevey and Lemasson (1937) reported Cynoglossus pellegrini from the Gulf of Tonkin.  
Available evidence (Li and Wang 1995; Kottelat 2001, 2013) as well as that contained in Chevey and Lemasson (1937; according to Kottelat 2001), supports recognition of C. purpureomaculatus as a valid species.

Chabanaud (1947) misidentified two specimens of Cynoglossus dollfusi as C. sealarki. Recently, Munroe (2017) determined that these two misidentified specimens were actually the holotype and the second known specimen of C. dollfusi.

Weber (1913) described Cynoglossus sibogae based on two specimens collected off Indonesia. Norman (1928) questioned whether C. sibogae was a junior synonym of C. brachycephalus Bleeker 1875. Menon (1977) regarded both C. sibogae and C. brachycephalus as synonyms of C. kopsii (Bleeker 1851). Later authors (e.g., Li and Wang 1995, Mohsin and Ambak 1996, Munroe 2000, Wang et al. 2016) consider C. sibogae to be a valid species distinct from C. kopsii and C. brachycephalus. Although further research is required to clarify the taxonomic status of these nominal species, for the purposes of this work, C. sibogae is regarded as a valid species.

Plagusia trulla (now C. trulla), described by Cantor (1849), has a complicated nomenclatural history. At least two other species, Cynoglossus borneensis Bleeker 1858 and C. sinicus Wu 1932, have been entangled in the synonymy of P. trulla (Menon 1977). In his global revision of the genus Cynoglossus, Menon (1977) incorrectly regarded C. borneensis as the senior synonym of Plagusia trulla. However, since C. trulla was described earlier than C. borneensis, this former species has precedence and C. trulla is the appropriate name for this taxon.  

Cynoglossus sinicus Wu 1932 is currently (Kottelat 2013) regarded as a junior synonym of C. trulla. According to Kottelat (2013), Li and Wang (1995) treated C. sinicus as specifically distinct (and valid) from C. borneensis (or from a species locally misidentified as C. borneensis). Given the taxonomic uncertainty regarding the specimens Li and Wang (1995) identified as C. borneensis, more work is needed to determine what species they actually had under consideration.

For the purpose of this assessment, the account of Cynoglossus trulla also includes information reported for C. borneensis and C. sinicus.

Paraplagusia guttata (Macleay 1878) has had a complex nomenclatural history. It has been considered a junior subjective synonym of Paraplagusia bilineata (Bloch 1787) by many authors, including Menon (1980) in his revision of the genus Paraplagusia. Chapleau and Renaud (1993) in their treatment of species of Paraplagusia from Australian waters also considered this species as a synonym of P. bilineata (Bloch 1787), as did Johnson (1999, 2010) and Larson et al. (2013). In contrast, Li and Wang (1995), Randall and Lim (2000), and Hutchins (2004) considered P. guttata as a valid species.
 
Paraplagusia bilineata (Bloch 1787) has had an equally complex nomenclatural history, with many nominal species of Paraplagusia placed in its synonymy. Likely, several of these nominal species are valid, but the taxonomic work to resolve this problem has not been conducted. Preliminary observations (T.A. Munroe unpublished data) indicate that P. guttata should be recognized as a valid species and it is therefore treated as such herein.

McCulloch (1907) originally described Symphurus strictus var. australis based on a single specimen collected in relatively deep water off southeastern Australia. This taxon is now regarded as a valid species, Symphurus australis.

Symphurus bathyspilus Krabbenhoft and Munroe 2003 was described from specimens collected in the Philippines and Indonesia. Other specimens tentatively identified as this species collected in other Indo-West Pacific localities likely represent a complex of at least six nominal species (M.-Y. Lee pers. comm. 2021). Further research is needed to evaluate the taxonomic status of these specimens, to better understand the diversity within this potential species complex, and to provide more accurate information on the distribution of S. bathyspilus (sensu Krabbenhoft and Munroe 2003).
This species was described on the basis of a single specimen, which has since been lost. As such, its taxonomic status remains questionable (Lee et al. 2013).

Symphurus gilesii was described from a single specimen collected in the Bay of Bengal (Alcock 1889). Later, Weber (1913), Weber and de Beaufort (1929), and Norman (1928, 1939) listed this species as occurring in the Kei Islands, Indonesia. Chabanaud (1957) recognized that the specimen from the Kei Islands represented an undescribed species, which he formally described as S. fallax. Subsequently, the type specimen of S. fallax has been lost (Desoutter et al. 2001) and some authors (e.g. Lee et al. 2013) have questioned the validity of S. fallax. For the purposes of this assessment, we consider the specimen from the Kei Islands to represent a species different from S. gilesii (Alcock 1889).

This species was previously considered a junior synonym of Symphurus microrhynchus (Munroe and Marsh 1997), but is now recognized as a valid species on the basis of morphological and molecular characteristics (Lee et al. 2016).

Originally described on the basis of a single specimen (Hubbs 1915), Symphurus hondoensis was subsequently considered by Matsubara (1955) to be a junior synonym of Symphurus strictus Gilbert 1905. Upon discovery of a second specimen of S. hondoensis, this species was redescribed and recognized as valid by Munroe and Amaoka (1998).

Norman (1939) recorded a specimen caught at JM Station 153 as Symphurus marmoratus. This damaged specimen was later described as a new species, Symphurus maldivensis, by Chabanaud (1955). No additional specimens have been reported, but S. maldivensis is currently regarded as valid (Munroe 1992, 2006, Adam et al. 1998). Additional specimens are needed to more properly assess the taxonomic status of this nominal species.

Bleeker (1879) described Aphoristia orientalis on the basis of a unique holotype that was subsequently lost (Lee et al. 2013). Limited diagnostic characters and loss of the holotype led to confusion regarding the identity of this and other, similar tonguefishes in the Indo-Pacific (Lee et al. 2013). Lee et al. (2013) examined morphological and molecular characters of a large series of specimens collected in Taiwanese and Japanese waters, redefined Symphurus orientalis (Bleeker 1879), and redescribed the species based on these specimens. They also designated a neotype for S. orientalis.

Weber (1913) described the nominal species, Aphoristia (= Symphurus) elongata. Unfortunately, Weber (1913) did not realize that elongata had already been used by Günther (1868) in naming another nominal species, Aphoristia (= Symphurus) ornata elongata. This latter name has priority. Therefore, Weber and de Beaufort (1929) proposed S. regani as the replacement name for the nominal species Aphoristia elongata Weber 1913.

Aphoristia (= Symphurus) woodmasoni Alcock 1889 was described on the basis of a single specimen collected off the Andaman Islands, India. Three additional specimens were later collected from the Bay of Bengal (Alcock 1892). Identifications of these specimens have been verified. Earlier records (Regan 1908, Norman 1928) that report this species from the Saya de Malha Bank are incorrect. These specimens were misidentified and later described by Chabanaud (1955c) as S. sayademalhensis. Additionally, other studies that have reported S. woodmasoni from Oman, Laccadive Islands, Indonesia, and the Philippines (e.g., Norman 1928, 1939; Chabanaud 1955a,b; Munroe 1992) also may not be based on specimens of this species. According to Chabanaud (1954, 1955c) and Krabbenhoft and Munroe (2003), these records may represent other tonguefish species. Likewise, the report of S. woodmasoni from the Philippines by Cabanban et al. (2010), which is based on the same series of specimens reported in Chabanaud (1955a,b), also may be in doubt. Resolution of taxonomic questions regarding the other specimens from beyond the Bay and Bengal and Andaman Sea, which were previously identified as S. woodmasoni, is necessary to establish the actual distribution of S. woodmasoni.
This species was reviewed by Allen and Burgess (1990).

According to Randall and Johnson (2007), specimens from Australia previously identified as Pardachirus poropterus are actually specimens of P. rautheri. Randall and Johnson (2007) also indicate that research is needed to clarify possible regional variations observed among specimens of P. poropterus, as these variations may reflect differences among members of a species complex, rather than population variation within a single species.
This species is presently under revision (Larson and Hammer in prep.).
This species was recently reviewed by Larson (2010); it has often been identified as Redigobius roemeri.
Revisonary work is required for the genus Stenogobius. This species is very similar to S. hoesei and S. watsoni.
