Revisonary work is required for the genus Stenogobius. This species name may be a senior synonym to S. blokzeyli (Larson in prep.).
Revisonary work is required for the genus Stenogobius.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius. This species is similar to four others in New Guinea and the Pacific.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius. This species may be synonymous with two other species from the same region.
Galatea congica is often confused with Galatea paradoxa. A revision of the genus needs to establish if both species are distinctive or not.

Galatea concamerata (Duval, 1840) is a synonym according to Poutiers (2016). Additional species are now considered conspecific with this species since the assessment in 2011 (kochii and concamerata), hence this is a new species concept.

This brackish water species was described by Philippi in 1851 from an unknown locality. Pilsbry and Bequaert (1927) recorded G. tenuicula langi from the mouth of the Congo river. 

The former IUCN Red List rationale that the species still was recorded around 1970 is incorrect. It is just listed by Richard and Old (1969) as being part of the Smithsonian collection, containing Pilsbry and Bequaert's material used in their 1927 publication. .

The taxonomy of the genus Galatea (Donacidae) is unresolved and such brackish water donacids are usually wide spread or very common where they occur, but there are no mentions anymore of this species after the early 20th Century.

The taxonomy of the genus Galatea needs revision, as already noticed by Daget (1998). Considering that brackish bivalves can be highly polymorphic, the number of species described is probably too high. In many articles the name Egeria de Roissy, 1805 is still used. Galatea seems to be endemic to the African Atlantic coast and Galatea aegypytaca (Philippi 1851), recorded from the Nile estuarium by Chemnitz, 1795, does not exist and is based on an erroneous location.
Considered by Daget (1998) and by Graf and Cummings (2019) as a distinct species and not a form of Coelatura aegyptiaca.

According to results from genetics studies, Orlova et al. (2019) proposed that the Pacific subpopulation be considered a subspecies with name Reinhardtius hippoglossoides matsuurae (Jordan and Snyder, 1901) or possibly as a separate species with the available name, Reinhardtius matsuurae (Jordan and Snyder, 1901). Further taxonomic study is needed to determine if more than one species should be recognized. Until such work is completed, only one species is recognized for the purposes of the Red List assessment.
The genus Galatea is in need of revision.
The genus is in need of revision.

Tachypleus tridentatus and T. gigas are sometimes the subject of misidentification. In China, three horseshoe crab nature reserves were established in Guangdong Province in 2004 for the protection of T. gigas (Kwan et al. 2016), even though T. gigas has not been recorded in these areas (Liao and Li 2001, Liao et al. 2001a).

In Hong Kong, the occurrence of T. gigas, T. tridentatus and C. rotundicauda was reported (Mikkelsen 1988), but recent population studies did not reveal any presence of T. gigas in Hong Kong waters (Li 2008, Shin et al. 2009, Morton and Lee 2010) and a recent literature review suggests previous reports of the presence of T. gigas in Hong Kong was a case of mistaken identity, based on the wrong labelling of photographs in a popular natural history book at the time (Laurie 2011, unpublished).

On 23 May 2012, five horseshoe crabs were seized at Sam Ratulangi International Airport, Manado, North Sulawesi, Indonesia under PP No. 7/1999 (Indonesia Government Regulation No. 7/1999). Although described as T. gigas, photographs indicate the seized animals were T. tridentatus (BKIPM 2012).
Eviota fallax closely resembles E. natalis (Greenfield and Allen 2012).
This species is part of the Eviota nigriventris complex (Greenfield and Tornabene 2014), and is closely related to E. raja (Allen et al. 2013).
This species is closely related to Eviota sebreei (Tornabene et al. 2016).
This species is part of the Eviota nigriventris complex (Greenfield 2017) and is closely related to E. pamae and E. bifasciata (Allen 2001, Allen et al. 2013).

This species is commonly confused with Oligolepis stomias and the two species may occur together (Larson in prep.). In southern Africa, records of this species is confused with those of Oxyurichthys keiensis. There appears to be at least one undescribed species which may be confused with this species. The genus is in need of revision.

The species name is often misspelled as 'acutipinnis'.
The taxonomy of this species has recently been reviewed by Larson (2010).

The taxonomy of the minute Assimineidae is completely outdated and in need of revision. Assimineids seem to be easily spread by birds and their distribution is erratic and instable. The species Assiminea hessei may possibly not belong in the genus Assiminea (Brown 1994). It is also possible that the Nigerian species may be a different taxon to the originally described Congo species, which is only known from shells. Since shells are near useless for identification, the type material can not be identified anymore.

Two species of the Atlantic brackish water genus Cyrenoida were described from the West Atlantic coast: C. dupontia and C. rhodopyga. The latter is presently considered as a form of C. dupontia (Huber, 2010).

The name Hydrobia lineata is pre-occupied by a fossil species Hydrobia lineata Jekelius, 1944 from Soceni (Romania). The name, Hydrobia lineata, for the taxon described by Binder, 1957 from Côte d'Ivoire, is a junior primary homonym and therefore invalid hence this species needs to be renamed. Until such time as a new combination is published it is assumed here that the references in the literature all apply to the same Hydrobia species and it is left here as Hydrobia lineata [name invalid].
The genus is presently placed in the family Tateidae and not in the Hydrobiidae.
The representatives of the genus Pachymelania are presently ranged in the family Hemisinidae
The representatives of the genus Pachymelania are presently ranged in the family Hemisinidae.
The representatives of the genus Pachymelania are presently ranged in the family Hemisinidae

This species is easily confused with Mulloidichthys vanicolensis, which is a congener and shoals together with M. ayliffe. The Pacific sister species is M. mimicus. Both mimic the Indo-Pacific snapper Lutjanus kasmira (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
The Clown Wedgefish is a recently described small species of wedgefish (Last et al. 2016). It is a distinct species which is not likely to be confused with other Rhynchobatus species.

Praschag et al. (2007, 2008) demonstrated that the widespread species Batagur baska comprised at least two genetically distinct species, and separated out B. affinis for the southern species occupying southern Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, and Sumatra in Indonesia, retaining the name B. baska for the more northern species from India, Bangladesh, and Myanmar. Praschag et al. (2009) further assessed the genetics and taxonomic status of a Cambodian relict subpopulation and eastern Peninsular Malaysian subpopulations and described them as the new subspecies B. affinis edwardmolli, with B. a. affinis occurring in western Peninsular Malaysia and Sumatra. Moll et al. (2015) reviewed the range-wide conservation biology and conservation status of the species.

Puffinus newelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into P. newelli and P. myrtae (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018). Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) found molecular evidence that Newell’s Shearwater Puffinus newelli and Townsend’s Shearwater P. auricularis are conspecific. Although they mention the morphological analysis in del Hoyo and Collar (2014: p386) which gave a Tobias score of 7 to newelli, these authors did not consider the characters in question: larger size (an effect size of 3.29 on tail length yielded a score of 2; new data in Shirihai et al. [2017] yields an effect size of 2.41, thus again a score of 2); cleaner-cut head pattern (score 1); bolder, squarer neck mark (score 2); all-white undertail-coverts (score 2); plus darker upperparts (scored 1 but uncounted).

(These characters and scores are revised below.)

Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) also mentioned that ‘Howell (2012) proposed a separate treatment based on their differences in morphology, breeding chronology (Ainley et al. 1997; Bourne et al. 1988), and breeding ecology (Spear et al. 1995)’ [NB these citations in quotation marks are not in the reference list below]. Thus it appears that there are behavioural and ecological differences between the taxa in addition to the morphological ones. Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) cited the case of Charadrius dealbatus as one in which morphological characters are strong but genetic ones non-existent, but they did not mention that del Hoyo and Collar (2014) accepted the morphological characters despite the genetic evidence. In the present case it seems appropriate to continue to consider that two species are involved, pending confirmation of the authors’ molecular work, clarification of the accuracy of the scoring used to maintain the split of newelli in del Hoyo and Collar (2014), and evidence of the behavioural and ecological differences between the taxa.

However, Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) also found that P. n. myrtae, ‘Rapa Shearwater’, is genetically more distinct from newelli than newelli is from auricularis. On this basis they propose that myrtae be treated as a full species. Such an arrangement is supported by Shirihai et al. (2017), who noted:

Rapa Shearwater is much smaller (in all biometric characters) than the other two taxa…, and is furthermore highly distinctive in having a unique combination of white undertail-coverts (vs. dark in both newelli and auricularis) and whitish inner webs to the remiges, as well as a white face.

There is a contradiction here with del Hoyo and Collar (2014), where the undertail-coverts of newelli, compared to auricularis, are given as ‘white vs white-edged grey’. Further consideration of this point, by examining images online and Plate 16.1 in Howell (2012: 147), indicate that auricularis has marginally more extensive black undertail-coverts than newelli. However, the information contained in Howell (2012) and the references he cited, plus that conveyed in Howell’s Plate 16.1, lead to somewhat differently scored and parsed characters for newelli vs auricularis:  larger size (effect size 2.41 [see above]: 2);  cleaner-cut and blacker head- and neck-sides (2);  more white on undertail-coverts (1); darker upperparts (1); somewhat different feeding ecology, using less upwelled, more stratified waters with more turbulent meteorological features (Spear et al. 1995; allow 1); breeding chronology (Ainley et al. 1997; no score allowed).

By this means newelli continues to achieve species rank under the Tobias criteria. We therefore retain P. newelli as a separate species from P. auricularis until independent genetic analysis supports Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) and/or until a new full assessment of morphological characters, and of the behavioural/ecological evidence, can be undertaken.

The taxonomic concept for Bigeye Sixgill Shark (Hexanchus nakamurai) has been revised and the Atlantic Sixgill Shark (Hexanchus vitulus) has now been resurrected to a separate species that occurs in the Western Central Atlantic Ocean (Daly-Engel et al. 2019).

Other Anguilla species have occasionally been stocked in Europe, but none have established a self-sustaining population. Pure A. rostrata (American Eel) have been recorded but are relatively rare (Boëtius 1976). Stocking attempts are likely to have caused this (Frankowski et al. 2008, Marohn et al. 2014). DNA analysis is the best tool to distinguish between the European Eel and other species (e.g. Frankowski et al. 2008), but A. rostrata have fewer vertebrae than A. anguilla (102–112, usually 106–108, vs. 111–119, usually 114–116). Hybrids have been found as larvae in the Sargasso Sea (Als et al. 2011, Pujolar et al. 2014a) and as yellow eels in Iceland where pure A. rostrata and A. anguilla also exist (Albert et al. 2006).

authority: Grace, Doosey, Denton, Naylor, Bart & Maisey, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This species is known only from the holotype collected in 2010. It is distinct from Mollisquama parini Dolganov, 1984, the only other member of the genus (Grace et al. 2015, Grace et al. 2019).
Gelochelidon nilotica and G. macrotarsa (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Sterna and lumped as S. nilotica following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Spatula clypeata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.
Zapornia pusilla (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Porzana.
Ardenna grisea (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus as P. griseus.
Thalasseus sandvicensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.

Larus michahellis and L. armenicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. michahellis following a review by the BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group. Prior to that, L. armenicus had been split and L. cachinnans (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) had been lumped with L. michahellis as L. cachinnans following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

L. michahellis and L. armenicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. michahellis following a review by the BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group. Prior to that, L. armenicus had been split and L. cachinnans (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) had been lumped with L. michahellis as L. cachinnans following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Onychoprion anaethetus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Calidris pygmaea (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Eurynorhynchus as E. pygmeus.

There is some debate over the taxonomic status of separate sub-populations of A. australis in Australia and New Zealand. Based on geographic distribution, geographic differences in vertebral counts and position of dorsal fin insertions, Schmidt (1928) inferred two sub-species. He therefore divided A. australis into A. australis occidentalis in mainland Australia, Tasmania, and Lord Howe Island, and A. australis orientalis distributed in New Zealand. Griffin (1936) renamed the sub-species A. australis australis in Australia and A. australis schmidtii in New Zealand. Ege (1939) retained these names in his revision of the genus Anguilla. Since then, a variety of papers examining the control region of mtDNA (Dijkstra and Jellyman 1999) and the 16S ribosomal RNA domain of mtDNA (Aoyama et al. 2000) suggested a single species. Although, many papers published since indicate both significant morphological (Watanabe et al. 2006) and genetic (Leander et al. 2012, Shen and Tzeng 2007) differences between the two proposed sub-species. At the glass eel stage, they are found to show genetic homogeneity, and it is therefore suggested that the species should be managed cooperatively by Australia and New Zealand as if it were a single population (Jellyman 2007).


The two subpopulations are considered synonyms of A. australis here, though this observed intraspecific variation is noted for the purposes of regionally specific conservation planning for the two subpopulations in the Australia and New Zealand.
This species has been confused with S. hasta in the past (Amir et al. 2014).

Haematopus ostralegus and H. finschi were previously lumped as H. ostralegus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014), but have once more been recognised as species following a review of additional material allowing the scoring of the taxa against each other and H. longirostris, H. chathamensis, and H. unicolor (G. Ehmke in litt. 2015, Hayman et al. 1986, Marchant and Higgins 1993). This restores the taxonomic position of the two species prior to del Hoyo and Collar (2014).
The specific name was incorrectly spelt on earlier Red Lists as kempi.
Hydrobates tristrami (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma.

Pelecanoides georgicus has been split into South Georgia Diving-petrel P. georgicus and Whenua Hou Diving-petrel following the application of the Tobias et al. (2010) criteria by Fischer et al. (2018) to a new form of South Georgia Diving-petrel, upon which it emerges as a species on the basis of a score of 8 in comparison with the population of P. georgicus from the South Atlantic Ocean and a score of 9 in comparison with that from the South Indian Ocean. 

There is a technical problem with the authors’ scoring of the two biometric characters, because they could be said to co-vary with the greater size of NZ birds. However, their data indicate that the bill of NZ birds is actually slightly shorter than those of birds from other populations, so the depth could be interpreted as independent of body size and the other character used. The authors appear to have used standard errors rather than standard deviations in their calculations. However, converting SE to SD yields scores of 1 as they indicated. While the scores for plumage differences in the original description are possibly on the generous side, the taxon is clearly valid, but much more study is needed to demonstrate the strength and consistency of the diagnostic characters. With these reservations, its status as a species is nonetheless accepted here.

Pelecanoides georgicus has been split into South Georgia Diving-petrel P. georgicus and Whenua Hou Diving-petrel following the application of the Tobias et al. (2010) criteria by Fischer et al. (2018) to a new form of South Georgia Diving-petrel, upon which it emerges as a species on the basis of a score of 8 in comparison with the population of P. georgicus from the South Atlantic Ocean and a score of 9 in comparison with that from the South Indian Ocean. 

There is a technical problem with the authors’ scoring of the two biometric characters, because they could be said to co-vary with the greater size of NZ birds. However, their data indicate that the bill of NZ birds is actually slightly shorter than those of birds from other populations, so the depth could be interpreted as independent of body size and the other character used. The authors appear to have used standard errors rather than standard deviations in their calculations. However, converting SE to SD yields scores of 1 as they indicated. While the scores for plumage differences in the original description are possibly on the generous side, the taxon is clearly valid, but much more study is needed to demonstrate the strength and consistency of the diagnostic characters. With these reservations, its status as a species is nonetheless accepted here.

Haematopus ostralegus and H. finschi were previously lumped as H. ostralegus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014), but have once more been recognised as species following a review of additional material allowing the scoring of the taxa against each other and H. longirostris, H. chathamensis, and H. unicolor (G. Ehmke in litt. 2015, Hayman et al. 1986, Marchant and Higgins 1993). This restores the taxonomic position of the two species prior to del Hoyo and Collar (2014).

Himantopus himantopus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as H. himantopus, H. leucocephalus and H. mexicanus and following AOU (1998) and SACC (2006). Prior to that, H. melanurus had been split from H. mexicanus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Ardea alba (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Casmerodius as C. albus. Casmerodius albus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously retained as a cross-regional species contra Christidis and Boles (2008) who moved C. albus into the genus Ardea and split it into two cross-regional species A. alba and A. modesta (note gender agreement of specific name for alba).
Ardenna carneipes (del Hoyo et al. 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.
Sternula albifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Sternula saundersi was previously placed in the genus Sterna (del Hoyo et al. 2014).
Calidris falcinellus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Limicola.
Charadrius alexandrinus, C. dealbatus and C. nivosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. alexandrinus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Gallinula chloropus and G. galeata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. chloropus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hydroprogne caspia (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Egretta picata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Ardea.

Puffinus lherminieri (incorporating baroli), P. bannermani, P. persicus, P. subalaris and P. bailloni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. lherminieri and baroli was subsumed under P. assimilis, following Brooke (2004), before which P. bannermani and P. persicus where split following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group is aware that phylogenetic analyses have been published which have proposed generic rearrangements which may affect this species, but prefers to wait until work by other taxonomists reveals how these changes affect the entire groups involved.

Larus glaucoides and L. thayeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) have been lumped as L. glaucoides (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018). Chesser et al. (2017) made Thayer’s Gull Larus thayeri a subspecies of Iceland Gull L. glaucoides, with the race L. g. kumlieni retained ‘as a separate group’ although the proposal (http://checklist.aou.org/assets/proposals/PDF/2017-C.pdf) on which the decision on thayeri was based argued that kumlieni is the product of non-assortative mating between the taxa thayeri and glaucoides; see also Ayyash (2017). The close relationship of thayeri and glaucoides is shown without commentary in Figure 8B in Sonsthagen et al. (2016). We accept Larus thayeri as a subspecies of L. glaucoides but treat kumlieni as an apparent hybrid population having no taxonomic status.
Larus argentatus and L. smithsonianus (the latter including vegae and mongolicus) (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. argentatus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Microcarbo pygmaeus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Phalacrocorax.

Has hybridized with P. phoenicurus. Proposed subspecies aterrimus (Portugal, S & C Spain) merged with gibraltariensis. Subspecies phoenicuroides and rufiventris intergrade, with birds from W China (S Xinjiang) named as subspecies xerophilus probably intermediate between them; these taxa speculated to represent a separate species, but morphological differences not very strong and limited evidence suggests vocal homogeneity (Boesman 2016). Six subspecies recognized.
Sternula lorata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Geographical variation minor; this species said to provide “an unexpected example of lack of diversification in a songbird occurring in oceanic islands” (Illera et al. 2014). Subspecies orbitalis appears to vary clinally from N to S; Madeira birds the most distinctive, and formerly separated as subspecies bella, while those from Cape Verde Is are closest to nominate, and those from Canary Is intermediate (underparts very much like nominate, upperparts more deeply coloured). Two subspecies recognized.

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. penicillatus, P. pelagicus and P. urile moved into Urile (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).

Upeneus randalli was initially misidentified as U. margarethae, which was only known from a single record in the Arabian/Persian Gulf. It is clearly distinguished from other goatfish species in this region (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).

Remiz macronyx has been lumped with Eurasian Penduline-tit R. pendulinus, after detailed molecular analysis (Barani-Beiranvand et al. 2017) suggested that there is very little difference between the forms and that R. pendulinus/macronyx, R. coronatus and R. consobrinus form three independent evolutionary lineages.

Further support for the two superficial distinctive types actually belonging to a single species can be found in the taxonomic notes in the Checklist, which mention taxa (bostanjogli, loudoni and altaicus) now known to be hybrids between the two species, while R. m. ssaposhnikowi is so variable that it, too, is probably better considered a hybrid, and the race R. p. caspius is admitted as possibly better belonging with R. macronyx. Such taxonomic uncertainty suggests a boundary between the two species so porous that the only reasonable course is to treat them as one.

According to van der Heiden et al. (2009), two very similar species, Citharichthys fragilis Gilbert, 1890, and C. gordae Beebe and Tee-Van, 1938, were originally described from the Gulf of California. The original description of C. fragilis was limited and no illustration was provided. Mussot-Pérez and van der Heiden (1985) recognized C. gordae as a valid species and extended its geographic range based on additional specimens; however, Castro-Aguirre et al. (1992) did not agree with this decision and treated C. gordae as a junior synonym of C. fragilis. van der Heiden et al. (2009) conducted a detailed study wherein they demonstrated that both species are valid. This decision is followed herein.
This is a new species that resembles Citharichthys fragilis Gilbert which is distributed in the Gulf of California and adjacent waters (Hoshino and Amaoka 1999).

According to van der Heiden et al. (2009), two very similar species, Citharichthys fragilis Gilbert, 1890, and C. gordae Beebe and Tee-Van, 1938, were originally described from the Gulf of California. The original description of C. fragilis was limited and no illustration was provided. Mussot-Pérez and van der Heiden (1985) recognized C. gordae as a valid species and extended its geographic range based on additional specimens; however, Castro-Aguirre et al. (1992) did not agree with this decision and treated C. gordae as a junior synonym of C. fragilis. van der Heiden et al. (2009) conducted a detailed study wherein they demonstrated that both species are valid. This decision is followed herein.
It is easily confused with Syacium ovale (Murakami and Amaoka 1992).
This species is very similar to the congener Syacium ovale (Murakami and Amaoka 1992).
Hydrobates hornbyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma.
Hydrobates markhami (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma.

As a result of most recent revisions of Acipenser baerii, the species is now accepted as monotypic; all previously described subspecies (A. b. baerii, A. b. baicalensis, A. b. stenorrhynchus, and A. b. chatys) are not valid (Ruban 2005).
<span>The taxonomy of this species requires revision (Bogutskaya and Naseka 2013).
Appeared in the IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006 under the name Stizostedion marinum.

The Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy (Committee on Taxonomy 2016) provisionally lists the following subspecies: Balaenoptera musculus musculus (Linnaeus, 1758) - Northern Blue Whale (found in the North Atlantic and the North Pacific); B. m. intermedia (Burmeister, 1871) - Antarctic Blue Whale; B. m. indica (Blyth 1859) - Northern Indian Ocean Blue Whale; B. m. brevicauda (Ichihara, 1966) - Pygmy Blue Whale; and B. m. un-named subspecies - Chilean Blue Whale.

The nominate subspecies B. m. musculus refers at least to the North Atlantic Blue Whale which was the basis for the first description of the species by Linnaeus. Animals in the North Pacific are similar in size and morphology to North Atlantic Blue Whales and are also regarded as B. m. musculus, pending a genetic comparison of these populations. The Antarctic form B. m. intermedia is distinguished by its large body size and Antarctic distribution in summer. The Pygmy Blue Whale B. m. brevicauda has a number of morphological characteristics that distinguish it from B. m. intermedia and B. m. musculus. It occurs in the Indian Ocean, excluding the Antarctic, from Africa and Madagascar across to Indonesia and Australia, and in the southwestern Pacific, including Tasmania and New Zealand. Blue Whales in the northern Indian Ocean have been tentatively assigned the name B. m. indica, but a clear distinction between B. m. indica and B. m. brevicauda has not yet been established.

Blue Whales in the southeastern Pacific are intermediate in size between B. m. intermedia and B. m. brevicauda (Branch et al. 2007a) and are genetically differentiated from both groups (LeDuc et al. 2017). They are provisionally designated as an unnamed subspecies with the common name Chilean Blue Whales. Chilean Blue Whales are genetically most similar to Blue Whales in the northeast Pacific (LeDuc et al. 2017); investigations into the genetic and morphological distinction between these two groups are ongoing. The respective winter ranges of Blue Whales from the eastern South Pacific (Chilean Blue whales) and from the eastern North Pacific may overlap in the eastern equatorial Pacific but their breeding seasons are probably six months out of phase (LeDuc et al. 2017).

Recent genetic work indicates that the genus Stenella is paraphyletic and it is likely that the Delphininae will be restructured in the coming years (LeDuc et al. 1999, Perrin et al. 2013).

Four subspecies of Spinner Dolphins are currently recognized: S. l. longirostris (Gray’s Spinner Dolphin), S. l. orientalis (Eastern Spinner Dolphin), S. l. centroamericana (Central American Spinner Dolphin) and S. l. roseiventris (Dwarf Spinner Dolphin) (Perrin 1990, Perrin et al. 1999). There is a zone of hydridisation between Gray’s Spinner and the Eastern Spinner where an intermediate form called the White-bellied Spinner occurs (Andrews et al. 2013). Smaller individuals in Arabian waters (Red Sea and Arabian Gulf) (Van Waerebeek et al. 1999) and morphologically different animals in West Africa may represent as yet undescribed subspecies (Cadenat 1959, Jefferson et al. 1997). Several studies have demonstrated significant meta-population genetic structure, especially where relatively insular dolphin communities are strongly associated with island resting habitat such as in the Hawaiian Archipelago (Andrews et al. 2013) and in the South Pacific (Oremus et al. 2007).

All Bottlenose Dolphins around the world were previously recognized as Tursiops truncatus, but currently, the genus is considered to be composed of two species: T. truncatus (Common Bottlenose Dolphin) and T. aduncus (the smaller Indo-Pacific Bottlenose Dolphin) (Wang et al. 1999, 2000a,b). The Common Bottlenose Dolphin has a worldwide distribution in tropical and temperate latitudes but exhibits a strong ability to adapt to local conditions, a complex social structure and strong site fidelity which results in considerable habitat partitioning throughout its range. This, in turn, has created strong population differentiation accompanied, in some cases, by marked morphological differentiation. The taxonomy of Bottlenose Dolphins is confused due to this geographical variation, and it is very possible that additional species will be recognized in the future.

Three subspecies are currently recognized by the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (2017) and a recent re-assessment of Tursiops taxonomy worldwide conducted by the International Whaling Commission confirmed their validity (IWC 2018). These subspecies are the Black Sea Bottlenose Dolphin (T. t. ponticus Barabash-Nikiforov, 1940) which differs morphologically and genetically from other forms including those in the nearby Mediterranean Sea (Barabash-Nikiforov 1960, Geptner et al. 1976, Natoli et al. 2005, Viaud-Martinez et al. 2008). The Lahille Bottlenose Dolphin (T. t. gephyreus) (Lahille, 1908), a larger form in the coastal waters of the western South Atlantic Ocean, is morphologically and genetically different from the offshore population in eastern South America (Costa et al. 2015, 2016; Fruet et al. 2011, 2015). The third subspecies is the nominate subspecies that includes the remaining Common Bottlenose Dolphins worldwide (T. t. truncatus (Montagu, 1821)). In the western North Atlantic, two forms, offshore and coastal, are distinguishable on the basis of morphology and ecological markers (Mead and Potter 1995) and have fixed genetic differences (Le Duc and Curry 1997, Hoelzel et al. 1998, Kingston et al. 2009, Rosel et al. 2009, Van Waerebeek et al. 2017a) and according to the recent IWC review the coastal population should be recognized as at least a different subspecies.
Anser caerulescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Chen.

Pleuronichthys guttulatus was described by Girard (1856). This species was later placed in the genus Hypsopsetta by Gill (1863). Based on a cladistic analysis of morphological features, Cooper and Chapleau (1998) recognized Pleuronichthys as the appropriate genus for this species. This arrangement was confirmed in the molecular work of Vinnikov et al. (2018). Although some authors as recent as Kells et al. (2016) have continued to recognize Hypsopsetta as the appropriate genus, this species is treated herein as Pleuronichthys guttulatus following Cooper and Chapleau (1998).

Some debate has surrounded the placement of Paralichthodes algoensis Gilchrist 1902. Previously, it was classified as belonging to the subfamily Samarinae of the Pleuronectidae (Regan 1910). Regan (1920) erected the family Paralichthodidae for this species. In 1929, Regan reduced its rank to the subfamily Paralichthodinae within the Pleuronectidae. This classification was retained by Norman (1934), Hubbs (1945), and Evseenko (2004). In contrast, Nelson (1976) reassigned P. algoensis to the Samarinae. Sakamoto (1984) considered this species as a member of the subfamily Pleuronectinae within the Pleuronectidae. However, more recent works based on both morphological and molecular evidence (e.g., Cooper and Chapleau 1998, Pardo et al. 2005, Campbell et al. 2019) classify P. algoensis as the only member of the family Paralichthodidae.

Mytilopsis africana is a brackish water species occurring in mangroves and sublitorally on stones, shells and other hard substrates, from Senegal to Congo. This species could be part of the lineage of the Caribbean M. hessei, that crossed the ocean via the slave trade.
The taxonomic status of this species requires verification.
This species is known from five specimens collected in Lago Budi, a coastal lagoon in Chile (Pequeño and Plaza 1987 ). The taxonomic status of this nominal species needs reevaluation.

Spinirhombus (now Pseudorhombus) ctenosquamis was described by Oshima in 1927 based on a single specimen collected at a fish market in Taiwan, which subsequently has been lost. The taxonomic status of this species is questionable. No other specimens have been reported by authors working on flatfishes of Taiwan (e.g., Chen and Weng 1965, Shao et al. 2008, Shao and Ho 2011).

Wu (1932) considered Pseudorhombus ctenosquamis as a synonym of P. cinnamoneus, but did not indicate that he had examined the type specimen. Norman (1934) provided an account for this species, but equivocated in noting that Wu (1932) considered it to be a synonym of P. cinnamoneus. Chen and Weng (1965) provided an account for this species, but all indications are that the information is based on that provided in the original description. Li and Wang (1995) considered this as a valid species. However, Randall and Lim (2000) do not include this species among the paralichthyids recorded from the South China Sea nor did Shao et al. (2008) list this species in their checklist of fishes of southern Taiwan. 

Given that no additional specimens have ever been recorded and authors working with the genus Pseudorhombus disagree, further research is required to establish the taxonomic status of this nominal species.

Taxonomic uncertainty associated with Atheresthes evermanni and A. stomias was resolved with the genetic study (Ranck et al. 1986) that confirmed their validity as separate species. The two species are also well distinguished from one another by external morphology (Yang 1988, Mukhametov and Orlov 2002).

Due to high similarity in both appearance, ecology and distribution, there was much taxonomic uncertainty associated with Atheresthes evermanni and A. stomias until genetics studies in the mid-1980s (Ranck et al. 1986) and morphological differences (Yang 1988) confirmed their validity as separate species.

This species may be easily confused with Glyptocephalus kitaharae (Jang et al. 2016). An mtDNA analysis of specimens of Glyptocephalus stelleri from four widely separated areas throughout the Japanese Archipelago reported no significant genetic differentiation among samples from these four areas (Xiao et al. 2010).

The genus Hippoglossoides, including Hippoglossoides robustus, H. elassodon and H. dubius, has been the subject of recent taxonomic uncertainty (Parin et al. 2014, Vinnikov et al. 2018). Kartavtsev et al. (2008) concluded that H. robustus is a junior synonym of H. elassodon; however, this was later refuted by additional genetic studies (Roje 2010, Parin et al. 2014). According to Vinnikov et al. (2018), the phylogenetic and taxonomic status of H. robustus are not yet fully resolved, and additional sampling of specimens from throughout the entire geographic range is needed. Some genetic studies are currently underway, and preliminary results suggest that they are separate species (I. Spies pers. comm. 2020).

Cleisthenes herzensteini (Schmidt 1904) is considered a junior synonym of C. pinetorum Jordan and Starks 1904 according to Vinnikov et al. (2018), but these authors mention uncertainty remains concerning this taxonomic decision and that further sampling across the entire range inhabited by these two nominal species is required.

The genus Hippoglossoides, including Hippoglossoides robustus, H. elassodon and H. dubius, has been the subject of recent taxonomic uncertainty (Parin et al. 2014, Vinnikov et al. 2018). Kartavtsev et al. (2008) concluded that H. robustus is a junior synonym of H. elassodon; however, this was later refuted by additional genetic studies (Roje 2010, Parin et al. 2014). According to Vinnikov et al. (2018), the phylogenetic and taxonomic status of H. robustus are not yet fully resolved, and additional sampling of specimens from throughout the entire geographic range is needed. Some genetic studies are currently underway, and preliminary results suggest that they are separate species (I. Spies pers. comm. 2020).

Orr and Matarese (2000) recognized that specimens previously identified as Lepidopsetta bilineata actually represent two species. In addition to L. bilineata, they described a second species, Lepidopsetta polyxstra, within the genus Lepidopsetta. Distribution records, ranging from the Salish Sea north to the Bering Sea, documented prior to recognition of two species in Lepidopsetta, may represent mixtures of the two species.

Orr and Matarese (2000) recognized that specimens previously identified as Lepidopsetta bilineata actually represent two species. In addition to L. bilineata, they described a second species, Lepidopsetta polyxstra, within the genus Lepidopsetta. Distribution records, ranging from the Salish Sea north to the Bering Sea, documented prior to recognition of two species in Lepidopsetta, may represent mixtures of the two species.

This species was originally described as Pleuronectes aspera by Pallas (1814). Later, this species was transferred to the genus Limanda by Bean (1882). Some authors (Sakamoto 1984a) placed this species back in the genus Pleuronectes. However, in the very same year, Sakamoto (1984b) considered this to be a member of the genus Limanda. There has been considerable debate regarding the number of species to be placed in the genus Limanda (Cooper and Chapleau 1998, Roje 2010, McCusker et al. 2013, Voronina and Chanet 2014, Busby et al. 2017, Vinnikov et al. 2018). Throughout this history, Pleuronectes aspera Pallas 1814 has more consistently been placed in the genus Limanda, except for the classification proposed by Sakamoto (1984a) and literature accepting this classification. A revision of the genus Limanda is needed, as recent data on larval morphology (Busby et al. 2017) and DNA sequences (McCusker et al. 2013) suggest that the genus is not monophyletic. Based on the morphological evidence (Norman 1934, Cooper and Chapleau 1998, Roje 2010, Voronina and Chanet 2014) and molecular data (Roje 2010, McCusker et al. 2013, Vinnikov et al. 2018), Pleuronectes aspera is regarded as a member of the genus Limanda Gottsche 1825.

This species was originally described as Limanda proboscidea by Gilbert (1896). This species has been variously placed in the genera Limanda (Cooper and Chapleau 1998, Roje 2010, Voronina and Chanet 2014), Pleuronectes (Sakamoto 1984 and literature following this placement), and Myzopsetta (Sheiko and Fedorov 2000, Fedorov et al. 2003, Mecklenburg and Steinke 2015, Vinnikov et al. 2018). Most frequently, it has been considered a member of the genus Limanda (e.g., Cooper and Chapleau 1998, Roje 2010, Voronina and Chanet 2014), but there has been considerable debate regarding the number of species to be placed in that genus (Cooper and Chapleau 1998, Roje 2010, McCusker et al. 2013, Voronina and Chanet 2014, Busby et al. 2017, Vinnikov et al. 2018). A revision of the genus Limanda is needed, as recent data on larval morphology (Busby et al. 2017) and DNA sequences (McCusker et al. 2013, Mecklenburg and Steinke 2015) suggest that the genus is not monophyletic. The most recent studies consider this species to be a member of the genus Myzopsetta (Sheiko and Fedorov 2000, Fedorov et al. 2003, Mecklenburg and Steinke 2015, Vinnikov et al. 2018). Herein, Limanda proboscidea Gilbert 1896 is regarded as a member of the genus Myzopsetta.

Hippoglossoides punctatissima Steindachner 1879 has been placed by various authors in the genera Pleuronectes, Limanda, and Myzopsetta (see Fricke et al. 2021 for further details). The most recent systematic review of the Pleuronectidae considers this species a member of the genus Myzopsetta (Vinnikov et al. 2018), and this decision is followed herein.
A taxonomic revision of the genus Limanda is needed (Busby et al. 2017, Vinnikov et al. 2018).

Liopsetta putnami (Gill 1864) has been treated as a junior subjective synonym of L. glacialis (Pallas 1776) by some, but most workers consider them to be separate species (Mecklenburg et al. 2018). Voronina and Chanet (2014) commented that additional genetics work is needed to resolve the relationships of species assigned to Liopsetta. Vinnikov et al. (2018), based on molecular data, recognized L. putnami and L. glacialis as distinct species. This species can be easily confused with smaller individuals of Winter Flounder (Pseudopleuronectes americanus).

Pleuronichthys cornutus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846) was described based on several specimens collected off Japan. Later, Pleuronichthys lighti Wu 1929 was described based on a unique holotype collected near Amoy Island, China. The present whereabouts of this specimen is unknown. Subsequently, P. lighti was considered as a junior synonym of P. cornutus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846) by several authors (Li and Wang 1995; Evseenko 2003, 2004; Suzuki et al. 2009). According to the taxonomic work of Yokogawa et al. (2014, 2016), both P. lighti and P. cornutus should be recognized as valid species. Molecular analyses conducted by Vinnikov et al. (2018) also support recognition of P. cornutus and P. lighti.

Pleuronichthys lighti Wu 1929 was described based on a unique holotype collected near Amoy Island, China. The present whereabouts of this specimen is unknown. Subsequently, P. lighti was considered as a junior synonym of P. cornutus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846) from off Japan by several authors (Li and Wang 1995, Evseenko 2003, 2004, Suzuki et al. 2009). According to the taxonomic work of Yokogawa et al. (2014, 2016), both P. lighti and P. cornutus should be recognized as valid species. Molecular analyses conducted by Vinnikov et al. (2018) also support recognition of P. cornutus and P. lighti.

According to Parin et al. (2014), conclusions by Vinnikov et al. (2006) and Kartavtsev et al. (2007) that Pseudopleuronectes schrenki is a synonym of P. yokohamae were not fully supported and required further examination of syntypes. Tsukagoshi et al. (2015) concluded that these are two separate species based on mitochondrial DNA analysis. Vinnikov et al. (2018) also found strong molecular evidence that these two species are indeed separate and should be considered sister species.

According to Parin et al. (2014), conclusions by Vinnikov et al. (2006) and Kartavtsev et al. (2007) that Pseudopleuronectes schrenki is a synonym of P. yokohamae were not fully supported and required further examination of syntypes. Tsukagoshi et al. (2015), based on molecular analyses, concluded these two are separate species. Similarly, Vinnikov et al. (2018), using molecular evidence, concluded that these two nominal species are indeed separate, and likely sister species.
This species is frequently referred to as Tanakius kitaharae or T. kitaharai in the literature, especially in Japan.
Guibord and Chapleau (2004) synonymized Nematops chui Fowler 1934 with Nematops macrochirus Norman 1931 after analyzing the only known specimen of the first nominal species.
Guibord and Chapleau (2002) synonymized Poecilopsetta megalepis Fowler 1934 with Poecilopsetta plinthus (Jordan and Starks 1904) after analyzing the holotype and only specimen of P. megalepis.

Comparing specimens of two similar flatfishes from Australia and New Zealand, Nielsen noted that New Zealand specimens agreed with all of the characters defining Azygopus and further observed that, although the New Zealand specimens shared characteristics with A. pinnifasciatus from Australian waters, several morphological features were different between fishes from the two locations (Nielsen 1961). Even though he could distinguish New Zealand specimens from Australian A. pinnifasciatus based on a number of characters, Nielsen (1961) was influenced by the overall similarities between specimens from Australia and New Zealand and, following taxonomic conventions of that time period (J. Nielsen pers. comm. as cited in Munroe 2012), chose not to recognize the New Zealand specimens as a distinct species, instead describing them as a distinct subspecies (A. p. flemingi). Munroe (2012) distinguished it as a separate species and this was followed in various checklists and in the book The Fishes of New Zealand (e.g. Munroe 2015, Roberts et al. 2015, 2020).

This monotypic genus has posed significant questions regarding the proper classification of this interesting taxon. Historically, it has been classified as a member of the Rhombosoleinae (Regan 1910, Norman 1934, Sakamoto 1984, Ahlstrom et al. 1984, Eschmeyer et al. 1998), as a member of the Rhombosoleidae (Jordan 1923; Chabanaud 1946, 1949; Chapleau and Keast 1988; Hoshino 2001; Chanet 2003; Guibord 2003; Gomon 2008; Munroe 2005, 2015a,b), or as a member of the subfamily Oncopterinae (van der Laan et al. 2014) based on morphological characters. And most recently, Campbell et al. (2019), based on molecular data, and Fricke et al. (2020) have placed Oncopterus in its own family, the Oncopteridae Jordan and Goss 1889.
Mihara and Amaoka (1995) synonymized Samariscus fasciatus Fowler, 1934 with Plagiopsetta glossa Franz, 1910 after analyzing the holotype and only known specimen of S. fasciatus.
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.

Chabanaud (1930) described Aseraggodes beauforti based on two syntypes from the Timor Sea. Randall and Desoutter-Meninger (2007) later re-identified the smaller specimen as A. kaianus and designated the larger specimen as the lectotype of A. beauforti.

As reported in the literature, Aseraggodes cyaneus has a widespread distribution in the Indo-West Pacific (Alcock 1890, Quero and Desoutter 1990, Winterbottom and Anderson 1997, Munroe 2000, Munroe 2001, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003, Fricke et al. 2018). However, the taxonomic status of such widely distributed subpopulations purportedly of this species needs further investigation. It is likely that a species complex is represented among these subpopulations.
Randall and Senou (2007) note that this species was previously identified as Aseraggodes xenicus by Matsubara and Ochiai (1963).

The taxonomic status of this species and Zebrias maculosus needs to be investigated (T. Munroe and R. Nair pers. comm. 2019). At present, both nominal species are considered valid (Eschmeyer et al. 2019).

In a recent redescription of the soleid Brachirus aspilos (Bleeker 1852), Okamoto and Motomura (2021) regarded B. dicholepis (Peters 1877), B. heterolepis (Bleeker 1856), B. marmoratus (Bleeker 1853), and B. sorsogonensis (Evermann and Seale 1907) as junior, subjective synonyms of B. aspilos. This taxonomic conclusion is followed herein.

Synaptura swinhonis was described by Steindachner (1867) based on a single specimen collected off Hong Kong. Since that time, no other specimens of this nominal species have been reported in the literature, but it has been regarded as a valid species by most authors (e.g., Li and Wang 1995, Munroe 2000, Voronina 2019). Okamoto and Motomura (2021) tentatively consider Brachirus swinhonis (Steindachner 1867) as valid, pending further specimens from Hong Kong. At present, this species is considered valid pending further investigation.

Chabanaud (1931) described Achirus rautheri on the basis of a single specimen taken from Port Darwin, Northern Territory, Australia. Clark and George (1979) and Desoutter et al. (2001) considered this species to be a junior synonym of Pardachirus hedleyi Ogilby 1916, whereas Larson and Williams (1997) treated it as a junior synonym of P. poropterus (Bleeker 1851). However, Randall and Johnson (2007), in a revision of the genus Pardachirus, concluded that P. rautheri (Chabanaud 1931) is a valid species.

The generic placement of Synaptura callizona Regan 1903 is uncertain. It has been placed in the genera Aesopia, Pseudaesopia, and Zebrias by various authors. The current name in the Catalog of Fishes is Zebrias callizona, but no references or justification are provided to support this listing. Stephens (2011), in an unpublished revision of Zebrias and related genera, concluded that Synaptura callizona Regan 1903 should be assigned to the genus Pseudaesopia, and this decision is recognized herein.

Soleichthys microcephalus was originally described by Günther (1862). Munroe and Menke (2004) redescribed this species because they discovered that specimens in collections previously identified as S. microcephalus actually represented three species (S. microcephalus, S. oculofasciatus, and S. serpenpellis). As such, specimens identified as S. microcephalus before 2004 may be incorrect.

Desoutter et al. (2001) considered Soleichthys multifasciatus (Kaup 1858) to be a synonym of Soleichthys heterorhinos (Bleeker 1856), but it has since been considered to be a valid species (Muchhala and Munroe 2004, Munroe and Menke 2004, Randall and Munroe 2008).

Li and Wang (1995) considered Soleichthys nigrostriolatus (Steindachner and Kner 1870) to be a synonym of Soleichthys heterorhinos (Bleeker 1856). More recently, S. nigrostriolatus has been treated as a valid species (Muchhala and Munroe 2004, Munroe and Menke 2004, Randall and Munroe 2008).

This species was originally assigned to the genus Cryptops (Hardenberg 1931a); however, the genus name Cryptops was preoccupied. The species was subsequently reassigned to the genus Typhlachirus by Hardenberg (1931b).

There has been some taxonomic confusion between this species and Zebrias keralensis. These taxonomic issues have not been fully resolved. At present, both nominal species are considered valid (Fricke et al. 2019).

McCulloch (1916) described a new species of sole from Australian waters as Synaptura craticula. Later, this species was transferred to the genus Zebrias. To agree with the masculine gender of Zebrias, the specific epithet for this species was changed to craticulus. Not all authors have agreed with the spelling of this epithet, instead they continued to use craticula (Allen and Swainson 1988, Allen 1997, Hutchins 2001, Larson et al. 2013) or craticulatus (Hoese and Bray 2006). However, according to the Catalog of Fishes (Fricke et al. 2021) and ETYFish (Scharpf and Lazara 2020), the correct spelling of the species epithet is craticulus.

Whitley (1966) described a new sole from Australian waters as Strabozebrias munroi. Subsequently, this species was listed both in the genus Phyllichthys and in the genus Strabozebrias by Hutchins (2001). Munroe (2001), based on morphological and pigmentation features, considered this species as a member of the genus Phyllichthys. Stephens (2011), in an unpublished thesis, also considered Strabozebrias munroi Whitley 1966 as a member of the genus Phyllichthys, based on these morphological and pigmentation features. This decision has not been universally accepted, instead, several authors have recognized this species as a member of Zebrias (e.g. Hoese and Bray 2006, Bray 2017). For the purposes of this assessment, based on the information presented in Munroe (2001) and Stephens (2011), this species is considered a member of Phyllichthys.
Gomon (1987) designated Zebrias scalaris as a replacement name for Synaptura fasciata Macleay 1882, which is preoccupied in Zebrias by Solea fasciata Basilewsky 1855.

Historically, a great deal of confusion has surrounded the species complex comprising Zebrias zebra (Bloch 1787), Zebrias zebrinus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846), Zebrias ommatura (Richardson 1846), and Zebrias fasciatus (Basilewsky 1855). Zebrias ommatura and Z. fasciatus have been regarded as junior subjective synonyms for both Z. zebra and Z. zebrinus by different authors. The more persistent problem involves the taxonomic status of Z. zebra (Bloch 1787) and Z. zebrinus (Temminck and Schlegel 1847). These have been considered synonymous by some authors (Ochiai 1963, Lindberg and Fedorov 1993, Li and Wang 1995, Kottelat 2013), whereas other authors (Wang et al. 2014) have regarded both as valid species. The most recent appraisal of these nominal species based on morphology and molecular data (Wang et al. 2014) concluded that both Z. zebra (Bloch 1787) and Z. zebrinus (Temminck and Schlegel 1847) are valid, while Z. ommatura  and Z. fasciatus are junior subjective synonyms of Z. zebrinus. These conclusions are followed herein.

This species, along with the rest of the family Hemitripteridae, was included for a long time in the family Cottidae, but the monophyly of the family Hemitripteridae was established in the 1980s leading Mecklenburg (2003) to consider its taxonomy well established.

Hexagrammos superciliosus is sometimes considered a subspecies of Hexagrammos lagocephalus or of Hexagrammos decagrammus (Gomelyuk 2000). Furthermore, the sexual dimorphism is so strong in this species that males and females were originally described as different species, females as Chirus guttatus and Chirus maculoseriatus, and the males as Chirus constellatus (Mecklenburg and Eschmeyer 2003).

Hexagrammos lagocephalus has long been considered a separate species from Hexagrammos superciliosus, however molecular data does not support this hypothesis and H. superciliosus is now considered a junior synonym of H. lagocephalus (Crow et al. 2004).

Shinohara (1994) and Crow et al. (2004) consider the genus Oxylebius to belong to the family Zaniolepididae, but Mecklenburg and Eschmeyer (2003) place it in the family Hexagrammidae. As this latter placement has been followed by recent authors (e.g., Kells et al. 2016, Pietsch and Orr 2019), we treat this species as a member of the Hexagrammidae. Further research is needed to clarify familial placement of this genus.
This species is currently considered to be the only species of the family Rhamphocottidae, however in past years it was considered part of the family Cottidae (Mecklenburg 2003).

Menon (1977) considered Cynoglossus maccullochi Norman 1926 to be a junior subjective synonym of Cynoglossus maculipinnis Rendahl 1921; however, more recent authors (e.g., Hutchins 2001 as mccullochi, Hoese and Bray 2006, Johnson 1999, Munroe 2001 as mccullochi, Wang et al. 2016) have considered both to be valid species.
This species is frequently misidentified as Symphurus elongatus (Mahadeva and Munroe 1990).
This species is frequently misidentified as Symphurus chabanaudi (Mahadeva and Munroe 1990).

Symphurus leei Jordan and Bollman 1890 was named after Professor L.A. Lee and Mr. Thomas Lee. According to Fricke et al. (2021), the appropriate spelling of the specific epithet should be leeorum because this is the correct form when the species was named after two people (ICZN Article 31.1.2).
Munroe (1990) placed Symphurus seychellensis Chabanaud 1955 and S. sechurae Hildebrand 1946 into the synonymy of S. melanurus Clark 1936.
This species was placed in the genus Apogon previously. After the elevation of the subgenus Ostorhinchus, it was placed in Ostorhinchus (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species was previously placed in the genus Apogon. After the subdivision of the genera and elevation of Ostorhinchus, the species was placed in Ostorhinchus (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species can be easily confused with the congener Parupeneus heptacanthus (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species is easily confused with Parupeneus heptacanthus (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species is easily confused with Parupeneus heptacanthus (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species was recently revised by Uiblein et al. (2019).
This species is easily confused with other goatfish species, including Upeneus heemstra (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species was previously misidentified as Upeneus guttatus and U. bensassei (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species is may be confused with Upeneus vittatus (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species may be confused with Upeneus vittatus (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).

authority: Marceniuk, Molina, Caires, Rotundo, Wosiacki & Oliveira, 2019
Chao, Chang, Chen, Guo, Lin, Liou, Shen & Liu, 2019

taxonomicNotes: This species has recently been described as distinct from an A. filamentosus species complex. These two species have previously been confused (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2018). This species has a blue lacrimal and preopercular flange and is commonly confused with A. spinifer that lacks the blue colouration of the head (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2019).
This species has recently been described as distinct from A. spinifer, with which it has been confused (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2018).
This species has recently been described as distinct from an A. spinifer species complex. The two species have been confused in the past (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2018).
This species was recently separated from Pogonias cromis (Azpelicueta et al. 2019).
Work is underway that will consider Harpagifer palliolatus a synonym of H. bispinis (M. Hüne pers. comm. 2019).

Acanthistius patachonicus and A. brasilianus have been confused in the past, but are confirmed as separate species. Acanthistius brasilianus does not occur in Argentine waters (Irigoyen et al. 2008, 2010).
As morphologically defined, Gymnogobius taranetzi has a polyphyletic origin (Sota et al. 2005) and therefore, the range of this species in Russia needs further clarification (Parin et al. 2014).
Stefanni et al. (2003) found that populations from the Atlantic and the western Mediterranean differs from those in the Adriatic (Venice).
The taxonomic status of this nominal species needs to be investigated further (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2020).
Although considered valid by Eschmeyer et al. (2018), this species is recognised in Japan as a species complex composed of a few species.
Two species have been confused under this species and some literature information may refer to the second species (Belobranchus segura).

Although Physeter catodon is still occasionally used in the literature, P. macrocephalus is recommended (Rice 1989). Both names are listed on the same page of the original description by Linnaeus (1758), and priority is unclear. However, P. macrocephalus is preferable because it is used much more frequently, and this will support nomenclatural stability.
Fricke et al. (2020) list this species in the genus Acentrogobius but it belongs in the genus Amoya (Z. Jaafar in prep).
The genus is presently under review and this species' distribution is uncertain.

It is likely that there is a species complex within Periophthalmus novaeguineaensis. Periophthalmus murdyi Larson and Takita, 2004, is a junior synonym. Type specimens of Eggert's original description (in 1935) include three specimens of P. darwini.

The specific name melanosticta has been treated as a noun by the original author and as melanostictus by some others. Here we follow the original spelling (melanosticta) as is being used in a revision of the genus (Larson and Hammer in press).
Allen (1991) described and illustrated this species, citing it as Stenogobius lachneri Watson, 1990, but Watson did not publish the name until 1994.
The genus Stenogobius is in need of revision.

Two subspecies are recognised (Collette 1974, 2004): Arrhamphus sclerolepis sclerolepis (southern Papua New Guinea and northern Australia) and A. sclerolepis kreftii (south-eastern Australia; south-east Queensland to Sydney, New South Wales).
Preliminary genetic investigations by P. Unmack and G.R. Allen indicate that this species contains several distinct populations that may warrant separate species status (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2019).

This is a poorly known nominal species, described by Linnaeus (1758) from an unreported number of specimens taken at Ambon Island, Indonesia. No type specimens are known to exist. Additional reports of this nominal species are limited. In an overview of the Soleidae, Kaup (1858) determined that the diagnosis of this nominal species by Linnaeus (1758) was correct, but did not indicate whether additional specimens had been examined. Kaup (1858) transferred this nominal species to the genus Solea. Günther (1862) provided a brief synonymy and some information in a brief description of this nominal species, but again did not indicate whether further specimens were available or if his account was based only on the specimens reported in Linnaeus. Günther (1862) indicated that the typical specimens were 30 lines long (~6.3 cm). Weber and de Beaufort (1929) included this nominal species among those listed as doubtful species from the Indo-Australian Archipelago.


Several studies have reported this species from China. Jouan (1867) purportedly examined at least one specimen of this nominal species from Hong Kong. However, Wu (1932) determined that the identification of this species in Jouan (1867) was uncertain. Li and Wang (1995) further remarked that no specimen or description were supplied by Jouan (1867) and noted Wu’s (1932) report of the uncertainty of this record. Li and Wang (1995) provide a synonymy, counts from the original description, and a discussion of the historical literature for this nominal species. They provided no new information regarding specimens from Chinese waters. Their account of this nominal species primarily is a discussion of the historical literature on this nominal species, but no new information was presented to resolve the question regarding the validity of this nominal species. 


Although it is currently regarded as a valid species in the Catalog of Fishes, the limited available evidence raises doubts concerning the validity of this species. Research is needed to determine whether this nominal species is valid. For purposes of this assessment, only the information from the specimen(s) examined by Linneaus is considered.
This species was previously placed under the junior synonym of Lestrolepis luetkeni (Ho and Golani 2019).

The nomenclatural history of the species is somewhat complicated. The name Stegostoma fasciatum (Hermann, 1783) has been the standard name used, however Dahl et al. (2019) concluded that the original name Stegostoma tigrinum Forster, 1781 is the correct senior synonym.

This small species (to 27 mm) was recently described as Haliotis thailandis Dekker and Patamakanthin 2001. However, Owen et al. (2019) determined that it had been incorrectly described, and it was a synonym of Haliotis papulata Reeve 1846, which in turn was not, as previously described, a synonym of Haliotis varia Linnaeus 1758.
This species was described in 2001.
This recently described species was previously identified as Squalus cf. mitsukurii (Daly-Engel et al. 2018).
Mangarinus waterousi belongs to a genus that has never been reviewed and it is uncertain whether it consists of one or several species throughout its range.
Stiphodon is a problematic genus (Watson 1995). Other species have been misidentified as S. elegans.
The species may be misidentified with other members of the Etmoperus lucifer clade (Ebert et al. 2017).
The Longfin Gulper Shark is recently described (White et al. 2017). An extremely long-based first dorsal fin is distinctive and distinguishes it from other Centrophorus species.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
This species was previously referred to as Pleuronectes ferrugineus, then Limanda ferruginea, and is now placed in the genus Myzopsetta (Vinnikov et al. 2018).

Henriques et al. (2014, 2016) used microsatellite makers to show that A. aequidens (sensu lato) included cryptic species – in particular with evidence of two southern African populations, one in South Africa and the other in Angola and Namibia. Subsequently, Song et al. (2017) demonstrated that global Atractoscion comprised four species and that A. aequidens was confined to southern/south-east Africa.
Sciaenia starksi is a junior synonym of S. wierneri (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2018).
This species is easily confused with Anoplocapros inermis (Matsuura 2008).

There is significant taxonomic uncertainty associated with this species in part due to the damaged condition of the holotype and possible confusion with Kentrocapros flavofasciatus (Stewart and Roberts 2015).
This species was previously considered a synonym of Kentrocapros aculeatus (Mundy 2005).
Russell (1990) recognized an undescribed species, Nemipterus sp. 3, which was later described as Nemipterus aurora Russell 1993.
This species was included as Nemipterus sp. 1 in Russell (1990).
This species has been previously misidentified as Nemipterus marginatus by most authors (Russell 1991).
This species has previously been confused with P. trivittatus (Russell 1990).
This species is often misidentified as Pentapodus setosus (Russell 1990).
This species is often misidentified as Pentapodus setosus or P. paradiseus (Russell 1990).
Records of this species from Australia refer to Pentapodus paradiseus.

Puffinus lherminieri (incorporating baroli), P. bannermani, P. persicus, P. subalaris and P. bailloni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. lherminieri and baroli was subsumed under P. assimilis, following Brooke (2004), before which P. bannermani and P. persicus where split following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Butorides striata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as B. striata and B. virescens following AOU (2003), and before then B. striata was split as B. striatus and B. sundevalli following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Gender agreement of B. striata follows David and Gosselin (2002).
Anous tenuirostris and A. minutus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993), cross-regional species, are retained as separate species contra Turbott (1990) who includes minutus as a subspecies of tenuirostris.
Its current taxonomic status is uncertain (Fricke et al. 2019) .

Wozencraft (2005) regarded this species as conspecific with the congeneric Congo Clawless Otter (Aonyx congicus). The two are here retained as distinct species (see van Zyll de Jong 1972, Wozencraft 1993, Somers and Nel 2013). Coetzee (1977) recognised three subspecies A. c. capensis (including coombsi and angolae), from southern Africa, W Zambia, Angola, Gabon, Nigeria and throughout West Africa; A. c. hindei (including helios), from Uganda to E DR Congo as far south as N Zambia; and A. c. meneleki, from Ethiopia. Only one subspecies, A. c. capensis, has been recognised within the assessment region (Meester et al. 1986), reaching as far north as Zambia and Angola (Skinner and Chimimba 2005).

The scientific name North American river otter was formerly Lutra canadensis. Although Lutra may still occasionally be used in some common literature, Lontra is now the accepted genus name for the species (Van Zyll de Jong 1972, 1987; Kellnhauser 1983, Wozencraft 2005).

Lutra sumatrana was first described by Raffles in 1822 as Lutra barang; by Gray in 1865 as Barangia sumatrana; and Lutra lovii by Gunther 1876. Pohle (1919) identified three species L. sumatrana in Sumatra, Malay Penisula and Thailand, L. lovii and L. brunnea in Borneo. Pocock 1941 compiled three species to L. sumatrana including in Vietnam. Recent genetic studies have confirmed it as a single species related to Lutra lutra (Koepfli et al. 2008).

The species was named as Lutra perspicillata by Geoffroy 1826 and as Lutrogale perspicillata by Gray 1865. Two subspecies were reported (Pocock 1941) (1) L. p. perspicillata - in northeast and southern India, Myanmar and Sumatra; and (2) L. p. sindica - in north and northwestern India and Pakistan. Another subspecies L. p. maxwelli, whose current status is uncertain, is reported from the marshes of southern Iraq (Mason and Macdonald 1986).

The spelling of the species epithet in Aonyx cinerea (Illiger, 1815) was incorrect; the genus name 'Aonyx' is masculine and hence the adjectival species name 'cinerea' should be changed to have a masculine ending. The species is now correctly named as A. cinereus (Illiger, 1815). Also referred to as Amblonyx cinereus (Illiger, 1815), Amblonyx concolor Rafinesque, 1832 and Amblonyx cinerea Pocock 1941. Two subspecies were reported (Pocock 1941) (1) A. c. concolor in northeast India, Myanmar extending to Sumatra and (2) A. c. nirnai in the hill ranges of southern India (Hussain et al. 2011).

Many authors have considered this species to be a junior synonym of Paralichthys brasiliensis, a species that is often confused with; however, these species can be distinguished by meristic characteristics and both are currently accepted as separate nominal species (Díaz de Astarloa et al. 2006).

Solitary polyps of Mussa angulosa have been sometimes identified as Scolymia lacera (Veron 2000; see also Fenner 1993). According to the World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS), this species is valid (database accessed September 2021).

Although this species is commonly considered to occur in the Caribbean (southern Caribbean to Jamaica and the Cayman Islands), it is likely that the form in the Caribbean is a different taxon (Weil 1992). For the purposes of this Red List assessment, and until further taxonomic study is conducted, it is considered valid in these areas of the Caribbean.

Orbicella franksi was identified as Montastraea annularis until 1994, when ecological, morphological, and molecular studies provided evidence that it was part of a species complex composed of three species: M. annularis, M. faveolata and M. franksi (Weil and Knowlton 1994). Consequently, most studies prior to 1994 do not distinguish between the three species, and information on population is difficult to disaggregate for the three taxa. Later, Budd et al. (2012) separated modern species of the genus Montastraea into three genera: Montastraea de Blainville, 1830 (Atlantic Montastraea cavernosa), Orbicella Dana, 1846 (Atlantic Orbicella annularis complex), and Phymastrea Milne Edwards and Haime, 1848 (Indo-Pacific).

According to the WoRMS database (accessed August 2021), Dichotaenia stellaris is a junior synonym of D. stokesii. Colonies from lower reef slopes or shaded habitats have markedly smaller corallites than those from more exposed environments, and are usually identified as D. stellaris (Veron 2000).

Montastraea annularis (Weil and Knowlton 1994) has been split into three species, including M. faveolata and M. franksi. Consequently, most studies prior to 1994 do not distinguish between the three species, and information on population is difficult to disaggregate for the three taxa. Later, Budd et al. (2012) separated modern species of the genus Montastraea into three genera: Montastraea de Blainville, 1830 (Atlantic Montastraea cavernosa), Orbicella Dana, 1846 (Atlantic Orbicella annularis complex), and Phymastrea Milne Edwards and Haime, 1848 (Indo-Pacific).

This taxon is now classified under the family Pocilloporidae, along with all Madracis species (Benzoni et al. 2018). Moreover, recent genetic and morphological evidence suggests it is highly probable that the Caribbean zooxanthellate species Madracis pharensis f. luciphila is actually a completely separate species to the cave-dwelling M. pharensis found in the eastern Atlantic (Azores and Mediterranean; Benzoni et al. 2018). As M. pharensis was originally described from the Adriatic Sea by Heller (1868), it is likely that the populations of M. pharensis f. luciphila described by Wells (1973) will have to adopt a new species name.

The consequences of these new findings are a restricted geographic range in what we now know as M. pharensis f. luciphila, compared to the 2008 IUCN Red List assessment. A recent work on the evolution of symbiosis and coloniality of Scleractinia has shown that the Madracis genus may not be monophyletic with two lineages diverging early in the tree, one of M. decactis, M. senaria, M. kirbyi and M. pharensis clustering with Dendrophylliidae in the Robusta clade, while M. asanoi, M. myriaster, M. formosa and M. carmabi together with Pocilloporidae in the Complex clade (Navarro-Campoy et al. 2020). These results must be taken with caution before taxonomic decisions are made as the phylogenetic analyses of Navarro-Campoy et al. (2020) are based on incomplete sampling of molecular markers across the analysed Madracis species, and mainly based on nuclear marker 28s, which is a multicopy gene with intragenomic variation.

Recent genetic revisions have confirmed a long-standing suspicion that M. pharensis in the Caribbean (a zooxanthellate form, often referred to as M. pharensis f. luciphila) is in fact not the same species as the M. pharensis found in the Mediterranean (a cave-loving species often found without zooxanthellae, sometimes referred to as M. pharensis f. pharensis to distinguish it from Luciphila in the Caribbean; Benzoni et al. 2018). Clear genetic and morphological differences suggest these are two different species and reduces the known range of this species compared to the 2008 IUCN Red List assessment, when it was thought to be pan-Atlantic and found in the Azores and Mediterranean (Benzoni et al. 2018). Madracis pharensis f. luciphila has smaller corallites more closely packed together (Benzoni et al. 2018).

Other studies of M. pharensis f. luciphila show strong genetic divergence between deep (>25 m) and shallow (< 25 m) Caribbean populations, whereby both hosts and zooxanthellae are genetically different between depth zones (Frade et al. 2008). Madracis pharensis was previously thought to have a very broad depth distribution, but these findings suggest the existence of deep and shallow taxa. The genetic divergence observed between deep and shallow M. pharensis is similar to that measured for well-established interspecific comparisons (e.g. M. mirabilis and M. formosa), making it likely that these two groups represent subspecies or even cryptic species (Frade et al. 2010). These findings further suggest that the range of M. pharensis is more restricted both geographically and depth-wise. Smaller than presumed effective population sizes and more limited genetic exchange may leave these populations more vulnerable than previously assumed.

Controversy around the taxonomy of M. pharensis and assignation of new names for potentially new species within this species complex will remain until a complete sampling of this taxon is undertaken, including the different populations of the species reported not only in the Caribbean and Atlantic (Benzoni et al. 2018), but also in the Pacific (Cairns and Zibrowius 1997, see discussion in Cairns 2000). In this updated Red List assessment, we include data collected from both forms and referred to them accordingly.
Molecular research is needed to resolve taxonomic uncertainties associated with the separation of Schizoculina africana and S. fissipara (B. Hoeksema pers. comm. 2022).

Even though the species was considered as part of the family Faviidae, this affiliation has been considered dubious and the species has most recently been placed within Caryophylliidae (Romano and Cairns 2000, Cairns et al. 2001) and now within Scleractinia incertae sedis (Hoeksema and Cairns 2013).

In 2012, the genus Diploria was split into two separate genera: Diploria, which consists only of the species Diploria labyrinthiformis; and a new genus, Pseudodiploria, which consists of the species Pseudodiploria strigosa and Pseudodiploria clivosa (Budd et al. 2012).
This species was previously placed in the family Mussidae, but is now placed under Faviidae (Budd et al. Budd et al. 2019).

This species is commonly confused with Meandrina braziliensis. Smith (1971) recognized two species in the Caribbean, the sub-massive and platy form, M. meandrites, and a free-living form, M. danae, and a third species in Brazil, M. braziliensis. Most reports in the last 20 years refer to the free-living form in the Caribbean as M. braziliensis. Review of the genus in the Caribbean has confirmed the identity of M. danae as the free-living form distinct from M. braziliensis, the identity of M. meandrites as a sub-massive platy form and a new crustos species yet to be described (Pinzón and Weil 2011).
This species was previously classified in the family Faviidae but is now under Montastraeidae (Huang et al. 2014).

Madracis formosa has been moved into Pocilloporidae, along with all Madracis species, as genetics has recently confirmed it is more closely related to Pocillopora than Stephanocoenia (Benzoni et al. 2018).

Orbicella faveolata was identified as Montastraea annularis until 1994, when ecological, morphological, and molecular studies provided evidence that it was part of a species complex composed of three species: M. annularis, M. faveolata and M. franksi (Weil and Knowlton 1994).
