Consequently, most studies prior to 1994 do not distinguish between the three species, and information on population is difficult to disaggregate for the three taxa. Later, Budd et al. (2012) separated modern species of the genus Montastraea into three genera: Montastraea de Blainville, 1830 (Atlantic Montastraea cavernosa), Orbicella Dana, 1846 (Atlantic Orbicella annularis complex), and Phymastrea Milne Edwards and Haime, 1848 (Indo-Pacific).

In 2012, the genus Diploria was split into two separate genera: Diploria, which consists only of the species Diploria labyrinthiformis; and a new genus, Pseudodiploria, which consists of the species Pseudodiploria strigosa and Pseudodiploria clivosa (Budd et al. 2012).
Siderastrea glynni is a subjective junior synonym of this species (Glynn et al. 2016).
The validity of this species is confirmed (Pinzón and Weil 2011, WoRMS database accessed January 2022).

There is no major taxonomic uncertainty associated with this species (J. Crabbe, D. Huang, N. Santodomingo pers. comm. 2021). Some previous authors have identified Madracis auretenra as M. asperula (e.g. Lewis 1960).

While species level distinction has been long accepted, Favia leptophylla was recently transferred to the genus Mussismilia based on phylogenetic (Fukami et al. 2004, Nunes et al. 2008) and micromorphological data (Budd et al. 2012).

There is discussion about species distinctions among Porties porites - Porites furcata - Porites divaricata, whether these species represent morphological variants of one diverse species or distinct species. It is suggested that genetic variation among these putative species occur along geographic gradients rather than taxonomy (Prada et al. 2014).

This species was described by Pourtalès (1871), the basis of record originally created by Cairns et al. (2009) and later revised by Hoeksema and Cairns (2021). Taxonomic description and habitat distribution is presented by Veron (2000).

Features that distinguish this species from other Madracis species are the combination of (1) a branching morphology and (2) decameral septal organization. Vermeij et al. (2003) proposed that hybridization between Madracis decactis and Madracis formosa was the process leading to this new taxon. Madracis carmabi has been moved back into Pocilloporidae, along with all Madracis species, as genetics has recently confirmed it is more closely related to Pocillopora than Stephanocoenia (Benzoni et al. 2018). Madracis carmabi shares characteristics with two other Madracis species, i.e., colony morphology and septal arrangement correspond to that of M. formosa and M. decactis, respectively. Close relationships and exchange of genetic information have been found among Madracis species (Diekmann et al. 2001).
Veron (2000) synonymized Isophyllastrea with Isophyllia.

There is discussion about species distinctions among Porites porites - Porites furcata - Porites divaricata, whether these species represent morphological variants of one diverse species or distinct species. It is suggested that genetic variation among these putative species occur along geographic gradients rather than taxonomy (Prada et al. 2014).
This species was previously placed in the family Mussidae but is now placed under Faviidae (Budd et al. 2012, Budd et al. 2019).
Molecular research is needed to resolve taxonomic uncertainties associated with the separation of Schizoculina africana and S. fissipara (B. Hoeksema pers. comm. 2022).

According to the World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS), this species is accepted as Scolymia wellsii. Species in the genus Scolymia may be misidentified and can be confused with newly recruited polyps of Mussa angulosa. In Brazil, it can be confused with Mussismilia hispida recruits (M. Kitahara pers. comm. 2021).

While field identification may be difficult, micro-morphological and micro-structural characters clearly differentiate Scolymia wellsi from its congeners, Scolymia lacera and Scolymia cubensis, as well as the colonial Mussa angulosa belonging to the same family and whose founder polyps strongly resemble Scolymia (Casebolt 2011, Budd et al. 2012). Molecular phylogenetics also support species-level distinction of Scolymia lacera and Scolymia wellsi (Fukami et al. 2004). The colour of live specimens ranges from brown to green (sometimes even purple), and it is not uncommon to see multicoloured individuals.

Scolymia cubensis has been reported to occur in Brazil (Neves et al. 2006), and while skeletal morphological differences are demonstrated between S. cubensis and S. wellsi collected in this study, a single specimen of S. cubensis was analyzed from Brazil. Nevertheless, future studies conducted on Scolymia spp. in Brazil, Colombia, Venezuela or any other Caribbean location where the species is suspected to occur should verify identification in the laboratory, on at least a portion of the specimens studied. Molecular techniques are also indicated as means to separate Scolymia representatives.

Madracis senaria has been moved into Pocilloporidae along with all Madracis species, as genetics has recently confirmed it is more closely related to Pocillopora than Stephanocoenia (Benzoni et al. 2018).

Madracis mirabilis (sensu Wells 1973)—a pale yellow shallow branching stony coral with cylindrical branches known as Yellow Pencil Coral—is a well studied species and the name ‘Madracis mirabilis’ is deeply entrenched within the literature to describe it. Locke et al. (2007) found this coral had never formally been described, and moreover, M. mirabilis (Duchassaing and Michelotti 1860) technically referred to a deep-water azooxanthellate species now synonymous with Madracis myriaster (Milne-Edwards and Haime 1849). Locke et al. (2007) described the Yellow Pencil Coral commonly known as M. mirabilis, as M. auretenra. However, many studies continue to use the name M. mirabilis to designate populations of this species (e.g. Frade et al. 2010, Veron et al. 2020) and there is some debate around whether replacing this well-established name with M. auretenra is adequately supported. The taxonomic debate about the validity of the new name M. auretenra in respect to M. mirabilis is based on the fact that the type specimen of M. mirabilis designated by Duchassaing and Michelotti (1860) was not revised by Locke et al. (2007) for the description of M. auretenra.
Onychoprion fuscatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna as S. fuscata.
Ardenna gravis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.
Hydrobates furcatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma as O. furcata.
Hydrobates melania (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma.

This speices was considered a junior synonym of Cephaloscyllium isabellum by Springer (1979) and of C. umbratile by Schaaf-da Silva & Ebert (2008), but resurrected as a valid species by Nakaya et al. (2013).

The genus Scoliodon, represented by S. laticaudus, was previously considered monotypic but now consists of three species with S. macrorhynchus resurrected from the junior synonym of S. laticaudus (White et al. 2010).
This is a newly described species that was previously referred to as Platyrhina sinensis (Iwatsuki et al. 2011).
This is a newly described species that was previously referred to as Platyrhina sinensis (Iwatsuki et al. 2011).

This species has been confused with the Kwangtung Skate (Dipturus kwangtunensis) that occurs further south; the Polkadot Skate has a shorter snout and more symmetrical pattern on blotches on the dorsal surface (Last et al. 2016).

The taxonomy of Lamiopsis has recently been resolved with White et al. (2010) resurrecting and redescribing Lamiopsis tephrodes from South-east Asia, and Akhilesh et al. (2016) redescribing Lamiopsis temminckii from the Arabian Sea.
This species was previously considered a subspecies of the Pacific Bluefin Tuna (Thunnus orientalis) or Atlantic Bluefin Tuna (Thunnus thynnus).

Previously, this species was included in the genus Tetrapturus (Collette et al. 2006). It is genetically similar to the White Marlin (Kajikia albida), but represents a distinct evolutionary unit (Collette and Graves 2019).

The Pacific (Thunnus orientalis) and Atlantic (Thunnus thynnus) Bluefin populations are now recognized as separate species (Collette 1999). Thunnus saliens Jordan & Evermann 1926 is a junior synonym of T. orientalis.
Additional research is needed to determine the range extent of this species and its' systematic status (McMahan pers. comm. 2020).

Delsman (1931) described Stolephorus baganensis proper (=S. baganensis baganensis) and Stolephorus baganensis var megalops from Indonesia; later, Dutt and Babu Rao (1959) described Anchoviella baganensis bengalensis from eastern India. Whitehead et al. (1988) and Wongratana et al. (1999) erroneously listed this species as S. b. macrops based off of Harenberg (1933). Whitehead et al. (1988) and Wongratana et al. (1999) considered S. b. macrops Delsman 1931 and A. b. bengalensis (Dutt and Babu Rao 1959) to be junior synonyms of S. baganensis. However, a recent morphological and genetic review of ten nominal species of Stolephorus concluded that S. b. megalops is a junior synonym of S. tri and S. bengalensis is a valid species (Hata et al. 2019).

Stolephorus waitei has long been considered the senior synonym of S. bataviensis and widely distributed in Indo-West Pacific (e.g., Whitehead et al. 1988, Wongratana et al. 1999). A recent morphological and genetic review of ten nominal species of Stolephorus concluded that S. bataviensis is a valid species and restricted the true S. waitei (reported as Stolephorus species A. in Whitehead et al. 1988) to Queensland, Australia (Hata et al. 2019).

If valid, this species is closely related to Apogon talboti (Kuiter and Kozawa 2019). This is a very poorly known species, which appears to have not been seen since it was described from the single unique holotype in 1929. It is probably a junior synonym of a previously described species (G. Allen pers. comm. 2020).
This species was placed in the genus Apogon previous to the subdivision of the genera and elevation of the subgenus Apogonichthyoides (Mabuchi et al. 2014).

Taxonomic research involving molecular methods is needed (Gon 2000). This species was placed in the genus Apogon previous to the subdivision of the genera and elevation of the subgenus Apogonichthyoides (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species was placed in the genus Apogon previous to the subdivision of the genera and elevation of the subgenus Jaydia (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species was previously placed in the genus Apogon. After the subdivision of the genera and elevation of Ostorhinchus, the species was placed in Ostorhinchus (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species was previously placed in the genus Apogon. After the subdivision of the genera and elevation of Ostorhinchus, the species was placed in Ostorhinchus (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species was previously placed in the genus Apogon. After the subdivision of the genera and elevation of Ostorhinchus, the species was placed in Ostorhinchus (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species was previously placed in the genus Apogon. After the subdivision of the genera and elevation of Ostorhinchus, the species was placed in Ostorhinchus (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species was previously placed in the genus Apogon. After the subdivision of the genera and elevation of Ostorhinchus, the species was placed in Ostorhinchus (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species was previously placed in the genera Apogon. After the subdivision of the genera and elevation of Pristiapogon, the species was placed in Pristiapogon (Mabuchi et al. 2014).
This species has been confused in the past with Amblygobius stethophthalmus (museum records).
This species is closely related to Amblygobius bynoensis (Allen and Erdmann 2012) and has been confused with it.
This species is a member of the Cryptocentrus leucostictus complex (Hoese and Larson 2004).
Previously considered a widely distributed species and at times with two subspecies, it is now distinct from F. lentiginosus (Richardson, 1844) (Hoese and Larson 2008).
This species is similar to Valenciennea randalli (Hoese and Larson 1994).
This species is very similar to Ogilbyina queenslandiae (Pogonoski et al. 2002).
Gill and Tanaka (2004) notes Pholidochromis cerasina may be confused with Pseudochromis fowleri Herre, 1934 and Pseudochromis fuscus Müller and Troschel, 1849.

This species is very similar to Pictichromis paccagnellorum and to P. coralensis (Randall and Schultz 2009). It is possibly a synonym of P. paccagnellorum (Allen and Erdmann 2012), but there has been no published synonymization, and therefore, the name remains valid. The species is genetically distinct, has a slightly different color pattern, and the caudal fin is distinct in being emarginate. As there are several characters that distinguish the species and it is genetically distinct based on BOLD blast tree, its taxonomic validity is not in doubt (J. Williams pers. comm. 2022).

Randall and Anderson (1993) note this species has previously been confused with Pseudochromis cyanotaenia and P. tapeinosoma. This species is a member of the P. tapeinosoma complex (Gill and Winterbottom 1993).
This species is a member of the Pseudochromis tapeinosoma complex (Gill and Winterbottom 1993).
This species is a member of the Pseudochromis tapeinosoma complex (Gill and Winterbottom 1993).
This species is a member of the Pseudochromis reticulatus complex (Gill et al. 2017) and may be confused with P. pictus and P. reticulatus (Gill and Allen 2004).
This species is a member of the Pseudochromis tapeinosoma complex. It was previously misidentified as P. tapeinosoma (Gill and Randall 1996).
This species is a member of the Pseudochromis tapeinosoma complex (Gill and Winterbottom 1993).

Stolephorus babarani closely resembles S. bataviensis Hardenberg, 1933 and S. baweanensis Hardenberg, 1933. Stolephorus babarani was previously misidentified as S. waitei Jordan and Seale, 1926 (Hata et al. 2020).

Stolephorus bataviensis, originally described as S. insularis bataviensis, has historically been considered a junior synonym of S. waitei (e.g., Whitehead et al. 1988, Wongratana et al. 1999). A recent morphological and genetic review of ten nominal species of Stolephorus concluded that S. bataviensis is a valid species and restricted the true S. waitei to Queensland, Australia (Hata et al. 2019).

Stolephorus baweanensis, originally described as S. insularis baweanensis, has historically been considered a junior synonym of S. insularis (e.g., Whitehead et al. 1988, Kottelat 2013). A recent morphological and genetic review of ten nominal species of Stolephorus concluded that S. baweanensis is a valid species and that some specimens previously identified as S. waitei are S. baweanensis (Hata et al. 2019).

Stolephorus bengalensis has long been treated as Stolephorus insularis (e.g. Whitehead et al. 1988; Wongratana et al. 1999). The name S. bengalensis, originally described as Anchoviella baganensis bengalensis by Dutt and Babu Rao (1959), has been regarded as a junior synonym of Stolephorus baganensis Delsman 1931. However, a recent morphological and genetic review of ten nominal species of Stolephorus concluded that S. insularis is a junior synonym of S. tri and S. bengalensis is a valid species (Hata et al. 2019).
Stolephorus tamilensis is closely related to S. andhraensis (Gangan et al. 2020).

This species was recently described as a new species in the genus Thrissina, distinct from T. vitrirostris (Hata and Motomura 2019). There remains some disagreement as to the validity of the genera Thryssa and Thrissina. Kottelat (2013) regarded the genus Thyrssa as a new spelling for, and a junior synonym of, Thrissa and gave precedence to Thrissina over simultaneous synonyms Xenengraulis and Scutengraulis. However, Thryssa is regarded as independent of Thrissa by Fricke et al. (2020), and for the sake of stability, retained the genus Thryssa.

This species was recently described as a new species in genus Thrissina, distinct from T. vitrirostris (Hata and Motomura 2019). There remains some disagreement as to the validity of the genera Thryssa and Thrissina. Kottelat (2013) regarded the genus Thyrssa as a new spelling for, and a junior synonym of, Thrissa and gave precedence to Thrissina over simultaneous synonyms Xenengraulis and Scutengraulis. However, Thryssa is regarded as independent of Thrissa by Fricke et al. (2020), and for the sake of stability, retained the genus Thryssa.

Other than the original collection (Bloch and Schneider 1801), nothing is known about this nominal species. Norman (1934) regarded this species as a junior synonym of Bothus lunatus. It was not listed among the species of Citharichthys in Gutherz (1967) field guide to the bothid flatfishes of the Western Atlantic. Munroe (2003) did not consider this species in his treatment of the flatfishes of the Greater Caribbean, nor did Robertson and Van Tassell (2019) include this species in the online checklist. However, it is listed in Paepke (1999) and considered a valid species in the Catalog of Fishes (Fricke et al. 2021). It is assessed here but the taxonomic status of this nominal species needs to be investigated.

Hata and Motomura (2019) recently described two new species, Thrissina cultella and T. serena, as distinct from T. vitrirostris. There remains some disagreement as to the validity of the genera Thryssa and Thrissina. Kottelat (2013) regarded the genus Thyrssa as a new spelling for, and a junior synonym of, Thrissa and gave precedence to Thrissina over simultaneous synonyms Xenengraulis and Scutengraulis. However, Thryssa is regarded as independent of Thrissa by Fricke et al. (2020), and for the sake of stability, retained the genus Thryssa.

Stolephorus tri was originally described as Engraulis tri by Bleeker (1852). Although Whitehead et al. (1988) and Wongratana et al. (1999) listed no name as a synonym of the nominal species, Hata et al. (2019) regarded Stolephorus insularis Hardenberg, 1931 (previously regarded as a valid species) and Stolephorus baganensis megalops (previously regarded as a junior synonym of Stolephorus baganensis and inadvertently misquoted as S. b. macrops) as the junior synonyms of S. tri. The applicable scientific name for the species regarded as S. insularis by Whitehead et al. (1988) and Wongratana et al. (1999) is newly regarded as Stolephorus bengalensis (Dutt and Babu Rao, 1959), which was previously regarded as a junior synonym of S. baganensis in Hata et al. (2019).
Weigmann et al. (2020) revised the genus Pliotrema, describing this species and Pliotrema kajae as new species, distinct from Pliotrema warreni.
Weigmann et al. (2020) revised the genus Pliotrema, describing this species and Pliotrema annae as new species, distinct from Pliotrema warreni.
This species is closely related to Pseudochromis punctatus (Randall 1995) and Pseudochromis melas is a sister species (DiBattista et al. 2016).

authority: Quattro, Driggers III, Grady, Ulrich & Roberts, 2013
taxonomicNotes: This cryptic species is most closely related to the Scalloped Hammerhead (Sphyrna lewini), and is morphologically distinguishable by the number of precaudal vertebrae (Quattro et al. 2013).
The Bay of Bengal population may represent a separate dwarf Iago omanensis-like species (Fernando et al. 2019, Psomadakis et al. 2019).

Regional synonyms of this species include: Perca ciliata Cuvier, 1828 (Java); Dules guamensis Valenciennes, 1831 (Guam); Dules vanicolensis Valenciennes, 1831 (Santa Cruz Islands); Dules haswellii Macleay, 1881 (Queensland); Dules rupestris hedleyi Ogilby 1897 (New Caledonia); Kuhlia caerulescens Regan, 1913 (Solomon Islands).
This species is often confused with Butis amboinensis.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List with the incorrect spelling of regani.

The taxonomy of anadromous Ponto-Caspian shads remains in question, with molecular studies revealing low genetic divergence between species inhabiting the Black, Caspian and Aegean Sea basins.

Given that a conclusive taxonomic revision has not yet emerged, the concept applied in the majority of recent literature is maintained for the purposes of this assessment. The Caspian Shad is therefore considered endemic to the Caspian Sea basin and not conspecific with the Black Sea shad (Alosa tainaica).

In addition, two putative subspecies referred to in some published literature as Astrabad shad (Alosa caspia persica) and Anzali shad (A. c. knipowitschi) are here considered synonymous with A. caspia.
The species was reviewed by Murdy and Shibukawa (2003). Previous records from Australia were a different species.

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).
Bathygobius fuscus was originally described as Gobius fuscus by Rüppell (1830) from the Red Sea.
This species was reviewed by Allen and Burgess (1990).

There was some uncertainty that this species should be known as Gobionellus atripinnis, however, it is currently considered to be valid as Ctenogobius claytonii. Gobionellus atripinnis is considered a junior synonym (L. Tornabene and F. Pezold pers. comm. 2015).

Microsatellite markers demonstrated within- and among-population genetic variability. Over most of its range, genetic differentiation was subtle. Geographically isolated and peripheral populations were much more distinct. Populations from Florida, the Pacific of Panama, Gulf of Guinea, and Costa Rica, were genetically differentiated (Ward et al. 2008). It is unknown to what extent larval dispersal versus adult migrations contribute to this differentiation (Adams pers. comm. 2011).
In Australia, Butis butis is often confused with this species.

This species is the senior synonym of Awaous melanocephalus (Bleeker 1849). Bleeker described the two species in the same publication, based on a male (A. melanocephalus) and a female (A. grammepomus). Awaous melanocephalus was first synonymised with A. grammepomus by Gunther (1861), although both names are still often used. Species of the genus Awaous are in need of revision.
Previously confused with the Whitespotted Whipray (Maculabatis gerrardi) from which it can be distinguished based on colour and morphometrics (Manjaji-Matsumoto and Last 2016).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, comprised of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including gerrardi). Reports of the species are often confused with the Coach Whipray (Himantura uarnak).

Prior to the recent species description, this species previously included Neotrygon kuhlii (Last et al. 2016a). The Neotrygon genus has recently been split and currently includes at least 11 species. It is difficult to distinguish some members of the genus based solely on morphology, thus the true distribution and overlap of species is not currently known. More work is required to fully understand where each member of the Neotrygon genus occurs,

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, comprised of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including bleekeri). Previously on The IUCN Red List bleekeri was treated as a junior synonym of uarnacoides (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007). However, Pateobatis bleekeri is considered a valid species by Last et al. (2016). This species was formerly referred to as Himantura alcockii/Himantura uarnacoides in the Arabian Seas region.

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, comprised of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including uarnacoides). Previously on The IUCN Red List, bleekeri was treated as a junior synonym of uarnacoides (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007). However Pateobatis bleekeri is considered a valid species by Last et al. (2016). This species is misidentified for Himantura lobiostoma, Pateobatis hortlei and Maculabatis pastinacoides (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007).
Ciconia episcopus and C. microscelis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. episcopus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The genus Lagenorhynchus is polyphyletic and likely an artificial genus (LeDuc et al. 1999, Harlin-Cognato 2010), and this species is likely to be included eventually in the genus Sagmatias along with L. obliquidens (Pacific White-sided Dolphin) (Vollmer et al. 2018).

Four subspecies of Dusky Dolphin (Lagenorhynchus obscurus) are currently recognized by the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (2018): African Dusky Dolphin L. o. obscurus off southern Africa, Fitzroy’s Dolphin L. o. fitzroyi off eastern South America, Peruvian/Chilean Dusky Dolphin L. o. posidonia off western South America, and the New Zealand Dusky Dolphin (un-named) off New Zealand (Perrin 2002). The populations centered in New Zealand, the west coast of South America, and southwestern Africa are genetically and morphologically distinct (Harlin-Cognato et al. 2007, Cassens et al. 2003, Würsig et al. 1997, Van Waerebeek 1993a,b). There is a hiatus in distribution spanning about 1,000 km along the Chilean coast (Van Waerebeek, 1994), and the animals off Patagonia in Argentina are smaller than those off northern Chile and Peru (Van Waerebeek, 1993b), suggesting that there may be separate subspecies in western and eastern South America (Van Waerebeek, 1993a,b).

Dusky Dolphins also occur around some oceanic island groups (e.g., Tristan da Cunha, Prince Edward, Amsterdam, and St. Paul Islands). The subspecies affinities of these groups are uncertain.

Genetic studies indicate that this species should be synonymized to Abudefduf saxatilis (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2010). It is provisionally regarded as a valid species (A. hoefleri) until current genetic studies are published.
There may be some taxonomic overlap of Centropomus armatus, C. robalito, and C. unionensis. Further taxonomic study is needed.
Chelonodon laticeps is morphologically similar to C. patoca (Matsuura 2002).
Atelomycterus erdmanni is closely related to A. baliensis and A. marmoratus, being sympatric with the latter (Fahmi and White 2015).

Hemitriakis indroyonoi is separable from the other congeners, H. abdita, H. complicofasciata, H. falcata, H. japanica and H. leucoperiptera, by a combination of vertebral counts, morphometric characters, and juvenile colouration (White et al. 2009).

This species has been confused with its congener the Japanese Wobbegong (Orectolobus japonicus). Species referred to as Orectolobus japonicus are likely a complex of Western Indian Ocean species including this species and the complex requires further taxonomic work (Last et al. 2010a, Last et al. 2010b).
Previously confused with Boeseman's Skate (Okamejei boesemani) which shares similar colouration to the Borneo Sand Skate (O. cairae) but differs in morphology (Last et al. 2010a).
The species is distinguished from Philippine Guitarfish (Rhinobatos whitei) and Goldeneye Guitarfish (R. sainsbury) by colour, morphology, and meristic characters (White et al. 2016).

The species is distinguished from its regional congeners, the Bengal Guitarfish (Rhinobatos annandalei) and Smoothback Guitarfish (R. lionatus) by colour, morphology, and meristic characters (Last et al. 2019).

Silfvergrip (2009) described the diagnostic features of A. japonica greater than 200 mm total length (TL). These include a plain colouration, with no distinct markings, and a total number of vertebrae between 112–119. Dorsal fin anterior margin is 8.5–9.5% of TL, in advance of anus. The mouth is small, about one fourth of head length, and distance from anus to end of tail is 5.6–6.0 times longer than distance from anus to dorsal fin insertion.

It is thought that there are at least four different subpopulations of A. marmorata based on morphological and genetic characters, in the North Pacific, South Pacific, Indian Ocean and Micronesia (Minegishi et al. 2008, Watanabe et al. 2009). Although, some studies using genetics have identified five (Ishikawa et al. 2004). Watanabe et al. (2008) suggested that total number of vertebrae indicated four morphological groups, but five different subpopulations in the North Pacific, South Pacific, Indian Ocean, Micronesia and Tahiti. Anguilla marmorata is thought to have between 100-110 vertebrae and can reach up to 2 m in length.

This species of shortfin eel has been proposed to have two subpopulations: one is described as the subspecies Anguilla bicolor bicolor (McClelland 1844), found in the Indian Ocean from the east coast of Africa to northwestern Australia and greater Sundaland; while the other, described as the subspecies Anguilla bicolor pacifica, is found in the West Indo-Pacific from southern China, Philippines and the Indonesian islands of Borneo, Sulawesi and New Guinea (Schmidt 1923). The two subpopulations are considered synonyms of A. bicolor here, though this observed intraspecific variation is noted for the purposes of regionally specific conservation planning for the two subpopulations in the Indian Ocean and West Indo-Pacific.

From a study conducted across the Indonesian archipelago, these proposed subpopulations were found to share many morphological similarities but significant differences in geographic distribution (Sugeha and Suharti 2008). It has been suggested that the two subpopulations share no overlapping continental range (Fahmi 2013). However, A. bicolor from the Indian Ocean has been identified in Malaysia using both morphological and molecular techniques (Arai et al. 2012a, 2015; Hamzah et al. 2015, Arai and Wong 2016, Arai and Kadir 2017b). More recently A. bicolor from the Indo-pacific has been found to recruit to the Indonesian islands of Java and Sumatera (Sugeha 2019 unpub. data). These indicate an overlap of ranges of the subpopulations. This, as well as almost identical morphological characteristics, suggests molecular techniques are the only fail-safe way to identify the subpopulations (Tanaka et al. 2014, Arai et al. 2015).

Anguilla bicolor is olive to dark bluish-brown dorsally and lighter ventrally from the jaw to the anus. Its dorsal fin soft rays number 240–250 and its anal fin soft rays, 200–220. This species typically has between 103 to 115 vertebrae (Ege 1939, Silfvergrip 2009). It is most easily confused with Anguilla obscura (and its distribution overlaps with this species in New Guinea). It can only be reliably separated from A. obscura by vertebral count (102–108 for A. obscura) (Ege 1939) and/or genetic analyses (Watanabe et al. 2004).

Anguilla mossambica is olive to greyish black dorsally and lighter ventrally, with the caudal fin confluent with the dorsal and anal fin (Froese and Pauly 2011). It has been suggested that this species and A. borneensis could be basal species of the genus (Aoyama et al. 2001, Minegishi et al. 2005, Fahmi 2015).

The morphological characteristics, ecology and distribution of A. celebesensis overlap broadly with those of both A. interioris and A. luzonensis making taxonomic distinction difficult in situ. The main difference is the ano-dorsal length which is measured as a percentage of the total length (TL) of the eel. In A. celebesensis, this value is between 6.0–11.9 according to Aoyama et al. (2000). The ADL/%TL of A. celebesensis has been found to overlap with other tropical anguillid species including A. interioris, A. marmorata, A. borneensis, A. bengalensis and A. obscura based on both morphology and genetic analyses (Sugeha et al. 2006b). Sugeha (2010) reported the range of total vertebrae and ano-dorsal vertebrae of this species found in Central Sulawesi (Indonesia) were 100–106 (Mean±SD = 102.86 ± 1.13) and 6–13 (9.48 ± 1.11), respectively. Further, ADL/%TL of the species was 6.00–17.65 with an average of 10.41 (SD = 1.61) (Sugeha 2010).

DNA sequencing has indicated admixture between A. megastoma and A. marmorata in some individuals from Vanuatu (Schabetsberger et al. 2015), American Samoa, and Bougainville (Gubili et al. 2018), and further observations of intermediate dentition suggests hybridisation (Schabetsberger et al. 2017). Samples collected from various expeditions across the Indo-Pacific also revealed another hybrid between A. megastoma and A. obscura (Barth et al. 2019).

The skin is grey to yellowish and more or less spotted with brown or black. It can be sometimes uniformly brownish red on the flanks and the back. The belly is white. Young specimens are grey and do not have spots. This species is also characterised by having 108–114 vertebrae (Smith 1999, Watanabe et al. 2011, Froese and Pauly 2012, Hewavitharane et al. 2017). Hewavitharane et al. (2017) found anodorsal ratios of A. megastoma and A. marmorata do not overlap, with values for anodorsal length (measured as a percentage of the total length) ranging between 8.2–12% and 14–17%, respectively, suggesting this is the only external morphological character that can distinguish these species.

Wanatabe et al. (2011) suggested A. megastoma may be separated into two subpopulations, eastern and western, within the western South Pacific due to statistically significant total vertebrae counts. Consistent results found by Hewavitharane et al. (2017) for vertebrae counts, further strengthens this hypothesis. Although Hewavitharane et al. (2017) adds considerably to the sample size supporting this hypothesis, these studies are based on relatively few specimens. Therefore, there is still a possibility this species may consist a single panmictic population in the South Pacific (Schabetsberger et al. 2018).

The Pacific Shortfin Eel, Anguilla obscura, belongs to the group of anguillids which have a short dorsal fin which originates slightly before the anus. This species most closely resembles A. australis and A. bicolor, from which it can be distinguished with certainty only by the number of vertebrae of which A. obscura typically has between 102 and 108. At the glass eel stage, this species can be potentially be distinguished from geographically overlapping A. marmorata and A. megastoma through caudal fin pigmentation, as distinctive patterns allow differentiation (Hewavitharane et al. 2017).

Anguilla interioris is generally considered to be most similar in appearance to Anguilla celebesensis, Anguilla luzonensis and Anguilla megastoma. The distance between the dorsal fin anterior margin and the anus (ADL) in A. interioris is 12.5–13.5% of total length (TL), whereas for A. celebesensis it is 7.5–10.5% of TL, with all other characteristics being almost equal (Silfvergrip 2009).  There does seem to be regional variation in this, as according to Sugeha (2010), A. interioris glass eel recruiting to the Poso River estuary had an ADL of 14.81–17.65% of TL. Without molecular identification, it is practically impossible to distinguish between specimens of A. interioris from A. celebesensis and A. luzonensis with certainty (Silfvergrip 2009). Differences in caudal fin pigmentation have also been documented between A. interioris and A. celebesensis (Sugeha 2010, Shirotori et al. 2016). This presents a possible diagnostic character, although at yellow eel stage they are unidentifiable. A. interioris can be distinguished from A. megastoma by the number of vertebrae: A. interioris typically has between 100 and 106 vertebrae and A. megastoma, 108–116.

Anguilla borneensis is the only plain-coloured, longfinned eel found in Indonesia. It typically has 103–108 vertebrae (Watanabe et al. 2014) and grows to a maximum length of 80 cm TL. It has been suggested that this species and A. mossambica could be basal species of the genus (Aoyama et al. 2001, Minegishi et al. 2005, Fahmi 2015).

Anguilla luzonensis is morphologically similar to other anguillids A. celebesensis and A. interioris, and so molecular techniques would be required to accurately distinguish this species (Minegishi et al. 2009, Leander et al. 2012). Similar to A. celebesensis, this anguillid eel is characterised by mottled colouration with broad maxillary bands of teeth. The two species cannot be distinguished by morphological differences in predorsal, preanal and trunk length or in number of vertebrae because of their overlapping range. Anguilla luzonensis is reported to have 103–106 vertebrae. It has a predorsal-fin length of 28.6–33.1% of TL; preanal length 39.6–44.8% of TL; preanal length without head length (trunk length) 26.4–31.3% of TL; distance between the verticals through the anus and origin of the dorsal fin 9.3–13.9% of TL; LG 35.5–46.9% of HL; TV 103–107; and AV 40–42. The body is elongate. Body colour when fresh is mottled with yellow, olive green, and dark brown or black. HL is 10.8-15.1% of TL, predorsal length without head length is 15.5–19.7% of TL. A. luzonensis has 61–66 caudal vertebrae (Watanabe et al. 2009).

Anguilla bengalensis has an elongate body and a conical head that is dorsally flattened. It has prominent thick lips and narrow bands of teeth on the jaws and is often difficult to distinguish from Anguilla marmorata. Some intraspecific variation has been observed within A. bengalensis to the extent that some authors (e.g., Ege 1939, Watanabe et al. 2014) refer to two subpopulations: one described as Anguilla bengalensis bengalensis commonly found in countries of the Indian Ocean region; and the other A. bengalensis labiata (African Mottled Eel) which occurs in Eastern Africa and as a vagrant in the Arabian Peninsula. The two subpopulations are considered synonyms of A. bengalensis here, though this observed intraspecific variation is noted for the purposes of regionally specific conservation planning for the two subpopulations in the Indian Ocean and in Africa. Several other regional synonyms for this species are known from specimens in Asia and Africa.

The most important parameter for distinguishing between A. bengalensis and A. marmorata is the distance between the origins of the dorsal fin and the anus (ano-dorsal % of TL). Typically, in A. bengalensis this feature is 10.5–12.5% of the total length, for A. marmorata it is 15.5–16.5% (Silfvergrip 2009). This species has between 106 and 115 vertebrae (Silfvergrip 2009).

Aplochiton marinus was synonymized with A. taeniatus (Fowler 1945, McDowall 1971, McDowall and Nakaya 1987) but Dyer (2000) regards it as a potentially good species. Aló et al. (2013) identified A. marinus unambiguously (100% accuracy) both from the genetic and morphological viewpoints.

Aplochiton taeniatus and A. zebra can easily be confused on the basis of traditional morphological criteria. Unambiguous identification should resource to DNA analyses until more powerful morphological criteria are developed. Findings of Aló et al. (2013) suggested that previously species misidentification might have been widespread in previous studies (Cussac et al. 2004).
This is a recently described species. It was originally placed in the genus Arius. A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including jenkinsii).

This species has probably been misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) fai in the literature (W. White pers. obs). More specimens of both this species and of H. draco from South Africa need to be examined to resolve the taxonomic status of this species. Presently, H. draco is considered a synonym of P. jenkinsii. The South African species had dark spots along the posterior margin of the disc, but this form has also been reported from the Arafura Sea and off Sumatra in Indonesia. It is possible that these may in fact be colour forms of the same species. Examples of specimens with dark spots along the posterior margin of the disc are from the Arafura Sea, Sumatra (Last and Stevens 1994, Fahmi pers. obs. 2007), and from western Sri Lanka (Morón et al. 1998, Manjaji 2004), and the Sulu Sea (B.M. Manjaji-Matsumoto pers. obs. 2002).

Previously, this species included two subspecies: P. o. occidentalis and P. o. sonoriensis. These subspecies are now recognised as separate species: P. occidentalis and P. sonoriensis. The previous entry for P. occidentalis on the IUCN Red List (LR/nt, 1996) does not refer to the current concept of P. occidentalis as that assessment included data for both subspecies, while the current assessment refers only to the population that was previously referred to as P. o. occidentalis.

The Argentinian Pouched Lamprey, classified as Petromyzon macrostomus Burmeister, 1868 was first described in 1867 in De La Plata River, in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and subsequently recorded in several rivers from Patagonia. It was considered a junior synonym of Geotria australis Gray, 1851. The taxonomic status of Geotria from across the “species” range was evaluated using both molecular analysis and examination of morphological characteristics by Riva-Rossi et al. (2020) and Geotria macrostoma (Burmeister, 1868) is now considered a valid species.
Formerly a monotypic genus (containing only U. asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) added five more species to Urogymmus, including U. granulatus.

Concha et al. (2019) synonymised the genus Zearaja with Dipturus based on morphological and molecular analyses, thus assigning species formerly in the genus Zearaja to Dipturus. The species Dipturus chilensis formerly was considered as occurring in both the Southeast Pacific and the Southwest Atlantic. However, Gabbanelli et al. (2018) resurrected Raja brevicaudata Marini, 1933 from Argentina out of synonymy with D. chilensis and Concha et al. (2019) described Dipturus lamillai Concha, Caira, Ebert & Pompert, 2019 as a distinct species from the Falkland Islands (Malvinas), Southwest Atlantic. Therefore, D. chilensis is restricted to the Southeast Pacific, from central Chile to the Strait of Magellan, and references to D. chilensis in the Southwest Atlantic refer either to D. brevicaudatus or D. lamillai.
The Marine Iguana (genus Amblyrhynchus) is a single species, with 11 subspecies after taxonomic revision by Miralles et al. (2017).
The taxonomy of this species remains unresolved and it may prove to be a synonym of the Smallspot Numbfish Narcine maculata (Last et al. 2016).
This species was recently described from 20 specimens and is morphologically similar to Encrasicholina pseudoheteroloba (Hata and Motomura 2020).

This species was recently described and is closely related to T. chefuensis (Günther 1874). There remains some disagreement as to the validity of the genera Thryssa and Thrissina. Kottelat (2013) regarded the genus Thryssa as a new spelling for, and a junior synonym of, Thrissa and gave precedence to Thrissina over simultaneous synonyms Xenengraulis and Scutengraulis. However, Thryssa is regarded as independent of Thrissa by Fricke et al. (2020), and for the sake of stability, the genus Thryssa is retained.
This species was previously identified as Apogon albimaculosus or Foa albimaculosa (Bray 2018).
A similar, yet undescribed species, may replace Ostorhinchus victoriae from Geographe Bay to Shark Bay (Kuiter and Kozawa 2019).

The taxonomy follows the view of the IWC Scientific Committee and the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy which now recognize Right Whales in the North Atlantic, North Pacific and Southern Hemisphere as three distinct species in the genus Eubalaena, namely E. glacialis (North Atlantic Right Whale), E. japonica (North Pacific Right Whale), and E. australis (Southern Right Whale) (IWC 2004), based mainly on the mtDNA phylogenetic findings of Rosenbaum et al. (2000).

The North Atlantic Right Whale was included in previous Red Lists together with the North Pacific Right Whale under the species name E. glacialis (Baillie and Groombridge 1996).

Rice (1998) classified Right Whales in the North Atlantic, North Pacific and Southern Hemisphere as the single species Balaena glacialis, in the genus Balaena along with B. mysticetus, the Bowhead Whale. While not all cetologists accept that the three Right Whale taxa qualify as full biological species, their clear geographical separation means that their treatment as separate taxa for conservation purposes is appropriate.

Rallus longirostris, R. crepitans and R. obsoletus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. longirostris following AOU (2000). Rallus elegans and R. tenuirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. elegans following AOU (2000). Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) included tenuirostris within R. longirostris.

Berardius minimus differs from all of its congeners by having the following unique characters: much smaller body size of physically mature individuals, proportionately shorter beak, and darker body color. Also, within 431 base pairs of mtDNA control region, it can be differentiated from B. bairdii and B. arnuxii at 16 and 22 diagnostic sites, respectively (Yamada et al. 2019).

No subspecies of the Rough-toothed Dolphin (Steno bredanensis) are currently recognized (Committee on Taxonomy 2017). However, based on genetics there is evidence of population structuring, both within and between ocean basins, and even within specific archipelagos (Oremus et al. 2012, Da Silva et al. 2015, Albertson et al. 2016). Analyses of photo-identification and satellite tag data indicate population structuring within the Hawaiian archipelago (Baird et al. 2008, Baird 2016), and similar population structuring has been identified in the Society Islands, French Polynesia, based on photo-identification data (Oremus et al. 2012). It is likely that subpopulation structure exists throughout the species’ range.

Many current publications erroneously attribute the name Steno (Delphinus) bredanensis to G. Cuvier in Lesson (1828), rather than to Lesson (1828) (Smeenk 2018), and this latter attribution is now followed by the Committee on Taxonomy (2020).
Onychoprion aleuticus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna as S. aleutica.
Thalasseus elegans (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Synthliboramphus hypoleucus and S. scrippsi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as S. hypoleucus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sternula balaenarum (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.

Previously considered to also occur in the Northwest Pacific, a separate species that is likely endemic to the Northwest Pacific, that is Squalus formosus, has now been split from S. blainville and S. blainville occurs only in the eastern Atlantic, Mediterranean and Black Sea (White and Iglésias 2013). This species has a historically unstable nomenclature that has confused its identification with other Squalus spp. across its range (Veríssimo et al. 2017).

Originally described by Verrill (1868), this species was at one point considered a synonym of M. alcicornis (Boschma 1948) but was subsequently considered as distinct by the same author (Boschma 1962). Millepora nitida is presently considered a valid species based on morphological (Amaral et al. 2008) and genetic evidence (de Souza et al. 2017). Millepora braziliensis is morphologically very similar to its congener, Millepora nitida - differing only in colony morphology, but not in morphometric traits of the skeleton (Verrill 1868, de Souza et al. 2017).

Recent genetic evidence suggests this species forms a species complex with Millepora complanata, M. alcicornis and M. complanata can only be differentiated morphologically, but not genetically (Ruiz-Ramos et al. 2014).

Originally described by Verrill (1868), Millepora braziliensis is considered a valid species based on morphological (Amaral 2008) and genetic evidence (de Souza et al. 2017). This species is morphologically very similar to its congener, Millepora nitida - differing only in colony morphology, but not in morphometric traits of the skeleton (Verrill 1868, de Souza et al. 2017).

Millepora striata was synonymized under M. squarrosa by Boschma (1948), but subsequent work based on morphometric analysis of dactylopore size and density shows that M. striata is distinguishable from the other Caribbean milleporids based on morphology (de Weerdt 1984). Genetic data also supports M. striata as being distinct from M. squarrosa and the M. alcicornis–M. complanata complex (Ruiz-Ramos et al. 2014).
The synonyms for this species require further examination.
This species has long been confused in Australia with Plectorhinchus schotaf (Forsskål 1775).
This species was treated as a synonym of Pomadasys argenteus (Forsskål 1775) by Bauchot et al. (1983), but valid as P. auritus according to McKay (2001) and Parenti (2019).
This species was recently described as distinct from Scolopsis taenioptera (Nakamura et al. 2019).
This species was recently described as distinct from Scolopsis taenioptera (Nakamura et al. 2018); it has previously been reported under this name in Australia.
Three allopatric species in the Scolopsis taenioptera complex are now recognized (Nakamura et al. 2018, 2019).
This species has been split from Gymnura micra and is morphologically similar but can be distinguished on the basis of clasper morphology and disc shape (Yokota and de Carvalho 2017).
Monotypic.
This new species was split from Hypanus americanus (Petean et al. 2020)
Charadrius alexandrinus, C. dealbatus and C. nivosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. alexandrinus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

McGuire et al. (2019) review in detail the status of the all-white taxon occidentalis, which although formerly given species status (‘Great White Heron’ [GWH]) has long been considered a subspecies of Great Blue Heron [GBH] Ardea herodias, in great part because the two taxa interbreed with regularity. However, given that the evidence points to assortative mating where possible, they conclude that occidentalis is indeed better treated as a species.

It is separated by diagnostic plumage (white vs. blue), behavior (mate choice and timing of mating) and habitat (saltwater-island vs. fresh/brackish water mainland).

There are, in fact, a few additional morphological considerations, with GWH having a shorter occipital plume but longer bill, tarsus and middle toe than GBH (supplementary material online with measurements not accessed). Applying the Tobias criteria to the situation, the taxonomic status of GWH involves a consideration of its

·       all-white vs grey/blue plumage (an exceptional difference: score 4);
·       shorter occipital plume (seemingly fairly distinctive from the authors’ Figure 3: allow 1);
·       longer tarsus (apparently the most distinctive of the longer characters measured, but perhaps insufficient to be allowed a score: ns);
·       timing of mating or habitat choice (only one of these permitted as a score: 1);
·       narrow hybrid zone (not more than 50 km as measured on Google Earth: 2).

On this basis BirdLife accepts Ardea occidentalis (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) as a separate species.

McGuire et al. (2019) review in detail the status of the all-white taxon occidentalis, which although formerly given species status (‘Great White Heron’ [GWH]) has long been considered a subspecies of Great Blue Heron [GBH] Ardea herodias, in great part because the two taxa interbreed with regularity. However, given that the evidence points to assortative mating where possible, they conclude that occidentalis is indeed better treated as a species:

it is separated by diagnostic plumage (white vs. blue), behaviour (mate choice and timing of mating) and habitat (saltwater-island vs. fresh/brackish water mainland).

There are, in fact, a few additional morphological considerations, with GWH having a shorter occipital plume but longer bill, tarsus and middle toe than GBH (supplementary material online with measurements not accessed). Applying the Tobias criteria to the situation, the taxonomic status of GWH involves a consideration of its

·       all-white vs grey/blue plumage (an exceptional difference: score 4);
·       shorter occipital plume (seemingly fairly distinctive from the authors’ Figure 3: allow 1);
·       longer tarsus (apparently the most distinctive of the longer characters measured, but perhaps insufficient to be allowed a score: ns);
·       timing of mating or habitat choice (only one of these permitted as a score: 1);
·       narrow hybrid zone (not more than 50 km as measured on Google Earth: 2).

On this basis BirdLife accepts Ardea occidentalis (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) as a separate species.
Microcarbo coronatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Phalacrocorax.
Ardea intermedia, A. brachyrhyncha and A. plumifera (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Mesophoyx and lumped as M. intermedia following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

A stranded Mesoplodon in Sri Lanka in 1963 was identified as new to science and named M. hotaula Deraniyagala (1963a, b). However, few details were provided on how it was distinguishable from other species of Mesoplodon. Two years later, Moore and Gilmore (1965) synonymized M. hotaula with the very similar M. ginkgodens. Dalebout et al. (2014) showed through genetic analyses and morphological comparisons (mainly skull) that M. hotaula was separable from M. ginkgodens and a valid species. They are, however, sister taxa.

So far, there have been six genetic studies undertaken on rockhopper penguins using different genetic technics and analysis (Banks et al. 2006; Jouventin et al. 2006; de Dinechin et al. 2009, Frugone et al. 2018, Mays et al. 2019, Lois et al. 2020). Jouventin et al. (2006) found only significant genetic differentiation between the northern and southern/ eastern populations. However, Banks et al. (2006) identified three species, and proposed a further split of E. chrysocome into southern (E. chrysocome) and eastern (E. filholi) ‘species’. This was not adopted by BirdLife International on the grounds of small sample sizes and limited morphological differences between the southern and eastern forms (BirdLife International 2008). However, further research by de Dinechin et al. (2009) also supported the split of chrysocome and filholi.
Recently, Frugone et al. (2018) analyzed two mtDNA (HVRI, COI) and two nuclear (ODC, AK1) markers from 13 locations of five putative Eudyptes species: rockhopper (E. filholi, E. chrysocome, and E. moseleyi), macaroni (E. chrysolophus) and royal penguins (E. schlegeli). They found a strong phylogeographic structure among rockhopper penguins from South America, subantarctic and subtropical islands supporting the recognition of three separate species of rockhopper penguins. Mays et al. (2019), on the other hand, using similar markers but different modelling also found genetic structure and low genetic flow, but in his analyses the best-supported population models for the southern rockhoppers combined E. c. chrysocome and E. c. filholi into a single lineage or 2 lineages with bidirectional gene flow, and thus proposed that they should be treated as different management units only. Lois et al. (2020) added new information on the southern rockhopper (E. c. chrysocome) from the southwest Atlantic Ocean. Studying the genetic structure of individuals from different colonies located in the southwest Atlantic they found evidence for two genetic clusters within the rockhopper, one northern (Falkland/ Malvinas Islands and Isla Pingüino) and one southern (Terhalten and Staten Island).
This species is newly described from old preserved material (Moore et al. 2020).
This newly-described species that can be distinguished from its congeners in having a smaller second dorsal fin and smaller eyes (Hsu et al. 2020).
Previously a junior synonym of the Striped Panray (Zanobatus schoenleinii), this species has larger thorns on the upper disc and a more heavily spotted disc (Last et al. 2016).

Recent phylogenetic analyses have shown that the species shows little genetic divergence from Royal Penguin populations (Frugone et al. 2018; 2019), suggesting that a reappraisal of the taxonomic status is needed.
This species concept has been revised to incorporate the taxonomic revision of Psammobatis parvacauda (Mabraganã et al. 2020)
Raja parva was split from Raja miraletus in 2016 (Last and Séret 2016).

The Argentinian Pouched Lamprey, classified as Petromyzon macrostomus Burmeister, 1868 was first described in 1867 in De La Plata River, in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and subsequently recorded in several rivers from Patagonia. It was considered a junior synonym of Geotria australis Gray, 1851. The taxonomic status of Geotria from across the “species” range was evaluated using both molecular analysis and examination of morphological characteristics by Riva-Rossi et al. (2020) and Geotria macrostoma (Burmeister, 1868) is now considered a valid species.
Cinclodes antarcticus and C. maculirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. antarcticus following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
There is some genetic evidence that suggests there is a cryptic species in the Red Sea (K. Yan Ma pers. comm. 2016).

authority: S. B. Johnson, Young, Jones, Warén & Vrijenhoek, 2006

taxonomicNotes: The species can be distinguished from the similar regional congener, the Shovelnose Guitarfish (Pseudobatos productus) by a narrower disc width and shorter distance between nostril and disc margin (Rutledge et al. 2019).
Bahaba polykladiskos should be classified under the genus Boesemania (N.L. Chao in prep. 2019).
This species has been confused with other Johnius species.
This species is often confused with other Johnius spp. (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2016).

Some researchers have suggested that Baird’s and Arnoux’s Beaked Whales are members of the same species (see Kasuya 2009), but the lack of known morphological differences may simply be due to the small number of measured specimens (especially for Arnoux’s Beaked Whale). Analysis of mitochondrial and nuclear intron sequence data has however revealed multiple fixed genetic differences, confirming that these species are reproductively isolated and valid taxonomic entities (Dalebout 2002, 2004). The species name has frequently been misspelled arnouxi or arnuxi. However, the generic and specific name given by Duvernoy (1851) was Berardius arnuxii. The type specimen was collected during the exploring voyage of the French corvette Rhin while in New Zealand. Berardius is from the name of the Le Rhin’s captain Auguste Bérard and the arnuxii is from the ship’s surgeon M. Arnoux who collected the specimen near Akaroa, New Zealand and presented the skull to the Paris Museum of Natural History in 1846. Unfortunately, Duvernoy misspelled the species name, omitting the 'o'.

This recently described species can be distinguished from the regional congener the Yellowspotted Skate (Leucoraja wallacei) by its elongated snout and a dorsal surface pattern of a single ocelli at the mid-base of each pectoral fin, paired small white spots, and no banding on its tail (Ebert and Leslie 2019).

The newly described species differs from congeneric North Pacific species (S. mitsukurii and S. japonicus) in having fewer vertebrae, larger dorsal fin bases with a shorter interdorsal space, and a more posterior origin of the pelvic fins (Dolganov 2019, Viana and Carvalho 2020).

This recently described species is distinguished by a lack of mid-dorsal thorns, three pairs of white blotches on the dorsal disc surface, and dark bands on the mid-ventral line of the tail (Misawa et al. 2020).

Milvus aegyptius (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) has been split from Black Kite Milvus migrans (del Hoyo et al. 2014)

Yellow-billed Kite Milvus aegyptius (with subspecies parasitus) differs from M. migrans by its
·       Yellow vs black bill (3);
·       Dark vs pale iris in adult state (2);
·       Head and nape concolorous with upper body vs pale grey streaked black, contrasting with dark brown mantle (2);
·       Finer black streaking below (ns[2])
·       Wing (from BWP2) male 423 (7.6; n9) vs 447 (10.5; n15), effect size 2.62 (2).

Some Arabian birds (treated as arabicus in some places but synonymised with aegyptius in the Checklist) show some features of migrans (Forsman 2016).

The genus Pycnopodia is monophyletic, and Pycnopodia helianthoides is the only species in the genus. Pycnopodia helianthoides is one of only two species in the sub-family Pycnopodiinae, the other is Lysastrosoma anthosticta from Japan (Accessed through: WoRMS, World Register of Marine Species at: http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=240764 on 2020-08-04).
This species is classified in Lilliconus.

In the past, there has been confusion arising from the use of the names D. acuta and D. elopsoides. Records of D. acuta in the eastern Mediterranean may refer instead to D. elopsoides (Whitehead 1985). However, this confusion has since been resolved (H. Hata pers. comm. 2017).


Additionally, Dussumieria albulina (Fowler 1934) was formerly regarded as a junior synonym of Dussumieria acuta Valenciennes 1847 but is now regarded as a valid species and is redescribed based on morphological characters (e.g. lacking parasphenoid teeth, higher gill raker counts, slender body, presence of melanophores on mid-part of pectoral fin) and mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase I (COI) gene analysis (Hata et al. 2020). All previous accounts of this nominal species (D. acuta) from Indonesia and the Philippines refers to the newly redescribed D. albulina. For the purposes of this Red List Assessment, D. acuta is distributed along the Eurasian Continent from the Persian Gulf to the Chinese coast and D. albulina is distributed from India, Indonesia, and the Philippines. These two species occur sympatrically in the eastern Indian Ocean from the southern coast of India to Singapore (Hata et al. 2020).

Dussumieria albulina (Fowler 1934) was formerly regarded as a junior synonym of D. acuta Valenciennes 1847. Hata et al. (2020) redescribed D. abulina based on morphological characters (e.g. lacking parasphenoid teeth, higher gill raker counts, slender body, presence of melanophores on mid-part of pectoral fin) and mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase I (COI) gene analysis, validating it as a separate species. All previous accounts of the nominal species, D. acuta from Indonesia and the Philippines refers to this newly redescribed species (D. albulina). For the purposes of this Red List Assessment, D. acuta is distributed along the Eurasian Continent from the Persian Gulf to the Chinese coast and D. albulina is distributed from India, Indonesia, and the Philippines. These two species occur sympatrically in the eastern Indian Ocean from the southern coast of India to Singapore (Hata et al. 2020).

The newly described Hemiscyllium michaeli Allen & Dudgeon, 2010 has been split from H. freycineti. As such, H. freycineti is now considered to be restricted to western New Guinea, whereas H. michaeli occurs in eastern New Guinea (Allen et al. 2016).

Hemiscyllium galei was recently described as a separate species by Allen and Erdmann (2008). It was previously confused with the Indonesian Speckled Carpet Shark (H. freycineti), which is apparently restricted to West Papua Province (far western New Guinea), Indonesia. The two species differ primarily in colour pattern, which provides the best means of separating the various members of the genus. Phylogenetic analysis with mitochondrial DNA (ND4) also clearly separates H. galei from other hemiscyllid species including H. freycineti.

Henry’s Epaulette Shark (Hemiscyllium henryi) is most similar to the Epaulette Shark (H. ocellatum) which has previously been thought to exist in Papua New Guinea, but likely is not found there. The latter species is most likely restricted to Australian waters (Allen and Erdmann 2008). Colour pattern features and DNA analysis provide the best means of separation between the two species.

Michael’s Epaulette Shark (Hemiscyllium michaeli) has recently been described as a new species (Allen and Dudgeon 2010). It was previously confused with the Indonesian Speckled Carpet Shark (H. freycineti) (Compagno 2002) which is apparently restricted to West Papua Province (far western New Guinea), Indonesia. The two species differ primarily in colour pattern which provides the best means of separating the various members of the genus. Phylogenetic analysis with mitochondrial DNA (ND4) also clearly separates the two species (Allen and Dudgeon 2010).

authority: C. Chen, Linse, Roterman, Copley & Rogers, 2015

taxonomicNotes:
Concha et al. (2019) synonymised the genus Zearaja with Dipturus based on morphological and molecular analyses, thus assigning species formerly in the genus Zearaja to Dipturus.

The species Dipturus chilensis was formerly considered occurring in both the Southeast Pacific and the Southwest Atlantic. However, Gabbanelli et al. (2018) resurrected Raja brevicaudata Marini, 1933 from Argentina out of synonymy with D. chilensis and Concha et al. (2019) described Dipturus lamillai Concha, Caira, Ebert & Pompert, 2019 as a distinct species from the Falkland Islands (Malvinas), Southwest Atlantic. Therefore, D. chilensis is restricted to the Southeast Pacific, from central Chile to the Strait of Magellan, and references to D. chilensis in the Southwest Atlantic refer either to D. brevicaudatus or D. lamillai.

Until recently, two species were recognised in the genus Delphinus: the Short-beaked Common Dolphin (D. delphis) and the Long-beaked Common Dolphin (D. capensis), as described by Heyning and Perrin (1994). The morphological differences between D. delphis and D. capensis in the North Pacific (Heyning and Perrin 1994) were supported by molecular evidence from both mitochondrial and nuclear markers (Rosel et al. 1994). However, the genus exhibits a great deal of morphological variation globally and the criteria used to distinguish between the two species in the North Pacific appear not to apply elsewhere (Best 2007). In South Africa, Samaai et al. (2005) found that based on skull morphology the majority of specimens belonged to D. capensis, however two specimens were within the range for D. delphis from the North Pacific, and a third specimen fell between the ranges for D. delphis and D. capensis (Samaai et al. 2005). The same molecular markers that were used to differentiate the two sympatric species in the North Pacific failed to reveal any genetic distinction between the described morphotypes in South Africa (Best 2007).

Subsequently, Cunha et al. (2015), in a global analysis of Delphinus which included nine specimens from the west coast of South Africa (eastern South Atlantic), concluded that all specimens analysed from the Atlantic Ocean belonged to D. delphis, and that D. capensis was not a genetically valid species.

In 2016 the Society for Marine Mammalogy Committee on Taxonomy removed Delphinus capensis from its accepted list of marine mammal species and now recognises all Common Dolphins globally as belonging to a single species, Delphinus delphis (Committee on Taxonomy 2020). It recognises the following subspecies:

  • D. d. delphis Linnaeus, 1758. Common Dolphin
  • D. d. bairdii Dall, 1873. Eastern North Pacific Long-beaked Common Dolphin
  • D. d. ponticus Barabash, 1935. Black Sea Common Dolphin
  • D. d. tropicalis van Bree, 1971. Indo-Pacific Common Dolphin


Cunha et al. (2015) noted that because the sympatric or parapatric Long-beaked and Short-beaked Common Dolphins off California in the eastern North Pacific appear not to interbreed, the Long-beaked Common Dolphins might eventually be described and recognised as a separate species, D. bairdii. Some researchers have considered the Long-beaked Common Dolphins in the Indo-Pacific, which has an exceptionally long beak, to constitute a separate species, D. tropicalis (Van Bree and Gallagher 1978; Rice 1998). However, another morphometric study concluded that that form should be considered a subspecies (Jefferson and Van Waerebeek 2002) and it is currently recognised as such, D. delphis tropicalis.

The non-concordance of morphological and genetic data for Common Dolphins has caused much confusion and a rigorous global taxonomic study of the genus is needed. Further phylogenetic analyses are necessary to resolve the controversies surrounding the classification and nomenclature. More changes to Delphinus taxonomy should be expected.
This species is closely related to Ostorhinchus holotaenia (Motomura et al. 2015) and comprises a species complex (Liu and Dai 2012).
Until Bathyraja cousseauae was described recently, this was often identified as B. brachyurops.
This species was previously mistaken for the similar Bathyraja brachyurops (Díaz de Astarloa and Mabragaña 2004) and reported elsewhere as Bathyraja sp. (J. Pompert pers. comm).

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted; a revision is underway with the Ph.D. thesis of Jimena San Martin.

This recently described species can be distinguished from its most closely-related regional congener, the Mangrove Whipray (Urogymnus granulatus) by a more angular snout, no white flecks on the dorsal surface, a uniformly white ventral surface with no broad black margin, and a longer tail (Last et al. 2016a).
Trimma caesiura belongs to a species complex (Winterbottom and Villa 2003).
Easily confused with the Southern Eagle Ray (Myliobatis goodei) (Last et al. 2016).

The Whitespotted Eagle Ray (Aetobatus narinari) (Euphrasen 1790) was originally restricted to the Western Central and Southwest Atlantic (Sales et al. 2019) but the range now also extends to the eastern Atlantic (Fricke et al. 2020).

Torpedo peruana Chirichigno, 1963 is tentatively recognised as a synonym of Tetronarce tremens (de Buen, 1959) (Carvalho et al. 2002). Torpedo microdiscus is also now included as a synonym of T. tremens (Carvalho et al. 2016).
Crassinarke dormitor is now included as a synonym of Narke japonica (Compagno and Heemstra 2007, Carvalho et al. 2016).

Based on the currently available evidence, the HBW & BirdLife Checklist treats Little Penguin as a single monotypic species. A series of peer-reviewed papers identified two genetically distinct clades, one restricted to New Zealand, and another comprising birds from Australia and New Zealand's southeast (Otago) (Banks et al. 2002; Grosser et al. 2015, 2016; Peuker et al. 2009 and Tavares and Baker 2008). A multivariate skeletal analysis further revealed osteological differentiation between the New Zealand and Australian clades (Grosser et al. 2017). In contrast, studies based on vocalisation (Miyazaki & Nakagawa 2015) and two conference abstracts on plumage colour (Macey et al. 2015) and mating (Clark et al. 2015) were inconclusive to distinguish the two lineages due to small sample size. In addition, an unpublished report (Boesman unpublished) found no support for strong vocal differences between the clades but it was also inconclusive based on a limited sample size of 6 recordings. While genetic evidence for two clades is well documented and accepted by the scientific community, there is an overall lack of data on acoustics, plumage, geographic relationship, behaviour and ecology on many colonies to deliver taxonomic decisions with objectivity, consistency and transparency as proposed by the Tobias criteria (Tobias et al. 2010). Therefore, a move to split the clades as two species appears premature, requiring further biological work to assess whether genetic differences between populations are supported by taxonomically meaningful phenotypic differences as suggested by Mattern & Wilson (2018).

The Common Blue Skate (Dipturus batis) and Flapper Skate (Dipturus intermedius) were synonymised in a taxonomic revision of European skates (Rajidae) in the 1920s (Clark 1926), before being recognised again as separate species in 2010 (Iglésias et al. 2010). Consequently, information for both species were reported as ‘Dipturus batis’ (the 'common skate complex') for much of the 20th and early 21st centuries.
Circus spilonotus and C. spilothorax (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. spilonotus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Records of this species off Argentina refer to Mustelus schmitti.
This species was redescribed by Winterbottom (2016) and Trimma caudomaculatum was resurrected from synonymy under T. tevegae.
This species was previously included as a synonym of Trimma tevegae (Winterbottom 2016).
This species is most similar to Trimma erdmanni (Allen 2015).
This species can be confused with Trimma preclarum as both species occur in the Palau Islands.
This species was originally described as T. lutea, but as Trimma is neuter, it should be T. luteum.
A wider geographic sampling of tissues is needed to resolve taxonomic uncertainty and the extent of the distribution (Winterbottom et al. 2015).
In the past, this species has been confused with Trimma caudomaculatum and T. tevegae, neither of which occurs in the Red Sea.
Falco peregrinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as F. peregrinus and F. pelegrinoides following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Larus argentatus and L. smithsonianus (the latter including vegae and mongolicus) (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. argentatus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Black Kite Milvus migrans (del Hoyo et al. 2014) has been split into M. migrans and Yellow-billed Kite M. aegyptius (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020). 

Yellow-billed Kite Milvus aegyptius (with subspecies parasitus) differs from M. migrans by its
• Yellow vs black bill (3);
• Dark vs pale iris in adult state (2);
• Head and nape concolorous with upper body vs pale grey streaked black, contrasting with dark brown mantle (2);
• Finer black streaking below (ns[2])
• Wing (from BWP2) male 423 (7.6; n9) vs 447 (10.5; n15), effect size 2.62 (2).

Some Arabian birds (treated as arabicus in some places but synonymised with aegyptius in the Checklist) show some features of migrans (Forsman 2016).

authority: Barbosa du Bocage & de Brito Capello, 1864

taxonomicNotes: Prior to 2018, the literature referred to this species as Squalus mitsukurii or S. cf. mitsukurii. Further, this species is sometimes confused with Squalus cubensis and may be confused with recently described or undescribed species in the South Atlantic (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020). Prior western Atlantic records of Squalus blainville may refer to this species (Kiraly et al. 2003, Pfleger et al. 2018), however eastern records of S. blainville represent a different species (Pfleger et al. 2018). Old records of S. acanthias in the Gulf of Mexico (and its junior synonyms S. fernandinus and S. barbouri) likely refer to this species (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020).

This species has been split from Gymnura micrura and is morphologically similar but can be distinguished on the basis of internal diagnostic characters such as the contour of the hyomandibula (Yokota and de Carvalho 2017).

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a). Reports of G. obtusus from South Africa are considered invalid and based on other species (Compagno and Last 1999).

The type specimen, lodged in the Museum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, has been examined by one of the assessors (P. Last) and is readily distinguished from the single congener (Sympterichthys moultoni) by absence of dermal spinules on illicium, meristic counts, and elongated second spine of dorsal fin; and from all other known handfish species by the combination of skin surface with covering of spiny scales, thin illicium of medium length, relatively deep body, 9 pectoral-fin rays, 9 anal-fin rays, and 22 vertebrae (Last and Gledhill 2009). Although the holotype was somewhat damaged and the number of specimens limited for both species within this genus, there is no taxonomic uncertainty. In addition to distinct morphometric and meristic differences, distributional disjunction frequently occurs within this group in particular (P. Last pers. comm. 2019).
This species was previously identified as Trimma okinawae (Winterbottom 2021).

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).
This species has been confused with Trimma chledophilum.
This species may occur more widely in the Western Pacific (Winterbottom 2019) but further genetics work is needed.

This species was reported with some uncertainty as occurring at Ilo-ilo in the Philippines by Naves and Fernandes Villar (Prain 1905), but was excluded from occurring in the Philippines by Merrill (1910).

Rice’s Whale (Balaenoptera ricei) is a distinct evolutionary lineage closely related to Eden’s Whale (Balaenoptera edeni edeni), Bryde’s Whale (B. e. brydei) and Sei Whale (Balaenoptera borealis) (Rosel et al. 2021). Previously considered an undescribed subspecies of Balaenoptera edeni and referred to as the Gulf of Mexico Whale or the Gulf of Mexico Bryde’s Whale, a recent morphological study of Rice’s Whale has revealed diagnostic differences in the shape and size of bones in the skull in comparison to the two subspecies of B. edeni. This morphological evidence reinforced earlier findings of significant genetic divergence and fixed DNA differences found in several mitochondrial DNA genes; together, these data supported the description of the new species B. ricei. With elevation of Rice’s Whale to species status, there is still uncertainty as to whether Eden’s Whale and Bryde’s Whale, each of which is clearly distinct, represent subspecies of B. edeni or full species.

The Catalog of Fishes online database (accessed March 2022) places this species in the genus Callionymus without justification. The genus Repomucenus is retained here based on published work by Nakabo (2002; 2013), Sonoyama et al. (2020) and Kim et al. (2021).

Before 2021, this species was thought to occur in the North Atlantic and in warm-temperate waters of the Southern Hemisphere, with a gap in its distribution in tropical waters; it was the only beaked whale species thought to have an anti-tropical distribution. The Southern Hemisphere population was recently described as a new species (Carroll et al. 2021), and M. mirus is now considered to be limited to the North Atlantic.
Monotypic.

The genus Scoliodon, represented by S. laticaudus, was previously considered monotypic but now consists of three species with S. macrorhynchus resurrected from the junior synonym of S. laticaudus (White et al. 2010).
There are no taxonomic concerns with relevance to the validity of the species and no taxonomic revisions underway.
