There are no taxonomic concerns relating to the validity of this species. It is considered valid according to the World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS) database (accessed October 2021).

This species is considered valid based on morphological (Amaral et al. 2008) and genetic evidence (Souza et al. 2017, Arrigoni et al. 2018, Boissin et al. 2020). Genetic diversity was very low compared to other milleporids from the same biogeographic region, with all nine specimens analyzed being genetically identical for the locus studied (16S) (Souza et al. 2017).

This newly-described species can be distinguished from the sympatric Sculpted Lanternshark (Etmopterus sculptus) by an indistinct colour gradation between the flank and abdomen compared to a sharp demarcation, a V-shaped arrangement of ampullae on the ventral snout compared to a U-shaped arrangement, and dorsal fins densely covered with dermal denticles compared to sparse or mostly bare dorsal fins (Ebert et al. 2021a).

This newly-described species can be distinguished from its most closely related congener, the Arabian Smoothhound (M. mosis), by its subdivided palatoquadrate compared to an undivided palatoquadrate and shorter labial furrows that are also shorter than the lower labial furrows (White et al. 2021).
This newly-described species is the only Notoraja species known from the western Indian Ocean and is an intense, dark blue colour (Weigmann et al. 2021).

For more than 100 years, Raja arctowskii (Dollo, 1904) was known only from three empty egg capsules; the species remained undescribed due to the lack of specimens that could be assigned to those capsules. In 2021, after trawled egg capsules and an egg capsule containing a near-term embryo became available, a full description of this species was published by Stehmann et al. (2021), placing the species in the genus Bathyraja.

This newly-described species is distinguished from its congeners by the combination of a massive head with short snout, stocky and relatively long trunk, short tail, and long pelvic fin anterior margin (Iglésias et al. 2022).

Prior to the recent species description, this species previously included Neotrygon kuhlii (Last et al. 2016a). The Neotrygon genus has recently been split and currently includes at least 11 species. It is difficult to distinguish some members of the genus based solely on morphology, thus the true distribution and overlap of species is not currently known. More work is required to fully understand where each member of the Neotrygon genus occurs.

Previously misidentified as Neotrygon kuhlii, Last et al. (2016a) resurrected Neotrygon varidens as the valid name for this ray. The Neotrygon genus has recently been split and currently includes at least 11 species. It is difficult to distinguish some members of the genus based solely on morphology, thus the true distribution and overlap of species is not currently known. More work is required to fully understand where each member of the Neotrygon genus occurs.

A study using allozymes as a genetic marker (Eitner 1995) indicated that an unrecognized fourth species of Alopias may exist, however this claim was based on data from a single shark specimen likely to have been A. vulpinus. Recent work investigating population structure of all three Alopias species using mitochondrial DNA control region sequences (Trejo 2005) has found no evidence indicating that a fourth species of thresher sharks exists.

Based on morphological observations, Zlatarski and Estalella (1982), Bouchon and Laborel (1986) and Fenner (1993) concluded that Colpophyllia breviserialis should not be treated as a valid species separate from C. natans but it is considered valid according to Reyes et al. (2010) and the WoRMS online database (accessed February 2022). According to Spathias (2017), a taxonomic revision of the Colpophyllia genus that is underway is intended to resolve the uncertain status of C. breviserialis.
Porites bernardi Gravier, 1909 is a synonym of P. gabonensis Gravier, 1910. Porites bernardi Vaughan, 1907 is an unknown species (WoRMS accessed January 2022, B. Hoeksema pers. comm. 2022).

Subspecies status formerly suggested for mainland and Japanese breeding populations, based on differences in vocalization patterns; some variation between these populations in morphology, coloration and egg size, but preliminary DNA analysis has shown no significant genetic distinction. Monotypic.

Has frequently been considered a subspecies of H. unicolor or of H. ostralegus; differentiation relatively weak, and species status perhaps questionable. Recent study of mtDNA, however, supported treatment as a separate species (Banks and Paterson 2007). Form H. ostralegus finschi has on occasion been associated with present species. Monotypic.
This species is very similar to Plectranthias lasti and a more detailed examination of additional specimens of both species is needed to clarify their separation (Gill et al. 2021).

This species was previously considered a synonym of Chaetodontoplus chrysocephalus, but is now considered to be valid (Eschmeyer’s Catalog of Fishes online database accessed June 2022). It can be misidentified as the other three closely-related species in the "melanosoma complex", C. dimidiatus, C. melanosoma and C. vanderloosi (Steene and Allen 2004). Some taxonomic issues remain unresolved (Tea et al. 2020). Genetic samples are needed to help clarify the taxonomy.
This species is closely related to Tosanoides filamentosus (Katayama and Masuda 1980).
The genus of this species has also been referred to as Neosynchiropus.
The genus of this species has also been referred to as Neosynchiropus.
The genus of this species has also been referred to as Neosynchiropus.
This species has also been referred to as Synchiropus ijimae or in the genus Neosynchiropus.
This species has also been referred to as Calliurichthys japonicus (Nakabo 2013).
The genus of this species has also been referred to as Minysynchiropus.
The genus of this species has also been referred to as Minysynchiropus.
The genus of this species has also been referred to as Neosynchiropus.

Ho (2015) reported several differences in counts and colouration between the type specimens and tropical southwest Pacific specimens identified as this species and suggested that the latter may be an undescribed species.

McCosker (1978) considered this species to be a synonym of Calloplesiops altivelis, but Conde (1983) considered it to be a valid species. It is valid in the Catalog of Fishes (online database accessed April 2022). Molecular data available in the BOLD online database (accessed May 2022) support C. argus as a valid species in a species complex with C. altivelis. In addition to having numerous fine white spots forming lines on the body and blue stripes distally on the dorsal fin, there are narrow white bars on the upper lip while C. altivelis has white spots on the upper lip (J.T. Williams pers. comm. 2022).
This species is closely related to Plectranthias inermis and a detailed morphological comparison is needed to clarify their separation (Gill et al. 2021).
The genus of this species has also been referred to as Neosynchiropus.
The genus of this species has also been referred to as Neosynchiropus.
The genus of this species has also been referred to as Neosynchiropus.
The genus of this species has also been referred to as Eocallionymus.

According to the Catalog of Fishes, there is high taxonomic uncertainty associated with this species. Fricke (2002) reported this species as incertae sedis or a taxon whose relationship with others is unknown or undecided. Nakabo (1982) also noted that insufficient information was available for this species and it could not be classified.
This species is closely related to Rabaulichthys altipinnis (Masuda and Randall 2001).

Combined morphological and molecular data led Last et al. (2016) and White et al. (2017) to conclude that Mobula eregoodootenkee is a junior synonym of M. kuhlii. However, Hosegood et al. (2019) suggested these were separate species, which was supported by Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. (2020), who also clarified the nomenclature as M. eregoodoo.

Recent revisions of the taxonomy of genus Mobula included the decision to consider the circumglobal Spinetail Devil Ray M. japanica (Müller & Henle, 1841) a junior synonym of the Mediterranean Giant Devil Ray M. mobular (Bonnaterre, 1788), causing M. mobular to become a circumglobal species (Poortvliet et al. 2015, Hosegood et al. 2018, White et al. 2018).

Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. (2020) argued that one of the traits that were used to support the differentiation between the two species, the maximum size of M. mobular purportedly in excess of 5 m disc width (DW), can be explained by past misidentifications of M. birostris, and therefore unsubstantiated. This also supports their recommendation to retain for the species the common name “Spinetail Devil Ray” instead of “Giant Devil Ray”.

The previously monotypic genus Manta was re-evaluated in 2009 with two species identified, Reef Manta Ray (Manta alfredi) and Oceanic Manta Ray (Manta birostris) (Marshall et al. 2009). Genetic evidence supported the separation (Kashiwagi et al. 2012). Both species have broad global distributions and are sympatric in some locations and allopatric in others (Kashiwagi et al. 2011, Lawson et al. 2017). A third species of manta ray has also been proposed (Marshall et al. 2009) with increasing genetic support (Hinojosa-Alvarez et al. 2016, Kashiwagi et al. 2017, Hosegood et al. 2018). Genetic evidence has also resulted in the genus Manta being subsumed within the genus Mobula (Poortvliet et al. 2015, White et al. 2018)

Due to the recent taxonomic changes, both present day and historical reports can often be unclear and without adequate descriptions, photographs or geographic locations, it can be difficult to conclusively attribute fisheries data to a single species. Care should be taken when using reports or accounts of the Reef Manta Ray. Melanistic (black) and leucistic (white) colour morphs occur in all species of manta ray (Marshall et al. 2009). Variant colour morphs often contribute an added degree of confusion when attempting to visually discriminate between species of manta rays in the field or in photographs, especially when close examination is not possible. It should be noted that these colour morphs could be a source of error, resulting in misidentifications in past or future studies or surveys of distribution.

The previously, monotypic genus Manta was re-evaluated with two species identified, Reef Manta Ray (Manta alfredi) and Oceanic Manta Ray (Manta birostris) (Marshall et al. 2009). Genetic evidence supported the separation (Kashiwagi et al. 2012). Both species have broad global distributions and are sympatric in some locations and allopatric in others (Kashiwagi et al. 2011, Lawson et al. 2017). A third species of manta ray has also been proposed (Marshall et al. 2009) with increasing genetic support (Hinojosa-Alvarez et al. 2016, Kashiwagi et al. 2017, Hosegood et al. 2018). Genetic evidence has also resulted in the genus Manta being subsumed within the genus Mobula (Poortvliet et al. 2015, White et al. 2018).

Due to the recent taxonomic changes, both present day and historical reports can often be unclear and without adequate descriptions, photographs or geographic locations, it can be difficult to conclusively attribute fisheries data to a single species. Care should be taken when using reports or accounts of the Oceanic Manta Ray. Melanistic (black) and leucistic (white) colour morphs occur in all species of manta ray (Marshall et al. 2009). Variant colour morphs often contribute an added degree of confusion when attempting to visually discriminate between species of manta rays in the field or in photographs, especially when close examination is not possible. It should be noted that these colour morphs could be a source of error, resulting in misidentifications in past or future studies or surveys of distribution.

White et al. (2017) concluded that Mobula rochebrunei (East Atlantic Pygmy Devil Ray) is a junior synonym of M. hypostoma (Atlantic Pygmy Devil Ray), with the latter species being confirmed as occurring in both the Western and Eastern Atlantic.

Combined morphological and molecular data led Last et al. (2016) and White et al. (2017) to conclude that M. eregoodootenkee is a junior synonym of M. kuhlii. However, Hosegood et al. (2019) suggested these were separate species, which was supported by Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. (2020), who also clarified the nomenclature as M. eregoodoo.

This species was recently described by Habib and Islam (2021). It is similar to, and sympatric with, Glaucostegus granulatus in Bangladesh, but the description of the new species does not change the taxonomic concept of G. granulatus.

Genetic (Rosel et al. 1995) and morphological (Brownell et al. 1987) data suggest that Vaquitas are most closely related to porpoises in South America. Genetic data suggest divergence from two sister taxa (Burmeister’s Porpoise, Phocoena spinipinnis and Spectacled Porpoise Australophocaena dioptrica) in the Pleistocene (i.e., at least 2.5 million years ago).

The use of Lutra for four New World otter species (L. felina, L. canadensis, L. longicaudis, L. provocax) has been widespread in the past. Van Zyll de Jong (1972, 1987) separated this group into the genus Lontra based on morphological criteria, which was confirmed by Wozencraft (1993). Koepfli and Wayne (1998) and Koepfli et al. (2008) re-confirmed this classification based on molecular data. Thus, nowadays the generic name Lontra should be accepted as valid for all New World otters (except Pteronura).
This species is closely related to Oculina varicosa (Wagner 2006).

Changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a). This species is often confused with Glaucostegus typus and Pacific Ocean records of G. granulatus are probably G. typus. A newly-described species, Glaucostegus younholeei Habib & Islam, 2021, is sympatric with G. granulatus in Bangladesh but the description of the new species does not change the taxonomic concept of G. granulatus.
This species was previously placed in the genera Anthias and Pseudanthias.
Diplodus levantinus replaces D. sargus in Israel (Fricke et al. 2016). There is no genetic information clarifying its relationship to the D. sargus species group.
Charadrius obscurus and C. aquilonius (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. obscurus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Twelve subspecies were recognised by Hung and Law (2016):
  1. Lutra lutra angustifrons in North Africa;
  2. Lutra lutra aurobrunneus in Garhwal Himalayas in northern India and higher altitudes in Nepal;
  3. Lutra lutra barang in southeast Asia (Thailand, Viet Nam, Indonesia and Sumatra);
  4. Lutra lutra chinensis in southern China and Taiwan;
  5. Lutra lutra hainana in Hainan Island, China;
  6. Lutra lutra kutab in northern India (Kashmir);
  7. Lutra lutra lutra is the most widely distributed, spanning from Portugal to South Korea;
  8. Lutra lutra meridionalis in from Georgia through Armenia, Azerbaijan and Iran
  9. Lutra lutra monticolus in northern India (Punjab, Kumaon, Himachal Pradesh, Sikkim and Assam) Nepal, Bhutan and Myanmar;
  10. Lutra lutra nair in southern India and Sri Lanka;
  11. Lutra lutra seistanica in Afghanistan, Eastern Iran, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, and Turkmenistan; and
  12. the Japanese subspecies, Lutra lutra whiteleyi, was considered a distinct species (L. nippon) by Suzuki et al. (1996).

The Chinese Sturgeon Acipenser sinensis is restricted to the main channel of the Yangtze and the Pearl rivers and the East and South China Seas. Though there is still disagreement about the taxonomy of the Pearl and Yangtze River populations, Chinese scholars commonly divide Chinese Sturgeon into two populations; one is the Pearl River Chinese Sturgeon, which spawns in spring, and is close to dying out. The other is the Yangtze River Chinese Sturgeon, which spawns in autumn and still maintains a certain amount below the Gezhouba Dam.
Epinephelus amblycephalus has been split into two species, with E. kupangensis now recognized from the western central Pacific and Andaman Sea (Tucker et al. 2016).

Three regional subspecies originally described by Wilson et al. (1991) have been confirmed by Cronin et al. (1996): Enhydra lutris lutris (Linnaeus, 1758) from Japan in the southwest Pacific throughout the Asian range of the Kuril Islands to the Kamchatka Peninsula and the Commander Islands, E. l. kenyoni from the western Aleutian Islands to Prince William Sound, Alaska, USA, along the Pacific coast of Canada and into Oregon state in the continental USA, and E. l. nereis (Merriam, 1904) from central to southern California, USA.

Gygis alba previously (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) lumped G. alba and G. candida, but latter now split as separate species following Pratt (2020). G. candida differs from G. alba by its shorter and more conical bill, with cobalt-blue over the basal third and the feathering forming a straight receding line, whereas on G. alba it makes concave arcs over the bases of the upper and lower mandibles (Pratt 2020). One common call of candida is a series of short raspy notes while its equivalent in alba consists of longer, lower notes; moreover, alba calls with low-pitched long-sustained notes that appear not to have been recorded in candida. Correct subspecific allocations and limits frequently unclear and disputed; some authors have preferred to recognize several additional subspecies, including royana (of Norfolk I and Kermadec Is), kittlitzi (Caroline Is), pacifica (Melanesia and other islands of S Pacific) and rothschildi (Hawaii), all of which herein synonymised with candida, but all are sometimes referred instead to G. alba. Birds of Seychelles and Mascarenes described as subspecies monte, but not reliably separable from candida. Two subspecies recognised.
Gygis alba previously (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) lumped G. alba and G. candida but latter now split as separate species (which see for details). Monotypic.

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Kuo et al. 2010, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Wisner 1999). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions (i.e., junior homonyms), were renamed as E. bobwisneri and E. luzonicus, respectively (Fernholm et al. 2013).

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Kuo et al. 2010, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Wisner 1999). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) followed Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions (i.e., junior homonyms), were renamed as E. bobwisneri and E. luzonicus, respectively (Fernholm et al. 2013).

The number of gill pouches in the original description of E. nelsoni was reported as four, based on the holotype, a small specimen with only four gill apertures. When latter dissected, it was found to have five gill pouches. Kuo and Mok (1999) redescribed the species based on 309 specimens, of which most of them had five and just nine had four gill apertures and/or pouches.

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Kuo et al. 2010, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Wisner 1999). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) followed Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions (i.e., junior homonyms), were renamed as E. bobwisneri and E. luzonicus, respectively (Fernholm et al. 2013).

Eptatretus chinensis was originally described from five specimens collected east of Hainan Island, at 600 m depth (Kuo and Mok 1994), and later redescribed by Chen et al. (2005) based on 30 additional specimens trapped from the South China Sea, at depths of approximately 500 m.

Chen et al. (2005) stated that this species was described based on five type specimens. However, there are only three type specimens listed in the original description and other two that were used in molecular studies, which have no type status (Kuo and Mok 1994).

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Kuo et al. 2010, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Wisner 1999). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) followed Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions (i.e., junior homonyms), were renamed as E. bobwisneri and E. luzonicus, respectively (Fernholm et al. 2013).

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Kuo et al. 2010, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Wisner 1999). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) followed Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions (i.e., junior homonyms), were renamed as E. bobwisneri and E. luzonicus, respectively (Fernholm et al. 2013).

Some six-gilled Eptatretus species previously misidentified (all or in part) as E. atami have frequently been reported from Taiwanese, Japanese or Korean waters (e.g., Honma 1998; Iwata 1993, 2000; Lindberg and Legeza 1959; Matsubara 1937, 1955; Mori 1952; Nakabo 2002; Sato 1984; Shen and Tao 1975; Strahan 1962, 1975; Strahan and Homna 1960, 1961; Yamada et al. 1986; Youn, 2002). Those from Taiwan were described by Kuo et al. (1994) as E. fernholmi, E. sheni, or E. wisneri. Those from Japan have been recently described by McMillan and Wisner (2004) as E. moki or E. walkeri.

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Kuo et al. 2010, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Wisner 1999). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) followed Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions (i.e., junior homonyms), were renamed as E. bobwisneri and E. luzonicus, respectively (Fernholm et al. 2013).
